translated: In some Member States, it is not simply a matter of informing an opinion that is not as well informed as it could be. That is certainly important, but it is also a matter of combating the disinformation spread by a very active anti-European movement and existing anti-European organizations. The Commission will have to be very vigorous in its responses to certain comments that will reach it as part of this campaign. Mr. Corbett, thank you for your appreciation. I gladly accept your invitation and, if I understand correctly, you would like me, when I come to Yorkshire, to discuss not only the reform of the European institutions, but also the structural funds. I will therefore come to perform this dual task. I forgot, moreover, to mention my concern to go, and I have already done so, before the national parliaments, not only by meeting their representatives here, but by going to see them in person. Ten days ago, I was in Westminster. You see, Mr. Corbett, that I am not afraid of difficulties. I am going to the Bundestag in Berlin next week. I have appeared before the French Senate. So, throughout this debate, whenever I can, I will also go directly to the national parliaments. Dialogue with citizens is not about propaganda or marketing, not even communication. I would like this dialogue to be truly a dialogue, and after a short film objectively explaining the issues of institutional reform, those here in the gallery can intervene and respond with an open microphone. We are going, I repeat, to conduct this dialogue initiative in ad hoc or structured cooperation with the Member States, and I very much hope, with your support, that the governments of the Fifteen will be able to join in this dialogue initiative, according to the terms they deem most appropriate and most suitable. Mr President, I would like to join the study circle set up by Mr Barnier, which includes 700 trainees, so that he has people to talk to. It is hardly pleasant to have to discuss issues of transparency or issues relating to the Intergovernmental Conference individually. Regarding the Intergovernmental Conference, Mr Barnier stated during his presentation to the House that social policy would not be decided by majority vote, but I note from page 63 that the fight against discrimination, freedom of movement and the right of residence – that is, the directives on the right of residence – all of social security, the renewal of Regulation No 1408, and social policy measures will be voted on – with a few exceptions – by qualified majority vote. Does Mr Barnier care that he is attacking the very heart of the legislative process in the Member States? It is to defend these issues that people go to the polls to determine a new majority in the Danish parliament, or in any other parliament. Can these issues be managed by Brussels? Are we here in the process of decentralization that Mr. Prodi spoke to us about this morning?

Here are two simple examples of the real problems behind the slow pace of the European justice system; delays in this field can cause serious personal hardship and sometimes even tragedy. I am not saying that our national legal systems are perfect, but all too often they have to wait for a preliminary ruling from the European Court. Statistics show a worrying trend towards longer waiting times for preliminary acts: I am not blaming the Court or its staff for anything, but rather criticising the structure of the Court itself and the lack of resources at its disposal in a rapidly expanding European Union. The proposals in this report are certainly acceptable as a temporary palliative, but Europe is a legal construct, for the proper functioning of which the courts are an essential element. In view of the forthcoming enlargement, the IGC must implement a radical reform and restructuring of the judicial system; otherwise we, as elected representatives, will have to deal with the growing dissatisfaction of our citizens who cannot obtain justice quickly and effectively. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the rapporteur for this excellent report. I also fully agree with his conclusions, especially where he proposes to increase the number of référendaires of judges at the Court of First Instance and to give it its own translation service. I believe that this is indeed necessary because we heard - when we were visiting the Legal Affairs Committee in Luxembourg - that, naturally and by virtue of decisions taken so to speak from above, when it comes to using a common translation service, the Court of Justice enjoys a certain priority over the Court of First Instance which consequently often fails to deal with important issues. However, I am also of the opinion that reforms must go beyond what we are about to decide here at this moment. For example, it is worth starting to reflect on those areas in which there already exist judicial bodies that operate in a similar way to the courts and on a preliminary basis: it is enough to remember Alicante, or what is provided for in the law on the European civil service. The Court of First Instance, after having assigned the necessary competences, could therefore become the last instance. In my opinion, we should also take action on the Commission's attitude towards renationalising, i.e. bringing decisions on competition matters back to the national level. I think we need to think about this, since these cases will no longer reach the Court of First Instance but will have to be examined, when documents are produced, directly by the Court of Justice. We need to think about how to resolve this situation. If necessary, provision should be made for the competent section of the Court of First Instance to examine the production of documents on competition matters. We should also think about whether it is right or not - we have even had cases of Members of Parliament or parliamentary groups who have brought actions against the European Parliament - for the Court of First Instance to have jurisdiction over these matters, although in reality these are constitutional issues which, strictly speaking, should be the responsibility of the Court of Justice rather than the Court of First Instance.

If this is the role the Commission intends to play over the next five years, we, convinced federalists, are certain that this is not the right path, and in this regard, we will ask for explanations and judge what the Commission intends to do. Reform is important, but if it leads to a weakening, reduction, and diminution of the Commission's supranational powers, the consolidation of European integration, which the Founding Fathers intended for the European Commission, is at stake. Mr. President, regarding the other points, for example, that of economic and social policy: it is true that the European social model is undergoing a profound crisis. It is true that the problem of unemployment is no coincidence the number one problem that none of our policies have managed to resolve. But it is not true that it can be resolved by formulating a list of the problems we addressed in the past, without having a clear vision, a proposal, a proposal by virtue of which, in our Europe, there are economies that are advancing at one of the most sustained paces, and it is no coincidence that these are the economies that have managed to make flexibility in the labor market and businesses their number one objective. If we continue to get bogged down in proposals that have yielded poor results to date, I do not know what we will do or what the Commission will be able to do. The same applies to enlargement itself, without it being linked to a much more effective reform of the European Union and its structures, as well as to proposals that the Commission could have formulated even within the framework of the Intergovernmental Conference. Mr. President, I would like to say something positive, perhaps contrary to the opinion of some Members, about the telegram you sent to the Austrian Government. Your position has convinced us: you were right not to further isolate that country. Nevertheless, we will see what the concrete gestures will be in practice. I repeat, Mr. President, in our opinion, this is a somewhat short-sighted vision. Above all, there is a lack of impetus in the areas I have mentioned, for example, regarding the Balkans. Is it possible to continue leaving the Balkans out of enlargement, without considering that Croatia, Macedonia, and other countries also have a right to be part of this common House? Madam President, Mr. Prodi, I would like to commend your proposal for a radical decentralization of the Union's activities and ask you why you are then presenting a legislative catalogue that centralizes. I remind you of your predecessor's speech five years ago. Like you, he promised "less and more," and Mr. Santer ended up delivering "much more and much worse," and I don't think you can deliver what you promise either. You talk about decentralization and centralize. The legislative catalog is a long list of areas where citizens lose influence and where you, Mr. Prodi, take it away from them, even in social matters.

The fourth point, which Mrs. Hedkvist Petersen just emphasized, is the promotion of a policy of equal opportunities for women and young people. The fifth point is the importance and role of small and medium-sized enterprises, as Mr. Vatanen said very vehemently just now. Finally, the positive effects on national administrations of the Structural Fund management system, the motivation of officials when they manage these Funds, even if it is sometimes complicated, and the importance of making further improvements to the Commission's evaluation, monitoring, and control procedures. I would like to inform the European Parliament in this regard of my intention to organize a seminar in mid-2000 with national and regional authorities on this issue of evaluating procedures for exchanging good practices in the management of the Structural Funds. I would like to raise a few specific points. Mr. Berend, you expressed the wish that zoning be implemented quickly. We are putting an end to zoning. Tomorrow, four new countries will be the subject of a Commission decision, and very soon, I hope, it will be Italy's turn. So, you will be satisfied on this point, since all the countries covered by Objective 2 will be zoned. Regarding the underground economy that you mention in your report, I am well aware that the analysis and production of statistics on this subject rely on the reliability of the data, and as Mr. Cocilovo mentioned, there is a problem with the reliability of these data. To a certain extent, they are taken into account in statistics on GDP and labor force surveys, and in any case, I would like to emphasize the efforts that Eurostat is making and will continue to make to improve the quality of statistics. You also mentioned, Mr. Berend, like Mr. Aparicio Sánchez, the lack of reform in the fisheries sector. On this point, which is of personal interest to me, I would point out that the small size of this sector - which does not mean that it is negligible - and its concentration in a very small number of regions do not make it easy to analyse it within a regional framework. This type of sectoral analysis is more a matter of practice and the competence of the Directorate-General for Fisheries, under the authority of my colleague Mr Fischler. However, I would like to assure you that the Commission will endeavour to include such an analysis in the second cohesion report, which will undoubtedly be more suited to these concerns. Several of you have mentioned points that should be included in this second cohesion report, and your rapporteur has touched on some of these points. I would first like to assure you that the merger of the periodic reports and the cohesion report should not lead to any loss of information or loss of interest in the content of this cohesion report which, for me, Mr Rapporteur, is an extremely important instrument, not only to account for what is being done and to say so in a transparent and rigorous manner, to examine or evaluate future directions, but also to create a public debate with citizens and, beyond that, with the elected representatives that you are, on this regional policy and on what a European regional planning policy could one day be.

What criteria will the Commission use to accept or reject these Member States' programs? Which Community body will monitor the financing of the Steering Group and the Monitoring Committee, as well as the correct and proper implementation of the program? Given that the European Social Fund's contribution for the period 2000-2006 amounts to EUR 2.487 billion, and the EQUAL initiative is co-financed by the Member States, will the Commission state how much Greece's contribution will be? The EQUAL initiative is not limited to specific groups of people. It aims to combat discrimination in the labor market. The initiative was adopted in Berlin, and there it was also determined that the relevant measures must also take into account and include professional groups of asylum seekers. I would like to emphasize this important element of the initiative. The Member States' programs drawn up within the framework of the Community initiative must comply with the provisions of the Social Fund Regulation. The EQUAL initiative is therefore subject to the Social Fund Regulation. It has been submitted to Parliament, and we expect its opinion next month. I must stress that EQUAL responds to national needs and plans, which are defined in accordance with the agreed European strategy. The Member States or national governments are primarily responsible for setting up the joint implementing bodies, submitting proposals, selecting those who will implement the programmes, and monitoring them. Within the European Commission, the Directorate-General for Employment is responsible for implementation, and budgetary control is naturally also carried out by the Directorate-General for Financial Control, the Anti-Fraud Office, and the European Court of Auditors. A final part of the question concerned the amount of the contribution made available. Greece has been awarded ECU 98 million. The grant amounts to 80%; in the case of island regions, particularly the remote Greek islands, the initiative contributes up to 85%, with the own contribution being 15%. Mr President, in my view, the guidelines for the EQUAL Community Initiative, and in particular the four actions they lay down, result in a very complicated, bureaucratic and, paradoxically, also non-transparent structure. For example, one wonders how a development partnership is supposed to prove that it meets the conditions of cooperation and representativeness, as required in paragraph 33 of the instructions for Action 2. On the other hand, the obligation to transnational cooperation and the complex requirements for planning and implementing development partnerships inevitably lead to large-scale projects, since only they can meet these conditions. This, however, contradicts the declared intention of focusing the general objectives on decentralised action plans, at the level of local authorities and in agricultural regions. At the same time, the participation of the truly disadvantaged, namely asylum seekers, immigrants and others, is made impossible or reduced to a symbolic level. Finally, given the small total—€2.8 billion for 15 Member States and such ambitious targets—I fear all we'll be able to do is demonstrate the evil that unemployment is. Since we're now at the drafting stage in Parliament, I would like to say, first, that it would be truly helpful in every way if you could put forward concrete proposals that we can consider.

I appreciate Parliament's flexibility on such a sensitive and complex issue as water service charges. I fully support the call for water prices to be set so as to provide incentives for users to use water resources sustainably. I also support the idea that each economic sector should contribute appropriately to covering the costs of water services and can therefore accept Amendments 43-46 and Amendment 85 in part and in principle. I believe we need legally binding rules requiring each economic sector to cover the costs of water services. This provides a clear economic objective against which progress can be measured. I therefore support the overarching objective of Amendment 105, which reflects the Commission's original proposal. I also support a gradual move towards covering environmental and resource costs. We are aware that the pricing of water and water services is an extremely complex issue and that it must take into account not only environmental but also social and economic objectives. However, this must not be used as an excuse for subsidising polluting and inefficient economic sectors. A Commission communication is planned for the near future that will address precisely this issue. I agree with Parliament that the 16-year period for implementation of the directive specified in the common position must be significantly shortened. The same applies to the possibility of an extension of a further 18 years. Amendment 28, which deletes the third extension, represents a step in the right direction and can therefore be adopted. On the other hand, a period of 10 years, as proposed in Amendments 24 and 26, among others, is too short. In my opinion, consideration should be given to including an explicit and mandatory provision to prevent deterioration in the overarching definition of the draft's requirements. The draft must also include stricter criteria for extending deadlines for heavily modified or artificial water bodies, as well as for setting less stringent environmental objectives. This concerns Amendments 6, 24, 25, 27, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 78, 80, 102, and 104. These can be accepted in substance and are supported to achieve a comprehensive solution. However, the requirement in Amendments 27 and 29 that the Commission must agree to any extension goes too far and therefore cannot be accepted. Another important area is the protection of groundwater. To break the current upward pollution trend, we need both a starting point and an end goal. Stricter criteria for interpreting monitoring results are equally essential. The most important sections of Parliament's Amendments 25 and 73 can therefore be accepted in principle. However, the new definition in Amendment 72 is too strict and cannot be used for these purposes. I propose incorporating Amendment 92 into a broader solution. Amendment 71 does not take into account seasonal variations or annual changes in the groundwater level.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament has played a pioneering role in affirming human rights within the European Union. We know that governments are often more sensitive to the interests of realpolitik, to commercial, geostrategic, or economic interests. We have defined conditions for states that wish to join our Union, and we must also define conditions for the states whose candidacy we support. Because we are among those who believe in democracy and its values. We know that freedom of the press and public information are the lungs of democracy. The air of freedom of the press must breathe through a democratic state. And democracy must also go hand in hand with free and informed public opinion. And there is no free and informed public opinion without unsupervised social communication, and there is no free and unsupervised social communication if journalists are prosecuted, arrested, or threatened. Mr. President, just as we rightly condemned UNITA's actions, which have undermined the peace process in Angola, and firmly called on both parties to end the war and make peace, we now condemn the persecution and threats and call on the Angolan government to allow journalists to work freely, as this is the prerogative of a democratic state and society. Mr. President, how much longer can we continue to cooperate with Angola? Human rights are systematically and persistently violated there, not only by UNITA but also by the government itself. The trials against journalists violate all legal principles. The Angolan government must immediately authorize a significant UN presence to act as an intermediary and inform us about human rights. Similarly, European observers must be allowed to attend the hearings of the journalists' trials. Europe, despite being a major donor, has so far remained too passive towards Angola. If the Angolan government continues to refuse to cooperate, we will have to take measures. Without national reconciliation, no reconciliation with Europe is possible. Angola will then remain, alas, a diamond in the rough. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I completely agree with the resolution being discussed in Parliament; I agree because the situation of repression affecting journalists, whether Angolans or foreign correspondents in Angola, is so serious and scandalous that we cannot turn a blind eye. But this resolution is insufficient, because in reality, it assumes that Angola is a state governed by the rule of law, which imposes certain difficulties on journalists and represses them. But that is not the point. Angola is not a state governed by the rule of law; it is a repressive dictatorship. Angola is at war, a cruel and protracted war. And we cannot accept the prevailing theory that the enemy must be crushed and physically eliminated in order to achieve peace. Therefore, the repeated appeals of the Angolan Church, the appeals made yesterday, for example, by Mandela and Mebeki for new peace negotiations to begin, must be supported by Parliament. We must therefore undertake, as another colleague has already said, a general debate on Angola, and not just on the situation of certain journalists who are victims of repression in Angola.

The financial resources with which the Council has allocated this cultural program contrast sharply with the importance that cultural and education policy and the program have for the objectives pursued by the European Union. Cultural activity creates an identity. Cultural activity is the expression of individuality, it is the expression of one's personality, it builds relationships and establishes communication. We want a diverse Europe. We want a Europe founded on the principle of diversity in unity. We want people to understand and learn to value differences. For this reason, we have spoken out in favor of the distribution of the budget and the allocation of resources to different types of measures. For this reason, we have rejected the heavy concentration of resources in large networks and network structures. We want to encourage small and medium-sized units, individual activity, because we want to make thousands of flowers bloom. I echo the words of the previous speakers. We are faced with a genuine contradiction—the principle of unanimity, the codecision procedure, and the Conciliation Committee—if what we want is to strengthen the principles of cultural policy in favor of a European conscience instead of further weakening them. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as you have heard, we all have, regardless of the political group to which we belong, a common political enemy: the Council. Decisions of the Committee on Culture almost systematically end up in the conciliation procedure, since there is always some Member State that takes culture hostage in exchange for other interests. In other words, the principle of unanimity appears to be a first-rate blocking instrument. The struggle for an acceptable compromise lasted almost two years, until the European Parliament was finally able to give the green light. Not even the expiration of the previous programs, Kaleidoscope, Ariadne, and Raphael, could soften the Council's position. The need to create a pilot transition program prevailed. All of this has once again highlighted the weaknesses of the European Union's cultural policy activities. The political battle over funding and program design is completely disproportionate to the funds allocated. Of the 410 applications submitted in 1999, only 55 projects were retained, for a total of just €6.07 million. In the context of this program, the Council was unwilling to give Parliament a single euro! The result is that until 2004, we were left with a modest €167 million. This is equivalent to the expenses incurred by a single medium-sized German opera house over the same period. In Europe, however, this amount is reserved for 29 countries and a period of five years. This is a huge disproportion! Despite our anger, we must be content with the progress made in the area of content. This is something we have made clear and is worthy of gratitude. We hope that one day the Council will be convinced and change its attitude.

This would jeopardize a greater number of jobs, as well as the credibility of this House by showing how far removed we are from the real world. I therefore urge this House to reject the entire report and not to make any amendments to the Commission's original proposal, which was excellently balanced. Mr. President, we cannot vote in favor of this report. Indeed, the European Union should place social issues at the heart of its construction. It is social rights that should govern economic choices, not the other way around. This is why we are opposed to the establishment, regarding social protection, of mechanisms copied from the Luxembourg process that run counter to this logic: broad economic guidelines, then convergence criteria, and finally, social issues, which are treated as a residual issue. The European Union should affirm a general principle: social rights acquired in the States cannot be reduced. Any Community intervention should aim to supplement, and then harmonize upwards, existing guarantees. To strengthen the financing of social protection systems, we need a policy of general wage increases and the introduction of a statutory minimum wage in each Member State. To combat poverty, the right to an income and the right to employment are inseparable. Finally, to prevent any commodification of health care, the European Union should take a clear stand against pension funds and oppose private insurance companies having access to the health system. In conclusion, I truly believe that social Europe cannot be satisfied with just speeches and pious wishes. The situation is too tragic for millions of people. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the objective of developing a concerted strategy to modernize social protection within the European Union is certainly a good thing, as was the launch, with the Luxembourg Summit, of the European convergence strategy for employment and employment policies. The labor market and social protection are in fact two sides of the same coin, requiring the synchronization of policies and regulations. If the labor market is efficient in terms of employment levels, flexibility, and wage efficiency, the welfare state and social protection cannot fail to be so, and vice versa. Previously, European countries each defined, in near-autarky, the rules for the operation and financing of the two markets. Fiscal and exchange rate policies were in place to ensure internal and external balance. With Maastricht and the single currency, fiscal policies have been severely limited, and it is no longer possible to resort to devaluation or seek lost margins of competition. Structural and cyclical gaps between countries can therefore no longer be made up for through deficits and exchange rates. As things stand, in the absence of full job mobility within the Union and a redistributive tax policy at the confederal level, the only degree of flexibility left is in the labour and social protection markets to rectify both structural and cyclical imbalances, the so-called asymmetric exogenous shocks.

In recent months, since I last appeared before the European Parliament, important events have taken place, including within the European Union. Allow me to recall two of them, one of which is very welcome to all MEPs and in particular to the Presidency: the inauguration of the Intergovernmental Conference, and the opening of negotiations with the future members of the European Union. We must certainly recall the events in Kosovo and in the Balkans in general, which have touched our feelings and our intelligence; important issues in the Middle East, where the President of the Parliament played a significant role in her last trip; some important events to unblock the summit between Europe and Africa, in which I had the honour of participating, in cooperation with the Portuguese Presidency; the large meeting that took place in Portugal, in Vilamoura, with the eighteen countries of Latin America, to try to build deeper relations also between the European Union and the countries of Latin America. Without a doubt, Chechnya has also been close to our hearts, and I will end my speech by saying a few words about this, in the light of an important conversation I had this morning with the representative of the Council of Europe, Mr Álvaro Gil-Robles, about his recent visit to that region. However, I believe that the Members of this Parliament have requested my presence to speak more directly about foreign policy and especially security policy in Europe after Helsinki. I will dwell briefly on this subject; I will then be happy to answer any questions that the honourable Members may wish to put to me. Let me remind you that the Helsinki Summit under the Finnish Presidency took place just two months ago, and not a century ago. Fundamental decisions for foreign and security policy on our continent were taken in Helsinki. There are mainly three types of decisions, and it is to these that I will refer. The first was the decision to set up, within the European Union, three types of committees for the adoption of decisions on crisis management: firstly, a Political and Security Committee; secondly, a Military Committee, representing the Chiefs of Staff of the fifteen countries of the Union; and thirdly, decisions on the relations which the European Union should maintain with third countries and with other organisations. I am referring essentially to the relations between the European Union and the Atlantic Alliance and to the relations between the European Union and those countries which, although geographically European, are not part of the European Union, or at least not for the moment. I will confine myself mainly to these three points, in order to update Members on what has happened. Firstly, and with regard to the decision-making bodies, this very morning, 1 March 2000, the Political and Security Committee (PSC), established at the last General Affairs Council, met for the first time. Thus, two months after the declaration and decision taken in Helsinki, a PSC meeting is taking place for the first time within the European Union. This morning I had the opportunity to attend, and to see the representatives at lunchtime.

These are the reasons why the guidelines are presented according to thematic priorities, because they must be taken into account, under each of the objectives, to varying degrees according to the specific situations of each of the Member States and regions. I would now like to respond quickly to some of the comments you have made, ladies and gentlemen, firstly on the procedure. It is true that the consultation of your House came late. Allow me to remind you that when the guidelines were adopted by the Commission, in draft form, in February 1999, following a new procedure designed to facilitate the submission of comments on this text, they were immediately submitted by my predecessor, Monica Wulf-Mathies, to Parliament. However, given the proximity of the European elections, it was only after the final adoption of the text in July 1999 that your House was able to begin examining these guidelines. Arriving in this college, among you, I want, ladies and gentlemen, to assure you that, in the negotiations on the programmes, which are only just beginning - Mr President Hatzidakis asked me about this - for most Member States, your observations will really be taken into consideration. And I can also assure you that, when the Commission adopts the guidelines for what is called the mid-term review, as provided for in the Regulation, the point of view of your Assembly, the one expressed in this report, will also be taken into account. Now, on the substance of the role of the guidelines, Madam Rapporteur, you have stressed that it is indeed within this framework that the aim is to provide guidelines on a certain number of European objectives, often very specific. I will not list them all: the implementation of intersectoral policies, increasing the efficiency of the use of public funds, helping the various partners to build regional or national programmes together, etc. The Commission takes due note of this, but several of these guidelines or questions fall more within the scope of other documents, such as the Vade-mecum or the methodological working document. I would like, in conclusion, to focus on certain concerns that you have raised, Madam Rapporteur. I am thinking, for example, of the idea that the guidelines are not sufficiently specific in their recommendations. This statement in your report must be put into the context of the negotiations last spring. The Commission has adhered to the very wording of Article 10 of the General Regulation on the Structural Funds, which provides that these guidelines are intended to provide Member States with general indicative guidelines, based on relevant and agreed Community policies. This is the very text that I quoted, in quotation marks. Furthermore, the guidelines cannot replace programming, nor ex ante evaluations, which must be the tool used to specify the priorities and effectiveness of these programmes. You then mentioned, Madam Rapporteur, the section on guidelines relating to urban and rural development, stressing that urban development is not sufficiently taken into account.

We will certainly raise the point raised by the honourable Member. We have heard the concerns expressed in this regard, and I will ensure that they are taken into account. Considerable concerns have also been expressed about the potential danger to the archaeological heritage of the area. We will also raise this latter point in our observations. A number of other hydroelectric projects planned by Turkey over the last 30 years have also been the subject of concerns, such as the effect they had on displaced farmers. On the whole, these appear to have been dealt with relatively satisfactorily, and I hope that this will prove to be the case with this project, in which the Commission—just to be clear—has no involvement. Question No. 39 of (H-0036/00): Subject: Drafting of the Charter of Fundamental Rights While welcoming, on behalf of all citizens, the drafting of a Charter of Fundamental Rights, and expressing the hope that it will be able to meet the challenges of 21st-century Europe, I would nevertheless like to ask the Commission the following questions: What are its positions on the content of the Charter? Which citizens is this Charter intended for (those of the European Union or, in the perspective of enlargement, of all European countries, including migrants, etc.)? Will the Charter incorporate the social achievements of the European Union, or will it have a broader programmatic character? What mechanisms will be implemented to clearly translate equality between the two sexes into practice? What is the Commission's view of incorporating the Charter into the Treaty on European Union? Like the honourable Member, the Commission welcomes the decision taken by the Heads of State and Government to launch the process of drafting a Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The Heads of State and Government themselves laid down, in the conclusions of the Cologne European Council, the broad outlines of the content of the Charter. According to these conclusions, the Charter must contain three categories of rights: the rights of liberty, equality and procedure, as guaranteed by the European Convention on Human Rights; the rights reserved to citizens of the Union; and economic and social rights, as set out in the European Social Charter and the Community Charter of the Fundamental Social Rights of Workers, insofar as they do not merely justify objectives for Union action. The Commission considers that the Convention responsible for drafting the Charter of Fundamental Rights must respect the mandate given to it by the Cologne European Council. However, this does not mean that the Convention should be limited to a codifying role of simply compiling existing rights from different sources. As I have already had the opportunity to say to this Parliament, the Commission is convinced that the Convention must be able, where appropriate, to adapt and develop these rights, taking into account current circumstances, in particular technological and social developments.

This is absolutely essential. We must also remember that no one voluntarily gives up power, whether man or woman. Men have never wanted to give up their position of power, when they enjoyed it, but very few women have been willing to give up their position of power, and I am thinking here in particular of their position of power with regard to children. I would also like to say in this regard that this is perhaps one of the reasons why there are so few men here today. We would, of course, like to be able to have this debate more or less among ourselves for the same reasons of power politics. What I wanted to emphasize here is that this is a ceding of power on the part of both parties. The Commissioner emphasized that it was necessary to use a combination of many different measures, and she mentioned Finland and Sweden by name. I will just say for the record that she could very well have mentioned Denmark as well. I say this, of course, because I come from Denmark. The Danish government is actually 45% women, which is actually slightly higher than Finland's. We do not have a female president, but we do have a queen, which can in a certain sense be considered equivalent. I would now like to address some of the points mentioned by the Commissioner, namely the question of financial resources. It is absolutely necessary for us to accept the fact that, if women want to achieve equality in the short term, it will cost money. It is also necessary, in the short term, to seek to ensure that our children are cared for and educated responsibly. This raises the question of adequate structures. One may wonder whether traditional industrial culture is truly good, and I am therefore very pleased with the very active participation of the Portuguese minister in the Lisbon conference devoted, among other things, to the development of information technologies. I believe that there are opportunities there, particularly for women, precisely because it is not a question of hierarchy, but rather of horizontal structures. Developments suggest, at least in Denmark, that there are more and more women entrepreneurs. There are two points that have not been mentioned that I would like to mention in conclusion. The first concerns the influence of the media. I think it is very important that we study the stereotypes created by the media. Does this pose a particular problem? I must say that I do not know precisely. I have the impression that it does, but I am not certain. The second concerns enlargement. I think it is very important in this regard to emphasize now that certain requirements must also be set so that the new Member States are represented by both men and women, which will also support women in those countries. I would also like to thank the Minister and the Commissioner for their statements, and I agree with the Commissioner when she says that it is time for fine words to be translated into action.

I take this opportunity to ask if the Commission can clarify the reasons for the delay in the Commission's report on the outermost regions, which has been awaited in Parliament for quite some time. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, also for the kind reception she gave to some of our suggestions in her report. Mr. President, distinguished ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the guidelines are intended to offer Member States guidance for achieving reform objectives within the framework of programming. However, the objectives formulated by the Commission in this regard, contrary to their purpose of providing guidance, represent more of a catalogue of possible measures within the policy areas. However, their true purpose is to indicate direction and establish priorities. I agree with the rapporteur that, unfortunately, the Commission document contains too few recommendations to Member States on administrative simplification, and I support some demands, such as focusing attention during negotiations on fostering a favorable environment for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are such job creators; clearly establishing targets for alternative sources of financing, including regulations on venture capital and private financing; and creating start-up aid for companies, including new technologies, as well as investments in the field of innovation. I particularly support my group's amendment to paragraph 10, which aims to ensure adequate inclusion of the private sector in the planning and implementation of projects. I would very much appreciate, Ms. Schroedter, if you would include this amendment in your positive arguments, specifically also under the aspect of subsidiarity. Mr. President, Commissioner, in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we unanimously maintained the view that it was a strategic and priority issue to support interventions from the Structural and Cohesion Funds that worked to improve employment opportunities for the unemployed and equality between men and women. Regrettably, the excellent Schroedter report failed to take this criterion into consideration, despite the abundant evidence—as we will see later in the Berend report—of how these Funds are indeed splendidly helping the most backward regions to close the gap between them and the most developed regions of Europe. They are growing, but at GDP levels. They are growing in competitiveness, but the increase in wealth is not reaching everyone because employment is not rising, and the gap in employment opportunities persists between different regions. Commissioner, read the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and make it a priority, because this is the greatest problem facing citizens. And in the review, in the allocation of reserves, please take into account, strategically, employment needs because that, ultimately, is what the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Funds require. Mr. President, the guidelines must be able to properly orient and strengthen the effectiveness of the programs for the critical seven-year period 2000-2006, so that sustainable development and job creation, especially for women and youth, finally become a reality, and that a balance between social and economic policies and environmental policy is ensured.

I will therefore repeat - in the wake of the rapporteur's excellent speech - that LIFE is the only financial instrument for the definition and implementation of a European environmental policy. It is an essential instrument, since it allows innovative actions to be undertaken in favour of nature and the environment in Europe, which are then taken up and developed by the Member States. This financial instrument is also deliberately democratic in inspiration, being accessible to both government organisations and NGOs. It is for this reason, ladies and gentlemen, that I ask you not to vote for the amendments that have not understood the spirit of LIFE. In fact, LIFE, through associations, can be used directly by European citizens for the benefit of actions of general interest. Several million - and did I say millions - of NGO members recognise in LIFE the Union's desire to build an ambitious policy for the benefit of the natural heritage. LIFE is also the key instrument of the Natura 2000 network in Europe, which allows us to protect the sites of high biological value in our countries and within which the Member States, in accordance with Community directives, have committed themselves to protecting the natural habitats of rare and threatened animal and plant species, as well as migratory birds. Those who oppose this policy in individual Member States are guilty, in my opinion, of holding back nature protection policies in Europe, which is a shame, since everyone in this House knows that LIFE does not have sufficient financial resources to implement the projects submitted by the Member States, many of which are rejected precisely because of a lack of funds. Let us not forget that LIFE currently represents only 100 million euros per year, equivalent to only one thousandth of the European budget. For information, I would like to remind you that agriculture, which has a real impact on the environment, is allocated - we all know this - 37 billion euros. In this context, my group believes it is vital to increase the funds allocated to LIFE and fully supports Mrs Lienemann's proposal to increase the amount earmarked for LIFE to EUR 850 million, since we are all well aware - and I cannot help repeating this - of the extent of our fellow citizens' expectations with regard to the environment and nature and how hesitant and unacceptable this compromise by the Council on the LIFE budget is, especially since the LIFE programmes have seen the implementation of a great many projects, demonstrating their ability to introduce new practices in the environmental field. The first sustainable development projects are, without doubt, precisely those promoted by LIFE. ? (FR) Mr President, the European Union's environmental programme, which can count on considerable funds (EUR 613 million), raises many questions about the correct use of public funds. A financial instrument of this magnitude must be transparent and effective, unlike what happens in the case at hand for the following reasons: poorly defined selection criteria, ambiguous operations that are not the result of consultation, failure to publish reports, absence of an evaluation policy.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have an important decision to make today. Does the European Parliament support the ecological principle of producer responsibility, according to which manufacturers are responsible for end-of-life vehicles? In Amendment 38, the Christian Democrats answer this question in the negative: car manufacturers and drivers should share the costs exactly. As the Directive on Packaging and Packaging Waste, which includes such cost-sharing, shows, this compromise is not working. Packaging still generates significant quantities of waste in the European Union, which also represents an environmental burden. Some Socialists, led by Bernd Lange, consider this principle to be correct, but according to Amendment 45, it should not be introduced until 2010 or 2012. The Common Position mentions 2006, which, in the opinion of the Green Group, gives the automotive industry more than enough time to prepare. I therefore call on my colleagues not to support Amendment 38 tabled by the Christian Democrats and Amendment 45 tabled by some Socialists. If car manufacturers have to bear the costs of recycling their vehicles themselves, they will design them with a view to making them easier and cheaper to reuse. The problem of using plastics in cars will be solved in the future, as PVC will be replaced by bioplastics made from plants, which will ultimately also be cheaper for consumers. For 20 years, the majority of this Parliament has strived to implement European environmental policy even more decisively. Under pressure from the German and French automotive industries in particular, this focus on strictly ecological objectives is now in danger of being lost. I therefore ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote against Amendments 38 and 45. In the Green Group, we broadly support the common position. Mr President, Waste from end-of-life vehicles represents one of our truly major environmental problems, both in terms of the amount of waste and the emission of polluting substances. We in the GUE/NGL Group therefore demand the most comprehensive and consistent regulations in this area. With this directive, we can take a major step forward. However, this presupposes that the Council's position is not dismantled and watered down during Parliament's reading. Some of the amendments tabled would, however, have this effect if adopted. This applies primarily to the amendments proposed by the PPE Group, but unfortunately, in my view, also to some of Mr. Lange's amendments. It doesn't take much imagination to imagine that the automobile industry in certain countries, such as Germany, engaged in intense lobbying before the adoption of this directive. For us, the inclusion of the following principles is crucial: the polluter is liable for the cost. Accordingly, the manufacturer must assume full responsibility, including financial responsibility, for the recycling of the vehicle. There must also be regulations for vehicles in use. We cannot accept any weakening of the Council's position on the entry into force date. The requirements for recycling after a certain number of years, as well as the corresponding percentages, must not be watered down. Furthermore, the use of hazardous substances such as lead must be restricted. We will vote against all amendments that go in the opposite direction in this regard.

That is why, dear colleagues, I ask you to support the amendments tabled by Bernd Lange, which will be supported by the Group of the Party of European Socialists because, in fact, they reconcile all the interests involved - economic interests and environmental constraints - while leaving the Member States free to decide how to implement these constraints, since these amendments provide that the systems in place in the Member States, and there are some that work perfectly well, will be able to continue to operate. Mr President, Madam Commissioner, the proposal for a directive on end-of-life vehicles before us today aims, on the one hand, to guarantee a high level of environmental protection in the Union, but also to preserve the proper functioning of the internal market in this sector. A word to say that, of course, historic and vintage vehicles must be excluded from the scope of this directive. Cars, I think we will all agree on this, are also part of our cultural heritage. That said, one of the stumbling blocks concerns Article 12, that is, the date of application of the directive. The solution proposed by Parliament, namely 18 months after the date of entry into force of this directive, for vehicles put on the market for the first time, is unrealistic. The European vehicle fleet includes several tens of millions of cars that will have to be taken back without having been designed for recycling. The common position was more practicable since it provided for 2006 for vehicles already in circulation. This would also allow companies time to set aside funds to meet these additional expenses. In this regard, I will therefore support, like my group, the common position which represents a balanced compromise, it seems to me, between the constraints on companies and the essential progress in environmental protection. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament is faced with an important decision today. Are we committed to forward-looking environmental and consumer protection, or is Parliament willing to accept becoming the servant of the German car industry, as the Florenz, Lange, and other amendments suggest? The credibility of Parliament, one of the pioneers of environmental protection, is at stake. It would be beyond scandalous if the EP were to reverse what the governments of the 14 Member States and the European Commission have proposed regarding producer responsibility and environmental protection. The intention behind the Florenz and Lange amendments is clear: this directive must be annihilated. The proposal for shared responsibility would gut the principle of responsibility and undermine all innovation. By erecting numerous obstacles, they want nothing more than to hinder an ecologically effective material flow management policy; through approvals, they want to delay the implementation of the directives by twelve years or more. This is completely unacceptable. I therefore make a special appeal to German parliamentarians: do not allow a political disaster to unfold today. The red-green government coalition did not cover itself in glory during the debate on the End-of-Life Vehicles Directive.

However, on behalf of my group, let me make one thing clear: social convergence strategies must not be an alternative to social legislation, but can only represent a very useful complement to what we are developing and what we expect from the Commission in terms of social legislation. The European Parliament should also try to persuade the Council to flesh out the common strategy in Lisbon and to launch an annual procedure to combat poverty as early as the beginning of 2001. I am pleased that the European Parliament is sympathetic to my group's idea, and I hope, Commissioner, that we can also count on your support. Finally, we are urging the European Parliament, the social partners, and social NGOs to be involved in this process without fail. This strategy is only likely to succeed if it has a broad, democratic basis, and we therefore hope for your support. Mr President, in November of last year, the governments of the EU member states adopted four main objectives, which have already been mentioned today: ensuring that work and a stable income are worthwhile, that pensions are secure and sustainable, that social inclusion is promoted, and that a sustainable, high-quality health care system is provided. These are four objectives formulated so comprehensively that everyone can support them. And it can only be of benefit to us if we appoint a group of senior officials to exchange experience on coordinating and evaluating developments within social and labor market policy. The Commission communication we are debating today formed the basis of the Council decision of November and presents in a balanced way how the debates can be made more informed, how we can gain more knowledge about the challenges that the Member States will face in the coming years in the area of social policy—think, for example, of the increasing ageing population—and where we will feel the effects of enlargement. Major social problems already exist, and public budgets are burdened with high social costs, which poses a problem for many Member States. If no reforms are implemented, there is a risk that the financial basis of social policy will deteriorate. A strong and competitive economy is, after all, the best basis for social security. It is therefore sensible to put these issues on the agenda. In the discussion on the coordination of social policy in the EU, we often use the term "social convergence." We liberals can support the concept of social convergence when it comes to developing common general objectives within the EU that countries intend to achieve with their national social policies. So, this is not about harmonization, but about common goals. EU countries organize their social policy in different ways. Our traditions are different, there are differences in our cultures, and despite many points of contact, there are also major differences between countries in the nature and extent of social problems. It must therefore be emphasized that social policy is a national matter. Social policy must, of course, adhere to a set of common framework conditions.

Therefore, a ceiling must be set for administrative tasks. The committee drew conclusions from these critical remarks. We attached particular importance to linking the creation of new jobs for disadvantaged and marginalized people in the social sector, tourism, and small and medium-sized enterprises with the promotion of start-ups in small and medium-sized enterprises, taking into account the necessary economic structural change. The integration of activities within the framework of the Community Initiative with the European Employment Initiatives is an essential requirement and a crucial prerequisite for achieving the objectives of the EQUAL program. We emphatically support the innovative approach of forming international development partnerships and organizing the exchange of experience at the European level as an integral part of the EQUAL program. The specific objective of achieving European benefits elevates regional cooperation to the European level, while maintaining cooperation between the most diverse regional actors. This is a good thing, and that is why we supported it. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, it has already been pointed out today that the first URBAN initiative was clearly a success. The fact that this initiative is now being continued as part of URBAN II, albeit with reduced funding, is thanks solely to committed Members of this Parliament, especially—as far as I have heard as a new Member of this Parliament—the rapporteur, Ms. McCarthy, whom I would therefore like to thank most sincerely for her commitment and, of course, also for her report on URBAN II. What is new about the URBAN II initiative is that it has been tailored to small towns and urban districts. This is important because small towns in particular often have fewer opportunities to obtain funding. On the other hand, however, the problems that lead to a strong need for renewal can be particularly concentrated in such towns and cities and can therefore have a strongly negative impact. In order to increase the effectiveness of the individual measures, the number of projects for Urban II has been limited to 50. I consider it important not to rigidly maintain this arbitrarily set numerical limit, but to leave it up to the Member States to decide how many projects they wish to allocate the funding to which they are entitled. However, it is important to ensure that, especially in small Member States, funding is not limited to urban districts of large cities. There, URBAN II would be a drop in the ocean, of dubious success, and would fizzle out. I also believe it is important not to excessively expand the selection criteria for URBAN II and thereby dilute them. A strictly defined catalogue of criteria is a prerequisite for the funded projects to serve as models and to be transferable to other problem cities in the future. Drawing on my own experience in local politics in a legacy industrialized region with many problems, I would like to conclude by asking you, dear colleagues, for your support of two points in the report, which I consider essential alongside the socio-political aspects. First, environmental protection is essential for sustainable urban development and should therefore be a general prerequisite for project funding. Second, the prevention and combating of everyday urban crime and drug-related crime must begin at the local level. They are essential for improving urban quality of life and must therefore also play a central role in the URBAN II initiative.

At the national level, we believe it is urgent that taxation of labour and business be reduced to levels equivalent to those prevailing in our competitor countries, but this is a matter for the Swedish Parliament, not the European Parliament. The fact that several countries are seeking different solutions in terms of tax and social protection policy provides an opportunity to adapt these to national specificities and to test different social protection systems. Tax harmonisation at the European level should only take place in exceptional cases, for example for certain environmentally related or capital taxes. We agree that a certain degree of harmonisation is necessary for the internal market to function, but we believe that Amendment 4 goes much too far and is too lacking in nuance. Joint resolution on the sinking of the Erika (RC B5-0181/2000) Mr President, we voted for the resolution concerning the sinking of the Erika in solidarity with the victims of this ecological disaster. However, we denounce the half-hearted nature of the resolution. Simply deploring the disaster and pitying its victims, without taking coercive measures to force Total to repair all the direct and indirect consequences of pollution for which it is entirely responsible, is doing nothing. It is revolting that Total is leaving it to volunteers and local authorities to repair the damage it has caused. It is equally revolting that it is the State that is releasing funds, which are insufficient, which is nothing more than a disguised subsidy to this company with its criminal activities. Simply raising the issue of flags of convenience is avoiding the essential point. Regardless of the flag of convenience Total uses, the guilty oil company is widely known and present in all European Union countries, and the relevant authorities could, if they wished, sequester all its assets until the company pays. And above all, we wish to denounce this economy where, to make additional profit, a company can pollute a region just as it can ruin it by closing factories. Mr. President, on behalf of the Breton Democratic Union, the Breton partner of the European Free Alliance, and in my own name, I call for the adoption of a real policy to avoid new disasters such as the sinking of the Erika. Regulations and means of control must not only be stricter, they must also be rigorously enforced. It has been made clear that a series of actors must clear the floor to ensure that the Erika is the last ecological nightmare on the Breton coast. This is already the seventh time that an oil spill has hit Brittany since the sinking of the Torry Canyon. No other region in the world has had to pay such a heavy price for the transport of polluting or dangerous products by sea.

Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank and congratulate the rapporteur and also point out that in her report she not only welcomes the proposal for a framework decision, but also proposes a number of amendments which have been highlighted in the various speeches we have heard, amendments which supplement or improve the original text, but which we cannot all discuss here in detail. In any case, the aim is to ensure the success of the euro. We must therefore do everything in our power to ensure that this success is not threatened or jeopardised by inadequate measures to protect against counterfeiting – and we are aware of initial attempts to do so. We have all pointed out that the transition phase creates many uncertainties and dangers. In addition to the work carried out against counterfeiting and the regular implementation of the provisions, the planned information campaign must therefore play a vital role. We must continue to devote ourselves intensively to this. These are also questions of cooperation. We need a definition of the precise responsibilities of the ECB, the national central banks, the Commission and Europol in all matters relating to the falsification of the euro. I am also wondering whether an interinstitutional or Community body should be set up to ensure coordination in matters of cooperation. In this connection, there is also talk of setting up a 24-hour early warning system and of establishing a common information system allowing for the rapid exchange of information between the various competent authorities. In addition to this report, the content of which we welcome, many questions still need to be clarified. I hope that the debate we are holding here will provide some of these clarifications. Mr President, Madam Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, to what extent is the euro a safe currency? This is a question we are very frequently asked by the public. This question will of course become increasingly pressing as we approach 1 January 2002, the date on which the euro will be in everyone's wallet. This question of the security of the euro concerns not only the stability and external value of this currency, but also its protection against counterfeiting. These are questions that also affect the population, because this money will be, as has been rightly said, something new for the citizens of the Union, both to the eyes and to the hands that handle it. The fact that this currency will be valid over a much wider area and will be used as the main currency throughout Europe will also be something new for the citizens of Europe. We will have to get used to it. It is therefore clear that we are being asked the question of what the EU is doing to protect the euro against counterfeiters. This is precisely what we are debating during this evening session. This is truly a topic of great interest to the public. It is therefore regrettable that it is being addressed at such a late hour. But that is how it should be. Of course, the European Central Bank has been considering this issue for a very long time.

Furthermore, the Court is of the opinion, Your Honor, that the transfer between Portugal and France does not violate the principle of rational and responsible exploitation of marine and living aquatic resources, since fishing pressure in subdivisions 8 and 9 does not increase or adversely affect the overall share of those resources allocated to Spain. Accordingly, the Council reiterates, Your Honor, its view that, without this transfer, France's fishing opportunities for anchovy in the Bay of Biscay would increase. Therefore, the Council reiterates, Your Honor, its view that fishing pressure would be greater and more detrimental to the stocks than the solution ultimately chosen. Specifically, 3,000 tonnes represent 57.5% of Portugal's fishing opportunities in 2000, compared to 5,008 tonnes, or 73.9%, in 1999. These figures represent, in our view and from the Council's perspective, a real improvement from a conservation point of view, compared with the 80% level laid down in Council Regulation 685/95. Question No 6 by (H-0788/99): Subject: Measures to tackle the continuing ethnic cleansing against ethnic Serbs and Roma in Kosovo The NATO Defence Ministers' Summit on 2 December 1999 issued a strong call for an end to ethnic cleansing against ethnic minorities in Kosovo. The European Parliament, in a resolution referring to certain acts of hateful violence perpetrated against the Serb and Roma population, also strongly condemns the persistent violence against the Serb population of Kosovo and calls on the leaders of the Kosovo Albanian community to fully respect United Nations Resolution 1244. The resolution also emphasizes that the past persecution of the Albanian population cannot constitute "a pretext for continued killings, abductions, arrests, abuse of power, harassment and intimidation, arson, looting, destruction of property, and occupation of homes." In light of the above, does the Council intend to reconsider funding for the reconstruction of Kosovo, as requested by the European Parliament? What other practical measures does it intend to take to put an end to ethnic cleansing? Honourable Member, I would like to express my deepest sympathy for the concern underlying the issue you have raised. We truly share the concerns that the Honourable Member feels regarding the threat that exists within Kosovo for ethnic minorities, whether in relation to the Serb population or the Gypsy population, and the aspects of discrimination, harassment, and intimidation that continue to occur in that territory. The Council has consistently underscored the need to bring to justice all those who perpetrated such acts and those who continue to perpetrate them. The Council also reiterated, in its December conclusions, the need for the full implementation of Security Council resolution 12/99 and has consistently supported the efforts undertaken by Mr. Bernard Kouchner to implement measures that may guarantee effective protection for minorities in that territory and, in particular, the effective implementation of measures that preserve its multiethnic character. In our contacts with leading political figures among the Kosovo Albanians, as was done very recently by the Portuguese Prime Minister, we have emphasized that the persecution of Serb populations, Roma populations, and other ethnic groups is completely unacceptable.

It would be beneficial if the Union reconsidered the reallocation of funds from environmental projects to better support the sustainable development of water policy. Regarding this proposed directive, it is worrying that the amendments considered by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection did not sufficiently take into account the importance of clean surface water for increasing natural areas with clean groundwater resources. In Finland, surface water is very clean. Artificial groundwater production is an environmentally friendly way of filtering clean surface water to replenish groundwater reserves. This process is carried out without the need for chemical treatment plants. The directive should not jeopardize this activity. In disagreement with the Council's common position, the Committee on the Environment also seeks to further limit the possibilities of water transfers. This would be problematic for countries with unevenly distributed water reserves. Ecologically sustainable transfers should not be restricted by EU regulations. Activities in this regard must continue to be controlled by regulations and have the appropriate authorization, but the same provisions do not apply, for example, to Finland and to a country suffering from droughts like Greece. Mr. President, Commissioner, water is an invaluable natural resource, indispensable for certain vital functions, and it is our duty to protect it. I believe that a framework directive on water policy in the European Union is essential, as the basic legal instrument for improving the quality and proper management of water resources, and I congratulate the rapporteur for the effort made to resolve this thorny issue and reconcile all opinions. However, I must mention that there are differences on the water issue between northern and southern countries, so the same solution cannot be adopted. There are regions in Europe with a structural lack of water, and this directive must take this into account. In recent years, due to climate change, the countries of the Mediterranean basin have been facing serious problems due to flooding and drought. Mr. President, we agree with the common position; But we also accept many amendments that have been submitted that aim to improve it. But we cannot accept amendments such as those that refer to the issue of calculating the cost of water because in my country, a large number of users are farmers. Furthermore, amendments that do not allow water to be transported from one river basin to another would condemn many regions in my country to water shortages. I believe that the issue of the elimination of hazardous substances must be approached on a realistic basis in order to achieve a resolution. Regarding the time required to implement the directive, it must be taken into account that there are countries where the infrastructure for implementing this directive requires significant time and resources. Mr. President, I believe that despite these observations, the common objective of the sustainable use of water resources remains.

European postal services The next item is the debate on oral question (B5-0010/2000) by Mr. Hatzidakis, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, to the Commission, on European postal services. Mr. President, the postal sector is still a sector in which old, outdated monopolies are allowed to operate, without competition. This has been the case for too long, due to the absence of a vigorous Commission in this sector. In all other sectors, the Community competition authorities have intervened, but not here. We have waited in vain for Commission proposals for 18 months. I would like the Commission to answer me today: when will we have new, modern postal services that can operate throughout the EU? One of the most important Community principles is the internal market. We are working hard to expand it to include more Member States. This requires efficiency, and efficiency means competition. Today, there are demands for liberalization and deregulation in all sectors. The EU is often at the forefront of this process. The Commission is driving this development in an exemplary manner. The Commission does so because we have many experiences with old monopolies incapable of providing good service, as a modern society demands. It also does so to keep up with technological development. Furthermore, the Commission does so to be able to lower prices, convinced that this is easier to achieve in a free market subject to the rules of competition. This is the case in a number of sectors; unfortunately, so far, with the major exception of postal services. I don't think it's precisely because customers are satisfied. We all know that criticism of price increases and delays in letter delivery are a constant topic of discussion. If we are truly interested in having a functioning internal market, we cannot continue to make exceptions for the activities of postal services. Some countries have advanced more quickly and created the conditions for freer competition in the postal sector. The Netherlands, Finland, and Sweden have gone the furthest. These countries have demonstrated over the past decade that some benefits can be achieved. In Sweden, moreover, this development has been taking place gradually, in an environment of broad political consensus. It is important that this process be allowed to continue and that it be given the necessary incentives. Experience shows that old monopolies are not capable of providing services that function as all of us, the customers, have the right to demand. Given the approach of this debate, those in favor of continuing the monopoly have sent a letter. In it, they refer to Sweden as a warning. Such criticisms could possibly be made in a number of situations, but not specifically in this area. A circular letter stated that the price of stamps has risen 59 percent since liberalization in 1993. This is true, if we consider this only on the condition that only 20 percent of the total postal market was taken into account, where, in practice, a monopoly still exists, that is, where the state is the sole player.

One point concerning the impact on businesses is of particular importance, as Mrs Thyssen, Mrs Peijs and Mrs Palacio Vallelersundi have pointed out: SMEs. Many Members have insisted on this aspect. The Commission is pursuing the issue of legal certainty for SMEs with particular attention. The system we are proposing significantly improves legal certainty for SMEs. Why? Is it just a political move? No, in the context of the system we are proposing to reform the material rules in such a way that the majority of SMEs will be covered by the block exemption regulations, as is the case with vertical constraints; the majority of SMEs, in fact, have less than 30% of market shares. We have considered a de minimis notification which contains a statement that SMEs are, as a rule, not subject to the strict prohibition of Article 81(1), as there is no problem of a dominant market position for such companies. We are continuing to work on other block exemption regulations and guidelines that will take into account the specific situation of SMEs in a comprehensive manner, firstly by eliminating the bureaucratic effects of the current notification system and, secondly, by making Article 81(3) immediately applicable, to the particular advantage of SMEs. The fourth issue is that of legal certainty. Of course, legal certainty, Mr Evans - I am the first to recognise this - is important for businesses, not only for the legal professions, which also play a very important role in the construction of Europe. Legal certainty is important for businesses: this is a topic on which the Chairman of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, Mrs Palacio Vallelersundi, who I am very grateful to, also stressed in her latest speech for her constant focus on the issues of the single market in the broad sense, including competition in this case. I am convinced that this proposal will increase the legal certainty of businesses, for three reasons: it will allow all restrictive agreements which satisfy the conditions for exemption to be authorised without a prior decision, by virtue of the direct effect of Article 81(3); it will create the possibility of assisting businesses in cases of interpretative doubt by publishing reasoned opinions; it will be accompanied by exemption regulations and guidelines to clarify the rules and ensure their certainty. (FR) Mrs Thyssen also referred to the legal privilege for in-house lawyers. Let me point out that the Court of Justice ruled on this issue, as you know better than I do, in 1982. That case law remains valid and there is nothing to justify calling it into question. The White Paper requires a re-examination of the issue in one aspect only: the exchange of confidential information. The guarantees which must be given to businesses are currently being discussed. I now come quickly, Mr President, to the report by Mr Rapkay, to whom I extend my heartfelt thanks for the quality of his work and for the substantial support given to the Commission's 28th annual report on competition policy.

Secondly, we must maintain the data as established in the common position. Thus, from 2006, free return of all vehicles will be granted, with no costs for the final owner. This, of course, is an extremely essential point, which cannot be amended. Is this too much of a burden? There is one thing we must not forget. The directive deals with whole vehicles, that is, vehicles that do not lack any essential parts. In the opinion of specialists, there are few whole cars that have no value. Because recycling, the reuse of components, is a sector that does not necessarily have to generate losses; on the contrary, there are currently a large number of companies that make a living from it and earn a decent living. The directive stimulates this entire sector, which is a sector of small and medium-sized enterprises. Since transport costs in this case are high, it will be necessary to implement a completely decentralized system, because transporting scrap metal more than 100 kilometers is not a profitable activity. I think it's positive that the directive does not apply to historic vehicles, and I think we should add this. Therefore, vintage vehicles, "oldtimers," in my view, should be exempt. It's also good that we clearly attribute responsibility to the manufacturers. This is a basic principle that we must uphold. They are responsible for the design phase. Consequently, they can do a lot for the environment through that design phase. We must also continue to support the manufacturers bearing all or a large part of the costs, as set out in the common position. I think it's a balanced formula and does not exclude a number of other aspects. I think we should maintain it.
