Legal certainty is important for businesses: the importance of this issue was also underlined by the Chair of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, Mrs Palacio Vallelersundi – whom I should like to thank very much for dealing, as always, with internal market issues in a broad sense, in this case including competition – in her recent remarks. I am convinced that this proposal will mean greater legal certainty for businesses, for three reasons: because of the direct effect of Article 81(3), it will allow the authorisation, without prior decision, of all agreements restricting competition which meet the conditions for exemption. It will make it possible, in cases of doubt as to interpretation, to assist businesses by publishing reasoned opinions. At the same time, it establishes exceptions and guidelines to clarify the rules and ensure their certainty. (FR) Mrs. Thyssen also raised the issue of the legal exception for legal advisors. I would simply like to recall that, as you certainly know better than I, the Court of Justice ruled on this issue in 1982. This case law remains valid, and there is no reason to question it.

The free take-back system, for example, for old vehicles and the increase in the percentage to be recycled will increase recycling activities and the number of jobs it generates. Therefore, for the consumer, for the environment, for the new jobs to be created in recycling, there is absolutely no need to amend the Council's common position, which is, in its current state, entirely acceptable. Mr President, like many others in this House, I believe that this is a good measure. It is a useful measure that we all need. Most of the technical issues have been resolved. Some details still need to be sorted out, but most of the technical issues have been resolved. We come to the final question. At the first reading, only the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs asked this question, and I was the only one, as rapporteur for the opinion of that committee, to ask Parliament the question, namely, simply, who pays? Thanks to the Council's common position, a reasonable compromise has been reached, in that manufacturers should pay a significant proportion of the costs and not all of them, as Mr. Bowis wrongly said. In fact—and this is what the lawyers tell us—they should not pay more than 20% or one-fifth of the costs, which is not unreasonable. For example, consider consumers in the United Kingdom who buy a Rover, as Mr. Lange indicated, or, for that matter, any other British make of car, and who, for years, have been paying an excessive price for these cars, higher than the price charged in other parts of Europe. Why should they pay? They have already paid. Why should taxpayers or future car buyers have to pay again to get rid of the vehicle from which the manufacturer has made a profit? I cannot accept that. Some amendments propose that. I cannot accept it, and I will vote against it. As far as these cars are concerned, the responsibility lies with the manufacturer. It is the manufacturer who must provide the infrastructure and bear a reasonable share of the disposal costs. The common position does not exclude the possibility of contributions from the government. The common position represents a reasonable compromise. Some of the amendments proposed today are completely unreasonable in that they relieve car manufacturers of the responsibility to pay even a small part of the cost of removing cars from the road. I cannot accept this, and on behalf of Europe's taxpayers and consumers, I am voting against these amendments. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, everyone agrees that we must consider how to deal with end-of-life vehicles in Europe, but in this instance, the Council has not set an example of sound European environmental policy. The way in which the German Presidency of the Council handled this issue was reprehensible. First, Mr Trittin, the Environment Minister, did not hold sufficient consultations within his cabinet; Then Federal Chancellor Schröder interfered in the proceedings like a bull in a china shop, without knowing the case.

Funds must be allocated to category seven, where a review of the financial perspective must be carried out. This is the key point. The most important thing is that the pre-accession aid money for Cyprus and Malta be taken from category seven and a review of the financial perspective be carried out, because if the Council does not support it, it would actually be contradicting the decisions it adopted in Helsinki in December. Regarding the amount indicated in the Brok report, €130 million, I would also like to say on behalf of the Liberal Group that we must find an amount we can negotiate until we reach the sum. The most important thing is to ensure a multiannual program in the correct category, so that we can begin planning in Cyprus and Malta. Mr. President, the Greens/European Free Alliance Group supports the decision taken by the Helsinki European Council, according to which the resolution of the conflict cannot be a precondition for Cyprus' accession. Strong pressure must continue to be exerted on the Cypriot government, even though the will of the majority of the population cannot be subjected to blackmail, to blackmail by a section of it, also because we harbor serious doubts about the representativeness of the government in that part of the island. It is clear that the window of opportunity—the "jacket of opportunity" mentioned by the Presidency—must be fully exploited. However, we are convinced that, although Turkish-Greek relations have improved, this cannot be enough. The solution to the Cyprus conflict lies above all in improving relations between the two communities with a view to the establishment—hopefully not too far off—of a federation. In particular, we must act to resolve the issue of establishing genuine freedom of movement and the problem of the demilitarization and disarmament of the island. The European Union, beyond financial aid, which is undoubtedly important, must play an active role in guaranteeing and promoting contacts between the two communities by establishing discussion forums and confidence-building programs. I would like to express my deep regret at this time for the absence from Parliament of Alex Langer, a peacemaker and an example for all of us of how to build coexistence between peoples. Mr. President, the mention of the dialogue between the two Cypriot parties under the aegis of the United Nations reminds us that, twenty-six years after the Turkish army's invasion of the island, the occupation of almost 40% of the territory continues with 35,000 soldiers, heavy military assets, and the installation of more than 50,000 settlers, in complete violation of the relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions. What can the European Union do within this framework to promote—without interfering in matters that concern exclusively Cypriots—the search for a fair and viable solution to this dramatic problem affecting a country with ties to the European Community for almost thirty years and destined to join the Union in the coming years?

And, if we're talking about serious and persistent violations, perhaps we can talk about certain Member States; we can talk about Italy and France, the first and third countries, respectively, condemned by the Council of Europe, by the Strasbourg Court. We can talk, ladies and gentlemen, about Belgium, about the Dutroux case, about the dozens and dozens of children kidnapped, tortured, raped, and murdered by figures from that country, and whose investigations are stalled, always stalled. We could, ladies and gentlemen, impose on the Council and the Commission, with a third of the MEPs, the obligation to question this matter. We could question the fact that the Austrians reject ten years, thirteen years, of party rule that has corrupted and rotted a country—Austria—just as it is corrupting and rotting countries like Italy, Belgium, and other Member States of the Union. We could indeed ask ourselves, ladies and gentlemen, why 76% of Belgian citizens have no confidence in their country's justice system, 56% of French citizens have no confidence in their country's justice system, 53% of Italian citizens have no confidence in their justice system... (The President cuts the speaker off) Madam President, my group, the EDD, and especially my party, are deeply concerned about this debate. We cannot, and in no way do, support Mr. Haider's sentiments or politics, and we deplore the references he has made to the Third Reich. However, we also deplore the fact that your Parliament is considering interfering in the politics of an elected government of any country, especially one that is part of the European Union. My party in my country is not in the least racist, but we do not accept the dictates or interference of the European Union. Do you intend to interfere in the British Parliament if we are elected? Madam President, the people of Austria have spoken by electing Mr. Haider to their Parliament. I believe they gave him 28% of the vote, so a coalition government will be formed. Your Parliament, let me suggest, Madam President, should wait to see whether Mr. Haider's party has any impact on the politics of that country. Then, and only then, could you consider whether human rights are being affected. Your Parliament can consider appropriate measures to counteract that situation, and then, Madam President, and only then could your Parliament consider interfering in the constitutional affairs of a European Union country. Madam President, as a member of the Liberal Party, I respect the concerns of some colleagues about democratic developments in Austria. You may be surprised by my reaction if I say that I fully understand the particular sensitivity toward Austria on issues related to respect for human rights, the awareness of responsibility for its own past, and the stability of democracy. Austria itself must respond to the often dubious image that prevails abroad, whether justified or unjustified.

On the basis of these assessments, we wish to express our firm opposition to the "modernisation" of social protection promoted by the Commission in its communication, concluding that we cannot give our assent to the report presented by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. This concludes the explanations of vote. (The sitting, suspended at 1.55 p.m., resumed at 3 p.m.) Next UN "Human Rights" session (continuation) The next item is the Council statement on the Union's priorities for the next session of the UN Commission on Human Rights (20 March 2000), including the situation in China. Mr President, I regret the absence of the Presidency-in-Office of the Council; this is a statement by the Council, and it would perhaps have been useful for a Council representative to be present for the continuation of the debate. I do not think it is idle to point out that the reason for including this item on the agenda was the need, expressed by all the political groups, for Parliament to organise a debate before the next meeting of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva to make its voice heard on a subject it considers to be of fundamental importance. I believe that, following the statement by the Presidency-in-Office of the Council, we are all in agreement that the current situation, as regards human rights, is very far from what we would like it to be. At Union level, we must say that the situation is not very satisfactory, since, for example, although the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms is a common element for all the Member States, the subsequent protocols have not been ratified or signed by all of them. Furthermore, it is a clear drawback in this respect that the European Union as such is not a signatory to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, with all the consequences that this situation entails. I hope that these problems can be addressed and discussed in the debate on the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. On the external level, I believe that most of the points included in the resolution give us a vision that is fairly close to reality and do not at all invite optimism, Mr President, given that aspects such as the abolition of the death penalty, torture still practiced in many countries that claim to be democratic or the situation of minorities in many parts of the planet require a clear, visible and effective response from the European Union. In my opinion, this resolution contains a number of essential points, but I would like to focus on one in particular: the need for greater coordination between the European Union and the United Nations. Mr President, in a world like the present one, dominated more and more by the phenomenon of globalisation, and not only in the economic sphere, we must give concerted and coordinated responses if they are to be effective. To ensure this effectiveness of our actions, it is necessary to implement in practice a coordination that does not currently exist. For this reason, Parliament defends the principle of the need to participate in the work of the Committee on Human Rights and other international institutions that address these issues. Furthermore, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Parliament would like to be able to participate in this type of meeting as soon as possible.

Madam President, the assessment of the reform process was certainly very high, which is to be acknowledged, perhaps even somewhat premature. My question: the reform is necessary not least because of the accession of new countries and thus the enlargement of the Union. How can we – the Commission, Parliament, and also the national parliaments of the accession states – meet this challenge more effectively, also taking into account the ideas and considerations of the accession states? The delegations are working actively – I am doing so in my delegation for the Czech Republic – but it is noticeable that we often treat each other in a very patronizing manner. How can the reform contribute to making the relationship and cooperation, the joint work between the European Parliament, the national parliaments, and also the Commission, more effective? I thank the honourable Member for highlighting the fact that the reform, apart from being useful in itself, is necessitated by the accession process and the enlargements, especially the enlargements that the Union will soon undergo. It is important that we carry out this reform not only for the sake of the Union as it currently exists, but also to make accessions possible. In the coming years, I will maintain the practice, which I have already established, of course, together with many of my Commission colleagues, of holding extensive discussions with the governments of the future Member States. We do this because we want to explain to them in every respect the system they will be joining. I would also like to draw attention to the enrichment provided by the training provided both by the Member States and by the Union generally, so that when the new staff join the Commission and the officials and administrators in the Member States have to cope with the realities, the difficult realities, of membership of the Union and the internal market, the breaking points will be hard to detect. I would like to see such a high level of development and preparation. All I can do now is promise to strive for it. First, I would like to wish the Commissioner a happy St. David's Day. Thank you very much for your speech. It is now crucial for the Commission not to lose sight of the fact that the reform process would be a complete waste of time without reconnecting with the European public. This, above all, must never be lost sight of. The Commission must serve the public, and the recommendations to reduce payment delays are certainly most welcome, but another major complaint from the people we represent is the red tape. Is there an intention—without compromising financial control—to reduce bureaucracy and red tape for applicants for European funding? This is constantly being criticized, and action is needed here. My second question concerns the audit follow-up panel. I certainly welcome this very much, but it is also important to include a reference to monitoring the recommendations we make to the European Parliament as part of our discharge procedure. Will you incorporate this into the work of your panel? Finally, I would like to say that the Socialist Group agrees with activity-based budgeting and the delegation of responsibility. You will be judged, as Mr Prodi put it, by your actions and not by your words.

By contrast, the 1995 Convention allows for the opening of ancillary procedures. This creates exceptional situations in addition to the general rule that the Commission would like to see included. Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam, the Commission would have preferred to adopt a new text explicitly enshrining the principle of unity. However, I do not believe that now is the time to call into question the agreement reached under the 1995 Convention – which, incidentally, was negotiated over a period of approximately thirty years. Consequently, the Commission has declined to submit a proposal and has limited its views to questions of an institutional nature. For this reason too, the Commission considers that it will not propose an amendment to the Regulation but would like to explain to the Honourable Members its views on the amendments before it. The Commission therefore accepts Amendments 1, 2, 3, and 5 proposed by the rapporteur, Mr Lechner, but not Amendment 4. The Commission considers that Parliament should instead support Amendment 4 tabled by the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, to enable the Commission to amend the annexes to the Regulation, assisted by a regulatory committee, in accordance with Article 5 of Resolution EC 1999/468. Consequently, the Commission accepts Amendments 3 and 4 tabled by the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, but not Amendments 1 and 2 concerning the concept of 'the debtor's centre of main interests'. The concept of 'the centre of main interests of a company or legal person' is adequately defined in Article 3. For all other cases not directly addressed, the reference in Recital 13 should be considered sufficient. Thank you very much, Commissioner Vitorino. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11.00 a.m. (The sitting closed at 12.05 a.m.) The shipwreck of the Erika The next item is the debate on Oral Question B5-0011/2000 by Mr Varela Suanzes-Carpegna, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, to the Commission on the shipwreck of the Erika. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should first like to express the appreciation shown by Mr Fischler's presence here today. Yesterday our President announced that he would be absent due to scheduling conflicts. I believe he has reconsidered and done what we have come to expect: he has shown this Parliament his appreciation and respect, as he always has, and for that I thank him. I raise my voice in this House today on behalf of the European Parliament's Committee on Fisheries to once again draw attention to the shipwreck of the oil tanker Erika and to express our concern. A twofold political consideration prompts our committee—and me, as its chairman—to raise this matter again. First, to demonstrate to the Commission, the Council, and the Member States that our Parliament cannot and will not forget this grave disaster.

We must be assured that the Council acts in accordance with Parliament's approach. Unfortunately, no initiatives have been taken on other issues so far. We are still waiting. The European Area of Freedom, Security, and Justice remains an area lacking clear regulations in important areas. Yet, we owe this to the citizens of Europe. After hearing the comments of the Ministers of Justice and the Interior, I am optimistic. I conclude that we will achieve this within the next six months. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that Mrs Terrón I Cusí's oral question is worth putting our foot down, because six months after the establishment of our new Parliament, we must be able to send a strong political message to the citizens of Europe. I believe that the Portuguese Presidency can make a positive contribution to this. We are all aware today of the immense expectations of our fellow citizens in terms of freedom, security, and justice, particularly social justice. But their disinterest, their distance, and sometimes even their disgust with politics urge us to take concrete measures to address their difficulties. This is the sine qua non for reconciling them with politics. For Europe to become a symbol of peace and fraternity, we need a bold and generous policy to help the most disadvantaged. A genuine plan to combat unemployment must be put in place, because it is the scourge on which racism, xenophobia, nationalism, and racist far-right movements thrive. Among the most disadvantaged—and it is important that I speak on this point—are immigrants and refugees. Thus, the almost systematic conditions of detention and the criminalization of asylum seekers are no longer acceptable. Every asylum seeker must have the right to a fair hearing and a suspensive appeal. Last week, somewhat by chance, I witnessed a scene of rare violence at Roissy airport, where two young women, admittedly illegal immigrants, were being deported to Conakry. They were treated like the worst criminals. They were naked, dragged along the ground by their hair, surrounded by a horde of CRS officers. The Portuguese Presidency must put an end to this kind of barbaric practice. On the contrary, our role is to support, reassure, and help those fleeing dictatorships. The Commission had proposed the creation of a European refugee fund. Parliament was very much in favor. Instead of procrastinating over the budget allocated to this fund, I believe you can take the decision to establish it. The Presidency and the Council can make concrete what was incomprehensibly rejected in Tampere, even though Tampere constituted an important foundation. Similarly, we cannot simply observe the rise of xenophobic currents in Europe and the trivialization of discrimination without taking far-reaching measures. Harmonization of anti-racism legislation is essential. What meaning do you intend to give to Article 13 of the Treaty? What do you intend to do to promote equal treatment in terms of pay between men and women? How do you intend to work towards the eradication of homophobia, racism, and sexism?

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of this debate, which I have followed with great attention and interest, I would like to offer a few thoughts to complement what I have already had the honor of expressing before you over the past few weeks in the presence of President Prodi. In their very thorough and carefully drafted report, your two rapporteurs, Mr Dimitrakopoulos and Mr Leinen, recommend that Parliament adopt a formal opinion under Article 48, so that, once the opinion has been adopted, the Intergovernmental Conference can actually begin its work on 14 February, as proposed by the Portuguese Presidency. For our part, having presented the opinion required of the Commission pursuant to the aforementioned Article 48 of the Treaty, we are pleased that this Conference can begin—earlier than originally planned, moreover. We know that the weeks thus gained will be very useful. After reading the draft opinion and listening to the statements made by the speakers from the various political groups, I would like to make a few further comments. First of all, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission understands the concerns expressed several times here regarding the scope of the Conference's agenda. I understand these fears, these concerns that the agenda is too short; and yet, as I explained to the Committee on Constitutional Affairs after the Helsinki Summit, I believe that it is possible to work on the basis of the Helsinki mandate. And it is in this spirit and within the framework of this mandate that the Commission has drafted its own opinion, making full use of the mandate and reading between the lines. We have not limited ourselves to what are, incidentally, inaccurately called the three 'leftovers'. Like Richard Corbett, I dislike the term 'leftovers', which suggests that these are three insignificant or marginal issues. But these are three extremely serious, important, and difficult issues—so difficult that in Amsterdam, the collective political courage was not sufficient to deal with them exhaustively. As for us – and here I respond to Mr Seguro, who expressed his concern earlier – we have not been satisfied with these three issues, even though I believe they are priorities and must be addressed now. They are the first, but not the only, issues that the Conference must address, Mr President. We have also addressed other issues, and we have expressed our idea that, given the difficult situation before enlargement, other issues should also be addressed at the Conference – if the Portuguese Presidency and, later, the French Presidency are ready to do so. We are ready to do so – whether it is the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which has begun to be drafted, the CFSP and the impact of negotiations on a defence policy on the institutions, or the very difficult issue of the revision of the Treaties, on which we will continue to work. A great many comments have been made on the Commission's opinion; all these issues have been raised and often dealt with in depth, sometimes with precise proposals for new articles. But no one has mentioned that we are outside the Helsinki mandate.

Mr President, Commissioners, when this House is called upon to reflect on the subject of human rights, it runs a great risk, which has also been highlighted in some way by the climate in which we are called upon to debate this very important subject. The absence of the Council and of almost all the Members makes us aware of the gulf that still separates noble, profound and formally useful declarations from the practical application of human rights in the field of everyday politics. I believe that this Parliament, starting with the contribution that Europe will make to the Geneva meeting, must bridge this gulf and act, not only on the level of principles, but also on that of truth and even loyalty. Human rights must not be interpreted solely in terms of denunciation or punishment. We must, as a Parliament, address the subject of human rights, above all from the perspective of prevention. We must therefore be able to export a culture of legality, a culture of law, a conformity of law. I believe that the long season of accumulating treaties and treaty signatures is definitively over. We now have many, perhaps too many, treaties that affect human rights: if these treaties remain merely a statement, they will only constitute useless collections of reflection. We must now move on to the next phase, that of the daily and coercive application of what is written in our treaties, even if we must not forget that certain fundamental treaties still need to be accepted. I am thinking here of the Rome Conference and the fact that fourteen of the fifteen States of the Union have not yet ratified the treaty on the International Criminal Court. I think that we must verify and modify certain political instruments that we use to measure the quality of human rights in the world. We have often used instruments that, formally, may be practical but, politically, prove to be completely useless. I am thinking of the use, even abuse, of the embargo in recent years and the overly cautious application of the clause suspending agreements between the European Union and third countries in the event that they fail to respect human rights. I believe that we are above all invited to update the horizon of the protection of fundamental rights. Globalization risks being interpreted as essentially repressive. In many countries, the principle of the universality of human rights is currently being questioned; it is believed that these rights and the right to life, denied by the death penalty, are dependent variables, while globalization, often taken in a punitive sense, risks being the only unifying fabric of the rights, actions, and policies of all the countries of the world.

I therefore consider it necessary to act in two directions. On the one hand, we should call on the Commission to approve, within the framework of the aid provided for the fishing sector, special measures to mitigate the impact of this disaster on the productive sector in the affected areas, and also call on it to demand from international bodies and from itself strict controls on vessels flying flags of convenience. In this regard, the current negotiation process for Malta's accession to the European Union must serve to require that country to rigorously control the oil tankers flying its flag. On the other hand, it is necessary to take preventive measures. Portugal is a country that has abundantly demonstrated its sensitivity to issues related to the sea. I would like to ask the Portuguese Presidency to examine the possibility of launching a comprehensive strategy for the prevention of marine pollution at European level, concentrating all the resources – technological, structural, and socio-economic – that we already have at our disposal to prevent a disaster like this from happening again in the future. Finally, I would like to highlight the work carried out by the volunteers and local authorities, which reminded me of times when, as mayor at the time, I experienced similar situations. Thanks must be given to those who, faced with vulnerability and a lack of resources, have courageously fought to combat the serious consequences of this disaster for coastal regions, the marine ecosystem, and Europe's fisheries resources. Mr President, as Chairman of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, I would like to congratulate the Commission, and in particular Commissioner Loyola de Palacio, on the response it has given to this incident, which has deeply shocked the whole of Europe. We in the Committee on Transport are ready to debate the Commission's communication on maritime safety and, later, of course, the legal conclusions it will draw from it. Allow me to make a few further comments: First, the Commission has rightly focused its investigations on the culpability of the Italian classification society RINA, because it must be examined whether Community law was applied. This is where our efforts must begin. Second, in such cases, we should examine whether, in addition to the shipowners, charterers, such as the oil companies, also bear responsibility, since they are complicit in environmental disasters like this and must therefore also pay for the damage. That said, the responses to this ecological disaster are entirely justified. However, this must not lead us to stigmatize all of merchant shipping, a sector so vital to the economy that accounts for around a third of transport volumes. Our response must therefore be measured, strict, but also reasonable. I am not at all opposed to considering tightening Community law, but, as other colleagues have emphasized, we must start with implementation, because—and we must not forget this—a legal framework already exists at the European Union level. This framework is sufficiently developed, at least when one compares the various regulations worldwide. Consequently, the Member States, also under the supervision of the Commission, must finally begin to actually apply Community law.

I have the great pleasure of handing the floor now to Prime Minister António Guterres. I thank the President-in-Office of the Council, António Guterres, and I now hand over to the President of the Commission, Romano Prodi. . Madam President, first of all I would like to warmly congratulate Prime Minister Guterres on the initiative that has been taken for the Lisbon Summit, and on the quality of the preparatory work. We fully share his analysis that we have heard and that has been so warmly applauded, and we support his initiative. I believe that together we can make Lisbon a successful Summit. In this speech I will simply present to you the Commission's contribution to Lisbon: our long-term strategy and our vision for this Summit. In Lisbon we have to decide on something very simple, and that is whether Europe can regain its long-lost leadership in the economy and technology. This depends on us, on the economic growth that we will be able to impose on the European system, on the level of employment that we will be able to create, on the level of education of our citizens, on the training of our working class. These are not new issues, as Prime Minister Guterres said. In fact, we are not doing another Luxembourg-type, Cardiff-type, Cologne-type exercise, but we want to address these issues, which we have already addressed, with a completely new approach: not one issue at a time but all together, to finally build a system of interventions. We are doing it now because it is the moment in which all this can succeed. In fact, we have a unique opportunity before us, an opportunity that has been built on the success of a wise policy implemented in the recent past: we have low inflation, a globally healthy balance of payments, public accounts in order, and we finally have unanimous forecasts of very strong economic growth, forecasts, as the Portuguese Prime Minister underlined, which do not however mean certainty of economic growth. Never before in the last generation has there been such unanimity among all scholars in Europe in predicting a possible long period of high growth. Not even with the increase in the price of oil has there been an interruption in this growth nor a recovery in inflation, as one might have feared. There are, however, some worrying signs, which however do not prevent us from continuing a development policy as we had thought and planned. The challenges of Lisbon are therefore very simple: we must respond to the technological challenge by recovering lost ground in the field of knowledge, of knowledge, of technologies, especially of reform technologies. We can thus return to a leading position; this is why we have taken the e-EUROPE initiative, thanks to which the Commission has decided, in its administrative reform, to give a concrete example. We have committed ourselves - and it is a commitment that I confirm in front of you - to create a Commission, we could better say an e-Commission, in the sense that every relationship of supplies, research, etc. with this Institution will no longer have to take place on paper but directly electronically.

Major public investments have been made at the federal, state, and local levels. They have been enormous, and they have been investments in new infrastructure. Be careful, here our direct effort—I repeat, direct at the public level and at different levels—is to build telematic highways, that is, the roads on which these new vehicles circulate. The market, individuals, and companies will build the vehicles for circulation, but we are the ones who have the obligation to build the new highways. Therefore, what Prime Minister Guterres said about computers in all schools, about the network that must include all peripheral regions, is not an obligation that can be imposed exclusively on the market, since the market does not do this, and, moreover, without it, we will not achieve these new development and productivity goals that are necessary. Therefore, our problem is to avoid a crisis in peripheral economies, which does not imply centralization or centralized programming, but rather requires providing peripheral economies with the same opportunities that we provide to centralized economies. This is why the program must be directed at schools; this is why we must address an entire age group and insist on ensuring that no one in that age group is left out of the new literacy program. Lisbon, therefore, has a very precise strategy. In Lisbon, in my opinion, the real problem is injecting new value into employment and growth, knowing that we can do it, and therefore, we must move toward this model based on secure balances. To summarize today's debate, I would like to recall a phrase used by one of your honorable Members, if I recall correctly, Mr. Goebbels, who said: "We have a deficit of the future in Europe." It's simply that. We have complained for a long time, while the seeds of what we had planted with great sacrifice in the roots of Europe matured instead. Now, please, let us also try to close the deficit of the future and give meaning to the new generations, knowing that we are working together soberly but seriously for something lasting. Clearly, then, it is essential to bring together the three processes. Unfortunately, our terminology is horrendous, but we truly bring together the problems of macroeconomics, labor, and structural problems now, and then we have the capacity and the possibility of achieving the results we desired, with very simple, even specific, actions. We remember European society: we have not yet achieved unanimity regarding European society, but there are hundreds of thousands of companies asking us for it. It must be done at all costs because the very idea of operating in fifteen states that are becoming one with different rules regarding the basic principles of business is an unsustainable idea: we can't sell it because it doesn't make sense. The same goes for the European patent: we can't sell it either; the provisions relating to public tenders, the capital markets; also the seeds of social security coordination, because it's useless for us to think about great opportunities for mobility, to create highly successful programs like ERASMUS and SOCRATES to make people more mobile, if we then don't have social security regulations that don't help us with this mobility.

Commissioner, we are facing a reform whose importance cannot be overstated. It transcends competition, it transcends the cohesion of the internal market. I believe it profoundly affects the very meaning of European integration, the meaning of the legitimacy of European integration. Therefore, Commissioner, we count on this interinstitutional dialogue to outline a reform that we all look forward to and which we believe we will bring to fruition with your guidance and our cooperation. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I warmly thank the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the entire European Parliament for the great interest shown in competition issues. Mr. President, in my opinion, this joint debate is the most vivid and valuable testimony to this. We have heard very profound considerations that, at the same time, reflect the philosophy of economic policy and the analysis of the institutional structure. Our common aim is to modernize and strengthen competition policy, a pillar of the social market economy and European integration. The common thread running through all these aspects of competition policy reform, which we will address together, is a thread aimed at ensuring more effective protection of competition, reducing the bureaucratic burden on businesses, and bringing decision-making processes closer to the public. I would like to personally and profoundly thank Mr. von Wogau for the dedication with which he has examined the dossier on the White Paper and the quality of his report. I would like to group the considerations made throughout the debate on the von Wogau report into four points that I do not consider criticisms of the Commission, but rather fundamental contributions, given that there are concerns that are right to have and that we want to overcome together: the issue of effectiveness, the risk of renationalization, the issue of consistency in application, and legal certainty. I will examine them very quickly one by one. Effectiveness: I am convinced that this reform makes it possible to strengthen, not weaken, the protection of competition within the single market. Ladies and gentlemen, the current notification system no longer allows this objective to be achieved, because it does not guarantee that the Commission is informed about the most serious restrictions—I recall that in thirty-five years, only nine prohibition decisions have been adopted after notification and in the absence of a complaint—it does not guarantee transparency and does not provide real legal certainty for companies, which, in most cases, receive a simple administrative letter that is filed away. The proposed system will improve the protection of competition, first of all because it will allow the Commission to focus its action on the most serious restrictions and, therefore, because it will involve national and competition authorities to a greater extent in the suppression of violations. Finally, because it will allow victims of infringements to have direct recourse to national judges, whose mission is to protect individual rights. The question of renationalization: first of all, although it is superfluous, I would like to recall and underline, if possible three times, that the White Paper does not in the least affect mergers and State aid—we are not considering a repayment in these matters—but, as far as Regulation No. 17 is concerned, there is a risk of renationalization.

We know the rest. We should then establish reliable technical inspections, similar to the mandatory technical inspections in France for vehicles over five years old. We should regulate the use of flags of convenience, require double hulls for the transport of polluting or hazardous materials, and innovate technologically to treat or collect hydrocarbons at sea. This would be, I think, the very least we can do at the dawn of the third millennium. We should ban non-compliant vessels from accessing European waters, determine the liability of polluters, shipowners, and charterers in the name of the "polluter pays" principle, strengthen maritime surveillance to prevent any degassing, impose serious and reliable inspections of tankers, reinstate a substantial "natural disasters" budget line for member states, and, in the meantime, release exceptional community aid and make disaster-stricken departments eligible for Structural Funds. I have also tabled a resolution on this subject on behalf of the EDD group. Mr. President, in recent years, oil tanker disasters have regularly occurred around the world without any meaningful or effective measures being taken. This time, it is particularly serious, also because it affected a major European state, an event that could happen again at any time. To limit these dangers, we urgently need a directive. The Fifteen are clearly not enough. Without claiming to be exhaustive, this would guarantee at least three points: no cargo ship or oil tanker will be able to anchor in a European Union port if it is destined for the scrapyard; all parties involved, including the transport charterer, are liable for any damage that may occur; and these parties must take out adequate insurance. Only in this way will the victims have a chance of having their claims for compensation met. However, we must recognize that the long-term objective must go even further. This means that we really need to establish the true costs for our entire energy supply system. Mr President, let me begin by thanking Commissioner de Palacio for the appropriate, clear and firm response she has given. I thank her very, very sincerely for it. This means that I also have the greatest respect for the information note she sent us on 10 January, but also for the actions she announced today. The Erika disaster highlights the fact that when strict transport regulations are lacking at European and international level, nature and the environment always suffer. The resulting damage, particularly from an ecological point of view, cannot be expressed in monetary terms. This is also why the debate is taking place jointly with my colleagues from the transport and environment sectors. During the Christmas holidays, when the Dutch media were focusing on the Erika disaster, I took a look on the Internet to get an idea of the situation and see what measures should be taken, especially after Prime Minister Jospin said that Europe should be more active in this area.

The Commission's delays must be reflected in the proposed timetable, so the 2003 date must necessarily be revised. While defining a sector reserved for public postal operators, based on weight and price limits, the postal services directive would allow for phased and controlled liberalization. The brutal reduction of these limits calls into question the balance between public service obligations and economic viability for postal services. In a context of globalization, where the logic of profitability and profit increasingly conflicts with the interest of territorial balance and social cohesion, it is urgent to recall here our commitment to the European public service, whether it concerns the postal sector today, the railway sector tomorrow, or the health sector the day after tomorrow. Mr. President, I am taking the floor, along with other Scottish members of this House, representing Scotland, to protest against anything that leads to a decline in the quality of rural life in remote areas. The post service and post offices are an essential element of the life of rural communities throughout Europe, not to mention Scotland. It would be a disaster if, intentionally or even unwittingly, measures were taken that would harm them. I do not believe that anyone intends to do anything like that. Nor do I believe that the Commission intends to declare war on the islands of Scotland or Greece. But they could accidentally cause great harm. The question is how quickly and by what methods the gradual liberalization of postal services should be carried out. If the limit for continuing the monopoly right of the postal service were set too low, it would become uneconomical to maintain universal service in remote areas at a price that remained affordable. The crucial question is to find a balance between universality and affordability. The message being conveyed very clearly from all parts of the House to the Commission today is that it must tread carefully. It should not, for example, jump from 350 grams to, as someone has suggested, 50 grams. On the contrary, it should proceed with caution. I imagine that anything less than 150 grams would be extremely unwise in these circumstances. The solidarity and cohesion of the peoples of all Europe depend on the belief that a letter can be sent anywhere and that it will be delivered anywhere else, all with a reasonably priced stamp. Let us defend universality and affordable prices! Mr. President, to guarantee a quality universal postal service, it is essential that its public character be maintained. Universal service, which entails the provision of quality postal services at affordable prices and provided throughout the country, constitutes the basis for the entire functioning of the postal system and must provide uniform rates throughout the national territory. However, for this to be the case, it is essential that it be maintained as a public service. Only in this way is it possible to guarantee that the network, from collection to distribution, is an integral network that cannot be fragmented or used only in part according to the convenience of the postal service operators.

However, the fear that this will lead to the creation of a European institution that restricts subsidiarity is unfortunately still too great. In any case, I will contribute my part to increasing support for Mrs. Theato's report. Mr. President, we are basically in favor of the resolution submitted to us, although we believe that this can only be an invitation from Parliament to the Council to ensure, through a Treaty amendment, effective criminal protection of the Union's financial interests. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor and the establishment of common criminal categories for all Union states is undoubtedly a good idea; however, I consider it impossible to consider putting it into practice without first creating a Union judicial system. We are, in fact, talking about criminal law, an area in which national states' resistance to communitarization is and always will be strong. In fact, it is unthinkable that substantive and procedural legal rules can be established for a single area, such as the protection of financial interests, without first creating a European judicial system. One need only read the precise and exhaustive justifications of the Theato report to realize how many and what problems still remain to be solved. Nevertheless, this idea must be promoted, and there is no doubt that in this attempt to protect financial interests, we will realize the need for a Community corpus juris, which must be incorporated into the Treaties. On behalf of my group and myself, I also express the hope that the financial soul of the Union will serve as a guide in establishing a European judicial system that respects the rights and guarantees of citizens; that is, a judicial system that enhances the guarantees that, unfortunately, in many states fall far short of acceptable levels. Consequently, on behalf of my group, I express a favorable opinion of the Theato report; However, I believe that, in substance, this is an issue that should be included on the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference. Mr. President, Mrs. Theato's report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests proposes, in particular, in a first phase, centralizing criminal proceedings through the creation of a European Public Prosecutor. This proposal goes radically against the spirit of the current system, in which criminal law and criminal procedure, which constitute the core of national legal systems, must depend on the sovereignty of each people and be the exclusive competence of each State. However, the idea of a European Public Prosecutor, on the contrary, aims to relegate States over time to a subordinate role in these matters. Furthermore, this proposal would trigger a succession of completely unpredictable reforms. According to the Theato report, the European Public Prosecutor would be necessary, in particular, to better frame the investigations of the Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF. But at the same time, we learned, in the Van Hulten report being debated today, that the European prosecutor would in turn be supervised by a European Union court.

I am therefore pleased that responsibility is being attributed to individuals without the Commission shirking its responsibility. In practice, experience – only 9 files were rejected, 94% of the cases the Commission had to deal with were not resolved formally but through unpublished, legally non-binding administrative letters, or simply by the expiry of the deadline – clearly shows that in the age of globalization and EU enlargement, the Commission's work is limited by time, personnel, and financial constraints. In conclusion, I would like to say what I expect from this reform: fair competition and the same competitive conditions for all, legal certainty for all companies, uniform application of competition policy, simplification of procedures in accordance with the one-stop-shop principle, coordination of national authorities, which I believe should be independent, close cooperation between national authorities and courts and the Commission, and a clear division of powers between national authorities and courts in the application of European competition and antitrust law. I expect the Commission to focus on the essentials by fulfilling its duties as the main guardian of European competition policy. I look forward to seeing what form the wide-ranging discussions in the first legislative proposal will take. The Commission's report confirms that, with the exception of Germany, state aid to companies is increasing. This only concerns the Commission from the perspective of competitive conditions. For our part, we are taking the view that the interests of the working classes are in the best interests of the people. Society gains nothing from these enormous transfers of public funds to private companies. Look at the automobile industry, where subsidies and various forms of state aid increased by 24% during the reference period. To what end? It's not to preserve jobs. All these companies have cut jobs, even layoffs. It's not to improve working conditions, because by producing more with fewer workers, working conditions worsen. Did these companies need state aid to survive? No, automobile companies have been raking in colossal profits for years. State aid is not only perverse because, as the Jonckheer report recognizes, it leads to a hunt for subsidies through offshoring from one country to another; it is unacceptable because it devotes public money to enriching a handful of private shareholders. It is because everywhere the richest are being favoured with state money that social protection is being reduced, public services are being abandoned, and hospitals are being closed throughout Europe. The purpose of my vote against the Jonckheer report is to affirm the need for a different policy, that is, the cessation of all aid to private companies and the use of the money thus saved to develop public services and hire staff for them. Mr President, the debate we are holding today is of extraordinary importance because the principle of competition has probably been the cornerstone of the internal market. In application of the principle of competition, the regulation developed Articles 85 to 94, competition policy itself, the review of all state aid and tax provisions likely to distort competition.

In the next IGC resolution, Parliament will have to deal in depth with the issues of diversification and flexibility. If we fail to create the system of concentric layers proposed by the Liberal Group, we will jeopardise the process of enlargement and integration. My colleagues, Mrs Frassoni and Mr Onesta, have already expressed a rather sceptical opinion on some aspects of the issue we are dealing with; I would like to express my concern about subsidiarity, not so much with regard to relations between the Union and the Member States, but rather with regard to relations between individual Member States and the regions which, within them, enjoy administrative autonomy. This is a subject which has not been sufficiently reflected upon and which is a source of concern from many points of view. I would like to highlight in particular one of the consequences that enlargement will have on this Parliament. A ceiling of 700 Members has been set, which represents the maximum number of Members with which Parliament can continue to function as a deliberative assembly. By applying the principle of digressive proportionality (six seats for each state and then one more seat for every half a million inhabitants), we already have a situation whereby Luxembourg, with 367,000 inhabitants, sends more MEPs to this Parliament than Wales, a region which, within the United Kingdom, enjoys partial administrative autonomy; Scotland, with 5 million inhabitants, currently has eight MEPs, while Denmark and Finland, with the same population, have 16. What will happen now if we maintain the ceiling of 700 members, gradually increase the population of the European Union by 26 percent and then adopt the Commission's (in my opinion unfortunate) proposal to draw up a list of candidates on a European basis? What will happen to a country like Scotland, which I represent here? It will become completely invisible! In these circumstances, Members of this House should not be surprised if, in discussing these issues, public opinion in Scotland and other countries in the same situation is beginning to ask whether enlargement should not take the form of the admission of new Member States from among the existing Member States. There is a growing body of opinion in Scotland that is moving in that direction. Mr President, it has often been said that the European Union is at a crossroads. This time it is the truth: we have launched - very successfully - the single currency and enlargement awaits us. We are wondering whether we are heading towards enlargement prepared or not. Will it be superficial enlargement or in depth? That is the crux of the debate when it comes to the Intergovernmental Conference, the agenda and the method. The Council has clearly chosen, for the time being, to enlarge without deepening. That is a danger to enlargement; a danger to any prospect of political union. The public will have difficulty understanding. The Council must realise that if the future of the Union is to be built on the foundations of a solid enlargement, it must go much further in the next Intergovernmental Conference.

The crisis of the Commission was, in fact, a crucial point in the relationship between Europe and its citizens, and the low turnout in the European elections was a worrying sign of this. Even deeper, however, is the sense of insecurity, the feeling of unpreparedness in the face of a new world that is advancing, a world that is changing completely, which through globalization ends up changing even our points of reference. This is not a completely new fact in history: Europe has already found itself faced with a similar change on another occasion, an explosion of its markets, a change in the parameters of reference, a different perception of the world. I am referring to the sixteenth century, after the discovery of America, when everything changed. Some countries - like France and Spain - were able to respond to the challenge by creating large national states; other countries - like Italy - were unable to cope with this challenge and lost all the records that they had accumulated in the first part of the millennium: records of science, technology, economic progress, defense structures and military organization, thought and literature. Today Europe is facing a similar challenge, and we know that, just as History has not forgiven in the past, it does not forgive today. In this perspective of great changes, to prevent our nation states from disappearing in the face of globalization, which poses unprecedented dimensions and challenges in our history, an economically strong Europe is necessary, because globalization requires unity, because every day we hear news of new agreements at a global level and every day we hear news of changes at a European level too. But even more necessary is a Europe that feels strong in the political field. In past years, the single market and the single currency have been the fulcrum of our action, the cornerstone of European life. Today, the new frontiers of European integration are political frontiers: common foreign and security policy, justice and internal security and - in a secondary order - the crucial question of the fundamental political values on which our coexistence is based. For this reason, the Commission has approved the strategic plan 2000-2005, a plan that was immediately sent to the European Parliament, which you already know and which, therefore, I will not go into in detail in this speech. Some may perhaps consider it too synthetic, but no political structure produces detailed five-year plans. This is the European Union, not the Soviet Union. Our plan identifies the major points of reference, the major directions of intervention: first, the development of new forms of government for Europe; second, the expansion and enlargement of the area of peace, freedom and security; third, the launching of a new phase of economic development; fourth, the protection and improvement of the quality of life. These are our major guidelines for action for the next five years. As regards the first - new forms of government for Europe - you already know that the Commission has committed to presenting a White Paper, and not a complete legislative text because, faced with the major problems that structurally change our way of being together, the Commission first prepares the debate; then it discusses its content with you; from here then a political document is born, and finally a legislative document.

It will then eventually be necessary, as I have emphasized, to change the paradigm and forget the post-colonial paradigm in order to give a more European dimension to development policies. From this point of view, I believe (like some speakers) that the new convention intended to replace the Lomé Conventions constitutes an important instrument of renewal and new dynamics in the approach to a partnership with such a large group of countries of the South, at a time when there is stability around negotiation processes at the international level, such as those that characterized the first round of the Seattle negotiations. I sense a certain degree of frustration in many contributions to this debate. I have made a statement to you on behalf of the Commission which, I believe, provides a useful framework for this discussion. We will provide more detailed information directly related to all the issues of coherence. This debate is not new. We are currently working on it within the Commission and, once the work is completed, I will present a report on the matter, since many have asked if it would be possible to see the report on coherence. I have no doubt that, because of the growing political attention being paid to these problems - which has clearly emerged from today's debate - it will be easier for the Commission and DG Development to put the issue of coherence at the top of our agenda. This also requires the introduction of additional new mechanisms within the Commission system, which may well include, as some political groups in this Parliament have suggested, the establishment of a special inter-service working group and some form of coherence monitoring within the Commission. I have read - and heard in the debate - that coherence is being used as a kind of magic bullet that fixes everything. I think it is important to leave it as a relatively well-defined discipline aimed at trying to reduce inconsistencies where they really do exist, and they most certainly do. Much of this has to do with a real disagreement between sectoral interests in each Member State, as has been said with great honesty in this House. People identify in a certain way with their spheres of interest, which is legitimate. I would, however, caution against the illusion that the inconsistency results from some mechanical deficiency in the system. This happens but represents only a small part of what we are discussing. Most of the debate relates to the well-known differences in interests established between genders and so on, and that is the problem. Mr. Mulder said that no farmer will start producing anything if the price is too low. This is true in our part of the world, but our partners and beneficiaries in Africa have a slightly different perspective. They are farmers, not only to earn a living, but also to live; that makes a difference.

English: We have recently had occasion to use the precautionary principle to ban phthalates in soft PVC toys and of course we apply it in many environmental areas. It is mostly used when environmental problems are involved, but of course also when human health is involved. We will therefore try to define very clearly the cases in which this principle should be applied. Mr President, Commissioner, with regard to the relationship between science on the one hand and the use of the precautionary principle on the other, the communication states that the use of this principle always requires a political decision in the absence of scientific evidence. This statement gives great power to science. We can ask ourselves who the experts are who will provide the required documentation and what position they will defend. The communication also states that a sufficient and recognised minority of scientific experts can also invoke the precautionary principle. I would like to know what the definition of a recognised minority is. How can this concept be described? How is a recognised minority created? If it is a political decision, I would like to know who will take it. The Commission? The Council? What role will be assigned to the European Parliament? What is the role of the scientific committees? What is the role of the food authorities that will be appointed shortly? Finally, will the decision-making process be transparent and public? These are the three questions I would like to ask. That is true, Mr President, the problems have been many, complex and sometimes obscure, but I will try to answer them anyway. Who will decide and who are the decision-makers? It depends on who is in the role of legislator; it is part of risk management. For example, it will be necessary to take into account public concern about a specific problem and judge on the basis of the scientific evidence available for a given case. It is true, however, that a strong majority of the scientific community is not necessary to resort to the precautionary principle; it is sufficient for there to be evidence put forward by a minority, or for science to be unable to give precise answers. In this way, a balance is maintained between the use of this principle as a political tool and science. It is not always easy to describe precisely how this process unfolds, but it is not a question of changing the scientific method. We use experts to acquire as much information and scientific facts as possible before making a decision, and I think that it will be good to behave in this way in the future too. This method should be seen as a tool for managing risks: we have to decide, for example, whether we should allow the population to be exposed to some risk, or whether we want to protect the environment. It is therefore necessary to take into account the available scientific data. We have to evaluate all these factors and evaluate what science tells us, and then decide whether or not to adopt a measure, whether or not to act. So there is no answer to all the questions, but this does not change the scientific system we have today, nor the way in which we use experts today.

Amendment No 18 refers to Directive 96/71 on minimum wages, which already applies and therefore does not require any changes to the text. If the Commission were to accept Amendment No 17, this would mean introducing a simple obligation to notify in the event of failure to issue a valid card. It is clear that this provision is contrary to the public order interests of the Member States. Nor can we accept Amendment No 19 for the reasons I have already raised in relation to Amendment No 10. The Commission's position is essentially the same in relation to similar amendments tabled for the second proposal. Let me also add that Amendment No 10 to the second proposal is completely unacceptable. As regards Amendment No 15 on the definition of self-employed workers, as I have just said, the Commission will seek an appropriate solution which takes account of the objections raised. I now come to Lord Inglewood's observation. He referred to the existing border controls for the United Kingdom. In this connection I would like to point out that there is no obligation for a Member State - and therefore also the United Kingdom - to abolish or change the border controls that still exist. This applies, as I said, to the United Kingdom, but it also applies to Belgium, where the problem has recently arisen. As regards Mr Karas's comments, I have the impression that he was referring to the possibility of workers from Poland being employed in his country. The Commission would like to propose a solution that applies to all companies established in the European Union that employ workers from third countries. The question is whether the two cases should be addressed simultaneously. In my view, this issue is part of the debate on the enlargement of the European Union and perhaps should not be addressed here. On behalf of the Commission, I would like to confirm to Mr Karas that I am at his complete disposal should he require further information on this very important point. Finally, I would like to thank Parliament for the very constructive debate on the most important aspects of these proposals and, of course, to express my gratitude to the rapporteur, Mrs Berger. Thank you very much, Commissioner Bolkestein. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11 a.m. Court of First Instance Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his report which, at first reading, gives the impression of merely confirming and accepting. Behind this report, however, lies a long and effective effort which has already borne some fruit; in fact, the Finnish Presidency document of 7 December 1999 included a commitment to broaden the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference to include the study of a future change in the organisation, composition and powers of the Community courts. I therefore express my recognition of the work of Vice-President Marinho. Mr President, the reform of the Community judicial system has become an urgent necessity if in future we wish to do justice within reasonable time limits, if in future the European Union wishes to equip itself with a justice system worthy of the political project already underway.

Mr President, the Commission's proposal for the further controlled and gradual opening of the postal market to competition is delayed mainly because of the reorganisation of services and the reallocation of powers of the Commission, as well as the need for the new College to re-examine these issues. As regards the various resolutions of Parliament concerning the postal sector, my colleague, Commissioner Bolkestein, has already responded to the main comments during the hearings which were organised by Parliament last year. Furthermore, as regards the consultation of Parliament, Commissioner Bolkestein will meet Parliament's Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism next Monday. The studies were sent to that Committee in September 1999, as well as to the Members who requested them, and are still available. These studies can also be consulted on the Commission's Internet site. I am sure that Commissioner Bolkestein will pay due attention to all Parliament's comments. The Commission, Mr President, is firmly convinced of the need for a new proposal for the further development and evolution of the postal sector. Moreover, the submission of a proposal is a legal obligation. I can confirm that it is Commissioner Bolkestein's firm intention to submit such a proposal to the Commission, for transmission to Parliament and the Council, within the first half of the year. The date set for the implementation of the next phase, 1 January 2003, remains the Commission's ambition. The proposal will take into account the studies carried out, and in particular the need to ensure universality of service, the development of effective consumer safeguards, the creation of a climate favourable to new jobs and the resolution of competition problems. The role of market opening, with a view to further modernising and improving postal services throughout the Union with new technologies, will also be examined in view of the potential benefits for the industry as a whole. The proposal, when it is presented, will take into account the views expressed by Member States, Parliament, users, universal service providers, their competitors and other interested parties, with whom thorough consultations have been carried out. The aim is to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for postal services in the interests of consumers and businesses throughout the Union. Mr Markov, you will be given the opportunity to speak in 5-6 minutes, but in the meantime please do not interrupt my fellow Members. Mr President, there is a mystery here. What happened to the Postal Services Directive that was adopted on 15 December 1997? Since then there has been a heavy silence from the Commission. I regret that it is Commissioner Monti who has to answer. I respect him very much and I believe that he is one of the most diligent and active Commissioners. Unfortunately, I cannot say the same for some of his colleagues. During this period, no progress has been made on the Postal Services Directive. Commissioner Monti said that this was partly due to organizational reasons and the reallocation of responsibilities.

This second option has prevailed, and I welcome it, but I hope that, in the future, coordination between the two institutions and the Council will be closer so that our work is more understandable, more fruitful, and more productive. Mr. President, our objective in establishing a framework for investment funds and other UCITS is to ensure maximum benefits for our investors' savings without subjecting them to great risks, which is why I wish to address the issue of derivatives in my remarks today. I firmly believe that the prudent use of derivatives can contribute to consolidating safer and higher returns. Despite their reputation for danger, derivatives are generally used by asset managers as a precaution. A contract that, for example, pays a substantial sum if, say, the NASDAQ or CAC 40 index falls, triggers an additional payment by the investor if the NASDAQ or CAC 40 index rises. Is that speculation? Not at all. Let's imagine we've spent several months building a portfolio of companies we feel confident about: well-managed, with good prospects, and a good investment. Then we worry that the entire stock market might crash, as it did in 1987. In that case, we have the option to sell everything and cash in, but that would mean losing all the research we've done on the winners. It would also mean incurring all the transaction costs involved in selling our holdings and then buying them back after the crash. The solution is to take out a derivative that compensates us if the NASDAQ or CAC 40 falls. But even with tailored derivatives or cheaper OTC derivatives that could insure against a relative decline in our portfolio relative to the index, we would still own the portfolio and the holdings, but we would have protected ourselves against the dangers of a sharp decline. In return, we may have gotten rid of some of the market's strongest stocks. In that case, which may be the most widespread use of derivatives by asset managers, we reduce our potential reward, but we also reduce our risk factor. This is a desirable development in a well-managed fund. History shows that investors benefit from a liberal, lean approach. An authoritarian system—a prescription of how private sector managers should invest and where they should invest—will only reduce returns for investors. Pension funds that are subject to regulations on where they can and cannot invest, as required for our government bonds, earn returns of 5.2% per year, barely half the 9.5% annual returns that free funds earned between 1984 and 1996. We are talking, of course, about returns after all losses have been deducted. Let us not confuse genuine concern for investors' interests with a populist fear of a new, innovative, liberal approach that is worthwhile. That is what we should be dealing with here today. Mr. President, the report presented to us today seeks to end the free movement of financial investments in Europe, even in its most sophisticated forms.

What can the European Union do in a context which, without interfering in matters which are the exclusive competence of the Cypriots, can promote the search for a just and lasting solution to this dramatic problem which affects a country which has been linked to the European Community for almost 30 years and which will be called upon to join the European Union in the coming years? I have heard, particularly from the Council, proposals or silences which are a little ambiguous, which in my opinion must be clearly clarified. I think that it is up to us first of all to recall the main reference on this matter for the entire international community, namely the resolutions of the United Nations. According to the Security Council, the solution to the Cyprus problem must be sought within the framework of a bi-zonal, bi-communal federation, in other words a single State - Commissioner Verheugen alluded to this - which includes two local administrations mandated by the two communities. Sovereignty, international personality and citizenship must be single and this State must be demilitarised. In this way, the international community clearly indicates that it rejects a fait accompli by force. Secondly, I think the European Union benefits from reducing as much as possible the margin for interpretation of the position defined by the Helsinki European Council. The solution to the Cyprus problem cannot be a precondition for Cyprus's accession to the Union, as Mr Poos pointed out, otherwise we would in fact end up giving Turkey a sort of veto right over Cyprus's accession to the European Union, which is unacceptable. Thirdly, finally, the position of the Helsinki European Council cannot lead to a reduction in our efforts to resolve the Cyprus problem before that country joins the Union. From this point of view, the other decision of Helsinki, namely the recognition of Turkey's candidacy for the Union, gives the Fifteen a new responsibility while at the same time offering the Union new opportunities. In my opinion, the dialogue with Ankara can and must integrate the determined will to obtain from Turkey the expression of a constructive attitude towards the dialogue between the two Cypriot communities, respectful of international law and which will allow the reunification of Cyprus and peace in the Eastern Mediterranean. Mr President, while we are practically all in agreement on the importance of financial support for Cyprus and Malta, the same cannot be said with regard to the budget heading from which the necessary funds should be drawn. The Council and the Commission propose to include the protocols in heading 4, a proposal which is in line with the budget decisions adopted by Parliament last December; the rapporteur returns to his position and now proposes to include financial support for Cyprus and Malta in heading 7. For its part, the Committee on Budgets even proposes to postpone the approval of the Brok report until the Council decides to raise the ceiling of heading 7, but this is an extremely risky strategy because, without a prior vote by Parliament, the financial protocols cannot be activated. Cyprus and Malta are therefore paying the price of a political game played by the Council and Parliament on the ceilings. Besides, what is the point of establishing ceilings if, with each new action, they are continually raised?

The Presidency takes note of your concerns and will pass them on through the appropriate channels. Intercommunal violence in Mitrovica and the situation of Albanian prisoners in Serbia, in particular the case of Flora Brovina). (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have not signed this compromise resolution for two reasons.
