Firstly, one of our colleagues, who is known for his open and tolerant attitude, Mr Sakellariou - I shall not name him - vehemently vetoed it because he wanted to defend your moral values. I have no doubt, and I am sure you will have no doubt either, that this is yet another important contribution he is making to the fight against racism and intolerance. Secondly, this resolution is unfortunately not very far-reaching. A number of tricks have carefully avoided addressing the central issue, namely the final status of Kosovo. None of you would assume that Kosovo could one day still be part of Yugoslavia. Likewise, none of you would assume that Milosevic could hold on for long if the international community were to finally find a solution to the question of Kosovo's final status. Finally, none of you would believe that, in the current situation, Milosevic has no interest in doing everything in his power to destabilize Kosovo, which he is doing and which we have already seen. Ultimately, in my opinion, none of you can believe that the current status quo contributes even the slightest to the stability and thus to the development of Kosovo. Incidentally, it is interesting to read a slip-up in the compromise proposal that undoubtedly escaped you. In it, you condemn the first direct attack on KFOR members. While I don't want you to be a prophet of doom, I fear that you will ultimately be one if you don't address the real problem, and I hold you fully responsible for what may happen. Rather, I believe that we must call on the Commission and the Council, which is unfortunately absent today, to raise firmly at the United Nations the question of Kosovo's final status, the growing number of small states in the region, the post-Dayton developments, and, finally, the question of genuine stability, which will finally make it possible to build democracy in these countries and to develop a Community policy in the region. Finally, I would like to point out that since July we have been calling for decisive action by the Council and the Commission to release the 3 000 Kosovo Albanian prisoners, as well as Mrs Brovina, Mr Kurti, and Mr Hoti. I note that the Union is moving towards a certain easing of sanctions, without, as yet, a single one of these prisoners being released in return. Why? Mr President, what is happening in Mitrovica, Kosovo, is horrific and reprehensible. Violence breeds violence, revenge breeds revenge. The police forces deployed are not strong enough to put an end to what is happening. Chief Police Commissioner Svend Frederiksen has expressed his despair at being able to permanently only have half of the agreed forces at his disposal.

I have been informed that ISA is not pathological in humans or mammals. The disease has existed since 1984 and has not been reported to affect human or mammalian health. The virus harms cold-blooded animals. It does not reproduce at temperatures above 25°C, and if present in fish intended for human consumption, it would be inactive upon ingestion. However, under no circumstances should infected fish be used for human consumption. As an added precaution, I have consulted the Scientific Committee on this matter. During the debate, several important issues, including compensation, related to our disease control strategy were raised. I deeply regret the losses suffered by the Scottish salmon industry. You may be aware that, with effect from 15 January 2000, under the new financial instrument for fisheries guidance, Member States will support disease eradication in aquaculture. The Commission services are drafting implementing rules to ensure the practical application of this instrument. Council Decision 90/424 constitutes another instrument of Community financial support in the event of disease outbreaks. However, I must emphasize that there are significant impediments. Budgetary resources are very limited, and priorities must be established with other diseases. Therefore, further reflection is needed. I regret, therefore, that I am not currently in a position to accept amendments relating to compensation through Decision 90/424. This is particularly the case with Amendments 3 and 5. However, I agree with the statement in Amendment 2 that no compensation has been paid to salmon farmers. I am not in a position to comment on the availability of commercial insurance. The Commission has included in its proposal the possibility of vaccinating salmon. The objective of this proposal is to introduce an instrument to combat the disease in emergency situations. I believe that a vaccine should not be used for preventive purposes, as Amendment 4 suggests. Experience in other sectors has shown that preventive vaccination has the perverse effect of creating healthy carriers of the virus. This could perpetuate an infection. I therefore cannot accept Amendment 4. You have also referred to the need for further scientific research into the nature of the disease. I agree that this research is necessary and understand that it is currently being organized in the United Kingdom. I will closely monitor the results of this research and take it fully into account in future legislative proposals. It is necessary to examine whether it is appropriate and how research should be organized elsewhere in the Community. In this context, I am happy to partially accept Amendment 1, bearing in mind, however, that scientific research is not carried out by the Commission, although it relies on the results of research carried out in the Member States. I can also partially accept the passage of Amendment 6 that states that Directive 93/53 should be amended as a result of scientific and technical evidence. As I have highlighted previously, the available scientific evidence indicates that AIS does not pose a threat to health.

The question of whether to extend the agenda still needs to be discussed. In this regard, I would like to commend the political attitude of the Portuguese Presidency, which has repeatedly pledged to Parliament to make the necessary efforts in this direction. Moreover, any extension of the agenda must not undermine the importance that each Member State must attach to the IGC, since the institutional framework on which the Europe of the future will be based is the foundation of European integration and is therefore a matter of the utmost importance for each country of the Union. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the light of this, I ask the House to approve the opinion presented by Mr Leinen and myself, so that the work of the IGC can begin on 14 February, where our representatives, Mr Brok and Mr Tsatsos, will face a difficult task on the basis of Parliament's assent. This also applies to the Commission and I would like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Barnier again for his contacts with Parliament and for his very constructive proposals. Mr President, the Group of the European People's Party is not satisfied with the outcome of the Helsinki European Council. The agenda seemed to us to be limited because we would have liked to focus on the Treaty, with particular attention to the Protocol on the institutions of the Union. In Helsinki, the governments agreed that as long as the Union has fewer than 21 Member States, a minimal reform will suffice; in reality, a profound reform is needed. The Helsinki European Council itself approved enlargement to include thirteen new Member States. There is clearly a contradiction between the opening of accession negotiations and the desire for a minimal reform. Our attention is instead on the Treaty and we want the agenda of the next Intergovernmental Conference to enable us to achieve a more profound reform of the Union. Mr President, this debate is taking place today because we did not want to postpone the start of the Conference. We could have done so; we could have voted on the 17th of this month and the Conference would not have been able to start on the 14th. However, we did not do so because we wish to send a clear political signal to the governments and countries applying for accession that we wish to proceed with this reform precisely in order to facilitate enlargement. I am pleased to be able to say this to the Portuguese Presidency, which has acquired great credit in the eyes of this House. The Portuguese Presidency shares many of the aspirations of this Parliament and has undertaken to do everything possible to ensure that the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference is filled with other absolutely necessary subjects. This aspiration of the European Parliament, Mr President, is not a self-interested aspiration. The European Parliament will nevertheless emerge politically strengthened by the Treaty resulting from this Intergovernmental Conference, for one simple reason: the Conference, as agreed in Helsinki, will examine which subjects will be moved from the current unanimous decision-making to qualified majority decision-making. The number of subjects on which decisions will be taken by qualified majority is therefore set to increase. It is now part of the Community heritage that in legislative matters for which decisions are made by qualified majority there is also the co-decision of Parliament.

This cannot continue. In a crisis, it must be clear from the outset that the polluter is liable. Mr. President, that was a very good White Paper, and I didn't say a word about the authority. My questions concern the positive list for animal feed. You are unclear on this in your White Paper. What is your timetable? How quickly will you come up with a positive list? When will the same requirements be placed on animal feed and production as on the production and control of food production? The last part of my question: When will BSE testing be mandatory in all member states? Here, too, you remained somewhat unclear in your White Paper regarding the obligation. I would like to thank the Commissioner for his comments. I believe the criteria set for the Food Authority are a concession to reality. Member States would not accept an authority endowed with regulatory powers, so such a proposal would make little sense. Some areas of the food industry clearly need better regulation, and this applies particularly to animal feed. As chair of a committee that will probably spend almost the next three years dealing with food, I must ask the following question: if, as you have said, Europe has the safest food control system, why do we need 24 new directives and regulations, and 20 new directives amending directives? Secondly, will this not exacerbate the problem of over-regulation by Brussels and poor implementation by Member States? On enlargement, what are the Commission's plans to involve the candidate countries in the debate on these new laws, particularly since the Commission clearly expects the laws envisaged in the White Paper to be part of the acquis communautaire by 2003? Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Mrs Ahern, Mrs Roth-Behrendt, and Mrs Jackson for their support for the White Paper. I find this encouraging, and I look forward to further discussions with them and other Members of Parliament on the issues it raises. Mrs Ahern asked about liability. This issue is not explicitly addressed in the White Paper. It merely mentions that we will establish regulations regarding traceability. Some of these already exist. After that, we can address the issue of liability. Despite my own background, I have not yet dealt in depth with liability issues, but I believe that subsidiarity may play a role here. But I have noted your suggestion and will reexamine this question. Ms. Roth-Behrendt asked about the positive list. We will address this issue in the annex to the legislation. The intention is to establish a positive list for animal feed. At present, there is a negative list, so to speak, which will be supplemented as needed. The establishment of the positive list is one of the measures for which a deadline is given in the annex: that will be 2002. The rapid alert system for animal feed is one of the points that we consider to be a weak point in food law. There is a rapid alert system for food, but not for animal feed. That is a shame, and it is wrong. Regulations must be put in place to close this gap, and this will happen.

In other words: a decisive leap in development policy is needed if we do not want the rich countries, including the member countries of the European Union, to build bulwarks around themselves to prevent massive immigration. In the global village, the great differences in the world will no longer be tolerated by its poorest part. At a certain point there will be a revolt and it will be absolutely justified. I therefore call on the Presidency of the Council to start the announced debate as soon as possible and above all to conclude it, so that we all, including European citizens, can realise the implications of globalisation, and so that we understand that a central element will be the radical changes in the field of development; as regards our development aid and its level, we are far from the 0.7% on average in the European Union that was promised. It is possible that others will do worse than us, but that certainly does not help us. But above all we must give countries the opportunity to trade with us. As far as I have heard - but I may have missed something - the word trade was not even mentioned in the Prime Minister's speech. I would simply like to say to the Commissioner that I hope that his proposal will be passed on to the Commission and the Member States, and I would also like to ask the Commissioner to give some concrete examples of sectoral interests that are blocking factors, not only in the Commission, but also in the Member States. I would also like to say that in my opinion the most effective thing would be for Parliament to ask for a proposal from the Development Council and the Commissioner for Development respectively; then we would perhaps have a starting point for discussion, instead of asking for a proposal from all the governments and the whole Commission, because it would be difficult to get anything good out of that. I will conclude with a few words on the Internet revolution. As Commissioner Liikanen is saying, we have a certain advantage in Europe in the mobile telephony sector. Let us use it, not only for the benefit of our own people, but also for the benefit of developing countries. This technique allows precisely the decisive leap that is needed, and in this case, the European Union can set the agenda, influence development and live up to its global responsibility. Mr President, to quote the headline of a newspaper article that appeared last week on the subject of the Union's development policy, I will say that 'The European Union's development cooperation is in a miserable state'. There is nothing new in this statement. Ever since we in Europe have been trying to advance development cooperation, the effectiveness and quality of our efforts have been called into question. There is a danger of widespread distrust about the possibilities for improvement, given that the Commission continues to refuse to look at itself in the mirror. Why has the critical report on the coherence of development policy not been made public? An important conclusion of that report concerned the internal contradictions of European policy.

But I also believe that in the future it will be necessary to create a suitably attractive universal service. We must define it precisely, provide it with a catalogue of services, and put it out to public tender. In the interior of the country, where we reasonably suspect that the service will not be profitable enough to cover costs, in my opinion, services should be established through regulations that guarantee fair and appropriate bidding conditions, so that all market forces, and also, naturally, the existing postal service, can compete, following the strategy of offering users a varied range of quality services. I believe we should prevent further subsidies and, instead, concentrate on ensuring that both private providers and users benefit from the new system. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, postal services, like all European public services, contribute to the social cohesion of the Community territory, in accordance with the terms of Article 16 of the Amsterdam Treaty. By ensuring a fair distribution of fares, that is, strict equality between citizens and economic actors in the cost of the service, by assuming universal service obligations and adapting to service quality requirements, postal services are part of our concern to promote equality between territories and the people who live in them. Postal services also constitute a powerful, and by no means negligible, element of civic ties. Indeed, as has been pointed out many times in this Assembly, is not the postal worker the last point of contact in the so-called "desert" or "fractured" territorial areas, whether these are isolated geographical areas or sensitive outskirts of our cities? I will cite as an example the initiative of the French postal service administration, which is preparing to guarantee, among other services, the presence of interpreters and notaries public in post offices in sensitive urban areas. Not to mention the jobs this represents, European public postal service administrations currently employ 1.5 million employees, who could clearly be threatened by the specter of brutal and uncontrolled liberalization. The European Parliament has committed itself to reconciling openness to competition with a universal service obligation that respects employment. We can welcome this, but we will ensure that this path continues, and for this reason we cannot but deplore the fact that the European Parliament is currently kept out of the decision-making process that governs the future of the postal sector in Europe. It is indeed regrettable that until now—as this resolution underlines—the Commission has not taken into account the resolution of 14 January 1999. This resolution, as we must recall, required that the European Parliament be involved in the development of the planned measures and that the reliability of the studies on the effects of liberalization be strengthened. These studies on the effects are necessary to assess the consequences that any brutal liberalization would have not only for the economic organization of the market, but also for its human and social dimension.

We therefore agree with the report, just as we agree, Commissioner, with the basic principles of the White Paper. Since the Treaty came into force, Community competition law has been one of the fundamental chapters of Community policy. Now, some forty years after they came into force, those provisions have begun to show signs of weakness. It was therefore urgently necessary to proceed with modernisation, and this particularly in five areas. Firstly, the system for issuing authorisations; secondly, decentralisation in the application of the provisions; thirdly, procedural rules; fourthly, the application of those provisions in court; and fifthly and finally, excessive formalism. The system for issuing individual authorisations needed urgent reform, as requested in unison by businesses, experts in the field and specialist lawyers. I have never attended a meeting of competition law specialists where a change in the system was not requested. A system which offers so few decisions, whether authorising or prohibiting, as the one currently in force can be considered anything but a good system. For some time now, national competition authorities have had the power to apply Articles 81(1) and 82. However, they have not had the power to apply Article 81(3), which has to some extent prevented the consistent application of Article 81(1). At present, as the Honourable Members are aware, two preliminary questions are pending before the Court of Justice, submitted by two German courts, in which the national judge is wondering whether it is possible to apply Article 81(1) without being able to use Article 81(3). A reform of this aspect was therefore necessary. The procedure to be followed in competition matters is essentially contained in Regulation No 1762. The voices of those who called for its amendment were unanimous. This unanimity in requesting its reform was motivated by the fact that the regulation did not define a proper procedure, that it did not establish time limits, that it did not regulate access to documents by interested parties and that it did not adequately recognise the rights of defence. The Court of Justice has recognised for some time that Community competition law could be applied by national judges, and the Commission published a communication on the matter as early as 1994. It was therefore necessary to facilitate the practicability of this route. One of the most frequent criticisms of Community competition law concerns its excessive formalism. As a result of the continental legal tradition, the definition of a given agreement as being anti-competitive or not depends more on the analysis of its clauses than on its effects on the market. It was therefore necessary to introduce the concept of economic analysis. The White Paper aims to resolve all these problems and, therefore, we support its proposals. It is also true that we have not overlooked some shortcomings, which the report focuses on. Firstly, the fact that, while addressing the issue of modernising Articles 81 and 82, importance has been given only to Article 81, and not to Article 82. In the current phase, in which the processes of concentration of companies or privatisation of monopolies have left dominant positions intact, when they have not even strengthened them, prosecuting abuses of dominant positions becomes particularly important. Secondly, Regulation No. 1762 must be repealed and replaced by a new regulation. In these terms, we intend to support the report.

It is the Commission that is responsible for technical security against counterfeiting. As has already been pointed out, in the summer of 1998 the Commission presented a communication listing all the areas where measures are required, namely the area of information, the area of continuing education – an important point – the area of cooperation between the eurozone states and, of course, cooperation beyond this simple framework and in the area of criminal measures. This is what the framework decision before you is about. Madam Rapporteur, I would like to thank you most sincerely on behalf of the Commission and, above all, I also thank Parliament for being able to draw up an opinion in such a short time. I attach great importance to this. The framework decision refers to ensuring that the Member States use the definition of the offences of counterfeiting. Having the same definitions is obviously the essential condition for reacting in the same way everywhere, because, as has already been pointed out, the main aim is to ensure that the euro is protected even before it is physically put into circulation. Of course, the Commission is also grateful to Parliament for taking its decision quickly - I hope that the text will be adopted just as quickly - which now allows the framework decision to enter into force as quickly as possible. This means that implementing measures can now be initiated. The Commission is now asked to submit, during the first half of next year, a report on the implementation of the framework decision in the Member States, so as to determine whether the importance of the issue is reflected in appropriate action. It has been pointed out that this framework decision falls precisely under criminal law. This innovation, this step forward, should therefore be acknowledged, even though Mr Schulz pointed out that, by supplementing this rather old convention, the step forward in question is rather timid. In response to the question of whether the Commission considers the Framework Decision to have a sufficiently solid legal basis in accordance with the Treaty, the Commission considers that the legal basis applied is correct. However, the Framework Decision will subsequently have to be supplemented by other legal acts. The Commission will propose a regulation on cooperation between all competent authorities and on cooperation with Europol. This proposal must provide for a duty of cooperation and must also oblige national authorities to report cases of counterfeiting to Europol and to submit seized counterfeit currency to the ECB for identification and classification, which will enable effective action to be taken in this area. As for the question of coordinating the various measures, since 1998 the Commission - and subsequently OLAF - has been working with experts from the Member States, the ECB and Europol to be able to combat euro counterfeiting effectively in advance. For its part, the Commission has already presented - as Mr Karas pointed out - a proposal for an information campaign on the euro, the proposed budget of which is 32 million euros. This is an amount that can be spent wisely, a substantial amount. This campaign will, of course, focus primarily on the security of the euro against counterfeiting.

Therefore, any proposal suggesting a major reform of the competition policy enforcement system must be carefully considered. The truth is that the single market is not yet complete. During my six months as a Member of this Parliament, I have become fully aware of the determination of many Members to promote what is called the European project. We hear daily about the need to promote a broader and deeper Europe. However, in reality, all of this is rhetoric in view of the national, regional, and local obstacles that continue to hamper the functioning of a genuine European single market. It is in this context that I wish to assess the Commission's proposals. I would like to make it clear that we have the utmost confidence in Commissioner Monti and that we respect him deeply. We consider him the right man to dismantle the cartels. However, he must recognize, like everyone else, that his particular proposals need to be assessed and subjected to rigorous scrutiny, a job that has been done by our rapporteur from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Mr. von Wogau. I would like to congratulate him, unfortunately in his absence, on the exhaustive and thorough manner in which he has undertaken the preparation of his report—and also for putting up with me, a constant source of irritation! He mentioned earlier the fact that the report was adopted by a large majority but without my support. Although I do not share his conclusions, I believe that he has illustrated, in his report, many of the issues that the Commission needs to address. First, the possibility of renationalizing competition policy. I know that the Commission is not in favor of this, but the possibility exists. I remain concerned about the capacity of the national courts and competition authorities. I remain concerned about the whole operation concerning the judicial process. I asked Commissioner Monti a few days ago what would happen if he were wrong and renationalization actually took place. Mr. von Wogau said that we can turn to the European Court. Well, in Britain, that is what we are doing at the moment. We see that the European Court is unable to issue interim measures in relation to a certain dispute we are currently having with France, for which we have the support of the European Commission. Unless one considers this to be a purely nationalist argument, the European Court took 10 years to deliver a judgment in the Factortame case, in which the British government was the defendant. So, from a judicial point of view, action should be taken. I ask the Commission what can be done to speed up implementation in this particular area. As for legal certainty, I agree with the argument put forward by Mrs. Thyssen. It is important that companies enjoy legal certainty. I said this again to Mr. Monti recently. He said that we should not always be dragged along by lawyers.

Finally, it should be remembered that the real solution to the problems of comitology for the European Parliament lies, in any case and in principle, in amending the procedure laid down in the Treaty for implementing the rules and in the gradual abolition of committees, whose existence is an anomaly that severely limits the Commission's executive powers and risks undermining the European Parliament's legislative powers. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, comitology is a term that most people are unfamiliar with, and very few know what it means. It evokes images of secret societies and conspiracies, and so it was in the past too. What it really means is that it defines the procedures for exercising the executive powers conferred on the Commission. These executive powers consist of a limited number of committee procedures. Until the Treaty of Amsterdam, there were approximately 20 variations of these committee procedures, which contributed neither to the clarity of legislative implementation nor to transparency for citizens. On the contrary, even the European Parliament was not even informed for a long time. The first step forward in the fight for greater transparency in this committee jungle was for the European Parliament to at least be informed about everything the European Commission intended to regulate within these various committees. This happened in 1988 as part of the Plumb/Delors exchange of letters. A further step towards transparency and participation by the European Parliament was the so-called modus vivendi of September 20, 1994, in which Parliament was granted not only information but also a certain right of objection. This also gave Parliament oversight powers. The Treaty of Amsterdam significantly improved the situation in that the number of committee procedures was drastically limited to three – as the European Parliament had long demanded – namely the administrative procedure, the regulatory procedure, and the advisory procedure. The information and oversight rights granted to the European Parliament in the past must now, under the Treaty of Amsterdam, be reaffirmed through an interinstitutional agreement. Our rapporteur, Ms. Frassoni, has done very careful work and identified which issues need to be clarified within the framework of this interinstitutional agreement and which administrative procedures within Parliament may need to be amended. A key problem is the time factor. When the European Parliament is informed, it must generally deliver its opinion within a very short period of four weeks if it so wishes. When it comes to issues affecting the health and safety of people in the European Union, the European Commission, as guardian of the Treaties and the only institution with the right of initiative, must be able to respond very quickly, within a few hours or days if necessary. Nevertheless, the European Parliament's right to information and, if necessary, to respond must be preserved. Our rapporteur proposes very practical solutions to these difficulties, which my group and I can only fully support. I have just one more request. There is something misleading in the German text of paragraph 2, and I urgently request clarification, also later from those responsible for printing. In my opinion, instead of "must be continued" it should be "must be preserved".

This proposal stands in stark contrast to the current system, in which criminal law and criminal procedure, as the core of national legal systems, fall under the sovereignty of each people and the exclusive competence of each state. The idea of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, by contrast, aims to relegate states to a subordinate role in this area in the long term. Moreover, this proposal would entail an entirely unpredictable chain of reforms. According to the Theato report, the European Public Prosecutor's Office would be necessary primarily to direct the investigations of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). At the same time, however, the Van Hulten report, which is being discussed today, reveals that the European Public Prosecutor's Office would itself be supervised by a European Union court. Thus, a small European reform can conceal a medium-sized reform, and a medium-sized reform can conceal a major reform. Moreover, a major reform can conceal a huge reform, because soon a European criminal law will be proposed, and why not a European Minister of Justice, who would be controlled by an extension of the powers of the European Parliament. In my opinion, we should therefore carefully consider the balance of powers that could be upset by proposing such a seemingly isolated reform. This ultimately shows that proposals such as the one for a European Public Prosecutor's Office reveal an inability to imagine Europe in any way other than pyramidal and centralized, that is, in the form of a superstate. The Europe of Nations Group, on the other hand, aspires to a polycentric Europe in which nations are interconnected. The outcome of such interconnection could conceivably be, for example, better coordination between national courts and perhaps the creation of national structures specializing in infringements detrimental to Community finances. The legal framework therefore already exists. It is sound in principle and only needs to be improved. Mr President, Mrs Theato is proposing an institutional revolution for two reasons. The public, indifferent to 20 million unemployed and thousands of cows infected with mad cow disease, is supposedly alarmed by the fraud that supposedly endangers financial interests. And these two reasons are supposed to justify a dual set of instruments: a European penal code for violations of Community law and a European public prosecutor. Mrs Theato has probably forgotten to mention a European prison, since the FBI, the European police force, and even OLAF, already exist. The whole thing is to be regulated by two regulations, one for the public prosecutor, one for the penal code, to be adopted on the basis of Article 280 of the Treaty, that is to say, according to secondary law, because one of the special features of secondary law is that it permits all kinds of absurdity. We are dealing with a double absurdity here. First, there is the classic, Eurofederalist ideological absurdity: a single market, a single VAT, a single diplomacy, a single army, and now a single criminal code and a single public prosecutor's office. And all this to combat fraud amounting to less than a billion, while many times that amount is being thrown out the window for the GSP, free trade zones or tariff gifts to Chiquita, and billions more are being lost from the fourth source of revenue, GDP, as a result of the budget rationing pact.

And it could go on like this. Commissioner, since time is short, I would like to quickly list the seven points - you mentioned some - that we think are essential and that we should work on: the obligation, as soon as possible, to sail in our waters, to have a double hull; the strictest possible control by the port State. Furthermore, the classification societies must be obliged to make their reports public because they are not made public. Harmonisation of sanctions between the fifteen Member States because they must not differ but be the same everywhere. Greater severity for flags of convenience, not because the ships that fly these flags are necessarily bad ships but because many bad ships use these flags; improving information on all the fleets in the world but this is already foreseen; defining and making responsibilities more severe. In this regard, I would like to know who owns the Erika because the notion of legal person in our law is one thing but behind it there are always shareholders, natural persons; where are the owners of the Erika? Perhaps in beautiful villas, on beautiful beaches, sunbathing. We would like to know their names and faces. Finally, improved training for crews. There is no such thing as zero risk in our society, but at least we must take maximum precautions. Mr President, I appreciate the Commissioner's statement. I have spent a long time at sea and therefore know from experience its power and destructive force, which make the correct design and maintenance of ships and vessels a fundamental factor. I would like to express my solidarity with all those who are dealing with the consequences of the splitting in two and the sinking of the oil tanker Erika. This was an environmental disaster and also a deplorable waste of resources. I would like to remind you that the oil industry, through the International Oil Pollution Compensation Fund (IOPCF), under the 1969 Convention and the 1992 Protocol, assumes responsibility for more than 90 percent of the estimated costs of the accident, or approximately 170 million dollars. This leads me to believe that we should also consider partial assumption of responsibility by shipowners, the flag State and inspection authorities. However, before rushing into a new regulatory push, let us carefully examine the existing provisions to ensure that they are applied correctly: it is better to respond to the call to amend and improve existing legislation rather than embark on new proposals. In this sense, I support calls to strengthen port State controls to ensure full and effective inspections, as well as calls to ensure that classification societies actually check the structural condition of ships and are held accountable for their actions. The call for improved design in hull construction, especially of double-hulled ships, is reasonable but will take time to be implemented across the fleet.

The Serbs' large-scale expulsion campaign was halted, but almost every day there are unacceptable incidents where people are killed, where people are prevented from living there and living the way they want. There are daily attacks on Serbs, Roma, and Bosnians, but there are also still attacks on Albanians. I was actually shocked by the report, if it's true, that an Albanian doctor, who certainly worked under great difficulty in the hospital in Mitrovic in the Serbian part, ultimately gave up serving his people there because his life was repeatedly threatened. These are incidents and situations that we cannot tolerate. I hear—whether it's true or not, I don't know—that the Serbs are still operating a mine in Kosovo, in the Serbian part. There are at least rumors that Serbian militias are still active. For me, it is irrelevant whether it is a Serb, a Roma, a Bosnian, or an Albanian who is threatened or killed in Kosovo. It is irrelevant who is working toward a division and separation in Kosovo. What is crucial for me is that the institutions we fund achieve what we want to achieve: a multi-ethnic Kosovo, a coexistence in Kosovo. We need more police; there are absolutely not enough police. We need an independent judiciary—certainly difficult to establish—and we also need funding for the High Commissioner for Human Rights. All of this must happen, and quickly. If we do not provide assistance quickly, the situation will worsen, and new conflicts and crises may arise. Therefore, I believe it is right that we acted quickly, that we recognized urgency, and that we provided the money. But we want to see action, and we also want to see success in Kosovo, and I ask the Commission to ensure that this money is used successfully, particularly to strengthen the police force and build up the judiciary. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Members of this House, and especially the rapporteur, for the speed with which they have dealt with this issue. This will undoubtedly enable us to allocate funds to Kosovo promptly and counter the concerns expressed by both Mr Swoboda and Mrs Pack. In this evening's debate, I believe I have identified three main concerns. Firstly, although we have made considerable progress – we could mention customs administration, banking administration, tax administration – it is true that we must make further progress. Forward, to finance what? This is where we have our first small disagreement. In some of your amendments, you are calling for a more precise definition of the type of bodies to which the Union's financial contribution applies. For example, in Amendments 3 and 5. However, in our view, greater discretion should be given to the United Nations administration, which knows the reality on the ground better than we do. We believe that, at present, a pre-determination of the intended use of resources would create more practical difficulties.

We must not forget that in 1999, 717,000 people came to compensate for our low birth rate. Therefore, a socially conscious immigration policy is absolutely essential in the social order, as President Gutierres recently stated in Spain. Particular attention must be paid to the situation of those whose job opportunities are threatened or weakened by economic changes, mergers, acquisitions, new technologies, and so on. A training policy to train and prepare people for new jobs is essential in order to safeguard existing jobs or to give them a second chance. Because, as the film title suggests, the postman sometimes rings twice. I simply believe that it is the responsibility of all European, national, and regional governments to ensure that he rings more than once. I believe, Commissioner, that the Commission has a responsibility to promote and coordinate these opportunities. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Andersson on his truly excellent work—which is why there is broad agreement—and thank the Members for their contributions. Allow me to make a few comments on what has already been said. First, I would like to emphasize that the debate on social protection between the European institutions began several years ago. In 1995, there was an initial communication entitled "The Future of Social Protection," followed by reports from the European Parliament, Ms. Weiler, and Mr. Pronk. Today we are discussing Mr. Andersson's report. I believe we have made considerable progress, especially since we are now debating the modernization of social protection. Second, it is important to consider the legal basis on which the European Commission can act. As is well known, the Treaty does not provide a legal basis for policies at the European level, but there is an agreement, reaffirmed at the last Council, that measures should be initiated to coordinate and exchange experiences and successful programs among the Member States. Thirdly, I would like to point out that the four objectives on which this report focuses – paid work, the economic sustainability of pension systems, social inclusion and, finally, the quality of healthcare – take a horizontal approach to gender equality issues, since within each of the categories mentioned by the honourable Members, there are specific programmes aimed at women. It is often necessary to address the problems identified with specific policies. I would now like to turn to the concrete steps we have taken. As you know, the Portuguese Presidency has already set up a high-level working group, which will present its first report at the June Summit. The Portuguese Presidency will give priority to the two issues of long-term pension security and social inclusion. I believe that the proposal to set up a contact group at parliamentary level is very positive and, once this high-level working group has been approved, can help us make further progress. Several speakers have commented on the role of social protection systems, the costs of social protection, and the impact of these systems on the competitiveness of Member States. I would like to point out that policies are intended to link competitiveness and social cohesion in Europe.

CURRENT AND URGENT DEBATE The next item is the debate on current, urgent and particularly important issues. Racist and xenophobic incidents in El Ejido (Spain) The next item is the joint debate on the following motions for resolutions: B5-0149/2000 by Mr Galeote Quecedo and others, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, on outbreaks of racism and xenophobia in the region of El Ejido (Spain); B5-0159/2000 by Mr Gasòliba i Böhm and Mr Sánchez García, on behalf of the Group of the European Liberal, Democrat and Reformist Party, on racist and xenophobic incidents in El Ejido (Spain); B5-0162/2000 by Mrs. Díez González and others, on behalf of the Group of European Socialists, on the racist and xenophobic outbreak in El Ejido (Almería); B5-0169/2000 by Mr. Puerta and others, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, on the xenophobic outbreak in El Ejido (Spain); B5-0175/2000 by Mr. Bautista Ojeda and others, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, on the xenophobic incidents in El Ejido (Spain). Mr. President, I am reassured by this debate because I see that the first three speakers are well aware of the situation because we are of African origin. First of all, I would like to congratulate the groups in this Assembly for the high degree of consensus reached on this resolution, mindful as I am of the effort we Members of this Parliament have made to avoid using an issue like this for electoral purposes. Secondly, I would also like to firmly state that neither Spain nor Andalusia are xenophobic or racist, which does not, of course, exclude the absolute condemnation of the use of violence by those who, individually or in groups, deserve only the law and only the law to pursue them rigorously and firmly. We must address the issue of immigration in depth and with rigor. The facts, which unfortunately precede political decisions in this area, undoubtedly confirm the priority of implementing the Tampere Agreements and Title IV of the Treaty without delay. Today's problems cannot be resolved within five years. That is a long time, as we are seeing. The legislation of the Member States must be adapted to the governments' agreements reached in Tampere, as the resolution itself states in its paragraph 7. The social integration of legal immigrants must be carried out without any excuses and without any delay. Furthermore, Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the labor market must be realistically regulated so that jobs filled by third-country nationals are subject to labor regulations that guarantee equal wages, social security, and social coverage, thereby eradicating labor exploitation and the pockets of marginalized citizens that give rise to the acts condemned in the resolution and that, ultimately, are the real background of the social problem raised there. Furthermore, solidarity, dialogue, and agreements between institutions—including European ones—at national, regional, and local levels, with employers, unions, and the immigrant communities themselves, whose countries of origin also bear undoubted responsibility, are fundamental.

In the context of the next IGC resolution, Parliament will have to seriously consider the issue of differentiation and flexibility. Both enlargement and the results of integration are threatened if we are unable to create the system of concentric circles proposed by the Liberal Group. My colleagues, Mrs Frassoni and Mr Onesta, have already expressed themselves, not without some skepticism, on certain aspects of the issue at hand. I would like to express my concerns about subsidiarity, not only between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Member States and their own autonomous regions. This subject has not received adequate attention, and there are many elements of concern. Allow me to draw particular attention to one of the implications of enlargement for this Parliament. It has been decided that Parliament could not reasonably have more than 700 Members if it was to remain a deliberative assembly. If we apply the current principle of degressive proportionality, namely six seats per Member State plus one seat per half a million inhabitants, we already arrive at a situation where Luxembourg, with its 367,000 inhabitants, has more Members of this House than Wales, which is a partially autonomous region of the United Kingdom. Scotland, with a population of five million, currently has eight seats in this House; Denmark and Finland have 16, for the same number of inhabitants. Now, what will happen if we keep the maximum number of Members of the European Parliament at 700, gradually include 26% more population, and then adopt the Commission's proposal—which I consider ill-considered—that we should have a European list of candidates. What will happen to a region like Scotland, which I represent here? It will become totally invisible! In these circumstances, Members of this House should not be in the least surprised that the people of Scotland and other similar countries are asking, in these discussions, whether enlargement should not also consist of the admission of new Member States from existing ones. This view is increasingly widespread in Scotland. Mr President, if I say that the Union is at a crossroads, I will not be announcing anything new at all. This has been said many times. But this time it is true: we have launched the single currency, an extremely positive element, and we are considering enlargement. The question remains whether we will be ready when enlargement comes or not. Are we going to enlarge without deepening, or are we going to enlarge while deepening? That is the debate, and that is what any discussion on the Intergovernmental Conference, its agenda, and its method will be about. It is clear that, for the time being, the Council has not opted for enlargement accompanied by deepening. This is dangerous for enlargement, dangerous for any prospect of political union and, above all, difficult for public opinion to understand. The Council must understand that if we want the future of the European Union to be based on sound enlargement, the next Intergovernmental Conference must go much further.

You referred to Article 11(1), which stipulates that the Funds' appropriations cannot replace public or equivalent structural expenditure by the Member State. Very well: that is the immutable rule. Could Article 11(1) authorise the following practice? Suppose that the funding of a self-governing region or a country under the Structural Funds increases, then the State could reduce the central funding allocated to that region proportionately, so that the total package of funding available corresponds to a formula set at national level, irrespective of the amount of Structural Funds provided by the Union. Is such a practice really permissible? Additionality is also an important issue for Wales, which I represent. Last week, it was even one of the reasons for a vote of no confidence and the resignation of the First Secretary of the National Assembly for Wales. It was only in 1991-1992 that the Commission won a battle with the United Kingdom over additionality, then in the context of the RECHAR funds. This led to the signing of an agreement in which the British Government agreed to introduce procedures to ensure that Community funds reached the areas for which they were intended and were genuinely additional. Despite this, problems persist in Wales and Scotland. Could the Commission look into this particular situation in relation to the agreement with the British Government? I gather, Madam, that the debate which I understand is taking place in Scotland is also taking place in Wales. I will check what you say and if you agree, I will also answer your question in writing, as I promised Mr MacCormick. I will try to give a brief answer, Mr President, by telling the honourable Member that the regional development plan presented by the Spanish authorities on 29 October does not allow me to conclude that there has been a distribution of Community resources between the Spanish regions of Objective 1 - because that is what it is about in Andalusia - and therefore of those destined for the region you represent. You should know, honourable Member, that since I was unable to understand exactly how things stood, on 14 December I wrote a letter, which I have here with me, to the Minister of Economy and Finance, Rato, to ask for additional information on the document presented. In the coming weeks, the Commission will begin negotiations with the Spanish authorities to draw up the Community support framework for the new period 2000-2006 and during these meetings I assure you that the Commission will obtain the necessary clarifications on the distribution region by region. On the subject of Andalusia, if you like, as soon as I have the data by sector and region, I will hasten to communicate them to you personally. Commissioner, the problem is that when Aznar has to collect funds from the European Union for Andalusia, he counts all the Andalusians, but when Aznar has to pay the Andalusian government in the form of services for all Andalusians, he no longer sees 400,000 Andalusians and this is very serious because 400,000 children are like the entire population of Strasbourg or a city larger than Granada, full of children that Aznar does not see.

The text of the proposed regulation was amended quite substantially in the Committee on Fisheries. All members of our group voted in favor of these amendments in committee and in plenary. Amendment 1 makes the text considerably clearer. The data collected is not intended solely for scientific purposes. It must be processed by scientists and then forwarded to the political bodies responsible for making decisions. However, it is of utmost importance that the collection be based on scientific evidence. Amendment 2 contains a modification of the Commission's original proposal. The Commission's proposal requires the preparation of very detailed studies for each individual vessel and each individual company. In addition to the extraordinary cost burden that such a proposal would entail, the cumbersome implementation procedures could also lead certain administrations to use these difficulties as an excuse for not providing the relevant information on time. There is also a risk that additional bureaucratic requirements in this sector could create mistrust among those affected. Regarding the second part of this amendment, it is necessary to identify and quantify job losses in this sector much more precisely. It should not be forgotten that the implementation of a Common Fisheries Policy must also include a social dimension in statistical and analytical terms. Amendment 3 makes it possible to take into account the important aspect of collecting environmental data. The particularly negative impact of failing to take such data into account is clearly evident, for example, in the decision to ban driftnets, which is not at all ecologically justified, as they are one of the most selective fishing gears. If this ecological dimension were not included in the data collection, the Commission could prohibit the use of any particular fishing gear at will. Amendment 4 requires scientists to process all data and present it to the competent authorities, including national and regional authorities, in a way that is useful for decision-making. Amendment 5 reduces the burdens contained in the Commission's proposal. For example, the competent authorities may only request information that improves operational knowledge of fishing activities, without requiring the disclosure of data protected by the right of confidentiality, such as tax information that does not fall within the Community's competence. Amendment 6 makes this article more binding by involving the Commission in the procedure and monitoring it. All data must be transmitted annually and the Commission regularly informed of the aggregated results. Finally, Amendment 7 requires the Commission to submit a report by the end of 2001. Since the Common Fisheries Policy is due to be revised in 2002, all policymakers must have access to the information that forms the basis of the Commission's proposal. Hudghton report (A5-0036/2000) The amendment to the directive presented by the Commission is important because it deals with a specific contagious viral disease, infectious salmon anaemia. It is transmitted in water via organic substances such as blood, feces, mucus, etc. Vertical transmission of the disease through spawn or milk has not been scientifically proven. However, it is known that other species such as trout, eels, or herring can carry the virus without becoming ill.

We therefore believe that a more realistic deadline should be found in the conciliation procedure. We voted against Amendments 25 and 72, which call for minimal anthropogenic pollution of all groundwater. We consider this requirement unrealistic, given the immense costs and extremely long timescales required to restore a virtually unpolluted state. This is the reason for our vote. Water is a renewable and limited natural resource, the wise use of which is essential. The Water Framework Directive will represent an important cornerstone of Community policy in this sector. The objectives of this directive are clear and ambitious. We agree with these objectives. The directive sets environmental limit values close to zero. However, we believe it would be more sensible not to set unrealistic deadlines that neither our Member States nor our industry can meet. Of course, we need a timetable, but it must be more gradual. A legal obligation to achieve zero emissions and to stop discharges by 2020 would amount to a ban on all identified substances. Such provisions could pose major problems for cross-border river basins and, with regard to the candidate countries, could complicate enlargement. Naturally, I would also like to mention a particular sector whose developments I am following very closely: agriculture, which is one of the largest consumers of water. It must accept – and is already beginning to do so – its role as a paying polluter, but at the same time, its specific characteristics and constraints must also be taken into account, particularly in the arid regions of the world. Regarding the amendments concerning radioactive substances, I am naturally in favor of controls, but this question depends on the legal basis established by the Euratom Treaty. Andersson report (A5-0033/2000). The EDD Group was unable to support the Andersson report. The explanatory memorandum (page 15) recognizes, among other things, that "the different levels of development and traditions of the Member States in the area of social security prevent uniform harmonization of social security systems in the Member States." However, the term "uniform harmonization" is one of those confusing terms that completely obscures the integration process in question. It is also correct, as the explanatory memorandum states, that harmonization is harmful: "Harmonization would also be harmful because it would place greater demands on weaker Member States and, at the same time, could put more socially developed states under competitive pressure to make cuts in their social security systems. Such harmonization would benefit no one." In reality, a social model is being introduced that amounts to harmonization—and uniform harmonization at that. Point D emphasizes that "the Union can add value by adopting genuine, binding and effective convergence criteria." The report then goes on to point out that the development of this convergence process will be promoted through consultations between the Ecofin Council and the Council of Social Affairs and Employment Ministers. Finally, point 7 emphasizes that "the social convergence process must be accompanied by effective and ambitious fiscal coordination." This brings us to the heart of the matter. This social harmonization project is not social policy; rather, it is a continuation of the EU's EMU project.

(The sitting was suspended at 11.50 a.m. for a formal sitting to mark the visit of Mr Vaclav Havel, President of the Czech Republic, and resumed at 12.50 p.m.) Votes (continued) The next item was the vote on the report by Mrs Stenzel on the Equal initiative (A5-0034/2000). (Parliament adopted the motion for a resolution) Recommendation for second reading: Report (A5-0027/2000) by Mrs Lienemann, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, on the Council common position for adopting a European Parliament and Council directive establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (9085/3/1999 - C5-0209/1999 - 1997/0067(COD)) Before the vote: I welcome the quality and ambition of this report on LIFE. I should just like to point out that LIFE is a financial instrument at the service of environmental policies within the European Union and in third countries, both in the neighbouring Mediterranean countries and in the countries bordering the Baltic Sea and in candidate countries. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy has tabled a large number of amendments, most of which were incorporated into the common position adopted by the Council. In the third phase of LIFE (2000-2004), this instrument is divided into three priority areas: LIFE-Nature (47% of resources), LIFE-Environment (47%), and LIFE-Third Countries (6%). These are, in my view, the most important changes: LIFE's contribution to sustainable development within the Community and to the development of Community environmental policy, particularly as regards the integration of the environment into other policies, and the implementation and revision of environmental legislation; improving the efficiency, transparency, and methodology of LIFE's implementation procedures, the procedures for informing and disseminating information to the public, and the procedures for cooperation between beneficiaries; LIFE's objective: this programme should aim primarily at sustainable urban development, in close coordination with the pilot projects implemented under the URBAN initiative, on which I have already had the opportunity to report; and the contribution of the projects supported to the sustainability of socio-economic measures and, consequently, to job creation. I consider it essential that the LIFE financial instrument continue to allow the participation of the candidate countries of Central and Eastern Europe. The other candidate countries (such as Cyprus, Turkey, and Malta) will also be able to participate in LIFE once appropriate agreements have been concluded with those countries. The main problem in the negotiations with the Council is, of course, the overall amount earmarked for the third phase of the LIFE programme (2000-2004). The Commission's proposal, approved by the Council, is EUR 613 million, while the Committee on the Environment considers that the corresponding budget should be EUR 850 million. I support the rapporteur's firm stance. The financial envelope in question has not been increased since the programme was launched, not even with the EU's enlargement to 15 Member States. If the report is adopted in plenary, a conciliation procedure must be initiated, as provided for in the codecision procedure, to resolve the issue of the funding allocated to this program. This type of procedure is common practice, as programs or legislative proposals all too often have budgets that fall far short of what they require!

So far, the Commission has had only limited success in reimbursing unjustly received funds. Criminal measures are the responsibility of the Member States. Given that these two legal aspects currently often overlap and that attacks on the EU budget are increasing cross-border—and are also perpetrated by organized crime—the division of competences between the Member States is unclear. Added to this are differences between national legal provisions and requests for mutual legal assistance that drag on or go unanswered. The Convention on the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests, signed by the European Council in 1995, and the two protocols thereto, have not changed this. To enter into force, this Convention must be ratified by all fifteen Member States. After five years, only four have done so. This inaction, which threatens to undermine the Union's credibility, has led Parliament to call for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. In doing so, there is no question of creating a transnational criminal and judicial system. Rather, the objective is to provide the Union with specific instruments to protect its financial interests, while respecting subsidiarity. With this report, we revive this idea and urge the Commission to submit legislative proposals to achieve this objective. In this regard, the requests emerging from the opinions of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs are fully taken into account. We express two recommendations that stem from the creation of OLAF and should guarantee its operational and legal effectiveness, its transparency, and the protection of individual freedoms. To this end, we need - the first recommendation - a legal act that establishes the crimes against the Union's financial interests and the guiding principles. In a proposed amendment, I recommend setting 30 September as the deadline by which the Commission must put forward its proposal. The second recommendation concerns criminal procedure. The Commission should propose - and here too I propose by way of amendment setting the deadline for 31 May 2000 - a legal act on the creation of an independent body, linked to the Commission at institutional level, and responsible for coordinating and monitoring the regularity of OLAF's investigative activities. The existing Supervisory Committee can only monitor the independence of the Director of the Office. Such a proposal should contain an independent statute for this body and define its tasks, which are limited to OLAF's internal investigations and prosecutions in matters affecting the Union's financial interests and its relations with national authorities. It remains out of bounds to influence the justice system within the Member States. The control of the legality of acts must be ensured by the Court of Justice. Furthermore, we call on the next Intergovernmental Conference to begin the debate on the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office responsible for the protection of the Union's financial interests, if possible on the basis of the now widely recognised study produced by renowned specialists, the famous Corpus Juris, as well as the feasibility studies that followed it.

These disasters are in fact due to major climate changes to which we are not uninvolved, because they are caused by human activities, especially those of developed countries. The greenhouse effect and deforestation also have significant consequences. As regards this regulation on the environmental dimension in the development process of developing countries, the Council has largely followed the amendments that we tabled and voted on at first reading. From this point of view, we can only be satisfied. However, I would like to stress one aspect that the Council has avoided - inadvertently, at least so I believe and hope - even though it is a fundamental issue: coordination between European actors and local interlocutors, namely local NGOs, basic communities and holders of traditional knowledge on the use of biological diversity. No project can be truly effective if it is not carried out in close cooperation with the population concerned. A final remark: if the creation of the steering committees is to be successful, I believe it will be necessary to reaffirm the desire to create a system of appeal open to civil society in developing countries for any measure that goes against legitimate social concerns. Mr President, the only key to the development of developing countries is their direct participation in this process, both in identifying problems and in solving them. As someone who has been involved in development cooperation work, I have noticed that in recent years this approach has succeeded, to some extent, in replacing the old paternalistic ideology, according to which industrialised countries think that development consists in transferring their standard of living to the most backward nations. The new paradigm of development cooperation stresses the importance of partnership and the ability of those who provide aid to listen to each other. In fact, it is necessary to be patient and to give the beneficiaries the opportunity to identify their problems themselves, draw up a development plan and carry it through. Those who provide help must ensure that they do not become indispensable and that the work creates local prosperity and activity. In this respect, Mr Wijkman has produced an excellent report, which highlights the importance of this paradigm as a valid and morally sustainable alternative. Unfortunately, at EU level, scientific and technological development projects for developing countries do not follow this approach at all. The European Union's framework programmes do not cover developing countries. In practice, environmental scientific and technological development projects cannot involve partners from, for example, North Africa. Of course, there is no stopping them from carrying out research: the problem is that there is no money. This is because developing countries cannot participate as partners in the consortia that apply for funding. Why? When you consider that Eastern European countries have been given more opportunities to participate, it becomes even stranger. Furthermore, the issues that concern us most closely are, for example, the desertification of North Africa and the problems affecting the Mediterranean basin.

First, indirect tax provisions; recently, thanks to Commissioner Monti, direct provisions and, in particular, the code of good conduct. This system has worked quite well, but, as in the famous film Casablanca, time passes and it is necessary to adapt the regulation we have applied until now to the new circumstances. In this regard, I noted a significant consensus in all the interventions. First, it is necessary to define clear and comprehensive standards at the level of drafting the regulation. The existence of confusing rules, regulatory gaps, or rules that only enshrine indeterminate legal concepts is probably more shocking in this part of the regulation than in others. This is all the more shocking, as is the case in the second part of the reform, where the application of the ordinance to national authorities is recommended. Third, the role that the Commission must play against the temptation to create independent agencies that would distort the very essence of the Commission in order to ensure uniform application by international organizations seems important to me. Fourthly, and I will conclude with this, as some speakers have already alluded to, the international legal order has changed. We saw this at the aborted Seattle conference and we see it in our bilateral conferences with various regions or countries around the world. The principle of competition must already be applied universally. And we must ensure that environmental and labour standards are respected in order to avoid dumping in this sector, that property rights are scrupulously respected, that state aid is reviewed, because, as has been said in this House, it distorts competition in many sectors and destroys jobs within the Union and, finally, that equal conditions are applied to prevent aid and internal distortions in other countries from ultimately spreading to international level through traps. Mr President, Commissioner, the Jonckheer report contains many good ideas on state aid to industry and several other sectors. First of all, it demonstrates Parliament's resolve to impose a reduction in state aid in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market. However, several of the conclusions still give rise to serious concerns within our group. For example, the fact that the reduced amounts and levels of state aid vary greatly from one Member State to another demonstrates the usefulness of such reviews. Aid stemming from selfish national concerns gives companies unjustified advantages, distorts competition, and leads to an inefficient and unprofitable distribution of scarce resources at European level. This is no longer the same thing at all; we are dealing here with atypical forms of aid. We must promote forms of state aid that require efforts on the part of the recipients. I am thinking in particular of state guarantees, on which the Commission recently adopted a position. They must obviously be considered state aid, but in my opinion they are a better solution than direct aid. The report on competition policy highlights the Commission's confidence in strict legislation rather than insisting on economic arguments that interfere with competitiveness.

I believe that there are circumstances where the question of principles and institutional rules fades into the background. I encourage the Council and its Presidency to continue to defend the fundamental values of the Union. I call on the Commission to be less cautious. With this resolution, our Parliament is assuming its responsibilities. That said, in my view, the resolution adopted today is a bare minimum, the least we could do. Personally, I defended an even firmer position and supported Amendments 1, 4, 6, 7 and 8, as well as the oral amendment proposed by the Socialist Group. I believe it is imperative that the Council only accept technical relations with representatives of the Austrian government, which include members of the FPÖ. Involving Jörg Haider's party in a government coalition will trivialise the far right in Europe, and constitutes an extremely serious precedent that could have significant knock-on effects in other members of the Union or in the candidate countries. The Austrian Conservative Party is taking on a historic responsibility here. Our fundamental values are at stake here: as democratically elected representatives of the European people, we have no choice. We must, as our voters demand, reject the unacceptable. Because when the spectre of barbarism resurfaces, "Not to oppose is already to surrender." I abstained from voting on the resolution. I condemn Jörg Haider's racist and xenophobic line. However, I cannot approve of an EU body intervening politically in the domestic politics of a Member State. That said, I cannot approve of paragraph 4 of the joint resolution and I cannot vote in favor of the resolution, even against the extreme right. (SV) It is obvious that Europe's political leaders have the right and the duty to react against Haider and his party. Europe's political leaders have the right to express their opinion on the political developments of another Member State, just as a Minister of State can speak out against racist politicians in a local authority. Finland's experience, however, shows that integration is a better way to combat anti-democratic forces than isolation. This is why I voted against point 2 of the resolution. This, however, presupposes that all parties respect human rights. The EU Presidency's "joint reaction" to the formation of the government in Austria is legally incorrect. The reaction of the 14 Member States lacks support in the Treaty. We must also not isolate forces in Austria that want to work to defend human rights. Despite my objection to the Council's approach and my view that it would be better to work for integration rather than isolation, it was essential to clearly demonstrate the European Parliament's position on issues of racism, which is why I voted for the resolution in the final vote. This concludes voting time. Adjournment of the session

Of course, progress could possibly be made if agreement on this issue could be reached at the Intergovernmental Conference. It remains to be seen whether there is a consensus. After that, we will see. For our part, we will take note of the proposals on this subject. Mr President, I join with the previous speakers in wishing Portugal a successful Presidency. You said that this particular issue is not currently on your agenda for the next Intergovernmental Conference, but if it were desired, you would consider it. Well, I and my 35 British Conservative colleagues in the European Parliament would like to ask you to do so. I realize that this is a provocative question. It is intended to be provocative, because it concerns a serious matter: some countries do not respect EU law as they should. We must find a way to force such countries to comply with the rules so that we can regain the trust of our citizens. I can't think of a better way of achieving this. Do you have a better suggestion? The issue here is whether the European dimension is strengthened or lessened, particularly through its inclusion in the Treaties. You will understand that this issue must be examined within the framework of the Intergovernmental Conference, and it is one of the issues on which only a special European Council summit can authorize the Portuguese Presidency to pursue it further, because it is one of the issues that lies outside the institutional framework in which the next Intergovernmental Conference will be held. Intergovernmental conferences are something of an event, and they can also be something like a Christmas tree. Therefore, the possibility cannot be ruled out that these issues, which have repeatedly arisen and been passed from one conference to the next, will be raised again. The problem is whether there is currently a consensus within the European Union to take up this issue again, bearing in mind, above all, that if such an issue is included, other, similar issues will probably also be added to the Conference's agenda. Mr Dimitrakopoulos has the floor on a point of order. Please be brief. Mr President, I realize I must hurry. I really liked what Mr Seixas da Costa said about Santa Claus. In Spain, they talk about the letter to the Three Wise Men. I would simply like to remind you that the European Parliament has already sent the letter with its reports to the Three Wise Men. Now it is up to the Presidency and the Council to deliver the gifts we requested in our letter to the Three Wise Men. As I suspected, it was not, strictly speaking, a point of order but a way of winding up the debate. We thank Mr Seixas da Costa, but he too can write a letter to the Three Wise Men. I would just like to say that this question of Christmas customs, which the honourable Member has raised, is extremely important. The only difference is that in this case, Santa Claus has someone who rules over him, and that is why Santa Claus can only give gifts if they have someone else's approval.

However, much remains to be done. The next major challenge is to relaunch the new round of world trade negotiations, which failed to get off the ground last December in Seattle. It must be a "development round," in which developing countries, which were effectively excluded from previous rounds, are fully represented. Because the best way to reduce world poverty is to help developing countries help themselves. Developing countries want trade, not aid; a little boost, but not a handout. And the best way to help developing countries help themselves is to open the world's markets to allow them to sell their products.
