In this way, the power of globalization can be harnessed for good, for the benefit of the poor and not just the rich, the majority and not a minority. Therefore, whether through the "New Deal" in Newcastle or fair trade in Freetown, Labour's objective of giving everyone a chance remains the same. Swoboda Report (A5-0031/2000). (FR) The Commission's desire to strengthen relations between the European Union and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and to open up the prospect of full integration into the Community for the latter, appears to respond to a priority concern: the construction of a political entity that respects nations and their sovereignty could not postpone for much longer the sending of a signal to these southeastern European states, toward which, since the end of the Second World War, history has not been kind. After having been crushed by the boot of triumphant communism, the region has continued to pay the price of the Soviet collapse since the early 1990s. However, in this difficult context, and particularly since NATO's military intervention in the Balkans, some of these states, all of them truly European, have demonstrated a sense of responsibility that legitimizes their aspirations for integration into the Community. In this sense, the case of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is both exemplary and emblematic. Exemplary because it demonstrates that the Balkan states are not beset by any kind of fate and that those countries willing to do so are now in a position to meet the usual requirements of the stabilization and association agreements required by the European Union. Emblematic because it positively illustrates the Fifteen's vision of the emergence of a common policy for the five countries of the region (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, FYROM, and Albania) capable of making economic and political stabilization a vital and urgent obligation. The UEN Group agrees to send this signal to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, insofar as it prioritizes the independence and sovereignty of states: while a satisfactory solution cannot be found in the Balkans without a significant policy of cooperation between the member states, its integration process cannot be blocked on the grounds that one of its countries would be deemed unworthy of this promotion. The Union is fulfilling its role by seeking, through its cooperation policy, to encourage nations to embrace a foundation of common values, the cornerstone of which is democracy and the freedom of its citizens.

As a representative of the Commission, I will ensure that the Charter and the actions it gives rise to represent the affirmation of a Union based on the set of fundamental rights, which are an integral part of Europe's common heritage. Only in this way can we help to re-legitimize in the eyes of European citizens, without exception, the project of an enlarged Union, based on respect for rights and freedoms, on the guarantee of personal safety and property and on effective legal protection, in other words a Union based on the political values that characterise contemporary democracies. I would also like to point out that 1999 was the year in which the 1999-2004 legislature of the European Parliament came into office, of the new Commission and, consequently, of the entry into office of a Commissioner responsible exclusively for the areas of justice and home affairs. In addition to these events, I would like to remind Parliament of some of the matters approved in 1999. In the area of immigration, borders and asylum, the Commission presented the proposal for a regulation to establish the EURODAC database and the proposal for a directive on the conditions of admission of third-country nationals to the Member States of the Union for the purpose of family reunification - as part of a specific integration policy for those legally residing in the territory of the Union. We examined a communication on common asylum procedures and a recommendation authorising the Commission to negotiate an agreement with Iceland and Norway to extend to these two countries the rules applied by the Member States of the European Union under the Dublin Convention. The Commission contributed actively to the work of the High Level Group on Migration and Asylum and, finally, in December, it presented a proposal for the creation of the European Refugee Fund. In the field of judicial cooperation, the Commission has presented proposals for regulations aimed at the communitarisation of certain conventions: one on judicial cooperation and the enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters (Brussels I); another on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters (Brussels II) and yet another on the summons and notification of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. We also presented, in 1999, a communication on victims of crime within the Union, initiating a debate which received further impetus at Tampere and which calls for the development of minimum standards on the protection of victims of crime, in particular as regards access to justice and the right to compensation for damages, including legal costs. I would also mention the presentation of the motion for a resolution on combating fraud and counterfeiting of non-cash means of payment. As part of the Union's legislative framework for combating financial crime, the Commission has presented a proposal for a revision of the Money Laundering Directive. In 1999, we saw the entry into operation of Europol and the Commission, for its part, sincerely hopes, following what the Portuguese Presidency has said here today, that with the entry into this new phase of the justice and home affairs sectors and the start of the reflection on the implementation of the new powers conferred on Europol by the Treaty of Amsterdam, the issue of democratic control and coordination between Europol and the competent judicial bodies, namely Eurojust, will also be addressed.

These two proposals make a significant contribution to implementing one of the four core principles of the internal market: the freedom to provide services. There is no doubt that the new regulation on the cross-border provision of services will improve both the functioning of the internal market and the competitiveness and efficiency of businesses. The strict conditions for issuing the EU services card—and I second my colleague Wieland on this point—are essential because they prevent crimes such as illegal immigration and fictitious contracts. Why do I consider this directive so essential? For three reasons: the economic importance of third-country labour within the EU, the competitiveness of businesses, and the proper functioning of the internal market. I therefore welcome, on the one hand, the establishment of a strict framework and, on the other, call for the controls carried out by the Member States to be organized in the most efficient and simple way possible. In conclusion, I would like to ask the Commission the following question, as I am regularly challenged on this subject: will the directive harm the accession negotiations? How do you interpret Article 1, given that it plays an important role for our country, which borders many of the new states, and in the accession negotiations? Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, until now, businessmen have had to find that two of the important freedoms, namely the free movement of persons and services, did not apply to them. Indeed, they still had to submit to bureaucratic and interminable immigration procedures imposed by the Member States in which a service was to be performed. Around 13 million third-country nationals reside in European territory. Although the exact number of businessmen among them is not known, I assume that their number is certainly not small. Until now, their access to the entire territory of the Union was therefore not governed by Community law. The two proposals for directives under consideration aim to promote the free movement of services within the internal market through the introduction of the EU services card. In this regard, I believe it is important to emphasize that the issue of this services card will be flexible, namely within five days following a simple notification to the Member State in which the service will be provided, and that, moreover, this document will have a limited period of validity and will not be renewed automatically in order to combat abuse. I have also carefully noted the reservations expressed by the Commissioner. After examining the amendments introduced, I have noted that we can largely endorse these reservations and we will conduct ourselves accordingly in tomorrow's vote. In conclusion, allow me to thank Mrs Berger for the great care with which she examined the various amendments and, in doing so, the important significance she has given to her report.

We also reject the amendments which seek to include the full cost of water by 2010. There is no doubt that we need to set water prices which encourage efficient use. However, at the same time, they must ensure the competitiveness of the productive sectors in the most disadvantaged regions without hindering their legitimate development. Finally, I would like to make a comment on the amendments relating to dangerous substances. These amendments establish that the objective to be achieved is a level of pollution equal to zero, or close to zero. However, I would like to point out that the level of zero pollution from any human activity has not yet been discovered. Ladies and gentlemen, we would be doing a disservice to the objectives of this important directive if we were not capable of giving it the flexibility and adaptability needed to ensure its application. I hope that, once again, Parliament will vote with a sense of reality, respecting the principle of subsidiarity and pursuing a fair balance between environmental objectives and economic and social considerations, the three essential elements for achieving the sustainable development that we all strongly desire. Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that this is an extremely important directive, as its objective is to improve the supply and quality of water. Citizens must certainly have the right to have clean water. It is important not only for the environment, but also for the health of the population. I am not speaking in a personal capacity, in fact I can say that I am part of that small group of Europeans who can still draw drinking water directly from the lake in front of their house. Our task is to commit ourselves to adopting all the necessary measures that can guarantee the improvement of water quality, and this work must begin immediately because there is no more time to lose. It is also important to set objectives that are sufficiently ambitious. Indeed, thinking of eliminating the direct discharge of effluents into waters and reducing the quantity of impurities and poisonous substances to zero by 2002 is not at all ambitious, on the contrary. It is simply a question of doing what is technically possible; no more, no less. Nevertheless, we must also have ambition. I would like to return to a point that has already been discussed. In my opinion, the Committee on the Environment has limited the issue of water transfer too much. This problem does not only concern Spain, but also the Nordic countries and I really hope that more room will be given to national solutions, provided that they are ecologically and economically better than those provided for in the directive. Mr President, Commissioner, congratulations to Mrs Lienemann on the excellent work she has done! Water and air surround us everywhere and we share them with all the inhabitants of the planet. Water is an indispensable condition for human life and there are more and more human beings in the world. Mrs Schleicher said during the day that it would be unrealistic to aim for clean water. Nothing could be more wrong! What is unrealistic is to continue to worsen the quality of water, to continue to worsen the conditions that make life possible.

It is an instrument that does not always lead to optimal solutions. The rudiments of economics teach us that the market is flawed in many respects, and anyone who denies this is nothing more than an ideologue. Competition should bring about a balance between supply and demand, ensuring an optimal distribution of resources and economic facts. However, optimal efficiency does not necessarily follow automatically. To prevent abuse, a general framework is essential, for example through antitrust law. But, for the most part, this only serves to prevent abuse and is not sufficient, in itself, to achieve socially legitimate objectives. Competition: yes. Limiting aid: where necessary and possible. But, given that aid occupies the bulk of the 1998 competition report, I would still like to say a few words about it, without prejudice to the report by our colleague Mr. Jonckheer. Aid for small and medium-sized enterprises in the research and development sector and for training in regional and environmental policy are undoubtedly conceivable and must be feasible. As long as they do not lead to unacceptable distortions of competition, aid aimed at such objectives must be permitted. The fact that decisions taken in these specific areas can be implemented is even more important than it is for antitrust and merger law. Aid must not simply be pilloried: it must be considered in a differentiated manner; it must also be assessed in terms of its contribution to achieving the aforementioned objectives. This last remark was addressed less to the Commission than to our colleagues in the EPP Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the report I have the opportunity to present to you today is an opinion on the Commission's annual report on State aid measures in force within the European Union and for which the Community has competence under Articles 87, 88 and 89 of the Treaties. The Commission's report is essentially descriptive in nature, describing the development of State aid in the manufacturing sector and in other sectors, according to various typologies, such as the method of financing and the objectives pursued. I would like to refer to the explanatory memorandum for the quantitative part of the report and will simply state here that the average annual amount for the period under review is around EUR 95 billion, which represents a decrease of around 13% compared with the period 1993-1995, a decrease which is essentially due to a reduction in aid in the Federal Republic of Germany. In short, the level of State aid declared is, broadly speaking, stable on average during the period covered and stands at around 1.2% of Community GDP, which is, coincidentally, more or less the equivalent of the Community budget for one year.

What happens when more women participate actively and equally in political decision-making? Based on developments so far, one can say that the agenda has changed—and when the agenda changes, the nature of decisions naturally changes as well. Whenever quotas are mentioned, the word competence is automatically mentioned. What is interesting, however, is that the competence requirements are rarely defined. Instead, it often appears as if men today, just as in the past, always possess the highest, undefined competence. Being a man is therefore synonymous with being the most competent. I consider this view to be proof of the tremendous incompetence of many of today's decision-makers. At the beginning of this year, in this plenary session, we called for March 8 to be declared an international holiday. Pending a positive decision on this issue, I would now like to take this opportunity to wish all social democratic women every success in the Women's World Marches, which begin in the spring on International Women's Day. This global campaign aims to draw attention to violence against women and the poverty of women around the world. Finally, I would like to underline what Commissioner Patten said at the end of the previous debate: the ideal police officer would be a Black grandmother. We don't have that yet, but they exist! Mr. President, the position of women in politics is an important issue that deserves more attention than this politically correct bickering we are currently witnessing. Undoubtedly, too few women are involved in politics. This is certainly not solely due to the male dominance of party apparatuses. In France, 95% of MPs are local politicians. Most of them do not belong to any party. In the leading bodies at the departmental level, independent MPs, other right-wing or other left-wing, constitute the largest group. To be elected as a local politician, one simply has to stand as a candidate. Access to national responsibilities often depends on the opportunities for influence that such mandates open up. Our group advocates for equal representation of men and women in the institutions of the European Union. Therefore, we oppose quota policies and positive discrimination, whether in favor of women or so-called social minorities. Minority policies, which establish superficial classifications in disregard of the profound unity of the human community, dangerously threaten the cohesion of the social fabric and the balance of our democratic model. First, if we establish quotas for women, why not also quotas based on age or ethnicity, quotas for Catholics, workers, and people who wear glasses? The introduction of social quotas in favor of the lowest-income categories would be no more idiotic than the creation of quotas for women. With such a philosophy, there would be no need to hold elections or advertise administrative positions. It would be sufficient to calculate the composition of ministries and parliaments statistically. Quota policies would only increase voters' disenchantment with politics by giving them, once again, the feeling that everything is happening behind their backs. On the other hand, such a policy is a sign of deep contempt for women.

In the environmental field, investments and objectives must be long-term. The future of future generations depends on it. Mr President, Commissioner, I will no doubt repeat what my colleagues have already said, but I believe the Council must be told time and again what we think of LIFE. I will therefore also emphasize – as the rapporteur has quite rightly done – that LIFE is the only specific financial instrument for the development and implementation of the European Union's environmental policy. This instrument is of fundamental importance because it provides the impetus for truly innovative measures in favor of nature and the environment in Europe, which are then taken up and expanded by the Member States. It is also deliberately democratic, as it is open to both governmental and non-governmental organizations. For this reason, ladies and gentlemen, I urge you not to vote for the amendments, which in no way reflect the spirit of LIFE. Through associations, LIFE can in fact be used directly by European citizens for measures in the general interest. For several million – I emphasize: millions – members of NGOs, LIFE demonstrates the Union's will to implement an ambitious policy in favor of the natural environment. LIFE is also the fundamental instrument for the Natura 2000 network in Europe, to which the Member States have committed themselves in accordance with the Community directive on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora and the migratory birds directive, and which enables the protection of biologically valuable areas in our countries. I would add that those who denigrate this policy in their own countries are responsible for slowing down nature conservation policy in Europe. This is regrettable, because everyone in this Chamber knows that the LIFE financial instrument is insufficient to implement all the projects submitted by the Member States, many of which have to be rejected for lack of funding. It should not be forgotten that LIFE is currently endowed with only EUR 100 million a year, which represents less than one thousandth of the Union budget. By way of comparison, agriculture, which has a real impact on the environment, as we all know, spends EUR 37 billion. In view of this, my group considers it essential to increase the LIFE budget and fully supports Mrs Lienemann's proposal to increase the budget to EUR 850 million. We know – and this must be said – how high our fellow citizens' expectations are in the environmental field and how half-hearted and unacceptable the Council's compromise on LIFE's financial framework is, all the more so given that the LIFE programmes have exceptionally high implementation rates and have made an effective contribution to the development of new environmental practices. This undoubtedly includes the first sustainable development projects. Mr President, the European Union's environment programme, with its considerable budget (EUR 613 million), raises numerous questions regarding the proper use of public funds. A financial instrument of this size must be transparent and efficient, which is not the case here for the following reasons: poorly defined criteria, dubious and uncoordinated projects, no publication of financial statements, and the absence of evaluation measures.

In order to facilitate the achievement of this objective, Directive 96/35/EC provided for the appointment of safety advisers for the transport of dangerous goods as those who have received appropriate professional training. The objective of this professional training for advisers was to provide knowledge of the essential legislative, regulatory and administrative provisions applicable to such transport. While this was a step forward at the time, the lack of specific provisions on the harmonisation of examination conditions proved problematic. It was therefore considered essential to fill this gap in order to achieve a high and uniform level of training for safety advisers and to avoid disparities in training costs, which would consequently affect competition between undertakings in the Member States. The Commission proposal aims to ensure uniform training for safety advisers, defines the minimum content of the examinations and defines the tasks of the competent authority and the requirements that the examining bodies must comply with. Our Parliament has expressed its support for the text. However, it tabled several amendments, most of which were incorporated into the Council's common position, in particular the need to draw up a questionnaire and declarations on the issuing of certain documents in the context of the "specification of the examination procedures proposed by the examination board". On the other hand, in order to be realistic, I support the postponement of the date of application of these provisions to three months after the entry into force of the directive. I conclude by insisting that harmonisation of the professional qualifications of these consultants will help to improve the quality of service in the interests of users, will minimise the risk of accidents liable to damage the environment and seriously harm the physical integrity of all those who might come into contact with dangerous goods. Koch report (A5-0104/1999) Last October I spoke on Mr Hatzidakis's report on the transport of dangerous goods by rail. My speech today will not be very different from what I said then. In practice, it is this: I deplore the fact that in such an important sector as the transport of dangerous goods, the adoption of harmonised standards is being incessantly postponed to the detriment of human and environmental safety. I would recall that a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States on the transport of dangerous goods by road entered into force on 1 January 1997. It included a certain number of transitional provisions valid until 1 January 1999. It is from that date that we should have taken a decision on a proposal from the European Commission aimed at eliminating these derogations. According to the usual procedure, the CEN, the European Committee for Standardisation, proposes standards for this sector which are subsequently included in the European Agreement concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road, signed in Geneva in 1957 (known by the acronym ADR), which is in force throughout Europe and whose provisions serve as the basis for the legislation applicable in the EU. CEN was unable to complete its work within the time frame set.

However, I wonder: If Turkey offers a brigade, should we also grant it the right to participate in decision-making on this policy? Indeed, structurally, there are several "Haiders" in the Turkish government. That seems questionable to me. Secondly, the Baltic states are also offering their services. Will they also be included in our defense policy? That is, to say the least, a rather interesting position. Mr. High Representative, you have emphatically recalled the progress we have made in this area from the Amsterdam Summit to the Helsinki Summit, and also the decisions already taken after Helsinki, for example, on the creation of the three committees or on the planning of a 50,000- to 60,000-strong rapid reaction force, which were also recently adopted during the informal meeting in Sintra. However, this rapid progress highlights even more clearly the gap between these decisions and the ongoing Intergovernmental Conference. In my view, we must find a viable compromise within this framework between those who rightly push for accelerated communitarization of this policy area and those who believe that such progress must continue to be achieved at the intergovernmental level. To the latter, I would say: pay attention, because this policy requires strong democratic legitimacy! We are aware of the weight of public opinion when it comes to foreign and security policy. I therefore ask you, only briefly of course, whether you believe some of the following issues can be addressed within the framework of the reform: redefinition of the dual structure between the Commission and the High Representative; a clear and unaffected differentiation between civilian and military crisis management. For the time being, this could mean, for example, integrating the Commission into the Political and Security Affairs Committee; strengthening the Community's competence for non-military crisis management; creating a Council of Defence Ministers; and harmonizing the EU Treaty, the NATO Treaty, and the WEU; Other questions would be the legal capacity of the European Union, increased cooperation in this area, parliamentary scrutiny, and, finally, financial resources. Do you think that some of these issues could at least be included on the agenda of the current Intergovernmental Conference? Mr. Solana, I'm sitting close enough to look you in the eye. I think you've aged; your face is full of wrinkles. I'm sorry to see you like this, and I could despair when I hear you talk about sandbox games, as Mrs. Maes said, while at the same time keeping quiet about other things. You appear here and don't say a word about the blood that is being shed in Kosovo at this very moment. Yet you, of all people, bear enormous responsibility, because under the pretext of ethnic cleansing, blood is now flowing in Kosovo in other ethnic cleansings. You are Spanish, you come from a great country, Mr. Solana. Spain was not like Franco; it maintained its unity and kept the Basque Country, Andalusia, and Catalonia—and that was quite right. Nobody equated Spain with Franco, and nobody jeopardized Spain's unity by foisting a fascist dictator. But today you identify Yugoslavia with Milosevic, you jeopardize Vojvodina, you jeopardize Montenegro, you jeopardize southern Serbia—you are responsible for the situation that has arisen.

But I was even more shocked to read that the French public authorities involved had known about this for days and had not asked the volunteers to take protective measures. I would like the Commissioner to inform me whether the European Commission was aware that there was a potential risk to public health, and if so, since when. Mr. President, we must learn lessons from the past. Tomorrow, maritime disasters like the Erika disaster could happen again off the coast of the Netherlands, England, Spain, or Belgium. The regulations we adopt today in Europe will be considered a precedent. Therefore, let us be tough on polluters and generous to those affected. Mr. President, I would like to say, echoing the words of some Members, that the situation, two and a half months after the shipwreck, remains particularly critical and is even becoming more widespread every day. There are two points of view: the environmental one, to begin with. The hull still contains 16,000 tons of leaking heavy fuel oil; And in addition to these leaks, last week we observed and recorded, unfortunately, thirty-five acts of ecological piracy, thirty-five tank cleanings, which are undignifiedly added to this absolutely catastrophic situation. Regarding this problem, Mrs. de Palacio has gone into great lengths, and I believe she has initiated the work without waiting for what is absolutely necessary today: the outline of European maritime law, thanks to a draft directive on the transport of dangerous goods by sea. From this perspective, she will once again encounter the French will to mark her presidency with regulations aimed at greater safety. But it is at the economic level where the second impact is occurring—first the environmental impact, second the economic impact—as many Members have said here. Shellfish farming, fishing, oyster farming, and fish farming are currently severely affected. Because the oil spill is compounded by the damage caused by the storm, in many places. Unfortunately, these activities have been terribly damaged. They will have, on the one hand, to rebuild, and on the other, perhaps more complicated, to regain commercial confidence. Faced with this situation, the inhabitants of Brittany, the Vendée, and the Charente, and foresters in other areas, await a signal from the European Union. We cannot, at the same time, frame this mandate as a rapprochement with citizens and remain "silent," without concrete responses, in the face of phenomena of this magnitude and magnitude. I have taken note, and with great care, of Commissioner Fischler's words, which are perhaps the most concrete we have heard today. It is true that there have been expressions of compassion and solidarity, and some announcements have been made, but today it is time for a concrete manifestation of European solidarity to follow this waiting period. The Erika oil spill is one of the catalogue of disasters that have recently occurred in Community waters, including the Braer oil spill in Shetland and the Sea Empress oil spill in Wales. These spills, in addition to causing irreparable ecological damage, have devastated local industries.

These proposals particularly benefit women. In parallel with this European strategy for social convergence, a concrete plan for legislative work in the social field and proposals for framework agreements, with pre-established timetables, are needed in the area of social dialogue. We hope that the Commission will present this in its proposal for a social action program. Social convergence is also necessary for enlargement, on the one hand, to strengthen the social model and, on the other, to prevent the risks of social dumping. In connection with enlargement, the Commission should consider presenting a special action plan in social policy matters. The discussions in committee have been constructive. There were many amendments, but we managed to agree on a report. The amendments that will now be voted on in plenary are only fifteen. This means that there has been a great deal of unity of opinion. Some of these amendments stem from the committee's processing. I will reject those. I will also reject the amendments tabled by the TDI Group, since, in my opinion, they add nothing new to the report. However, my group will approve Amendment 14 from the Liberal Group. I think it is a good proposal. It is true that it is similar to Amendment 1, but Amendment 14 is better. Finally, I would like to say that the EU is not just a partnership of a trade nature. The EU is also a Union for employment and social justice. Social policy has a major role to play in creating a Europe of citizens. With this report, Parliament wishes to make its contribution to strengthening the social dimension in European society. We hope that the Council and the Commission will take this contribution seriously and incorporate it into future social policy. The Lisbon Summit is an excellent opportunity to present a strategy of this nature. Mr. President, I would like to sincerely congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Andersson, on the report on the modernization of social protection presented here. As coordinator of the European People's Party in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I am very pleased with the compromise reached, for which Mr. Andersson has worked very hard. I am also very pleased that it has continued from a previous Parliament report, of which I was the rapporteur, and the lines of this report are partly also those of the previous one. The objective of the Commission's June 1999 communication, which forms the basis of the Andersson report, is to deepen collaboration between the Member States and the EU in the area of social protection. The other secondary objectives are: promoting employment, that is, ensuring that work provides a stable income; secondly, achieving secure pensions and viable pension systems; thirdly, promoting social inclusion; and fourthly, ensuring viable, high-quality health care. Gender-related aspects must play an important role in all of these objectives.

The first legal challenge arose when port development work began in early autumn 1999, without compensatory habitat improvements having been made. The Irish authorities therefore agreed to proceed with the grass removal, but this time they did so using mechanical means. The use of mechanical means led to a further legal challenge—to which I referred in my first answer—based on the argument that mechanical removal may have damaged the underlying layers of the mudflat and caused grass to proliferate in the estuary, with consequent environmental damage. To date, there has been no conclusive outcome of that legal challenge. The adoption of appropriate compensatory measures is a matter for the national authorities and does not require prior approval from the Commission. The Commission's role is to ensure that the standards set by the Wild Birds Directive are faithfully complied with, and there is no doubt that there would be problems with compensatory measures that have also caused damage. In this case, the Commission proposes seeking further clarification from the Irish authorities on the current position regarding compensatory measures and potential problems with the mechanical removal of grasses. At this time, we are not prepared to propose suspending funding from the Structural Funds. Mr. President, unfortunately, the specific case raised by Mrs. McKenna is not an isolated one. There are other examples of conservation in special scientific fields being harmed as a result of Community funding. Will the Commission consider instructing all Member States that, if in the future it is found that European environmental directives are being breached or that a proper environmental impact assessment is not being carried out, it will not only suspend funding but also withdraw the funds that have already been granted—in other words, reclaim the funds from the Member States? Only measures of this kind will curb these practices in the future. (SV) This is a matter of great importance. As Members of the European Parliament are surely aware, our predecessors in the Commission, Ritt Bjerregaard and Monika Wulf-Mathies, jointly sent a letter last year on the relationship between the Structural Funds, Structural Fund money, and the Habitats and Birds Directive. The message sent in this joint letter is still valid today. We cannot give countries money with one hand and with the other take them to court and, perhaps, force them to pay fines. That is why it is important that this be coordinated. Obviously, the result could lead us to have to make difficult decisions. However, in my opinion, the main effect is that countries will think carefully and, above all, will send their lists of Natura 2000 sites, so that we can monitor and conduct appropriate studies. Ireland has shortcomings in this regard, as do other Member States, but we hope that this pressure will yield results. Once again, I want to emphasize that the content of this letter is still valid.

I must confess that even in my own country, Flanders, we still have a long way to go. We too have recently been criticised by the Commission in this regard. Every reasonable person wants this framework directive to be used to put pressure on negligent politicians. The common position on this point is a farce, a completely voluntary effort, a real affront to the OSPAR agreements. Not to mention the deadlines for implementation, which can even be extended up to 34 years. Then my children will be older than I am now. Let's face it: this is not a serious proposal. Tomorrow we will have the choice between a weak and non-binding framework that will poison our children's future; or we can vote in favour of the amendments of my group, the rapporteur or the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy. Finally, one more point. In recent months, lobbying activities have intensified enormously and what has particularly struck me in this dossier is the pressure exerted by the Council of Ministers. In my country, even by the Flemish and Walloon Ministries of the Environment. The Ministers have preferred the weak common position to the strong position of our Parliament. I wonder whether this choice was made with the approval of the Green Ministers of the Environment of my country. Ladies and gentlemen, fine words are no longer enough. We must change course with great determination. Tomorrow, when we vote, we have the opportunity to say clearly that Europe is committed to a responsible and future-oriented water policy, which can only help to strengthen our credibility. The debate is suspended. It will resume at 9 p.m. Dialogue on Europe: perspectives for institutional reform The next item on the agenda is the Commission communication on Dialogue on Europe: perspectives for institutional reform. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is discussing this right now and is far from concluding its work today. So I am here essentially to talk to you, as your House's agenda indicates, about a new initiative by the Commission, which intends to give its response, which is not the only one, to the great challenge of mobilising all the players in the European construction. Among them, in the front row, there are you as parliamentarians, but I am also there as Commissioner, as well as the Council Ministers, the national parliamentarians and I would even say the officials who work in our institutions and who are committed and motivated by the European construction. This morning, in the long debate which I attended alongside President Prodi, many of you mentioned the democratic deficit, the remoteness of the European institutions. In saying this, I am not just raising the question - which has already been formulated clearly and forcefully by one of you: who does what? At the very least, citizens need to understand who does what among our various institutions. It is also essentially a question of knowing: what are we doing together and what do we intend to do in the future, in particular with the countries that will soon be joining?

From this perspective, activity-based management is the key tool for ensuring correspondence between objectives, actions and resources. The second point is human resources. This is the backbone of our action: staff are our true wealth, they are the wealth of the Commission. They are staff of the highest quality, a quality that is difficult - perhaps impossible - to find in individual national administrations, precisely because of the methods and criteria for recruiting staff. This is the impression I had when I came to the Presidency and which I have confirmed in my daily work. However, at the same time, I found very low morale on the part of the administration: before, there was pride, the pleasure of being part of an institution admired by all; today there is often demoralisation, generated by months and months of criticism. All this must change, and this is one of the fundamental motivations for our reform. Recruitment, career structure, mobility, disciplinary regime, everything is regulated with absolutely new criteria: more space for individual merit, credible and above all verifiable evaluation systems, continuous training and greater responsibility for managers. These are the areas in which we will move. Third point, also very delicate and key in the previous crisis: financial management. This is the crux that must ensure efficiency and security. We will create a management and control system in each Directorate-General. Today we have a fully centralised control system; with the reform we are moving to a control system that combines decentralisation of management controls and an effective central audit system: this means that we will have a central financial service, which will provide guidance and advice for financial management, decentralisation in each Directorate-General of the entire chain, i.e. programmes, commitments, contracts, expenditure and the related ex ante control systems, and an external audit service that will monitor all these operations. This is a complete revolution in the way the Commission works, it is a completely new organisation, which also requires a completely new culture. We are aware of the problems linked to this transition phase and it is this transition that has caused most concern among our staff: we will therefore adopt the necessary security and safeguard measures. With the reform, in fact, the Commission wants to become an administration that is a model of excellence throughout Europe and the world. We also want to be a model for the advanced use of information technology. We want to be a model of fully computerised administration. The Commission has been accused of being buried under paper and we will then be a paperless Commission, that is, a Commission without the use of paper instruments. This is to be more efficient internally and to multiply the use of new technologies externally. This is a revolution that is not only technical but a complete organisational revolution. I will now leave it to Neil Kinnock to explain the details of this reform, not without first thanking him for the intelligence, enthusiasm and energy with which he has carried out this work.

First of all, perhaps the most important aspect of the proposal is the idea - intrinsic to recycling and reusing waste - of using materials that can subsequently pollute less. Another important point is that waste - including waste containing PVC - and not just waste containing lead, cadmium and mercury - should not be incinerated or shredded. Parliament is involved in a debate on this elsewhere. Another issue is who should pay the costs. I agree with previous speakers when they say that 'the polluter pays', and our proposal underlines this better than ever. Although we know that in the end the costs will probably be passed on to consumers, it is the producers who must pay, and they are required to cover the costs prior to 2006 under some of the amendments. In any case, we prefer the first reading amendment. It is also important to set the percentage and the date by which vehicles must be made of recyclable materials, but I think the proposal sets deadlines that are very far away. Finally, Mr President, I believe it is necessary to encourage the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises which, rigorously approved and with the necessary authorisation, can promote the creation of jobs in this crucial sector, avoiding the monopolies of large companies. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament must face real responsibilities today. It is a question of establishing what we will do with the millions of vehicles that we abandon every year. In some of our States, voluntary environmental agreements have already been signed so that our ditches, canals and fields no longer fill up with those hideous and dangerous abandoned cars, from which a frightened chicken occasionally emerges. Naturally, I come from a country that is proud of its car industry and its commercial successes, both in Europe and in third countries. And I value its importance for the international prestige of my country. I am aware of the proactive behaviour of the European car industry which has implemented a vast research programme to develop a national information system for the dismantling of vehicles at the end of their life. I am aware of the difficulties the Council has encountered in finding a compromise. That is why today we must be understanding alchemists, concerned about our environment. This century must necessarily be the century of waste management. For me, in any case, the "polluter pays" principle must be applied. I am sure that the car industry, increasingly respectful of the environment, had foreseen this awareness. And it assumes its responsibilities. But it is up to the States to apply this directive, and let us be careful not to detail it too much, because the industrial traditions, the methods of the demolition and shredding professionals are different depending on whether we are in Italy or Finland. I oppose making the owners of the vehicles responsible. These men and women who travel in Europe pay for their cars, their national taxes, their catalytic converters, their fuel taxes, and therefore they already pay a high price for their splendid car and the freedom to travel.

Our general policy, however, is to recognize the inherent dignity and exceptional contribution of indigenous peoples to the development and plurality of society, which we consider particularly important in the context of the Northern Dimension, which we are trying to develop and which we are discussing with North America. The Commission shares the growing concern over the disappearance of the Russian journalist, Mr. Babitsky, and the conditions of independent media in Chechnya in general. This issue is at the top of our list of major concerns in the face of the critical situation of the civilian population in Chechnya, to which Mr. Posselt has just referred. There are alarming reports of human rights violations. It is clear that there has been a disproportionate use of force in this conflict. The Commission delegation in Moscow participated in a demarche of the European Union Troika on the 11th of this month. She highlighted her serious concerns regarding freedom of the press and freedom of expression and urged the Russians to clarify the circumstances of Mr. Babitstky's detention, taking into account their human rights obligations. We expect an appropriate response from the Russians. Meanwhile, the conclusions reached by the General Affairs Council earlier this week confirmed the message I gave today. We are ready to revisit the issue at the EU-Russia ministerial troika in Lisbon on 2 March, if necessary. Finally, regarding Cambodia and the Khmer Rouge, we fully agree that the highest-ranking Khmer Rouge leaders must be able to be prosecuted for the crimes for which they are responsible. I fully agree with the arguments put forward by Mr. Morillon. We strongly supported the troika's approach to Foreign Minister Hor Namhong on 4 February this year. The European Union has emphasized its full support for the UN's efforts regarding the need for a tribunal to prosecute the former leaders of the Khmer Rouge. Furthermore, we also welcome the ongoing dialogue between the two parties. The optimism of Kofi Annan, Secretary-General of the United Nations, about the chances of reaching an agreement on the proposed tribunal is encouraging. The Commission will continue to remind the Cambodian authorities of the problems relating to the rule of law, democratic principles, and human rights, through the EC-Cambodia Cooperation Agreement, which entered into force on 1 November. Debating human rights twice in a few days has been useful. I hope we will have more opportunities, but I hope we will have fewer examples of their violations in the years to come. Thank you very much, Mr. Patten. The debate is closed. The vote will take place at 6 p.m. Environmental disaster in the waters of the Danube The next item is the joint debate on the following motions for resolutions: B5-0164/2000 by Mr Leinen, on behalf of the PSE Group, B5-0167/2000 by Mr Maaten and Mr Thors, on behalf of the ELDR, B5-0168/2000 by Mr Oostlander and Mr Grossetête, on behalf of the PPE-DE,

Thus, we have been presented with an urgent request, which we have granted. We have been asked for €35 million. We agree to grant it and ask the Commission to be very vigilant so that, once the decision is taken, the sums are committed and disbursed as quickly as possible. This is a macro-financial aid. It has provoked reactions here and there because it does not respect the canons of liberal beauty, which consist of not intervening financially to support an administration. That is not our opinion. Our opinion is that it is essential to contribute to the establishment of an administration in Kosovo, and there is nothing absurd about directly contributing to the payment of public officials in that region. Furthermore, it would have been something very useful that we could have done in Russia throughout the 1990s to prevent the liquefaction of that state. The second major problem is that we have been asked, the donors have made commitments, and it is clear that we are the only ones paying. The others do not pay. We call for an end to this unilateral approach to financial solicitation. We want the Commission to commit to the amendments we propose in this regard. We want to link the delivery of all aid to the mobilization of funds owed by other donors. This is not to limit or skimp on our financial support for Kosovo, but, on the contrary, to ensure that our contribution is matched by that of other donors. From this perspective, the proposed aid package is a two-stage aid program, and the second tranche should be released as soon as donors have expressed their interest. Finally, we have three questions for the Commission in this regard: first, we must be regularly provided with the list and amounts of contributions from other donors. We want to know what others are paying at the time we are paying. Second, we want an accurate record of the calls for tender and the pace of their commitments. During the budgetary procedure, we were told that it was urgent to vote on the money for Kosovo, and according to our information, to date it has not yet been made public, nor has any call for tenders been organized. This is serious, as it delays the entire reconstruction process in Kosovo. Finally—and as a consequence of what I just said—we want the Commission to report very regularly, monthly, to the Committee on Budgets on the status of expenditure implementation. We have Commission documents that speak of firm commitments. We do not need firm commitments; we simply need commitments, and we need to know what is actually being paid and, above all, what is not being paid. Kosovo has suffered too much from payment delays. Mr. President, as we have spoken about Kosovo so often today, and it is time to take stock of what has already been achieved in Kosovo, if anything has been achieved.

With regard to the future provisions on aid to the steel industry, which will come into force in July 2002, we will ensure that rigorous discipline continues to be applied, the need for which is now shared by the industrial circles themselves. When we have finalised our proposal on the new rules and chosen the most suitable legal form, I will be happy to explain our vision to you. Well, Mr President, what I take home from this debate, for which I am very grateful to Parliament, is the intellectual and political support, I believe without distinction, of the European Parliament for competition policy, a fundamental appreciation for the work that the Commission is doing and a confidence that it can continue to do so in the future, things for which I am particularly grateful. We will continue, in particular with the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, but more generally with Parliament, the interinstitutional dialogue that has been established. In this regard, I liked your expression, Mrs Palacio: we must all row and, if possible, in the same direction. Competition is not an objective, as Mr Rapkay rightly pointed out, but a very important instrument in our European construction. As Mr von Wogau said at the beginning of the debate, competition is ultimately not an abstract thing: it is in the interests of citizens, it is the basis of the social market economy. I would also like to say that, in the European construction, competition has had and will continue to have a civil and not just economic value. Thank you, Commissioner Monti. The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. Criminal law protection of the Union's financial interests The next item is the report (A5-0002/2000) by Mrs Theato, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, containing Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of criminal law protection of the Union's financial interests. Mr President, year after year we learn, especially from the reports of the European Court of Auditors, that the European Union budget suffers losses due to waste, mismanagement, irregularities and - as is suspected - even outright fraud. Parliament has long been involved in initiatives to protect European taxpayers' money, which ultimately feeds the Union budget. In this context, the fight against fraud, aimed at revealing, punishing and preventing such practices, deserves particular attention. The establishment of UCLAF, the task force and the creation of the Anti-Fraud Office OLAF were important steps on this path, as was the regulation on the protection of the Community's financial interests and on-the-spot checks. In obvious cases of fraud, however, the Union can only impose administrative sanctions; so far, the Commission's requests for the restitution of funds received without due cause have had little success; criminal prosecution is instead reserved to the Member States. Since the two legal areas often overlap, and since actions against the Union budget are increasing in all countries and are also perpetrated by organised crime, the competences between Member States are not always clear.

And it was a woman who was elected. The other event concerns France, where a law was passed aimed at ensuring equal representation for women and men, following the declaration made in April 1999 at the "Women and Men in Power" congress. The ministers concerned committed to taking concrete measures and policies that would change the balance of power. We must congratulate Prime Minister Jospin for having endorsed this commitment in the clearest and most formal manner. Numerous declarations have been made and policies implemented in the Member States. Certainly, the figures speak for themselves. And the figures for Europe are still problematic. Women represent 24% of members of governments, and an average of 22% of members of national parliaments, a rate varying from 6% in some Member States to 40% in others. The number of women in committees exercising power, developing policies, is very low. Even in countries like Germany and Belgium, which have specific legal obligations regarding the number of representatives of both sexes, the participation rate of women in the various committees does not exceed 18%. Therefore, concrete policies must be promoted. We need a mixed policy that will include long-term political commitments, as is now the case in Sweden and Finland, where we now have a rate of 56 and 44% women in government, respectively. We need organization and statistical monitoring. We need appropriate control and structures based on the culture, mentalities, and specific problems of each region. And, naturally, these policies require a budget, financial support. Increasing the number of women, or, as French Prime Minister Jospin has stated, increasing women's influence in decision-making centres, is the best way to renovate political life, to change the approach to problems, to enrich political thinking with new ideas and experiences - those that women transmit through their different lifestyles and development. The recent initiative of the Finnish Presidency to establish indicators that record and reflect women's participation in decision-making centres is of great importance. These are indicators that encompass national parliaments, regional councils, municipal councils, and give a comprehensive picture of women's participation in each Member State. I believe that creating and supporting statistical data is a major political issue, a political tool or means for setting targets, comparing performance and supporting our efforts. Such an initiative for systematic monitoring is also included in the draft that I am going to submit for the fifth programme for women. It should be added that, while legislative measures and institutional interventions by Member States have an impact on the decision-making centres of political power, we do not observe the same effects in the private sector. From my contacts with very large European companies and multinationals on our continent, a dramatic picture emerges. There are companies that employ thousands of workers at European level, and often hundreds of thousands at global level, and in which the participation of women in management and leadership is less than 2%!

I fear very much that we are once again inheriting an authority that moves like an anonymous satellite across Europe: I would welcome such an authority like the devil holy water. I hope it does not come to that. I also welcome the White Paper. But do you think the food safety agency will have enough teeth to prevent something like the beef war we have experienced and to prevent France refusing to lift the ban? You have said that the Commission could refrain from granting subsidies to countries that act like France? Would you also suggest that the Commission could make interim payments, for example, similar to those that British farmers are now demanding? Mr President, Commissioner, you said in last week's plenary session that the future European Food Safety Agency would not be located on the periphery, but you did not say what you meant by periphery. For example, the work of the EU unit established in Dublin has shown that physical distance is no longer an obstacle to efficiency and networking. The primary tasks of the future food agency have been the subject of data collection, numerous announcements, and a great deal of coordination. Recommendations for the development of this food safety have been published and - as you have seen - scientific knowledge has been pooled and disseminated. With current technology, all of this can be done anywhere in the European Union. So I ask you where you plan to locate this agency. As for the composition of the authority: firstly, it will employ local scientists who will collaborate and consult with scientific experts in the particular fields being studied at a given time. In addition, this food safety authority will have a council. You will notice that we have not specified the composition of this council in the White Paper. This is an issue I expect to be discussed between Parliament and the Commission in the coming weeks and months. I envisage the council being made up of key players or representatives of key players. Its function will have to be set out in detail in the proposal I will present to the Commission in September. We have not done this yet, but it will be done in September. I do not expect the council to have any function of directing scientists in how to carry out their work. That would undermine the independence of scientific advice. But it would have overall competence, which would include, for example, asking this authority to investigate particular areas requiring research. Mr. Florenz asks whether Parliament will have a say in this matter. This is a matter that requires consideration and discussion. There may be a number of views on this. Some might argue that it would not be wise for Parliament or Members of Parliament - or, indeed, people appointed by Parliament - to be part of the council.

We know that this directive is based on EC law and not on EU law. Before the elections, however, all of us - the Council, the Commission, Parliament, the press, the trade unions and companies - worked to make this Europe more understandable to the citizens. We demanded that the citizen should be able to move from the EEC to the EC and then to the EU. The EU is now a clear concept. We will therefore be doing ourselves and the citizens no good if the document we issue is called an EC service provision card and not an EU card. The citizen is interested in the EU world, that is his world. I therefore call on the Council and the Commission to move in this direction. Mr President, it is later than expected at the beginning of this session, so I will try to be as brief as possible. One of the reasons why we have been so late is that we have rightly devoted part of our time today to reaffirming this Parliament's vigorous opposition to any form of xenophobia and racism. Of course, the directive does not directly address these issues. It does address the needs of the internal market, as well as the need to ensure flexibility and to adopt a reasonable and flexible attitude to enable third-country nationals to find employment both as employees and as self-employed. This in itself means avoiding unnecessary restrictions on foreigners simply because they are foreigners. We fully agree with this approach, which we believe to be appropriate and reasonable, and we will therefore support the broadest possible interpretation that we believe to be in accordance with the law. Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to highlight the excellent work done by Mrs Berger and, in general, by the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, which has included innovative ideas in this directive, which I hope will be taken up by the Commission and the Council. I have, however, tabled an amendment. Mr Berger, in Amendment No 2, to recital 6, you call for legal certainty. The first point on which we disagree is the three-month extension of the residence permit, which in reality creates legal uncertainty. You have expressed the concern, shared by Mr Wieland, that a worker might disappear once his work permit has expired, but it seems to me that this possibility is strengthened by the three-month extension. If the validity of the service provision card expires on a certain date, it must expire on that date; legal certainty demands it. Secondly, with regard to point (d) of Amendment No 10, which refers to the first Directive, it is provided that, for reasons of public security or public order, a Member State may challenge the validity of the card. There are already ex ante checks provided for in Article 4 of the Directive. Such a provision would make no sense for a worker from the Schengen area, who has already been checked to enter the first Member State; the second Member State may, ex ante, oppose a justified refusal to allow that worker to enter its territory.

(Parliament rejects the motion for a resolution) Motion for a resolution (B5-0136/2000) tabled by Mr Queiró, Mr Muscardini and Mr Berthu, on behalf of the UEN Group, on the Commission's strategic objectives for 2000-2005 (Parliament rejects the motion for a resolution) Motion for a resolution (B5-0142/2000) tabled by Mr Hautala, Mr Lannoye and Mr Maes, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group, on the strategic objectives 2000-2005 (Parliament rejects the motion for a resolution) Joint motion for a resolution on the Commission's five-year strategic programme (Parliament adopts the resolution) Joint motion for a resolution on the coherence of the Union's various policies with development policy (Parliament adopts the resolution) Motion for a resolution (B5-0125/2000) tabled by Mr Dupuis, among others, on behalf of the TDI Group, on the Commission's Committee on Human Rights United Nations (Parliament rejects the motion for a resolution) Madam President, I did not want to interrupt you during the vote, but I noticed that attention was waning and that you only mentioned the Greens when referring to the amendments from the Greens/European Free Alliance Group. Our group stands for unity in diversity. This is something we want to make clear to Parliament. For this reason, I would like to ask you to use the full name of our group. Very well, I will do so. (DE) Madam President, I should like to table an oral amendment, or rather a clarification, since the passage I am referring to is worded differently in various translations. I hope the author agrees with my proposal. The second sentence should read as follows: "..., weshalb diese Hilfen," then "without conditions and" is deleted, followed by the text "without the obligation of reciprocal orders from the parts of the European Union that must be made." The English version should read "and therefore that the aid must not be dependent on the reciprocal orders from the donor countries." If this clarification is included, we can accept the amendment. Is there opposition to taking this oral amendment into consideration? (The House agreed to the oral amendment) - On Amendment 9, I just wanted to clarify that in all cases—in this amendment, the term has been translated differently—we use the official name FYROM. Of course, I see no problem with that. (The Assembly expressed its agreement on the oral amendment) (Parliament adopted the resolution) Report (A5-0021/2000) by Mrs Frassoni, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the agreement between the European Parliament and the Commission concerning the detailed rules for implementing the new Council decision of 28 June 1999 - "Comitology" (1999/468/EC)

For the aquaculture and oyster farming sectors, defenseless against the pollution that inexorably washes up on the coasts, the consequences are very serious, not only because of the immediate pollution in the first few days, but also because of the subsequent loss of market share and consumer rejection of a product with all the guarantees, but which is itself compromised by the pollution. These are peripheral areas with a precarious economic balance, which has been severely damaged by this oil spill, which, unfortunately, is not an isolated incident. The main resources of these regions—like those of other neighboring areas—are those provided by nature. Nature that is too often damaged by human activity, which could be prevented with greater prudence and stronger control by the public authorities. "Prevention is better than cure," as the saying goes, and the budget also says. Ladies and gentlemen, prevention is very cheap compared to the cost of disasters like this. Mr. Fischler says he is always there when Parliament calls him. In the case of the Erika, however, he gave the impression – perhaps not to us, but certainly to the inhabitants of Brittany and Vendée – that he was not available as Commissioner for Fisheries, or only temporarily. As this Parliament already pointed out in its first resolution of 20 January of this year, the needs of fishing companies, oyster farming, and tourism, which are particularly affected, must be taken into account. That is why we called on the Commission then to urgently adopt measures for the fisheries sector by mobilizing special funds. Galicia and Brittany, both at the ends of the earth in Europe, have become sisters as a result of this oil spill. Nor can we understand why experiences like those of the Urquiola or the Amoco-Cádiz have not led to strengthening maritime legislation, both with regard to safety in the transport of dangerous goods and with regard to flags of convenience. We demand that this time be the last. We demand that we all learn lessons and swiftly amend our laws and fill the gaps that repeatedly confront us with the unbelievable and make the unbelievable a reality. The polluter pays principle seems appropriate and, moreover, necessary. It is now time for the polluters to start paying, because so far, it has been the victims and the taxpayers who have paid. And the polluters should not only pay, but also clean up the affected areas. I am therefore pleased with Mr. Fischler's response, especially his recognition of the need for retroactive measures and a rapid response to the requests received. On behalf of my group, the Socialist Group, I would like to send a message of solidarity to those affected: to the fishermen, farmers, and entrepreneurs who ensure that the sea delivers its products to the markets on time, to the mayors and political leaders, as well as the volunteers who participated in the cleanup. They all rest assured of our solidarity. I would like to ask the Commissioner two questions. Parliament adopted a resolution calling for the polluter pays principle to be applied in this case and for both the shipowner and the cargo owner to be held liable for the damage.

Mr President, I agree that from the point of view of efficiency and the analysis of services offered in relation to costs, progress still needs to be made. But why always under the banner of "privatization" and "liberalization"? I myself do not understand that at all, and I am a business leader. Except that we are not concerned with ensuring identical conditions of access to postal services for everyone, but that we are only concerned with the conditions for capital development for companies in large urban areas. However, Members of Parliament must be the representatives of all citizens, and that means that they are obliged to think not in terms of business economics but in terms of political economy. Very concretely for postal services, that means, firstly, that the question of employment must be a priority. I have nothing against liberalization and privatization, but the premises must be in agreement. Secondly, we must have a guarantee that there will be no reduction in postal services for citizens. Examples from Germany and Sweden show that this threat is very real. Mr Stenmarck, Sweden is the only country where, after liberalization, prices have radically exceeded those in all other Member States of the European Union. This is precisely one possible effect. We must ensure that this does not happen. Thirdly, it remains essential, firstly, to ensure a universal postal service at a reasonable price for every citizen, everywhere. Secondly, a single price must be observed for all Member States. And thirdly, mail delivery and collection must be guaranteed every working day. As for the question of the price/service ratio for the respective weight categories of postal items, further price reductions are possible. This is also what the Post Office itself states. We must not stay at more than 300g; the analysis shows that a minimum limit of 150g must be guaranteed so that this can still be counted. I believe that today's debate has been beneficial and important insofar as Mr Bolkestein knows the position of this Parliament and can therefore also take account of the problems from the outset. Mr President, the 1997 directive, published on 21 January 1998, which initiated a partial liberalisation of postal services in Europe, provided for a subsequent revision, albeit in a complicated form, since it was to be the subject of a Commission proposal before the end of 1998, then to be decided before 1 January 2000, and finally to enter into force before 1 January 2003. However, at the moment, the revision is at ground zero. The first two stages have not been complied with, which, logically, should jeopardise the third. First question: in any case, were the deadlines provided not too short? Clearly, yes. It is really difficult to see how the Commission could have assessed, before the end of 1998, as provided for in Article 7 of the directive, the effects of a text which entered into force in February of that year.

I encourage Members to ensure with their votes today that we succeed in establishing a sound foundation for Europe in the short term, if not in the longer term. Mr. President, my first words of thanks go to the rapporteur, Mr. Schmidt, to my colleague, Mr. Goebbels, and to my colleagues from the Villiers and Lulling Group, who, despite holding differing positions on some points, have always displayed an extraordinarily constructive attitude. As the rapporteur has already pointed out, we are probably discussing one of the most important issues we will discuss in this parliamentary term. Collective investment schemes have long been the primary savings instrument, the instrument through which millions of individual citizens, non-experts, non-professionals, consign or transfer their life savings to these institutions. This would be the first reason to say that liberalization must proceed, but with caution. Why? Because the failure of a bank is a problem that can be solved by any government. The bankruptcy, the suspension of payments, of an organization of this nature would create a political, social, and civic problem of incalculable consequences. A second argument leads me to emphasize the need for prudence in the regulation of these organizations. It is my belief in the social market economy, which is based on a functioning market, but one that operates subject to certain rules designed to guarantee the general interest, which, at this particular time and on this particular issue, is limited to consumer protection. This basic principle of liberalization, increased competition, and increased investment opportunities, linked to prudence for the protection that consumers deserve, is what has determined and inspired my Group's position on most of the controversial issues that have been raised here. First, the problem of investment in non-harmonized organizations, that is, in organizations that fall outside the scope of this directive. It is obvious that, by expanding the proposal we are studying here, the possibilities, the investment range of collective investment schemes, those schemes that remain outside will be forced to invest in high-risk funds. And it would be foolish to allow regulated schemes, protected schemes, to invest in schemes dedicated to such risky investments as those I have mentioned. Secondly, the issue of derivatives is one that has divided us most, internally within the Group and in relation to other Groups. We have reached a compromise solution. We all agree that investment in derivatives must be limited by regulation, by law, to prevent a harmonized fund from losing all its assets through an investment in high-risk products. It is obvious that this risk is greater when the investment is in derivatives not traded on regulated markets, the famous OTCs. We believe we have reached an acceptable compromise solution, and I congratulate myself on that. As this topic does not end here but will return to this House, I would like to make some reference to the working method between the Commission and Parliament. The texts we are discussing here are old, and they were already old when they arrived in this Parliament because they had undergone significant changes during the Finnish Presidency of the Council. We are faced with two options: return the matter to the pen, that is, return the proposals to the Commission so it can send us a harmonized text, or continue moving forward.

Undoubtedly, the events in Kosovo and in the Balkans as a whole have touched all of our hearts and minds; there have been important developments in the Middle East, where the President of Parliament played a significant role on her recent visit; some important things have happened to pave the way for the Europe-Africa Summit, which I was privileged to attend with the Portuguese Presidency; there was the major meeting in Portugal, in Vilamoura, with the eighteen Latin American countries to forge closer relations between the European Union and the countries of Latin America. Undoubtedly, Chechnya was also close to our hearts, and I will have the opportunity to say a few words on it at the end of my remarks, after an important discussion this morning with the representative of the Council of Europe, Mr Álvaro Gil-Robles, about his recent visit to the region. But I understand that you have invited me here to report to you directly on foreign policy and, above all, security policy in Europe after Helsinki. I will briefly address this; If you wish to put any questions to me during Question Time, I will be happy to answer them. Allow me to remind you that the Helsinki Summit, under the Finnish Presidency, took place not a century ago, but only two months ago. Fundamental decisions were taken in Helsinki for foreign and security policy on our continent. These were essentially three types of decisions, and I would like to address them. The first was the decision to set up three types of committee within the European Union to take decisions in the field of crisis management: first, a Committee for Political and Security Affairs; second, a Military Committee representing the Chiefs of Defence of the fifteen Member States of the Union; and third, there were decisions concerning the relations that the European Union must maintain with third countries and other organizations. I am referring in particular to the relations between the European Union and the Atlantic Alliance, and to the relations between the European Union and those countries that, although geographically part of Europe, do not belong, or at least do not currently belong, to the European Union. I will essentially limit myself to these three points to keep you informed of developments. First, and as regards the decision-making bodies, the Political and Security Committee (PSC), set up at the last General Affairs Council, met for the first time this morning, March 1, 2000. Thus, two months after the Helsinki Declaration and decision, we are having the first meeting of the PSC in the European Union. I had the opportunity to meet with it this morning and to have lunch with the representatives. I can tell you that you can be satisfied. The fifteen states have appointed expert diplomats at ambassadorial level to address, under their responsibility, one of the most important issues we will have to face in the coming months. Second, the Military Committee, representing the various Chiefs of Staff of the fifteen states, will hold its first meeting on March 7, just over two months after the Helsinki Declarations. This Military Committee, as you can imagine, has several responsibilities.
