In a preliminary, interim phase, its main task will be to advise the Council and myself and to make the initial decisions on how to establish the definitive bodies, which we absolutely want to have operational by the end of 2000 or the beginning of next year.

Furthermore, an extraordinary budget line must be used, as extraordinary as the catastrophic situation is. First of all, we would like to express our condolences to all the families and communities that have lost a member in this terrible tragedy. The loss of life is what truly makes this particular disaster extraordinary in Europe. It is regrettable that we do not have an instrument with which to provide assistance in situations like this. I would like to thank the Commissioner for his detailed statement on this matter and his proposal that we organize ourselves at the European level to provide assistance to Member States and those in their regions that suffer tragedies like this. That is important. Another thing we must remember is that in the past, we did have a budget line. It was very small. It couldn't do much, but Members of this House repeatedly abused it by proposing actions when the disasters were not even significant. Officials and ministers from Member States went to Brussels, whispered to the Commission, obtained a few euros, and scored a political point by returning with aid for their constituencies. So there wasn't much sympathy for that budget line when it was abolished. I think we should reinstate that budget line. When there was the earthquake in Greece, which was a major disaster, the Community lacked an instrument with which to offer its condolences or solidarity to the Greeks. The same thing happened when there were floods in France and the same thing now. Those are major disasters, and we should have an instrument, which we don't have. We must reinstate that instrument and we must make the rules very strict so that only in situations where major disasters occur do we resort to that particular instrument. We can save it from one year to the next and ensure that when something major happens, we have an instrument to deal with it. This time in Ireland, it wasn't as serious, although we had very strong Atlantic gales. We have also had floods in Ireland, so I want to express my solidarity with the people of Ireland who have suffered through them. Ladies and gentlemen, we should not, all of us, lose our memory. It is true that there is a joint decision by the Commission and Parliament aimed at abolishing the emergency lines. It's also true that there's a lot of European money—Commissioner Barnier has indicated that, in the case of oyster farming and agriculture, Article 30 of the Rural Development Regulation would be used; in the case of forestry, Article 33; in the case of businesses, the derogations from the competition law set out in Article 87(2) of the Treaty; and in the case of public facilities, the Structural Funds. Even so, not a single cent more than what was distributed before the storm will be released today to demonstrate concrete, active solidarity. It's simply a matter of states playing the game of connecting vessels and taking here what they will give elsewhere.

It is clear that e-mail and e-commerce will become increasingly important in the future, and I believe that this is a strong point for our post office. We know that by 2002, around 1.2 million jobs will remain unfilled in the field of e-commerce, because there is a shortage of workers with the necessary qualifications to meet the needs of this market. In my opinion, this is an area in which the post office must intervene with training courses, as well as professional and continuing education to prepare its employees to meet this interesting challenge. Existing post offices in rural areas naturally have a strategic advantage, since the post office can rely on a dense distribution network throughout Europe; even the smallest village has a post office. In the future, e-commerce will increasingly use the post office, as many people order goods and send invoices and other documents via e-mail and websites. This also increases the importance of the physical processing of these transactions, which gives new meaning to collection, sorting, transport and delivery. I believe this is an opportunity that we cannot miss for the future. Our job as politicians is to defend the interests of consumers; we want them to be able to get the most out of the money they earn from their work, and reducing the costs of postal services is therefore a key objective. We will have to check, including by benchmarking, how much a consumer currently spends on a public postal worker and how much on a private postal worker. Transparency is also essential for trade unions, because the position of a trade unionist who has to represent his colleagues in a private company is very different from that of a trade unionist for a public postal service; however, I believe that it is also important for the trade union to have similar economic and social framework conditions in order to get the best for workers in a spirit of fairness, loyalty and solidarity. I also think that in future it will be necessary to make the universal service more attractive: we will have to define it precisely, draw up a list of the planned services and put them out to tender. In my opinion, in rural areas, where there is a risk that costs cannot be covered, services should be specified by a regulatory body which should call for tenders to allow all market forces to participate - and therefore also existing postal services - thus following a strategy that is best for the consumer and aimed at stimulating efficiency. In my opinion, we should avoid providing additional subsidies; instead, we must ensure that private companies and consumers can benefit from the new system. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, postal services, like any European public service, contribute to the social cohesion of the Community territory in accordance with Article 16 of the Amsterdam Treaty. By ensuring tariff equalisation, that is to say, strict equality of citizens and economic actors with respect to the cost of the service, by assuming the obligations of the universal service and by adapting to a requirement of quality, postal services share our concern to ensure equal treatment of the different territories and the people who live there.

It is true that economic aid, in this respect, is certainly an essential element of the possibilities for action that will be given to those who are present on the ground. I repeat here the statement that Doris Pack has just made to us, and I insist on the fact that we in the European Parliament have to fulfil our responsibilities in this regard, but obviously by asking that we are not alone. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to warmly thank the rapporteur, our colleague Mr Brok, for his report. If the Council had worked as quickly as Mr Brok did, we would indeed be much further ahead. We must truly deplore the Council's negligence in this matter. In his report, the rapporteur quite rightly starts from the principle that we have a duty to provide rapid assistance but also, quite rightly, from the principle that this assistance cannot be offered without limits and without discernment. In this regard, I would particularly like to emphasise Amendment No 5, which makes it very clear that the exceptional financial aid appropriations can only cover the budgetary needs of Kosovo's public, semi-public and municipal administrations and institutions that are controlled directly or indirectly by UNMIK. It must be clear, Commissioner, that we support UNMIK, that we support the institutions set up by the United Nations - in particular, of course, the fourth pillar - and it is unacceptable that we support parallel structures that have been formed and continue to exist in Kosovo. What should be done with this money? I would particularly like to emphasise human rights. In Kosovo, the West fought for human rights. What is happening in Kosovo today? It has been possible to put an end to the large-scale expulsions carried out by the Serbs, but unacceptable incidents are taking place almost every day; People are being killed, people are being prevented from living where they are and as they wish. Every day there are attacks against Serbs, Roma, Bosnians, but also, as before, against Albanians. If this information is correct, I was truly frightened to learn that an Albanian doctor, who worked - certainly with great difficulty - at the hospital located in the Serbian part of Mitroviça, finally gave up operating there for his fellow citizens because his life was regularly threatened. These are incidents and situations that we cannot tolerate. I heard - I don't know if it's true or not - that the Serbs are even continuing to exploit a mine in Kosovo, in the Serbian part. Rumors claim that Serbian militias are still active. I don't care whether the threats or crimes are committed against a Serb, a Roma, a Bosnian, or an Albanian. I don't care who is working to dismember and partition Kosovo. What matters to me is that the bodies we fund achieve the goal we want to achieve, which is a multi-ethnic Kosovo, a coexistence in Kosovo.

The Commission supports this codification and will work to draft a codified version as soon as possible after the proposals have been adopted, subject to its right of initiative. However, I cannot adopt the wording of the recital as is. Furthermore, the Commission believes that some of the amendments tabled by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs would substantially modify the content of the first proposal. Accordingly, the Commission regrets that it cannot accept the following amendments to the first proposal. Amendment 8 would make implementation of this directive more difficult by replacing the more precise reference to the instruments referred to in "Article 19 of this Directive" with the more general reference to investments "covered by this Directive." Furthermore, this amendment could lead to divergent interpretations in different Member States, as they will likely seek relevant instruments in other articles of the directive. Amendment 16 jeopardizes investor protection, as the prohibition on providing security with the depositary is a contradictio in termini. Stock exchanges, clearing houses, and securities exchanges also do not automatically cover securities lending transactions carried out through them, unlike securities trading. Therefore, we cannot adopt the proposed amendment. Amendment 42 addresses an issue that was not modified by the proposal and has not raised any problems since the directive entered into force. I therefore see no reason to delete Article 22(3), which leads me to reject the amendment. Amendment 44 is unacceptable because requiring non-harmonized funds to comply with the requirements of the regulations "imposed by the Directive" relating to credit, lending, short selling, and the depositary creates a situation in which very few funds, for example Swiss funds, can offer their investment services. This is inconsistent with the Commission's objective of broadening the range of investment modalities. Furthermore, I do not rule out that the wording of the amendment violates the GATT agreements. We also cannot accept the proposed amendments to the first paragraph of Article 22a of Amendment 47, as they contradict the principle of diversification enshrined in Article 22, especially given that UCITS are required to disclose a benchmark in their prospectuses, as agreed by the Council. However, the main problem with the first proposal lies in Parliament's amendment, which considers the possibility of using over-the-counter instruments for general investment purposes. The Commission notes that the national law of some Member States already provides for the use of OTC derivatives for general investment purposes. However, the Commission has decided to suspend its view due to the high risks inherent in this type of investment compared to more traditional financial instruments. In my opinion, OTC derivatives can create problems because they are not liquid instruments, their prices are difficult to estimate, and they entail counterparty risks that are not hedged. It seems inconsistent to adopt an overly cautious approach to investments in non-harmonized funds or deposits while allowing free rein to invest in much riskier instruments such as OTC derivatives.

Once again, I would like to thank not only the rapporteur but the committee as a whole for the quality of the work carried out. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. Closure of the annual session I declare the 1999-2000 annual session closed. (The sitting will close at 10.41 p.m.) Opening of the annual session I declare the 2000-2001 session of the European Parliament open. Agenda Mr President, the second item on this morning's agenda is the recommendation for second reading on cocoa and chocolate products, for which I am the rapporteur. Yesterday at around 8.30 p.m., I learned purely by chance that the vote was to take place at noon today. However, it seems to me that it was scheduled for noon tomorrow. I am therefore completely unprepared and have not even had the opportunity to prepare the voting list or check whether roll-call votes are necessary. As you know, this issue is quite controversial and has also received considerable media attention. I have been a Member of this Parliament for 10 years and, as rapporteur, I have always been informed when the order of voting has been changed. I would therefore ask that this vote be postponed until tomorrow. This would solve my problem without, I believe, inconveniencing anyone, since it is a relatively short vote. Mr President, we have nothing against this postponement of the vote. I would simply like to insist that the other scheduled votes, in particular on the Lisbon Summit, also take place tomorrow. On this condition, we have nothing against the postponement. According to information from the relevant services, the list of votes scheduled for tomorrow is quite long. Mr President, like Mr Lannoye, I was surprised yesterday evening to hear that the vote on my report at second reading was also scheduled for 12 noon. The political groups have urged me to urge you not to hold the vote at 12 noon, but tomorrow, as the political groups have not had the opportunity to request separate roll-call votes. It was a great surprise that the vote was scheduled for 12 noon. On behalf of many others, I would also like to ask that the vote be scheduled for tomorrow. Mr Blokland, the officials of the relevant departments inform me that your report is already scheduled for tomorrow's vote. I now ask the House whether it agrees to postpone the vote on the Lannoye report until tomorrow. If so, this will be deemed agreed. Annual legislative programme (continuation) The next item is the continuation of the debate on the European Commission's annual legislative programme for 2000. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, if the citizens of Europe are looking for that Europe, they are looking for it above all in Brussels and, above all, at the Commission. As a parliamentarian, I'm not happy about this, but I have to acknowledge it, at least for the time being and for the time being. But it also means that the Commission faces an enormous challenge. If you want to bring about the major turnaround you spoke of, Mr. Commission President, then you have to start doing it damn quickly.

I am also pleased to confirm that I will be attending the next meeting of the Joint Assembly, which will be held in Nigeria in March. The Commission would like to give the Joint Assembly a more important role, particularly in promoting a more intensive political dialogue with our development partners. The Commission agrees with the rapporteur that combating poverty remains the most important objective of development policy and will always play a key role. However, to develop, countries must be actively involved in the global economic system. Regarding trade with our development partners, the Commission wants to guarantee that any new measure takes into account the specific economic and social constraints of ACP countries. Ms. Lucas mentioned that the Stabex and Sysmin systems should be continued. I disagree. This system has not proven effective because, in reality, it benefits very few of the 71 countries. I consider it too slow. Therefore, it is understandable that developing countries welcome the new system because it will be more flexible. With regard to the future accession of countries to the Lomé Convention—for example, East Timor—I can only reiterate what I recently said in the European Parliament's Committee on Development and Cooperation, namely that the door is open. The applicants themselves decide whether they wish to knock. After that, we will take a position. Regarding Cuba's application to accede to the Lomé Convention, the Commission notes that, according to its recent statement, the ACP countries support Cuba's application. The EU has always considered that a constructive attitude towards Cuba is appropriate, as reflected in the EU's common position. However, it must be acknowledged that the negotiations will be difficult. As for Côte d'Ivoire, I can report that the total amount of EUR 28 million has been repaid, as agreed after the financial irregularities were verified. As for the budgetary financing of the European Development Fund, I can say that this is currently being reviewed. The Commission is in favor, but we cannot provide any further details on the timing or procedure at this stage. Regarding Article 366A, I can say that during the negotiations on a new partnership agreement, a new procedure for dealing with violations of human rights, democratic principles, and the rule of law was introduced. As things currently stand, following the adoption of the Amsterdam Treaty, Parliament will be informed of all decisions on the basis of Article 300, and the Commission will continue to respect Parliament's decisions in this matter. There are no plans to use the assent procedure in Parliament in connection with such decisions. This would require an amendment to the recently adopted Amsterdam Treaty. Finally, a comment on the South Africa Agreement, which the rapporteur also mentioned. I am pleased—I almost want to say happy—to be able to inform you this evening, at the end of this debate, that the South African President has today promised to resolve the outstanding issues, as proposed to South Africa by the EU Council of Foreign Ministers last Monday.

(Parliament adopts the legislative resolution) Report (A5-0019/2000) by Mr. Di Pietro, on behalf of the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, on the draft Council act concluding the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union (9636/1999 - C5-0091/1999 and SN 5060/1999 - C5-0331/1999 - 1999/0809(CNS)) Before the vote, Madam President, I should like to denounce the absence of the Presidency-in-Office of the Council. I believe that in these matters of the third pillar, in these conventions that are so important for the construction of this area of freedom, security and justice, it is unacceptable that the Presidency-in-Office of the Council is not here today. And then, Madam President, I would like to discuss the problem of translations. I'll give just one example because we don't have time, but this is a case in which translations are very important because they are all very precise legal concepts. In Amendment 83 in Italian, which is the original, it says that "il minore deve essere assistito da una persona di sua fiducia o da un perito o legale externo." This "legale externo," in the French version, becomes a "avocat neutre," and I don't know what a "avocat neutre" is. I think it's a contradiction in terms. But, in the Spanish version, the lawyer disappears; there is no longer a lawyer. Madam President—you have said this several times—this is a very serious problem. In this matter, I believe that legal linguists will have to do very thorough work to arrive at a reasonable version. I completely agree, Mrs. Palacio Vallelersundi, this is not the first time this has happened, and it is indeed very worrying. We will study this problem and check all the translations. Madam President, I just wanted to join Mrs. Palacio Vallelersundi's before the vote begins to say that I deeply regret the Council's absence from this debate, when such important votes are being held on the Third Pillar. I would like to ask you, Madam President, to express to the Council our hope that it will attend votes like this in the future. I fully agree; I am aware that its absence is unusual, and I will convey this. Regarding Amendment 31, Madam President, I would like to add that in the sentence—I will read it in French, which is the version I have here at hand—s'il est exigé par le droit de l'Etat membre requis ou requérant que la personne donne son consentiment. Add the words "par le droit de l'Etat membre requis ou requérant". (Parliament adopts the legislative resolution) Madam President, I just wanted to say that, in the heat of the previous situation, I forgot to tell you that, in the last paragraph of my report on the deficit, in the Spanish version, there is an error: instead of saying that "we consider the proposal to be correct", an "s" was left out and it says "the proposal does not seem correct", which is exactly the opposite. That was the point, nothing else. Motion for a resolution (B5-0132/2000) tabled by Mrs Bonino, inter alia, on behalf of the TDI Group, on the Commission communication on the five-year strategic objectives

This must contain minimum requirements regarding the age and characteristics of ships for access to Community waters and ports, as well as a general principle of environmental liability that allows for a clear definition of the liability of individual actors, particularly charterers, and severe penalties for infringements. The Commission must ensure the coordination of information activities, must not shy away from disputes over the negligence of certain major ports or shipowners, and must place the issue of flags of convenience at the heart of the negotiations with Malta and Cyprus. I would recall that the Erika was registered in Valletta. However, Member States must not shift their own responsibility onto the Union either, because the safety of all depends on the precision and effectiveness (and therefore the means) of port State control. We must and will be particularly vigilant in the coming months to ensure that the victims, who undoubtedly bear no responsibility for this disaster, are fully compensated by the perpetrators, and that this time the lessons of maritime safety are truly learned from the oil spill, thus deterring those responsible for it once and for all from endangering the lives of our coastal communities. The most effective prevention is to threaten every potential perpetrator with severe financial penalties. Katiforis report (A5-0017/2000) We agree that fishing is one of the economic sectors with the greatest interest in protecting the marine environment. However, it must be taken into account that many causes contribute to damage to the marine environment: pollution and contamination by oil tankers and other maritime traffic, industry, the pressure of human activity on coastal areas, and, of course, unregulated fishing. However, it should be emphasized that small-scale coastal fishing is a good example of how fishing can be reconciled with sustainable development that is not destructive to the marine environment. We believe it is possible to reconcile a fishery management policy based on the conservation of the marine environment with the interests of the fishing sector. To do so, however, it is important to take into account the interdependence between income from fishing and increased fishing effort. Consequently, the Common Fisheries Policy must adopt measures and provide appropriate financial resources to safeguard the income of those who depend exclusively on fishing, particularly during periods of stagnation or reduction in fishing. This underlines the importance of the proposals we have put forward with this objective in mind. The Commission communication sets out a series of objectives and proposals, stressing the need to continue efforts in the areas of control and surveillance, to adopt new technical measures regarding the selectivity of fishing methods, to monitor the application of legislation, and so on. In its communication, however, the Commission simultaneously reveals that it does not consider itself in a position to enforce compliance with these legal provisions. There is no lack of existing measures and appropriate means, as the Commission has at its disposal a whole range of binding regulations, measures, and decisions (of international and Community origin) in the areas of fishing and the protection of the marine environment.

Unlike Mrs Kaufmann, I am not in favour of strengthening control over the European Central Bank because I am in favour of its independence. But politically, control must be established appropriately. It is also a matter of establishing the Commission, Council and Parliament triangle in the area of foreign and security policy, an area where everything has so far been far too concentrated on the Council side alone, and of paying particular attention to primitive crisis management measures, for which the powers lie solely with the Commission. All of this has not been sufficiently included in this general concept. We must examine whether changes are necessary to this end within the framework of the Intergovernmental Conference. The Portuguese Presidency of the Council has also stated that it will initiate discussions on this subject with a view to considering an extension of the mandate. I would also like to point out another important point. The debates we are having these days, for example, on the government of a European country, nevertheless show that we must establish that the European Union has an intellectual and moral orientation and aims at the rule of law, the Community and the common good and that binding fundamental rights must therefore also be incorporated into the Treaty because this will constitute an important stabilizer. I ask those who still have great reservations in this area to ask themselves whether the time has not come to perceive this connection and to show the necessary courage to achieve the necessary progress in the field of fundamental rights. The European Union does not need – or almost does not need – new instruments, it does not need new powers. What it needs are the instruments that allow it to use its powers. That is why we must ensure that the instruments function in such a way that we can carry out, on behalf of the citizen, the tasks that are already formally entrusted to us by the Treaty. I believe that this is where the efforts of this Intergovernmental Conference should be particularly focused. If we manage to make progress in this area, we will also be able to consider the historic mission of enlarging the European Union. This is where the decisive emphasis must be placed. I am convinced that, under your leadership, dear Presidency of the Council, this element will evolve in a positive way. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you will have understood from listening to various speeches that the idea of placing trust in the Portuguese Presidency, of not making its work more difficult by postponing the start of the Intergovernmental Conference, strongly prevailed, not without contrast, within the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and among the chairmen of the political groups in this Parliament. I can assure you that it was not easy to do so last week in the committee that I chair, but ultimately, we decided to bet on the Portuguese Presidency and we would like to win this bet.

Dialogue on Europe: Challenges of Institutional Reform The next item on the agenda is the Commission's communication - "Dialogue on Europe: Challenges of Institutional Reform". Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is currently in the process of debating this matter and its work is far from being completed today. I have therefore come to speak to you, as indicated on the agenda of your Assembly, about a new initiative that the Commission is proposing to provide its response, which is not the only response, to a major challenge that must mobilise all the players in European integration, first and foremost of which are naturally the parliamentarians that you are, but also the Commissioner that I am, but also the ministers who sit on the Council and the national parliamentarians and I would even add the officials who work in our various institutions and who are committed to and motivated by this European integration. This morning, in the long debate I attended alongside President Prodi, many of you spoke about the democratic deficit and the distance between us and the European institutions. In saying this, I am not just trying to ask the question - one of you said it very clearly and forcefully - who does what? And the least we can do is ensure that citizens understand who does what between our different institutions. The question is also immediately what we are doing together and what we want to do together in the future, particularly with the countries that will join us. So, this democratic deficit also concerns us and that is why, the very day after the opening of the Intergovernmental Conference, during which I will have the honour of representing the Commission alongside Mr Prodi, and working, I repeat, in close confidence with your two representatives, Mr Brok and Mr Tsatsos, we decided, a short while ago, within the College, to launch "Dialogue for Europe and on Europe", to take our part in this direct contact with the citizens. All the Commissioners have committed themselves, each time they have to go to a country, and not only to their country of origin, to a region - for my part, this happens three or four times a month - to dedicate a moment of their schedule to a direct dialogue with citizens, not only with the elites or institutional leaders that we usually meet, to also establish direct contact, in a university, in a high school, in a factory, to go and meet people, answer questions and listen. This will therefore be the part that we will play, as you yourselves will play, in this necessary effort, this burning obligation, which consists of reducing the democratic deficit, that is to say the distance of citizens from what we are doing. We wish to conduct this initiative in cooperation with the Member States, in liaison with the European Parliament. We will make a regular summary of it, so that the state of opinion is properly measured and we can adjust or redirect it. We also wish to conduct it in consultation with national parliaments, local elected representatives, non-governmental organizations, socio-professional circles and the media. Opinion leaders, political groups and parties, European and national parliamentarians, elected representatives, as I just mentioned, of local authorities or national parliaments, the Committee of the Regions, the Economic and Social Committee and civil society organizations, and academia will be involved.

I can tell you, Mr President, that the Bureau has decided in principle to publish a register on the internet in which Members must declare their financial interests, and the Quaestors are examining the legal aspects involved. However, a decision is expected shortly. (Parliament approved the Minutes.) Reform of the Commission The next item is the Commission communication on the reform of the European Commission. I give the floor to Commission President Romano Prodi. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in July of last year, I solemnly made a commitment to reform the Commission here before you. I would like to briefly recall what happened in July: the crisis in the previous Commission had led to its resignation; I had just been appointed President of the Commission, and you had approved my appointment. The culmination of this was my commitment to reform the Commission: a radical reform that must lead to a veritable revolution in the way the Commission works. Today, this commitment has finally been fulfilled: the reform is presented to you here, in a well-structured White Paper just adopted by the Commission. I would like to emphasize that, in this case too, the Commission has decided unanimously, with one voice. In brief, what are the main focuses of this reform? First, defining political priorities and, through the targeted allocation of resources, translating them into concrete actions. This is the core of the system, because with the help of priorities and the targeted allocation of resources, policymakers will be able to assert their leading role and fully assume their responsibility. To this end, we have developed a mechanism entirely new in political programming: a system that enables the Commission to establish annual political guidelines, then, on these basis, organize the budgetary procedure, set concrete objectives for the Directorates-General, and—crucially—monitor the relationship between available resources and assigned tasks. From this perspective, activity-based management is the key tool for ensuring the alignment of objectives, activities, and resources. The second point concerns human resources. They are the backbone of our actions: staff are our true capital, the Commission's capital. These staff possess extremely high qualities, which, precisely because of our recruitment procedures and criteria, are rarely – or even never – found in the individual administrations of the Member States. This impression, which I gained upon taking over the Commission Presidency, was confirmed in my daily work. At the same time, however, I have noticed a very poor mood among the administrative staff: whereas they were once proud and happy to belong to an institution admired by all sides, they are now demoralized by months of criticism. All of this must change, and this is one of the main reasons for our reform. Recruitment policy, career development, mobility, disciplinary procedures – all of this will be governed according to completely new criteria: greater consideration of individual merit, credible and, above all, verifiable evaluation systems, ongoing training, and greater responsibility for managers. We will take action in these areas. The third point, which is also quite delicate and has played a significant role in the crisis we are currently experiencing, is financial management.

Mr President, speaking last, I have the privilege, Commissioner, of telling you that this House is largely in favour of your initiative and has shown that it has complete and, in my opinion, entirely justified confidence in the way you are steering this ship. But, since we are in the same boat, we want to row too. This is why I believe it is absolutely necessary to establish an interinstitutional dialogue to reach a safe harbor, to fine-tune and qualify this very important reform. The many ideas that have been put forward in this House could be divided into three broad categories. Firstly, some Members, and in particular Mrs Randzio-Plath, Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, are concerned about whether this new system of legal exceptions will be fully compatible with the Treaty. I share their concern and believe that we must examine this aspect. Secondly, there is the question of legal certainty for businesses. It is true, Commissioner, that the Commission is not a machine for producing legal certainty. We all agree. But it is no less true, and all the groups in this House have repeated this, that the European industrial fabric is a fabric of small and medium-sized enterprises and that the Commission often plays a role of auctoritas, of legitimation, of legitimacy, of the internal market. In this regard, I would like to express my opinion on the remarks made by Mr. Karas. There have only been nine rejection decisions. But here, I will speak from my experience as a lawyer. How many times does a lawyer with two companies and a project not change that project, faced with a Commission orientation given ex ante, to ensure that it complies with these competition rules! This is an aspect that must be taken into account. Thirdly, there is the problem of the uniform application of Community law. On this point, there is nothing to add to Mrs. Thyssen's excellent speech. While biodiversity and cultural diversity are, in my opinion, a good thing, the same cannot be said for the diversity of application of the law, of what constitutes the essential core of the internal market, namely, competition law. This point still needs to be refined. Only some countries, such as Germany, have a specialized jurisdiction. Perhaps this is an avenue worth exploring, but we must explore others. What we cannot do, Commissioner, and I would like to end with this, is to lay ourselves open, to provide weapons to those who present the European institutions as a matter for the big, the powerful, the rich, and not for the citizens, the small and medium-sized enterprises, who would find themselves subject, in the worst case scenario, which will never materialise because sufficient measures will be applied to avoid this situation, to courts handing down dissimilar judgments, very late and without any real possibility of controlling the situation other than by doing what the French call "the obstacle course", namely waiting I don't know how many years for the Luxembourg Court, which, as we know, is currently saturated, to deliver its judgment.

I believe the Italian Prime Minister raised this point during your meeting on February 24. Can you tell us your position on this subject? Mr. President, Europe has been jolted awake by Bosnia and Kosovo. The European Union is finally realizing that it cannot afford to constantly let the Americans take the political and military initiatives. The decision to establish an autonomous peacekeeping force is excellent. However, if Europe wishes to be able to intervene militarily in critical moments, a flexibility clause must be included in the Treaty. Mr. Solana can play a decisive role. He is not crazy, I can assure you! He is a passionate and competent man. The only question is whether this accumulation of functions does not exceed the scope of his powers. Mr. Solana is not only Secretary-General of the Council but also Secretary-General of the WEU, High Representative for Foreign Policy, and Head of the Planning and Early Warning Unit. Does Mr. Solana still find time to sleep, Mr. President? Frankly, I find this accumulation of functions unacceptable from a democratic point of view, especially since Mr. Solana was not democratically elected: he is a senior civil servant who is not accountable to any parliament. His situation threatens to overshadow Commissioner Patten, as we have seen once again today. Clearly, as the European Security and Defence Policy takes shape, the Commission and Parliament are becoming less and less involved. I find this situation equally unacceptable. Of course, everything must be done to improve the effectiveness of European policy, but this must not lead to undesirable concentrations of power. Solana must keep Europe's eyes wide open without falling asleep himself. Mr. President, the European Union was created above all to guarantee peace, and I am pleased that Commissioner Patten and Mr. Solana have also repeatedly emphasized this. We have also opted for joint development through democracy, cultural diversity, and tolerance. Yet today, we are powerless in the face of the misfortune in Chechnya and indifferent to the wars taking place in Africa, in a large number of countries with which we nevertheless have ties since they are former colonies. They are, in part, our ACP partners. War is the continuation of decadent underdevelopment. We intervened militarily in Kosovo after being unable to prevent a war from breaking out in the former Yugoslavia. Today, we are unable to maintain peace there. This is why the European Union lacks credibility. I do not believe, Mr. Solana, that we will be able to restore this credibility through military means. As representatives of the European Free Alliance, we all come from nations and regions that have never been at war with a foreign country but have always had to defend themselves against their aggressors. We are very sceptical of your current plans for the rapid formation of an armed force, not because we are opposed to a European defence, but because such defence must and can only result from an effective and democratic decision-making process.

With regard to the type of projects to be supported, the focus should also be shifted from small-scale, revenue-generating projects, which are difficult to monitor, to investment projects where the benefits are most often obvious. This will meet calls for greater transparency in the use of funds and successfully counteract the temptation to place an unnecessary, long-term burden on local tax revenues in areas where such projects are carried out. It will also demonstrate how seriously Parliament takes the call for such reforms. If these changes are adopted by this House today, I believe they will represent another crucial step towards achieving the historically significant objectives for which the funds were originally established: providing financially sustainable support to disadvantaged areas in the European Union, where living standards must be raised to a level of dignity not through handouts but through concrete assistance. I call on the House to approve these changes. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I, too, would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her report, which has been drafted with such diligence and care. There is no doubt that the European Union's structural policies and cohesion policy are the essential instruments for creating the conditions for growth and reducing economic and social disparities in the regions. Despite the measures taken so far, these disparities are still quite pronounced, and in terms of unemployment, even unacceptable. In order for the objectives of these policies to be achieved as fully as possible, they must be coordinated and implemented on the basis of well-considered and sensible guidelines. Let us not forget that, if these policies are effective, they will also be visible to European citizens, who will see an immediate improvement in their quality of life! Let us also bear in mind that the remote and island regions of the European Union deserve special attention, because their geographical location places them at a significant disadvantage in terms of economic and social development—unless, of course, the Commission intends to build bridges or submarine tunnels to connect them to the European mainland. Finally, let me say that structural policies as a whole must be made more flexible so that they respond to changed conditions and thus to the new challenges and opportunities that the new millennium, for which we all hope for the best, will bring. Mr President, Mrs Schroedter's report undoubtedly contains many important points, and I congratulate her on this. However, we should pay more attention to the direction and results of the Community's regional policy. Here are a few problems in brief: the enormous level of mass unemployment is not only not being reduced but is becoming even worse as a result of structural policy. Agriculture and agricultural regions are suffering irreparable damage as a result of the regional policy being implemented, which is having disastrous consequences for employment in rural areas and the living conditions of farmers, particularly in the South. Regional imbalances within the Member States are increasing at an alarming rate. The data from the sixth report clearly show that regional disparities have increased considerably over the last ten years. Almost no attention, if any, is paid to the enormous problems of the Union's island regions, where deficits in infrastructure, transport, communications and energy are leading to a continuous exodus of the population.

Based on this firm position, we also believe the time has come to call for increased efforts by the Commission and the Member States on behalf of those currently drowning in Mozambique. The one million euros made available is completely inadequate for the needs estimated by the Mozambican government at $65 million. The time has also come to demand greater effectiveness. We hope that the debate held this early afternoon, the Commissioner's knowledge of the situation in Mozambique, and Mr. Nielson's visit will lead to greater efforts by all sides in aiding Mozambique. Mr. President, the situation in Mozambique is extremely dramatic. Every day, every hour of delay costs many lives. Only a few helicopters are available to rescue tens of thousands of victims. The water is rising inexorably. Famine and epidemics are looming. It seems as if the whole world is watching helplessly. The question is whether the Commission is reacting quickly enough. To be honest, I have my doubts. Commissioner Nielson left for Mozambique today. That may be quick by European standards, but perhaps very late given the emergency situation in Mozambique. The European Union, unlike a number of Member States, has so far pledged only a very limited amount of support. What options does the Commission see for offering rapid, effective assistance? What might emergency aid and reconstruction support look like? What can Commissioner Patten say about international coordination to date? Why was it not possible to offer rescue operations with a larger number of helicopters at an earlier stage? The international community could certainly also help Mozambique with generous debt relief. Not only because the country is pursuing relatively good policies, but above all because the extent of the human suffering absolutely demands it. Mr. President, all the reports and images reaching us testify to the scale of the tragedy affecting Mozambique. Hundreds of thousands of people have been torn from their homes, numerous deaths, a lack of food and drinking water, and destroyed homes and crops. And all this in a country that is one of the poorest in the world and therefore lacks the slightest resources to provide the affected populations with the speed they need. It is therefore essential that the European Union and the relevant Member States intervene to provide swift, unplanned assistance to this country and its population. As you know, the Portuguese Presidency and Commissioner Nielson have left for Mozambique today, given the seriousness of the situation. We are pleased about this. But even more than their presence there, it is urgent that a short- and medium-term action programme be adopted and implemented without delay, in cooperation with the Mozambican authorities, to guarantee the assistance required by the situation. It is precisely in this spirit, and in the conviction that swift and extraordinary action is now required, that I wrote to Commissioner Nielson today, before your departure, in my capacity as Chairman of the Committee on Development and Cooperation, asking him to meet us immediately on his return to inform us of the situation and, in particular, of the emergency measures which the European Union has already taken or which are still planned.

In the future – and this is already the case today – pensioners will have considerable sums of money at their disposal. Unlike young people who are penniless, older people have accumulated capital that they want to make grow, and they are therefore interested in this directive. If national governments attached importance – as the European Union attaches in this directive – to multiplying the money earned during working life, the explosive problem of pensions would have already been solved. Mr Bolkestein, as Commissioner, you bear a very great responsibility for the future of older people and pensioners, a future that I hope will be better once we have finalised this directive, which will be very soon, as Mrs Villiers and Mrs Kauppi have proposed. Mr President, first of all, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to express my warm thanks to the rapporteur, Olle Schmidt, and the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which is responsible for the matter, as well as to the rapporteur, Brian Crowley, and the members of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, whom I would like to thank for their detailed and important work in refining and broadening the proposals. Since the approval of Directive 85/611, the investment fund sector has undergone a long process of development, and it is now important to modernise the rules. The new proposals aim for the highest level of investor protection, which is a prerequisite for the market integration that follows the introduction of the euro. Given that the average European family invests its savings in investment funds, the proposals contain provisions for prudent management – and I want to stress this point – prudent management in terms of investment policy and risk spreading. The two proposals form a coherent whole. The first proposal expands the number of instruments in which an "undertaking for collective investment in transferable securities" - a UCITS - can invest. As has already been pointed out in this House, UCITS are among the major players in modern capital markets. Their presence offers a large number of traditional investors the opportunity to participate in these markets, taking into account the principle of risk spreading and adequate supervision. By allowing diversified forms of investment, individual investors can also benefit from all the advantages of new investment techniques. The second proposal expands the role that these important intermediary institutions can play on the European Union's capital markets with regard to the development of the investment fund sector. If we allow the establishment of branches and the establishment of certain services on a cross-border basis, these institutions will finally be able to exercise the freedoms granted by the Treaty of Rome, of which they have been deprived all these years. The Commission welcomes many of the clarifications proposed by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and will take up many of its ideas. The Commission will take up amendments – and I am using the numbering in its most recent form – 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 13, 19 and 21 to the first proposal and 23, 28 and 32 to the second proposal, as these are very useful clarifications and improvements.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that it is also worth taking note—since this was one of the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency's program—of the statement that it is necessary to enhance development policy within the framework of European Union policies, and particularly within its foreign policy. We believe this is absolutely essential, otherwise we will fail to implement any consistent action in terms of policy coherence, if we are unable to give development policies the prominence they should have as an instrument for affirming the principles and values that shape Europe's integration into the international system. To achieve this, it will be necessary, at the right time, as I have emphasized, to change the paradigm or leave behind the postcolonial paradigm so that development policies acquire a European dimension. I believe in this regard (and some interventions have also indicated this here) that the adoption of the new Convention replacing the Lomé Conventions is an important instrument for renewing a new dynamic in the approach to cooperation with such an important group of countries of the South at a time when the considerable instability surrounding international negotiation processes such as those surrounding the first round of negotiations in Seattle is worthy of mention. In many of the contributions to this debate, I seem to sense a certain degree of frustration. I have made a statement before you on behalf of the Commission, which, in my opinion, provides a useful basis for this debate. We will provide you with more detailed information that directly addresses all the issues relating to coherence. This debate is not new. We are currently working on this issue in the Commission, and once that work is completed, I will report on it, as many have requested the report on coherence. I have no doubt that, as a result of the growing political attention to these problems—something clearly reflected in today's debate—it will be easier for the Commission and DG Development to put coherence at the forefront of our work programme. This also requires the introduction of other new mechanisms into the Commission system, which may well include, as some of the political groups in Parliament have suggested, the establishment of a special working group with cross-departmental representation and the establishment of a kind of coherence watchtower in the Commission. I have read—and heard in the debate—that coherence is being used as a kind of one-size-fits-all panacea. It seems to me important to maintain coherence as a defined and relatively clear discipline that seeks to remedy inconsistencies where they actually exist, and there is no doubt that they do in our case. Much of this is due to genuine disagreements between the sectoral groups in each Member State, as has been said quite frankly in this Parliament: people tend to identify more or less with their spheres of interest, which is legitimate, moreover.

If the IOPC Fund ceiling is insufficient, and it is clearly underestimated, it must be increased. Our resolution calls for this. If the increase is insufficient, the polluter will have to finance the balance. It would be particularly unfair to see an oil company, whose profits this year amount to ten billion francs, refuse to compensate 100% of its own victims, the vast majority of whom are small businesses and employees. The affected populations, Commissioner, are waiting for concrete signs of solidarity at European level. Our resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to help repair the damage caused to the fisheries sector affected by the consequences of the disaster. Blue Europe, the CFP, must show today that, beyond the constraints it imposes on fishermen, solidarity is not a word it ignores. The European Union must also participate in the restoration of environments in the affected wetlands and coastal zones, whose biological value is of interest to the entire Union. Mr. Fischler has just told us that he would welcome France's requests, and I welcome this. We have a driving role to play in this essential issue of marine pollution. Twenty years after the Amoco Cadix disaster, laxity and irresponsibility still reign supreme in Europe when it comes to maritime safety, with the fruits of new oil spills. This time, inertia must not prevail. A general framework for maritime safety must be quickly defined, respecting the principle of subsidiarity, and this vicious spiral of widespread irresponsibility must finally be brought to an end. Mr. President, the economy of the Western Atlantic is devastated, oiled by the Erika's fuel. Fishermen, oyster farmers, shellfish farmers, tourism professionals, local and regional authorities are growing impatient while waiting for aid and treatment of the wreck, which apparently is still leaking and constitutes a veritable time bomb. Europe, which inadvertently eliminated the budget line "natural disasters for the benefit of member states," must react. React first in the name of solidarity, but also in the name of its share of responsibility for this umpteenth oil spill. Indeed, citizens have difficulty understanding why Europe accepts what the Americans refuse and why Europe, usually so quick to legislate on environmental matters, has so far ignored maritime safety. Europe must legislate as soon as possible and shed full light on this shipwreck. But in the meantime, the Commission must urgently mobilize European funds to help the affected businesses, treat the wreck, clean up the coastline, increase waste storage capacity, ensure its treatment or recycling, and establish a research program on oil recovery at sea. Finally, the Commission must reinstate a substantial budget line, "natural disasters for member states," and make the affected departments eligible for Structural Funds. What is the Commission's opinion on these proposals? What decisions have already been taken and those does the Commission intend to take?

This is why radical reforms are needed and therefore a broader agenda for the IGC. The Finnish Presidency has only listened to the governments that are in favour of the minimalist approach, while unfortunately ignoring the opinion of Parliament. Portugal has the opportunity to learn from its Finnish predecessor what should not be done. It is vital that Parliament and the Commission are involved in this IGC. In many areas, these two institutions share common interests and positions. An effective assessment of this common commitment must, in any case, coincide with Parliament's right to approve future Treaty changes. Of all the priorities, this is the most important. What is the Commission's opinion on this? This also means that the President of our Parliament and the other two political representatives must be able to participate on the same political level as the Commission, and not only in a working group. There is no reason why directly elected representatives of the citizens should be relegated to a second place compared to the Commission. Radical reforms are a commitment that we must make to the new Member States, but also to ourselves. If we allow Europe to weaken as a result of enlargement, we will sink into our own political swamp. Mr President, for days now I have not understood this Parliament which seems to have a masochistic taste for self-mutilation. After having limited its participation in the IGC to a paltry two seats on its own initiative, Parliament is today refusing to complete the agenda of the Conference. Indeed, whether through weakness or stupidity - and neither of these alternatives seems glorifying - this House is rushing to give its opinion and is thus renouncing the only instrument of command given to it by the Treaty, namely, renouncing the requirement to be given a complete agenda before it can take a decision. Why should we vote on this opinion tomorrow, 3 February, under the urgent procedure, when we could wait until the opening of the session in Strasbourg on 14 February and, from a position of strength, impose a complete and therefore coherent agenda on the Council? It takes a good deal of hypocrisy to mask the weakness we are displaying today. It takes hypocrisy to bitterly regret, in the resolution, that the agenda of the IGC is not up to the challenges of the future, when we impose short deadlines on ourselves with culpable naivety and prevent ourselves from imposing a more ambitious agenda. If at the end of the IGC democratic gaps are highlighted, the blame will be on the political groups that wanted this hasty participation. Whether we like it or not, the decision-making body is now moving to the fifteen Member States, because Parliament has extinguished the only light that allowed it to shed some light on the discussions. I therefore appeal to the Members of the vast majority of Parliament - who decided in November that the future of Europe deserved a broader debate than the residue of Amsterdam - to arm themselves with good will and to take action with their governments to convince them of the need to expand the IGC, a possibility that is also envisaged in the resolution of the Helsinki Council.

Mr Poos, I beg your pardon. There has been some lack of clarity precisely on the point which you asked. With regard to MEDA, Malta and Cyprus can participate in regional programmes, but not in country-specific programmes, because the incomes are too high. Thank you very much, Commissioner Verheugen. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday. Question Time (Council) Question No 1 by the Honourable Member (H-0022/00): Subject: Control of access of oil tankers to Community waters In connection with the accident involving the oil tanker ERIKA off the coast of France, which resulted in an oil slick, what measures does the Council intend to take to control the access to Community waters of oil tankers flying flags of convenience which do not comply with Community safety standards? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 24 January the Council addressed the consequences of the sinking of the oil tanker Erika the previous month. On that occasion, the Council, while also taking on board the emotion of public opinion over the disastrous effects of that event, expressed its concerns about the safety of oil tankers and the environmental protection associated with it. The Council was not insensitive to this type of problem and to the need to adopt additional measures in this regard. On that occasion, it was stressed how important it was for the Council to adopt new measures both at Community level and in the context of its work with international organisations. As is well known, Community legislation currently requires port authorities to carry out inspections on board all foreign ships, including those flying flags of convenience, and to detain them if they fail to comply with international standards. There is a 1995 directive on this matter. As regards the future, the Council noted that the process of reflection under way within the Commission should shortly be concluded with a communication on the safety of oil tankers and with new proposals aimed at strengthening controls and the qualifications of inspection bodies. It also provides for the need to strengthen the very structures of oil tankers that call at Community ports. This issue is being followed by the Council of Transport Ministers and, therefore, I can inform you on behalf of the Council that we will not fail to give top priority to the proposals that the Commission, as everything indicates, will present in this area, which we believe to be essential, in terms of environmental protection. Naturally, Parliament will also be called upon to express its opinion on these proposals, given that these are matters subject to codecision. I am pleased that the Council considers my question as a subject for reflection. The President-in-Office of the Council comes from Portugal, a country directly threatened by a situation of this kind. If we reflect too long, however, it could happen that, between now and next summer, an oil tanker in similar conditions runs aground off the Algarve and destroys the Portuguese summer tourist industry; that, if this is the fate, the sea currents carry the pollution all the way to the island of Madeira - because they are going in that direction - and also compromise tourism in the Canary Islands.

The Commission insists on the need to first examine these applications from the point of view of their safety and efficacy before granting an authorisation. I can only ask you again to bear in mind the technical nature of the Commission's proposal and to await the independent proposal for a new directive on additives in food before addressing broader issues. I would like to address some of the specific issues that have been raised during the debate. First of all, with regard to the comments made by Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf, I wish to assure you that we will amend the procedure for authorising genetically modified additives in Directive 70/524 on additives and not in the novel food directive. This is a directive whose subject matter concerns raw materials more specifically than additives. The text referred to by Parliament comes from the directive that was adopted in 1998. However, the vertical legislation of Directive 90/220 on the manner of carrying out environmental risk assessment of GMOs has since been amended and is still being amended today. It is now in Parliament's second reading. I am convinced that we should wait for the final version of Directive 90/220 and, more specifically, Article 11 thereof. Reference has also been made to the question of whether this proposal could create a risk of monopolies being established. Mr Kindermann and Mrs Auroi have raised this issue. I would just like to make a few comments on this issue. First of all, this project has been under way since 1993, and therefore it cannot be said that it has taken any other producer of goods by surprise. Indeed, any such applicant can still submit their application relating to a particular product. I also wish to point out that the Commission has never approved any application for authorisation of GMOs for inclusion in additives. Mrs Roth-Behrendt referred to the question of the appropriate legal basis, namely whether that basis should be Article 37 or Article 152. Again, I repeat what I have said previously on this point and assure her and the House that it would be highly inappropriate for the Commission to seek to justify a measure taken on the basis of Article 37 by simply excluding from the provision any reference to public health. This is an issue that has been considered on at least two occasions by the European Court of Justice, which has established the legal criteria for situations identical to the present one, which require consideration of the appropriate legal basis when presenting a legislative text. The Court's case law appears to be quite explicit on this point. As a general comment on the amendments suggested here, particularly with regard to the problem of the legal basis, it would, in my view, be inappropriate to base the legal basis on Article 152 in these circumstances, as that would almost certainly run counter to the objective criteria that have been set out by the Court. A number of you - Mr Nicholson in particular - have referred to the problem relating to labelling.

The adoption of this report will have serious consequences for European agriculture if the concentration of phosphorus and nitrogen, for example, cannot exceed the basic values for these substances in the aquatic environment and if a value close to zero is set for pesticides in the aquatic environment. European farmers will, for example, no longer be able to produce bread wheat with a high protein content for making bread. This will result in the relocation of agricultural production to other countries outside the EU, and this will entail significant social and employment costs. I cannot accept the parts of the Water Directive that concern these points. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, water is a precious resource. Millions of people do not even have access to clean water, a prerequisite for survival. We should therefore not be surprised that water is the basis of wars. The capitalist world is also positioning its pawns to gain maximum control over water supplies. In this matter, there is rarely any question of any general interest or solidarity. Europe is therefore faced with a difficult task: to bring together Community water policy, fragmented in terms of both objectives and resources, into a more coherent legislative framework. I must admit that in my country, Flanders, too, there is still a long way to go. Only recently, the Commission rapped us on the knuckles about this. Any sensible person wants this framework directive to be used as a sword in the back of politicians who are currently guilty of failings. In this respect, the common position is a farce, an informal work, a real affront to the OSPAR agreements. We are faced with an implementation deadline that can be extended to 34 years. My children will then be older than I am now. Admit it: this is not serious. Tomorrow, we could vote for a weak and informal framework that will poison our children's future. Or we will vote for the amendments from my group, the rapporteur, or the Environment Committee. This is just to conclude. Over the past few months, we have been under enormous pressure. What is striking about this issue is the enormous pressure coming from the Council of Ministers. In my country, this was done by both the Flemish and Walloon administrations responsible for the environment. They opted for the weak common position rather than the more ambitious stance of our Parliament. I really wonder if this approach is known to the Green environment ministers in my country. Dear colleagues, fine words are no longer enough. We must resolutely change course. In tomorrow's vote, we can clearly show that Europe is committed to a responsible and forward-looking water policy. This can only increase our credibility. The debate is suspended and will resume at 9 p.m.

The Group of the European Liberal and Democrat Party adopted a position on the internal disintegration of the Union, approved last November, in which it proposed the creation of a system of concentric circles in Europe, "the onion model." In its resolutions on the next IGC, Parliament must fully address the issues of internal differentiation and flexibility. Enlargement and the very achievements of integration will be threatened if we are unable to create the system of concentric circles proposed by the Liberal Group. My colleagues, Mrs. Frassoni and Mr. Onesta, have already spoken, with a certain skepticism, on some aspects of the matter at hand. I wish to add my voice of concern regarding the issue of subsidiarity, not only between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Member States and their own autonomous communities. This is an issue that has not received the attention it deserves, and there are many aspects about which we should be concerned. Let me draw attention, in particular, to one of the repercussions of enlargement for this Parliament. The limit of 700 was set as the maximum number of Members who can constitute a Parliament in which the Assembly's deliberations are viable. If we apply the current principle of diffuse proportionality—six seats for each State and one more seat for every half million inhabitants—we will have a situation where Luxembourg, with a population of 367,000, will have more Members in this Assembly than Wales, which is partly an autonomous community of the United Kingdom. Scotland, with a population of 5 million, currently has eight seats in this Assembly; Denmark and Finland, with the same population, have sixteen. What will happen if we maintain the limit at 700, if over time a 26% increase in population is added, and then approve the Commission's, in my opinion, ill-considered proposal that there should be a European list of candidates? What will happen to a place like Scotland, which I represent here? It will become totally invisible! In such circumstances, Members of this Parliament should not be in the least surprised if, in these negotiations, the people of Scotland and other similar countries ask whether enlargement should not also take the form of admitting new Member States integrated into existing ones. In Scotland, more and more people support this point of view every day. Mr. President, to say that the European Union is at a crossroads is, without a doubt, nothing new. It has been said many times. But this time it is true: we have launched—and this is something extraordinarily positive—the single currency, and enlargement lies ahead. The question is: are we going towards enlargement prepared or not? Are we for enlargement without going deeper, or are we for enlargement by going deeper? That is the debate, and that is what any discussion regarding the Intergovernmental Conference, its agenda, and its method is all about. It is clear that the Council, for the moment, has not opted for enlargement by going deeper. And that's dangerous for enlargement. Dangerous for any prospects for political union, and certainly difficult for the public to understand.

It seems to me that there is a broad consensus of opinions; however, the Rapkay report contains some comments that we should consider very carefully. I will highlight only two of them for the sake of brevity. The first concerns a further increase in transparency. This Parliament knows the extent to which all of us consider the issue of transparency in competition policy to be important, and I personally have, since the first day, September 1, 1999, when I appeared before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Mr. Rapkay, with regard to the international dimension of competition policy, I can confirm that the Commission is ready to provide Parliament with a report on this subject, to which Mrs. Randzio-Plath has also drawn our attention. Within this context, I can say that we maintain very satisfactory bilateral relations with our counterpart authorities in the United States, Canada, and Japan, and that we are working to ensure the emergence of a genuine competition policy within the World Trade Organization. I also warmly thank you, Mr. Jonckheer, for your report on the seventh report on State aid in the European Union. I will not address the issue of codecision here, but not because I do not consider it important. It is of very significant institutional importance that obviously goes beyond the specific issue of competition. Consequently, I do not have the right to comment, and this issue obviously belongs to the broader context of the Intergovernmental Conference. Regarding your suggestions, Mr. Jonckheer, you already know that my services are—despite their limited, albeit highly qualified, resources—working very actively on the development of the State aid register and the State aid indicator. I await with great interest the results of the seventh report, the planned timeframe of which is: creation of the services now, in January, and approval by the Commission in March 2000, to assess whether the latest trends are confirmed. Mr. Jonckheer, Mr. Thyssen, and Mr. Gemelli have referred to the candidate countries' readiness regarding competition in general and State aid. I can only say that we are working actively and specifically with them. They are preparing; they all already have competition laws and are establishing the corresponding authorities. Regarding energy and, above all, environmental concerns, which, as you know, are also mine, I can say that we are finalizing the review of the incorporation of State aid into the environment. I would also like to highlight, in the context of State aid problems, the issue raised by Mrs. Riis-Jørgensen, among others, regarding the recovery of unlawful aid. In April 1999, the Commission approved a new procedural regulation introducing specific rules on recovery. Over the next few months—I can assure you of this—you will see how seriously we intend to take these rules. Finally, Mr. President, I would like to warmly thank Mr. Langen for his report, which is more sectoral in scope but no less important in terms of its contribution.

This should be enough to demonstrate the topicality of the issue, but we can also mention the next Summit between the European Union and the OAU, finally set for next April, in Cairo. It should be added that any analysis, even superficial, inevitably leads us to the conclusion that something, indeed a lot, is wrong in terms of North-South relations, including those between the European Union and the least developed countries. Suffice it to think that the number of so-called least developed countries has increased from 25 to 48 in the last thirty years and that the latter, although they currently represent 13 percent of humanity, account for only 0.4 percent of world exports and 0.6 percent of world imports; or the unfortunate circumstance that public development aid, promoted by rich countries, has decreased by about 23 percent. Moreover, the recent cuts to the Community budget made in this sector for the current financial year are part of this trend, as well as constituting a negative and incorrect political signal. The unsuspecting Mr Camdessus, still Director of the International Monetary Fund, stated in his speech last Sunday at the opening of the UNCTAD - and I quote - that "the international community gives with one hand and takes away with the other". He was obviously referring to the aid granted by the most advanced countries to the developing countries. It seems like a joke, given the source from which it comes, but the statement was actually made: I heard it myself. It is an observation that does not seem far from current reality and leads me to reiterate the need to rethink and relaunch North-South relations on new foundations, or the need to re-examine the role of the European Union in this area, because the promotion of a new, more just and equitable world order cannot and must not cease to represent a strategic objective of the Union; it is therefore essential to reflect on the current globalisation, taking into account the essential orientations and dominant interests, in particular the very serious negative effects that it causes in developing countries. The conclusion of a new agreement with the ACP countries is a fact. This is in itself a positive development, especially given the pressure that was exerted to end it and the fact that even several Member States were opposed to continuing down this path. We will have the opportunity, in due course, to analyse in more detail the exact terms in which the agreement was defined. However, it is certain that, despite the fact that it contains new and innovative elements, the European negotiators were rather cautious and kept below the proposals that we had formulated at the time. The novelties are constituted by some features of political relevance in the new partnership agreement. The latter is undoubtedly the result of a complex negotiation in which both sides made substantial concessions, which is true as far as the European Union is concerned, especially in the areas of good governance and trade. But above all it was the result of the strengthening of the ACP group, which, it seems, has found a new spirit since the Seattle Summit. I would like to stress, in particular, that a new way of addressing problems, particularly in trade matters, seems to be emerging and that an appropriate approach in this area is truly indispensable.

It is therefore likely that there are many forms of life out there, and that many of them are more advanced than ours. Remembering that the first television programs from Earth are now in space 50 light-years away, far beyond the nearest stars, I invite you to imagine with me what the life forms among the stars might think of us when they look at us. What do they see? They see a beautiful planet, full of life, but they see that its atmosphere is polluted and overheated. They see that forests are being cut down and deserts are expanding. Of living creatures, they may see that many animals are treated cruelly and that rare ones are disappearing forever. How do they see the currently dominant species, that is, us? Well, they see that the planet's resources are distributed unequally.
