They see fighting over territory, they see medicines that can cure diseases, but not in the parts of the world where they are most needed, schoolbooks, but not in the least developed parts of our planet, where 50 percent of the world's population never makes a phone call in their entire lives. How do they see human relationships? They see us killing each other. They see us limiting each other's freedom. They see an endless series of local wars. They see some of our children being drafted into the army as soldiers, or treated as prostitutes or slaves. They see men and women, people of different ages, minorities, people of different skin colors, people of different races or religions, immigrants, even neighbors, being treated in a discriminatory way. We all know the situation. The United Nations Convention on Human Rights of 50 years ago was an attempt to correct the situation. We should honor it, and I think we do. Only in Europe are human rights enshrined in law. Here in the European Parliament, some Members do not want the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which is currently being debated, to become enforceable by law. I say: shame on you! Human rights should be enshrined in law in every country in the world. That is what we must strive for. As Commissioner Patten said, much remains to be done. Finally, if you were to ask me: What if there were no life among the stars, and we were alone? - an equally disturbing thought - I would say: Don't you think we have a responsibility to ensure that our children behave properly, before we let them go and populate other planets? Mr President, human rights are universal, indivisible and interconnected. Many people know this famous slogan by heart, taken from the conclusions of the United Nations World Conference on Human Rights in 1993. It is a good thing that this is so. But we must ask ourselves whether the European Union's human rights policy reflects the unitary and homogeneous vision expressed by the slogan. We must also ask ourselves whether the European Union has a human rights policy or not. With this last question I am not referring to the effort it takes for Member States to coordinate their foreign policy positions with one another and to form a common front against human rights violations in other countries such as China, for example.

What I see all over Europe is people drinking Coca-Cola, eating hamburgers, wearing baseball caps, watching Hollywood movies, and often doing all of these things at the same time. Now, I don't believe that protectionism and regulation are the way to defend Europe's culture, but I do believe in lending a hand whenever we can. This is what the Culture 2000 program aims to do. Therefore, I say to the Council of Ministers: do some real monitoring of this program. Is what we are doing enough? And I thank Mrs. Reding for the support and help she has provided so far and encourage her to continue her good work; we are on her side. Madam President, I also want to warmly congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Graça Moura, and the Commissioner, Mrs. Reding, for their contribution to the achievement of this program. The "Culture 2000" program was finally formed at the end of last year in the conciliation between Parliament and the Council. The final agreed solution can be considered acceptable, considering that the adoption of the program required unanimity by the Council. It is to be hoped that the next IGC will decide to extend the qualified majority to the cultural sector as well. It is truly unusual that legislative provisions, the processing of which is subject to the codecision procedure, require unanimity by the Council. This framework program for culture replaces the current Kaleidoscope, Ariane, and Raphael programs. I would especially like, once it is launched, to fully utilize all the possibilities the program offers for the translation of books and literary works. I hope and believe that, despite the avalanche of new technologies, literature will retain its status. We need the depth that literature conveys in a world of superficiality and inconstancy. Furthermore, literature is of great importance in transmitting our cultural tradition and increasing our mutual understanding, as well as in safeguarding linguistic richness and plurality. In this context, I am very pleased to report that shortly after the official launch of the Socrates and Culture 2000 programs, which will take place in March in Lisbon at the Council of Ministers meeting, the Portuguese Presidency will organize a meeting to reflect on the situation of public libraries. I hope that this meeting will also encourage the Commission to actively take public libraries into account within the framework of the fifth Information Society Program. Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, in a sense, this agenda has come full circle. Today we have spoken a great deal about Europe as a community of values, tolerance, human dignity, human rights, a positive attitude toward the enlargement process, openness, and respect for others. Policies on youth, education, and culture are an important instrument for ensuring respect for these values, for ensuring citizens' trust in the European Union, and for ensuring the credibility of the European Union in its eyes.

Unless, of course, one doesn't care about equal access to postal services for everyone, but instead focuses exclusively on the capital utilization conditions for companies in large urban centers. Members of Parliament, however, should be representatives of all citizens, and that means they are obliged to think in economic terms, not business terms. In concrete terms, this means for postal services: First, the issue of employment must take priority. I have nothing against liberalization and privatization, but the premises must be right. Second, it must be guaranteed that there will be no reduction in services for citizens. Examples in Germany and Sweden show that this danger certainly exists. Mr. Stenmarck, Sweden is the only country where prices have risen significantly more sharply after liberalization than in all other member states of the European Union. That is also an effect that can arise. We must take precautions to prevent that from happening. Third: First, universal postal services at an affordable price for every citizen, everywhere, remain essential; second, maintaining a uniform price for all Member States; and third, daily mail delivery and collection on working days. Regarding the question of value for money for the respective weight categories of mail, further price reductions can be considered; the Post Office itself says so. It is not necessary to stay above 300g, although analysis suggests that a minimum weight of 150g must be guaranteed for it to even be worthwhile. I believe that today's discussion was appropriate and important in this respect, so that Mr. Bolkestein knows how this Parliament stands and can take things into account from the outset. Mr. President, we are in the first phase of the revision of Directive 97/67/EC on postal services, and further liberalization would, I very much fear, lead to a significant reduction in services provided in the public interest. At Mr Bolkestein's hearing, my colleague Véronique Mathieu expressed the wish that impact studies be carried out on each proposal immediately after its announcement, so that the effects of the planned liberalization would be known before the legislation was adopted. What is the current state of affairs? Are the results of these impact studies available? As you know, we EDD MEPs, along with other Members, defend rural life, that is, the preservation of jobs and social cohesion, which is reinforced by the provision of a high-quality universal service. I would love to be able to say that, based on the examples we see every day in my country, in my very rural region, we can move on to a further phase of liberalization without any concerns. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and if the European directive is applied together with the French 35-hour law, which changes the working time criteria—for example, 1,700 mail items per workstation per hour, compared to the current 1,400—then in rural areas, either the opening hours for the public will be reduced or certain post offices will be closed. This already represents an unacceptable reduction in the public service. I have my local newspaper here, in which I read: "The Postal Directorate informs the public that as of January 3, 2000—this is very timely—the last collection will take place at 3:45 p.m. and not 4:30 p.m. as before."

I therefore believe that this point, which in itself justifies a broader revision, must be urgently placed on the agenda of the IGC. In our view, the central questions that must now be asked regarding the convening of an intergovernmental conference for the revision of the Treaties go far beyond the controversy raised here concerning the size of its agenda, the possibility of formulating proposals for new subjects to be included on it, or the level of Parliament's participation. The important questions, in our view, concern the possibilities and objectives of the IGC, but also the topics that will be debated there. We have doubts about its possibilities because the objectives in view are far from being in line with the planned enlargement to which reference is constantly being made. This is particularly evident from the content in question, especially with regard to the points left unresolved in Amsterdam – which heralded the subsequent formation of unacceptable directorates – but also with regard to those relating to the second and third pillars, which are beginning to take shape, particularly in the direction of an undesirable militarization of the European Union. These are several of the essential reasons why we are not in favor of the motion for a resolution we are now considering. The European Parliamentary Labour Group abstained from the final vote on the Leinen-Dimitrakopoulos report. The text is overly ambitious, and MEPs from the British Labour Party believe that the IGC should prioritize the Amsterdam leftovers in preparation for enlargement and should not extend beyond these objectives. Important work is currently underway in terms of reform, and this must be the priority for the time being in order to allow for the consolidation and strengthening of the EU institutions. Expanding the agenda and drastically revising the Treaties would risk destabilization. The key element in this text, as amended, is the call for a Charter of Fundamental Rights to be included in the Treaties. In our view, this would create a complex legislative burden, and it would be preferable to have a political and declaratory charter explaining to citizens what their rights are. Our priorities should be: the number and responsibility of Commissioners; the weighting of voting in the Council; the extension of qualified majority voting in areas that will benefit the UK and Europe (but not Treaty changes, defense matters, border controls, or taxation); and the extension of codecision in all areas to which qualified majority voting is extended. Beyond this, we are concerned that the suggestions for "flexibility" and enhanced cooperation are not appropriate at this time. The Amsterdam provisions have largely remained untested, and increasing emphasis on opt-outs could weaken the EU at a time when enlargement is being considered and candidate countries are being asked to sign up to the single market and other EU legislation. (SV) In order to influence developments, the European Parliament must adopt a more constructive attitude to the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference than is reflected in this resolution, which is too concerned with disappointment and negativism about the decision taken by the European Council in Helsinki in December 1999.

Our report, as you know, Commissioner, advocates the application of the codecision procedure to basic legislation on state aid. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my part in today's debate concerns the Steel Aid Code. It concerns state aid which has been granted in Europe on the basis of this code and which the Commission has examined. In 1998, there were a total of 27 cases, on which the Commission has drawn up its own report. The ECSC Treaty will soon expire. That is why we must above all deal with how steel aid is to be managed in future. Parliament welcomes the decisions of the European Commission set out in the report, including that of requesting the repayment of funds in certain cases, thus applying Article 88 of the ECSC Treaty. At the same time, the competitiveness of the European steel industry is also the subject of the recent Commission communication, which we have not yet discussed in Parliament. As in other areas, the steel industry is also subject to a general ban on state aid under Article 87(1) of the EC Treaty. According to this article, state aid is essentially incompatible with the single market. Exceptions are only permitted in clearly defined cases. Under Article 88, the Commission is required to monitor state aid. The main case in 1998 was the equity injection of EUR 540 million into Preussag in Germany. Member States must also notify the Commission of their aid plans. The rules in force for the steel industry were introduced on 18 December 1996. They provide for the possibility of granting aid to the steel industry only in certain clearly defined cases. These include aid for research and development, aid for environmental protection, social aid to encourage the closure of steel plants and aid for the permanent closure of uncompetitive companies. In addition, there is a special regulation that grants up to EUR 50 million to one Member State, Greece. As can be seen, the practical management of the Steel Aid Code over the years has led to problems that are not fully explored in the report. From Parliament's point of view, it is important to talk today about derogations to be applied once this Steel Aid Code has expired. A relaxation of the current fundamental lines of the Steel Code is a possibility that cannot be ruled out. Nobody wants to see a race for subsidies in Europe. This would seriously undermine the single market despite the consolidation of the steel industry in recent years. Parliament therefore considers it essential to amend the Steel Aid Code, also in view of the unequal treatment feared by the industry; the Commission will have to submit new legislation to the Council. It is known that the Council has so far refused to approve this new legislation. This is also due to the thesis that, once the steel aid code has expired, without the annoying control of the European Commission, one can go back to doing what one wants.

The van Hulten report represents progress, but it is not enough. Furthermore, we must clarify our roles in the area of financial oversight. The Court of Auditors must check to what extent this or that element of the EU's financial functioning might be incompatible with the regulations, but it is not its role to check whether expenditure complies with the objectives set. It is the European Parliament that is responsible for political evaluation. Our job is not to hunt down criminals - that is OLAF's. So tell me, for example, which national parliament obtains all the documents relating to preliminary investigations! I would therefore like to repeat, with all the stubbornness I can muster, that the provision on access to information and documentation must be significantly improved compared with the draft texts that have been seen on the internet, otherwise this fight will lead nowhere. Mr President, I would like to sincerely thank the rapporteur for his report. I am pleased to be able to address him in Dutch now that Mr Van den Berg has done so, otherwise I would probably have had some qualms. I think that this report is a significant improvement, particularly in terms of the amendments. I am a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and in our country, a rapporteur is always proud to receive 100 proposed amendments because that means he has raised an interesting issue. I believe that this is the case here, although I think it would be excessive to dwell on these 100 amendments for too long. I would add that our coordinator in the Committee on Budgetary Control is Mr Pomés Ruiz, who is Spanish and has therefore made a very considerable Spanish contribution to this debate. Mr President, I think that one of the important points that has been mentioned is essential: the proposal to appoint a rapporteur for the Standing Committee on Public Administration Control. This is a proposal of the utmost importance. I am only surprised that the Socialist Group wants to eliminate this proposal by means of another proposal from Mrs Morgan, because she does indeed want to delete it completely. I do not really understand what she is getting at. On the one hand, we hear all sorts of praise for the rapporteur and, at the same time, Mrs Morgan wants to pursue a kind of scorched earth strategy, both on this particular point and on a number of other important points, which has the effect of emptying the entire report of its substance. I do not know whether the aim is to meet Mr Kinnock. I certainly know Mr Kinnock. Mr Kinnock is willing to listen to our expectations, but is just as willing to deviate from them if he sees fit. I do not really think it is useful to resort to extreme tactics like scorched earth. Finally, there is the question of civil servants. I do not entirely agree with Mr Haarder, in fact. I share the view that the section on civil servants is completely inadequate. This is because, firstly, no emphasis has been placed on the importance of public service in general and, secondly, because there are all sorts of proposals, the question of whether they are sensible and whether they will bring about any improvement is very real.

The Community can intervene to connect local stakeholders so that they are not, in effect, reinventing the wheel in their own region. We have an important role to play in the Community, in the European Union, in this regard. SAVE is the only Community-wide program aimed at promoting the rational use of energy. It focuses on non-technical elements, helping to build energy-efficient infrastructure; and the objective of this program is to create an environment conducive to investment and energy efficiency. We must also realize here that there is a niche in industry for energy savings. We have heard a lot about the competition problems with renewable energy, but energy efficiency saves money at the company level, it saves money everywhere, in fact, and therefore, it should not create problems. We can all support this principle. I must say that, as with motherhood, although we offer our support, we sometimes do very little in a substantial and concrete way to help mothers or those involved in energy conservation. We could do much more given the major commitments we have made to reduce CO2 and greenhouse gases and reduce dependence on energy imports. We are not undertaking the kinds of actions that our citizens want. We are not making the connection so that citizens can actually do something concrete, whether at home, in the office, or within industry, to support actions to combat global climate change. If we could communicate this, it would be very interesting to do so. I would like, once again, to thank everyone who has contributed to this reconciliation process. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like once again to thank Mrs Ahern for her work as rapporteur for this proposal, as she has contributed, with the collaboration of other parliamentarians, to achieving a result that is ultimately very reasonable, even improving certain aspects of a Commission proposal and, of course, of what the Council had accepted, at the very beginning, from a budgetary point of view. As Mrs Ahern has very rightly said, both the budget for the SAVE programme and that of the Altener programme are more symbolic than ever, because the burden is borne by the countries, the EU states, the regions, or even, in some cases, the municipalities. But in any case, just because its volume is relatively small does not mean that it no longer has the important symbolic value implied by the fact that there is a will throughout the Community to support this type of action which contributes to us actually meeting our Kyoto commitments and, moreover, to us achieving the diversification of our energy sources, the security of our supply and, in the case of SAVE, to us moving towards lower consumption, greater efficiency in the use of energy, thus contributing to achieving the objectives set. Furthermore, with regard to these programmes, namely, the SAVE programme, greater efficiency and economy, and the Altener programme, renewable energies, there is a very great technological challenge to be met, which from an economic point of view, can give rise to important opportunities for industry and also for job creation in our countries and, consequently, in the Union as a whole.

I will now briefly review the five areas where the most important changes are made. First, the changes to the definition, in ESA 95, of the concept of the institutional sector of general government; this is important because public debt refers to that which will be totalled by the general government as a whole. The lack of precise criteria for its definition would produce "deviations" in the estimates of the public debt of the various Member States. Second, public debt or, where appropriate, surplus is equivalent to the balance called respectively of financing needs or capacity of the general government sector of ESA 95. Third, public investment is equivalent to the gross fixed capital formation operation according to ESA 95 of the general government sector. Fourth, public debt is defined according to ESA 95, as are the flows or interests arising from such liabilities/assets. Fifthly and finally, the aggregate to which public debt will refer will be the gross domestic product at current market prices, estimated on the basis of the definitions of the European System of Accounts 95. Ultimately, it seems to me that the Commission's proposal represents a correct and concrete adaptation of the criteria established in the European System of Accounts 95, and I therefore approve it in its entirety, in the terms in which it was presented by the Commission. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to say first of all that my group welcomes this proposal, as it makes the statistical basis for an Economic and Monetary Union oriented towards stability and real growth more uniform, immediately comparable and precise. The various sectors have already been mentioned. For me it is crucial that statistical data are from now on more reliable and comparable. This is necessary because we must be able to trust each other, and this applies to the various institutions of the European Union and to all the Member States within the Monetary Union. An adjustment of the procedure is important for two reasons: firstly, for the single market. Reliable and immediately comparable data and statistics are generally of great importance for an accurate representation of the situation and developments in the single market. Secondly, for economic and monetary union. The 1993 regulation on the application of the protocol must be harmonised, at national and regional level, with the methodology of the European System of Integrated Economic Accounts. This is essential for the correct and reliable recording of deficits. This adjustment will allow a more precise assessment of the deficits and debt situation in the Member States. At a technical level, it will have very concrete repercussions on the actual position of the States, since the data are automatically adjusted in line with the government deficit. I also find it positive that the estimate of the deficits for the financial year 1999, which should be published in March 2000, is already being carried out in accordance with the new ESA, which bases the analysis on consolidated and economically relevant aggregates. I would also like to take this opportunity to briefly appeal to all governments and political parties to do everything possible to never have to initiate the excessive deficit procedure.

I'm telling you this myself, as an entrepreneur who is certainly interested in this. But a system like this cannot function! It only works if it is coupled. Let me give you an example: The European Union was right to subsidize the Grönitz steelworks in Brandenburg, even though only 700 of 5,000 jobs remain. But those are competitive jobs, because this steelworks is now the number two tool steel manufacturer in the Federal Republic of Germany. Anyone who now essentially jeopardizes the production of this steelworks by demanding back the subsidies granted at the time is not only endangering the steelworks itself, but is also endangering an employer in this region on whom, of course, small and medium-sized enterprises also depend. This, of course, cannot be the European Union's competition policy! If we want competition, then we must achieve this coupling between economic necessities and business prerequisites. This is also the only chance of building regional economic cycles in underdeveloped regions in this way, which will lead to people having social security and increasing purchasing power. This means we must give far greater consideration to demand-side economic policy than just supply-side economic policy! Mr. President, never since I was elected to this Parliament in 1994 have I encountered a report with such anti-Irish undertones as the report by Mr. Jonckheer we are debating today. I would like to quote from the report verbatim: "State aid per employee... is highest in Italy, Germany... and Ireland, but Ireland clearly comes first when state and Community aid from the Regional and Social Funds are considered together." I believe the rapporteur is simply juggling the numbers here. I find it difficult to understand how he can include the Regional and Social Funds in this mathematical equation. I would remind my colleague that the European Union has agreed to the new guidelines for regional aid for the period up to and including 2000. This was merely an extension of the political objectives of completing the internal market in Europe. Regional disparities must be overcome if the internal market is to develop successfully and prosperously. I welcome the fact that after 2000, grants of 40%, and in the case of SMEs and their fixed capital investments, an additional 15%, are planned for companies that locate in Objective 1 regions. I remind Mr. Jonckheer that Irish companies, or foreign companies in Ireland, are separated from the continental European market by two major seas. No other Member State is at such a disadvantage. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, the ban on cartels is the core of a functioning competition order in Europe. The Commission has found the practical implementation of the enforcement of the ban on cartels unsatisfactory; this is initially acceptable. However, opinions differ regarding the solution. The Commission's proposal does not formally deviate from the ban on cartels, but in effect, this proposal is a transition from a ban subject to authorisation to a licence subject to authorisation. This represents a transition from the prohibition principle to the abuse principle. I and other colleagues strongly reject such a drastic change in the system. I do not accept that a practical implementation problem should be the reason for a change in the legal system.

It is therefore also extremely important that this cumulative condition can be accepted. In conclusion, I would like to repeat that, in my opinion, our colleague Mr Di Pietro has done an excellent job in presenting a report which offers, within the limited framework of existing possibilities, all the guarantees for the preservation of individual human rights and fundamental freedoms. However, if we want to give European citizens a greater sense of security, we must work even harder on judicial cooperation. Mr President, my group is pleased that we are reaching a convention aimed at regulating the daily practice of mutual assistance in criminal matters. The purpose of this regulation is to define the mutual rights and duties between States or citizens or in the relationship between citizens and the authorities. The proposal before us is complex because, although it deals with agreements between Member States, it nevertheless has far-reaching consequences for the relationship between citizens and the authorities. However, the Council's proposal is woefully inadequate in the area of legal protection. In the words of rapporteur Di Pietro, the proposal even displays colossal shortcomings. The convention allows for chain requests for mutual legal assistance that involve the authorities and criminal justice systems of other Member States in the proceedings. The way this is regulated means that no judge can control this entire chain. Additional measures are therefore necessary, such as requiring judicial police officers to comply with any request for testimony in a criminal case involving documents of their own origin. Another point that my group has a problem with is that the Council's proposal flouts the principle of proportionality. In any case, no limitation of the scope is put forward. The convention is therefore not only applicable to the fight against serious and organized crime. It is not even mentioned anywhere that it is limited to criminal law. It is therefore not unthinkable that the Union will soon be fighting mosquitoes with cannons and that citizens' rights will go up in smoke. Mr President, the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, which we are examining today, contains the bare minimum for effective and rapid collaboration between the various judicial and investigative bodies. It concerns notifications, the exchange of information, the temporary transfer of detainees, the restitution of property, testimony by videoconference, investigative and undercover activities, telephone tapping, and so on. This is the bare minimum on which we can agree, and I hasten to add that if certain amendments were to pass, such as, for example, Amendments 32 and 81 or 70 or 71 revised, the entire Convention would be reduced to a simple exchange of notifications or information. Therefore, it should be thrown out, and we would vote against it. I hope that the common sense of the Members of the various groups will encourage them to reject these amendments. The fact that this issue was not the subject of a framework agreement and remained at the level of the conventions constitutes a defeat for Parliament.

It is right to focus on the access of education systems and public administrations to the Internet and their use of the Internet and to create the so-called 'knowledge society', just as it is right to draw attention to access to risk capital and to promote small and medium-sized enterprises by other means. In its proposal for the summit, the Commission has set quantitative targets for the development of employment, unemployment and female employment. In addition, the Commission has also set the objective of reducing poverty problems in Europe over the next ten years in its proposal. I think it is important to place emphasis on common targets, because the policies of different countries in these matters will and must be different. Some Member States of the Union - without mentioning any and without forgetting any - are faced with high youth unemployment, while in others, for example Denmark, youth unemployment is very low and there is a real war going on between employers and training institutions to grab hold of young people. There are differences in problems, systems, cultures and traditions between countries and therefore the choice of instruments to achieve the common goal of employment growth and reduction of social exclusion must also be different. The formulation of employment policy ensures this through the process of exchange of ideas and experiences decided in Luxembourg and although there are many common features of the problems we will have to face in the coming years on the front of social and employment policy, there are also common challenges, and some of them each country will have to solve on its own, but it is equally important that in finding a solution to social problems, countries do not hinder each other, but instead work together and inspire each other. I believe that it is important to pursue a common goal, but it is equally important that each country retains its own sovereignty and responsibility in the formulation of social and employment policy and that there is a certain competition between the systems, which can act as a catalyst for dynamics and development in the formulation of social and employment policy. Mr President, as a representative of Flanders and on behalf of what I would call the nation-regions represented in the European Free Alliance, I was struck by your plea for a strong European approach aimed not so much at strengthening the power of the fifteen Member States, but rather at strengthening their cooperation. You spoke of the existence of fifteen distinct public opinions, but in reality there are many more, as there are enormous differences within the Member States. As a Belgian, do I need to remind you of the differences of opinion between Flanders and Wallonia? Or between the former East Germany and West Germany? There is also the danger of a division of public opinion as a result of globalisation. Just as we once had the gap between rich and poor, we now see the gap emerging between those who can keep pace with the developments in our society and those who cannot and remain on the margins.

We expect the Commission to take this into account in its proposal for a social action programme. Social convergence is also a necessity in view of enlargement, partly to strengthen the social model, partly to counter the risks of social dumping. The Commission should consider drawing up a special action programme on social policy in the context of enlargement. The discussion in committee was constructive. Many amendments were tabled, but it was still possible to reach a consensus on the report. The amendments now put to the vote in plenary have been reduced to 15, which shows a considerable convergence of views. Some of the amendments are now being re-tabled after being discussed in committee. I intend to reject them. I am also against the amendments tabled by the TDI Group, as I do not believe they add anything to the report. My group, however, intends to support Amendment No 14 tabled by the Liberal Group. I think it is a good proposal. It is certainly similar to Amendment No 14. 1, but Amendment No 14 is better. In conclusion, I would like to say that the European Union is not just about trade cooperation. The European Union is also about employment and social justice. Social policy plays a very important role in creating a citizens' Europe. With this report, Parliament intends to make its contribution to strengthening the social dimension in the European reality. We hope that the Council and the Commission will take this contribution seriously and take it into account in future social policy. The Lisbon Summit will provide an excellent opportunity to present such a strategy. Mr President, I warmly congratulate Mr Andersson on the report on the modernisation of social protection that we are debating today. As coordinator of the Group of the European People' s Party in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I am pleased with the compromise that we have managed to reach thanks to Mr Andersson' s strong commitment. I am also pleased that he has taken up a report which I signed in the previous parliamentary term and that the broad lines of his text partly reflect those of mine. The Andersson report refers to a communication published by the Commission in June 1999, the ultimate aim of which is to deepen cooperation between the Member States and the European Union in the field of social protection. From this perspective, important partial objectives are defined: firstly, the promotion of employment and the concern that work should guarantee a fixed income; secondly, the recovery and economic sustainability of pension systems; thirdly, the promotion of social integration and, fourthly, the guarantee of high-quality health services at reasonable costs. In order to achieve these objectives, it is essential to pay close attention to aspects relating to equality between the sexes. I believe that the Commission communication should be welcomed, not least because these four factors, if not the main terms of public debate, are particularly felt by many citizens of the European Union.

Diplomatic pressure is only effective when it is backed by credible economic and military threats. The rest is just wishful thinking. Member States must therefore either allocate more money or make a greater commitment to modern mobile units so that our soldiers have the best possible equipment to protect themselves; we will then welcome the decisions taken last Monday in Sintra. The third heavy burden on your shoulders is ensuring parliamentary control. This must first and foremost be exercised at Member State level. No soldier may be sent on a mission without the consent of the national parliament. It is therefore wrong to talk about a European army. It is a force composed of national units. What is new is that it is fast, well-prepared, and has an effective joint command and modern equipment. There is also, of course, room for a certain right of scrutiny and control on the part of our Parliament. You are often our guest, whether here in plenary or in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, and we consider you to be someone who is both able to talk and listen. Finally, I would like to express my delight with you at the incredible unity of thought and the speed at which this new cooperation is being established. Some of us met the Portuguese Minister of Defence yesterday. He was as delighted and positively surprised as you are that we were able to agree on so much. Remember that there are also non-aligned countries around the table. We share your joy as long as we do not move so quickly as to create a breach in transatlantic cooperation. This is something I would like to emphasize again, and finally, I would stress that the objective of all this is to become so credible that, when we exert economic and military pressure, military intervention never takes place. That's the goal of all this, and it is therefore also important that you work in collaboration with Mr. Patten, because it is military, economic, and diplomatic pressures that, within the Community, will put a barrier to encroachments on the territories surrounding us. Mr. President, Mr. Solana, we are all big children. You are making grand plans, and in your roadmap to 2003, there are 60,000 soldiers. It's extraordinary what we decided to do in Sintra in 2004, 2005, and 2006. But in the year 2000 for Kosovo? You spoke with Mr. Gil-Robles; I received an email from a former colleague, Pierre Pradier, who is in Pristina at the moment. He tells the story of a Serbian doctor who has just been assassinated in Pristina. He treated Roma, Albanians, Serbs, and that's unforgivable in Kosovo. He was murdered, he has three children. We need police officers in Kosovo today! We need soldiers who don't follow a doctrine.

What we need is better internal control and more dismissal options. We must change the Staff Regulations and disciplinary procedures, and not least, the practice. Article 52 of the Staff Regulations, on dismissal for serious omissions, is currently barely applied. We should do a thorough clean-up and clean up our own backyard rather than demand the construction of new, great institutions. Mr President, we all want to contribute to the fight against fraud in Europe. But the question is, what contribution is the European Union making to this? The answer is that we know shockingly little about it. The Tampere Summit was about fighting crime. Everyone was supposedly satisfied with it, but there was hardly any progress on the substance. European anti-fraud legislation is not in force because, as has already been pointed out, the Member States do not ratify the treaty texts that are presented. So, a lot still needs to be done there. But what needs to be done? Two things, and Mrs Theato's report shows this clearly. First, the same sanctions must apply to European fraud in all Member States of the European Union. Harmonization in this specific area. Secondly, a European Public Prosecutor's Office must be created, with two tasks: first, to assist and support national prosecutors in prosecuting European fraud cases, and second, to ensure judicial oversight of Europol and OLAF, because these two investigative agencies can currently operate without legal oversight. We needn't be afraid of the European Public Prosecutor's Office; everyone around me sees only ghosts. It really is a positive thing. Just like Europol. Europol, police cooperation, is not above national police services, but serves as a forum for the exchange of information between police departments. That is precisely what a small, limited European Public Prosecutor's Office must do, only not at the investigation stage, but at the prosecution stage. Parliament is in favor. The Committee of Independent Experts is in favor as is the same. I appeal to the Council of Ministers and the European Commission to also commit to this measure. Mr President, I would like to focus on the issue of Corpus Juris. I wholeheartedly support the observations made by Mrs. Morgan on this matter. The Corpus Juris was established without any public debate or participation. A European Public Prosecutor's Office, committed to the continental European principle of investigation, with Europe-wide decision-making powers overriding national law, would have a lasting impact on the traditional system in Ireland as well as in the United Kingdom. Member States have a right to be informed about the possibility of a unified criminal code and a European Public Prosecutor's Office. When such a plan was first presented, it was stated that it would be limited to cases of fraud against the EU budget. But when the Corpus Juris was actually launched in San Sebastian in 1977—in front of a select audience of 140 legal experts and behind closed doors—the then President of the European Parliament, Gil-Robles Gil-Delgado, stated that this was only a preliminary stage and that the intention was to extend EU jurisdiction in criminal matters to all areas of crime. We need a public debate on this issue. Member States and their citizens must be fully informed. The question of a potential threat to the traditional legal system in Ireland and the United Kingdom must also be addressed.

Mr President, I have taken note of your statement and the existence of this joint resolution. Provided the Bureau services confirm that it has been duly tabled, it goes without saying that it will be taken into account. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday at 12 noon. (The sitting closed at 8:14 p.m.) Approval of the Minutes of the previous sitting Mr President, I would simply like to announce that there was a terrorist attack in Madrid this morning. One person was killed in a car bomb explosion. My point is simply to reiterate, on behalf of my group, such terrorist acts. Thank you very much, Mrs Fraga. We have already heard of this deplorable incident. Unfortunately, Spanish society is once again being ravaged by murderous terrorism, and your words, as you will understand, resonate with the President particularly given that this sitting is taking place under the Spanish Presidency. (Parliament approved the Minutes.) Resumption of session I declare the session of the European Parliament, which was adjourned on Friday, 21 January 2000, resumed. Madam President, please allow me to remind you that tomorrow marks the second anniversary of the Monte Cermis disaster. Two years ago, in Cavalese, Italy, an American aircraft flying from the NATO base at Aviano cut the cables of a cable car during a low-level flight exercise – flying below the altitude permitted for safety reasons – and killed more than 20 European citizens. Since then, the families of the victims, denied the consolation of justice because the guilty pilot was not brought to justice, have been expecting at least prompt financial compensation from the United States. I therefore appeal to the President of Parliament and the President of the Commission to lobby the US authorities for immediate compensation and thus help the victims' families obtain justice. Thank you, Mrs Angelilli, I take note. Agenda The next item on the agenda is the establishment of the order of business. At the request of various political groups and following the conclusion of the Conference of Presidents which has just concluded, I propose that you add to the agenda, pursuant to Rule 50 of our Rules of Procedure, a one-and-a-half-hour debate on topical, urgent and important issues relating to the Union's response to the intergovernmental negotiations in Austria. If you agree to this proposal, the President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Seixas da Costa, and the President of the Commission, Mr Romano Prodi, will open the debate. Who wishes to speak in favour of this proposal? Madam President, I take the floor to support the decision of the Conference of Presidents and, just as I publicly criticized the Presidency in January, I now take this opportunity to say, on my own behalf and on behalf of the Socialist Group, that we consider the statements made by the Presidency on this subject to be appropriate; we share their content, timing, and form. Now, Madam President, it is truly difficult to find a debate more in keeping with Rule 50 of our Rules of Procedure. This is a topical, extremely important, and urgent debate. Therefore, we believe we must amend the agenda to accommodate it. (Applause) Does anyone wish to speak against this proposal?

That requirement is clearly the single market. To what extent has the single market already been consolidated? I would like to remind Mr. Prodi and his colleagues, who are still here, of the results of the study that the Commission itself carried out among 3,000 European companies. Nearly 40% of the companies in this study still bear additional costs to homologate their products or services according to national specifications. This is a study by the Commission itself. These are classic symptoms of the continued obstruction exercised by national governments; red tape blocks market entry. The Commission's program reflects a worrying complacency regarding the completion of the internal market. We must keep the pressure high in all areas, removing additional barriers, intensifying pressure on Member States that flout single market rules, and, of course, extending it to new areas of fundamental importance, such as financial services. Only on a solid foundation such as the single market can the enlargement agenda be successfully implemented. An enlarged Europe must enhance the Union's current virtues. A single market extending throughout the enlarged Union will be a colossal achievement. I conclude by saying, on behalf of my Conservative colleagues—and we constitute the second largest national delegation in this Parliament—that we are committed to fully supporting the Commission and Mr. Prodi in accomplishing this historic task. Madam President, Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, at the time of our investiture vote, we gave you an appointment for today. Today the serious business begins, as it is precisely now that we are going to pronounce on your program. Allow me, in the words you have spoken before this House, to focus my speech on what you have called new governance. It makes it an instrument of reconciliation with our fellow citizens. But behind this term "new governance," I believe there simply lies the question of the functioning of the institutions, the question of the functioning of our public authorities, if we agree that the European Union must be a public authority. The articulation between the Union's institutions, the powers of the Member States, and local and regional authorities is all very well. But is this how we will reconcile citizens and European integration? Is this truly how we will respond to the fundamental questions, which are not so much "who does what," but rather "what we do together," since this is what sows confusion among our fellow citizens? In your speech, you mention the challenges that await us: those of globalization, those of enlargement, and, I would add, the future of our social model. That is why my group and I insist so much on this draft charter, because we believe that if we have included the drafting of this charter of fundamental rights in our timetable, it is because we find ourselves at a time of rendezvous with history, where our Union needs to redefine the values around which it has been built within its current borders, but also in the perspective of the future enlargements that we desire, although not at any price. Our fellow citizens expect more Europe from us, but not just any Europe.

These concerns are justified. It has been said many times: justice delayed is justice denied. The Commission has every sympathy for the comments raised. For this very reason, I would like to formulate my response as follows. As Parliament is well aware, the Commission is convinced that, without a radical reform, in the short term, the Community judicial authorities run the risk of no longer being able to carry out their tasks within a reasonable timeframe. The Commission has therefore consulted a group of experts to advise on reforms that could be implemented in order to enable the Court and the General Court to maintain the quality and coherence of their case law in the decades to come. The Commission takes note of the request from the General Court to strengthen its staff, but considers that for the time being the proposed transfer of competences should be considered in the light of the study just mentioned. In other words, once the study is completed, the Commission will issue an opinion as soon as possible. Thank you, Commissioner. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11.00. Exceptional financial assistance to Kosovo The next item is the debate on the report (A5-0022/2000) by Mr Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the proposal for a Council decision providing exceptional financial assistance to Kosovo (COM(1999) 0598 - C5-0045/2000 - 1999/0240(CNS)). I have been informed that the rapporteur will be a few minutes late. I propose that we start the debate immediately, pointing out that the rapporteur will speak as soon as he arrives in the Chamber. Mr Bourlanges, as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, now has the floor. Mr President, this is an important and urgent matter. Parliament, at the request of the Commission, is taking a quick decision because it is necessary to spread the news that men and women are dying today in Kosovo simply because the temperature has dropped to -25 degrees and that some people, who work for free, are doing a huge amount of work in order to ensure minimal support. We have therefore received an emergency request, to which we are responding favourably. EUR 35 million has been requested. We agree to grant it and we are calling on the Commission to ensure that, once the decision has been taken, the sums are allocated and paid as quickly as possible. This is macro-financial aid, which is causing reactions everywhere because it does not respect the canons of the free market doctrine which consist in not intervening financially to support an administration. We do not share this opinion, but we believe that it is essential to contribute to the establishment of an administration in Kosovo and that it is not at all absurd to contribute directly to the payment of public officials in the region. It would have been very useful if we had been able to do so in Russia in the 1990s to prevent the dissolution of that State. The second major problem is that we are called to provide assistance, as promised by the donors, but then we are the only ones who pay since the others do not contribute.

On the contrary: its draft must comply with the criminal law legislation of each Member State. The intention to achieve a unanimous decision may lead to compromises that do not stand up to this scrutiny. Scrupulous parliamentary scrutiny by the European Parliament, but above all by the national parliaments, is of great importance. Di Pietro's proposal to delete the current Article 18, which concerns, among other things, the interception of telephone conversations, is understandable but very rigorous. The wording of Article 18 is unclear: it restricts the activities of the intelligence services, but apparently permits the interception of telecommunications by one Member State on the territory of another without prior authorization. In doing so, Member States would make themselves largely vulnerable, and it is doubtful whether sufficient guarantees exist to protect both the state in which the interception takes place and its citizens. Suggested additions, such as repeated references to the European Convention on Human Rights, the rights of the defence and suspects, as well as the failure of Member States to implement the European Convention on Human Rights, excessively bloat the text of the Convention. I recognise the problem, but believe it could have been resolved with a single amendment to the text. Despite certain reservations, the Dutch members of the EDD Group will not withhold their support for the Di Pietro report in the vote. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have before us a report that is of the utmost importance, not only for its content, but also because it represents a first step towards establishing smoother relations in the field of judicial cooperation. This has taken place exclusively at the level of intergovernmental relations, and European citizens have not been able to discern any concrete signs of the oft-invoked Union citizenship in this area. On the one hand, judicial measures have nothing to do with the Community dimension, but on the other, we are already experiencing a degree of freedom of movement for people from which criminals also benefit. However, according to Article 29 of the Treaty, the Union's objective is to offer citizens a high level of safety within an area of freedom, security and justice by developing common action among the Member States in police matters and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and by preventing and combating racism and xenophobia. It must be stressed that the creation of Europol is already a step forward, but the next step must now be taken: strengthening judicial cooperation in criminal matters, so as to gradually establish a genuine European judicial area in line with the objective of creating an area of freedom, security and justice. The aim of this draft Convention is therefore to supplement the traditional instruments already existing in other areas of law and to facilitate their application in the Member States, with a view to improving judicial cooperation in criminal matters through rapid and effective mutual assistance, while fully respecting the essential guarantees of the rights of the defence and the general principles of human rights enshrined in the law of the Member States themselves and in the European Convention on Human Rights. It is precisely this reservation regarding essential rights, freedoms and guarantees that has led us to support the withdrawal of the proposed text on telephone interception, recommending that the Council propose an autonomous legal instrument to remedy this situation.

Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I completely agree with you. The problem is not Mr Kouchner, but the legal basis for his action, that is, Resolution 1244. Having said that, I believe that the Union's responsibility, and therefore your responsibility and ours too, is to work towards overcoming the provisional nature of Resolution 1244 and developing a future perspective for the entire region. In my view, the lack of a fixed perspective is provoking or encouraging the violence, accidents, and murders to which Mr Alavanos referred. Does the Council intend to raise the question of Kosovo's definitive status? And if so, does it intend to do so in conjunction with a general reorganization of the region, avoiding, as far as possible, the creation of numerous microstates, as some seek, and reuniting the separate parts, in this case Kosovo and Albania? Since the author is not present, Question No 7 lapses. Question No 8 by (H-0796/99): Subject: New INTERREG initiative. In point 1 of Annex 2 to its draft communication on INTERREG, entitled 'Promoting urban, rural and coastal areas', the Commission permits the renovation and development of historic town centres by means of a joint cross-border strategy. However, residential buildings are excluded from this. Given that rural areas contain many houses of historic interest, including very small buildings, and given the need, for various reasons, to combat rural depopulation and make rural areas more attractive, does the Council not consider that these objectives could be furthered by also providing financial support for housing projects in the INTERREG areas? Mr President, The Council, and I would even say particularly the Portuguese Presidency, are extremely aware of the importance of the problems to which you, Mr President, referred in your question, and I would like to say that we have always paid the greatest attention to Community policies for the development of rural areas. In this regard, I would like to point out the new aid scheme for rural development, adopted in May 1999, which constitutes the Community reference framework for promoting the sustainable development of rural areas. As we know, this was one of the developments that took place during the negotiations on Agenda 2000 and the treatment of agricultural issues at Community level. Through the European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund (EAGGF), the aim of this Community support framework is to reverse the trend towards rural degradation, to which you, Mr President, quite rightly refer in your question. On the other hand, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) also contributes, within its remit, to promoting economic and social cohesion by correcting the main regional imbalances and contributing to the development and restructuring of rural areas. In this regard, it should be remembered that the ERDF also contributes to promoting sustainable development and the equally sustainable creation of jobs in rural areas. The combined effect of these Community instruments enables us to implement a development policy for rural areas, which today, moreover, represents a development and support line of the Common Agricultural Policy in one of its fields of action, as well as of regional policy.

Let us say it once again: the European Union's cooperation and development policy is inconsistent. Therefore, on behalf of the Greens/European Free Alliance Group, I call on Parliament, the institutions, and the Commission to finally try to bring coherence to our policy. Mr. President, I consider this debate particularly timely not only because of the importance of the issue of development in general, but also because of its relevance. The Seattle meeting failed, and North-South relations were on display there for even more reasons. The meeting held in that North American city highlighted that globalization entails profoundly unequal and unfavorable outcomes for the poorest countries. At this very moment—and clearly influenced by that failure—the Tenth United Nations Conference on Trade and Development is still being held in Bangkok. In the meantime, as has been said, the negotiations that determined the future of the Lomé Convention have been concluded. That alone is enough to highlight the relevance of this topic today. And we can also add the upcoming EU-OAU summit, finally agreed for next April in Cairo. But any analysis, however cursory, inevitably leads us to the conclusion that something, or even much, is wrong in North-South relations, including between the European Union and the least developed countries. Suffice it to consider that the category of so-called least developed countries has grown, in the last thirty years, from 25 to 48 countries, which now represent 13% of humanity, but account for only 0.4% of global exports and 0.6% of global imports. Or the unfortunate circumstance that public development aid, promoted by rich countries, has been reduced by almost 23% since 1990. Moreover, the recent cuts related to this area in the Community budget for the current financial year are part of this trend, in addition to constituting a negative and misleading political signal. The rather unsuspecting Mr. Michel Camdessus, still director of the International Monetary Fund, stated in his speech last Sunday at the opening of the UNCTAD meeting—and I'll quote—that "the international community gives with one hand and pulls with the other." He was referring, naturally, to the support granted by developed countries to less developed ones. Such a statement, which seems ironic coming from whom it comes, but the truth is that he uttered it, I myself had the opportunity to hear it, does not seem to me to be at odds with current reality and moves me to affirm that it is essential to rethink and cast North-South relations in new molds, in particular the need to rethink the role of the European Union in this framework, because the truth is that the promotion of a new, more just and equitable world order cannot - or should not - cease to constitute a strategic objective of the Union, so it is essential to reflect on the globalization underway, taking into account its essential orientations and the dominant underlying interests and, within that framework and in particular, the enormous consequences and the pernicious effects it has for the least developed countries.

Finally, his proposal would deny a passport to those companies that do not want to carry out the activities covered by the Investment Services Directive. As regards Mr Huhne's question, he mentioned forward hedging transactions this morning; but such transactions are already permitted under the existing Article 21(1) of Directive 611/85 on UCITS. So what Mr Huhne is asking for is already possible. Mrs Villiers referred to the possibility of improving portfolio management. This too is already possible under the current legislation. I am referring to the same Article 21(1) mentioned in relation to Mr Huhne's question. Mrs Kauppi asks why the Commission has prepared a package of measures divided into two separate proposals. The fact is that the first proposal is essentially about the product, while the second is mainly about the service provider and prospectuses for UCITS. The separation of these two proposals which deal with two different sets of issues should facilitate the negotiation process in the Council. The Commission must not only listen to Parliament and take its proposals into consideration but, as is well known, it must also deal with the Council. That is why the Commission has presented these two proposals separately. Finally, Mr Balfe complained about the limitations, which in his opinion are excessive, which characterise the entire proposal presented by the Commission. It seems to us, however, that these limitations are justified, firstly, by the need to diversify investments, secondly, by the vulnerability caused by the need to repay investments at any time, and thirdly by the aim of avoiding excessive interference in investment funds. For all these reasons, the Commission believes, also considering the caution that must always be used in this sector, that these limitations are necessary. The debate is closed. The vote will take place at 12.00. Mutual assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States The next item is the report (A5-0019/2000) by Mr Di Pietro, on behalf of the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, on the draft Council act establishing the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, by letters of 3 August 1999 and 3 December 1999, the Council asked the European Parliament, pursuant to Article 39 of the Treaty, to express its opinion on a draft convention between the Member States aimed at ensuring better mutual assistance in criminal matters. As you can see, therefore, this is a very important project which will actually help the Member States of the Union to equip themselves with a more complete and more homogeneous instrument of mutual assistance. In truth, there are still today, within the Council, some divergences regarding the type of convention, regarding some of the clauses contained therein. Some of these differences have already been resolved, others remain. The spirit of the proposal, however, is to provide legal practitioners - magistrates first and foremost, but also interested citizens - with a valid operational tool for the fight against crime, while respecting fundamental guarantees of defense and the general principles of human rights.

This infectious anemia of salmon is caused by an orthomixomicrovirus that decomposes the salmon's blood, thus causing its death. The disease spreads easily through mucilage in salt water, etc. The 1993 directive allows for the removal not only of the diseased fish, but also of all fish from an infected farm, just as if a cow in a herd becomes ill, the entire herd is slaughtered as a precautionary measure. Now, we are being proposed to relax this directive so that not the entire stock is culled, but only those fish reported as diseased. As for the other fish, there would then be time to wait and see what happens, depending on local circumstances. I consider this an extremely dangerous approach. I would like to draw my colleagues' attention to this, because one cannot be satisfied with the claim that the temperature limit of 27ºC provides sufficient protection for humans and therefore there is no danger. But does this also apply to women? There are no studies on human tissue in this regard yet. There is also a risk to the environment, because, as we know, salmon have an incubation period, and consequently, when consumed, they can transmit this virus without themselves becoming ill and therefore pose a danger. Another danger to the environment is that this disease is transmitted to wild fish, as we have seen. For this reason, together with my colleague Patricia McKenna, we have tabled amendments to the Commission's proposals. Mr Piétrasanta explained why we support some aspects of the Commission's proposal, particularly the development of a vaccine and compensation for fish farmers who are forced to cull their fish. The idea of changing the culling policy does not make us very happy. Now, although it has been stated on several occasions that Norway has done a better job in combating the ISA epidemic and that the proposed changes will enable us to achieve a similarly high standard to Norway's, it must be said that there is more than just a difference between Norwegian policy and Community policy. This is a Community measure which also applies to Ireland, where I come from, should similar unfortunate circumstances arise there. There are further differences, namely the approach to inspections of infected holdings, the closure periods, restrictions on the movement of contaminated fish and material, and so on. Before we hastily copy the Norwegian eradication policy, we should try to see whether we cannot contain the disaster by other means. A lot has been said about BSE in the past. For years the Greens have been urging us to tackle the BSE problem. If we had done that at the time, many farmers and the EU could have saved a lot of money. This is also to do with environmental protection, with the protection of farmers themselves, and with the protection of public health. I would like to thank Mr Hudghton for his excellent report on infectious anaemia in salmon and his general support for the measures proposed by the Commission. I would also like to thank all my previous speakers for their contributions this evening.

The first is the harmonization of national spatial planning policies and regional development policies. Subsidies are not enough to achieve development when infrastructure or public services are lacking. This is therefore a fundamental question that we must ask ourselves: how can we ensure that the Union's policy is coordinated with subsidiary national spatial planning policies? The second challenge is that of enlargement, which will naturally have considerable consequences in both budgetary and geographical terms. These are two projects that I invite the Commissioner to implement and in which I ask him to involve us. Finally, in this period of natural disasters, I would like to raise the issue of the use of the Structural Funds. We know that it is up to each Member State to redistribute part of the envelopes. We should not, as the Member States tend to want, see Europe disappear completely. Today, public opinion and the press accuse us of being absent, even though we are going to finance a large part of national efforts. I believe we must be able to say this loud and clear. I think we should also establish or require Member States to provide information on European aid whenever it is mobilized to repair damage caused by natural disasters or accidents. Mr. President, the priority given to financial and monetary criteria reinforces the rise of inequalities in all their forms. For experts on the French plan, for example, the most likely scenario today is a widening of regional differences within each country. However, the Structural Funds have contributed to slowing this process. Our project for a Europe focused on meeting social needs aims for upward convergence of living conditions. Its implementation would certainly imply an extension of redistribution instruments such as the Structural Funds. In particular, we are proposing a unified capital tax, which would provide funding for funds used to support the harmonization of social protection systems and the reduction of working hours at European level. However, the Commission, which is required to present guidelines, is doing so only reluctantly and vaguely. The report proposed today restores the role of politics. It is one of the steps towards an employment and sustainable development policy. This is what will lead us to vote for it. Mr. President, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work. I believe that in the coming years, faced with the challenge of globalization and enlargement to the East, Europe will need more than ever adequate and precise guidance on the programming and revival of its economy. Therefore, Europe as a whole, and each of the Member States in particular, will have to make the best use of all its resources and capacities, and therefore also the available structural funds. To achieve this, we need a European Commission that, beyond its good intentions, clarifies its guidelines and commits itself as much as possible to monitoring the use of these resources by Member States.

Furthermore, the way this Council is being prepared is very illustrative of this. First, the degree of seriousness and depth of the document presented in January. Second, the various preparatory conferences, the contribution that both employers and trade unionists are making to this Summit. And above all, the latest contribution in terms of research made at the recent meeting, attended by Nobel Prize winners and Ministers of Science and Technology. It demonstrates the seriousness and attention to content in the preparation of the Summit. But we also support the initiative with regard to the central objective already stated here, because for the first time not only is the issue of employment and social issues once again at the center of the European debate, but it is once again considered possible to "achieve the goal of full employment." For many years, many people said that this was impossible, that in the new societies it would no longer be possible. I congratulate you, Mr. President, for bringing this issue back to the agenda without denying social cohesion and values that, for us, are fundamental, because they are not only the foundation of the founding project of the European Union, but also the foundation of our civilization and, above all, of our way of understanding the degree of demand for solidarity among all Europeans. We already said it here in January, and I would like to repeat it: we are not content with this strategic objective being the priority of a presidency; it is only a priority for six months. And we once again challenge the Council and the Commission to include it: not as a six-month priority, but as a goal of the European Union, as important as enlargement or the deepening of the European Union. Only in this way can it fulfill the objective of seriousness with which the Presidency is preparing this Extraordinary Council. Congratulations, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, and Mr. President of the Commission, I would like to express my delight at the fact that such an active agenda in favor of employment and economic development has been raised for the Lisbon Summit. It is an agenda that emphasizes the need for a strong and dynamic economy and improved competitiveness to guarantee the goal of greater employment in the EU. It is thought-provoking that the EU is so far behind the United States in terms of both research and development of new technologies and job creation. We need to join forces to promote research and development, including research related to information technologies. We need to strengthen the internal market and create the conditions necessary to maximize the benefits of new technologies and develop trade via the Internet. It is right to draw attention to the issue of access to and use of the Internet by educational systems and public administrations and to create what has been called the "knowledge society." It is also right to focus on access to venture capital and to strengthen the position of small and medium-sized enterprises in other ways.

We demand that this opportunity bring significant changes to our life in society, that democracy also be synonymous with equality between men and women, that the latter not be excluded economically or socially, as is the case today. That values dear to women, such as peace, fraternity, equality, justice, security, and environmental protection, predominantly guide life in the European Union and, if possible, in the world. To achieve this, women must be given the opportunity to intervene against the inertia of a society that has until now been essentially imbued with masculine values. Our experience teaches us that freedom and the ability to decide cannot be begged for, they must be won. Let us continue this conquest and may this new century bring us victory, not over men, nor over anyone: the victory of equality between men and women. We cannot afford to miss a single opportunity. The great challenge now facing all Europeans in general, and women in particular, concerns the new economy and new technologies in the information sector. The Lisbon Summit, which will be held at the end of the month, particularly concerns women. We must increase the employment rate in Europe, which is significantly lower than that of the United States and Japan. To do this, we must put many more women into work and into new jobs, in which the European Union has a deficit. I therefore ask the Council and the Commission what proposals they intend to present at the next Lisbon Summit so that the new economy and the new Europe we wish to build definitively incorporate equality between men and women. Mr President, Commissioner, I welcomed your intervention because you dared to mention the Member States where women's political representation is a success, namely Finland, France and Sweden, but also because you did not fail to mention the States where things are going less well, which is the case in my own country in particular and Greece, a country you forgot to name. I have also heard that very few women are likely to stand on the lists in the next elections to be held in Greece. I believe that this is very serious. I appreciated your intervention because I believe that it is high time that we had concrete means within the European institutions to improve the position of women in politics. This is why I believe it is essential that this Parliament continues to insist on quotas and that this is clearly stated in the resolution. I myself, Commissioner, am a product of quotas, and I do not believe that a single Member of this House can demonstrate that I am less competent as a result. In some of our European countries, it seems that meritocracy remains such a male-dominated principle that women have no chance at all.

Between 1998 and 1999, loyalists attacked and shot dead 123 people, compared to 93 for republicans. In 1999, 193 cases of legal proceedings were brought against loyalists and 97 against republicans. Since 1 January 2000, there have been six murders perpetrated by loyalists, compared to two by republicans; loyalists have been involved in six serious shootings, including one that resulted in a death, and republicans in five shootings. Mr President, this situation cannot continue and must be remedied. Mr President, the Treaty of Amsterdam set out an important objective for the Union. A task that all Members, the Council, and the Commission must undertake during this legislative period: the creation, as has already been said, of an area of freedom, security, and justice. The Tampere Council, the driving force behind this objective, proposed some goals, but the five-year period provided for the development of Chapter IV of the Treaty is too long for the urgent solutions that certain problems require. My first thought is that Parliament must not remain on the sidelines of the important decisions that will be taken in this area and that its participation in the decision-making process must be guaranteed, particularly since this is a citizens' project, as the Commissioner rightly said. My second thought is that we must move quickly towards the adoption of a common asylum system. We must approve common procedural standards and, above all, put an end to the current confusion between immigration for political reasons and that motivated by economic reasons. The latest laws on foreigners, adopted in my country, Spain, or in Belgium, are a warning and demonstrate that the communitarization of immigration policy must be adopted as quickly as possible. My third thought concerns the Union's external action in the field of immigration and asylum.
