We must not and cannot give the impression that the Union only wants to defend itself against an avalanche of refugees and economic immigrants. We must focus on a policy of development cooperation with the neighbouring countries of the East and the Mediterranean area, but with rigour, with economic resources and in close collaboration with public institutions, which cooperate to protect citizens whose most fundamental rights are violated or who wish to emigrate in order to meet their most basic needs. Finally, with regard to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, European citizens need to visualise their citizenship. The euro, employment, or even security are not enough for them. They need the "European soul," as a famous Spanish professor put it. Mr President, unlike some of the previous speakers, I would like to return to the words of our Portuguese ministers and Mr Vitorino. As Mr Ceyhun said, the words of this trio resonated like music to our ears. As with all music, it must have a beautiful melody and be well orchestrated. Many of us here are looking forward to the next six months with great optimism.

This is particularly evident in France: in the Champagne-Ardennes region, which I represent, GNP fell from 105 to 94% of the Community average, in the Pays-de-Loire region from 95 to 91%, and in Auvergne from 89 to 83%. The Rhône-Alpes and Alsace regions are no exception to this general trend. It is also evident in Sweden and Finland, where unemployment has risen alarmingly in recent years, and in several regions of the United Kingdom. In view of this, it may seem surprising that Objective 2, intended for industrial and rural regions undergoing economic restructuring, was sacrificed in the context of the reform of the Structural Funds in favour of Objectives 1 and 3: it has ECU 22.5 billion at its disposal for the period 1999-2006, roughly the same amount as in the period 1994-1999. The areas eligible under Objective 5b will have to make the greatest sacrifices in this regard: in France, 27% of the population eligible for Structural Funds will no longer be eligible at the end of the transitional period, and this percentage is even higher in some regions such as Pays de la Loire, Alsace and Basse-Normandie, right-wing electoral strongholds disadvantaged by the left-wing government's partisan philanthropy. On this basis, it is extremely doubtful whether regional policy can contribute to a balanced development of the territories of the Member States of the European Union. Von Wogau report (A5-0069/1999) Given the employment situation in the Community and the European Union's stated ambition to combat unemployment decisively, the Commission's analysis of industrial concentrations should take account of factors other than competition alone. As an example, I would like to cite the restructuring of ABB-Alsthom Power, from which a large delegation of workers from all over Europe is here in Strasbourg today. The management of ABB-Alsthom Power, which was formed from a merger in June 1999, has announced a restructuring that will lead to job losses in some countries. This disastrous employment situation raises numerous questions, particularly regarding the information provided to the European Works Council, which has existed since 1996. This means that the Community directive on European Works Councils must be updated and strengthened. This also includes monitoring mergers, taking into account employment, the environment, and consumer concerns. The report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs was inadequate in this regard, which is why I abstained. (PT) The Commission wishes to apply the principle of subsidiarity in the area of Community competition policy, and for this reason it is decentralising decision-making powers regarding abuses of dominant positions through agreements between undertakings that distort the market, transferring them to national authorities and courts, while still leaving matters relating to mergers and State aid subject to the notification system. The current position is aimed at creating faster and cheaper forms of competition policy, with Community law now being applied at the level of national courts rather than the European Court of Justice, and even referring the matter to specialised courts. This partial renationalisation of competition policy may entail higher costs for the Member States. On the other hand, and the rapporteur points out that, in the name of competition policy, state monopolies have often been replaced by private monopolies, through the privatisation of important public sectors and undertakings, as has happened in Portugal, with negative consequences for the country and for workers.

In response, the Commission has made several commitments and has undoubtedly adopted numerous reform measures. It must be acknowledged that the new President, Mr. Prodi, and his team are genuinely committed to implementing the financial control requirements established by Parliament. Nevertheless, the reform of the European Commission must now be placed within the framework of the debate that will take place in the run-up to the upcoming Intergovernmental Conference and the reform of various EU policies and initiatives. The current Treaties of the European Union will be amended to ensure, for example, that enlargement is a success. I am sure that the forthcoming reforms of the Community institutions will be analyzed during this debate. But for the small Member States, it is important that the reforms of the European Commission that are about to take place do not jeopardize the representation of small Member States within the Commission. Mr. President, the Commission is asking for discharge for 1997, but, in reality, it does not deserve it. The 1997 financial year was the responsibility of the old Commission; therefore, the new Commission feels that it has no responsibility to assume. It is true that the implementation of the 1997 budget was the responsibility of the old Commission, but the new Commission has, on the other hand, undertaken to clean up the past scandals, and I must confess that I am not at all impressed by what it has done so far. The old mentality of covering things up and supporting one's friends is unfortunately still present. Some people say that we would be better off putting the old culprits into oblivion and starting afresh, but I do not think we can start afresh unless we have first sorted things out. I am thinking particularly of the recent scandals affecting the ECHO programme. I am absolutely shocked at the difficulty in obtaining documents relating to this affair. I am the rapporteur for the ECHO programme in the Committee on Budgetary Control, and I find it extremely difficult to carry out my work when the Commission refuses to give me the information I need. From the outside, one gets the impression that the Commission has things to hide. My investigations unfortunately also tend to show that this may be the case. The Commission is not putting everything on the table and is repeating its age-old practices. These are the practices that were fatal to the former Commission. I therefore fully support the request to give the Assembly unconditional access to administrative documents, otherwise we cannot carry out our work. Thank you very much, Commissioner Schreyer! The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. Follow-up to the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts The next item is the report (A5-0001/2000) by Mr van Hulten, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the follow-up to the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts on the reform of the Commission.

In some passages of the Commission's proposals, perhaps excessive caution has been exercised, for example, with the demand that the imprisoned defendant be allowed to decide whether or not to consent to temporary transfer to another Member State of the Union for the purposes of an investigation. Personally, I consider it unacceptable that Mr. Pinochet, for example, should be allowed to decide whether or not to be transferred to Spain for a face-to-face interview. Or with the demand that the witness or expert—and not just the accused—be provided with legal counsel during remote questioning. But these are minor deficiencies, unintentional on the part of the rapporteur, which will hopefully be remedied by the vote of this House. The rapporteur has demonstrated commendable commitment, which must be acknowledged, and for which I thank him. The overall result is remarkable and will hopefully be fully taken into account by the Council. As already mentioned, one issue, the most sensitive, remains unresolved: it concerns Article 18 of the Convention, which concerns the direct interception of telecommunications by another Member State, without the latter requesting assistance from the Member State in which the interception is carried out, which is now possible thanks to modern technology. This issue is highly controversial, as it represents a potential source of abuse. While it could be argued that the proposed arrangements are, on the whole, better than nothing, the Committee nevertheless found them inadequate and insufficiently secure. It therefore merits further consideration. At a time when the conflicting reports on ECHELON raise the specter of Big Brother, it is likely that more detailed research will be needed into the instruments and methods that can, on the one hand, protect individuals' rights and, on the other, facilitate the effective, yet lawful and legal, fight against crime. The aim is therefore to achieve, wherever possible, a delicate balance between the effectiveness of the fight against crime and the respect for human freedom and dignity: an objective pursued not only by individual Member States but now also by the policy of the Union, which aspires to become an area of freedom, security, and justice. This objective may still be a long way off, but it can be achieved step by step. The most important step will be the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States, but for today we will content ourselves with this small step because it goes in the right direction. Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent explanations. They highlight some serious flaws in this proposal. The lack of linguistic clarity will inevitably lead to legal uncertainty. But legal certainty is something that is absolutely essential on such crucial issues. Because of its sloppy drafting, the Convention can be interpreted very broadly, and it ignores the strict conditions that must apply to surveillance under the European Convention on Human Rights. Article 18 permits surveillance in another Member State without its involvement. Not only should this be deleted, but the entire surveillance title should be scrapped altogether. An FBI initiative compiled the user requirements that form the basis of current legislation. The Council proposal containing these requirements, ENFOPOL 98, was adopted by this Parliament last May in the Schmid report.

The fundamental question, in my opinion, that this Parliament, the Commission, and the Council must ask themselves is this: What is Europe? What does Europe mean and give us beyond and beyond the parameters of our national borders? Europe is its people, its history, and now its community; but the reason Culture 2000 is so important to us is this: I bet that when we ask the question "what is Europe?" we answer by saying "it is our art, it is our literature, and it is our heritage." That is what Culture 2000 represents. It represents the possibility of maintaining a European identity in the 21st century, an identity that silences the echoes of division, war, poverty, opportunity, and poverty in reality. And beyond that—and this is more prosaic, Madam President—it means that we have the capacity to learn from previous policy initiatives and implement them in new programs that are broad, cross-cutting, and that benefit our creative industries to the extent necessary. The program promotes mobility and opens the doors of culture to the socially disadvantaged and excluded. I only regret that we do not have sufficient funds to promote this program in line with our aspirations and to make it available to everyone. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have now reached the end of a long journey. After the conciliation stage, our institutions can now officially approve the new "Culture 2000" framework program. We will thus have a fully suitable instrument to carry out, over the next five years, clear, well-structured, and—I am sure—fruitful action in favor of the cultural sector. I welcome this happy ending here today and express my gratitude to you. I thank all those in this Parliament who worked to make a successful conciliation conclusion possible. I wish to express my particular thanks to the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Media and Sport, and in particular to its rapporteur, Mr. Graça Moura, its chairman, Mr. Gargani, the European Parliament delegation and the leaders of the political groups, the Conciliation Committee and its chairman, Mr. Imbeni. All of them have made a constructive, balanced, and decisive contribution. Throughout these negotiations, they have been of great help, and it must be said that the difficult, sometimes painful, negotiation was nevertheless completed in a minimum amount of time. We now have a framework programme, the first of its kind for the cultural sector, which allows us to consider our action from a new angle and to work for culture in a more comprehensive, but also more complete and in-depth way. I would like to welcome, along with the Honourable Members, these satisfactory results, which, despite a budgetary situation that falls short of our ambitions, should allow us to consider the future in a completely positive light. I would like to underline what President Gargani just said: the Commission has issued a statement on the mid-term review.

This is, in reality, an international agreement and a trade agreement. In conclusion, let me express the great hopes I have for the peace process in that region, a part of the world that desperately needs it to regroup and reform and help its millions of disadvantaged and poverty-stricken citizens. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, it is obvious that the rules must be respected. It is also obvious that our partners must enforce them. Everyone understands that we are concerned about this today, but I would not want our demand to be seen as selective. Nor would I want our oral question to be received as an accusation. Because our demand is not selective, the Commission must also feel invited to study the use of Community funds in the regions neighboring Israel. And because the Commission's question is not, and should not be, seen as an accusation, I wish to recall two essential points for the balance of our action. First, everyone familiar with the region knows that the development of the Palestinian economy is closely linked to the economic cooperation agreement with Israel. The Oslo Protocol provides for customs integration encompassing Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Anything that would separate the two economies would seriously affect Israeli-Palestinian cooperation, including joint ventures, Palestinian subcontractors, and Palestinian exporters. Second, nowhere in the agreements between Israel and the European Union are the borders of the State of Israel defined. The definition of these borders is precisely what is at stake in the ongoing negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Any attempt by the European Union to impose its own conception of Israel's territoriality would be, at the very least, a blunder that would be detrimental to these negotiations and to our understanding of the role Europe should play in the region. I support the cautious approach the Commissioner has taken and continues to take on this issue, firstly because it is not a simple matter. It is complex; it is always difficult to determine the origin and provenance of goods. This is even more so in the Middle East, because there is a situation there in which there are numerous joint ventures between Israel and the Palestinians, in which in some cases the products are manufactured partly in the Palestinian area and partly in the State of Israel. But these developments are good; they bode well for the future, because if trade is conducted this way in the Middle East, it will form the foundation of the peace agreement. Therefore, since it is not an easy or simple matter, we must be prudent and proceed with caution. The second reason why the Commission should proceed in this way is that if the European Union wishes to play a role in the area ensuring peace, it must be considered fair and impartial, and it would be neither fair nor impartial to rush into a decision without letting the talks and the groups that are meeting determine the situation both regarding the conditions relating to the trade agreement for the area with the State of Israel and, as I say, regarding the goods and their provenance at the same time.

It is no longer sustainable that the community should have to pay for the damage caused by individuals, often through criminal activities. We must introduce liability for those who cause all sorts of damage to our environment, because then they will think twice before transporting crude oil in a tanker that is about to break up. More than five years ago, in 1994, when I became a member of the Legal Affairs Committee of this Parliament, I was assigned to draft the report on environmental liability. Since then I have been waiting for an initiative from the Commission that will give me material to work on. This scandal must be put to an end as soon as possible, and I hope that the debate on this dossier will not be adjourned for the umpteenth time in February! - (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, the storm that marked the turn of the century should ultimately make us reflect on certain issues. It has become clear that man, today as always, is incapable of escaping natural disasters. Natural disasters have always existed and will continue to exist in the future. It is natural that solidarity must be shown in this regard. There is no doubt that we need a pan-European civil protection service, and a budget line for natural disasters must be included in the European Union budget. But the most important thing is to recognise the principle that in the relationship between nature and man, it is always man who makes mistakes, perpetuating his mistakes sometimes for centuries. Nature never makes mistakes, because it cannot make mistakes. The damage, in the case in question, depends on population density, the shape of the infrastructure and obviously on the many monocultures, if we are talking about forests. It is clear that we must provide all the help possible, but in doing so we must bear in mind that electricity and telephone cables may be buried more often in the future. We must shorten the cycles and ensure reforestation with mixed forests, which are more stable than monocultures. The most important debate in this context is the one on climate. In Europe we are privileged because we have the Gulf Stream and because it still works. America and Southeast Asia are much worse off than us when it comes to storms. Fortunately, we have the Gulf Stream, but we too, like everyone else, are subject to the greenhouse effect, and this is partly caused by man, although it is difficult to prove climate change mathematically. We must pay more attention to the recommendations of the Kyoto Conference on the environment. We must reduce CO2 emissions, use renewable energy sources and, in this context, ask ourselves what the state of health of Europe's forests is. Mr President, I believe that what we must deplore first and foremost is the loss of human life. An irreparable loss. Secondly, we welcome the solidarity that has emerged between the French departments and citizens, as well as that shown by other countries towards France, the country most affected. Given the very limited time available to me, Mr President, I will simply highlight two aspects of our resolution. The first aspect seems to me to be implicitly acknowledged by the Commissioner, when he asks whether these are natural disasters or not.

Furthermore, in this regard, we should also consider whether it would not be better to use an early warning system, a sort of yellow card instead of immediately resorting to the red card, which will act as a fine and threaten the survival of the company. Mr President, speaking last gives me the privilege of being able to tell the Commissioner that the majority of this House supports your initiative and that you have shown total confidence, in my view fully justified, in the way in which you are steering the ship into port. On this boat, however, we also want to do our part as rowers: and if we also want to row, it is precisely because we are all in the same boat. I therefore believe it is absolutely necessary to establish an interinstitutional dialogue that will enable us to steer, refine and specify this very important reform. The various ideas heard here could be grouped into three broad categories. Firstly, the concern expressed by many, and in particular by the Chair of the Economic and Financial Committee, Mrs Randzio-Plath, to ensure that this new system of legal exception is fully compatible with the Treaty. I share this concern and believe that the issue should be addressed. Secondly, the issue of legal certainty for businesses. It is true, Commissioner, that the Commission is not a machine for producing legal certainty. We agree on that. But it is no less true - as reiterated by all the members of this House - that the European industrial fabric is a fabric of small and medium-sized businesses, and that the Commission often plays the role of auctoritas, of legitimation, of guarantor of the legitimacy of the internal market. And it is in this respect that I would like to express my opinion on a remark made by Mr Karas. There have only been nine decisions of denial. But here I have to draw on my experience as a lawyer: who knows how many times a lawyer, with two companies and a project, in the light of a preventive orientation expressed by the Commission, has ended up changing that project, so as to make it compatible with the competition rules! This aspect cannot be ignored. Thirdly, the problem of the uniform application of Community law. In this regard, there is nothing to add to the excellent speech by Mrs Thyssen. I consider biodiversity to be a positive fact, I also consider cultural diversity to be positive, but not diversity in the application of the law, and in particular of competition law, which is the hard core of the internal market. And here we need to refine things. Only in some countries, in Germany for example, is there a specific jurisdiction. Perhaps this is a path to explore, but certainly not the only one. What we certainly cannot afford, Commissioner - and I would like to conclude on this very point - is to leave room and provide arguments to those who are trying to present the European institutions as something intended for large bodies, for those who matter, for the rich and not for the citizen, not for small and medium-sized enterprises, which in the worst case scenario - but this will not happen, because measures will be taken to avoid it - would find themselves relegated to a justice system that issues conflicting judgments, with very long delays, without any possibility of control except what the French call the parcours du combatant, that is, taking on a procedure that lasts years until the judgment of the Court of Justice, which as we well know is currently overloaded with work.

In this context, the various references to regional cooperation with neighbouring countries take on significant political significance. The agreement is also particularly important because it can and must also serve as an example for the other countries in the Balkan area. However, this process must be supported by a real political will on the part of the European Union to move closer to these countries. We know that some of them are undergoing democratisation processes, others have yet to assert the democratic authority of the State, while others owe their balance to a military presence in the area. In any case, these countries are now aware that, once the difficulties have been overcome, they will be able to establish a concrete link with the European Union. Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I do not intend to join the unanimous chorus of colleagues. I think the report is a small masterpiece of hypocrisy. In paragraph 4, mention is made of the exemplary nature of the agreement. We know that, from Lithuania to Turkey, there are thirteen candidate countries and that there is only one black hole in Europe, the Balkans, and while these countries are denied the possibility of applying, we would like to make them believe that the agreement is miraculous. Paragraph 11 indicates that symbolic measures can replace the political agreement, the political prospect that being a candidate represents. The report is not only a masterpiece of hypocrisy, but also an aberration, because, ladies and gentlemen, even if negotiations start tomorrow, the agreement will be concluded in a year and will enter into force in three years. I defy you to doubt that, among the Balkan countries, applications for membership will not be submitted in due form within these three years by Croatia, Macedonia and Bosnia. A few days ago Racan announced Croatia's formal application for membership by the end of 2000. I am sure that we will have other applications for membership and that this beautiful work, this beautiful intellectual architecture will crumble, because it will be overtaken by events, as we have been overtaken in the last twenty years by everything that has happened in the former Yugoslavia. All this would not be serious if there were no problems that we know about in this region of Europe, if there were no problems that are being faced, but have not yet been solved by the new government of Macedonia, the problems of cohabitation between the Macedonian majority and the Albanian minority, with the issues connected to Kosovo, if there were no known economic problems, the problems of neighborhood with a particularly powerful mafia in Serbia, if there were no problem constituted by a veto that should be denounced for what it is, the veto of Greece that, after almost ten years, continues to prevent this country from calling itself by its name, and I hope that the interpreters did not use the term FYROM when I spoke of Macedonia. This is absolutely absurd. I think it is an insult, first and foremost, to our Greek colleagues, to the citizens of Greece. We urgently need to find a solution to this issue. Finally, by a very happy chance, I learned of a letter sent by Georgievski, President of Macedonia, to Commissioner Fischler, dated 8 March, in which, referring to Article O, which has become Article 49 of the Treaty, he asks that Macedonia be allowed to join the European Union.

Mrs. Aung San Sui Kyi cannot feel totally abandoned, including by Europe. My request is that this country once again have a privileged position on the agenda. Mr. President, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, the European Union's affirmation in the world cannot be determined solely by economic power. An essential feature of what distinguishes us is the systematic reference to human rights, both on our part and on the part of those with whom we interact. The European Parliament, which has managed to overcome the limitations resulting from selfishness and "national interests" sometimes expressed in the positions of Member States and even other European Union institutions, has played a fundamental role in promoting and defending human rights. Therefore, it can be said, for example, that the European Parliament has never allowed the situation in East Timor to be forgotten, which could have been the worst enemy of a just solution for its people, who always opposed the Indonesian occupation. That is why, even recently, we opposed arms sales to Indonesia, a position that, unfortunately, the Council ignored. But it is not enough to prevent or put an end to situations of outrageous aggression perpetrated by individuals or institutions against the weakest. It is essential that, once violations are committed, the perpetrators do not go unpunished, whoever they may be, wherever they may be, in Indonesia or Angola, Cuba, China or Burma, whether the perpetrator is a civilian or a military officer, a soldier, a general or a minister. Let justice be done in Indonesia. Let justice be done in East Timor. President Wahid needs our support to address the difficult situation at hand. This resolution, at the initiative of the EPP, rightly includes an express reference to East Timor. What happened there in that country, and which I witnessed in part, representing this Parliament, cannot go unpunished. Speaking about East Timor must also mean remembering the situation of tens of thousands of East Timorese refugees on Indonesian territory, in inhumane conditions, controlled by Indonesian soldiers and militias, used as bargaining chips. This is an intolerable situation that urgently needs to end. Mr. President, a few very brief comments on behalf of the Presidency of the Council. First, to recall that the Presidency's role is above all a task of coordination, of seeking common positions on the initiatives that the Fifteen must adopt in the Council, recalling that the experiences of previous sessions of the Commission on Human Rights have revealed—precisely thanks to this coordination work by the Presidencies—a great capacity for the European Union to assert itself as an entity with its own policy within the Commission, something that should be maintained. I would also like to say that the European Parliament's participation in the preparatory work is important for the coherent affirmation of the European Union's positions on the various situations, which is why the Presidency naturally welcomes all proposals, particularly all contributions arising from the texts of the resolutions submitted.

We therefore call on the Commission to take specific measures and to introduce the principle of equal opportunities in all programmes for tourism and business development. Mr President, Members of the Commission, I would like to begin with a few words of optimism, which were offered to us in the communication of the High Level Group in October 1998, when on the first page it was written: "By the end of the next decade in the Union there will be the possibility of creating between 2,200,000 and 3,300,000 new jobs in tourism activities", and it was added: "only by creating the right conditions". I believe that the Commission and this Parliament are called upon to answer two questions: what are the right conditions and what can be the role of the European Union in this regard? The Commission and Parliament can help us understand first of all what exactly we are talking about, because even the term "tourism", as was also pointed out in the Viceconte report, is still an ambiguous term, a sort of variable dependent on latitudes, climates, many occasions, many elements of interpretation; it can be synonymous with vacation or it can actually be a place of production, income, wealth and employment. The data is missing: we have no data on the economic impact, which still remains absolutely mysterious. We have criteria for collecting and interpreting statistics that are completely at odds with each other, despite what a directive from the Commission and Parliament in 1995 said. I believe that it is essential, in order to develop a strategy, to have a homogeneous and as rigorous as possible reading of these data, also to ensure that tourism is truly capable of producing employment. There is no automatic mechanism in this sense: often in the past there have been large accumulations of wealth thanks to the growth of the tourism industry, without this being matched by an increase in employment. There is no legal basis and we believe that this is the great limitation, today, of any intervention in the tourism sector. A legal basis translates into a capacity for coordination, planning and strategy, which are essential for tourism in the European Union to be competitive with other markets. A legal basis would avoid having to draw, as has happened in the past, on structural funds, a sort of pocket money, moreover made available in minimal amounts: let us remember that the Commission communication indicated a sum equal to 4,700,000,000 euros in the last five years, which corresponds to the cost of 400 kilometres of motorway. There is no possibility of giving the States a strong signal: recognition of the legal basis of tourism would allow the States to recognise the European Union's competence which at the moment is absolutely sporadic. We are in complete agreement with the Community measures indicated in the Commission communication: advantageous taxation, that is, tax measures capable of offering that productive fabric - which, let us remember, is made up of 95 per cent small and medium-sized enterprises, equivalent to 2 million small and medium-sized enterprises involved in the tourism sector in Europe - truly competitive conditions on this market; paying particular attention to professional qualifications in the European Union, and therefore investing in training; and finally, committing to transparency in the labour market.

In my view, such parameters—particularly those related to quality, resulting from investments in continuing training, vocational training, adaptation measures, and the retraining of older workers—are, given their sustained medium-term impact, much more important and binding than the mere formulation of always controversial annual quantitative targets for job creation or reduction. If, among other things, as the Portuguese Presidency's programme also emphasizes, the Commission could launch a new phase of social dialogue, focused on a coordinated strategy of socialization and knowledge dissemination—in short, on an employability strategy and the definition of its rules—this could constitute progress towards worker participation in the sound and consensual management of restructuring and reemployment processes. Thirdly, I do not consider the decline in the workforce due to an ageing population to be an inevitable fate for the European Union, not only because of the scope offered by increasing female employment and immigration, but because the widespread trend towards early retirement and premature withdrawal from the labor market must be decisively curbed by gearing the coordinated reform of social protection systems not toward significant cuts in future pensions, but toward actively exploiting longer life expectancy and extending working life. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, you, Mr Prodi, come across as very reform-minded and very ambitious. You and your ambition are most welcome. It will be necessary, given the enormous task that awaits you. But in order to implement all these reforms and also to advance the 2001 legislative program, one must be completely confident not only in one's own strengths as reformers, but also in the opinions of others. You say you will undoubtedly come to this House and ask for more resources for the Commission, but the Commission must be fully aware of how thin the financial cushion is on which we stand. We have 1.27% of the Community's GDP. Not a euro more, not a euro less. It will not be us who refuse these new resources; you will have to ask the Council. This financial perspective is finely tuned. In order to finance your stability plan in the Balkans, a substantial revision of Category 4 will have to be negotiated, and you will remember the enormous difficulties we encountered in adopting the 2000 budget. I would remind you that this group, the PPE-DE, does not like to finance new political initiatives by sacrificing existing ones. Political priorities must be defined by this Parliament and the Members of the European Parliament. Never think that the budgetary reform you are proposing will conceal the limitations of the Community's financial system. We would do well to make every effort, by mutual consent, to achieve budgetary austerity, but be fully aware that the inadequacy of resources, the lack of financial autonomy, and poor budgetary implementation remain urgent issues that need to be addressed. So we ask ourselves: Does the Commission have the political will to resolve them? Madam President, the Commission's communication is well-worded, but so vague that all sorts of interpretations are possible.

This is not the point, obviously, because such a quota would be unrealistic. The report does not mention the timeframe within which this quota would have to be achieved. To calm matters and reassure Members, I have tabled an amendment to the resolution by which we simply note that the Commission is committed to making significant efforts to increase women's participation in Community research programs, which is even commendable. Furthermore, it must be noted that the Commission has written to us verbatim that it considers it essential to achieve a minimum of 40% women's participation at all levels of the implementation and management of research programs. This is not a quota. It is a very legitimate declaration of intent on the part of the Commission, insofar as it concerns its own programs and not those of the Member States, which would do well to be inspired by this good example of the Commission and to continue to deploy the same efforts within the framework of their research programs. May this be conveyed to them! (FR) It is gratifying that the debate on Mrs. McNally's report, on the subject of increasing and facilitating women's participation in research and science, is the subject of a fairly broad consensus. In this matter, a better translation of the notion of equal opportunities into everyday reality is both highly desirable, and I can only welcome the implementation of a policy that will result in the satisfaction of women's legitimate aspirations: to benefit from equal access to scientific studies, to obtain positions of responsibility truly commensurate with their achievements and capabilities, as well as the rapid implementation of accompanying measures that will allow them to reconcile family and professional life. But this necessary realistic and pragmatic policy, which should focus on eliminating the specific obstacles identified as indisputable factors in this inequality, must, in our view, be based on the concept of complementarity, the only one that can justify a proactive policy in this area. Our reflection and future actions must focus on respect for these values, which are truly respectful of differences, and not on the postulate of gender equality, which is fraught with contradictions. Nothing justifies abandoning ourselves to the facile practice of quantitative policies based on quotas, contrary to the notion of citizenship with which the members of the UEN Group identify, and whose likely consequences would be the opposite of what Ms. McNally's report seems to seek: the participation of women in scientific and research work in proportion to their worth. If they have the opportunity to demonstrate their true merits, if they eliminate as much as possible the barriers related to the specific nature of their status, and not within the framework of a conflict in which they would give the impression of fighting against the privileges of men, women will demonstrate their interest in achieving the fulfillment of their professional careers and will succeed in modifying the imbalances that still disadvantage them.

My second question will be of a more technical nature, but it is important with a view to the most harmonious possible transfer to the European Union of the responsibilities of the Atlantic Alliance and the Western European Union. In this area, you mentioned the creation of three committees: a political and security committee launched today, and the Military Committee. You then mentioned your relations with third countries that are members of the Atlantic Alliance or associate members of the WEU, but are not members of the European Union. Within the framework of the functioning of the provisional institutions, whose creation has just been decided, could you tell us, Mr. High Representative, what status you intend to confer on the members of the Alliance and the states associated with the WEU—I repeat—that are not yet members of the European Union? Could they, for example, occupy observer positions within the various political and security committees or the Military Committee? These countries are concerned about the danger of being isolated, and I wish to express my understanding of their desire to participate with you in this endeavor. Mr. President, Mr. Secretary-General of the Council, as you will understand, we in this House have followed with great interest the information you have provided us with regarding the outcome of the informal meeting of Defense Ministers held in Sintra and its significance for the process of European integration in matters of security and defense. I am also grateful that you have shared with this Parliament the telephone conversation you had with Mr. Álvaro Gil-Robles. However, in the area of foreign policy, I have doubts about whether we are moving at the pace required by needs—as some of my colleagues have already said this afternoon—without, of course, ignoring the difficulties you are encountering. I will give you an example: During the recent tour of the President of the European Parliament to the Middle East, which you mentioned, the various parties to the conflict agreed on a demand for a more active European Union presence in the peace process underway in the region. Do you believe, Mr. Secretary General, that the representatives of the Community institutions and the governments of the Member States are acting with the coordination and balance required of those who, like us, aspire to mediate between two opposing parties? I believe this Parliament has some doubts about this; I don't know if you share them. In that regard, as you know, the European Parliament has been working on the initiative to form a common diplomatic corps for the Community, obviously without the aim of replacing the diplomatic services of the Member States, but rather to complement them and eventually contribute to their better coordination. I could ask you, Mr. High Representative, for an initial reaction to this initiative, without prejudice to what you can give us in greater detail in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Mr. Solana, it has been repeatedly said in this House that prevention is better than intervention. Certainly, it is better, but I don't see why Europe should not equip itself with the tools that allow it to intervene when prevention fails.

Furthermore, a huge warehouse has been built, the planning permission for which appears difficult to obtain, and the Drogheda Corporation is also planning other infrastructure. How can the Commission guarantee that this type of development, financed through structural funds, does not jeopardise the necessary nature conservation efforts in the area? Is the Commission prepared to suspend all funding pending a review of the regional development plans? (SV) The Commission is aware of the construction of this port, but it has had no knowledge of the construction of this warehouse, or of the other infrastructure mentioned by the Member. The construction of the port is being financed through structural funds, and its main consequence is the dredging of the mouth of the River Boyne and the temporary storage of masses of sediment collected on the Stegrennan mudflat. The area around the Boyne Estuary has been designated a Special Protection Area under the Wild Birds Directive. This means that any exploitation in or near the river estuary must comply with the protection rules laid down for this area by the EU Habitats Directive. Since 1998, the Commission has received a number of complaints alleging that the construction of the port would damage the Stegrennan mudflat, which is now part of the protected area, and that the applicable protection rules had not been complied with. After examining these complaints during 1998 and early 1999—a period during which the project received no Structural Fund support—the Commission was satisfied by the summer of 1999 that the protection rules had been taken into account in the construction of the port. A detailed study of the environmental consequences had been carried out. The most negative consequence of the project, namely the loss of the Stegrennan mudflat, is only temporary, as the contractor in charge of the work is required to rehabilitate the site. At the Commission's request, the Stegrennan mudflat was formally included in the Boyne Estuary Special Protection Area, of which it was not previously part. To compensate for the negative effects of this temporary disappearance of the mudflat on the bird populations concerned, it was also planned to improve other breeding sites for these species in the estuary area. However, since the summer of 1999, this latter measure has been the subject of litigation. The Irish authorities first reversed the originally planned improvement measure. Then, following a complaint filed by an environmental non-governmental organization in an Irish court, they reinstated it. However, the new provision contained minor amendments that led to a new complaint. Given that Ireland has committed to compensatory measures, and that a number of other problems have now been resolved, the Commission cannot propose today to freeze financial assistance from the Structural Funds. However, it is prepared to discuss with the Irish authorities the issue of compensatory measures for the improvement of certain natural habitats, particularly in light of the legal action still pending before an Irish court.

Since both legal aspects often overlap and violations of the Union budget are increasingly cross-border, including those committed by organized crime, jurisdiction among the Member States is unclear. Added to this are differences in individual national legal provisions and lengthy or even unfulfilled requests for mutual legal assistance. The Convention on the Protection of Financial Interests, signed by the European Council in 1995, and the two subsequent protocols have not changed this. To enter into force, it must be ratified by all 15 Member States. So far, after five years, only four have done so. This deadlock, which threatens to undermine the Union's credibility, has led Parliament to propose a European law enforcement agency. This is by no means intended to create a transnational criminal and judicial system. Rather, the aim is to equip the Union with specific instruments to protect its financial interests, while respecting subsidiarity. With today's report, we revive this idea and call on the Commission to submit legislative proposals to achieve this goal. The concerns expressed by the Committee on Legal Affairs, as well as those of the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, will be fully taken into account. We make two recommendations arising from the creation of OLAF and intended to ensure its operational and legal efficiency, transparency, and the protection of individual rights. To this end, we need – the first recommendation – a legal act that defines criminal offenses detrimental to the Union's financial interests and establishes guiding principles. In one amendment, I support the deadline for the Commission to submit its proposal by 30 September. The second recommendation concerns criminal proceedings. The Commission should propose – and here, again, I have amended this by 31 May 2000 – a legal act establishing an independent body, institutionally linked to the Commission, to coordinate and monitor the proper conduct of OLAF's investigative work. The existing Supervisory Committee can only monitor the independence of the Office's Director. The proposal for such a legal act should include an independent statute for this body and define its tasks, which should be limited to investigations and internal prosecutions by OLAF that harm the Union's financial interests, as well as its relations with national authorities. Any influence on the administration of justice in the Member States is excluded. The Court of Justice should be responsible for monitoring the legality of legal acts. We also call on the upcoming Intergovernmental Conference to open the debate on the creation of a European law enforcement agency to protect the Union's financial interests, if possible on the basis of the now widely recognized study, the so-called corpus juris, prepared by renowned academics, as well as the feasibility studies published subsequently. Further support for this project can be found in the second report of the so-called Five Wise Men. The Commission, Mr. Barnier and Mr. Vitorino, as well as some Member States are also open to the idea. I ask you, dear colleagues, for your positive vote on this report, which the Committee on Budgetary Control adopted by a large majority. We can once again send a signal that Parliament is actively preventing mismanagement, and especially fraud, and, where necessary, imposing penalties. Mr President, I am pleased to be able to speak in the debate on this report and to congratulate Mrs Theato.

Who would want such a thing? Is it not our responsibility to evaluate and choose ways to counteract this policy? Europe is a community of law. Among the principles we are called upon to defend are democracy, respect for human rights and the rule of law. It is imperative in a democracy not to judge election results, but to respect them. We must therefore respect the decisions that the Austrians, for reasons inherent to their policy, have deemed it appropriate to take. It is a question of respect for the principles of the rule of law that the Presidency of the Council does not express itself in the way it has done, i.e. in a way that is contrary to the Treaties. It is a question of political intelligence not to isolate the ÖVP, but to help it - as an undoubtedly democratic, rule-of-law and European-oriented party - to ensure that Austria, equally undoubtedly, remains a member of this European Community. For this reason, the ÖVP Members must have our support in this difficult situation, because isolation is definitely the wrong path! (Applause) Madam President, as we say in my part of the world, 'the Welsh always try three times'; as you will have realised in the course of this debate, I have three times expressed the desire to comment briefly on a debate that has undoubtedly proved to be of a very high standard and, at times, even moving. Firstly, on behalf of President Prodi and my colleagues in the Commission, I would like to thank you for the support and understanding that many Members have given to the position taken by the Commission in its statement yesterday. I obviously owe a response to those who have denounced - and I repeat the exact words used - the ambiguity, acquiescence and fragility of the Commission's opinion. I feel obliged to state before this Parliament that there is no ambiguity, no fragility or acquiescence in the opinion expressed by the Commission, nor in the action which the Commission itself has taken on this matter. In our statement yesterday morning we explicitly stated (as did the President this afternoon) that we share the concerns expressed by the fourteen Member States in their statement on Monday. Secondly, we specifically stated that we will work closely with all Member States to examine developments in Austria. Thirdly, we have made it very clear that we will defend, with courageous impartiality, the wording of Article 6 of the Treaty and the values which are expressed therein, as well as our firm intention - in the spirit of Article 7 of the Treaty - to ensure that these values, freedom, democracy and fundamental rights, are not undermined. There is no ambiguity, no fragility or acquiescence in all this. And when I say that the Commission has expressed this opinion, I am also referring to my dear colleague Franz Fischler, who is Austrian and who, in endorsing the statement made yesterday morning, has once again demonstrated his integrity, his independence and his loyalty to the oath he took as a member of the European Commission.

Shifting the tax burden from labor to the consumption of raw materials and natural resources, on the other hand, makes a lasting contribution. Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Giorgos Katiforis on the report he has presented to us—not here today, but in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Politically speaking, these are two completely different reports. In general terms, we could say that the first report is a left-wing report, addressing social aspects alongside economic problems. The report we now have before us, for which I believe my colleague has championed very well, is "hybrid." Starting from a structure with social aspects, the main conclusions are withdrawn. So what does Mr. Katiforis propose, and what can we conclude from the report? He has offered us an ambitious report in a hopeful Europe, in which quantified targets for the desired results should be set. And Europe has made progress with procedures based on quantified targets. Why, for example, was the proposal to increase the working population in Europe to 75% of the population withdrawn? A working population of 60% is very low compared to Japan or the United States, and with such a low employment rate, we cannot produce the same as those countries. We must therefore increase the employment rate through competitive jobs. Just as was the case at the Lisbon Summit, we must prepare the workforce here for new technologies through scientific training. Investment must also grow at a faster pace. Mr. von Wogau's idea that the workforce must be flexible is an argument all too familiar to us. I would counter him with the example of Portugal, where labor laws are inflexible and the unemployment rate is below 5%—and has been falling steadily in recent years—because investment is growing much faster than the Community average (no doubt with Community support). We therefore strive for a Europe with economic growth, but also with social considerations. Mr. President, Like many of my colleagues, I would like to thank Mr. Katiforis for an interesting report. Reading it and considering the picture of the EU economy it paints, I find it to be a rather worrying one. Investment is too low, unemployment is still far too high, and growth is insufficient. Therefore, it is perhaps not surprising that the euro is losing ground against other currencies, despite rumors of secret purchases by the European Central Bank. The rapporteur states that stability is not an end in itself. I can only agree. There is far too much talk about stability, convergence, and coordination, but far too little about the factors necessary for innovation and development. In my view, cooperation within the EMU is a heavy colossus that cannot really keep pace with the enormous flexibility of the economy. My conclusions, however, differ from those of the previous speaker. I believe that we must focus on the human factor, firstly through macroeconomic policies that create increased demand and new jobs and secondly - and perhaps first and foremost - through measures in working life such as training, the democratisation of companies and good social conditions.

I understand that it is not a contentious issue that the Council's statement on the upcoming session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights will not include the declaration on the 50th Anniversary of the Geneva Conventions, and that this statement, to make it in a noble and solemn manner, has been postponed to the March plenary session. I understand that there is agreement on this point. Madam President, this afternoon in this House, reference was made to a number of reports from this morning's BBC Today programme, which alleged that some of my colleagues are running companies they own that act as lobbyists or are in some way abusing their position as Members of this House. These allegations are very serious and are completely false, malicious, and politically biased. They were disseminated with full knowledge of their falsity. We are currently receiving legal advice. The Register of Interests of my colleagues is complete. If we discover that any Member of this Parliament or any of its employees has collaborated with the BBC in this farrago, we will expose them to the opprobrium of this House. That's exactly it. We fully agree. b) Sessions of 1 and 2 March 2000 in Brussels Sustainable urban development - Rural development - EQUAL Initiative. (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners and members of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, I have been tasked with preparing the European Parliament's report on the Interreg III Community initiative programme. When the matter came before committee, we studied more than 100 amendments, and as of today, 17 more amendments have been tabled, some of them previously tabled in committee. Before entering into the debate on the content of the resolution I am proposing, I would like to inform you about the elements I have taken into account in guiding my work as rapporteur. First of all, I would like to remind you of the role of the Interreg III Community initiative, based on the principles of transnationality and innovation. This program represents a European-wide development engine. Interreg is one of the four Community initiatives planned for the period 2000-2006 and will have the largest financial allocation, €4.872 billion compared to the current €3.604 billion. The Interreg initiative, created in 1990, is based on the desire to prepare European regions for the creation of a borderless Europe, within the framework of the achievement of the large single market. When the Structural Funds were reformed in 1994 and 1996, the Interreg CIP integrated new aspects that contributed to the development of trans-European energy transmission and distribution networks. These programs have fostered cross-border, transnational, and interregional cooperation within the European Union, favoring the balanced development of the Community area. This is the objective of the Interreg III programme, whose guidelines are being submitted to us today by the European Commission, in accordance with the provisions of European Community Regulation No. 1260 of 1999 concerning general provisions for the Structural Funds. It is based on three aspects: Chapter A, which organizes cross-border cooperation between territorial authorities in border regions, both within and outside the European Union, based on common development strategies whose implementation is the responsibility of the Member States and local and regional authorities; Chapter B provides for transnational cooperation between national, regional, and local authorities in several Member States or candidate countries seeking accession to the European Union, within the areas of spatial planning, transport networks, and the environment.

Thirdly, the EU and the ACP countries have agreed on a new specific procedure to be launched in serious corruption cases. This is a real innovation, both in the EU/ACP context and in international relations in general. This procedure will be applied not only in corruption cases involving EDF resources, but also more broadly, in any country where the Community is financially involved and where corruption is an obstacle to development. It is therefore not limited to EC activities. This is a very important aspect, given the eligibility of public finances to benefit from the funds. By including this provision in the Partnership Agreement, the European Union and the ACP States are jointly sending a clear and concrete signal, which will undoubtedly be appreciated by European taxpayers and hopefully also by European investors. Another new element in the EU-ACP agreement is migration. We have reached a balanced agreement on cooperation in this area. The new dimension of the Partnership Agreement reflects the orientations adopted by the EU in accordance with the Treaty of Amsterdam and the conclusions of the European Council in Tampere, Finland, in October 1999. The European Union is committed to defining and implementing an immigration and asylum policy based on the principle of cooperation with the countries and regions of origin. The Agreement concluded with the ACP countries opens the way to new initiatives, in particular on the rights of third-country nationals within the Union, and to new measures to facilitate their integration. We have also decided to take measures on illegal immigration. The EU and the ACP States will launch a process to define, in a framework to be negotiated with each ACP country, the ways and means of repatriating immigrants illegally present in the territories of each party. The provisions also cover persons from third countries and stateless persons. These innovative orientations offer valuable opportunities for improving the governance of public affairs. The Agreement also provides a good regulatory framework to support the mutually reinforcing effects of trade cooperation and development aid. We have decided to launch a process to define new trade agreements that pursue the objective of liberalising trade between the Parties and to adopt provisions on trade-related issues. We have found a solution to the difficulties raised by the ACP States regarding the timetable for trade negotiations. Negotiations will start no later than 2002. This two-year preparatory period will be devoted to strengthening the process of regional integration and the capacity of the ACP countries to conduct trade negotiations. A period of six years is foreseen for the conduct of these negotiations. We will take into account the economic and social constraints of the ACP countries in two ways: first, by promoting social and human development policies that accompany economic and trade reforms and, second, by helping the ACP States to play an active role in the international economic and trading system through institutional capacity-building and cooperation in multilateral fora. This approach will lead us to a regime that is fully WTO compatible. Economic operators will tend to establish closer relations with ACP partners. Domestic and foreign investments will increase and there will be a greater transfer of know-how and technology, which will boost the competitiveness of ACP countries and facilitate their gradual integration into the world economy.

In my view, the Commission would demonstrate balanced human resources management if it allayed some of these concerns, so that the liberalization of a sensitive sector such as postal services could be carried out under the calmest possible social conditions. Mr. President, it seems that postal services and post offices are a very hot topic in Parliament at the moment, and rightly so, given their importance. Just last week, in the UK Parliament at Westminster, the newly elected Member of Parliament from our European Free Alliance partners, Plaid Cymru, the Welsh party, made his maiden speech on this topic. A debate was also held recently in the Scottish Parliament, in which special reference was made to the role that post offices play, particularly in rural areas, in providing services and maintaining rural communities. Liberalization is not the only potential threat to postal services. Post offices in Scotland, as we have heard, are concerned with much more than merely dispatching the mail. Governments and some local authorities have traditionally used them as agencies for the payment of pensions and other benefits, as well as centers for the collection of housing rents, the collection of local taxes, and so on. But as the modernization of public financial systems increasingly leads to direct electronic monetary transactions to and from bank accounts, the viability of rural post offices is threatened. If a rural post office, usually linked to the only local shop, closes, it can pose a serious threat to the continuity of the community and to social inclusion. Rather than allowing post offices to be undermined by liberalization or the modernization of systems, governments, including the Commission, should be promoting and supporting the extensive network of post offices and viewing them as an asset that can be leveraged to provide public information and services from a location accessible to residents. Mr. President, the postal service has the task of ensuring that everywhere, in the city as well as in the most remote rural areas, the mail is delivered every day at the same rate for everyone. One hundred and fifty years ago, postal services were a public matter and, therefore, like public transport and energy supplies, constituted a fundamental task of public administrations. These highly useful and esteemed tasks gave citizens a reason to go and vote. Today, they show much less interest in an administration that no longer handles these tasks. I heard a Christian Democrat politician in a village in the Netherlands say: "The mail belongs to everyone, and if you take it away from us, you are robbing us." Meanwhile, the existing postal services gradually lost democratic control, and competition increasingly gave way. Newcomers are only interested in those aspects of the work where they can make the most profit with the lowest costs and at the lowest price. The only way they can remain the cheapest for any length of time is by compromising quality for customers and staff. These companies have always existed, but they were once banned, and now they are praised as a sign of progress.

However, I do have a slight concern, listening to the Commissioner, regarding the commitments made by the services in the Committee on Budgets. It had been clearly agreed - I am not saying that this is a good or a bad thing, but it was a contract - it had been clearly agreed between the Commission services and the Committee on Budgets that there was agreement on Amendments 4 and 7, that is to say, that there was an agreement on the idea of linking the mobilisation, the implementation, of the second tranche of macro-financial aid to the prior respect of the commitments made by the donors. However, I understood, listening to Mr Solbes, that this commitment had to be made in dotted lines. Commissioner, an agreement is an agreement. Yes or no, do you confirm the agreement reached by your services in the Committee on Budgets, or do you relax this conditionality, which would be a breach of commitment to us? No, Mr Bourlanges, I believe it is a fundamental problem. The problem is: how to implement the compromise we have accepted. What I proposed to you, and what I am still saying to you, is that the Commission will make a statement, in the Council decision, along the following lines: The exact amount and precise timetable for the second tranche will be decided in due course, taking due account of the evolution of Kosovo's external financing needs and the contributions of other bilateral donors. In this sense, we believe that we are fully respecting what we have agreed. I simply ask the Commission, before implementing the second tranche, to come and inform the Committee on Budgets. I fully agree, and we will do so. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11 a.m. Altener The next item is the report (A5-0011/2000) by Mr Langen on the joint text, approved by the Conciliation Committee, for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council adopting a multiannual programme for the promotion of renewable energy sources in the Community - Altener (C5-0333/1999 - 1997/0370(COD)). Mr President, I thank Mr Langen - although he is not present here - for the work he has done to get the programme adopted by both Parliament and the Council. The project has been long and difficult. We must continue to promote, in particular, studies analysing the use of renewable energy sources. Although the new directive has many advantages, it also has its drawbacks. One example is the use of peat. Peat should not be classified in the same category as fossil fuels. While peat cannot be directly classified as a renewable, non-fossil energy source, it must be defined as a separate category, particularly with regard to environmental taxation. It is not fair to apply the same criteria to peat as to coal, for example. Promoting renewable energy sources is a partial solution to eliminating the Union's dependence on imported energy.

Several questions remain unanswered, however. For example, the program does not seem to give any priority to the fight against AIDS. The situation in Africa has now become so serious that AIDS kills more people than armed conflicts. I hope the Minister will devote some of his time to this problem. Medicines exist in the United States, but the United States markets them at a price that is too high for the African population. I would like to ask the Minister what exactly he is doing about the situation developing in Ethiopia, where drought has set in, causing crop failure, and where, in six months, the scenario we experienced a few years ago will inevitably repeat itself, with famine and people dying by the thousands. Meanwhile, Eritrea and Ethiopia are at war, and the European arms industry does not hesitate to send rifles, after which we will send bread. Mr. Deputy, you will understand that I do not agree with your reading of my colleague's speech at the meeting of the Committee on Development; there is no contradiction between these positions, quite the contrary. Unless we are megalomaniacal, we could not, in our Presidency programme, engage in a sort of exhaustive inventory of all possible and imaginable situations concerning all the major issues raised, particularly in the context of external relations. You will understand that nothing would have been easier. All we had to do was take a glossary on development and list all the points one after the other. We are responsible enough to see that we must only take the points that we can manage within the framework of our Presidency and what is – we must always be aware of this – the capacity of governments within the Council. We must see what the limits are to management, particularly of national indicative programmes. The Member mentioned the issue of Ethiopia, which falls within the framework of the National Indicative Programmes, but as you know, there are various Community actions to combat AIDS. You are right on this point, Mr. Deputy, the United States will probably not do any better. Furthermore, in terms of development aid policy, I think that Europe has no reason to be concerned simply because our behavior in this area has nothing to envy that of the United States. The Member's question arises from the issue of the arms problem; it is a question of a broader political nature, which does not seem to me to fall within the scope of this question, but which the Council will obviously consider in the future if it wishes and if it decides to place it in a specific context. Is the Council aware of the social problems caused by the export of food products by the European Union to developing countries below the production price?

On the one hand, if we establish quotas for women, why not also create quotas based on age or ethnicity, quotas for Catholics, workers, people with glasses. The establishment of social quotas in favor of the most modest categories would be no stranger than the establishment of quotas for women. With such a philosophy, it would then no longer be necessary to organize elections or administrative competitions. It would be enough to determine the composition of ministries and assemblies based on statistical calculations. The policy of quotas can only increase voters' disaffection with politics by giving them, once again, the impression that everything happens without their knowledge. On the other hand, such a policy highlights a profound contempt for women. They must not have access to political or administrative functions based on automatic mechanisms linked to certain quotas, but rather based on the recognition of their merits and skills. Would you, ladies and gentlemen, be so devoid of pride as to be ready to accept a ministerial or elective office based on the purely mathematical calculations of a quota system? Women are worth much more than a quota. Only by basing ourselves on the principle of meritocracy will we improve the quantitative and qualitative presence of women in the decision-making process. Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, I applaud your words even if some of the male colleagues still present in the Chamber may have something to say about them. I know that there are also women who do not want to hear about quotas or positive actions because they believe that such positive discrimination will humiliate and stigmatize them forever in their careers. However, the statistics prove it: positive actions, or quotas - if they are not applied blindly and without discernment - have increased the number of women in the decision-making process. This is why it is fair to point out that the use of quotas, on a transitional basis, helps to balance the participation of men and women, particularly in political life. I would like to take this opportunity to remind the Commissioner of some of the European Parliament's requests and initiatives that her predecessor has not yet followed up on and that are closer to our hearts than quotas. First of all, our report, adopted last year on International Women's Day in Strasbourg, which calls on the Commission to submit to the European Parliament a new proposal to amend the 1976 directive on the implementation of the principle of equal treatment of men and women. Following the Treaty of Amsterdam, there was no longer any need to maintain positive action at the level of a tolerated derogation from the principle of equal treatment that recognises only an individual right and not a right that belongs to society which wants to achieve such equality in a democratic manner. As things stand today, it should be undeniable that the right to equality of women and men is a fundamental right of a democratic society which requires that equal treatment and equal opportunities be achieved through a set of active measures, including positive actions.

What was Mr. Giorgos Katiforis proposing to us that was omitted from the report? He proposed an ambitious report, in an optimistic Europe, that sought to establish numerical targets for the desired results. And Europe has made progress with numerical targets. Why, for example, was the proposal that Europe's labor force should grow toward 75% of the population omitted, when we currently have levels of around 60%? A labor force of 60% is very low compared to that of Japan or the United States, and we cannot produce the same as those countries with such a low employment rate. Therefore, we need to increase the employment rate with competitive jobs. As advocated for the Lisbon Summit, we must prepare a scientifically trained workforce for new technologies. And we need investment to increase at faster rates. This idea, defended by Mr. von Wogau, according to which what is needed is workforce flexibility, is an argument we are very familiar with. I would like to contrast the Portuguese example, where labor laws are not flexible and where the unemployment rate is less than 5%—and has been steadily declining in recent years—because investment is increasing (with Community support, obviously) at rates much higher than the Community average. Therefore, what we want is a Europe with economic growth, but with social concerns. Mr. President, I would like, like others, to thank Mr. Katiforis for this interesting report. Reading it, one gets a picture of the EU economy that, in my opinion, is quite alarming. Investment levels are too low, unemployment remains too high, and growth is insufficient. Therefore, it is perhaps not too surprising that the euro continues to lose ground against other currencies, despite rumors that the European Central Bank is secretly buying euros to stem its fall. The rapporteur confirms that stability in itself is not an objective, a view I share. There is too much talk of stability, convergence, and coordination, but too little about the factors that foster innovation and development. For me, the EMU collaboration is like an enormous colossus, unable to keep up with the rapid movements of the economy. My conclusions are completely different from those of the previous speaker. I believe we must invest in human resources, on the one hand, through a macro-policy that creates demand and new jobs, and on the other, through measures such as training, business democratization, and good social conditions. I see that, in these areas, the EMU project has its greatest weaknesses. We cannot build European economies from above, as if we were a new Baron von Münchhausen. On the contrary, we must mobilize workers and the people in the member countries.

In Tampere, the idea of also distributing operational powers was considered. We continue to call for a revision of the agreement to provide for better parliamentary and judicial oversight. The agreement should also be viewed critically with regard to EURODAC. Parliament modified the text of the treaty. It must be ensured that the Council conforms to Parliament's approach. Unfortunately, no initiatives have yet been launched on the other issues. We are currently still waiting for them. Europe, as an area of freedom, security, and justice, is still an area without clear regulations in important areas. However, we owe this to the citizens of Europe. After hearing the words of the Ministers of the Interior and Justice, I am optimistic. I expect that we will succeed in doing so in the next six months. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that Mrs Terrón i Cusí's oral question hit the nail on the head. Six months after the inauguration of the newly elected Parliament, we must be in a position to send a firm political message to the citizens of Europe. I believe that the Portuguese Presidency can make a positive contribution to this. We are all now aware of the immense expectations our fellow citizens have regarding freedom, security and justice, particularly social justice. However, the citizens' disinterest, their distance, and sometimes even their aversion to politics, compel us to take concrete measures in the face of their difficulties. This is the essential prerequisite for reconciling citizens with politics. For Europe to become a symbol of peace and fraternity, we need a courageous and generous policy to help the weakest. A real plan to combat unemployment must be implemented, because this scourge is a breeding ground for racism, xenophobia, nationalism, and far-right racist movements. Among the most vulnerable—and it is important that I address this point—are immigrants and refugees.
