Thus, the almost universal detention and criminalization of asylum seekers can no longer be tolerated. Every asylum seeker must have the right to a fair hearing and to a suspensive appeal. Last week, quite by chance, I witnessed a scene of almost unsurpassable violence at Roissy Airport, in which two young women, who had apparently entered the country clandestinely, were deported to Conakry. They were treated like serious criminals. They were naked, dragged across the floor by their hair, and guarded by a horde of CRS riot police. The Portuguese presidency must put an end to such barbaric practices. On the contrary, our task is to accompany, assist, and offer security to those fleeing dictatorship. The Commission proposed the creation of a European fund for refugees. Parliament warmly welcomed this proposal. Instead of endlessly debating the amount of money allocated to this fund, I believe you should decide to create it. The Presidency and the Council can give concrete form to the points that were inexplicably rejected at Tampere, even though Tampere provides an important foundation. Likewise, we cannot simply state that xenophobia is on the rise in Europe and discrimination is becoming more and more commonplace without taking comprehensive measures to counteract it.

The final demand concerns the future powers of the European Parliament in the areas under discussion here: competition policy and state aid, with a view to the Intergovernmental Conference. As you know, Commissioner, our report puts forward the idea that the codecision procedure should apply to the adoption of fundamental legal texts on state aid. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my part in today's debate concerns the Steel Aid Code. This covers public aid in Europe that was awarded under this code and that the Commission has examined. There were a total of 27 cases in 1998. The Commission submitted a separate report on these cases. The ECSC Treaty will soon expire. Therefore, the question that must concern us today is, in particular, how steel aid will be handled in the future. The European Parliament welcomes the decisions of the European Commission set out in the report, including the decision to reclaim funds in one specific case, thereby applying Article 88 of the ECSC Treaty. The competitiveness of the European steel industry is also the subject of the Commission's most recent communication, which we have not yet debated in Parliament. As in other sectors, the iron and steel industry is subject to the general prohibition of state aid under Article 87(1) of the EC Treaty. According to this article, state aid is generally incompatible with the common market. Exceptions are permitted only in precisely defined cases. Article 88 obliges the Commission to monitor state aid. In 1998, the largest case was the injection of equity capital to PREUSSAG in Germany amounting to EUR 540 million. Furthermore, Member States must notify the Commission of their planned aid in advance. The applicable rules for the steel industry were established on December 18, 1996. According to this, aid to the steel industry may only be granted in certain, precisely defined cases. These include research and development aid, environmental protection aid, social aid to encourage the closure of steelworks, and aid for the permanent closure of uncompetitive companies. In addition, there is a special arrangement of up to €50 million for the Member State of Greece. However, there have evidently been problems with the practical implementation of the Steel Aid Code in recent years that were not fully discussed in the report. From Parliament's point of view, it is important that discussions begin today about a follow-up arrangement following the expiry of this Steel Aid Code. A weakening of the existing basic principles of the Steel Code must not be decided upon. No one wants an unrestrained subsidy race in Europe. This would significantly impair the internal market, even after the consolidation of the steel industry in recent years. Therefore, Parliament considers it necessary for the Steel Subsidy Code to be amended in light of the unequal treatment alleged by the industry, and for the Commission to submit a successor regulation to the Council. It is well known that the Council has so far refused to adopt such a successor regulation. This is partly due to the belief that once the Steel Aid Code expires, one can once again do what one pleases without the burdensome control of the European Commission. We therefore demand that, after the expiration of the Treaty, steel aid must be regulated by a Council Regulation pursuant to Article 94, because this is the only way to ensure the necessary legal binding force and clarity.

As Members of Parliament, we must particularly emphasize that the process initiated to strengthen fundamental rights is more important than ever, because the respect and inviolability of human values and the rights of minorities, including the rights of all people living in the territory of the European Union, are an essential component of the principle of the rule of law in the European Union. Therefore, the Charter of Fundamental Rights must also be legally binding. It must not remain a mere declaration. Equally important is the support of democratic forces in Austria; none of us wants to exclude Austria. We know that most Austrians respect these values. They have also demonstrated; not all of these demonstrations have taken place outside Austria. Certainly, there are also many protest voters who have long wanted a change in Austrian politics. In my opinion, Parliament must support these democratic forces. I also appeal to the Austrian President to explore all possibilities so that a government made up of democratic forces can be formed. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would simply like to emphasize the importance of a stance such as that just evoked by the chairman of our group, Francis Wurtz. I welcome the statements by the Council Presidency and the 14 Member States, which reject official bilateral contacts with the Austrian government if Jörg Haider's party participates in the government. Our insistence on this is all the more significant given that, as is well known, we fundamentally disagree with the policies of the European Union—its economic and social policies, its democratic deficit, or the involvement of its Member States in the dramatic Balkan war. This disagreement lends even more weight to our recognition today: it is exceptional in that the danger of the rebirth of a perverse neo-fascist component in Europe is exceptional. This danger does not concern Austria, but Europe. We are speaking of ourselves, not of Austria. We are aware of the social causes that, together with unemployment and insecurity, contribute to fueling tendencies in this direction; We are aware of the cultural secondary causes, such as ethnic hatred and racism, but we cannot avoid pointing out that the inability and unwillingness of those right-wing extremist forces to reckon with fascism could create an explosive mixture in Europe. This concerns the Alpine region, all our countries: conditions are being created that could once again pose a threat to democracy and European civilization. With its statement, the Council Presidency has made it clear that it is aware of this dramatic situation for civilization. Europe is proving that it has not forgotten Auschwitz; Europe is encountering a soul. Now, however, it must be consistent and act accordingly, and first of all, the Commission must be consistent. Instead, in this case, it has adopted an unclear and indecisive stance, which makes the significance of the Council Presidency's statement even more obvious. In this sense, the Commission's actions must be corrected. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as regards the fundamental democratic principle of respect for human rights and for the freedom and sovereignty of peoples, which is opposed to any form of fascism, Nazism or communism, new or old - and all my previous speakers have spoken about the sovereignty of the Austrian people - we note that this sovereignty is being denied today, precisely by our Parliament.

Nothing to prevent the spread of unemployment, nothing to protect workers, nothing to prevent large companies from plunging part of the population into poverty simply to enrich their shareholders! If this report has any merit, it is that it has made it clear that the working majority of society has nothing to hope for from the European institutions in terms of maintaining, let alone improving, their living conditions. (FR) By voting against this report, we speak for all those in Seattle and throughout Europe who have expressed their rejection of a world reduced to a pure market logic. We vote against this report in the name of the development of public services, and above all in memory of the victims of the Paddington train crash, whose deaths were not an inevitable fate but the result of the absurd desire to give priority to competition where regulation is needed. This report is essentially a primitive piece of work, inspired by nothing other than the law of the jungle, because competition cannot solve any of the problems facing humanity at the beginning of the new century. Whether it be the balance of the biosphere, the promotion of culture, or cooperation with the developing world, unbridled competition is a factor of regression and insecurity. Do you perhaps think that Europe's 18 million unemployed are victims of an overly timid application of this competition policy? We are convinced of the opposite, and we do not believe that state aid is fundamentally too high. According to what iron rule, according to what criteria of effectiveness, should it be set? Finally, after Seattle, do you consider it serious to advocate a greater role for the WTO? Such stubbornness suits only the legal advisers of multinational corporations. Jonckheer report (A5-0087/1999). (FR) I welcome the quality of the Seventh Report on State Aid in the EU, the fact that it is now published annually, and the fact that the Directorate-General for Competition is providing general information intended for the public on its website. I am pleased with the rapporteur's approach to State aid. There is too often a tendency to condemn State aid as a measure that distorts competition. An effective competition policy is certainly a prerequisite for the proper functioning of the internal market and of Economic and Monetary Union. However, as the rapporteur points out, such aid is often essential, not only as a contribution to the survival of one undertaking or another, but also to sustainable development (Article 6 of the EC Treaty), to services of general interest (Article 16), and to economic and social cohesion (Article 158). But it must, of course, be monitored, and this is the task of the European Commission. The annual aid granted by EU Member States to the eligible sectors totaled €95 billion between 1995 and 1997, of which 40% went to the manufacturing sector. This aid decreased significantly compared to the previous period, 1993 and 1995 (a decrease of 13% of the total amount and between 3.8% and 2.6% of the aid volume for the manufacturing sector). The decrease in aid is mainly due to the reduction in aid to the new German Länder.

It must also be clarified what to do if state aid is declared unlawful. How can we ensure that unlawful state aid is repaid? Currently, there are no common rules in this area, and we urge the Commission to ensure the harmonization of repayment rules. This is the right way to create a level playing field. We are also proposing, as several colleagues have already mentioned, a register and a "scoreboard" showing countries' levels of state aid. We have taken up your suggestion here, Mr. Monti, regarding the Internal Market Scoreboard. This has inspired us to propose the same for state aid. I very much hope, Commissioner Monti, that you will support this proposal, and I look forward to your comments and your opinion. Finally, I welcome the Commission's 28th Competition Report, which, like previous reports, is well done. However, as I have said, our primary objective must be transparency and openness. We must continually develop the transparency and openness of state aid and focus our efforts on these areas. This is important, not least in view of the upcoming enlargement. I would like to thank Mr. Jonckheer, who addresses the associated problems very thoroughly in his report. He examines how we can ensure that these countries meet our requirements, but also how a level playing field can be created. Of course, Liberals and Greens have different views on how the world should be, but we largely agree on the objectives and will try to find a sensible solution to our problems. Mr. President, Commissioner, we simply have two questions to answer. Is state aid to companies or agreements between companies legitimate in a market economy, and who should monitor these exceptions to the absolute rules of the market economy? On the first point, we state quite clearly that if the requirements of sustainable development, which the European Union is pursuing, are to be taken into account, companies must be granted state aid, whether in the form of tax exemptions, differentiated taxation, or simply direct aid. It is equally legitimate for there to be agreements between companies or voluntary restraint agreements that make it possible to reduce the negative effects of competition on social or environmental requirements. We therefore state clearly and unequivocally that, yes, it is legitimate for aid to exist and that agreements can be made, but we also say that each of these agreements must be explicitly justified. The von Wogau report proposes transferring control of the legitimacy of such measures to national competence. While we see a certain risk in this, we will nevertheless vote for it because we recognize that the Commission cannot do everything. We demand that this be done with the utmost transparency and that the Commission be granted greater investigative powers to retrospectively review the legitimacy of these exemptions. Mr. President, once again we are debating the European Union's competition policy. But under what conditions is this debate actually taking place, and what conclusions should we draw?

The situation in the refugee camps in Ingushetia is dire and worsening; in most cases, there are no hot meals available all day. The Russian authorities no longer provide them, so it's the non-governmental organizations that are taking care of it. In Grozny, there are currently around 20,000 people in a truly desperate situation; they have to walk for miles to find food. But there is something that could be described as a positive development, which I would also like to share with you. The Representative of the Council of Europe informed me that, during a meeting with the President and the Foreign Minister yesterday evening, the Russian authorities accepted the inclusion of Council of Europe staff in the humanitarian mission currently under the leadership of the Russian authorities in Grozny, and that they are in negotiations with the Presidency-in-Office of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) so that, if necessary, staff from that organization could also be included. This is the only positive news I can convey to you at the moment; I hope that in the next few hours we will receive further information from the representative, Mr Gil-Robles, and above all, better news regarding the authorities of the Russian Federation. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I will conclude by simply repeating what I said at the beginning. It is a great satisfaction to be able to take part in the work of this Parliament, to collaborate with you in the work which is being carried out jointly by all the Member States and together with the Commission, and whose clear aim is to enable our European Union to participate with the greatest possible weight in peacekeeping operations at international level. Europe's purpose is not to wage war anywhere, but to work together to ensure peace and stability throughout the world. I would like to thank Mr Solana very warmly and give the floor to Mr Poettering on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party/European Democrats. Thank you, Mr Poettering. It goes without saying that a contribution from Commissioner Patten in this debate would be extremely appropriate. And we have agreed that I will give him the floor as soon as he wishes. Would you like to speak now, Commissioner, or a little later? (The Commissioner indicates that he would like to speak later.) Very well, thank you. Madam President, Commissioner Patten, Mr Javier Solana! We are not a local person, but the opposite. We welcome the rapid progress achieved following the Helsinki Summit. It is well known what an important role you played in this. I am also pleased that you mentioned Mozambique in this context and the substantial humanitarian aid that can be provided with these resources. Of course, we cannot talk about foreign policy without mentioning Chechnya. My friend Jacques Poos will speak on this later on behalf of our group. I would like to concentrate on Kosovo at this point. The situation in Kosovo shows only too clearly that military means cannot bring about a long-term solution to the crisis there. KFOR forces have provided and continue to provide important and invaluable services there, but armored vehicles and anti-personnel defenses cannot, in the long run, solve political problems and ethnic conflicts.

The Council consults us and Parliament gives its opinion. We want an Intergovernmental Conference, but not this one. Is an IGC necessary? Of course, but not of this type. We need to go much further in the agenda, we need to be much more daring in the issues that the Intergovernmental Conference will address, we need greater transparency and greater democracy. Greater democracy means ensuring greater participation by Parliament, allowing the Commission to exercise even more - yes - its capacity for initiative. It is also a question of setting clear objectives. The functionalist method has run its course, for better or for worse. We have come this far with the functionalist method. We have undoubtedly achieved results, but now we need to make a qualitative leap; in politics, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, this means persuading the other Community partners that the worst thing now would be short-sightedness. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at this point, having come to the end of the debate to which I have listened with great attention and interest, I would like to make a few reflections to complement the orientations and speeches that I have had the honour of giving before you in recent weeks, alongside President Prodi. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, your two rapporteurs, Mr Dimitrakopoulos and Mr Leinen, in their report, the fruit of extremely precise and serious work, have proposed that Parliament adopt a formal opinion, pursuant to Article 48 of the Treaty, so that, thanks to the adoption of that opinion, the Intergovernmental Conference can actually start on 14 February, as proposed by the Portuguese Presidency. For our part, having, pursuant to the same Article 48 of the Treaty, drawn up the opinion requested from the Commission, we are satisfied that this Conference can be started, among other things earlier than we had initially imagined. We know, and I am also aware of this, that the coming weeks will all be extremely useful. I would simply like to make a few observations based on the reading of the draft opinion and the interventions of the speakers from the various groups. First of all, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission understands the concerns expressed by many of you about the breadth of the agenda of the Conference. I understand this concern and the fear that the agenda is too full. However, I believe that we can work, as I already said in the aftermath of Helsinki before the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the basis of the Helsinki mandate. It is with this in mind and within the framework of this mandate, using all its phrases and all its interlinearities, that the Commission has worked on drawing up its opinion. We have not limited ourselves to what are improperly called the three left-overs. Like Mr Corbett, I too do not like the term 'left-over', which gives the impression that these are three minor or unimportant issues. Instead, these are three extremely serious, important and difficult issues, so demanding that in Amsterdam the collective political courage to deal with them in depth was lacking. For our part - I am responding to the Honourable Member Seguro, who just expressed his concern about this issue - we have not been satisfied with addressing these three aspects, even though we consider them to be priorities and worthy of being addressed now.

This is in line with the fundamental principle of non-discrimination enshrined in the founding Treaties of our Union. Marinho report (A5-0003/2000): . (SV) The main task of the upcoming Intergovernmental Conference is to reform the EU in the face of the accession of new Member States. It is therefore obvious that we support the European Parliament's formal approval of the holding of this Conference. However, we believe that the Intergovernmental Conference should limit itself to matters necessary for the implementation of enlargement. We held the same view in November 1999, and for this reason, we wish to refer to our explanation of vote of 18 November 1999. . (FR) In the opinion it has just adopted on the forthcoming Intergovernmental Conference, the European Parliament calls for "launching a constitutional process." This desire to place all nations under a legally superior text is also expressed in the first meetings of the body charged with drafting a so-called Charter of Fundamental Rights, which is in reality a disguised constitution. It is even expressed in the incredible drift of the European Parliament, which today, through a resolution, seeks to erase the results of the free elections held in Austria. The same desire to reduce nations to the level of mere subordinate administrative regions is transparent in every page of the report prepared by the commission for the Intergovernmental Conference. The main idea is to generalize qualified majority voting, while modifying the content of this qualified majority to transform it into a simple double majority of the States and the people, in order to increase the Commission's room for maneuver and reduce that of minority states. The French will undoubtedly be very interested to know, in passing, that the Commission is requesting the amendment of Article 67 of the Amsterdam Treaty to introduce majority voting and codecision with the European Parliament. Let us recall that this article, which deals with the transfer of immigration policy within the EU, stipulated that for five years, decisions would have to be taken unanimously by the Council, which would then assess the possible opportunity to modify the system. In France, in the National Assembly and the Senate, at the time of ratification, many parliamentarians were reassured that the Council would in any case have the freedom to choose and could maintain unanimity. However, today, the very Minister of European Affairs who prepared the Amsterdam Treaty and who, years later, has become a European Commissioner, Mr. Barnier, is proposing that at the next Intergovernmental Conference, the Council should address these matters by majority. This is the kind of mechanism to which we are constantly subjected when European integration is played out with the Brussels institutions. The French must be aware that not only is the goal of all these operations to dismantle their country as a center of responsible decision-making, but also that every means will be used to wrest their consent.

The two great resources of the Atlantic coast, closely interconnected: fishing and tourism, have both been severely affected. There is a risk of losing the season and dragging on into an extremely serious crisis at the end of the year. It was therefore fully justified for our Parliament to draft a new resolution, to which our group has made a significant contribution, emphasizing several points that we consider to be of the utmost importance on the ground. The first is that polluters must assume full responsibility. Our resolution calls for the application of two principles: that of "the polluter cleans up," as it is unacceptable that the cleanup of coasts polluted by a cargo of hydrocarbons should not be the responsibility of the owner, but rather of public authorities, that is, the taxpayers, that is, the victims. The second principle is that of "the polluter pays." This responsibility, as stipulated in our resolution, must also extend to the fishing and aquaculture sectors and companies. This is essential; This means that the polluter cannot claim to limit the amount of compensation for victims to the maximum set by the FIPOL, that is, to the goodwill of the major oil companies. If the FIPOL ceiling is insufficient, and it is clearly underestimated, it must be increased. This is what our resolution calls for. And if the increase is insufficient, the polluter must finance the remainder. It would be particularly iniquitous for an oil company, whose profits this year amount to 10 billion francs, to refuse to compensate 100% of its own victims, the vast majority of whom are small businesses and workers. The hard-hit communities, Commissioner, expect concrete signs of solidarity at the European level. Our resolution calls on the Commission to take measures to help repair the damage caused to the fishing sector affected by the consequences of the disaster. Blue Europe, the CFP, must now show that, beyond the obligations it imposes on fishermen, solidarity is not a word it ignores. The European Union must also participate in environmental restoration in affected wetlands and coastal areas whose biological value is of interest to the entire Union. Mr. Fischler has just told us that he would welcome France's requests, something I welcome. On this essential issue of marine pollution, we must act as a catalyst. Twenty years after the Amoco Cádiz disaster, laxity and irresponsibility regarding maritime safety continue to reign supreme in Europe, along with their consequences: new oil spills. This time, inertia must not prevail. We must quickly define a general framework for maritime safety, respecting the principle of subsidiarity, and finally put an end to this infernal spiral of widespread irresponsibility. Mr. President, the economy of the western Atlantic is in ruins, covered in fuel oil from the Erika. Fishermen, oyster farmers, shellfish farmers, tourism professionals, and local and regional authorities are impatiently waiting for aid, as well as for treatment of the hull, which apparently continues to leak and is a veritable time-delay bomb.

In that case, obviously, no reciprocity is established in favor of European UCITS. We will also oppose the removal of the right of States to increase the rate to 35%... (The President cuts the speaker off) Mr. President, this matter is of fundamental importance for Europe. A Europe facing the imminent pensions time bomb must take all necessary measures to encourage savings and optimize the benefits that the people of Europe can derive from their savings. I welcome many of the advances in Mr. Schmidt's report. UCITS are a great success in the European Union. They constitute a safe product that can be marketed across borders. But the time has come to update the legislation. Mr. Schmidt has done excellent work in this regard. It is no secret that, personally, I would have much preferred if Mr. Schmidt's report had not been so amended as it passed through Parliament. But I appeal to this House to take a balanced and common-sense approach to this issue. The radical measure advocated in this report is to allow UCITS to use OTC derivatives. I appeal to everyone here to assess the products that these UCITS will use. We are not talking about the use of derivatives for speculative purposes. We are talking about the use of derivatives to reduce the risks and increase the returns on the savings of ordinary Europeans. Mr. Schmidt deserves to be applauded for securing Parliament's support for over-the-counter derivatives. We must not be afraid to move forward and react to changes in the market. Yes, we must continue to ensure that UCITS provide a balanced and protected product for consumers. The report provides very adequate consumer protection. But some of the amendments go too far in limiting the use of OTC derivatives. I believe that these derivatives will be added to the portfolio of unit trusts, which can only help people across Europe achieve high returns on their savings. I greet Mr. Schmidt. Thank you very much, Mr. Kuckelkorn. Dear colleagues, I can now give you an initial answer on the question of the curtain and the window. If we open the curtain, we will find a protective screen that cannot be easily removed. I am afraid, therefore, that we will have to postpone the experiment until the next plenary session. I will try to find out at that time what the room looks like with the curtain open. Mr. President, since its entry into force on 1 October 1989, the UCITS Directive has been a great success, thanks in particular to the very high level of protection it guarantees to investors. The investment fund industry has increased its assets fivefold in the European Union, taking advantage of the directive and the positive image of UCITS among investors. The cross-border marketing of investments within the European Union has seen rapid growth, and the directive itself has become a model piece of legislation worldwide. But it's clear that, after ten years, given the development of markets and the availability of increasingly sophisticated new financial products, the directive is somewhat outdated.

Will the legal basis today be sufficient to legally justify the creation of a new, specifically Community-based criminal law which, although subsidiary, will always be in competition, in practice and in certain areas, with the traditional and fragmented criminal law of the Member States? Given the doubts, would it not be more correct to include the reform of the judicial system on the agenda of the IGC, introducing these proposals into the more general reform of the Union's judicial system, similar to what is being requested for the European Public Prosecutor? Are these matters not of the utmost importance for a revision of the Treaties which contributes to the solidity of the area of Freedom, Security and Justice in the Union? Mr President, the EU is today the subject of strict surveillance. Confidence in the European Union has deteriorated considerably. Strong measures are needed to remedy this. We therefore welcome the increased resources allocated to OLAF, in order to effectively address all suspicions. At the same time, we consider it self-evident that those who have committed criminal acts against the EU should be held accountable. It is regrettable that the Convention on the Protection of the Economic Interests of the Union is applied by only a small number of Member States. We therefore believe that it would be a good idea for the Commission to be given the task of putting forward proposals that involve developing the existing legal framework. However, I am not convinced that these efficiency gains should be achieved by implementing common European legislation or centralising the fight against this type of crime. In this context, I am therefore sceptical about the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's office, which I believe would be very difficult to achieve within the framework of the current Treaty. We have greater faith in the Eurojust programme, which enables national prosecutors to work together. The main problem is not the lack of prosecutions for criminal acts committed against the Union, but the fact that such acts occur so frequently and are so rarely discovered. The challenge for the Commission and for ourselves, however, is to find the right balance. The fraud and negligence that do occur must not result in us being locked into an outdated, hierarchical bureaucracy, where excessive control over details prevents the development of a modern administration. We therefore welcome the aggressive approach that characterises the Van Hulten report. The policy to be followed must aim at giving each administration responsibility for its own supervision. Our experience of modern administrative functioning shows that openness, decentralisation of responsibilities and truly competent evaluation are just as effective as bureaucratic and meticulous supervision. The major challenge here is to create a modern and efficient administration without losing anything in terms of legal certainty or our capacity for control. This requires specific training, more modern recruitment methods, and above all, transparency and openness of the system. The best protection against irregularities is the possibility of effective supervision of the administration.

This has been under discussion for four years now. The Commission must change its internal organizational structures and strengthen the coherence and effectiveness of its measures. Ideally, this could be achieved through a special working group on landmines, endowed with the necessary financial resources. Furthermore, faster contracting and implementation procedures, an expanded multiannual budget line, and significantly improved management of the programs launched by the Commission would be necessary. A proper evaluation of the effectiveness of landmine clearance programs must be carried out in every country where landmines pose a serious problem. In my view, the landmine problem also encompasses many of the organizational, procedural, operational, and financial management difficulties facing the Commission and the Union. Are these problems a thing of the past, or will we find that the European Union is still unable to achieve its objectives, even in this relatively compact and limited area? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Nielson, the conclusion of the new EU-ACP agreement is an important step towards greater coherence. And it is good that criteria such as human rights, democracy, the rule of law, and good governance are more firmly anchored in this new treaty than before, that former colonial relations no longer shape the majority of our relations, but that these political criteria have been given greater weight here. Because that is the prerequisite for any development. If these criteria are not met, then development has no chance. That, Mr. Modrow, also applies to Cuba. I welcome the fact that Cuba is moving closer to this process. But for that to happen, a great deal of change must also take place in Cuba. We are all familiar with the reports from Amnesty International. It may well be that you, as one of the last rulers of communism, see things somewhat differently than large sections of this House, and that you have problems with good governance. Nevertheless, this is an important criterion for the European Union. I would like to address a second topic. We are talking about coherence here. Many colleagues have cited examples of the extent to which the various policies are incoherent. But in my view, development policy as such also needs more coherence. It is incoherent if coordination with the Member States still does not work, if, in some developing countries, Member States and the European Union are implementing very contradictory projects. It is also incoherent towards the European taxpayer if we pursue a development policy that is included in the Union budget, but the EDF remains outside it. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, if you ensure that these EUR 13.5 billion are in future subject to scrutiny by Parliament, the Committee on Budgetary Control, and mechanisms such as OLAF, then I believe you will increase the level of acceptance. I think that this should also be a demand for the Intergovernmental Conference: the anchoring of the EDF in the European Union budget. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, although we believe that this text is well-intentioned overall, we did not vote in favour of it in committee and we will not be voting in favour of it in plenary either, for two reasons which, incidentally, have led us to table a number of amendments which I would like to outline very briefly.

Faced with this neoliberal globalization, dominated by financial markets, the demand, as evidenced by our request, is growing for another idea of the world, according to which the common law would be that dictated by the duty of solidarity in an increasingly interdependent world. No one can ignore the challenge to civilization posed by the lack of nearly a billion jobs. The need to make unprecedented efforts in terms of development and access to knowledge. In this regard, all ideas deserve consideration, and we believe that the Tobin tax is an important one, as are other forms of transactions that are conceivable. This tax can help curb speculation without penalizing the activities of the real economy and help free up new resources for human investments, at a time when the UNDP estimates that $40 billion a year is needed to eradicate poverty, provide access to drinking water for all, and meet health needs. As the debate is launched on a global scale on the capacity of politics to influence the economic sphere, the introduction of this tax could become one of the symbols of the political will to reconquer the democratic spaces confiscated by international financial operators. And I would like to respond to the Commissioner who said that a minimum number of industrial countries was needed to achieve this. It seems to me that the European Union is made up of a significant number of industrial countries and I believe, like Harlem Désir and several other speakers, that the European Union that we form can take the initiative in this regard. In any case, I believe that the European Parliament would do itself honor by echoing the desire of citizens to control the world in the sense of well-being for all. Madam President, I too welcome the holding of this debate, which is long overdue. We know very well that each generation, over time, has blindly fallen into what one might call a dominant ideology, that is to say a set of prejudices accepted as such by the ambient conformism and which, however, end up revealing to subsequent generations how fraught with tragedy they have been. Free trade and the permanent beatification of globalization constitute, in our eyes, the dominant ideology of today, that is to say the great error of our end of century, as dangerous as was once the ideology of the dictatorship of the proletariat in the corridors of the Kremlin, or, long before, the certainty erected into dogma that the earth was flat. Our world is today dominated by a single logic, I was going to say a single god, that of money at work and not of man at work. With the exchange of goods and services amounting to 36,000 billion francs, the product of only four days of speculation, the financial bubble no longer owes much to the productive activity of individuals. It feeds on itself in a bidding war that constantly denies, everywhere, the humanity of man, that of the rich as much as that of the poor, even if it is the latter who, in the end, find themselves excluded from most of the planet's decision-making centers, which are monopolized by a tiny minority, what Jean-Pierre Chevènement recently aptly named: "the globalized elites."

I too would like to compliment Mrs Hudghton on her report and support her changes to the original proposal both in relation to the issue of compensation and in relation to the development of a vaccine. I think that Amendments 7 to 13 are not acceptable and in particular I believe that Amendment 13 not only goes against the aims of the proposal but could make the situation even more difficult than it is under the current rules. This is not to deny the importance of environmental considerations in relation to fish farming. Mrs Hudghton has already mentioned the final report of the joint UK Government and industry working group on infectious salmon anaemia and the measures that are important for all fish farms, not just those affected by the virus. Secondly, as the motion for a resolution on the Katiforis report is being adopted this evening, paragraph 28 is of particular importance. This paragraph calls on the Commission and the Member States to step up measures to combat the possible negative effects of aquaculture on the marine environment. Thirdly, in line with what has been said previously about the collection of fisheries data, I hope that the Commission will launch projects and studies looking at aquaculture in the environmental context; this is the approach that should be taken in relation to the environment and not the one suggested by Amendments Nos 7 to 13, which I hope the honourable Members will reject. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not agree with the chorus of satisfaction expressed by my colleagues who are delighted at the watering down of a directive that respects the precautionary principle and that lays down provisions to protect the health of consumers. Infectious salmon disease, caused by an orthomyxomicrovirus that breaks down the blood of salmon and kills them, spreads very easily in salt water through mucus, etc. The 1993 directive allows not only sick fish but the entire herd to be slaughtered, just as, when a cow is sick, for reasons related to the precautionary principle, the entire herd is slaughtered. Now we are being proposed to soften this directive so that not the entire herd is slaughtered, but only the fish declared sick. As for the others, we should wait for the course of events, acting according to local circumstances. I think it is very serious to proceed in this way and, in this regard, I would like to draw the attention of my colleagues to the fact that we cannot be satisfied with stating that a temperature of 27ºC has all the advantages for the human race and that, therefore, men are not at risk. And what about women? No studies have been carried out in this sense on human tissue. There is also a risk for the environment, because we know that the disease has an incubation period in salmon and that, therefore, when these fish are consumed, they can be healthy carriers of the virus, thus constituting a danger. And this is not the only risk to the environment, as the disease is transmitted, as we have seen, to non-farmed fish. All this has led me, together with my colleague Patricia McKenna, to table some amendments against the Commission's proposals.

We would like to go further on a number of points. That is why we will vote for Amendments 102, 103 and 104 proposed by the Green Group, which we believe will further improve our position on these issues. As regards water pricing policy, extreme situations sometimes arise that require exceptions to the principles set out in the report. Personally, I believe that Amendment No 43 from the Environment Committee provides for the necessary exceptions, and that the wording on this subject is even more satisfactory in Amendment No 105 from the Green Group. I do not believe it is necessary to provide for exceptions applicable to cases other than those indicated in these two proposals. However, opinions on this subject are divided within our group. Amendment No 107, which addresses this issue, has been accepted by a number of us. Overall, I believe that the Environment Committee's proposal, as submitted to us in the Lienemann report, is valid and can provide a good basis for reaching a difficult compromise. Mr President, every satellite photo proves that we do indeed inhabit the blue planet: this abundance, however, is an illusion. The very recent disaster on the Danube reminds us that rivers and streams are the lifeblood of our planet and that pollution knows no bounds. Water is a renewable and limited natural resource. It becomes scarce when it is not well managed and when geographical and climatic conditions are unfavourable. Within the Union, this issue is of crucial importance in the Mediterranean region, but also in other European countries where we are witnessing the gradual drying up of wetlands. Sensitive, humid or arid areas, inequalities between States, inequalities between different regions within States, climatic, economic, geographical and geological particularities, are all obvious points that we wish to recall, but which must not, however, lead to distortions of competition in the Community. We have, however, tabled amendments to recall the importance of the specific relationship between agriculture and water, a key factor in the occupation and development of the territory. It is understood that the needs of agriculture in the South are much greater and that this specificity must be taken into account in this framework directive. Moreover, it is not only in the States of the Union that solutions to these problems are being sought: the countries of the Euro-Mediterranean partnership, in Turin in October, directly called for a Marshall Plan on water for the southern coast of the Mediterranean. Fortunately, we are not there yet. In Europe, however, there are droughts, desertification in certain regions, but also floods, and the directive clearly highlights this. We have suffered from this recently in France, and also in the Rhine Valley and in Central Europe. We need this framework directive as an essential element of a sustainable development policy that must make the different uses of water compatible with each other. But it is necessary to integrate the protection and conservation of biodiversity into this new management. The "water" issue will not be closed today in any case. Indeed, the issue of enlargement and climate change are opening up new perspectives.

In addition to water quality, its quantity is also important, as there is not enough of it throughout Europe, especially in regions with very arid zones. I regret that the Commissioner who is actually responsible for this matter, Ms. Wallström, cannot be here, as this is certainly an extremely important directive, on which the Commission has been working for a very long time, and the legislation for water protection, which is being debated today at second reading, affects all citizens of the European Union and also all inhabitants of the candidate countries, who will have to comply with EU legislation upon accession. We have been working on this issue for ten years, and this comprehensive approach only became possible after a hearing initiated and organized in 1994 by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy. From that time until today's second reading, many people have worked hard on the issue in the European Parliament, the European Commission, and the Council of Ministers. We managed to reduce the 243 amendments from the Committee on the Environment to 27, to which, however, another 30 have now been added. As you can see, many and very diverse aspirations are at stake. Some seek to tighten the provisions, others seek greater precision, and many are driven by national interests. In my political group, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)/European Democrats, there were naturally also different points of view. Our approach is to try to establish realistic objectives and practically applicable solutions. Some of the amendments that I and some other colleagues have tabled on behalf of our group undoubtedly improve, from that perspective, the requirements proposed in the common position. Some amendments, which we support, aim to strengthen the European Parliament's negotiating position in the subsequent conciliation with the Council of Ministers. We clearly reject all unrealistic demands, which undermine the European Parliament's credibility. Among these, I include the requirement for zero entry of hazardous substances, that is, the requirement that this be reduced to zero by 2020. This would mean the end of all agricultural activities and many industrial activities. In this context, I would like to emphasize once again that, despite everything, we have already made considerable progress with the national and European water protection laws currently in place, however incomplete they may be and even though the Member States have poorly respected them. I just want to point out that we now have salmon in the Rhine, something that would have been unthinkable 20 years ago, and that even in the Elbe, which suffered from a particularly high pollutant load, salmon will be introduced again. This does not mean that we do not have to continue making enormous efforts to continue improving water protection and to maintain the surface and groundwater that are still in good condition, which will undoubtedly also entail high costs. Just in recent days, many concerns have been expressed from the agricultural sector. Agriculture, too, needs sufficient, clean water to thrive. With the guidance our Group has maintained in the negotiations with the Council of Ministers, it will be possible to reach a solution favorable to agriculture as well.

We need more police forces; the existing forces are completely insufficient. We need an independent judiciary—which will certainly be difficult to establish—as well as funds for the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights. All this must be done, and quickly. If we do not provide assistance quickly, the situation will deteriorate, and new conflicts and crisis situations could result. That is why I think we did well to act quickly, to accept the urgency, and to release funds. However, we want to see action and successes in Kosovo, and I urge the Commission to ensure the proper use of these resources, particularly with regard to the development of the police and the establishment of the justice system. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Members, and in particular the rapporteur, for the promptness with which they have dealt with this subject. This will undoubtedly enable us to disburse aid quickly and address the concerns that Mr Swoboda and Mrs Pack have expressed to us. It seems to me that three basic types of concern have emerged from this evening's debate. Firstly, although much progress has been made in this respect - we could mention customs administration, banking administration, tax administration - it is true that we still have some way to go. To finance what? This is the first point where we see a certain divergence. In one of your amendments, you suggest establishing in a more limited way the type of institutions to which the Union's funding contribution refers. For example, Amendments Nos 3 and 5. However, in our view, in both cases, greater room for manoeuvre should be given to the UN administration, which is more familiar with the situation on the ground than we are. We believe that predetermining the destination of resources at this time would create additional practical difficulties. Ultimately, we will have to place our trust in those on the ground who can make certain decisions better than we would. The second concern, which I believe some of you share—it was Mr. Bourlanges who expressed it first, but others have also expressed it—concerns the problem of other donors. Is the Commission making an excessive effort while others are not implementing their cooperation? Some amendments in your report go in this direction. Amendments 1, 2, and 4, for example. I would say to Mr. Bourlanges and those who raised this point that the fundamental problem does not lie in the spirit, which we completely share. The fundamental problem is that it is true that the distribution of effort between the various donors is currently based on the declarations of the high-level steering group, but it is no less true that these have no legal value; they constitute only a political commitment. This is why we would ask, and we have also provided a note to Mr Brok to this effect, that Amendment 1, the spirit of which we accept, be worded differently, so that it does not imply any conditionality on the provision of Community resources.

Mr President, Dear rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank the rapporteurs, who have succeeded in producing well-founded reports in a short space of time. Nevertheless, my group has criticized the timing of the committee's work. The reports were submitted late, and, moreover, they were dealt with in a great hurry, at least in the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism. This missed good opportunities to discuss the results of previous programs, good practices, and shortcomings. In connection with the INTERREG program, our group would like to highlight the cross-border activities, particularly cooperation beyond the Union's external borders. Important regions in this regard include the Balkans and the Adriatic, but I believe cooperation with Russia should not be forgotten. My group therefore reiterates the problem of practical monitoring of the funds and stresses the need for better coordination of the INTERREG, TACIS, ISPA, and PHARE programs. This is currently lacking, and the Commission has not yet put forward any concrete proposals for improving coordination. Parliament expects the Commission to present a detailed study on this to our committee as soon as possible. The involvement of businesses, organizations, and other stakeholders is crucial for practical implementation. Based on previous experience, cooperation projects require better planning, more precise monitoring, and a more results-oriented implementation. Projects often stall halfway through, their effectiveness stymied by administrative and bureaucratic red tape. We must also demand a binding commitment to the projects from our cooperation partners and the fulfillment of their share. Our group resubmits several amendments that were rejected during committee discussion. In this context, I would also like to refer again to the URBAN report, in the explanatory statement of which the rapporteur thankfully also addresses the minimum amount of EUR 500 per inhabitant set out in the Commission's guidelines. This cannot work as a blanket target. Rather, it must be possible to determine this amount according to the conditions in the respective target area. This aspect is so important that it should appear in the conclusions rather than the explanatory memorandum. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, INTERREG is one of the most European of all structural funds. Projects are not intended to be supported solely in one region or country, but in neighboring regions in two or more countries. Unfortunately, this only applies to part of the money, namely only those within the EU. But it is precisely the regions bordering third countries that need a functioning instrument for cross-border cooperation. The regulation pretends that this is indeed the case. But it is not. The fact is that the Commission has not amended the regulation for years, even though Parliament has long demanded it. In practical terms, this means that for the foreseeable future, these regions will be degraded once again to a degenerate form of peripheral zone funding. Parliament has been calling for a joint fund to be created for cooperation with third countries since 1996 in order to alleviate the difficulties. Nothing has happened! The difficulties are being dragged out again, at the expense of the affected regions. Parliament is once again calling for improvements and cross-border cooperation, and we expect a common fund to be established and the regulation to be amended again in cooperation with the other Commissioners.

Mr. President, the Council's approval of the draft Convention on mutual assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union is approaching. The prevailing view is that it is about time. According to the action plan for combating organized crime, adopted by the Council in April 1997, work on the Convention on mutual assistance in criminal matters should have been completed before the end of 1997. Even more time will have to pass before the Convention enters into force, as it must be ratified by the Member States. Despite the new rules introduced by the Amsterdam Treaty, which provide for the entry into force of the Convention as soon as it has been approved by at least half of the Member States, I would like to urge the Member States to spare no effort to accelerate its ratification. The experience of previous ratifications of European Union conventions in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters is regrettably disappointing. This Convention will not create a new or different system of mutual assistance. On the contrary, its objective is to improve the tried and tested mechanisms that have long been in place, such as those provided for in the 1959 Council of Europe Convention on Mutual Assistance and the Benelux Treaty. The draft prepared by the Council contains provisions on a number of issues that have been debated by several Members. One of the notable achievements of the Convention is that, to the extent possible, Member States receiving requests for assistance must follow the formalities and procedures indicated by the requesting Member States. This is particularly important with regard to the possibility of using evidence obtained in court. Furthermore, requests can be made directly between competent authorities, without having to go through the central administration. Broadly speaking, there are two types of provisions: those establishing an obligation to provide assistance, such as provisions on telephone and videoconferences, controlled deliveries, and the interception of telecommunications; and those that do not establish such an obligation and merely provide a legal framework for Member States that wish to cooperate in the prescribed manner, for example, the provisions on joint investigation teams, covert investigations, and the forwarding and service of procedural documents. The Commission particularly welcomes the inclusion of provisions relating to new or modern investigative techniques, given their effectiveness in combating the type of crime most likely to profit from open borders: organized crime. It is all too easy to get carried away by the obvious need to improve the effectiveness of criminal investigations. However, we must not forget one aspect common to all action relating to criminal proceedings: the right to a defense. I greatly appreciate that Mr. Di Pietro's report, whom I congratulate on the excellent work he has accomplished in such a short time, includes the right to a defense as one of its main points. Currently, Member States are solely responsible for ensuring respect for this right, subject to the control of the Council of Europe Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.

This criticism is not new. Ever since Europe began trying to do something about development cooperation, the effectiveness and quality of this assistance have been called into question. Hope for improvement is threatened with extinction if the Commission continues to refuse to look at itself in the mirror. Why was the critical report on the coherence of development cooperation policy not circulated externally? One of the key findings of that report concerned the internal contradictions in European policy. Particularly in the areas of agriculture and trade, European policy is in contradiction with development cooperation policy. We are failing to provide serious development aid to the least developed countries. This is due to the divergent views of different EU countries regarding development cooperation. We must no longer regard development cooperation as an instrument under Foreign Affairs or External Relations, but rather as an independent policy area. I advocate a transparent, supportive, and effective development cooperation policy. As long as the European approach to the issue of development cooperation remains a source of inefficiency and waste of money, it is preferable for this role to be devolved to the Member States. Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to forward to Parliament as soon as possible the document I mentioned, so that we can reflect positively on the solutions that could be found. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this initiative is a relevant and entirely sensible one. As many colleagues have already said before me, we often find highly contradictory situations between what we claim to do with development and cooperation policy, on the one hand, and what we undo, on the other, with other sectoral policies whose interests are contrary in terms of the development of these same countries. We are not only talking about the concrete impact of our common policies, tourism, the environment, agriculture, fisheries and industry. We generally talk, more seriously, about contradictions between our economic and trade policies, on the one hand, and our defense policies, on the other. Finally, there is a set of contradictory situations. In my opinion, the contradictions are not so serious in terms of Community policies; they are more serious with regard to certain objectives and certain industries of some Member States. We must be aware of this. On the one hand, we often adopt resolutions on peace processes in other parts of the world, as we did very recently in the case of Indonesia, a case that should raise the cogs to the heavens, and then we find, on the other hand, that certain European countries were supplying that country with arms and war material. These are, in my opinion, the most serious contradictions in this area, more serious than the contradictions of a certain incompatibility of sectoral policies, which of course exists. It is obvious that there are always contradictions between different policies, even in a given country. This is normal. At the European Union level, we must also be aware that there will be contradictions between the various common policies, in this case in development policy. We must be aware that these contradictions exist and that they must be minimised. This objective of minimising contradictions is a just and wise objective, and the basis for the presentation of this resolution.

Similarly, with regard to judicial and criminal matters, which we have discussed today, I believe that not only should we coordinate the different criminal, judicial and administrative legislative systems, but that we also need to finally formulate common rules: what is a crime in Italy must also be a crime in Great Britain, Spain and so on. I believe that we, the Parliament of the European Union, representatives elected by the citizens, must give the greatest impetus to achieve a European Union that provides for the regulation of all areas of citizens' lives, including that of justice, as well as that of pensions. We will vote against this report; in fact, by allowing the cross-border interception of telecommunications and reversing the burden of proof, the Convention will provide a favourable legal framework for large-scale electronic espionage operations in the EU. This means making an electronic espionage system such as the American operation ECHELON perfectly legal in Europe too. This Convention will be the source of serious abuses against individual rights to privacy. This is a terrible threat to civil liberties in the European Union. We also find the following unacceptable: joint investigation teams, controlled deliveries, covert operations, vagueness in the text on the scope of the Convention, failure to respect the principle of proportionality and lack of democratic guarantees. Resolution on the Commission's strategic objectives 2000-2005 Commission President Prodi said that 'the responsibility for Africa lies with us' and not, it seems, with the United States or any other large country. I worked in Africa 30 years ago; it was then a poor and underdeveloped continent, but its problems have since become catastrophically worse. Last year, two million people died of AIDS in Africa, while around 200,000 died in war. In Zambia, 25 percent of teachers died of AIDS. In some countries, children had better prospects in basic education and healthcare 20 years ago than they do today. Our policies for Africa lack coherence: there is an uncontrolled overlapping of initiatives, and above all the debt burden still blocks the road to real development. It is clear that Africa is now a forgotten continent. In its communication on the strategic objectives 2000-2005, the Commission reiterates the need to make Europe a "global player" that makes its voice heard in the world. What should be the objective of this global player? The citizen probably expects a response that includes better defense of European countries, this being the essential and traditional mission of the political association. Well, such an answer does not appear anywhere. At most, one finds generic phrases about "strategic partnerships" and the new opportunities for developing trade that would apparently result from the complete integration of Europe. The fact that the main objective is omitted is a very indicative fact that highlights one of the serious shortcomings of the European Union - a little-known shortcoming, almost always implicit, but which explains in large part the disaffection of citizens. In the work programme for the year 2000, annexed to the strategic guidelines, there is a very significant passage in this regard.

During this visit, as requested by honourable Members and others, I will inaugurate the European representation in FYROM. The deadline for the conclusion of the negotiations is December this year, but everything will depend to a large extent on the goodwill and determination of the negotiators. The agreement could enter into force within three or four years, taking into account the time needed for ratification in the parliaments of the Member States. I would like to make a few brief comments on several points in the draft resolution. We recognise that the agreement must to some extent serve as an example for other such agreements, although we will take into account that we are dealing with different countries, each of which has its own identity and interests. I share the very widespread concern that each country should be treated on its own merits and not forced to follow the pace of the slowest in developing relations with the Union. That was never the intention. The very fact that negotiations are starting with FYROM, before all the others, proves that we can and do make the necessary distinctions. On the regional aid referred to in the report, we agree that technical and financial assistance should be partly earmarked for projects with a cross-border or regional dimension and that there should be an evolutionary clause on the prospect of accession to the European Union contained in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, as this will reflect the position of the European Union on its relations with the Western Balkan countries as set out in the conclusions of the Cologne European Council. We strongly support the need to decentralise assistance programmes as much as possible. As regards the provisions on EU assistance to the Western Balkans, Members will be aware that we are drafting a new regulation to simplify and streamline its management and to bring it all together in one regulation. I am aware of the concern that the end of the PHARE programme in these countries and, above all, the loss of association with the name PHARE will cause in FYROM and elsewhere. I have noted with concern what Members have said in this regard. I will return to this issue, although it is worth pointing out that having two PHARE programmes running risks creating real confusion. I would like to stress, however, that whatever we call the programme, our commitment to the integration of FYROM and neighbouring countries into the European family is stronger than ever. In general, I trust that Members will share my satisfaction in seeing Macedonia reach this stage in a relatively short time. I hope that other countries in the region will step up their efforts to make similar progress. I look forward to more debates like this in the coming years, hopefully marking the success of what we are trying to do in the Balkans, which in my view remains the most important test of what Europe can do on its doorstep. Thank you very much, Commissioner Patten. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12.00.

Mr. President, I have had the privilege of listening to the Commissioner speak on this matter on several occasions, and I fully agree with his approach. However, I would like to ask you something different. We just heard Commissioner Barnier say that he is very interested in improving communication with the public and focusing the Commission's information policy on the main issues the Community will address this year. Would the Commissioner be prepared to advocate allocating part of the Commission's information budget to inform and consult citizens on this issue of the Citizens' Charter? It is very important that the public feel involved in this process. I know that the Convention will have a major impact in this regard, but it does not have the resources available to the Commission. Will the Commission consider using its information budget to ensure public participation in this debate? The Commission's policy is to encourage an open and broad debate on the Charter of Fundamental Rights, not only with non-governmental organizations but also with citizens, especially in the case of a project with such far-reaching implications as this Charter. I can assure you that the Commission will do everything possible to encourage debate on the future Charter of Fundamental Rights. The best way to achieve this is to have a clear text, one that citizens can easily read, and at the same time, a text that serves as a legal instrument. The two are not incompatible at all. The challenge we face is to combine both concepts in the final version of the Charter. I am very pleased to know that I can count on your support in this regard. Question No. 40 by (H-0095/00): Subject: Article 6(1) and Article 7(1) and (2) of the Treaty on European Union. Article 6(1) of the TEU stipulates that the Union is founded on the principles of liberty, democracy and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is clear, as can be seen from statements made over recent years, that Jörg Haider and the Austrian Liberal Party do not respect the human rights and fundamental freedoms of third-country nationals and minorities residing in Austria. Therefore, can the Commission indicate when it intends to find, pursuant to Article 7(1), "a serious and persistent violation by a Member State of principles referred to in Article 6(1)" and to call on the Council, acting by a qualified majority, to suspend certain rights arising from the application of the Treaty to Austria, in particular the voting rights of Austria's representative on the Council? Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by recalling the position adopted by the Commission—and reiterated again this morning by President Romano Prodi—regarding the composition of the new Austrian Government, which includes ministers from Jörg Haider's Austrian Liberal Party. I am referring, of course, to the declaration issued by the Commission on 1 February 2000, the essential outlines of which I will begin by recalling.

In my opinion, it is important that the Community initiative can be launched promptly and that the report receives the approval of a large majority, so that the Commission too can be persuaded to take account of the constructive proposals of the European Parliament. It should be remembered that Parliament has placed the EQUAL funds in the reserve, so that the opinions of Members can also be reflected in this Community initiative. The European Parliament is therefore justified in insisting that any change in priorities should only be possible if Parliament is consulted again. I am firmly determined to make the EQUAL initiative worthy of the name. It should ensure equal opportunities for all disadvantaged people in the European Union and prevent social disintegration. It should also prevent exclusion from continuing to be an everyday reality. Finally, it should offer everyone the opportunity to benefit from a Community initiative, regardless of age, sex or origin. That is what I intend to do and I therefore call on the House to give the report a convincing approval! Madam President, the mere fact of having a debate today on the new Community initiative URBAN is in itself a considerable success, and it is no small achievement that your rapporteur is here tonight, given that Air France cancelled my flight at 2.10 p.m., but I did it anyway! A year ago, when the Commission presented its proposals for AGENDA 2000, it cut the URBAN initiative. However, we politicians knew that there was a growing tide of support for the continuation of this initiative in 2000. Parliament can therefore take credit for the successful campaign for URBAN and for convincing the Commission and the Council to reconsider. Urban policy has always been at the forefront of Community policies. In my own Member State, for example, we are developing a strategic approach in a White Paper and a government taskforce on urban areas has been appointed to follow up on the problems of urban communities. With eight out of ten Europeans living in urban areas, it is legitimate to help our most disadvantaged communities to address familiar problems such as poverty, social exclusion, unemployment, crime, drug addiction and all the related issues. For example, in my own region of Manchester, the URBAN Community Initiative has been a huge success. URBAN money has been invested in one of the UK's most deprived neighbourhoods, Moss Side. The Millennium Youth Park project is trying to re-engage young people in activities that will revitalise their communities, and with support for small businesses and social policy, we are starting to see a real revival in a previously deprived urban community. The work done under this URBAN programme has been disseminated to the wider community through communications and information campaigns in local supermarkets and well-known British pubs. We would like to see these examples of good practice spread across the Union through information and awareness-raising campaigns. The specific guidelines of the initiative are essentially intended to promote local and regional diversity.

These services are also a strong and not negligible element of civic ties. Indeed, as has been repeatedly pointed out, is not the postman the last contact in territorial areas that are defined as depopulated or disintegrated, whether they are isolated geographical areas or the at-risk suburbs of our cities? I cite as an example the initiative of the French postal service, which has undertaken to ensure the presence of interpreters and public scribes in post offices in degraded urban areas. Without considering jobs in related industries, the European public postal service currently employs one and a half million people, who are put at risk by the spectre of a brutal and uncontrolled liberalisation. The European Parliament is proud to have succeeded in reconciling openness to competition with the constraints of a universal service that respects employment needs. We are pleased, but we want all this to continue. For this reason, we can only deplore the fact that the European Parliament is currently kept on the sidelines of the decision-making process that governs the fate of the postal sector in Europe. It is regrettable that to date - as is emphasised in the resolution - the Commission has not taken into account the resolution of 14 January 1999 which required, we recall, that the European Parliament be involved in the preparation of the measures envisaged and that the reliability of the impact studies on liberalisation be increased. These studies are necessary to assess the effects of any type of uncontrolled liberalisation not only from the point of view of the economic organisation of the market, but also with regard to the human and social dimension. The delays accumulated by the Commission are having an impact on the proposed timetable and the date of 2003 must absolutely be reconsidered. By defining a sector reserved for public postal operators, on the basis of weight and price limits, the Postal Services Directive allowed for gradual and controlled liberalisation. The drastic reduction of these limits calls into question the balance between public service obligations and the economic viability of postal services. In a context of globalisation, in which the logic of profitability and profit is increasingly opposed to concerns about territorial balance and social cohesion, it is essential to remember our attachment to the European public service, be it postal today, railway tomorrow, health care the day after. Mr President, I rise to protest, like other MEPs representing Scotland, against anything that would diminish the quality of life in the most remote rural areas. Postal services and post offices are a vital element for rural communities throughout Europe and, in particular, in Scotland. It would be a disaster if, intentionally or not, actions were to be taken that would damage them. I do not believe that anyone intends to do so, just as I do not believe that the Commission has decided to declare war on the islands of Scotland or Greece. However, the Commission could unwittingly cause very serious damage to these communities. The point is to determine at what speed and by what methods the gradual liberalisation of postal services should take place.

A social, economic, and cultural phenomenon, tourism concerns the majority of European citizens, whether as beneficiaries or as providers of a wide variety of services. Every year, nearly 200 million Europeans leave their usual place of residence for a period of time to go on holiday, most often in other European countries. Moreover, Europe remains the main tourist destination for third countries, even though it faces increasingly strong competition and an increasingly diverse and attractive offering. Since the Treaties do not provide a specific legal basis for the implementation of a genuine Community tourism policy, the European Union must contribute to improving and encouraging cooperation in this sector, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, in order to realize the potential that tourism offers in terms of employment. Vocational training and labour mobility are essential tools in a strategy to combat unemployment in Europe, particularly for tourism service providers, in order to meet the multicultural demands of demand and ensure appropriate customer service. Employment in tourism is often highly seasonal and precarious, which is an obstacle to its sustainable development. It is therefore all the more urgent to acquire and disseminate management and technological know-how in order to encourage new production methods and promote a tourism offering that best meets market trends.
