The adoption by Member States of tax measures favourable to SMEs in order to reduce, in particular, the burden on the labour factor would be, as the report indicates, an excellent way of encouraging employment growth in labour-intensive sectors and, consequently, in the tourism sector. This area of activity is also a decisive element in the economic and social development of the least favoured regions: I am thinking in particular of the outermost and island regions, whose strengths in this area are undeniable. Let us not forget that, in these outermost regions, tourism represents the leading industry in terms of revenue. The revenue and employment generated by tourism contribute significantly to reducing imbalances and encouraging convergence of their economies towards the average rate of Community development. Furthermore, tourism can foster a certain cultural and economic rapprochement, insofar as it allows for greater awareness of the different European cultures and thus contributes to developing respect for European ways of life. It goes without saying, therefore, that tourism, developed wisely, in the long term, must represent a sustainable source of income for local economies while safeguarding and enhancing the rich landscape, culture, history and environment. Finally, I would like to stress the vital role that the European Union should play in promoting new forms of tourism in new places: I am thinking specifically and particularly of introducing Europeans, continental Europeans, to the most remote European destinations, the outermost regions. Mr President, we have launched a major debate on very little because, ultimately, the basic document is nothing more than a Commission communication following the conclusions and recommendations of a high-level group on tourism and employment. Not only is it about very little, but the document we are talking about is also rather old, given that it is dated 28 April 1999, that is to say almost a year ago.

I therefore appeal to those ministers not to undermine this agreement, which was reached with great difficulty. I would like to call on the Commission - and I am pleased that Commissioner Solbes is here this evening - to present us promptly with this multiannual financing programme, with the related report, as requested by Parliament, so that it can be taken into account in the preparation of the preliminary draft of the next budget, in line with what we have been promised. Finally, I would like to point out that, although we have just agreed on EUR 35 million, we know that this is an insufficient palliative; we must reach agreement as soon as possible on a multiannual programme for the necessary reconstruction of Kosovo. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I apologise for the delay, which is due to the other issue which unfortunately also appears on today's agenda again. The Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy recommends releasing the EUR 35 million because the money can really be used to benefit the people affected. Although the grounds for criticism - essentially the lack of willingness to help the people of Kosovo - are not very serious, we will continue to be critical. The procedure would certainly be much further along if the Council administration had not forgotten to inform the European Parliament in good time and to send us the documentation through official channels, thus preventing us from opening an in-depth debate on the matter. I call on the administration to take the necessary measures to avoid similar omissions in the future. We are refusing to draw the necessary conclusions from what has happened just because we have the interests of the affected populations at heart. Before releasing the funds, however, it is essential to set some conditions. The first is that the money must be allocated to reasonable initiatives and not to those who could use it for other purposes. In other words, the money must really be allocated to the areas for which Mr Kouchner is responsible and not to others. Even if the Commission and the Council have taken a different position because of the difficulties in implementing our proposal, we also believe that the other donors must honour their commitments. This is a UN-led mission and it is not acceptable that only the European Union is fulfilling its commitments! In the interests of the victims, other donor countries must also honour their promises within the timeframe provided. This leads me to argue that this issue needs to be addressed much more thoroughly, not only in relation to this specific project, but in relation to all development aid in South-Eastern Europe. They show that the European Union is willing to help by providing funds, but that there is a lack of unity in political leadership. We have so many coordinators reporting to so many superiors that we will soon be called upon to appoint a coordinator of coordinators. Perhaps a more constructive meeting between the competent authorities of the European Union and other institutions, from the OSCE to the United Nations, could be needed to consider and establish a new, single and coordinated procedure for providing effective aid to local populations.

I would like to ask what new initiatives the Council can take to safeguard the interests of these farmers in the upcoming world trade negotiations, particularly in the face of large-scale, industrial-style production in the United States and New Zealand, where economies of scale make it extremely difficult for European family farms to remain competitive and where, of course, European food safety standards do not apply. I fully understand the Member's concerns and I can see that we need to make an effort and achieve a certain consistency, including within the European Union, on this issue. We also need to consider the consequences, particularly in terms of financing and compensation for farmers. However, as you know, this issue is a matter for the European Commission, which will have to develop it. The Council has a limited capacity to intervene in this matter. Mr President, allow me, in turn, to welcome the presence of the President-in-Office in this chamber. However, I do not think he answered my question, which specifically concerns addressing the problem of homelessness and housing. I also asked whether the Portuguese Presidency planned to meet with the non-governmental organizations actively engaged in this area. I appreciate and fully endorse his comments on the need for multiple policies and a multidisciplinary approach, as well as the need to combat the underlying causes of exclusion, which can lead to homelessness, not to mention drug addiction. My question relates specifically to homelessness. It is whether a new Presidency could take a new initiative to try to overcome some of the difficulties to which the President-in-Office referred in relation to aid at the intergovernmental level. I feel that Europe can play a very active role in this regard, if only by serving as a forum where Member States can exchange experiences and the practices that seem to work best. Mr. Deputy Speaker, regarding the possibility of the Presidency supporting the actions of non-governmental organizations, particularly in the specific case of combating homelessness, I would like to say that this type of initiative is welcome, and we are more than open to any possibility of supporting them. We have collaborated with Portuguese non-governmental organizations and with some of their initiatives presented as part of the Portuguese Presidency's action, which we link to all the concerns underlying our own program. We do not have any specific concrete initiative in this area, so we are not closed to the possibility of an initiative by non-governmental organizations being proposed to us in this area during our Presidency. This initiative must fall within the Council's capacity for action. However, it must be understood that anything that could affect the Commission's right of initiative will, of course, have to go through the Commission itself. Mr President-in-Office, you have spoken to us a lot about the future: what the Commission will do, what the Presidency will do in Lisbon, etc. And you have made an announcement that terrifies me, Mr President.

What is absolutely necessary is a minimum of certain rules, valid within the Community, with an obvious increase in guarantees to the maximum levels, also to protect ourselves in view of enlargement. I think about what this Community, these conventions or judicial relations could be if, for example, a fascist country like Turkey were to join the European Union: I would be truly perplexed. It is necessary to have a corpus juris - and everyone has said so - and common rules, especially procedural ones, which guarantee a common rule of law throughout the Community. It is obvious that this is mainly a matter for the IGC and that it is an aspiration to which Parliament can contribute only in a limited way since everything depends on the Council and the Commission. I believe that this first half of the year, in which the Commissioner is Portuguese and the Presidency is held by Portugal, is an excellent opportunity to give an initial boost to this common aspiration. This is precisely why we are in favour of amendments Nos. 78 and 79, which already prefigure a minimum of certain rules on wiretapping and videoconferencing. On the one hand, we are awaiting the outcome of this vote with great attention, precisely to avoid a total emptying of this convention - which, I repeat, already establishes minimum rules - and, on the other, we are also in favour of waiting for any proposal that comes from the Commission so that this minimum Community right is finally implemented. Mr President, faced with the growing phenomena of organised crime at an international level, the Member States should undoubtedly collaborate with each other as much as possible; indeed, the institutional conditions should be created to start a concrete and effective process of cooperation in the judicial field: a process that must, however, face all the necessary stages to avoid inappropriate forcing to the detriment of legitimate national indications in matters of justice, over which the Member States are sovereign, and above all to avoid forcing that ends up trampling on the fundamental rights of citizens. We must therefore proceed with caution when faced with a document such as that of the Council where, as the rapporteur also underlined, after years of discussion, it is now claimed that everything can be resolved in just a few months. Furthermore - and I agree with the assessments of the Honourable Di Pietro - the Council text appears to be far too full of contradictions, inconsistent formulations and gaps. And justice, more than other sectors, obviously cannot be treated in an inconsistent and contradictory way. In the opinion of our group, the report as a whole also appears to be very questionable, despite the introduction of some corrective amendments, sensitive to the protection of personal freedoms and respect for national sovereignty. The report deals with disciplines that are too heterogeneous, there is no graduality and it proceeds by approximation. In conclusion, we will vote against this report, reiterating that the Europe we hope for must be a Europe of rights and guarantees: rights and guarantees that require gradual and responsible reflection, as well as very serious in-depth analysis. First, general rules and institutional certainties must be established, and only then can we proceed to the establishment of practical conventions.

Finally, I would like to address the issue of liability. Not only in terms of the maximum amounts, which I believe must be similar to those in North America. We have set $180 million; in the US, they talk about $1 billion as the upper limit for compensation. I believe we need to increase the current amount and approach a level similar to that in the US, but also reconsider the level of insurance and thus the liability of shipowners, including those who charter the ships, the owners of the cargo, in this liability. As long as the responsibility of the cargo owners is not demanded, I believe the problems will not be definitively resolved. I'll conclude; I don't want to go into this in any more detail. We'll have an opportunity to do so another time. However, as one speaker said—and I thank everyone for their absolutely constructive and pertinent contributions—we must not allow ourselves to be saying in one, two, or three years' time that we didn't do what we should have done. For my part, after discussing this in the College of Commissioners, I can say that the Commission is ready to present to Parliament and the Council the legislative measures, amendments, and directives necessary to provide us with the highest possible safety standards. What is required is the political will of this Parliament – and I note that I can count on it – as well as that of the Council of Ministers. Thank you very much, Commissioner. We have noted your willingness. I have received, pursuant to Rule 37(2), eight motions for resolutions to conclude this Commission statement. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday at 12:00 noon. Storms in Europe. The next item is the Commission statement on storms in Europe. Mr Barnier has the floor on behalf of the Commission. Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your words, especially for the very concrete proposals for the victims, who expect a great deal from the European Union and our help. Personally, just a few days after that terrible storm, I wrote to you asking the French authorities to adjust the Objective 2 areas so that all storm-damaged regions, both in France and in other countries, would be eligible for Objective 2 aid. I believe this has been done, since you haven't said anything about it. We all know that if you don't meet the Objective 2 criteria, it's extremely difficult to get aid. It's better to address this problem immediately. You also know that this isn't just a short-term problem, but a medium- and long-term one as well. Let me explain. I was just in Lorraine when that terrible storm destroyed about 20% of the deciduous forest there. A 20% loss represents an enormous loss for some forestry communities. We know, for example, that a tree takes 150 to 200 years to reach full maturity. The loss for these communities will therefore not be spread over one, two, or five years, but over a much longer period.

However, close attention must be paid to its viability. This requires taking into account natural base emissions that cannot be influenced, as well as diffuse emissions, which are difficult to control, and which also substantially pollute water. Mr. President, in the 21st century, we must accept the fundamental notion that our relationship with water has completely changed. In the 20th century, the aquatic environment was for us a free dumping and disposal system for poisons, special waste, chemicals, etc. The consequences are already visible! We must change this way of thinking and recognize that water is one of the most important elements for our lives, and our responsibility in this regard extends far beyond our current generations. The directive must also be explained in this context, and the public must be able to clearly understand what we intend to do in this area and what the Commission intends to do. Water protection is also, at its core, a social issue, and a decisive social issue. For this reason, it is necessary to strengthen the application of the "polluter pays" principle, otherwise everyone will have to bear the consequences. In view of the progressive deterioration of water resources, it is important that we do not limit ourselves to preserving their current state, but that in tomorrow's vote we strive to ensure a real qualitative improvement. Mr. President, some six years have passed since our colleague Karl-Heinz Florenz, supported by Ursula Schleicher, called for a reorganization of the entire water policy. This has already been done. This is not an easy matter, and I think that the effort made by Mrs. Lienemann deserves our full respect. The decision-making process surrounding this water framework directive is at a very important stage. The issue was raised under the codecision procedure, and at the first reading, we were already able to adopt important and more tailored legislation. The Community position put forward at the end of last year already represented a significant improvement over the original proposal. It is very difficult to adopt policies in this area because the differences are so vast. I would like to say the following to my Spanish colleague: in northern Europe, we have often had to fight flooding, and also water pollution caused by industry, while the problem for our colleagues in southern Europe is often that water has to be transported over long distances simply to supply drinking water or water for agriculture. Let me elaborate on two elements of this proposal. First, quality. The Netherlands is greatly influenced by European water policy. A very significant proportion, one-third of the drinking water we consume, is extracted in the Netherlands from surface water. The Netherlands is located downstream, in a delta, and therefore the quality of the surface water we receive is of the utmost importance. Another important point of discussion is the establishment of water quality standards. A number of amendments have raised questions about the proposed standards, particularly the OSPAR standard for 2020.

The new element in the URBAN II initiative is that it was designed for small towns and urban neighborhoods. This is important, because small towns and cities often have the least chance of obtaining funding. On the other hand, however, it is precisely in such towns that the problems that make renovation necessary are particularly concentrated and have a strong negative impact. In order to increase the effectiveness of the individual measures, the number of URBAN II projects has been limited to 50. I believe it is important that this arbitrarily imposed numerical limitation not be rigidly maintained, but that it be left to the Member States to decide how many projects they wish to distribute their funding resources to. However, it is necessary to ensure that, specifically in small Member States, it is not only the neighborhoods of large cities that once again benefit from this aid. In those countries, URBAN II would be nothing more than a drop in the bucket; it would be of dubious success and would fizzle out. Likewise, in my opinion, it is important that the selection criteria for URBAN II not be excessively broadened, and consequently not distorted. A rigorously defined set of criteria is precisely the prerequisite for the projects being supported to achieve model status and be transferable in the future to other cities with problems. Finally, based on my own experience in municipal politics in a region that has been industrialized for many years and is plagued by many problems, I would like to ask you, dear colleagues, to specifically support two points of the report that I consider essential alongside the sociopolitical aspects. First, environmental protection is an essential aspect of sustainable urban development and, consequently, should be a general requirement for project funding. Second, the prevention and fight against common crime and drug-related crime in cities must be included at the local level. These are essential for improving the quality of life in cities and, consequently, must also play a central role in the URBAN II initiative. Mr. President, distinguished rapporteurs, esteemed listeners, I congratulate the rapporteurs, who have produced well-documented reports in a short period of time. However, within my group, the timing of the work carried out by the parliamentary committee has been criticized. The reports are arriving late, and, moreover, their processing has been rushed, at least in the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism. We have therefore missed a good opportunity to discuss the results of previous programs, their shortcomings, and appropriate implementation methods. Within the scope of the INTERREG program, my group emphasizes cross-border activities and, in particular, cooperation with territories beyond the borders of the Union. Important regions include the Balkans and the Adriatic, but I think we should not forget the cooperation we pursue with Russia either. My group wants to once again highlight the need for better coordination of the INTERREG, TACIS, ISPA, and PHARE programmes, among others.

The Court indicates that these problems are emerging now and points to measures that can be taken now to alleviate the problem. However, as Mr. Marinho pointed out, we need more, but that must wait until the IGC. In my own country, the mythology speaks of the teeming hordes of faceless bureaucrats in Brussels, but there is never any mention of the number of European judges. There are fewer than three dozen at the head of the European judiciary—far from excessive, given the responsibilities associated with their tasks at the heart of the European legal system. Their great importance can be seen in the political implications of the delay in resolving the pending dispute between France and Great Britain over British beef, which has caused so much anger in my country and so much frustration with the functioning of the Union's dispute resolution procedures. This situation has been made worse, some of my advisers believe, by the French Code of Procedure, which makes it virtually impossible for non-French nationals to take legal action against the French Government. It is certainly perceived de facto as impossible. This situation stands in very unfavourable contrast to the British courts, where Spanish fishermen have successfully taken the British Government to court in very similar circumstances. Mr President, what is happening in France appears prima facie to be a case of discrimination against other EU nationals on grounds of nationality, and therefore appears to constitute a breach of the Treaties. I would therefore ask the Commissioner, who was kind enough to comment on my remarks in the previous debate, to look into this and report his findings to Parliament and to me. I would be grateful if the Commissioner could confirm, in his final statement, that this will be so. Mr President, on behalf of the President of the Commission, Mr Prodi, I would like to make the following reply. The Commission notes the position adopted today by the European Parliament regarding the request from the Court of Justice and the Court of First Instance, which seeks, on the one hand, to entrust the Court with the examination of certain actions which currently fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Court and, on the other, to increase the number of members of the Court. On behalf of the Commission, allow me to add that I have listened with great interest to the arguments which have just been put forward in this Chamber and that I fully understand the underlying concern. The concern is legitimate. It has also been said that justice delayed is justice denied. The Commission understands these considerations. Understanding them, I would like to continue my reply as follows. As your Parliament knows, the Commission is convinced that, without in-depth reform, the Community legal bodies run the risk of no longer being able, in the short term, to fulfil their mission within a reasonable time.

President Arafat will meet the Council of Ministers next week. This will be an excellent opportunity to address the need for bold action to improve Palestinian governance and strengthen the rule of law. The Commission is actively involved in these efforts. The Commission has also increased its support for Israeli-Arab regional cooperation projects. Last year we committed over €20 million to these projects. The package included renewed assistance for people-to-people activities and cross-border cooperation where Israelis and Arabs meet at expert and non-governmental body level. Members will recall that the European Union is the largest financial donor to global efforts to reconcile the people of the Middle East. A number of issues naturally emerge as potential additional targets for EU support in the next phase of the peace process - including helping to consolidate a settlement in the Golan by contributing to security arrangements and supporting demining and the reconstruction of communities in the Golan Heights. Syria's economic development will require assistance in the transition from a war economy to a peace economy. Reconstruction and rehabilitation in southern Lebanon, the only area in the Middle East with an ongoing military conflict, will also require significant efforts. We must also continue to provide support for economic reform and social development in Lebanon as a whole. We must find a solution to the problem of Palestinian refugees, who constitute the largest refugee group in the world, numbering nearly 5 million, a figure indicative of the daunting challenges that lie ahead. We must support initiatives to increase the availability and improve the distribution and management of the region's very limited water resources. Last but perhaps most importantly, we must encourage closer regional cooperation in a variety of areas, bringing together all the countries concerned in a joint effort to address their common problems. It is already clear that the financial resources currently available for Community assistance to this part of the world will not be sufficient for the level of support that will be needed in the event of permanent peace. I want to underline this point. I would like to remind the Council and, if necessary, Parliament, quite emphatically that we must not continue to allow a gap to open up between our rhetoric and what we can actually do. I repeat that a change in Middle East policy will require a shift in the support that we will be called upon to provide and will be expected of us. I hope I can add that we will want to provide it. We have made progress in recent weeks and months, as Minister Gama said earlier, but it is inevitable that this will be a tough process fraught with difficulties and disappointments. We will do everything we can to bring this process to a successful conclusion and to meet the obligations and challenges that will come with it. Finally, I will repeat for some who have entered the Chamber in the last few minutes what I said at the beginning of my remarks: I will not be able to stay until the end of the debate, mainly because I had planned the debate this morning and I have scheduled a meeting on the Balkans for this evening.

Thirdly, the Military Staff will represent the senior military officers of the fifteen states who, with me, will form the Civil and Military Secretariat, whose task will be to prepare, with the assistance of the Military Committee, any crisis management operation that may need to be launched in due course within the European Union. This crisis management will not be strictly a military operation; rather, these military officers, the Military Committee, will also be responsible for advising on logistics for any humanitarian operations where the involvement of armed forces may be necessary. Today, Mozambique is certainly an excellent example of how, from a military-logistical perspective, intervention may be necessary not for military but for purely humanitarian purposes. We are working hard, and if I had told you a few months ago, when I had the pleasure of speaking before you for the first time, that on 1 March 2000 I would be announcing that on that very day the Political and Security Committee had met for the first time, that in a week the Military Committee would be functioning, and that the next day the first members of the Military Staff would be moving into the building we have in the European Union, many of you would no doubt have thought the High Representative had lost his mind. We have not lost his mind; we have simply worked hard, intensively, and determinedly, and we have undoubtedly had the help and support not only of you but also of the Heads of State and Government of the countries you represent. Few initiatives in the European Union have been carried forward with as much determination, momentum, and commitment as has been the case in crisis management since Helsinki up to the present day. In less than two months, in cooperation with the Commission, we have set a mechanism in motion. I would like to thank Commissioner Patten, who is here with us, for his support and the tremendous energy he too has expended in bringing all these issues to the most successful conclusion possible in a relatively short space of time. Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to move on to the second issue I wanted to discuss with you. We have already spoken about the bodies we have set up, but we have a fundamental duty, for the sake of our credibility: that Europe must be able to equip itself with the military capabilities to act in times of crisis management. I would like to reiterate that the European Union's intention with these military capabilities is not to wage war, but to build peace, to participate in crisis management, and to intervene wherever there is war or conflict in order to contain, defuse, and prevent it, in the spirit of the Helsinki Summit, which, as you will recall, wisely decided to create, with the participation of all European states, a force of 60,000 troops capable, when the time comes, of taking up their positions in 60 days – that is, in two months – to prevent a crisis and to continue this action for a year to prevent conflict. It is a large-scale operation, a major objective that we have set ourselves, but I can tell you that we are capable of rising to the challenge set by the Heads of State and Government in Helsinki.

Mr President, less than a year has passed and it is already clear how differently this Parliament is approaching the first and second reports. The first report was widely publicised, solemnly debated and used, as were the controversies and press leaks that preceded it, to massacre first the President of the Commission and then the majority of European Commissioners, even though they had nothing to do with fraud, mismanagement and nepotism. Reading now what happened less than a year ago, it is clear that that report was intended to serve anything but to bring about truth or reform, as is claimed today, so much so that this second report, which could have brought much more substantial elements, was commissioned with the specific mandate not to deal with specific cases, since it is not interested in pursuing the illicit acts contained in this report. It does not interest the large groups in this Parliament or the majority of the trade unions, who are verbally committed to defending the European civil service but in reality are busy with the corporate protection of their members, using the broad powers granted to them in a questionable manner. Trade union representatives are on the disciplinary board and the Statute committee so as to make the unfaithful official irremovable and to keep the Statute in check. Trade union representatives are also, incomprehensibly, members of the competition commissions, and I would not be surprised if trade union members were already members of OLAF, causing serious damage to this institution which should, at least formally, guarantee that it is super partes. I therefore understand why we are meeting at this hour, which is usually used for other activities and not for debate, discussion and information. Mr President, with regard to its internal reform, the Commission finds itself in a truly difficult position. After the events that led the old Executive to resign, expectations are enormous. Sometimes I have the feeling that the more radical the proposals put forward, the greater the consensus in the Chamber. On the other hand, the situation cannot be changed overnight with a couple of amendments decided on at the table because the complications arise at the time of implementation, when it comes to defining the details. This is probably the reason why the Committee on Budgetary Control also found it more difficult than expected in addressing the problem, even if it nevertheless reached a noteworthy result: the report presented by my Honourable colleague Van Hulten, whom I expressly thank for the work done. Unless it is made even more lenient by adopting some amendments, the report imposes some clear and unequivocal objectives on the Commission. Allow me to state the first one first: we do not want financial control to be abolished. Even if not in all cases, the controller must be able to continue to carry out preliminary checks on commitment and payment operations where there are risk factors or uncertainty. By renaming the current Directorate-General for Financial Control the Directorate-General for Audit, the Commission is not sending the right signal because, while it is easy to change its organisational chart, things get complicated when it comes to redrafting legal texts, in particular the Financial Regulation.

Will you do everything in your power to ensure that a staff statute is adopted as soon as possible? In the meantime, can you ensure that Parliament's rules are properly applied and that staff are paid, as they should be, according to the work they do for us? Without them, we would not be able to function. Mr President, I also have a point of order. Are there any rules regulating demonstrations in this Parliament and outside the Chamber, so as to ensure that Members can enter the Chamber unhindered and carry out their obligations? If there are such rules, who is responsible for enforcing them, and how are those responsible for them meeting this task? Mr President, I would like to return to the issue of the assistants' statute, which we have always considered a priority, and inform you that the Italian members of the PSE Group have, at the request of our Group Chairman, Mr Barón Crespo, handed over the contracts we concluded with the assistants to the Quaestors. I consider this a concrete step towards resolving this problem, and I therefore ask the Bureau of Parliament to consider whether it should not encourage all Members to do the same. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to state that I fully support a statute for staff. When I arrived in Parliament yesterday, I was handed a document concerning the proposed demonstration by staff in front of Parliament. As all colleagues know—and many of you have contacted me over the past six months—requests for exhibitions and the like are first referred to Parliament's Comart Committee. To give you a neutral example: for obvious reasons, no commercial exhibitions of any kind are allowed in this Parliament. After receiving a letter yesterday, I immediately suggested to staff that they hold a meeting or demonstration soon, perhaps as early as next month. The holding of such events must under no circumstances interfere with the normal work of Parliament. Yesterday afternoon, during the deliberations of the Bureau of Parliament, I signed a letter informing staff accordingly. As I understand it, you were already informed verbally of this decision last Thursday by the Committee of Group Chairmen. So you were aware of the decision. We are always open to the problems of staff, and there is certainly the possibility of an event of this kind during the next part-session of Parliament. But there must have been a misunderstanding, because you clearly received a letter from someone else which you took as an acceptance. However, all exhibition requests are first examined by the so-called Comart Committee. As you can see, we have a great many exhibitions here in Parliament, whether they are dedicated to different countries or on any other topic. This is by no means an attempt at censorship and in no way contradicts the very realistic and justified demand for a staff statute. Thank you very much, Ms. Banotti. Your comments can certainly help to clarify several of the questions raised here. Mr. President, we are dealing with a problem of fundamental importance here.

Regarding Amendment 15 on the definition of the term "independent," the Commission will, as I noted earlier, seek a satisfactory solution to the objections raised. I would now like to address what Lord Inglewood noted. He referred to the border controls that exist in the United Kingdom, and I would like to tell him that there is no obligation for any Member State, and therefore not for the United Kingdom, to abolish or modify the border controls that still exist. This also applies, as has been said, to the United Kingdom. This also applies to Belgium, where this case recently arose. With regard to Mr. Karas's observation, perhaps I may clarify that I have the impression that he is referring to the possibility of using workers from Poland to work in his country. The Commission would like to propose a solution to this problem, and that this solution would apply to all companies established in the European Union that employ workers from countries outside the EU. The question then is whether the two cases should be considered equally. In my view, it is more a question that is part of the debate on the enlargement of the European Union and perhaps not of this debate. However, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to make myself available to Mr. Karas should he wish to have further information on this truly important issue. I remain at his disposal. Finally, I would like to thank Parliament for the very constructive debate on the most important aspects of these proposals and, of course, the rapporteur, Ms. Berger. Thank you very much, Commissioner Bolkestein. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:00 a.m. Court of First Instance Mr. President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on a report which, when read, gives the impression of merely confirming and accepting. However, behind this report lies long and effective work that has already borne some fruit: the incorporation into the Finnish Presidency document of 7 December 1999 of a commitment to broaden the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference to the study of future modifications to the organization, composition, and powers of the Community courts. I therefore express my gratitude to the work of Vice-President Marinho. Mr. President, reforming the Community judicial system has become a paramount necessity if, in the future, we are to deliver justice within reasonable timescales, if, in the future, the European Union is to provide itself with a justice system worthy of the political project we have undertaken. Today—I must say this with pride and satisfaction—we have had a good opportunity in this House to demonstrate to what extent we Europeans believe that the European political project is much more than the internal market, a project based much more on principles than on economic interests.

Safeguarding the social function of the market is the discriminant between liberalism tout court and a system that serves to improve the quality of life of the person. One aspect to be considered in the new legislation is the economy of the outermost and island regions that must be safeguarded. Therefore, I believe that it would be appropriate to also think about creating two foci of an external market, establishing a profitable relationship with Russia and the Mediterranean countries precisely to make the economies less peripheral. I hope and in this regard I thank Professor Monti that the new legislation will be given the broadest possible slant from the point of view of economic policy and guaranteeing its social function. Mr President, competition represents the strength and the heart of the European single market policy. A free and open market can only exist thanks to competition, delimited by clear and uniform rules of the game. This thought is formulated perfectly in the report by the Honourable Karl von Wogau. But Europe is constantly evolving. The economies are growing, the Union will open up to another 10 or 15 States. If we continue with the current policy, the European Commission will not be able to cope with the workload. Therefore, we need to modernise competition policy. There is no question about that. That said, I still have doubts about the proposed decentralisation. I wonder how the Commission, the guardian of the Treaties, can ensure that competition decisions are made in the same way in London, Palermo, Helsinki and in the future also in Budapest and Ankara. Legal disparities must be avoided and the courts that issue the least severe rulings will be inundated with competition cases. It is not enough to say that the Member States have 40 years of experience. In the Netherlands, the competition authorities are just starting out, as the market is very small and at the same time, unfortunately, is often described as a relevant market. In contrast, in Germany, an experienced Kartellamt exercises its powers in a gigantic market. The European Commission's belief that all countries will almost automatically interpret the legislation in the same way could be described as "misplaced confidence", and that is a mistake. We need to work towards uniformity. I am thinking of specialised national courts with the possibility of direct appeal to a special competition chamber within the European Court of Justice. Such a chamber in Luxembourg is essential to gather the necessary experience. Furthermore, the broad economic and social interests associated with these cases do not allow a judgment to be delayed for two years, as is currently the case. What does the Commissioner think? I would like to end my speech with an important comment on small and medium-sized enterprises. In order to give them greater security, the European Commission should draw up an exemption regulation for small and medium-sized enterprises, so that horizontal exemptions are possible in addition to vertical exemptions. By working together, small, independent companies must be able to stand up to large chains, and European competition policy must therefore not aim to make their lives impossible.

There is no justification in our society for terrorist actions such as that which cost the lives of the Socialist Speaker of the Basque Parliament and his bodyguard. Moreover, this is a Member of Parliament elected by popular will of Basque society. We hope that these victims will be the last in a process B, as you said, full of barbarity B and that a way can be found to ensure coexistence and peace among the Basque people. B (ES) Madam President, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, I would like to add my voice to those of my colleagues who are expressing their sorrow at the truly perverse and cruel attack in the Basque Country, who are offering their condolences to the families and are firmly condemning actions that have come from far away and which must be put to an end. One day the terrorist organisation ETA killed some policemen; then it murdered some soldiers; then it exploded a bomb in a supermarket, killing men, women and children; another day, it killed in the streets of Madrid a general commander, Quintana Lacaci, who had defended democracy on February 23; yet another day, it assassinated the spokesperson of the Popular Party in the city hall of San Sebastián, Gregorio Ordóñez; then it was the turn of the university, in the faculty where a professor of constitutional law, Francisco Tomás y Valiente, taught, killed with absolute coldness. A few days ago, after assassinating Lieutenant Colonel Blanco, this organization killed in this infamous manner the socialist deputy Fernando Buesa, spokesperson in the Parliament of Vitoria, and his escort Jorge Díez, a member of the Basque autonomous police. I want to reiterate that those who kill, like the terrorist organization ETA, must be condemned, but those who support and understand such attacks must also be condemned. It is useless to ask these people and these organizations to take the road to democracy from one day to the next. We must appeal to society as a whole, especially to democratic parties, regardless of their national or nationalist dimension, regardless of their pro-European dimension. However, we must also deplore the fact that there are organisations that are silent, people who are silent and others who only lament the deaths as if they were the result of a road accident. All this must be said here very loudly, so that the voice of all European democrats can unite and be heard in the Basque Country, saying that the time has come not to leave, not to separate and not to kill. It is time to share; share the Basque Country, share Spain, share Europe. That is the only way, Madam President. That is why we give you our full support. Madam President, on behalf of the Union for a Europe of the Nations Group, I express our sorrow for the victims and our rebellion against terrorism and against those who protect it. I believe that we are facing a human tragedy, thinking of the families and friends; to a political tragedy, thinking of the political family to which one belongs, but also to a cultural tragedy because the culture of death and violence is increasingly stronger against the culture of respect for others, of democracy and democratic life.

I have no doubt about this and believe it is an essential element. In this context, I also wanted to point out that we must be careful what we say. Last week, the new Finance Minister of the Austrian coalition spoke of the Austrian Parliament as a farce and a theater. We, who have had to live under dictatorial conditions, know that a dictatorship with a sham parliament can exist. We know there is no democracy without a living parliament. I believe such language is enormously dangerous, and I would like to condemn it from here. Regarding the four major priorities to which President Prodi systematically refers, regarding the analysis of the challenges, I would say that we completely agree with him. But I would like to point out to the Commission that there has been a change in priorities for the Socialist Group. In our view, the top priority is the economic and social policy agenda, which includes what your priorities also call quality of life—that is, the rights of citizens as consumers and also as individuals. These are issues that we repeatedly take for granted but fail to emphasize sufficiently, such as the European social model and its adaptation to new realities, consumer rights and environmental protection, and sustainable development. When we talk about the commitment to full employment, we must begin with the fact that full employment no longer means the same thing today as it did in the Beveridge era at the end of the Second World War, namely work for the male head of the family. We must start with gender equality, with the famous gender mainstreaming, which is one of the topics less addressed in Prodi's program. This presupposes that we give priority to gender equality, the adaptation of the social model, and above all, the clear fight against populism at a time when our economic and social cohesion is under threat. This, too, must be given the highest priority in the Commission's work. And it must be accompanied by a clear fight against racism and intolerance, to provide practical confirmation that the Union has become a magnet for the rest of the world and, because of its prosperity and aging demographics, a hotbed of immigration. This, in my view, must be the main objective we must pursue. Here, I would add another element: economic governance, with a single currency—I believe it will prevail. This, too, is an issue on which the Commission must make progress. Given the ambitious goals, and especially given something important the Commission has done, namely deciding on enlargement in the course of a negotiation and integration process, I would like—and my group would, of course, like—to see more clarity regarding the revision of Agenda 2000. Does the Commission believe there will be no revision until the end? And we also definitely consider burdens a key issue. I think a theoretical reflection on governance in general can be very interesting.

My group is pleased that the Social Affairs Council, at the end of last year, gave the green light to a better cooperation strategy and that, moreover, a group of senior officials has already been tasked with presenting an initial report to the Council in June 2000. But we would like, as a Parliament and especially as a Social Democratic group, for Lisbon to take a further step now. It is very important that this European Parliament advocate, through our colleague's report, for a truly European strategy for social convergence, by analogy with what was put in place for employment via the Luxembourg strategy, a strategy, therefore, equipped with Community objectives, guidelines, national action plans and evaluations of benefits. We believe that this approach is ambitious, but nevertheless achievable. It is indeed obvious that the harmonization of social security at European level is not realistic. The systems, in terms of financing and organization, are too diverse for this, and this is also an important reason why social protection is barely making it onto the European agenda. It is also why scenarios such as Dany Peeters' thirteenth Member State or the European social snake have barely gotten off the ground. But this new avenue is particularly interesting. The employment strategy has proven that it can work, and social convergence is also necessary because our social security systems face the same challenges and, in the era of EMU, social security systems otherwise threaten to become an element of social competition. But let me make one point clear on behalf of my group: social convergence strategies can in no way be an alternative to social legislation. They can only serve as a very useful complement to what we are putting together and what we expect from the Commission in terms of social legislation. I also think it is a good thing for the European Parliament to try to convince the Council to implement the Community strategy at the Lisbon meeting and to launch, at the beginning of 2001, an annual procedure aimed at reducing the poverty rate. I am pleased that the European Parliament supports this idea from my group and we hope, Commissioner, that we will also have your support. Finally, we insist that the European Parliament and the social partners as well as social NGOs be closely involved in this process. Only a broad and democratic basis can guarantee the success of this strategy and we hope for your support. Mr President, the wording of the four main objectives that the governments of the EU Member States accepted in November of last year and which have been discussed today is so broad that everyone should be able to approve them. Let me remind you of them: there is the idea that all work must be worth doing in order to ensure a guaranteed income, the certainty of being able to provide pensions and the need to make the pension system sustainable, the promotion of social integration and the guarantee of sustainable and high-quality healthcare. On the other hand, we could only benefit intellectually from the creation of a group of high-level officials, which would be the hub for the exchange of experiences in coordinating and evaluating progress made in social and labour market policy.

The Commission has obviously looked at this issue and I am pleased that the reports to date have looked at it so carefully. I would like to stress, however, that the concern about depleted uranium weapons is about the way in which they are used. The uranium in them is released into the air, it is inhaled and therefore it could have much longer-term effects on the people of Kosovo who have breathed it than we have been able to observe so far. This is indeed what is said to have happened after the use of depleted uranium weapons in the Gulf War. I would therefore like to ask the Commission whether it is prepared to consider continuing the monitoring checks and for how long it would be prepared to carry out monitoring of the long-term effects not only of depleted uranium weapons but also of other environmental effects which we know have occurred at least locally in Kosovo. How long will you continue to monitor the effects of these weapons? Thank you, Mr Bowe, for your supplementary question. We must reiterate that it is not yet confirmed that depleted uranium was used in the conflict and no depleted uranium was found in the clean-up operations in Kosovo. However, the symptoms and problems you are talking about could arise and could be the effect of the use of depleted uranium, the report itself mentions this. No cross-border effects have been detected and the majority of the weapons were used on the territory of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. The problem is that access to the area in question is restricted due to the current political isolation of the country. A great responsibility lies with the United Nations, because they are the recipient of the report and therefore they must assume their responsibility. However, through the environmental and regional clean-up plan we can continue to carry out monitoring actions and provide our assistance and for the time being this is the context in which the Union can operate. It is important to continue to monitor the situation, and among other things, this provides the Member States and also the United Nations and the Commission with food for thought about military secrets and their effects on the environment. In the long term, this also provides food for thought about the use of these types of weapons themselves. - (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, in a few months' time, hundreds of thousands of holidaymakers will once again be heading to the Adriatic beaches for their summer holidays. We know from the media that bombs and weapons have been thrown into the sea close to the coast. Can you assure us that holidaymakers this summer will be able to swim in the Adriatic without danger, and are there any plans to study the threat we are facing in more detail? I would like to be able to guarantee many things, but unfortunately I cannot. We form our judgements on the basis of reports like this and the verification missions we send in cases like this.

Let me assure Mr. MacCormick, among other honourable Members, that the current situation, in which excise duties differ between Member States, is truly unconducive to the smooth functioning of the internal market. However, this situation is not limited to alcoholic products. If we look at gasoline, for example, we will see that excise duties in Germany are different from those in the Netherlands, and consequently, Dutch motorists cross the border to fill up their tanks in Germany. This is actually a distortion of the internal market. If it were up to me, I would wave a magic wand and equalize excise duties across Europe. That would eliminate smuggling, unless products are intrinsically more expensive in one Member State than in another. But I don't have a magic wand, and it's not up to me. This is an area where there must be unanimity, as Mr. MacCormick knows, and unless all Member States agree on the harmonization of excise duties, it will never be achieved. Once again, towards the end of this year, the Commission will present a report on the situation with excise duties, and I will obviously be available to debate that report with Parliament. Thank you very much, Commissioner. Today we will heed your advice and try to have a glass—or two, perhaps—of Alsatian wine, which we do not know how taxed, although I assume it is also highly taxed. As the time allocated for Question Time with the Commission has expired, Questions 55 to 114 will be answered in writing. Question Time with the Commission is now closed. (The sitting, adjourned at 7:30 p.m., resumes at 9:00 p.m.) Community policy in the field of water (continued) The next item is the continuation of the debate on the recommendation for the second reading on Community policy in the field of water. Mr. President, the situation regarding freshwater in Europe is not as serious as in other parts of the world, but, generally speaking, it is a well-established fact that the demand for water has continued to grow and its quality has continued to decline. Added to this are the problems of water pollution affecting the potential new Member States in the east. Incidentally, a cyanide reservoir has just burst in Romania, threatening aquifers that supply the population of Yugoslavia. I understand that Mrs. Wallström, whom I very much thank for her presence this evening, is going to pay a visit to the area. I believe that no country, no government, and certainly no Member of this Parliament can fail to recognize the need for this directive to end the current fragmentation of water policy and facilitate the implementation of a program of specific measures for each river basin. The process has been difficult and complex, the interests at stake are multiple, and opinions are divided. I have no doubt that the rapporteur for this term, Ms. Lienemann, has devoted great effort and dedication to reconciling and reconciling positions, and she has succeeded to a significant extent.

Fortunately, I say! As is perhaps well known, the Mediterranean, unlike the cold seas of the North, is a small and warm sea, where it is very difficult, if not impossible, for schools of fish of a certain species to form. Consequently, the idea, put forward in the explanatory statement of the report in question, of establishing TACs in Mare Nostrum is inappropriate in our opinion. Finally, as regards the amendments proposed by the United Left group, we would vote in favour. In fact, we believe it is very important to financially support traditional fishing and artisanal activities, as well as income support for fishermen during the periods in which the so-called biological stop is applied: in essence, to make an important and responsible economic activity compatible with the due respect for the environment. Mr President, first of all I am pleased to see that the Katiforis report takes into consideration the multiplicity of factors responsible for the degradation of the marine environment: pollution, uncontrolled fishing, the presence of extraction platforms, the pressure of human activity on coastal areas are sources of potential environmental damage on a large scale, both in coastal areas and offshore, and fishing is a further victim of this state of affairs. It is therefore right to examine in depth and analyse the interrelations between fishing and the environment. The use of selective gear that reduces by-catches and limits fishing waste is certainly an essential point, as is, on the other hand, the reduction of fishing pressure not only in coastal waters. The reduction of fishing capacity and fishing pressure on fish stocks does not necessarily go hand in hand with maintaining an obsolete fleet and limiting modernisation. More modern vessels, in addition to allowing more adequate safety and hygiene conditions, can also help reduce certain impact factors. Furthermore, it is important to state the concept that it is not possible to classify a whole segment of fishing as more environmentally friendly a priori: in some cases, it is true that small-scale fishing has a lower impact on the environment and its resources. I am also satisfied that the report takes into consideration the possibility of launching an information campaign for fishermen and consumers on the risks arising from the reckless exploitation of fishery resources, just as I am satisfied with the request made to the Commission to propose the establishment of a European prize to be awarded to various categories of the sector and to all those who offer services and advice for responsible behaviour, for the purposes of the sustainable management of fishery stocks and the conservation of nature in the marine environment. Mr President, as not only a member of the Verts/ALE Group, but also as a Member of the Galician Parliament, I would like to make two brief considerations in this speech. Firstly, fishing production and the conservation of marine life and resources are two aspects of the same issue. It is the shipowners and sailors of the countries with the greatest fishing activity who are most interested in respecting their living environment, since without it they cannot guarantee the future of this type of economy.

We will work towards this. We will see whether we can reach a consensus on this. Question No 5 by (H-0785/99): Subject: Proposal for a regulation fixing the total allowable catches for certain fish stocks for the year 2000, particularly anchovy. According to recent reports from the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, anchovy stocks in ICES area VIII are currently in a critical state. Have the Council of Ministers responsible for Fisheries and the Commission considered the impact on the anchovy stocks in ICES area VIII of the transfer of the quota for ICES areas IX and X and CECAF area 34.1.1 from Portugal to France (overfishing of 5 000 tonnes per year) and considered their responsibility for the current state of these stocks and the foreseeable economic and social consequences for this fishing sector? Given the clearly precarious situation of these stocks, does the Council consider it acceptable to create a permanent basis for such overfishing and for exceeding the total allowable catch (TAC) originally set at 33 000 tonnes per year? What measures will the Council take, and when, to take account both of the critical state of anchovy stocks, of the quota transfer referred to, and of the principle of relative stability of fishing activities? Mr President, the Portuguese Presidency has a strong interest in obtaining a full answer to this question, not least because it relates to an issue that, in a positive sense, concerns Portugal, and I will explain why in a moment. The Council is aware of the critical situation of the anchovy stocks in the Cantabrian Sea, to which the honourable Member referred. At the last Council of Fisheries Ministers on 16 and 17 December last year, the Member States operating this fishery, namely France, Spain, and Portugal, considered that the application of the precautionary principle, which, on a Commission proposal, reduced the total allowable catch from 5,000 tonnes to 2,000 tonnes, had been too cautious. In order to strike a balance between the need to reduce biological risks—that is, the impact on fish species—and the economic and social problems caused by restricting fishing, a compromise was found by setting the total allowable catch at the intermediate level of 16,000 tonnes, instead of the 33,000 tonnes envisaged in 1999. Provision was also made for its review in the light of new scientific information on species conservation, and appropriate data are expected to be available in the first half of this year. For the southern anchovy stock, in ICES area IX, the total allowable catch for the whole of 2000 was set at 10 000 tonnes, compared to 13 000 tonnes in 1999. The exchange of quotas between Portugal and France was reduced proportionally, from 5 008 tonnes in 1999 to 3 000 tonnes in 2000, to be caught in French waters. I would like to point out that this quota transfer does not increase the pressure on anchovy stocks as a whole, for the entire Community fisheries area. In accordance with the principle of relative stability, the allocation key for anchovy in the Cantabrian Sea allocates 90% of the stock to Spain and only 10% to France.

For the time being, that is my opinion. It may be the subject of discussions here and elsewhere. I will listen to any suggestions, but my first conclusion is that this authority should occupy a central rather than a peripheral position. Ladies and gentlemen, I find myself in a very difficult situation because I cannot change the agenda. I would suggest that you discuss this subject within your political groups and raise the issue during the Conference of Presidents. If you consider these sessions following a Commission statement to be important, I would suggest that we request more time than the half hour allocated to them. This time, the questions from Members lasted six minutes, and the replies and the Commissioner's statement lasted 29 minutes. As you can see, half an hour is really not enough time for such sessions. I hope that you will discuss this within your political groups so that we can participate in better-structured sessions with the Commission on future occasions. The debate is closed. Question Time (Committee) The next item is Question Time to the Commission (B5-0003/2000). I would like to inform you that we will be devoting approximately one hour and fifteen minutes to Question Time. The allotted time will therefore be slightly shortened because the interpreters are working in a continuous session today. I call Mr Purvis on a point of order. I object to the fact that we are reducing the time for Question Time; it is one of the rare occasions when ordinary Members have the opportunity to speak, and I ask you to extend it to one and a half hours, as stipulated in the agenda. That is the agenda, and I think we should stick to it. Dear colleague, if we stick to the agenda, we should have started at 5:30 p.m., but you see what time it is. In any case, I hope we do not end up in a night session. First part Question No. 28 of (H-0781/99): Subject: Construction of a nuclear power station in a region of Turkey with high seismic activity The two earthquakes, measuring over 7 on the Richter scale, which recently occurred in Turkey give rise to the greatest concern at Turkey's stated intention to build expensive nuclear reactors at Akuyu, at a time when the surplus energy produced by the Ataturk dams is being exported to third countries and the EU is using its own resources to help repair the damage caused by the earthquakes. One is led to believe that the Turkish nuclear program, which ignores the dangers to the inhabitants and ecosystems of the country and the entire region, serves as a front for a strategy adopted by the political-military authorities of Turkey to acquire nuclear technology that will allow them to equip themselves with nuclear weapons, insofar as they are seeking to acquire the same reactors, of Canadian origin, that India and Pakistan possess. What actions does the Commission intend to take to prevent any nuclear catastrophe and to oppose the acquisition of nuclear weapons by a country that wishes to join the EU and allocates considerable sums to nuclear programs, even while absorbing Community credits in the form of financial assistance?

In many ways, the treatment inflicted on the original inhabitants of the United States of America violates the most fundamental human rights. The story of the Dineh Indians is significant. With the discovery and—certainly—exploitation of black gold and, later, uranium and oil, every means was used to drive these people from their lands and send them to regions offering few prospects other than poverty, deprivation, and pollution. The region of Arizona that is to become the new territory of the Dineh Indians was affected, in 1979, by the largest nuclear disaster in the United States. Therefore, plans are underway to send the last 4,000 Dineh Indians to these lands. The struggle of these Indians is supported by more than 250 NGOs, and we learned about this situation through the work of the Belgian organization For Mother Earth. It is also significant for American society, which has heard little about it. They are rightly concerned about the wars and genocides taking place in other parts of the world, but they unfairly ignore the genocide taking place in their own country. Today, the Dineh Indians are beginning their final fight for their right to land, their right to dignity and, above all, their right to choose their way of life. However, they are only a few, while their adversary is a very powerful economic force. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I endorse many of the comments made by previous speakers, but I would like to emphasize a few more points. The Dineh people are part of the Navajo Indians of North America. They have faced exclusion and have been struggling to survive for decades. They have been living in appalling conditions for many years. The poverty in which they live forces them to reluctantly give in to the financial and economic pressure exerted by the mining industry. The relocation law introduced in 1974, which aimed to redistribute Navajo reservation lands, authorized the displacement of population groups. These relocations are naturally unacceptable because human rights are violated, both economically and socially and culturally. The Dineh Indians are being moved like pawns and losing in the process not only their history and their essential land—the land of their ancestors—but also any prospects for work and a source of income. The relocation law was pushed through Congress by a group representing the mining industry. Congress never considered where the region's inhabitants should go and what impact this relocation would have on their lives. The population had no say in the matter. This resembles human trafficking. The relocation was carried out, and the Dineh people were moved to a region polluted by uranium. After a dam burst in New Mexico in 1979, releasing 370,000 cubic meters of radioactive water and 1,100 tons of pure uranium, this area is one of the most polluted regions in the world.

Two questions: First, you said you will initiate dialogue with citizens, and I am already starting with 700 trainees at the European Commission. Do you also intend to address citizens via the media, i.e., via television and the Internet? My second question is critical. The European Commission has just submitted a proposal on transparency. If I compare it with the transparency proposal that is working in the Netherlands at legislative level, it is only a pale reflection of it and has attracted much criticism in the Netherlands. My question is therefore the following: how do you intend to steer transparency with regard to the IGC, because the directive we currently have is not a good example of this? Madam Deputy, Minister Maij-Weggen, since we are talking about transparency in relation to the IGC, you know very well how things will be done. Negotiations are starting right now, in fact. The group of representatives is meeting in Brussels, and I will try to join them shortly. The documents will mostly be open documents, working documents. We will not be discussing in front of the media during the negotiation sessions that will take place throughout the year between the ministers and the European Council, but I have committed myself—I cannot do anything else at this stage—to practicing this transparency and to reporting, in the most appropriate forums, on these negotiations and the Commission's point of view. I confirm to you, while thanking you for raising this point with me, that we will use all modern means, television in particular, which will be able to broadcast our public debates in this or that country, or even at European level. We will open an Internet forum and create permanent discussion forums. The Commissioners will undertake to respond quickly to all questions that are asked. We will use all these modern means. But I believe that we must also make the effort to reach out to the people as closely as possible. I would like, in all regions of Europe - perhaps this is still a bit utopian - I would like a Commissioner, when he or she can, a Member of the European Parliament, a Minister, to be able to take part in public debates. I have proof that it is possible. Most of you hold these debates in your constituencies, in your regions. From the slightly more selfish point of view of the Commission, I would like this institution, in the minds of citizens, to have a face, for the men and women who make it up to be able to meet citizens as often as possible. Mr President, I welcome Mr Barnier's commitment to visiting the regions to explain himself and listen to what citizens have to say. I would like to invite him to my own region, Yorkshire, which participates fully in the European single market and is a major beneficiary of European structural funds. He can go there wearing the two hats he wears as Commissioner. I would like to ask him how vigorously the Commission intends to conduct this information campaign?

One of the most important transfers—the Tajo-Segura transfer—has been in operation for many years, almost 30, and is authorized for 658 hm3 per year. The largest amount transferred in a single year was 453, and the transfer average in 20 years is just over 200. We cannot be accused of poor management. And is the Commissioner aware that, of these 263 hm3, 25 hm3 are used for irrigation on the left bank of the Levante, 30 hm3 for supply in the Júcar area, 7 hm3 for supply in the southern Júcar area, and the remainder in the Segura area, divided equally between supply and irrigation? We are not managing our resources badly either. We cannot be prohibited from making transfers if our economy and the development of our territories depend on them. I am not addressing the issue of quality and available technical improvements because I believe we will renegotiate this directive. But look: in this pluralistic Europe, which we are building in the spirit of Community, we must seek pluralistic, not uniform, solutions. I therefore appeal to the common sense of the Commission, the Council, and this Parliament not to standardize the various European countries in their voting on issues where subsidiarity must be enforced. Commissioner: Andalusia is not Lapland. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me first thank the Committee on the Environment, and especially the rapporteur, Ms. Lienemann, for her ambitious and constructive work on this framework directive for water policy. Water is one of our most important natural resources, as numerous speakers have already emphasized. An ambitious and balanced European water policy is an important aspect of sustainable development in Europe. Water is also one of the areas to which I will devote particular attention during my term of office. I am pleased with the spirit of consensus that permeates the amendments tabled by Parliament. Many of these amendments are based on the extremely constructive, informal discussions that took place between Parliament and the Council during the first reading. Most of the amendments proposed by Parliament improve and tighten up the text. The Commission can accept 72 of the 108 amendments in whole, in part, or in principle. A large number of the amendments tabled by Parliament indicate that conciliation will be unavoidable. With a view to these upcoming negotiations, I therefore appeal to Parliament to vote for an ambitious position. First, I would like to outline some of my main arguments. We now have the opportunity to put the commitments made in the context of the OSPAR Convention into practice. Before we consider making these objectives legally binding, we must first consider their political nature, as reflected in some of Parliament's amendments. Regarding water charges, this directive will determine Europe's water policy for the next three decades. It is therefore our duty to ensure, today, that we find the right incentives and drivers for effective fee structures and pricing that contribute to improving our environment in a cost-effective way.

Finally, our resolution clearly establishes that it is essential, in the area of maritime safety, to break out of this infernal spiral of widespread irresponsibility, this pernicious system of mutual paralysis in which States pass the buck to the Union, and the Union to the States, for the greater benefit of the polluter. Let each play its part. Let the Commission, whose American bias has for once not come into play, when it would have been beneficial, define a general framework for maritime safety as soon as possible. This should include minimum age requirements and characteristics for vessels to access Community waters and ports; and a general principle of environmental liability that makes it possible to clarify the responsibilities of the various players, especially shipowners, and to impose harsh sanctions on them. Let the Commission take charge of coordinating information, let it not be afraid to confront the laxity of some large ports or major shipowners, and place the issue of flags of convenience at the heart of the negotiations with Malta and Cyprus. I recall that the Erika was registered in Valletta. However, obviously, States should not be exempted from their own essential responsibility within the Union: the rigor and effectiveness (and therefore the means) of port state control determine the safety of all. We must remain, and will remain, particularly vigilant in the coming months to ensure that the victims, who of course bear no responsibility whatsoever for this catastrophe, are fully compensated by the polluter, and that this time the oil spill truly teaches lessons in maritime safety, so that polluters are definitively dissuaded from risking the lives of our maritime populations. The most effective prevention is to make any potential polluter run the risk of receiving heavy financial penalties. Katiforis report (A5-0017/2000) We agree that fishing is one of the activities most important in promoting respect for the marine environment. However, it is important to bear in mind that many causes contribute to the degradation of marine spaces: pollution from oil tankers and other maritime transport, industrial activity, human pressure on coastal areas, and, of course, uncontrolled fishing. However, it is worth highlighting that small-scale coastal fishing is a good illustration of the possibility of combining fishing activity with sustainable development that is not harmful to the marine environment. We believe it is possible to reconcile a fisheries management policy based on the conservation of the marine environment with the interests of fishing communities. To achieve this, however, it is necessary to take into account, in particular, that there is a correlation between the yield of fishing activity and increased fishing effort. Therefore, measures must be adopted within the scope of the Common Fisheries Policy and adequate financial resources allocated to guarantee the income of those who live exclusively from fishing activity, such as fishermen, particularly in times of cessation or reduction in fishing activity.

Are not thousands of dead and wounded, tens of thousands of refugees enough to justify it? The second country, and I will be very brief on this one, because Mr. Patten knows it very well, is Burma. It is intolerable that we remain silent about Burma. I have the impression that this country is slowly being forgotten. For ten years, an elected president has been under house arrest there. For ten years, parliament has not functioned. Many MPs have been assassinated or fled, and only a small number still reside in Burma.
