Hundreds of thousands of refugees from Burma are in Thailand and India, and yet it seems that this country is no longer being paid attention to. I think that following the upheavals in Indonesia, Burma should also be put back on the agenda. It is still unacceptable that Ms. Aung San Sui Kyi feels completely abandoned, particularly by Europe. My request is that this country also be placed at the top of our priorities. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Commissioner, the economic power of the European Union cannot be the sole determining factor in its assertiveness in the world. What distinguishes us is the systematic reference to human rights, both at home and among those with whom we maintain relations. The European Parliament has been at the center of the promotion and defense of human rights, which seek to overcome the limits of selfishness and "national interests" that are sometimes reflected in the positions of Member States and even other institutions of the European Union. This is why it can be said, for example, that the European Parliament has never forgotten the situation in East Timor, which could have been the worst enemy of a just solution for its people, who have always opposed the Indonesian occupation. This is why we recently opposed the sale of arms to Indonesia, a position that the Council unfortunately ignored. But it is not enough to avoid or put an end to situations of revolting aggression by individuals or institutions against the weakest. The perpetrators of crimes must not go unpunished, whoever they are, wherever they are, in Indonesia, Angola, Cuba, China or Burma, whether they are civilians or military personnel, soldiers, generals or ministers. Justice must be done in Indonesia. Justice must be done in East Timor. President Wahid needs our support to deal with the difficult situation he inherited. It was at the initiative of the EPP that Parliament included a specific reference to East Timor in this resolution at the time. There are those responsible for what happened in this country, some of which I witnessed as a representative of Parliament, and they cannot go unpunished.

I believe, however, that we should do everything possible to limit the transport of dangerous goods as much as possible, in all countries, whether they are transit regions or not. Mr President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Koch, on his magnificent work and his positive collaboration with the Commission in improving the texts, presenting this report and this proposal; ultimately, only one amendment was tabled, which concerns the requirements for the aptitude test for safety advisers for the transport of dangerous goods by road, rail or inland waterway. We believe that the collaboration, the joint work of the two institutions, Parliament and the Commission, is important and that the cooperation that exists with the Committee on Regional Policy, and specifically with the Transport Group, is magnificent. The common position includes practically all the amendments accepted by the Commission, harmonizes the minimum requirements for the examination of safety advisers, and, at second reading, we can accept the proposed date, which is much more realistic than the one initially projected by the Commission, bearing in mind that we have been debating this issue for several years now. Very briefly, I would also like to thank the various Members for their contributions and to say that safety is a priority for the Commission in the area of transport. As Mr Simpson so aptly put it, we must never assume that the process is a done deal, that it has concluded. The process of increasing the margins, the safety guarantees in transport, is a process that must be improved day by day. In this sense, I would also like to touch very briefly on the problems of tunnels, to which Mr Rack and Mr Swoboda referred, and which, in the case of Austria, are undoubtedly a very sensitive issue, which is why efforts must be made to see how to increase their safety. In one of the major accidents that occurred recently, the goods being transported were not dangerous in themselves. Margarine and a few kilos of paint, which normally did not present a risk, caused a real catastrophe. We must therefore study how we can further adjust the requirements to ensure maximum safety. Finally, I would like to say that it is necessary to address the safety of all types of transport. This week, we will hold a debate here to discuss the safety of maritime transport, following the Erika disaster, and we will have to discuss the safety objectives of air transport throughout this year. But I would like to say, ladies and gentlemen, that safety is a priority objective of the Commission. As I will say during the debate on Erika, we are not waiting for a disaster to occur before devoting ourselves body and soul to the security aspect, but we are working on it in the face of these circumstances, which only highlight the urgency of an effective response to this type of problem.

The Commission must be able to refuse new posts if it is not given more staff. The staff system is too rigid: there must be greater rotation of officials, especially at the top of the hierarchy. It must also be much easier to fire inefficient and incompetent officials. I am therefore very pleased that a reform of the disciplinary procedure is being introduced. The bad experiences so far with disciplinary matters show only too well how necessary a reform is. Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I cannot help thinking that this is essentially an Anglo-Netherlandish-Scandinavian debate, judging by the speakers. I find that a little worrying. I hope, like many others, that the state of emergency in the relations between the Commission and Parliament is about to end. We must get out of this logic, in which we do not even have time to put out one fire before we immediately have to rush to put out another one that has broken out elsewhere. As Mr Blak says, we must instead establish a system in which roles are clear. First of all, we need strict regulation, and we need to apply it. Codes of conduct and ethics committees are not enough. We need strict rules that establish, among other things, what can be decentralised, what can be transferred externally and what must be independent. I find it disturbing that in this debate independence is being praised without specifying in relation to what, and with what decision-making rights. In short, we need to have basic administrative regulations for the Union, for its institutions and for relations with the Member States. That is what is missing. We have asked for a European public prosecutor and criminal law, but the Union also needs its own administrative law. It would certainly be a step forward if the Commission were to accept the proposal, put forward by the Ombudsman, for a binding code of conduct for good administration. The Van Hulten report is a step in the right direction, but it is not enough. Secondly, we must also clearly define our powers in the area of auditing. The Court of Auditors has the task of ascertaining whether or not the rules are complied with, but it must not enter into the merits of the appropriateness of a given act. Political assessments are the prerogative of Parliament, which should not go hunting for thieves, because that is OLAF's job. Tell me which national parliament receives, for example, all the preliminary investigation files! At the risk of sounding stubborn, I would like to add that the regulation on the disclosure of documents must be much better than the draft that is circulating on the Internet, because otherwise we will get nowhere in this battle of ours. Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur most sincerely for his work. I am pleased that I can address him in Dutch, as Mr Van den Berg did. Otherwise I would perhaps have felt a little guilty. This report shows a clear improvement, thanks also to the amendments. I am a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and in our committee a rapporteur is always proud to receive 100 amendments, because he knows he has raised an interesting issue.

Böge Report (A5-0023/2000) As a Member of the European Parliament, and above all as a citizen and consumer, I welcome the European Commission's proposal, which represents a further step towards improved food security within the European Union. This proposal has two aspects. On the one hand, it involves amending the 1991 Council Directive on health conditions by abolishing the provisions relating to scrapie in sheep; on the other, it proposes the entry into force of a new regulation laying down the rules for the prevention and control of certain transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSE), or BSE-type diseases, affecting sheep and other animal species. The idea behind these new rules is to create a specific legal basis for combating scrapie in sheep. I am all the more pleased with this result, given that it was one of our most important demands, which we formulated in our BSE follow-up report. Moreover, I consider it essential, for the sake of consistency, that we integrate the existing scrapie legislation, which is limited to trade in sheep and goats, into a single, comprehensive system of new rules on TSEs, covering all animals throughout the European Union and intended to ensure protection against contaminated food and animal feed. This regulation is all the more welcome given that there are still uncertainties regarding scrapie in sheep. Some scientific hypotheses suggest that scrapie could be a precursor to BSE in cattle and thus the origin of the BSE epidemic. Although the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention and control of certain TSEs still needs to be clarified and expanded—particularly with regard to the detection and control of scrapie—it nevertheless represents a significant improvement. This is a pledge to European citizens, who have frequently expressed their concern about European policy in the food sector. Your concerns, which our European Parliament has taken up, have been heard. The debates on the precautionary principle and issues of traceability, responsibility, and transparency have prompted the European Commission to publish a White Paper on food safety. This White Paper sets out a number of ideas and, most notably, proposes the creation of an independent European food authority. All this is part of a European strategy to regain consumer confidence. Now it is up to us, the European leaders, to prove that the internal market and the free movement of goods can be reconciled with food safety! Cederschiöld report (A5-0008/2000) Mr President, I voted in favor of this recommendation to revise copyright law because I consider it to be one of the most important areas of activity for the European Parliament. In my view, the product of intellectual creation is far more important than the finished constructions, the physical products that we can undoubtedly see and touch, while the mind and science produce results that, although they cannot be touched, are nevertheless of inestimable value. We, as the European Community, should therefore support them far more vigorously, not only through patent protection, but by encouraging and supporting scientists, those who, using their knowledge, do everything they can to offer future generations far more than we have had in the past. We are fundamentally opposed to the European Community concluding copyright treaties on behalf of the Member States.

Consistency, uniformity, and universal standards of good quality in a decentralized system of financial control are ensured by a range of measures. One is to ensure high-quality training; another is to ensure that no Directorate-General can take over responsibility for financial control unless and until the audit service is absolutely convinced of the robustness of that system. Another measure is the establishment of a central financial service, as honourable Members will see from the White Paper, to ensure that these standards are implemented and supervised. And there is also the theoretical and practical approach to an effective and independent internal audit service. In a parliamentary reply of this type, I will not go into all the details, but I am sure that upon examination, Mrs. Theato will be able to see that the details of the White Paper give us strong assurances. It will also be demonstrated that we have taken into account the representations in this House, and especially in the Committee on Budgetary Control, which is significant with regard to the use of ex ante visas in the Directorates-General. The ex ante system can be used if it is considered, in a Directorate-General, that it is an important and effective means of improving financial control. Naturally, there are several requirements within the Commission that depend on the number and nature of the financial transactions carried out by each Directorate-General. The White Paper takes this into account too, but when there is a desire or a clear need to use such a system, it must certainly be possible to use it. Lastly, the transition. I share Mrs Theato's reservations about the so-called "soft legal standard." We have already had this discussion, and she knows that I distinguish between different forms of codes that can have a very positive effect and which can ultimately be transformed into what we might call a "hard legal standard." But in this matter, there is no room, in my opinion, for the "soft legal standard," and that is why, in the transition period, there will be full adherence to the current Financial Regulation until this law is changed through a proper democratic process in this House and the Council. The White Paper fully guarantees this and contains provisions for doing so. In addition, however, and this is very important because this is a transition period, there will be training, advice, support, guarantees, and the new head of the audit unit will take full office on 1 May. With all this and a number of other guarantees, I think we can be as confident as possible that the system will be completely safe even during the transition period. I must make two further points because this is a key issue at the heart of the reform. My first observation is that citizens believe - for reasons I understand very well - that this transition carries risks of either irresponsibility or inertia.

This will determine who is prepared to vote for the legally dubious retroactive nature of the measure, which would be costly for future car buyers and represent a devastating blow to the European automotive industry. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to briefly address the economic consequences of this directive and express my support for the amendments tabled by my colleague Bernd Lange, as they have the advantage—and I would like to emphasize this point in particular—of reconciling environmental requirements with economic necessity. The Council's common position stated that vehicle manufacturers must bear all or most of the costs of take-back and recycling. However, as Mr Lange so aptly pointed out, this solution would place European manufacturers at a severe disadvantage. Coming from a car-making country, I can tell you that it would be impossible to retroactively impose on car manufacturers the full financial responsibility for all their brand's vehicles currently in use, in other words, the cost of 80% of the European vehicle fleet. This solution is unacceptable, because these manufacturers have not had the opportunity to incorporate the environmental requirements we now impose on them into their manufacturing processes and their cost price. The common position puts European car manufacturers in a less favourable position than newcomers to the European market. Of course, our task here is not to defend this or that national interest or this or that industrial lobby; our task is, far more, to defend Europe's competitiveness on the global market and jobs in the sectors in which we are genuinely competitive. I therefore call on you, ladies and gentlemen, to support the amendments tabled by Bernd Lange, which are also supported by the Group of European Socialists, because they actually reconcile all the concerns at stake - economic interests and environmental requirements - and leave it up to the Member States to decide how they wish to implement these requirements. These amendments provide for the continued existence of the systems already in place in the Member States - some of which work quite well. Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal for a directive on end-of-life vehicles, which we are debating today, aims, on the one hand, to ensure a high level of environmental protection within the Union and, on the other, to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal market. I should just like to mention briefly that historic vehicles and classic cars must, of course, be excluded from the scope of the directive because, I think, we would all agree that they are part of our cultural heritage. However, there are differences of opinion, among other things, on Article 12, that is, the date from which the directive applies. The solution proposed by Parliament, namely 18 months after the directive's entry into force for vehicles first registered after that date, is hardly realistic. The European vehicle fleet includes tens of millions of cars that must be taken back without recycling requirements having been taken into account in their design. The Common Position would be more practical, as it provides for 2006 for vehicles already registered.

I note that the President-in-Office of the Council is prepared to answer everything, but I must ensure that questions are put and answers given at this sitting. Mr Rübig has the floor. Mr President, fourteen Member States have imposed bilateral sanctions on a Member State because a democratically elected government was formed there. Both parties have participated in the government before. To date, no violations of rights have been reported. Are preventive sanctions compatible with the Charter of Human Rights? Would a right of veto for the President-in-Office of the Council over the formation of national governments be compatible with the Charter of Fundamental Rights? Is the call for violent demonstrations compatible with the Charter of Fundamental Rights? Mr President-in-Office, as President-in-Office of the Council, I cannot give you an answer for the simple reason that the statement by the Portuguese Prime Minister was made on behalf of fourteen Heads of State or Government of the Member States of the European Union at bilateral level and not as President of the European Union. I would like to say, however, that the complex of preventive measures implemented by these Member States of the European Union at a strictly bilateral level includes steps which, I would say, are politically preventive at the diplomatic level. We consider them entirely justified and consider that they meet the demands of what would be appropriate in the face of the actions of a party and of representatives of a party who, it seems to us, as participants in a European Union government, offer no guarantees that they can fulfill the Union's objectives. I do not wish to dwell on this issue on behalf of the Presidency of the European Union, because this concerns an intervention by my government, undertaken at the request of and in cooperation with fourteen Member States, and not as the Presidency of the European Union. Mr President, I have the honor of being part of the group drafting the Charter, and I will therefore not ask the Council to speculate on the content of the Charter or to provide information on whether the Charter should be programmatic or legally binding. I would like to know what will happen to the draft charter drawn up by the working group. Will the Council consider this draft a document that it must accept in its current form, or will it reserve the right to amend it as it sees fit? Will the Council simply approve or reject this document, or will it have the right to redraft the draft charter? The answer is neither yes nor no. I do not know, Mr President; that will depend on the decision taken at Council level. Question No 8 (H-0042/00): Subject: The granting of export credit guarantees and their role in the construction of the Ilisu Dam in Turkey. At the G8 meeting in Cologne, the OECD was called upon to prepare the establishment of common standards for the granting of export credits. These credits can be used to distort competition or to support questionable projects. Will the EU take a leading role in establishing common standards? The need for this was demonstrated recently by the British Government's announcement that it intended to grant an export credit to a company involved in the construction of the Ilisu Dam in Turkey.

I therefore believe, as Amendment No 10 expresses, that today's debate should lead us to call for a rapid suspension of this policy of sanctions. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we did not have to wait for the end of the conflict in Kosovo to realise that, after several wars in the territory of the former Yugoslavia with their negative consequences for the stability of the Balkan area, a comprehensive and lasting strategy for the whole region would be necessary in order to guarantee peace and stability in south-eastern Europe. This strategy, outlined in the Stability Pact approved on 10 June 1999 in Cologne, takes into account the region of south-eastern Europe in its entirety, while recognising the differences and disparities in development of the various countries which are part of it. The European Union's contribution under the Stability Pact, the so-called "Stabilization and Association Process", is the development of the regional concept developed by the European Community in 1996 for the five countries of the region - Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Albania - the most significant aspect of which was to establish political and economic conditions to facilitate the implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement, which should thus contribute to the stability of the region. An important contribution to the stability of the Balkans consists in establishing relations between the European Union and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia on a completely new basis, with a view to the full integration of that country into the European Union through the mechanism provided for by the Stabilization and Association Process. The necessary prerequisite is that the countries concerned are prepared to accept a certain number of conditions. We believe that a strong political signal should be sent to these countries that one day they can be ours, while obviously respecting their sovereignty. Without any illusions, the mandate we are giving the Commission today can constitute, once agreement is reached, the first decisive step towards peace and stability in a region so troubled, whose peoples have already shown that they can legitimately aspire to be part of our area of freedom and development. We cannot add further suffering to that endured under the Soviet yoke and to the price they later had to pay when forced to become part of the Communist bloc. As far as we know, from a political and economic point of view, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is now in a position to establish new contractual relations with the European Union, going even beyond the cooperation agreement in force since 1 June 1998 which aims, in practice, to respect the acquis communautaire, especially in key areas of the internal market. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia will certainly have to make great efforts, but, given the political and economic reforms already introduced under the Cooperation Agreement and the adoption of transitional periods in certain areas, this country will be able to meet the conditions for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement. Sharing the view that the development of the region is also a factor of internal stability, confirming the negotiating mandate as proposed to us and underlining that this is a bilateral agreement with the European Union, we agree with the rapporteur when he notes that this is the first concrete application of an integrated and long-term strategy for South-Eastern Europe and that the main question is how the Balkans will be structured in the future in order to ensure peace and stability.

All of these elements must be applied cumulatively. It is also important to bear in mind that there is a wide range of measures that can be adopted when using the precautionary principle. For example, a research program, outreach campaigns, recommendations, etc. Recourse to the precautionary principle, therefore, does not automatically imply a prohibition. This communication is not intended to be the final word on this matter; however, it is the first time that the Commission has made a structured presentation of the principle and its operational application. By setting out in detail how the Commission applies and intends to apply the precautionary principle, we hope to clarify the situation at the Community level and contribute to the debate taking place at the European and international levels. Mr. President, Commissioner, thank you very much for the explanation. I have three brief questions. First: we have had to wait a long time for a Commission opinion on the precautionary principle, and in the past, it was not at all clear whether the Commission spoke with one voice. Is what you have expressed here today also the opinion of your colleague the Commissioner for Industry, your colleague the Commissioner for External Trade, your colleague the Commissioner for Competition, and your colleague the Commissioner for the Internal Market? You will undoubtedly tell me yes, but I would like to know from you whether these gentlemen also know what consequences it has. The next question, Mrs. Wallström: when will you begin to apply this in legislation, for example, in laws on chemicals or in other areas? The last question: will we be able to recognize where this has been applied in the laws? In other words, will there be an additional statement in each proposal stating that the precautionary principle has been examined and that this result has been reached? Thank you very much, Mrs. Roth-Behrendt, for these questions. Naturally, the entire Commission shares them. This is a joint communication drafted by three of us—Mr. Byrne, Mr. Liikanen, and myself—but it was unanimously adopted today by the Commission. It has received the strong support of the other Commissioners and has been submitted for consultation across the various Commission services. We have therefore worked extensively on this document, and I am sure that all Commissioners are familiar with the guidelines and principles set out in this document. Yes, I would like to say that we already use this working method in the case of several difficult issues, such as a new strategy on chemicals, for example. And I am sure that we will also explicitly mention it when we work with this principle. We recently had a case in which the precautionary principle was used when the use of phthalates had to be banned in the manufacture of soft PVC toys, and we naturally apply it in various environmental areas. This principle has been used primarily in the environmental field and also, naturally, in other areas relating to public health.

The other principle of the Council's common position in the draft directive is retroactive. However, it contradicts all generally accepted economic and legal principles to retroactively impose financial responsibility on a manufacturer for its product. It would also retroactively alter the owner's responsibility, because a consumer may have modified the product in various ways over the years. All EU Member States currently have laws regulating the scrapping of cars. These vary from country to country. However, pending the implementation of this EU directive, each member state in the Union should regulate the disposal of end-of-life vehicles as best as possible so that EU regulations do not become retroactive. This does not preclude a financing model through the creation of funds. Mr. President, the environmental and economic importance of this directive is obvious and widely recognized. The common position represents an acceptable compromise, but one that is rather difficult and precarious, so that there is only very limited scope for improvement if the entire directive is not to be jeopardized. I therefore maintain that Parliament must not impose anything, and it would be paradoxical if it did so at the expense of diminishing the environmental impact of the directive. I would point out that car manufacturers have admitted that they can live with the directive; the costs are not excessive: disposing of a car costs less than 1% of the purchase price of a new one. Moreover, the financial liability of manufacturers will not come into force until 2006, when a large proportion of the vehicles currently on the market will no longer be on the market. For the remaining vehicles, provision could be made for a form of cost-sharing, as proposed in Amendments Nos 44 and 45 tabled by Mr Lange, which, in my view, are the only ones consistent with the balance of the common position and with experience in certain countries and therefore deserve to be supported. Mr President, this is an extremely bad directive. First of all, as my colleague Mr Bowis pointed out, it is retroactive in nature, and that is fundamentally wrong. Second, it imposes enormous costs on the European automotive industry, which would have a detrimental impact on competitiveness and the labor market. We in this Parliament constantly talk about the need to stimulate the European labor market, yet we continually adopt measures that result in a reduction in jobs. In my view, the directive is also bad in other respects, which have not been sufficiently addressed in this debate. It is like many European regulations. It is far too prescriptive. It imposes a specific recycling model. The assembly line was, if I am not mistaken, invented by Henry Ford about a hundred years ago, and what we are proposing here is essentially the establishment of an assembly line like the one in the 19th century, only this one runs backwards, dismantling vehicles and disassembling the individual components for recycling. However, we should pause for a moment and consider that the sales prospects for recycled plastic bumpers are extremely uncertain. The plastics industry does not want these products back and cannot afford to take them back. There is already a very successful industry that shreds cars, recovers metals and generates energy by burning the non-metal parts.

As regards the former, the Commission has sent us a series of proposals, contained in two directives and an action plan, which aim to implement the following decision taken by the Heads of Government in Tampere: "to ensure fair treatment of third-country nationals residing legally in the territory of the Member States. A more incisive integration policy should aim to guarantee them rights and obligations similar to those of Union citizens". Precisely the opposite, Mr President, of what we have seen and discovered in recent days in El Ejido: a world of irregularity, exploitation and indecent living conditions, which had already been denounced. I hope for a prompt adoption of the integration measures and I also hope that the governments that wrote such beautiful words in Tampere - including the Spanish Government - will make every effort to implement them. I have less hope for the development of an effective and fair European policy, consistent with the Council's declarations on immigration. The only proposal put forward is the directive on family reunification - a key issue, given that in recent days the media have shown us many single men in El Ejido -, but we do not know whether it has already been accepted by governments. Outside the community, some governments are working to renew their immigration policy. This is also what is happening in my country, but in spite of the government; in fact, the majority party is the only one that does not like the new immigration law. The objective of combating racism and xenophobia, explicitly stated in the Treaties, should also be the objective of all the institutions and all the political leaders of the Union. On 28 February 1998, the European political parties signed the Charter of European political parties for a non-racist society. The Popular Party did so too. This obliges it to behave consistently, but the local leaders of this party are pouring fuel on the fire, boycotting the attempts by other institutions to put it out. The party to which the mayor of El Ejido belongs should act decisively and unequivocally, in accordance with the commitments made in that declaration. Only with great unity, as the Honourable Hernández Mollar said, with responsibility and with firmness, will El Ejido be able to overcome, together with Spain and Europe, those episodes that today cause us deep shame. Mr President, one can only feel disgust and indignation at the scenes of lynching against Moroccan newspaper workers that have taken place in El Ejido. We do not know how much of the responsibility lies with the racist commandos of the extreme right, nor how much is attributable to the ordinary people who were reckless enough to associate with these groups. We would like to reiterate our full solidarity with Moroccan workers who are not only exploited by unscrupulous employers, but also find themselves subjected to attacks of this kind. If among the attackers there are people from the poorest strata of the population, we can only tell them that they are digging their own graves.

And finally, and I'll end with this, the requirement relates to the future powers of the European Parliament in the areas at hand, competition policy and State aid, in the perspective of the Intergovernmental Conference. Our report, as you know, Commissioner, advocates the idea of the codecision procedure being in force for basic State aid legislation. (DE) Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my participation in this debate concerns the Steel Aid Code, that is, public aid granted in Europe in accordance with that Code and supervised by the Commission. In 1998, a total of 27 cases were examined, on which the Commission has prepared its own report. The ECSC Treaty is due to expire very soon. Therefore, the issue that should concern us today is above all the future application of aid to the steel industry. The European Parliament welcomes the decisions outlined by the Commission in its report, including the one concerning the repayment of aid received in a specific case, pursuant to Article 88 of the ECSC Treaty. The Commission's most recent communication, which has not yet been debated in Parliament, also addresses the issue of the competitiveness of the European steel industry. The general prohibition of State aid established in Article 87(1) of the EC Treaty also applies to the ferro-steel industry, just as it does to other sectors. Pursuant to this article, State aid is in principle incompatible with the Common Market. Exceptions are permitted only in precisely defined cases. Pursuant to Article 88, the Commission is obliged to monitor State aid. In 1998, the most important case was the equity injection of €540 million to the Preussag company in Germany. Member States must also notify the Commission in advance of any aid they intend to grant. The rules applicable to the steel industry were established on December 18, 1996. According to these rules, aid may only be granted to the steel industry in certain precisely defined cases. These include aid for research and development, aid for environmental protection, social assistance to encourage the closure of steel plants, and aid for the permanent abandonment of the activity in the case of uncompetitive companies. In addition, there is an exception for Greece, with a maximum limit of €50 million. In recent years, however, there have been obvious problems in the practical application of the Steel Aid Code, which are not fully detailed in the report. From Parliament's point of view, it is important to begin debating consecutive regulations now for the time when the current Steel Aid Code expires. The fundamental principles of this Code should not be watered down. No one wants to open the door to uncontrolled competition based on subsidies in Europe. This would seriously affect the functioning of the internal market, even after the consolidation of the steel industry in recent years. Parliament therefore considers it necessary to amend the Steel Aid Code with regard to the unequal treatment denounced by the industry and for the Commission to submit consecutive regulations to the Council.

Unfortunately, I missed any reference to the corresponding standards. I wonder where you got these standards and values from. I am convinced that the Bible, the Word of God, is the only pure source of demanding standards and genuine values. This insight, which has grown in the tradition of our continent, is a crucial element that deserves due recognition. Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I don't know which to base my decision on—the strategic objectives for 2000-2005 or your speech for 2000-2010? Have you already included your second term in office? But seriously. The enlarging Union needs to be strengthened through streamlining and limitation. First, streamlining. What you say in your program about concentrating on the Commission's core tasks can only be a very first step. The activities of the entire Union must be reduced to the core areas of policy. These are the social and ecological orientation of the market, the safeguarding of the currency, the guarantee of citizens' rights internally, and the representation of common interests externally. It is not just a matter of speaking with one voice in the world, but even more importantly what we want to say with that voice. Secondly, the new buzzword is flexibility. But increasing flexibility can, or threatens to, very quickly lead to intergovernmentalism. We must firmly adhere to linking the member states through joint decision-making bodies. This also applies, incidentally, to the involvement of civil society, which is to be welcomed. But citizens do not need new bodies or institutions, and certainly not a new mixing of responsibilities. (Applause) Transparency is not more access to more paper; rather, transparency for citizens is finally more clarity about who, when, what, and with what authority decides in Brussels and Strasbourg. That is transparency! Thirdly, the European Union cannot and must not expand without limits. Its limits arise not from the question of how many states want to join, but how many it can accommodate. (Applause) If the price for enlargement were the weakening or even the dissolution of the existing Union, then it should not be paid. It would be too high, not just for the Member States that are already there, but also for the states that want to be admitted to this Union. A Union that is merely a geostrategic concept has no future, just as one that is merely a free trade zone has no future. But the Union will remain more than a market and will only receive legitimacy from the peoples of Europe if it sees itself as a community of shared destiny. That is far more than just your new economic and social policy agenda or a new and improved quality of life. Not only the Commission, not only the European Parliament, but also the peoples and states in our European Union will have to find new answers to the question of how and why we want to live and act together. This involves nothing less than reinventing the European Union without destroying the existing one! (Applause) Madam President, in the view of the Liberal, Democrat and Reform Group, the most important task of the Commission and of the Union as a whole is to ensure the successful implementation of enlargement.

At the same time, financial support through the PHARE programme can also be essential. However, the EU's policy in the Balkans is currently fragmented, disorganised and contradictory. There are various types of agreements or relationships - or lack thereof - that lead to the embargo in Yugoslavia and create a fragmented and ineffective approach. The concept of regionalisation for the Balkans, which includes everyone without exclusions and without a spirit of revenge, is missing. Finally, it is necessary and useful for the European Union to intervene in resolving the FYROM name issue, which, unfortunately, is dragging on and could lead to greater tensions. It is also necessary and useful for it to intervene in a more active and time-limited management of the negotiations between the FYROM authorities. The Commission's expressed desire to strengthen relations between the European Union and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and to open up to the latter the prospect of full integration into the Community, seems to us to respond to a priority concern: the construction of a political entity respectful of nations and their sovereignty could no longer postpone sending a signal to these South-Eastern European states, which history, since the end of the Second World War, has not spared. After being crushed by the jackboot of triumphant communism, the region has not finished, since the beginning of the 1990s, paying the price for the collapse of the Soviet system. However, in this difficult context, and more particularly since NATO's military intervention in the Balkans, some of these states, all authentically European, have demonstrated a sense of responsibility which legitimizes their aspirations for integration into the Community. In this respect, the case of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is both exemplary and emblematic. Exemplary because it proves that the Balkan states are not bound by any inevitability and that they are, for those who have the will, already today able to meet the usual requirements of the stabilisation and association agreements required by the European Union. Emblematic because it positively illustrates the Fifteen's plan to see the emergence of a common policy for the five countries of the region (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, FYROM and Albania) which would make economic and political stabilisation a burning and urgent obligation. The UEN group is all the more in agreement with sending this signal to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because it gives due importance to the independence and sovereignty of States: if a satisfactory solution cannot be found in the Balkans without a strong policy of cooperation between the States that compose them, there can be no question of blocking their integration process on the grounds that one of their own is deemed unworthy of such promotion. The Union is fulfilling its role when it seeks, through its cooperation policy, to encourage nations to embrace with it a foundation of common values of which democracy and the freedom of citizens are the cornerstone. It departs from this role when it substitutes itself for the peoples in its choices, or failing that, it reinvents a new form of "sense of History" which only grasps the notion of self-determination of peoples in one direction.

The majority of Members of this Parliament do not want this situation, but we must be careful in our choice of means so that we do not achieve the opposite of what we want. Madam President, dear colleagues, I emphatically reject all declarations, expressions, or feelings of xenophobia or racism. I vigorously defend the good of human rights and the rule of law that are inherent in Europe. But precisely for this reason, I do not agree with the senseless actions initiated by the Presidency (unfortunately, the Portuguese Presidency) on behalf of the other fourteen states, in a truly institutional blunder. This is not the way to combat extremism. It may even be a way to do it a very welcome favor. The flood of confused and hasty measures that have been launched against Austria are throwing everything into disarray without any sense or reason, creating great uncertainty among honest citizens, and harboring dangers that have not been taken into account. There is an insurmountable contradiction between positions that have been adopted in the name of upholding human rights and the rule of law, but which at the same time violate the fundamental rights of Austrians and disregard the crucial rules of the rule of law, in this case the norms of the Treaties. What do we ultimately want to achieve by embarking on an intergovernmental conference? A Europe of 27 or a Europe of 14, or an even smaller Europe? We are for Europe, for a Europe that honors all the steps that have brought us here, for a Europe that respects the Treaties and the law, for a Europe in which Austria is needed. This must be said! Madam President, I am pleased and proud that this Parliament has overwhelmingly condemned the formation of a coalition government in Austria that includes Mr. Haider's Freedom Party. Mr. Haider has demonstrated in word and deed over the past few years that he deserves to be excluded from normal democratic discourse. Not only did he express admiration for Adolf Hitler, praise the Waffen-SS, and refuse to condemn a terrorist bombing that killed four Roma, he is also a member of the regional government of Carinthia. He has led the way in abolishing measures in favor of Austria's Slovene minority and in support of immigrants. Some have said we have no right to interfere in Austrian politics. They are wrong. The European treaties oblige us to protect fundamental rights. Some have said we must accept the results of democratic elections. But democratic elections do not make democrats out of those who threaten democracy. The same argument against Germany in the 1930s led to the tragedy of the Holocaust, which claimed the lives of six million Jews. But we should not condemn Mr. Haider for his ambition. He will not change on this point. The real culprits are Austria's Christian Democrats, who have become Judas and resurrected a threat to Europe that we thought had perished in Berlin in 1945.

- (DE) Mr President, I would like to preface my supplementary question with a Tibetan greeting wishing happiness and peace. In Tibet, it is not just human rights and the environment that are at stake, but also a unique cultural heritage that can convey important values to us Europeans too, including calm, slowness and empathy, compassion as the Dalai Lama calls it. The question that arises is what the Commission can do to support His Holiness the Dalai Lama and his proposal for a peaceful solution to the Tibetan question. I would point out that inaction means the death of Tibetan culture and the end of the Tibetan people. I have great sympathy for what the honourable Member has said about the cultural heritage and the Buddhist tradition. Like the honourable Member, I have read the Dalai Lama's autobiography, which is an extremely moving account, not only of his responsibility in Tibet and towards Tibet, but also of his spiritual convictions. The Commission, like others, has called for a dialogue. The Dalai Lama has made it clear that what he wants is a peaceful dialogue. I would have liked the Chinese authorities to have reacted consistently and positively to the Dalai Lama's openness. During President Clinton's visit to China, or at least around that time, the President of the People's Republic of China gave the impression that dialogue was on the agenda. This would not only be beneficial for Tibet and all those who believe in peace and stability in Asia, but it would also be very much to the advantage of the Government of the People's Republic of China if it responded to the attempts to open up a dialogue. Question No 31, by the Honourable Member (H-0795/99): Subject: Rejection by the Commission of the Code of Good Administrative Behaviour in the European Union According to press reports, the Commission has rejected the proposal of the European Ombudsman, Mr Jacob Söderman, to grant citizens the right to good administrative behaviour in the European Union. The Commission itself has approved the idea of a Code of Good Administrative Behaviour, but has not accepted the specific proposal for it, limiting itself to providing a series of additional indications for a better service. Can the Commission say whether these reports are true, what the reason is for this behaviour and how it explains the difference which has arisen between the statements and the facts on the reform of the Community administration; whether it considers that the incident is compatible with the five-point programme agreed between the European Parliament and the Commission in September, and whether it is in a position to present a detailed proposal for a Code of Good Administrative Behaviour on which Parliament can also take a position? Commissioner Patten may speak on behalf of the Commission. The press reports to which the Honourable Member refers seem to me to be misleading and inaccurate. In November 1999, the Commission approved at first reading a Code of Good Administrative Behaviour to be included in its Rules of Procedure. The Commission is currently consulting staff representatives on this document, a process which should be concluded in the coming weeks, at the end of which the Commission will approve the Code at second reading.

Mr Pietrasanta explained why we support some aspects of the Commission's proposal, particularly those relating to the development of a vaccine and the introduction of compensation for farmers who are forced to cull their fish. However, we are not at all happy about the prospect of changing the culling policy. It has been said that Norway has done a better job than we have in controlling the outbreak of infectious salmon anaemia and that the proposed changes will bring us more in line with the Norwegian approach; however, there are more than a few differences between the Norwegian policy and the EU policy, which will also apply in my home country of Ireland in the unfortunate event that similar cases arise. There are other differences between the two policies in relation to disease inspections, periods of inactivity, restrictions on the movement of fish and contaminated material, and so on. Before we rush to copy the Norwegian culling policy, we need to test these methods to see whether they can reduce the scale of the disaster. BSE has been discussed in the past and the Greens have been calling for this disease to be addressed for many years. If this had been done, a great many farmers could have been saved and a great deal of money would have been saved at Community level. It is also a matter of protecting the environment, farmers and public health. I would like to thank Mrs Hudghton for her excellent report on BSE and for supporting the measures proposed by the Commission, and I would also like to thank all the speakers for taking part in the debate on this issue. The Commission's proposal is designed to ensure a more pragmatic approach to controlling a disease which has the potential to cause major losses to salmon farms. However, this approach must not in any way affect our aim of reducing and, if possible, eliminating the disease and cannot be adopted if the proposal contains a threat to public health. Furthermore, the environmental implications must be taken seriously. Experts say that BSE is considered a non-pathogenic disease for humans and mammals. Since its appearance in 1984, no case of infection in humans or mammals has been reported. The virus affects cold-blooded animals and does not reproduce at temperatures above 25oC. Even if it were present in fish intended for human consumption, it would be inactivated once ingested. In any case, infected fish cannot be used for food and, as an extra precaution, I confirm this to the Scientific Committee. A number of important issues have been raised in the debate in relation to our strategy for controlling the disease, including compensation. I deeply regret the losses suffered by the Scottish salmon industry. As you know, from 15 January 2000, Member States can promote the eradication of the disease in aquaculture with the help of a new financial instrument for the provision of fisheries information. The Commission services are currently preparing implementing rules which will enable this instrument to be put into practice. Council Decision 90/424 constitutes another Community instrument for financial support in the event of disease outbreaks.

It is an indisputable fact that the turnout in the European elections was low. To improve it, we can act now and fight crime in Europe with a Europe-wide approach. - (DE) Mr President, I too would like to thank the rapporteur. The Theato report can help to restore trust in the European institutions, and I think we all recognise the urgency of this, if we think about the results and the low turnout in the last European elections. Every year the same problem arises: the Court of Auditors in its report denounces various frauds committed by the Member States, but for now the European institutions have too few instruments to act and ensure that a concrete response is taken to remedy this state of affairs. So every year this procedure leads to a loss of trust. In my opinion, the report and the proposal by Mrs Theato could help to reverse this trend, by making it clear that the European institutions are ensuring that European financial resources are used wisely and without fraud. A first step has already been taken with the transformation of UCLAF into OLAF, an independent institution. Now it is important to take the second step, creating a clear legal framework within which OLAF can act. For this reason we need a European Public Prosecutor's Office that also provides precise legal guarantees to those under investigation. I must add with regret that my group will not approve this report unanimously, and I hope that some of my colleagues will review their position during the debate. Unfortunately, there are still strong fears that a European institution will be created here at the expense of subsidiarity. I will do my part to ensure that Mrs Theato's report meets with broader consensus. Mr President, we are essentially in favour of the resolution that has been submitted to us, even if we believe that this can only be an invitation from Parliament to the Council to ensure, through a change in the Treaties, effective criminal protection of the Union's financial interests. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor and the creation of criminal figures common to all countries of the Union is undoubtedly a good idea, but I believe it is impossible to think of implementing it without first having introduced a Union judicial system. We are talking, in fact, about criminal law, the field in which the resistance of the national States to communitarization is and will always be strong. It is unthinkable, in fact, that substantive and procedural legal norms can be created for a single sector, such as the protection of financial interests, without first having created a European judicial system. It is sufficient to read the precise and exhaustive motivations of the Theato report to realize how many and what problems still need to be solved. This idea should be encouraged, however, and there is no doubt that it is precisely during this attempt to protect financial interests that the need for a Community corpus juris to be introduced into the Treaties will be realized. On behalf of myself and my group, I also express the hope that the financial soul of the Union will lead the way in creating a European judicial system that respects the rights and guarantees of citizens, that is to say, a judicial system that raises the guarantees that, unfortunately, in many States are not at an acceptable level.

Mrs Rothe, let me put it this way: I am convinced that the current context has improved for reaching such agreements. I have no commitments at the moment. Nor do I expect them until we have started direct discussions. They will come later. The context has changed because the Helsinki decisions made a great many things finally possible and, above all, because the participants have completely changed their political strategy. I have always believed that the old position, according to which Cyprus would only join once the political conflict was resolved, contained a weakness, in that it did not convincingly stimulate the Turkish Cypriot community to really get involved, because, faced with this strategy, the Turkish community had nothing to do but sit back and wait. The question of Cyprus's accession would then not have been raised. Now the Turkish community must seriously reckon with the risk that Cyprus will actually join the European Union, with the growing prospects for well-being and security that this brings for the Greek community, while the already much less prosperous Turkish community continues to be left behind. I am therefore firmly convinced that the motivation to link the peace process to the settlement of the conflict has increased enormously since Helsinki. That was also the underlying idea. After a few weeks, it is still too early, Madam, to already make an assessment, but I certainly have no reason to assume that the new course of action will fail. There is no reason for that. There is still no reason to say that we will succeed, but I can truly say that the conditions for progress have improved considerably. Lastly, the Cyprus question obviously plays a role in the discussions with Turkey. During my meeting with the Turkish Foreign Minister a few weeks ago in Brussels, I naturally urged Turkey to adopt a positive and constructive attitude towards this issue. I have the following reservation, however: we cannot be 100% certain – at least I am not – that all it takes is to press a button in Ankara for everything to work in Cyprus! It has not been that simple for a long time. Instead, we must strive, in our discussions with both communities, to bring them to an agreement. This is what we are doing; we have funds and programs for this. I must make it clear to you that I need the Financial Regulation submitted for your decision before we can begin. The Financial Regulation is the legal framework for addressing the priorities set out in the partnerships with Cyprus and Malta. I cannot begin anything without it; I lack the legal basis. If the so-called lack of coherence has anything to do with this specific point, I would like to say that this Regulation is a legal framework and nothing else.

I would like to know whether the document the Commission has just presented provides for such a clause. Thank you very much, Inger Schörling. These are two important questions. I am pleased to have the opportunity to clarify them. No, we should not start with a cost-benefit analysis, but rather based on an assessment of what we know, what science can teach us, and how we should consider it in relation to the risks we believe exist for the environment or for human and animal health. On the other hand, once we have decided to take a certain measure, we must then choose one that is cost-effective, so as not to adopt measures that are completely absurd from the point of view of effectiveness. We should therefore not start with a cost-benefit analysis. The other question concerns the reversal of the burden of proof. It is absolutely true that we need to apply this in certain cases. I took the case of the chemicals strategy as a good example of an area where it is necessary. It is indeed this area, but one could say that this communication on the precautionary principle is horizontal; it concerns all specific policy areas. That is why it is not specifically a question of a reversal of the burden of proof in this regard or what the burden of proof will look like, but rather of political decision-making and the basis for it. However, it is absolutely true that we must, for example, when it comes to chemicals, ensure that we achieve a reversal of the burden of proof. Mr President, I believe that, in order to work, the precautionary principle should be quite radical, otherwise we constantly get lost in the tortuous twists and turns of interpretation. Let us take an example: it has been shown that an anticryptogamic product causes blind children; it is therefore teratogenic. Very well, it's an anticryptogamic, an antimycotic. It was a British laboratory that proved the teratogenic effect, perhaps the only one, however, to have carried out tests. Well, in my opinion, since the threat is so serious for health, the precautionary principle requires that the product be immediately withdrawn from the market, as New Zealand has done, for example. I would therefore like to ask the following question: when human health is at stake, or when serious effects on human health are possible, should we analyse the costs and benefits? A blind child is too high a price in my opinion; no profit could compensate for it. I would like to know whether, ultimately, the precautionary principle as you understand it, Commissioner, would presuppose in this case that the product be withdrawn from sale until other laboratories provide proof to the contrary. Mr President, I am the first to hope that we can use the precautionary principle in such a way that it is considered radical in terms of protecting human health and the environment.

The White Paper and the report come at the beginning of a necessary process of reflection, discussion and reform, which is not yet concluded, as various questions remain to be clarified, both from us, from the judges, from the Member States and above all from the small and medium-sized enterprises concerned. Competition policy must continue to be managed centrally and cannot be renationalised, because that would be risky for the internal market and for Europe's position in the world economy, but must be Europeanised within the framework of subsidiarity. I therefore also welcome the fact that responsibility begins with the individual, without however the Commission shirking its own. Practical experience - with only nine cases rejected and 94 per 100 of the cases submitted to the Commission resolved not formally, but through non-public and legally non-binding administrative letters, or simply because the deadlines expired - clearly shows that the Commission's activity has been affected by the temporal, personal and financial constraints of the era of globalisation and the enlargement of the European Union. In conclusion, I would like to announce my expectations for the reform: fair competition and a level playing field, legal certainty for all companies, uniform application of competition policy, procedural simplification based on the one-stop-shop principle, coordination of national competition authorities, which I consider autonomous, a close relationship between national authorities and judges and the Commission, as well as a clear allocation of competences between national authorities and judges when it comes to applying European competition law; I expect the Commission to focus on the essentials in fulfilling its mandate as the ultimate guardian of European competition policies. I am curious to see what form the ongoing extensive discussions will take when they lead to the first legislative proposal. The Commission's report confirms that, with the exception of Germany, state aid to companies is increasing and this worries the Commission, not only from the point of view of the conditions of competition. As far as we are concerned, we are looking at it from the perspective of the interests of the working classes. Society does not benefit from these huge transfers of public funds to private companies. Just look at the automotive sector, where state subsidies and other aid increased by 24 percent during the reporting period. For what purpose? Not to maintain employment, because all these companies have cut jobs and laid off workers. Not to improve working conditions, because by making fewer workers produce more, working conditions get worse. Did these companies need state aid to survive? No, the companies in the automotive sector have been raking in colossal profits for years. State aid not only has perverse effects, because, as Mr Jonckheer's report acknowledges, it leads to the hunt for subsidies through transfers of activities from one country to another, but it is also unacceptable, because it uses public money to enrich a handful of private shareholders. The fact that the richest are favoured everywhere with state money has led to the deterioration of the welfare state, the abandonment of public services and the closure of hospitals throughout Europe.

Faced with this changing global framework, we must find our appropriate position. Fortunately, evaluations of EC aid provide us with an important means of improving what we are doing and, hopefully, also of overcoming the challenges I have just mentioned. To address the results of the evaluations in more detail, I would like to mention the following problems: objections to Community policy are too numerous and too vague, and this negatively affects coherence. This situation is due to the complexity of our own structures, but also to some very clear inconsistencies between sectoral policies and the interests of the Member States. The Commission has an aid system that is too complex and too fragmented in terms of instruments, procedures, and institutional mechanisms. Policies are often determined more by the instruments available than by their intended objectives and clearly defined priorities. Human resources are too scarce in relation to the volume of aid we are supposed to manage. On average, there are 2.9 people in the Commission managing $10 million in aid, compared to 4.3 at the World Bank and between four and nine in the main Member States. This poses a real problem: there are many very different financial instruments, each with its own characteristics and, in particular, a number of different budget headings. It is difficult to reconcile this situation with the needs of an effective management system. In order to confront and resolve these problems, the Community must engage in effective dialogue with the Member States and Parliament. It is absolutely essential that we address the issue of coherence realistically and pragmatically, which means holding the debate within the appropriate institutional framework, that is, in the Council and Parliament. The lack of concerted action among the 15 Member States and between them and the Community also requires study. If we focus Community development policy on internationally agreed strategies and objectives, we will pave the way for better complementarity with the Member States. This largely coincides with what Minister Amado has just said. When we talk about policies today, we are referring to a process of convergence. This already provides part of the solution. We are in the midst of formulating new regulatory guidelines and need to identify priority areas for Community action. Everything is becoming increasingly complicated. The same applies to development cooperation. No single donor is capable of addressing the full range of issues, from macroeconomic issues to the regulatory framework or from sectoral policies to a variety of new interrelated themes such as gender, the environment, good governance, and institutional reforms. It is important to find flexible mechanisms that can accommodate a division of labor according to the expertise and capacity of the various donors in each developing country. This must be done at the Member State level and should lead us to the formulation of sectoral policies for Community action. That is what we want to achieve. In order to identify priority areas for EC support, the specific characteristics of the Community in relation to the Member States and international institutions must be taken into account.

This current economic context is very much on our minds, as the objective of these restructurings is to rationalize corporate management. While it is economically plausible to make structural changes to become more competitive and gain market share, this analysis can be condemnable when it is carried out at the request of financiers, often shareholders, with the sole, unspeakable goal of increasing the financial values of these companies, and thus be able to increase the profits they will thereby obtain. In this sense, the various recent announcements mentioned by my colleagues, both in the case of Michelin and Goodyear, are symptomatic. Rationalized management, as well as improved results—in my opinion, and in order of priority—must be at the service of the company and, therefore, of the workers, and then, eventually, the resulting financial consequences. Now, today we are witnessing a phenomenon of concentration, corporate regrouping, and offshoring, with the consequences we are familiar with—both in terms of product quality and specifically on the social level—from the perspective of unemployment, more difficult working conditions, and greater flexibility, consequences that are dramatic on the human level, especially for the family unit. There is, therefore, a danger that the planet will become two-headed: on the one hand, poor countries, suppliers of labor, and on the other, rich countries, suppliers of capital. Shouldn't Europe be the barrier to maintaining a certain balance between greater profitability and greater well-being? We must not forget that what basically makes a company function and achieve good results is human capital. To conclude, I would remind you that the third letter of the name of the EDD Group, to which I belong, stands for "difference." Europe has a duty to make its voice heard as an alternative to unplanned restructuring and with a view to "all benefits," the voice of difference in this uniform wave of restructuring. Mr. President, last month in the United Kingdom, in a region bordering my own, the Michelin Group announced a significant number of layoffs at its Stoke-on-Trent plant due to the company's restructuring and increased global competition in the global tire market. I, like all Members here, regret this job loss. Similarly, I regret the announcement made by Goodyear that prompted this resolution. But I certainly doubt that a European Employment Council would have been able to change this corporate decision. This House is very good at issuing resolutions and legislating, and sometimes, in this institution, we forget that Europe cannot survive alone. We need multinational companies that base their businesses on our continent. In the few months I've been here, it's been astonishing to me that while we all talk about incentivizing businesses to grow in the EU, virtually every resolution we pass encourages them to leave. At our last plenary session in Brussels, we voted on the End-of-Life Vehicles Directive and tried to make its rules retroactive, adding huge costs for European car manufacturers they couldn't have foreseen. Two days later, Toyota, which employs several thousand people in my region, announced that this directive would not only increase the cost of cars but could also lead to redundancies at its Derbyshire plant.

And this is because this agenda is limited to just three topics that concern only two of the European Union's institutional bodies in a fragmentary way. I will not repeat them, since they are well known to all. This observation is justified on the one hand by the constant demand that is being made, sometimes very intensely, by European citizens, and on the other hand by the enormous dimensions of this great undertaking that the European Union has already embarked upon, that of enlargement. With this in mind, the new Intergovernmental Conference cannot fail to include on its agenda topics whose treatment would guarantee the regular functioning of all, and not just some, of the European Union's institutions. It should also include topics that affect daily life and are therefore obvious to the European citizen. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament, in numerous discussions and in light of the numerous reports produced to date, has openly expressed its support for the convening of the Intergovernmental Conference. At the same time, however, I request that topics be included that improve and complement the reform, and I repeat, of all the institutional bodies. But topics that directly affect European citizens should also be added. Such as health, energy, culture, transport, even tourism. On the one hand, the question of whether the agenda will be extended is still under discussion. And at this point, I would really like to emphasize the political leadership of the Portuguese Presidency, which has repeatedly committed itself before the European Parliament to making every effort in this direction. On the other hand, the question of increasing the number of topics for discussion in no way diminishes the importance that each member country attaches to the Intergovernmental Conference because the institutional framework on the basis of which Europe will evolve in the future is the fundamental principle of European integration and is therefore of supreme national importance for each member country of the Union. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, having taken note of this information, I ask the House to approve the opinion that Mr Leinen and I have presented to you, so that the work of the Intergovernmental Conference can begin on 14 February and so that our two representatives at it, Mr Brok and Mr Tsatsos, can, in accordance with the opinion of the European Parliament, undertake the difficult work that awaits them. The same applies to the European Commission, and I would like once again to thank Commissioner Barnier for his contacts with the European Parliament and for the very constructive proposals he has presented to us. Mr President, the Group of the European People's Party is not satisfied with the outcome of the Helsinki European Council. We felt that the agenda was relatively inadequate, as we were basing our decision on the logic of the Treaty and, more specifically, on the Protocol on the institutions of the Union. In Helsinki, governments agreed that as long as the Union consisted of fewer than 21 states, a de minimis reform would suffice, but that with more members, a thorough reform would be required.

Ladies and gentlemen, this decade can be, I would even say must be, the decade of Europe. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, dear colleagues, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats welcomes this debate and we are pleased that the Commission has tabled a document to prepare for it. We also welcome the conclusions we find in this document. Furthermore, we broadly welcome the speech just delivered by the President of the Commission, Mr Prodi. The conclusions of the document indicate that the five-year term of the Prodi Commission will be a period of major changes. Europe will progress in its integration and the Union will, at the same time, embark on a phase of enlargement that will ultimately lead to the reunification of our continent. This is ambitious, one might even say prophetic. Mr President of the Commission, we hope that it succeeds in this way. But we also say that the present is the foundation of the future and that we can only shape the future if we prove ourselves in the present. I say this seriously and I say it with concern! I am thus addressing the ongoing discussion on the conflicts that are currently dividing the European Union. We, the European Union, are a Community! We belong together, even when there are problems. This is the time not to isolate but to unite and complete, together, this work of uniting Europe! Mr President of the Commission, in recent weeks, you have represented and defended the European Parliament on several occasions. You have considered yourself the guardian of the Treaties – which is your role. We expressly express our respect, our gratitude and our support for this, including for the letter to the Federal Chancellor of the Republic of Austria to which you referred. (Applause) Mr President of the Commission, we agree with you on the objectives: in the 21st century, we want a strong, capable, and democratic Europe. A Europe that defends its values of human dignity, democracy, and the rule of law, both internally and externally, and at the same time looks after its interests in the world with dignity, patience, and convincing confidence. The message of Europe, of the European Union, to the world cannot be arrogance or even European nationalism; no; it must rather be one of cooperation, partnership, and peaceful development. Globalization therefore represents for us the opportunity to organize this ever-closer world under the banner of peaceful competition and solidarity. Seen from this perspective, globalization presents more opportunities than dangers, more rapprochements than divisions, more mutual enrichment than limitation. But we also know that we can only meet these major challenges of globalization together, as Europeans. Globalization is not only an economic process but also a cultural process. We therefore say that we want a partnership in the world; we do not want – as some predict – a clash of cultures, a clash of civilizations; rather, we want partnership, encounter, exchange and peace.

In this area, too, we see that the structure of the economy differs from one country to another, and that the paths by which the current level has been reached differ. Therefore, it is not good to implement a single policy, which would likely be full of exceptions and adaptations. It would mean that Member States would be deprived of certain tasks that are theirs for no apparent reason, and that the Brussels bureaucracy would intervene unnecessarily. It is preferable for Member States to adopt measures to promote employment themselves. They obviously understand more about this matter than the Commission. Hence my reluctance to adopt Community measures to promote employment, even when it concerns the tourism sector. It would truly upset us if, despite everything, Parliament were to attempt to achieve this objective through unofficial means by extending its powers. Mr. President, as you will understand, we cannot endorse the resolution before us in its current version. First of all, I would like to thank Mr. Viceconte for all the work he has done on this report. This is a very extensive report. We warmly welcome this report, just as we welcome the original report on which it was based, the report of the High Level Group established by the European Commission. I trust that the European Commission will not forget this. Having established it, I hope that the European Commission will effectively make use of it and therefore not allow it to languish in the corridors and become covered in dust. Tourism is essentially made up of small businesses and is therefore a very fertile area for job creation. As has already been said in this debate, three million potential jobs over the next ten years is something worth fighting for.
