Europe can no longer refuse the recognition—both in economic terms and in terms of political action—that the fastest-growing sector of its economy deserves for its economic and social position. We need a more dynamic vision based on tourism's contribution to job creation. We must recognize a sector that is predominantly related to cross-border activities and therefore deserves a European policy with a stimulating, innovative, and active approach to sustainable business development. I know the Commissioner is very interested in IT. He has convinced me of this. But his IT and tourism portfolios, in fact, fit very well together. There are several reasons why tourism is an ideal breeding ground for integrating job creation strategies. Let's look at some of these reasons. The importance of tourism to the economy and its growth potential is evident. Various sectors of the population are employed by the tourism industry, especially the most vulnerable groups such as young people, women, and unskilled workers. I am not saying that it is not necessary to improve skills within the sector—of course we must—but let's consolidate jobs first. The availability of unskilled, temporary, and seasonal labor is very important in some economic areas of the Community.

I will limit myself to mentioning just a few: our ability to combine development policy with trade policy and to achieve synergies between aid and economic cooperation; our neutrality and defense of the Community's supreme interests; the fact that we represent a critical mass and are able to tackle relatively large challenges compared to what each of our Member States can normally do. I will not forget our presence on the ground: fundamentally, it seems to me that the greatest value we represent is the fact that, being a successful regional cooperation enterprise, we can be seen as a neutral and desired partner for this experiment worldwide; that is something no one, apart from us, can claim. It is essential that Community policy be more effective and that we develop a more cooperative strategic framework. This is what the Commission must address, and to this end, it will have to prepare a proposal in the form of a general policy statement in the coming months. We will launch a broad and open consultation process to gather the views of all the various stakeholders. I consider this process almost as important as its content, and we will allocate all our resources to active participation and invite everyone to participate with us. At the same time, we have also embarked on the process of improving coherence and of clarifying and openly highlighting the real or imagined problems we encounter in this regard. This will be an ongoing process that I view as a kind of permanent quality control effort, and I invite Parliament to participate in this ongoing effort to improve the coherence of what we are doing. Mr. President, first of all, I thank Mr. Amado, as well as Mr. Nielson, for their words. I am also pleased that Mr. Amado referred to the EDF. The problem is not here, in this Parliament, nor in the Commission; the Council must take the necessary steps to establish the EDF budget, therefore, this sermon really must be delivered in the Council. Mr. President, I also thank Mr. Nielson. The new Lomé Convention has been referred to at length, but this is certainly not the subject of this morning's meeting. We wanted to talk about coherence. That is the issue. Since the early 1990s, the European Parliament, the Commission, and the Council of Ministers have recognized that European policy coherence is not operating adequately, especially in the area of development policy and other Union policies. Attention has been called for this problem on several occasions: in 1992, 1995, and 1997. All the examples are included in the resolution before us. I myself have raised questions on this issue for years. The obligation for coherence was even introduced into the Amsterdam Treaty in 1997. Furthermore, in 1998 it was agreed that the European Commission would prepare an annual report reflecting the progress made. But what have we seen since then? Fine words, even today, but no report. It's too ridiculous to explain.

To put it bluntly, a hierarchy of oppression has been created. And as long as citizens are not equal before the law, this inequality will lead to discrimination and the erosion of human rights. In our enlargement process within the EU, we have rightly placed great emphasis on human rights and the protection of minorities. We must not waver from this commitment. But we must also look in the mirror and recognize our own imperfections. Yes, conventions have been signed, but action is needed. I would recommend continuous audits of human rights practices, constant vigilance, not only outside our borders but also within them. That is why I would welcome an annual report from all Member States, requiring them to report any complaints against them and the action taken, because what happens in one Member State affects us all. What happens in another part of the world affects us all. The case of Pinochet in Chile is as important as that of Haider in Austria. Human rights and civil liberties are inextricably linked. Human rights do not exist in isolation; they are linked to our development policies, our economic policies, our internal affairs policies; in fact, they are at the very heart of our democratic functions. I will repeat what Mr. Patten said: we must engage, we must inform, educate, and thereby effect real and lasting change. Mr. President, "Europe represents ideals, values, and principles. We must honor the intellectual history of Europe. We must rehabilitate the values that unite it. Intellectual life began in Europe and spread throughout the world. We must live with our conscience." These were the words of Czech President Vaclav Havel in this Chamber three hours ago. In a particularly edifying speech, marked by human knowledge, wisdom, historical knowledge, and an understanding of Europe's intellectual and Christian heritage, he indicated the sources of inspiration from which our work in favor of human dignity and human rights must draw. We must be grateful that our Europe has heads of state of the caliber of Mr. Vaclav Havel. I would like to raise two subjects. First, that of civil society. Mr. Vaclav Havel said earlier that the communist regimes of Eastern Europe were methodically destroying civil society: popular movements, churches, and independent trade unions. This is what is happening in China, with the Falun Gong movement and the Catholic and Protestant churches. It is also what is happening to Tibetan Lamaism. We must never forget to defend civil society. I would also like to raise the issue of the death penalty. The EU, like my own country, Sweden, is founded on a worldview centered on human equality and the unique and inviolable value of human existence. Based on this principle, humankind must always be given a chance to reconsider its actions. This must be said to the US government, the Russian government, and the Chinese government. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office, Mr Commissioner, in my view, the approach of the EU Member States in Geneva should aim to prioritize the situations in Kosovo, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Sierra Leone, and China.

Hence, this first agreement with Macedonia is crucial, as it will be the model. I am convinced that the other four countries are asking themselves: what will happen? What will the European Union do with Macedonia? Will it do the same with us? Since this model constitutes the first step forward, it is so important. Macedonia is also a model in another sense. The rapporteur has already pointed this out very clearly: the issue of interethnic relations. There is no need for us to reproduce it here in an overly idealistic way. During the presidential elections, it seemed that it was not working at all that well, but compared to the rest of the region, we could talk about the Macedonian model. Much would be gained if we managed to export this model, together with the Macedonians, to the rest of the Western Balkans. This prototype also applies to regional cooperation. I fully agree with the rapporteur that a balance must be struck between, on the one hand, promoting regional cooperation and, on the other, maintaining openness to Bulgaria and Greece, and not closing it off. Mr. President, Commissioner, if we take this first step well, much will have been gained. If we botch it, much more will have been lost. Mr. President, let me state first of all that I have no problem approving, in principle, this well-prepared report. I simply want to draw attention to an issue that, in my opinion, has not been addressed in the report and which constitutes a serious problem for Macedonia and for the effectiveness of the financial and other aid provided by the EU. I am speaking of the sanctions against Yugoslavia. So that there are no misunderstandings: I, too, believe it necessary to decisively address the problem of the Milosevic regime. But, first of all, these sanctions have a broad and negative impact on many neighboring states, including Macedonia, which find themselves in a very difficult economic situation. Secondly, in a politically counterproductive manner, the entire Yugoslav people are being held responsible for Milosevic and his clique, thereby violating human rights. Consequently, I believe that, as stated in Amendment No. 10, the issue under discussion today should lead us to quickly end this policy of sanctions. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, it was not necessary to end the Kosovo conflict to conclude that, after several wars in the territory of the former Yugoslavia, with their countless negative consequences for the stability of the Balkan region, a comprehensive and lasting strategy for the entire region would be necessary to guarantee peace and stability in Southeastern Europe. This strategy, which took shape in the Stability Pact, adopted on June 10, 1999, in Cologne, considers the region of Southeastern Europe as a whole, but at the same time recognizes the diversity and uneven development of the various countries that comprise it. The European Union's contribution to the Stability Pact, embodied in the so-called "Stabilization and Association Process," represents the development of the regional vision that the European Community developed in 1996 for the five countries of the region—Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and Albania—and whose most important aspect consisted of establishing political and economic conditions designed to support the implementation of the Dayton Peace Agreement, which should contribute to regional stability.

Within the Member States, regional disparities are dangerously widening. One need only look at the data in the sixth periodic report to realise the strong acceleration in regional inequalities over the last ten years. The attention paid to the colossal problems of the Union's island areas is laughable, if not non-existent, precisely when the lack of infrastructure in terms of transport, communications and energy condemns these areas to desolation. This state of affairs is not only the fault of regional policy, but also of the economic and social policies implemented by the Union in general. Large sections of the population condemn these policies outright as dangerous and repressive. Unfortunately, the new guidelines do not mark any change of direction and there is no indication that, with their application, anything will ever change. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to speak briefly to highlight two points in the reports under consideration, which are of essential strategic importance in our vision of the Union. The first concerns the essential and central importance that we continue to attribute to economic and social cohesion. We are therefore concerned about the rumours that the importance of this objective is diminishing in the Commission's considerations. We continue to believe that economic and social cohesion is a central objective of the Union. The second is that I agree with the comments made by a colleague on the issue of the islands, and I would like to draw attention to the outermost regions. In future, we would like to see greater courage in the treatment of issues concerning the outermost regions, such as, in the case of my country, the Azores and Madeira. I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Commission to explain to us the reasons for the delay in its report on the outermost regions, which Parliament has been waiting for a long time now. Mr President, I would first of all like to thank the rapporteur, also for her willingness to take on board our suggestions in the report. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the guidelines are intended to provide guidance to Member States in achieving the reform objectives in the context of programming. However, contrary to the claim to provide guidance, the Commission's recommendations on this matter are rather a catalogue of possible measures in the various policy areas. Their original purpose would be to indicate the direction and priorities. I share the rapporteur's view that the Commission document unfortunately contains insufficient recommendations to Member States to proceed with administrative simplification. I also support the calls to focus attention in the negotiations with Member States on areas such as promoting a favourable environment for labour-intensive small and medium-sized enterprises, by setting clear objectives for the creation of alternative sources of financing, including venture capital and private financing programmes, support services for new businesses as well as for new information technologies and investment in innovative sectors. I particularly support an amendment tabled by my political group to point 10, aimed at ensuring adequate participation by the private sector in the planning and implementation of projects.

Fourthly, given the merits of LIFE, Parliament has included in its annual budget increasing amounts earmarked for this programme, so that the approval of the proposal supported by the Council and the Commission would represent an unacceptable reversal of the trend. However, our concerns are not limited to the financial aspect. Climate change and water management policy are a source of great concern for European citizens and have already received much attention from this House. We therefore believe it is essential to approve our amendments Nos 5 and 6, which aim to define the concepts of sustainable management of groundwater and surface water and reduction of greenhouse gases, by including them among the objectives of LIFE-Environment. I would like to conclude by congratulating Mrs Lienemann on her report and take this opportunity to inform her that, although our preference for the accompaniment of LIFE is for an advisory committee - as has been clearly demonstrated in the Committee on the Environment - we will vote in favour of her amendments on comitology because we do not wish to contribute to the implementation of the Council's proposal, which we frankly consider to be worse. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, LIFE is the most important financial instrument, the only financial instrument, in fact, that the European Union has which is exclusively intended for the environment. It must therefore absolutely meet our ambitions, ambitions which undoubtedly come at a price. The key point in the discussion with the Council will, of course, be the allocation for LIFE III. The common position provides for a package of EUR 613 million for the period 2000-2004, which is insufficient. The Liberal Group is in favour of increasing this sum to EUR 850 million. We will therefore support Mrs Lienemann's amendment, which points out that the funds earmarked for LIFE were not increased at the time of the last enlargement of the Union, not to mention the new round of candidate countries. The funds we are requesting do not represent a mountain of wasteful expenditure. On the contrary, they do not yet reach the levels needed to cover actual needs. A drop in the ocean, I would say, compared to Europe's structural policies. The environment definitely plays a secondary role in the European budget, although it is first and foremost an investment, an investment in natural resources, certainly, but also in employment, since it has been shown that an active environmental policy can create new jobs, as is evident from the great success achieved by LIFE: a success for NGOs, businesses, local authorities, third countries. Almost a third of the 8,500 applications received met the required conditions and around 1,300 projects received co-financing between 1992 and 1998. This is a success which, according to the precise will of this Parliament, must last over time. This is why we support Amendment No 14 which defines, in broad terms, the fourth phase of the LIFE project. When it comes to the environment, investment and ambition are realities that must exist in the long term. The future of the new generations is at stake. ? (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, I may repeat what my colleagues have already said, but I think it is necessary to reiterate once again, for the benefit of the Council, what we think of LIFE.

I believe there is agreement that waste and residues from ships should be disposed of in ports. The logical consequence, it could not be otherwise, is the following: the number one rule for maintaining clean seas is that disposal on the high seas must no longer be profitable. That is the point, and we have discussed it in this Parliament and achieved a majority. In January, Commissioner, we had a very comprehensive debate with you on the consequences of the Erika accident and on that occasion we once again reviewed all the key points for ensuring safe ships and clean seas. The directive on port facilities for waste and cargo residues that we are currently examining also concerns precisely what can be done to make the seas cleaner. Just one figure, for information: every year, 70,000 cubic metres of waste are illegally dumped in the North Sea alone and, conversely, only a maximum of 5 to 10 percent of ships follow the correct procedure, that is, dispose of their waste in ports. Such a scandal is also unacceptable to the Council. The Council also maintains that all ports must have adequate collection facilities and must equip themselves with them. The conflict is basically only about the question of cost coverage. In the first reading, Parliament, by a large majority, maintained that the ships themselves must contribute at least 90 percent. This is the difference compared to the Council, which instead proposes an unspecified contribution, but such a contribution could also be equivalent to half a euro, which is clearly too little in this case: in this way nothing would change, there would be no economic pressure on the ships to adopt a consistent line of conduct. A flat-rate contribution to disposal is necessary for all ships, regardless of the actual use of the disposal facilities, i.e. the economic incentive to discharge into the sea must disappear. In the Baltic Sea this has been possible - some colleagues have already mentioned it - thanks to the HELMKOM Convention, which provides for a no special fee system. If it worked there, it should also work in other European seas, because it is not just the environment that is at stake, but clean water, tourism, and, crucially, alongside environmental considerations, neutrality in terms of competition is also at stake. The conditions applicable to ships in ports must be the same for everyone and only if these conditions are set together by Parliament, the Commission and the Council can neutrality of the conditions of competition for ports and ships be re-established. I believe that the credibility of the Union and especially of Parliament is also at stake. People are fed up with the hypocrisy of Europe and of Ministers in the face of disasters, as we saw in the case of the Erika. When oil spills onto the coasts, politicians and Ministers appear and get busy, each with their own bucket to clean the beaches, but when, after two weeks, a tough directive is on the agenda, the fine words of the day before are already forgotten.

The nature of the Union has not changed. From the beginning, it has acted in function of a few dozen large financial and industrial groups and their lobbies. But the Prodi Commission now wants to transform the European Union in order to nominate it to lead the world alongside the United States, while entering into competition and conflict with them. This new imperial policy presupposes the reorganisation of European and national institutions, the consolidation of state power, greater competition, the establishment of a European army and the redistribution of financial resources. That we still dare to invoke the defence of a "European social model" is a shameful lie because the more the European Union fights the United States, the more it becomes a clone of it. We will therefore vote against these objectives because we oppose this policy both in the Chamber and on the streets. The drafting of a European Charter of Fundamental Rights would be the only glimmer of light within such a policy, but once again nothing has been planned so that the people of Europe can take charge of it by deciding democratically. We abstained from voting on the resolution for the following reasons. Firstly, the resolution does not clearly enough denounce the rather vague nature of the priorities and commitments formulated in the Commission's programme. Secondly, we believe that, in the context of defining priorities for the next five years, the main issue that the Commission must address concerns its role in the framework of interinstitutional relations within the European Union - and in this context neither the programme nor the resolution are mentioned. In our view, there is a factor that will condition the role that the Commission will play in the near future and that is linked to the return of the European political initiative by the governments of the Member States following the failure of the Santer Commission. We believe that this aspect is extremely positive, as it allows the national parliaments, on which the governments depend, to continue to claim the indispensability of their democratic mandate in the construction of Europe. The truth is that the European Parliament continues to fail to win the trust and even the interest of public opinion, which insists on not thinking in European terms, as demonstrated by the abstention rate recorded during the last elections. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the mechanisms used for cooperation between the governments of the Member States, making them more coherent, transparent and democratic. We welcome President Prodi's commitment to improving the public image of the Commission and agree that the Commission should consult with Parliament and the Council. However, we believe that the highest priority should be given to reforming the mechanisms of government cooperation, in particular through the creation of a Council of Ministers for Europe which, in concert with each other and in coordination with the other European institutions, will enable the political decisions taken within the European Councils to be transformed into concrete actions. Corrie report (A5-0032/2000) Madam President, the work of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly in 1999 was characterised by growing concern about the sustainability of the cooperation model resulting from the Lomé agreements. As early as 1994, with an initial resolution to which our colleague, Dominique Souchet, had contributed largely, the Joint Assembly had expressed alarm at the foreseeable consequences of the Uruguay Round, which had contradicted the very principle of Community preference, which is essential to cooperation.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, I too would like to thank the rapporteur for this excellent report. I also fully agree with his conclusions, in which he proposes, in particular, increasing the number of assistants to the judges at the Court of First Instance and providing the Court of First Instance with its own translation service. I truly consider this necessary because, during the Legal Affairs Committee's visit to Luxembourg, we heard that, quite inevitably—as if by God's grace—the Court of Justice takes precedence over the Court of First Instance when using the joint translation service, and that, as a result, important cases often cannot be adequately dealt with at the Court of First Instance. However, I also believe that the reforms must go further than what we are about to adopt here. I think, for example, that it is worth considering, in areas where quasi-judicial panels already make decisions in advance—I'm just citing Alicante, or as is also planned for European civil service law—making the Court of First Instance the final instance, if necessary, and establishing final jurisdiction there. I also see that we probably need to do something about the European Commission's tendency to renationalize competition decisions and shift them back to the national level. It seems necessary to think about this, because these cases will then no longer end up in the Court of First Instance, but rather as references to the Court of Justice. We should consider how to deal with this situation. Perhaps there should also be the possibility of making references in competition cases to the specialized chamber of the Court of First Instance. Furthermore, we must also consider whether it is right—and we have just had cases in which Members of Parliament or political groups have sued the European Parliament—that the Court of First Instance has jurisdiction over such matters, even though they actually involve constitutional issues, and these matters logically belong before the Court of Justice rather than the Court of First Instance. One final point: I also believe that OLAF requires constitutional oversight. At the moment, OLAF exists in a vacuum and can do whatever it wants. I believe it is necessary for a court to oversee OLAF. The only court that could reasonably do that would be the Court of First Instance. That, too, would be a stimulus for the further reform process. Mr President, first of all, I would like to join with those who have congratulated the rapporteur on his work. The European Union is a system based on the law. It must therefore have courts that can give effect to that law. Moreover, if the courts are unable to deal with the cases brought before them adequately and expeditiously, what happens is what Mrs de Palacio Vallelersundi has already mentioned: that is, as we all know, justice delayed becomes justice denied. The report on the Court of Justice shows that this is precisely what is happening, and it shows what steps can be taken now to contain the problem. But, as Mr Marinho has already said, more needs to be done, and that will have to wait until the Intergovernmental Conference.

If we had had such provisions, I repeat, the disaster would probably not have occurred. This is why we believe that we must review the applicable texts and, in particular, the 1992 protocol which exempted charterers, in this case the oil tanker charterer, from all liability. However, if the charterer is exempt, he is of course less involved in the controls carried out by the oil companies. We must therefore review the regulations and I thank you, Madam Commissioner, for pointing out all the current inadequacies of the European provisions. Furthermore, we must above all, as you said, strengthen controls: those of the flag State, those of the classification societies. You told us that RINA was an Italian classification register recognized by the Commission. Under what conditions is this recognition carried out? What are the guarantees of reliability? You will send a mission. We await the results with great interest. We must also strengthen controls by maritime authorities, controls in European ports. It should be remembered that there is a Paris Memorandum, which requires a minimum level of control: a quarter of the boats calling at European ports must be inspected by the maritime authorities of the country concerned. This obligation is not respected, either in France or in many other European countries. Why? What conclusions has the Commission already drawn from this or is preparing to draw from it? It also seems to me necessary to strengthen the control imposed on the charterer, in this case the oil tanker. If its financial liability is involved, this control will undoubtedly be more stringent. Finally, coordination between maritime authorities is necessary to achieve a sort of European system similar to the coast guards that monitor the coasts of the United States. I would first like to thank my colleagues responsible for the environment in my group for addressing this particular problem jointly with their team responsible for transport. This disaster affects both transport and the environment and is not confined to one area. We find ourselves once again in Parliament debating yet another maritime disaster. I could list the disasters that have struck this sector during my ten years in Parliament, but I only have three minutes. There is no doubt that it is high time that the Member States, but also that paper tiger known as the International Maritime Organization, and, last but not least, the oil companies and tanker owners, assume their responsibility by acting to put an end to these ecological and human tragedies that have been repeated over the years. How many Erikas do we have to endure before the established authorities provide us with a proper system of port state control that is effective throughout the European Union, not just in certain regions? How much more pollution do we have to endure before the industry builds tankers with separate tanks and double hulls?

The world's major financial centers would be far from devoting the proceeds of the Tobin tax to finance humanitarian interventions and UN benefits, without being able to derive any tangible benefit. As regards the function of the Tobin tax to prevent future currency crises, it must be remembered that it would not eliminate the causes of overvaluation. That is why, as Mr Karas stated, this task should be entrusted to the political bodies responsible for the overvaluation of certain currencies compared to their real value; also, subject to the adoption of control measures for currency imports and exports. Otherwise, this would not be feasible. Despite the apparent wisdom of the Tobin tax, it hides several obstacles and, personally, I think it will be difficult to find an agreement on its introduction. It must be remembered that today money is above all information and that in the future the world economy will increasingly be based on it and on human resources. That is why the uninterrupted flow of capital between the world's financial centers is not just a mere speculative character without any connection to the real economy. If, with fiscal instruments such as the Tobin tax, we try to influence this feedback mechanism, which gives operators freedom of choice, the economic consequences would be extremely high and higher than the revenues that could be obtained from the tax. Having said that, I repeat what Mr Karas rightly said, namely that our group is firmly opposed to the adoption of the Tobin tax. Madam President, I speak as a supporter of a tax on speculative capital movements across currency borders. It seems to me completely self-evident that action is necessary. Over the past 30 years, the volume of currency transactions has increased 83-fold: firstly, the total global reserves of all central banks barely amount to the value of the operations carried out in a single day on the foreign exchange market; secondly, the annual global exchange of real goods and services amounts to just three and a half days out of 350 of foreign exchange market activity, that is to say, 1 percent of capital movements are for the exchange of goods and services and 99 percent are for speculation. The size, unpredictability and irrationality of global foreign exchange markets have made it increasingly difficult to manage national and regional economies. Computer-controlled trading programs have turned a blip into an avalanche, sweeping away jobs, lives and businesses around the world. The only arguments against it are: first, the tax would undermine the efficiency of the foreign exchange market - a bit fanciful in light of the speculative follies we have seen destroying jobs around the world, in East Asia, Europe and Latin America. Chirac has described those engaged in such operations as the AIDS virus of the world economy. It is necessary to throw some sand into the cogs of currency speculators, stockbrokers and financial operators. Obviously this cannot be done in one country or within one currency zone, but it could be done internationally with global cooperation.

On the contrary, we are extremely encouraged by the extremely positive and constructive reactions expressed during the consultation period last month, and I therefore think that, despite a possible slight delay in the design and implementation of the reforms, the understanding and commitment generated by the consultations we have diligently conducted will contribute to vigorous implementation. I would like to see matters carried out more quickly, but it is better to do things according to the rules. Madam President, we admire Mr Kinnock's thinking and realism. While he paints a picture of a well-functioning, efficient administration, he also points out the difficulties that will arise, which are already foreseeable. Mr Prodi has said that the Commission will delegate certain tasks. The political priorities must therefore already have been set out. But surely it is more important to first set out what you intend to do before getting rid of certain things. I can imagine that otherwise you will antagonize a lot of people. Enlargement – I mean the enlargement of the Union – is one of the major challenges. I would also like to point out that maintaining peace will require far greater effort to engage many more people in this area. We must move away from the rather bureaucratic approach currently practised, for example, in all development cooperation and resolutely pursue cooperation for peace. Can Mr Kinnock say what he expects from the Council and from Parliament regarding the timing of such priorities? I thank Mrs Maes not only for her comments just made, but above all for the tireless commitment to change that she has shown since becoming a Member of Parliament. I would like to assure her that we have no motivation whatsoever to delegate matters; we are concentrating on key tasks and priorities, not in order to avoid any obligations, but in order to provide an absolute guarantee that we can fully meet the most important obligations placed on us. Among those obligations, surely—and here I agree with Mrs Maes—is the preparation of an effective, smooth, and trouble-free enlargement that works for the mutual benefit of both the people of the acceding countries and the citizens of the existing Union. Being able to guarantee that we can play this absolutely vital role as a catalyst for enlargement with the greatest possible effectiveness is one of the reasons for ensuring that we focus most conscientiously and rigorously on our priorities. I would also say to her that the mechanisms for strategic planning and programming made possible by activity-based management, which we intend to introduce, may seem terribly dry and devoid of any shred of idealism. However, having been raised to believe that the triumph of ideals must be organized, I may be in a position to ask her to understand and support our mechanistic views on this, as they concern the great and central concerns of the Union and its enlargement. I hope that, given the level of cooperation and partnership we have with the Council and Parliament on all matters relating to this policy, we will not only be able to implement policy developments promptly and as effectively as possible, but will also be able to act in a coordinated manner at the right time, thereby achieving the greatest possible benefit for the Union.

We also need stricter criteria for interpreting monitoring results. The most important parts of Parliament's Amendments 25 and 73 can therefore be accepted in principle. The new definition contained in Amendment 72, however, is too strict and cannot be applied for this purpose. I would propose that Amendment 92 be incorporated into a broader solution. Amendment 71 does not take into account seasonal variations and annual changes in groundwater levels. The proposal therefore cannot be accepted. The Commission considers it unrealistic and unnecessary to establish standards that ensure that the least intensive water purification treatment possible is sufficient to produce quality drinking water from surface water. Instead, we prefer an annex to the measures required under Article 11 to encourage action in this area. The status required under this proposal must ensure that the requirements for good-quality surface water are met. This part of Amendment 41 cannot therefore be accepted. The Commission appreciates Parliament's efforts to ensure that the so-called combined approach is given a central role. Amendments 22 and 47 define this approach and its scope, which the Commission can support in principle. To achieve the greatest possible legal clarity and proportionality, however, we want to reword Amendment 47 and add a de minimis provision. Water transfers are already included in the controls, but an explicit mention makes the text clearer. This part of Amendments 49 and 87 can therefore be accepted. It is not necessary, however, to set the condition that all measures to steer demand be taken. The proposal already establishes that water abstraction must be carried out in accordance with the ecological use of a river basin. These parts of Amendments 49 and 87 cannot therefore be accepted. The Commission approves Amendment 76, which implies that radioactive substances are explicitly included in the proposal. In summary, the Commission can adopt 72 amendments in full, in part or in principle. The following amendments cannot be accepted: 1, 4, 9, 11, 13, 15, 19, 23, 39, 40, 51, 59, 61, 64, 66, 70, 71, 71, 72, 74, 77, 79, 81, 83, 87, 89, 90, 91, 95, 97, 98, 100, 101, 103, 106, 107. In conclusion, I would like to say that I welcome Parliament's efforts to resolve the issues on which the Council's opinion differs. Significant progress has been made and the constructive tone of the discussions creates an excellent working climate for future negotiations. The number of obstacles remains the same, but I am confident that at the pace of legislative work, we will achieve our common goals of developing a water policy of which we can be proud. A firm decision by Parliament will go a long way towards establishing an ambitious European water policy for the next three decades. I would like to hear the Commissioner's views on Amendment 45.

Now, and I would like to say this to the Netherlands, the negotiations on this took place at an earlier stage. The result is a 30% increase, so we are not exactly unhappy about it. It is always better, of course, and I will always advocate for more money to be made available, and somewhat more quickly. However, I think this program offers good opportunities for many programs. I would like to emphasize that culture is not only supported by this fund. Culture falls not only under the Culture portfolio, but also in many other areas. Considerable financial resources are also available for culture in the Structural Funds. We must keep this in mind and take it into account accordingly. Fortunately, I sit on the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, and will therefore ensure that this is properly discussed. We have decided to agree that the budget is sufficient, because if it is not approved, it will be to the detriment of the citizens. I have always supported the rapporteur in this. Nevertheless, I believe it is necessary, and he has repeatedly said so, that the co-decision procedure be amended at the upcoming Intergovernmental Conference; then there would be no need for the principle of unanimity. We are entirely positive about the numerous improvements that have been made. No more megaprojects, space for cultural networks, great attention to promoting reading, translation, and translation services, which are certainly important for the smaller language areas. I would like to warmly congratulate the rapporteur and Ms. Reding on "Culture 2000." All that remains for me to say is: now we get to work. Madam President, all the previous speakers have actually already taken the words right out of my mouth. I believe there is agreement among the political groups in the European Parliament and the members of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Media and Sport, of which I am a member. It is with a heavy heart that I, too, will vote for the joint text for a decision by the Council and the European Parliament. Not because our delegation and our rapporteur and chairman, Mr Gargani, have not done an excellent job – they have put in a great deal of effort – nor because I completely disagree with Commissioner Reding's views on some points – within the margin available to her, I think she has demonstrated a truly positive attitude – but because of the Council's negative and unacceptable position. It's a disgrace! This amount, EUR 167 million for such a long period, is a disgrace for the European Union! It's truly sad: we are now forced to literally humiliate theatre groups, young musicians, forward-looking art projects and writers – yes, to humiliate them by praising one and rejecting thirty. This naturally awakens in these people the feeling that Europe is alien, dismissive, even hostile to the efforts of cultural creativity, which the European Union should actually be committed to – after all, our path is not just the euro, not just enlargement, not just geostrategic considerations. Our task is to lead the cause of European unification to cultural prosperity.

The Commission communication we are examining today, which formed the basis for the discussion on which the Council took its decision in November, provides a balanced account of how we can improve the discussion and broaden our understanding of the challenges that Member States will face in social policy in the coming years, as populations age and the consequences of enlargement take hold. Many Member States already have serious social problems and are faced with significant social expenditure in their public budgets. If reforms are not introduced, we risk eroding the economic basis on which social policy is built; a strong and competitive economy is the best guarantee of good-quality social security. We are therefore pleased that these issues are on the agenda. The term "social convergence" is often used in discussions on social policy coordination within the EU. As Liberal MEPs, we accept the notion of social convergence, insofar as it involves the EU establishing broad common objectives that states must strive to achieve through their national social policy. It is therefore not a question of harmonization, but rather of common objectives. It is a fact that EU Member States organize their social policy in different ways. We have different traditions, different cultures, and despite many similarities, the nature and extent of social problems also diverge considerably from country to country. This is why it is important to emphasize the fact that social policy is a national prerogative. National policy is obviously subject to a number of common frameworks, whether these are the minimum social rights established by the Treaty, the guarantee of free movement of workers without them risking losing their social rights, the coordination of economies, and economic cooperation. Coordination and cooperation are elements that must be added, but convergence must be based on objectives and not on means. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Jan Andersson, for his very constructive efforts to try to reconcile different points of view and thus secure support for his report. I will vote for his report, but there are a few points that are not entirely to my liking. I do not agree with the point that calls for the Commission to intervene against so-called unfair competition between social and tax systems if such intervention is intended to hinder innovation, development and improvement in the efficiency of our social systems or if it is intended to prevent a reduction in the excessively high tax burden in many Member States. I am sceptical about the detailed regulation that might result from Commission intervention regarding the extent and quality of childcare and care arrangements for the elderly, and I am sceptical about the value of a common poverty line.

The question is of great importance, and I would like to know, since one could speak of a baby scam, whether the Commissioner will ensure that these funds are not withheld from the Andalusians, so that the funds that the European Union pays to Andalusia on the basis of the population register take into account these 400,000 children that Aznar does not count when it comes to providing them with schools and services. Madam President, please remember – please do not take this as an admonition – that we are dealing with strictly Community issues. I know that these are very important issues in Spain and that there are different points of view... I tell the Commissioner that Aznar is the President of the Spanish Government. Would you answer the question? As I have noticed, Madam President, you have a strong voice, and I hope it was loud enough to have been heard in Madrid. However, I realize that your words were not directed at me directly. I have replied to you. It is important to me that Structural Funds, and in particular Objective 1, go where they are needed. There are criteria that must be observed, and we know roughly what each European region should or could receive. Regardless of this—and this is no excuse, but I must comply with the general Structural Funds Regulation—I must speak with the national authorities of each country and with the government of each country. It is their responsibility to distribute the funds as objectively and fairly as possible. I need to find out first, so I told you I couldn't reply today. Since I have no information, I wrote to the Minister for Economic Affairs and Finance on December 14. I am growing impatient that I have not yet received a reply, but I will send it to you as soon as I have it. I regret that the Commissioner has once again found himself drawn into a nitpicking and, in this case, passionate debate. In Spain—let me remind you all—we are in the middle of an election campaign, with 25 days to go until the elections. It is a consolation for the Commissioner that these elections are taking place in 25 days, so he will probably not be asked questions of this kind again. But I think it is important to say that Andalusia will receive 50% more under the Community framework and that Spain also holds a record for the use of the Structural Funds, which means that distribution is based strictly on the implementing rules and is managed in a decentralized manner through the regional development plans and the various Community support frameworks. In conclusion, I would like to put a specific question to the Commissioner: does he consider it necessary to amend the implementing rules for the Structural Funds, or does he consider the current distribution criteria acceptable? I find this debate very informative. I realize that there is a dimension that is not exclusively Community in nature. Regardless of this, we must accept that elections are constantly being held in all the countries of the Union.

Now we are being asked to provide the legal basis for such surveillance. It is the combination of these two documents that should be examined. The requirements stipulate that the authorities have access to the facilities of all service providers, i.e., telephones, mobile phones, the internet, etc., and the current, extremely lax draft leaves the door wide open to abuse. I would also like to ask: Given that the requirements stipulate that the police have access to all service providers without exception, does that include the internal parliamentary service? Are we adopting regulations that allow the police access to our own systems for particularly base motives? Moreover, there is no threshold for serious offenses in this proposal. This leaves it wide open to abuse. Regarding the reversal of the burden of proof, something that is recognized in fundamental international law, the presumption of innocence is essential. This is not guaranteed. Neither the preamble nor the main text adequately addresses the right of defense, a fundamental principle of fundamental international rights. This issue must be taken extremely seriously. We are deeply concerned about the direction we are taking here without proper public debate in national parliaments or elsewhere, and without the involvement of civil liberties organizations from across Europe, which are extremely concerned about these developments. Mr President, I am neither a member of the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, nor am I a lawyer, but like almost all my colleagues, I understand how necessary it is for there to be, alongside the single economic area in Europe, a corresponding single area of justice, freedom, and security. In this respect, issues of judicial cooperation in criminal matters are certainly important. What have I realized after reading the relevant texts? I have realized that, given all the contradictions, the conflicting views on what Europe actually is, given the diversity of judicial systems, which not only creates confusion and inefficiency but also leads to downright dangerous situations, it is risky to rely on Council regulations. This applies, for example, to Article 18, to which many colleagues have referred, and according to which any country – any large country, if you like – any country that has the technical means, can monitor the telecommunications traffic of another country without the consent of the country concerned being required. I think the Legal Affairs Committee and the rapporteur, Mr Di Pietro, have presented an extremely interesting report. Unfortunately, Mr Di Pietro was unable to explain the well-founded reasons for this in his five minutes – and thus very short – speaking time. In any case, it is about protecting the rights of countries, defendants, and citizens. In my opinion, this approach should be pursued in more depth and with greater courage. However, I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that in this context, criminal law sets confusing, even schizophrenic, framework conditions. A young person, a student or pupil, who smokes a hashish cigarette is subjected to educational intervention in one country; in another, he is treated as a criminal and placed in the "schools of crime," namely reformatories and prisons.

Perhaps it is no coincidence that there is no one here among the conservatives, because what has been defended here as market freedom has nothing to do with the worthy principles of the social market economy that have brought us so much well-being in Western Europe over the past decades. For if we continue the path—and this is the ideology—of declaring financial markets sacrosanct and even asserting that any intervention in their functioning is opposed to progress and economic growth, we will be on the wrong path, and this could take on truly dangerous dimensions. Owners of cash assets are currently accumulating gigantic assets that are in turn urgently needed to be reinvested. We are facing asset inflation on a global scale. Thus, speculative bubbles are continually emerging in the financial markets, causing growing economic instability, which in turn endangers the entire economy. It is precisely small and medium-sized businesses and many workers who suffer the consequences. It is possible to oppose this. The least that should be done to achieve this is to finally carry out in-depth studies on the subject, not only by the Commission but also by renowned economic institutes throughout Europe. This is also feasible. And finally, the wolf should not be left to guard the sheep. It is not true that the Tobin tax is not technically feasible. It is possible in the computer age. It cannot be ignored that tax havens are often nothing more than the hard drives of large European banks here among us. In short: we cannot allow real capital and financial capital to become so far apart, otherwise, we will find ourselves facing a situation we have already experienced several times in the last century on this continent and which has led to major catastrophes. Madam President, distinguished colleagues, let us tax capital speculation, for this will have unprecedented consequences. This tax would affect those who should be taxed: the speculators. Who defends these speculators, while nurses and teachers pay sky-high taxes? Article 73c of the Treaty on European Union regulates the possibility of tax transaction. Those who oppose the capital tax support tax avoidance centers, tax havens, which number 62. The Union should reach a tax agreement that, in principle, could be signed by any country. The moderate Tobin tax would not cause major tax evasion problems. The claim that if not everyone applies the tax, nothing can be achieved in this area is curious. The European Union was founded thanks to the push of a few countries, and you can see what we have become today. In reality, the biggest problem is political: the goal is not to tax capital, but to raise taxes on citizens. The capital tax would politicize the undemocratic and powerful global financial system.

He described globalization as a positive process, and I agree with him. In my view, globalization has contributed to the fact that numerous countries previously excluded from world trade are now participating and integrated into the world trading system, and to my knowledge, not a single country has yet been disadvantaged by world trade. In other words, like Mr. Gasòliba i Böhm, I also view globalization as positive and believe that it has contributed to a new international division of labor, something many have striven for for years. Secondly, Mr. Gasòliba i Böhm noted that it has not yet been proven that exchange rates are stabilized by the Tobin tax. He is probably right about that. I, too, am unaware of any reasons why levying a tax on speculative currency transactions should lead to exchange rate stabilization. These are, in my view, two important observations, and that is why I have repeated them here. Furthermore, Madam President, allow me to point out that none of the speakers this evening has made any connection between the Tobin tax and the functioning of the European Union. We are all familiar with the Treaties of Rome: as we all know, one of the four fundamental freedoms enshrined in them is the free movement of capital. Madam President, I can assure Parliament that, in my daily work, I also endeavour, with my departments and my colleagues, to achieve full integration of European financial markets in order to facilitate and make capital movements as flexible as possible. In other words, by virtue of my office, I am opposed to any measures that would make international capital movements more difficult. But you can hardly expect this Commissioner to agree to a tax that would specifically impede international financial transactions. To reiterate, I believe the Tobin tax is contrary to the Treaties of Rome, and this is a weighty theoretical objection that has not been raised by any of the speakers this evening. After these, in my view, very fundamental remarks, there are now practical reservations about the Tobin tax, as expressed by Mr. Karas and other speakers. It was pointed out that the European Union—unfortunately, I must say—has not been able to agree internally on certain tax measures. This demonstrates how difficult this issue is. If we have not been able to reach agreement internally, how could we convince the other trading partners? That would be a laborious process. Mr. Jonckheer stated that this is one of the measures that could stabilize the financial markets. However, this addresses a symptom, whereas we should be addressing the causes, and in my opinion, it is better to combat the causes than to try to treat the symptoms, which is probably impossible and, as I said, certainly violates the Treaty of Rome. To eliminate these causes, one must consider the situation in the countries concerned. Can these countries boast what is known in English as good governance? Do these countries have low inflation and low interest rates? Do the markets for factors of production, including the labor market, function flexibly? This is not always the case. Therefore, when looking for the reasons for exchange rate instability, we must focus primarily on the elements of good governance.

The European Union voted against this proposal. The European Union's position on the approach to China in the Commission on Human Rights was reconfirmed at the General Affairs Council meeting on 21 March 1999: no European Union initiative on China or co-sponsorship of a Chinese resolution, and the European Union voted against the non-interference proposal. It is not true that, had the resolution been put to the vote, the cohesion of the European Union could have been maintained. The United States of America submitted a draft resolution on China at the fifty-sixth session of the Commission on Human Rights and is pressuring the European Union to endorse it. This circumstance has provoked strong reactions from that country: the Chinese authorities are making representations to the countries and institutions of the European Union to refrain from supporting the United States' initiative. This initiative is under discussion within the Union, but a decision is not expected soon. It is in the European Union's interest not to rule out any option as far as possible, in any case until after the meeting to be held on 25 February 2000 within the framework of the EU-China dialogue on human rights. In light of the changes in the composition of the Commission on Human Rights, the vote on the non-interference proposal is expected to be close. It is therefore important that this year, too, the European Union countries reach a consensus on their position regarding the possible vote on the resolution. In this context, it is important to note that the European Union consistently opposes China's requests that the human rights dialogue automatically exclude the submission of a resolution to the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva. The European Union unequivocally believes that, while a very valuable instrument for exchanging views and understanding the conditions of the other party's position, dialogue should also yield concrete results on the ground. If this is not the case, a resolution by the Commission on Human Rights may be necessary, possibly as the dialogue continues. The European Union also consistently reaffirms to China that the Commission on Human Rights is the appropriate forum for raising human rights issues and that, regardless of China's decision to endorse the initiative or not, it is, in any case, legitimate from that perspective. The next human rights dialogue will be held on 25 February in Lisbon and, among other things, will include seminars on legal issues and women's rights, with the expected participation of representatives from academia and civil society. The next human rights seminar will be held by the Portuguese Presidency in May 2000, and in the last round of dialogue, in October 1999, the Chinese side accepted the European Union's proposal for technical assistance to support the ratification process of the United Nations International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, signed by the Chinese government.

I would also like to thank the various Members for their interventions and to tell them that safety is a priority for the Commission in the field of transport. And as Mr Simpson very rightly said, the process can never be taken for granted, acquired or concluded. The increase in margins, in safety guarantees in transport is a process that must continue to improve day by day. In this sense, I would also like to briefly refer to the problems of the tunnels, mentioned by Mr Rack and Mr Swoboda. In the case of Austria, this is undoubtedly a very sensitive issue, which requires an effort to see how to increase safety. In one of the serious accidents that occurred recently, the goods transported were not in themselves dangerous. The margarine and a few kilos of paint, which, in principle, did not pose any risk, caused a real catastrophe. We must therefore consider how the criteria can be further refined to ensure maximum safety. Finally, I would like to reiterate that we must consider safety in all types of transport. This week we will be holding a debate here on maritime safety, following the Erika disaster, and later this year we will have to discuss the safety objectives of air transport. But, ladies and gentlemen, safety is a priority objective of the Commission. As I will have occasion to say in the Erika debate, we are not waiting for a disaster to address the issue of safety, but we are working on it regardless of these events, which only demonstrate how urgent it is to provide an effective response to this type of problem. I would like to thank all those who have spoken, and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Koch. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12.00. Transport of dangerous goods by road The next item is the report (A5-0104/1999) by Mr Koch, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council [COM(1999) 158 - C5-0004/1999 - 1999/0083(COD)] amending Directive 94/55/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States with regard to the transport of dangerous goods by road. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the directive which came into force on 1 January 1997 on the approximation of the laws of the Member States with regard to the transport of dangerous goods by road contains certain transitional provisions whose validity is limited and depends on the completion of certain standardisation work by CEN, the European Committee for Standardisation. Delays in the work of CEN have led to problems in the application of the abovementioned directive. In particular, the annexes have not been able to be adapted to the latest technological and industrial developments. This is, in my opinion, regrettable and forces us to intervene to remedy the failures of others. I therefore accept the proposal to amend Directive 94/55/EC under discussion today. Failure by the European Union to act would force Member States to amend their national legislative provisions for a short period, namely until the CEN's work is completed, which would lead to unnecessary costs and uncertainty.

Mr President, I thank Mr Langen—although he is not here himself—for the work he has done to push this program through both Parliament and the Council. The project was long and difficult. The study to record the use of renewable energy sources must continue to be given great importance in the future. Although the new directive contains many positive aspects, it also has shortcomings. One example is the use of peat. Peat must not be placed in the same group as fossil fuels. If peat cannot be directly classified as a renewable, non-fossil energy source, a separate class must be defined for it, particularly in light of the environmental tax. Peat must not be measured by the same yardstick as, for example, hard coal. The development of renewable energy sources is a partial solution to ending the Union's dependence on energy imports. Research also plays a particularly important role with regard to the next round of EU enlargement. Dependence on energy imports primarily affects Eastern European countries, whose economic structures continue to suffer from the dependence on Russian energy created during the Soviet era. The EU must adhere to the Kyoto Protocol. We are all concerned about the environment and the future of our children. The share of renewable energy sources in total energy production must be increased, but in a sensible way. We must not forget that we will no longer be able to base the majority of our energy production on renewable energy sources for much longer. For this, we need a climate-friendly energy source: nuclear energy. Mr President, on behalf of the PSE Group, I welcome the fact that we have reached a result in the conciliation procedure on the Altener II programme. First of all, I would like to sincerely thank the rapporteur, Mr Langen, for his truly excellent work on this report. I would also like to thank the head of the delegation to the Conciliation Committee, Mr Provan. As Mr Langen has just said, it was a truly tough battle in the Conciliation Committee. But we can see today that the conciliation outcome also clearly bears the European Parliament's signature. Mr. Langen pointed out that a number of Parliament's substantive points and demands were adopted, and on the most important point of conflict with the Council, the financial allocation for this multiannual program to promote renewable energy sources in the Community, we were at least able to reach agreement with the Council – as has already been said – almost halfway there. That is not satisfactory, and I want to make that very clear. But we made this compromise because it was important to us that this program be launched very quickly. After all, in the next few years, the share of renewable energy sources in energy consumption is to be doubled to at least 12%. That is the declared goal of the European Union. The Altener Program, as the only EU program with the exclusive objective of promoting renewable energy sources, truly plays a key role in this. With this new five-year program, the actions from the Altener I Program must be expanded. These include, among other things, deepening the exchange of information and experience among stakeholders in the field of renewable energy sources, expanding local and regional energy agencies, and establishing new grids and promoting existing ones. These are just a few examples.

First, improve the effectiveness of its development policy. As is known, a comprehensive evaluation of development policies was carried out in 1995, and its conclusions were presented during the German Presidency. The main conclusions underscore the need for a more coherent European Union policy and a general strategic vision for the European Union in relation to development problems. Aspects relating to the need for greater coordination and greater complementarity between policies, harmonization and simplification in the organizational framework within which the Union's cooperation policy is currently implemented, the need to make aid management more efficient and to review, in particular, its intervention mechanisms, and the need to strengthen the evaluation system and make the aid process more transparent are highlighted. A second aspect worth mentioning reinforces the need for greater complementarity between the European Union and the policies of the Member States. It is well known that a significant portion of aid is currently provided by the national policies of the Member States, which are not always complementary and not always coordinated. Much of the waste or inefficiency of aid from the European Union is due precisely to this inability to coordinate and complement each other between what each Member State is doing and what the European Union institutions propose or do. From our point of view, it is also absolutely essential that we all contribute as soon as possible to strengthening mechanisms of complementarity and coordination between the policies implemented by the Member States and those of the European Union. A third aspect worth highlighting is the strengthening and coherence of its policies, the proposed topic of debate today. First, we all agree that it is not enough to improve the conditions of aid and that it is necessary to better articulate other European Union policies so that development objectives can be achieved not only through aid and assistance, but also and above all through a more integrated view of the different policies that contribute to its consequences. As is known, a Council resolution was adopted in June 1997, and the Commission was left to present evaluation reports. The first of these, which already establishes some aspects of policy coordination, particularly in the areas of peacebuilding, food security, fisheries, and migration, was communicated to the Council in May 1999. However, as is also known, a Commission communication on coherence is expected, along with the communication on "development policy." It is natural that in the coming months, still during the Portuguese Presidency, this debate can be enriched in light of the contributions the Commission intends to present in this regard. Policy coherence will always be—obviously—limited, and it is natural that any contradiction between policies is also an element of balance and balancing between contradictory and conflicting interests within the Union. Only in this way is it possible to regulate any contradiction between policies.

However, today I want to talk specifically about prevention. A new war is being prepared in the Gulf region. The Iraqi Government, as you know, has refused to comply with United Nations Resolution 1284, and this refusal will foreseeably lead, within the next six or seven weeks, to the denial of entry visas to the commission that is supposed to oversee the destruction of nuclear, biological, and chemical weapons. In that event, the United States Government and Her Britannic Majesty's Government have made it clear that they are determined to resort to military measures. My visit to Iraq and meetings with leaders and personalities of the Iraqi administration, particularly with Mr. Tarek Aziz, have convinced me that there is indeed a possibility of convincing the Iraqi Government to cooperate in the implementation of Resolution 1284. However, the responsible authorities in the Western countries must clearly state that, once the United Nations commission's mission has been successfully carried out, the embargo will be lifted and trade relations can be normalized. I would like to know what Europe and you, Mr. Solana, are doing, or what you intend to do in the near future, to avert this threat of war, which, today, can be prevented; tomorrow it may be too late. In this context, I would also like to know if it is not possible to do something to induce the Iraqi government to take a humanitarian step, that is, to provide information on the 615 missing persons in Kuwait or to release them if they were under its control. Mr. President, Mr. High Representative, Mr. Commissioner, we have all observed the particularly moderate and almost conciliatory reaction of the international community in general, and of the European Union in particular, to the war in Chechnya. Now, what has happened and what is still happening in Chechnya resembles genocide. If not, how can one describe the complete annihilation of a regional capital of 400,000 inhabitants, the constant and excessive bombing of towns and neighborhoods where the entire civil society was found, perhaps mixed with some Chechen combatants? How should we describe the sinister filtration camps, comparable to concentration camps, where the population suffers the worst humiliations and from which healthy men, aged 15 to 65, rarely emerge alive? How can we describe the rapes, the looting, the arson attacks, the deportations, known as "cleansing," which recall the worst episodes of the European Middle Ages? And what can be said of the difficult situation faced by Russian and international journalists, as well as the expulsion from the sites where the massacres take place, of humanitarian organizations and all the international commissions of inquiry? If that is Realpolitik, if we truly lack the means, then, Mr. High Representative for the CFSP, Mr. Commissioner, I address you both: let us at least use the means we have, that is, the aid programs for Russia.

Commissioner Monti and his colleagues face a tremendous challenge, and in the ELDR Group, we are concerned about a weakening of the drive for competition policy, both in the examination of mergers and in the supervision of restrictive methods. Delegating to national authorities is very good, but we would like to underline what Mr. von Wogau said in his report about the need for regular supervision by national authorities to ensure that there is no reduction on the European side, and we would particularly ask Commissioner Monti to reassure us that there will be random checks in this regard. Mr. President, in the limited time available to me, I would like to support the work done by all the rapporteurs and share many of the things that have been said here, particularly by my colleague Jonckheer, criticizing the excessive bundling of data and the need for transparency and a socioeconomic assessment of aid. I also share the criticism that the lack of emphasis has been placed on the development of Article 82, especially when we may witness abusive conduct in a context of market concentration. As a Member of the Basque Country, I wish to express my full support for the measures implementing due market competition. I say this in case there were any doubts about the criticisms we have directed at the Commission, in general, and at Mr. Monti, in particular, for their persecution of incentives for Basque companies and for considering them as state aid. Our disagreement persists to the extent that the Commission continues to fail to understand the nature of the general system and co-responsibility of our agreement, which means that our Basque tax rules have the same nature, basis, and purpose as the rules of the Member States of the Union, and which apply generally to all taxpayers who, by virtue of the connecting points, are subject to them. Mr. President, Commissioner, yes, we definitely need competition. We need to compete in the areas of maximizing unemployment reduction, improving healthcare, social justice, and high social standards. Furthermore—the above are criteria of political and economic competitiveness—we also need to compete, naturally, in the business economic sphere: maximum product quality, equal market access conditions for all companies, and the offering of environmentally friendly products. In other words, we must be able to combine the necessary criteria of political and economic competitiveness with those of business economics. I sometimes get the impression that, unlike what happened in my country—in the GDR—where competitiveness was prioritized above all else from a political and economic perspective, without paying attention to business competitiveness, the opposite is now very often the case, and society thinks almost exclusively in terms of business economics. I say this from my position as a businessman who is absolutely interested in this aspect. But a system cannot function like this. The only possible way is a combined approach.

In the postal sector, the first phase has already begun, with universal service providers embarking on a process of modernization. Rather than the process of liberalizing the sector, new technologies and logistics are the key factors influencing employment. As for the availability of the studies, a point raised by Mr. Staes and other Members, copies of each of these studies were forwarded to Parliament in September 1999. They have all been available on the Commission's website since August 1999, and the Commission is willing to provide a copy to anyone interested. The studies have been the subject of some criticism, particularly from the public postal services. I am aware that all the studies undertaken have encountered difficulties in collecting adequate data. This did not surprise us, as universal service operators do not always have detailed mail collection systems. Does this not speak volumes about management capacity? No single methodology for accessing the cost and financing of universal service is accepted by all parties. Nevertheless, Mr. Bolkestein is convinced that the studies undertaken are sufficiently clear and precise to form the basis of the decision-making process. I finally come to three interventions on a subject I am supposed to know better than postal services: competition. Mr. Purvis, I found your remark on the call for tenders, methodologically provocative, interesting and certainly worth exploring. Mr. Medina Ortega, I am just as convinced as you that we will have to be even more vigilant after liberalization, because we do not want the disappearance of public monopolies to give rise, due to a lack of merger control, to private operators. This applies as much to the postal sector as to other sectors. If I may give you an example of this type of vigilance, I would cite the case of Deutsche Post, for which the Commission, following complaints and legal action, initiated a formal state aid review procedure in July. We have just received the German government's response to the comments submitted. The state aid review procedure covers the issue of cross-subsidies between monopolistic mail services and commercial courier activities, as well as the financing of Deutsche Post's recent and numerous acquisitions. I will not go into detail due to lack of time, but this perhaps illustrates, among other things, the fact that the Commission does not stop its work with the progress of liberalization. In a sense, that is where its work begins. Finally, it goes without saying, Mr. Radwan, that limits must be placed on competition, and these limits exist. If we look specifically at the issue of competition and services of general interest, when a Member State defines a public service mission, it is important to quantify the costs generated by this mission, and state aid that compensates for these costs is certainly not a violation of competition. I do not entirely agree with the terms you used, Mr Radwan, when you said that it was time to take into account the needs of citizens rather than exclusively the need for competition.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every year in Europe, nine million vehicles are sent to the scrapyard and disposed of. Although they are no longer fit for circulation, these nine million vehicles have the characteristic of being marketed and transported beyond borders, not only within the Community but also outside the Community. It is therefore correct in principle for the European Union to establish common rules on the recycling and treatment of these nine million vehicles.
