In our opinion, the directive has some weaknesses that Parliament would like to address and thus provide an instrument that actually points the way forward for the future. For this reason, a great many amendments have been tabled. I believe that the scope of this directive goes too far. I do not think it is necessary for vintage vehicles to be included in the directive. Nor do I think that motorcycles should be included in this directive, because such a culture of recycling is rooted in this sector that a European directive is superfluous. Even for special vehicles, I do not think it is appropriate to aim for a very high recycling rate. For special vehicles such as ambulances, I would prefer a high recovery rate. That is my main concern in this area. In my opinion, the directive correctly prescribes the obligation to demonstrate how a vehicle destined for disposal is treated in Europe. In this case, we can accept the Commission's proposals. The Member States ensure that special collection centres are set up which empty the fluids contained in the vehicles, for example by disposing of more than 32 million bottles of used oil, removing brake fluid, etc. An important aspect addressed in the directive is the question of what to do with used parts and scrap products. It cannot be ignored that the rate is an important element, but not the only one, in recycling, recovery and so on. Indeed, it should not be forgotten that, when it comes to the mobility of a vehicle, 80 percent of environmental pollution is caused by its circulation, 1 percent by its reuse and 19 percent by its construction. Therefore, percentages are not the only parameter to be applied in relation to environmental compatibility, but are only one of many parameters to be taken into account. I am of the opinion that we need clear objectives. But percentages must not become an end in themselves; we must realize the importance of the global perspective linked to the environmental pollution caused by a vehicle. I prefer to think that from a vehicle that today weighs 1,400 kilos and on average travels 200,000 kilometres, we will in future move to a car that will weigh only 1,000 kilos, but will still be able to travel 200,000 kilometres. In this way, 400 kilos less would still be transported for 200,000 kilometres. This is real progress in environmental policy, because it will lead to a significant reduction in CO2 emissions and, if I have understood the Kyoto Protocol correctly, it is the essential point. For this reason, we believe that vehicles in which optimal and demonstrably lighter construction methods are used in future will produce less CO2 and should therefore be given special preference as regards the incineration rate. It is not up to the individual Member States, but up to you, Commissioner, together with your staff, to decide whether such lightweight vehicles - many are even talking about three-litre vehicles - should be given special preference.

This, too, is characteristic of American society, which itself knows little about it. Americans are rightly outraged by wars and genocides in other parts of the world, but unjustly remain silent about the genocide in their own country. Today, the Dineh Indians are facing their final battle for their right to land, their right to dignity, and above all, their right to their own way of life. There are only a few of them, and their opponent is an economic power. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with the comments of my predecessors, but I would like to emphasize a few things. The Dineh belong to the North American Navajo Indians. They are excluded from society and have been fighting a struggle for survival for decades. For years they have lived in deplorable conditions. These wretched circumstances force them to submit against their will to the financial and economic pressure of the coal industry. The 1974 Relocation Act, which redivided the territory of the Navajo Reservation, authorizes the relocation of the population groups. These relocations are unacceptable, as they violate human rights in economic, social, and cultural terms. The Dineh Indians are being shuffled around like chess pieces, thus not only losing their history and the land of their ancestors, which is so vital to them, but also leaving them with no prospect of finding work or income. The Relocation Act was pushed through Congress by a group representing the coal industry. Congress never considered where the people living in the area would go or how the relocation would affect their lives. The population had no say in the matter. This is practically human trafficking. The relocation was carried out, and the Dineh were relocated to a uranium-contaminated area. Following the rupture of a dam in New Mexico in 1979, releasing 370,000 cubic meters of radioactive water and 1,100 tons of pure uranium, this place is one of the most contaminated in the world. The United States government, the coal industry, and all of us must accept our responsibility and provide an acceptable alternative: either the soil is decontaminated, or the Dineh Indians are given a place of livability and all the necessary psychological, social, cultural, and financial support is provided. The rights of the Indians must finally be respected. We therefore call for a vote in favor of this resolution: we in Europe must not allow ourselves to be intimidated by American interests, asserted by financial, religious, and industrial groups. So let's send an express message to the United States! Mr. President! There is, of course, much to criticize in Chechnya regarding human rights. According to human rights organizations, Russian soldiers have killed civilians, both elderly women and men, in Grozny, apparently even executing them. Civilians have reportedly been burned alive in bomb shelters. We insist that these human rights violations be investigated. Contrary to promises, the human rights violations committed in Alfanyurt, for example, have still not been investigated. International governmental and non-governmental organizations must be granted access to the area. On 6 December 1999, the General Affairs Council of the Union decided to send representatives of the Member States to Ingushetia to investigate the humanitarian situation, and I am, to say the least, curious to see the results.

However, structurally and generally, all of us, regardless of where we are, what class we are, what race we are, what religion we are, whether at home or at work, in every sphere of society, are subordinate to men - with some individual exceptions, as it is perhaps fair to point out. In my country, Sweden, several political parties have spontaneously decided in recent years to introduce a quota of seats for women in assembly bodies. This has resulted in an increase in the presence of women in decision-making, and has in turn created space for further research. What happens when more women take an active and equal part in decision-making? The conclusion so far is that this has led to a change in political priorities, and a change in political priorities naturally also leads to a change in the types of decision-making. When we talk about gender quotas, the word "competence" is always automatically mentioned. But the interesting thing is that the competence requirements are rarely defined. It would seem that, today as yesterday, men systematically possess even the most undefined skills. In short, being a man would be synonymous with having greater competence. And such a view seems to me to be proof of the high level of incompetence that characterizes many of those who make decisions at the moment. In this Assembly, we have already put forward the request this year to make March 8 an international holiday. While waiting for this to become a reality, I would like to take this opportunity to wish every success to all the socialist women in the Women's World Marches that will begin on International Women's Day this year. This is an initiative of global importance, focused on violence against women and female poverty throughout the world. Finally, I would like to say, as Commissioner Patten concluded the discussion just now, that the ideal policeman would be a black grandmother. We do not have such policemen, and yet they would exist! Mr President, the role of women in politics is an important issue that deserves something better than the politically correct revival we are witnessing. There are probably few women involved in politics, although this is not necessarily due solely to the predominance of men in party apparatuses. In France, 95 percent of elected officials are municipal councilors, the vast majority of whom are not affiliated with any party. In departmental institutions, the largest party in France is the non-affiliated party, both on the right and the left. To be elected as a local councilor, you just have to want it. However, access to national responsibilities often depends on the inclusion that these mandates offer. The UEN Group advocates equal representation of men and women in the bodies of the European Union. This is why we reject the policy of quotas and positive discrimination, whether it is expressed in favor of women or of supposed social minorities. Minority politics, by neglecting the profound unity of the human family to establish superficial divisions, seriously threatens the cohesion of the social body and the balance of our democratic model.

Question No. 3 (H-0027/00): Subject: Indictment of NATO before the International War Crimes Tribunal. Human rights organizations, such as Human Rights Watch in the USA, have already gathered considerable evidence against NATO in connection with the air strikes in Kosovo and Serbia, with a view to filing a complaint with the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. On the basis of this evidence, some of which has already been submitted to the above-mentioned court, NATO is accused of serious violations of international humanitarian law and of deliberate killings. Does the Council consider that such allegations should be left to the judgment of the International War Crimes Tribunal to be subjected to a thorough judicial investigation? If a judicial investigation into the allegations against NATO is carried out, how does the Council intend to deal with the Secretary-General/High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy, who held the office of Secretary-General of NATO during the relevant period? Is there a procedure for relieving him of his duties until the charges have been investigated in court? Mr President, the question posed by Mr Alexandros Alavanos is worthy of general reflection. The Council has repeatedly expressed its conviction that the application of severe measures by NATO was necessary and justified to counter extremist and irresponsible actions that constituted a clear violation of United Nations Security Council resolutions. I understand that there can be different opinions about NATO's actions and their legality. Everyone is free to hold such positions. In my homeland, the various parliamentary groups held different opinions. That was the way things were and not otherwise. In any case, the Council's clear position is that the air strikes carried out by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia were carried out with the aim of ending the human catastrophe unleashed by the Belgrade regime in Kosovo. This objective was formally and comprehensively expressed by the position of the General Affairs Council on 8 April in Luxembourg. These NATO measures, it must be said, were not taken lightly, but as a last resort, when it became clear that the possibilities of a negotiated solution had been exhausted and that the Belgrade authorities were concentrating their forces to expel the Kosovo Albanians from their homeland. The Honourable Member will no doubt have learned that, during her recent visit to NATO Headquarters, Prosecutor Del Ponte emphasized that the International Tribunal is obliged to investigate all accusations brought, including those made against NATO, particularly by Canadian pacifist groups. This mandatory examination will be carried out as and when such accusations are made. In any case, I have with me a statement from the Prosecutor in which she states that no investigations into NATO are currently being conducted by the Office of the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, and that there is no formal investigation into NATO's actions in the Kosovo conflict. All information received over the past six months, both from individuals and groups, requesting an investigation into NATO's actions during the Kosovo conflict has been registered by the Prosecutor. The Prosecutor will, of course, examine all other information and advise in due course whether there are grounds for action.

Tomorrow we'll be discussing a few points. First, we know that the transport of people and goods by ship is the most environmentally friendly of all other modes of transport. At the same time, we know that ships contribute significantly to ocean pollution through garbage, cargo residues, and oil sludge. Heavy fuel oil is the fuel used by ships, and we know that 1% to 3% of this heavy fuel oil remains as oil sludge, which is traditionally dumped into the oceans. I think we agree that ships must dispose of garbage and residues in ports. And from this it follows—and there can really be no other logic: The top priority for clean seas is that illegal dumping on the high seas must no longer be profitable. That's what it's about, and that's what we've debated here by a majority. We had a very detailed debate with you in January, Commissioner, on the consequences of "Erika." There we summarized all the points on ship safety and clean seas. And this directive on port reception facilities for cargo residues is also about the question of how we can make the oceans cleaner. Just for your information: We know that 70,000 m3 of waste is illegally dumped into the North Sea alone every year, and conversely, we know that a maximum of 5% to 10% of ships now take the proper route, namely disposing of their waste in ports. This scandal is unacceptable from the Council's point of view, too. The Council also says that all ports must have appropriate port reception facilities and be equipped with them. The conflict now ultimately revolves around the question of how to pay. In its first reading, Parliament said by a large majority that ships must make a substantial contribution, namely at least 90%. And that is the difference to the Council, which tells us there must be a contribution. But a contribution can also be as little as half a euro, and in this case, God knows, that would be far too little. Then nothing will change. There is no economic pressure on ships to behave accordingly. What is needed is a flat-rate disposal fee for all ships, regardless of actual use of the disposal facilities. This means that the economic incentive for disposal at sea must be eliminated, which – as has already been explained here – was possible in the Baltic Sea with the HELMKOM Agreement, with the no-special-fee system. What works there must also be able to work for the rest of Europe's seas, because it's not just about the environment; it's about clean waters, it extends to tourism, and – crucially – alongside the environmental issue, it's also about competitive neutrality. All ships in ports must be able to comply with the same conditions, and only if Parliament, the Council, and the Commission work together to create these conditions will this competitive neutrality be restored for ports and ships. I think it's also about the credibility of the Union, and of Parliament in particular. I think people are tired of experiencing catastrophe hypocrisy from Europe and its ministers, as we saw with "Erika."

There have been examples in Spain: Michelin, ABB-Alstom, and there are examples in Italy, which my colleagues will cite. There is also another disguised form of dismissal, practiced in Spain, for example, by the company Ericsson, under the name "outsourcing" (precise terms are avoided, such as the word "dismissal"). Outsourcing means subcontracting services to companies, transforming stable and permanent jobs into jobs that can be terminated at any time, without union or social rights. This is, in reality, another disguised form of dismissal. Commissioner, if the European institutions believe what they say about full employment, they must take clear measures: revise the directives to ensure worker participation in these negotiations, revise the directive on collective dismissals, reduce working hours, link European subsidies to a clear commitment to maintaining jobs, and include social and labor rights clauses in the international agreements signed by the European Union. Mr President, once again, this Parliament is unfortunately having to deal with the restructuring of companies in Europe. Once again, workers are threatened with job loss. This time, it is the Goodyear workers in Cisterna di Latina. As has already been mentioned, some 600 employees and just as many families are affected, who could be deprived of their only source of income in a month. These workers—despite their cooperation and professionalism, which have made the Cisterna plant one of the most productive in Europe—are in danger of being excluded from the production cycle, while the Goodyear company, after years of receiving state subsidies and Community aid, can close its doors with complete peace and tranquility. I consider this truly unfair: unfair to the workers at the Cisterna plant and unfair to all those Italian and European citizens who, albeit indirectly, through their taxes, have made it possible for Goodyear to benefit from this state aid. The European Commission and the Council must finally fully acknowledge their responsibilities in this regard, both with regard to the adoption of the common position on informing and consulting employers and with regard to Community financial aid and state aid, which should be granted only to companies that undertake to conclude long-term employment agreements. We are calling on the Commission today, above all, to protect the workers at the Goodyear plant in Cisterna and, therefore, to exert every possible pressure on the company to reach an agreement as soon as possible to ensure the continued existence and operation of the plant in Cisterna. Finally, I would like to point out, Mr President and Commissioner, that time is truly of the essence, and therefore all the measures envisaged—including those already mentioned by the Commissioner in his introductory remarks—must be implemented immediately and in a timely manner. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, if European companies are to remain viable, they will undoubtedly need to adapt structurally to better meet the new challenges. We are fully aware of the current economic background, as the aim of the planned restructuring is to rationalise corporate management.

If we believe in the principle of equal representation between women and men in decision-making, we must make the necessary commitments to make that principle a reality. Mr. President, at the Second International Socialist Women's Conference, held in Copenhagen in 1910, it was agreed that the essential demand, women's suffrage, should be linked to all other aspects of women's struggle and that, furthermore, as stated in the resolution, "Women's Day must be international in character and its preparation must be thorough." It is also worth noting that Women's Day was later banned in all countries where fascism and Nazism came to power during the interwar period. In 1910, women's suffrage was on the agenda. Today we are concerned with how women can participate in the decision-making process. Women are not a homogeneous group. Women belong to all social classes. Women have individual needs and interests. However, structurally and pervasively, regardless of where we find ourselves, regardless of class and religion, at home or at work, in all segments of society, we are subordinated to men, although it should be added that there are some individual exceptions. In recent years in my country of Sweden, many political parties have voluntarily established female quotas in representation and in the work of political assemblies. This has led to an increase in the number of women in political decision-making, which, in turn, has given rise to a new branch of research. What happens when more women participate actively and equally in political decision-making? What has been shown so far is that the agenda has changed, and when it changes, other types of decisions are also made. When people talk about gender quotas, they always automatically refer to eligibility. What's interesting is that the eligibility criteria are rarely defined. It often seems that men, today as yesterday, always have the most undefined eligibility. Being a man would therefore be equivalent to possessing the greatest aptitude. This perspective, in my opinion, is evidence of gross incompetence on the part of those who make decisions today. This year, in this House, we have requested that March 8 be made an international holiday. While we wait for this to materialize, I want to take this opportunity to wish all socialist women success in their Women's World Marches, which will begin in the spring, on International Women's Day. This is a worldwide activity that focuses on violence against women and the poverty of women around the world. Finally, as Commissioner Patten pointed out at the end of the previous debate, I want to say that the ideal police officer would be a black grandmother. We don't have one, but there are some!

Europe, which has inappropriately abolished the budget line "Natural disasters for the benefit of member countries", must react, above all in the name of solidarity, but also in the name of its share of responsibility for this latest oil spill. In fact, citizens struggle to understand why Europe accepts what the Americans refuse and why Europe, usually so quick to legislate on environmental matters, has so far glossed over maritime safety. Europe must legislate as soon as possible and shed light on this shipwreck. But, in the meantime, the Commission must urgently mobilize European funds to help the companies affected, treat the wreck, clean the coastline, increase waste storage capacity, ensure its treatment or recycling, and establish a research program on recovering oil from the sea. Finally, the Commission must reintroduce an appropriate budget line "Natural disasters for member countries", allowing the affected regions to access the Structural Funds. What is the Commission's opinion on these proposals? What decisions have already been taken and what does the Commission intend to take? What follow-up has the Commission given to the resolution voted on 20 January 2000 by the European Parliament? For the time being, we have not seen any measures materialise. Mr President, echoing some of my colleagues, I would like to reiterate that the situation two and a half months after the shipwreck remains particularly critical, revealing its gravity more and more every day. The situation is dramatic from two points of view. Firstly, it is tragic from an environmental point of view. The wreck in fact still contains sixteen thousand tonnes of heavy fuel which continues to leak and, apart from these leaks, unfortunately last week we observed and recorded thirty-five acts of ecological piracy, thirty-five chemical clean-up operations, which shamefully add to this absolutely catastrophic situation. Mrs de Palacio has dwelt at length on this problem and I believe that she has implemented without delay what is absolutely necessary today, namely the establishment of European maritime law through the proposal for a directive on the maritime transport of dangerous goods. Well, from this point of view, the honourable colleague will be able to count on France's willingness to distinguish its Presidency by approving regulations that move towards greater safety. The second shock - after the first, the environmental one - is manifested on the economic level and many colleagues have reiterated this today. Shellfish farming, fishing, oyster farming, fish farming have been seriously affected because the oil spill was added, in many places, to the damage of the storm. Unfortunately, these activities have suffered terrible damage and, if on the one hand they must rebuild, on the other, perhaps more arduous task, they must regain the trust of consumers. Faced with this situation, the inhabitants of Brittany, Vendée, Charente and, moving on to other sectors, foresters, are waiting for a sign from the European Union. We cannot place this legislature under the banner of reconnecting with citizens and at the same time remain "silent", without concrete answers, in the face of phenomena of this kind and magnitude.

We're not just asking for more oversight, or just more oversight through Europol, but the motto "less is sometimes more" applies to us here. If a large proportion of Europol's employees are currently occupied primarily with legal self-monitoring of data protection, and if demands are received from 15 national parliaments, this is a lot of oversight, and it's ineffective. We want less oversight and more parliamentary oversight exercised by the European Parliament without thereby hindering Europol's work. At the same time, we support the creation of a European Police Academy proposed in Tampere as a step in the right direction. Third: the expansion of Parliament's rights in this context. If the creation of such an area, in which the Union can also interfere with the fundamental rights of Union citizens, is decided solely by diplomats and bureaucrats, while Europe's elected representatives can only watch developments from the sidelines like a rabbit watches a snake's movements, then such an area will not gain the acceptance of citizens. Therefore, it is urgent that Parliament be granted codecision rights in this regard and—as I have already indicated—that the principle of democratic oversight be strengthened. We want an area of freedom, security, and law for the citizens of Europe, not against them. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I have nothing more to say to the Council. The previous speaker already explained it, using a quote of mine from the last committee meeting. Why does the Council have so much difficulty cooperating with us on the construction of the area of security, freedom, and law? This question continually preoccupies me. I will try to shed some light on this matter from my perspective. The construction of the area of security, freedom, and law moves at the intersection of the constituent elements of national sovereignty. The police and the justice system are very clear elements of statehood itself, that is, sensitive political areas for the member states. The merger of this intersection of these fields, going as far as the communitarization of these policies—that is, the delegation of powers from the national capital, from Lisbon, Berlin, or Paris, to Brussels—means ceding a portion of power. Naturally, it's very difficult to deviate from traditional forms, even if it's recognized that police cooperation is necessary and that we can only combat international crime at the European level. It's necessary to draw conclusions and say that we must then communitarize the instruments organizationally and legally. This means that the governments that must do so and that see the need for it, at the same time recognize that they themselves lose power with the implementation process. They also have a complicated European Parliament. But we have to finally resolve this. Because if we continue acting as we have done with last year's experiences, the following will happen: the debate on security and citizens' rights will be marginalized in national parliaments due to the half-national, half-European structure.

I have proof that this is possible. Most of you hold these debates in your own constituencies, in your own regions. In the slightly more selfish vision of the Commission, I would like this institution to have a face in the eyes of the citizens, that the men and women who make up this institution could meet the citizens as often as possible. Mr President, I would like to express my appreciation for the commitment made by Commissioner Barnier to visit the regions to explain and to listen to what the citizens have to say. I would like to invite him to my region of Yorkshire, a large European region that participates fully in the single market and is a major beneficiary of the European Structural Funds. He can come and visit us in his two capacities as Commissioner. I would like to ask you how vigorous the Commission will be in this information campaign. In some Member States the problem is not so much providing information to a not very well informed public, which is certainly important, but rather countering the disinformation spread by overactive anti-European organisations and movements. The Commission will have to be very vigorous in responding to the comments it receives during the campaign. Mr Corbett, thank you for your appreciation. I gladly accept your invitation and, if I understand correctly, you want me to speak not only about the reform of the European institutions but also about the Structural Funds during my visit to Yorkshire. I am ready to undertake this dual task. I forgot to mention, among other things, how much I do to intervene, as I have done, before the national parliaments, not only by speaking to their representatives here, but by going to meet them on the spot. Ten days ago I was in Westminster. As you can see, Mr Corbett, I am not afraid of difficulties. Next week I am going to the Bundestag in Berlin. I have already spoken before the French Senate. So throughout this debate, whenever I can, I will also speak directly before the national parliaments. As regards dialogue with citizens, it is not a question of propaganda or marketing or even communication. I would like the dialogue to be truly such, and that after a short film explaining objectively what is at stake in the institutional reform, those sitting here in the gallery can speak and respond freely to the microphone. As I repeat, we intend to pursue this dialogue initiative in specific or structured cooperation with the Member States, and I sincerely hope that, with your support, the governments of the Fifteen can join in, in the way they deem most appropriate and most suitable. Mr President, I would like to join Commissioner Barnier's study group with the 700 trainees, so that you will have someone to discuss with. It is not much fun to discuss the Intergovernmental Conference and transparency alone. In relation to the Intergovernmental Conference, Commissioner Barnier, in his presentation to Parliament, said that social policy is not subject to majority voting, but on page 63 I read that the fight against discrimination, the right to movement and residence - therefore the directives on residence - social security as a whole, the revision of Regulation No. 1408 and the provisions in force in the field of social policy - with some exceptions - will be subject to the qualified majority rule.

It is not up to you to decide this; it is up to us to do so. This, too, is linked to the newfound self-awareness of this Parliament. I would like to discuss this with you, nothing more, nothing less. We can spare ourselves any further incursions into any area whatsoever, and I respect you as a serious Commissioner who wants to take his job seriously. I ask you to respect us as Members who want to take theirs seriously, which also includes the Tobin tax. Madam President, there seems to be an omission and that, in the list of resolutions tabled, which you have just mentioned, no mention has been made of the joint compromise motion for a resolution by the PES, the Liberals, the GUE, the Greens, and Mrs Kuntz and Mr Coûteaux. Dear colleague, I take note of your statement and the existence of this joint resolution. If the Presidency's services confirm that it has been submitted, it will of course be taken into consideration. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday at 12 p.m. (The sitting adjourned at 8:14 p.m.) Adoption of the minutes of the previous sitting Mr. President, I simply wanted to disseminate some information: a terrorist attack took place this morning in Madrid. It was a car bomb. There was one death. I simply wanted, on behalf of my group, to condemn these terrorist acts once again. Thank you very much, Ms. Fraga. We have indeed been informed of this regrettable event. Murderous terrorism has unfortunately, once again, struck Spanish society; the Presidency associates itself with your intervention with particular intensity, as you will understand, since the Presidency of this sitting is also Spanish. (The minutes are adopted) Resumption of the session I declare the session of the European Parliament resumed, which was interrupted on Friday, 21 January 2000. Madam President, allow me to remind you that tomorrow will mark the second anniversary of the Cermes tragedy. Two years ago, at Cavalese in Italy, an American plane coming from the NATO base at Aviano, during a low-altitude exercise - below safety limits - cut the cables of a cable car, causing the death of more than 20 European citizens. The families of the victims, who did not feel that justice had been done since the pilot responsible did not face any punishment, expect, at the very least, rapid financial compensation from the United States. I therefore call on the President of this House and the President of the Commission to stand as guarantors, alongside the American authorities, for immediate compensation, in order to defend the rights of the victims' families. Madam, thank you and I have taken due note of your intervention. Agenda The next item is the order of business. Following the request made to me to this effect by several political groups and following the meeting of the Conference of Presidents that we have just held, I propose that we schedule a debate of one and a half hours on a topical, urgent and major issue, in accordance with Rule 50 of our Rules of Procedure, concerning the Union's reaction to the government negotiations in Austria.

There is no provision for a direct transition from INTERREG II to INTERREG III, which in fact leads to uncertainties in programming and funding gaps. This is a shame, because it will certainly put good projects at risk. In implementing INTERREG, coordination and synchronisation with the other financial instruments involved must be ensured. This is particularly important in order to increase the efficiency of the funds used, but it does lead to problems. The difficulties arise above all from the annual duration of the funds, which are allocated on a project-by-project basis, for example under PHARE, whereas the contributions provided under INTERREG last for several years and are allocated on the basis of the measures taken. This will cause practical problems in the future, and I hope that this will not prevent the satisfactory implementation of INTERREG. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the LEADER Community initiative has proven to be a good instrument for stimulating innovative developments and pilot projects in and from rural areas. It is therefore certainly a good thing that this Community initiative has been maintained and reintroduced in a new form within the LEADER+ programme. The new LEADER+ programme can now be implemented throughout the entire rural area of the European Union, which offers greater possibilities for project funding. It is certainly important to ensure coordination between LEADER+ and other European Union support measures, but it is equally important to ensure coordination with other forms of promotion at national level. On the one hand, fragmentation of support measures must be avoided and, on the other, synergy effects must be exploited. From this point of view, the aim of increasing networking between areas benefiting from the LEADER programme must certainly be welcomed. The agricultural sector is one of the cornerstones of rural space and must be able to participate in the LEADER initiative; structural changes affecting agriculture can also be supported through the LEADER initiative, contributing to the creation of new jobs in rural space. The LEADER+ programme must take into account all economic interconnections in rural areas and the possibility of achieving the best result only through joint commitment. The implementation phase of LEADER must now begin. The operational programmes must be approved by the Commission as soon as possible, which means that the processing of funding requests must be practicable and efficient, and the assignment of tasks must be done as quickly as possible. Five months is foreseen, which is too long in my opinion. The timeframe should be shortened. Those who have developed and finalised a project are in a hurry to move on to the implementation phase. Although I am fully satisfied with the new look of the LEADER+ Community initiative, I would like to draw attention to an aspect that is particularly close to my heart: in its presentation, the EU Commission called for an observatory for the LEADER+ programme without going into the specifics of the implementation of this proposal. In my opinion, the following questions arise: who will work there? How will these people be selected? Above all: where will the necessary funds be found and where should such an observatory be located? I am of the opinion that the LEADER+ programme does not have a cent left to spend on additional administrative expenditure for tasks which, in themselves, should be carried out by the Commission.

To justify this, the upcoming enlargement of the Union is cited. This surprises me because it is a misinterpretation. A federal and centralist EU that increasingly governs the Member States actually has less chance of expanding. A flexible EU that focuses on fewer but essential areas and respects national differences and national democracies has a better chance of encompassing many more countries. Point D of the motion for a resolution calls for a more effective and transparent economic policy at EU level. However, it is impossible to discuss this without mentioning monetary union. The current text says nothing about the major democratic and political problems associated with monetary union and the central bank—this is not defensible. If we want a more democratic EU, we need to review the entire concept of EMU. The central bank must be placed under political control so that monetary policy can be guided by a political objective such as increasing employment or welfare; To achieve this, central bank transparency must be improved. The frozen and failed monetarism of the Stability Pact must be reexamined and rejected if we are to have a homogeneous policy that places the objective of well-being first. Article 56 of the Treaty, which prohibits any intervention in the free movement of capital and currency speculation, must be abolished so that dangerous currency speculation is curbed through political control. Most EU countries today have governments dominated by Social Democrats. It is remarkable that none of them are demanding a change in the direction of monetary union, now that they have the opportunity. Declaring that monetary union could be a counterweight to the globalization of capital also damages credibility. The resolution demands that the European Parliament be given greater power over the Intergovernmental Conference. It is important to emphasize, however, that the Intergovernmental Conference is and must be a conference between the Member States. It is the Parliament of the Member States, or of the people in popular votes, that must lead the development of the treaty. It is therefore out of the question for the European Parliament to be granted any formal influence in the negotiation or ratification process. Mr. President, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs has presented a substantially positive text for which I will vote, even if I myself had introduced several enlargement amendments. However, what has happened in recent days shows that all those who had expressed fundamental criticism of the way in which enlargement and the revision of the Treaties were organized were right. We cannot envisage a Union of twenty-eight Member States without facing the question of whether Europe shares certain principles, certain common values, whether it is reduced to a free trade economic area or whether, on the contrary, it has a greater aspiration: to be a supranational union, in aspects yet to be defined, also wishing to chart a new path of civilization and democracy in the world.

The two proposals form a coherent whole. The first broadens the range of instruments with which an "undertaking for collective investment in transferable securities" (UCITS) can operate. As has already been mentioned in the discussion, these bodies are to be counted among the main players in modern capital markets; their presence ensures that a greater number of ordinary investors can operate on these markets in compliance with the principle of risk spreading and protected by adequate controls. By allowing diversified forms of investment, private investors can exploit all the advantages offered by new investment techniques. The second proposal broadens the role that these important intermediary bodies can play on the capital market of the European Union with regard to the development of the investment fund sector. By allowing the creation of compartments and the provision of certain services at cross-border level, these bodies will be able to benefit from the freedoms provided for by the Treaty of Rome, which they have not been able to enjoy so far. The Commission welcomes many of the clarifications proposed by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and will take on board many of the ideas put forward by it. The Commission will accept amendments - I use the last numbering - Nos 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 13, 19 and 21 relating to the first proposal and Nos 23, 28 and 32 relating to the second proposal, as they represent useful clarifications and improvements. I also welcome the ideas - although they need to be formulated appropriately - contained in Amendments Nos 1, 10, 11, 14, 18 and 20. I also support the concept of the maximum percentage of counterparty risk underlying Amendments Nos 17, 36 and 45. I can also accept the idea expressed in the second paragraph of Amendment No 47. All the amendments mentioned so far relate to the first proposal. As regards the second proposal, it is possible to accept the ideas presented in Amendments Nos 1, 2, 3 and 4. 24, 25, 29, 30 and 41 and parts of Amendment 27, which contain interesting suggestions, although they need to be worded appropriately. The Commission is prepared to accept them, provided that some changes are made to their wording. I also note the request from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs to codify the entire text once it has been adopted - Amendment 7 of the first proposal and Amendment 22 of the second proposal. The Commission is in favour of a codification and will endeavour to produce a codified version shortly after the adoption of the proposals, reserving its right of initiative; however, I cannot accept the current wording of the recital. The Commission also considers that some amendments tabled by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs would radically change the content of the first proposal. The Commission therefore cannot, albeit reluctantly, accept the following amendments relating to the first proposal. Amendment 7 8 is not acceptable, as the proposed generic reference to investments "referred to in this Directive" in place of the more precise reference to instruments "referred to in Article 19 of the Directive" makes implementation more difficult. Furthermore, this amendment could lead to different interpretations in Member States, which would perhaps look for instruments mentioned in other articles of the Directive.

We believe that poverty and segregation are the main threats to peace and freedom. Although I agree with what my party colleagues have said and with the spirit of their document, I would like to draw attention to two shortcomings that must be corrected in the future. The first concerns women, gender, or women's rights. You referred to women's contribution to increasing production and growth. This is important, but equal opportunities between men and women are not only necessary for productivity but also for democracy in our societies. It is therefore surprising that the words "equal opportunities," "gender," or "women" do not appear in "Shaping the New Europe." In your speech, you referred to women, but they are not mentioned among the strategic objectives. Is this due, Commissioner, to the fact that mainstreaming is already so established in the Commission that it is unnecessary to mention women? How do you explain this absence of women? The EU must not become a Union with a male face. My second question concerns Africa. Africa is also not mentioned in Shaping the New Europe, but all the other continents are. Africa is home to the largest number of refugees, the greatest poverty in the world, and a cruel AIDS epidemic. I know that Commissioner Nielson and others are doing good work, but the entire Commission, including its strategic objectives, needs to pay greater attention to this continent. Finally, I would like to welcome the Commission's declaration, as it states, for the first time, that the EU is prepared unilaterally to take measures to facilitate developing countries' access to our markets. My question is: when will this become concrete? Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, we have before us a fundamental document for the future and destiny of Europe. However, among all these aspects, two, closely linked, stand out in particular: peace and stability in Europe and beyond. These are objectives that must be pursued as a priority. We have all shared this idea for some time, but we must also clearly state that these objectives cannot be achieved without enlargement, even though this may entail costs. Today, we must choose for the coming decades between a Europe that is perhaps less wealthy but a beacon of peace and civilization for the entire planet, and a Europe that is perhaps more opulent, but without prophecies. However, these goals can only be achieved if the Intergovernmental Conference, which will conclude this year, launches a constitutional reform that grants adequate and real powers to the Commission, which can no longer be the mere executor of Council decisions or Parliament's codecisions, but must play the role of true government of Europe. The first advocate of this reform should be Parliament if it truly wants to expand its role as interpreter of the will of the European people and acquire the importance that is characteristic of a truly democratic and strongly integrated Union.

In light of the events of recent days, one might wonder what the point of these intergovernmental conferences and these Treaty amendments will be, when the Heads of State and Government - in reality, the European Council - take a position in relation to a sovereign Member State by intervening in that Member State's democratic process. Everyone is free to have their own opinions about Mr. Haider - personally, I consider him a very dangerous political figure - but it is not our place to intervene in the democratic process of a sovereign and friendly country. At the intergovernmental conferences and when we review the Treaty amendments, we must take into account the fact that the EU is evolving every day, including, as we have just seen, in ways that are contrary to the Treaty. I welcome Commissioner Barnier and the Portuguese Presidency to this chamber this afternoon. February 14 will see the launch of the IGC, which will be completed by the end of the year 2000. The task is enormous, but it can be accomplished. I think there is general agreement among all the groups here this afternoon that the Helsinki agenda will not be sufficient to cover the reform needed to prepare Europe for enlargement. In other words, we must go beyond the important "Amsterdam holdovers." These include the extension of qualified majority voting—we accept this in my country, except in areas relating to taxation—the reweighting of voting in the Council to favor the larger states, and the number of Commissioners in an enlarged Europe. On the last point, Ireland wants to maintain the right to appoint a full and non-discriminatory member of the Commission, regardless of the number of Member States that join Europe. We are willing to consider a reweighting of votes in the Council of Ministers, provided that the larger Member States agree that each Member State should have a full and non-discriminatory member of the Commission. When I raise this particular point, I know that I am speaking on behalf of a large number of smaller states. During the IGC, we should also be debating the possible division of the Treaties into two parts: a policy area and a constitutional area. We are prepared to accept this division if it does not limit the control that the smaller Member States had in the renegotiation of all the Treaty policies. In other words, if we are not fully represented in the Commission, we will not contribute to the political discussions. We are therefore following this whole issue very closely. We welcome the Charter of Fundamental Rights and look forward to seeing its contents. Mr President, the Treaty of Amsterdam set the number of Members of the European Parliament at 700, and we must debate in Parliament how these 700 seats will be distributed within the enlarged Europe. Mr President, I strongly recommend the adoption of the Dimitrakopoulos/Leinen resolution. This clearly expresses not only our disappointment at the inadequacy of the agenda, but also our desire to see the Intergovernmental Conference held as soon as possible.

B5-0166/2000 by Mr Queiró, on behalf of the Union for Europe of the Nations Group, on Angola; B5-0178/2000 by Mrs Maes and others, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group, on freedom of the press in Angola. Mr President, before starting the debate on Kosovo or Mitrovica, I would like to express to you the sense of disappointment that I feel. In fact, this is not the first time that we have spoken about Kosovo. We have already adopted resolutions, but most of the time they have been a waste of time, they have had no effect. I appreciate that the Commission is always present; I appreciate that Commissioner Patten is present, with the powers that fall within his remit, but I note, along with many other colleagues, that the Council is systematically absent. However, we must also work with the Council. I note the presence of a Council official who is diligently taking notes and will report back to us, but otherwise nothing happens. I urge Parliament to change its procedures and to have the Council present at the debate on topical issues, so that we can start a direct consultation. I think we must consider this possibility. I invite you to communicate my complaints to the Bureau of Parliament. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there are two reasons why we have not signed this compromise resolution. First of all, one of our colleagues, known for his openness and tolerance, Mr Sakellariou - not to name names - forcefully imposed his veto and thus wanted to set himself up as the defender of your morality.

I believe that this is an important step, although its impact on national systems is not particularly evident. Unfortunately, to the displeasure of the rapporteur, I have to say that my group cannot accept Amendment No 3. We believe that it would be detrimental to the legal position of the creditor and to legal certainty. As regards Amendment No 6, we had tabled a similar amendment in committee. I am a little surprised when I think that you in the PSE Group did not support it at that time. We now intend to support your Amendment No 6, but, as I have already said, I wonder why you did not accept ours in committee. I also hope that transparency will be introduced and that it will be possible to make a comparison between the fastest and most effective procedures in the various States. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, the Commission would like to stress that the proposal for a regulation under consideration this evening is only and above all a reformulation of the 1995 Insolvency Convention. It is well known that the Convention is the result of many years of discussions, often difficult, often laborious, and that for this reason it represents a compromise between the principles of unity and territoriality, that is to say, between the principles underlying the different legal systems of insolvency law in force in the Member States. The awareness that the evolution of the global economic situation and, in particular, of the internal market may make it necessary to resort more frequently to insolvency proceedings, which often have a cross-border nature, fully justifies the fact that the European Union, as such, should equip itself with the binding legal instruments necessary to ensure that insolvency proceedings are carried out in compliance with a set of common structural principles and guarantee rapid execution. Unfortunately or fortunately, declarations of bankruptcy by companies will become increasingly common in our daily economic life. This will be a factor in the renewal of the business fabric that must not be blocked by the existence of slow bureaucratic procedures or obstacles that prolong the agony of no longer viable businesses. It is therefore important to try to identify a legal framework of reference that is adequate to the new needs of the globalised economy. The proposal for a regulation under consideration was not put forward by the Commission, but following a joint initiative by two Member States - Germany and Finland - under the right of initiative that they share with the Commission in this field. The Commission considers that the regulation in question does not imply any substantial change compared to the text of the Convention. As early as 1981, the Commission had expressed its position in favour of adopting the principle of unitary bankruptcy. Furthermore, this perspective had been taken up in the proposals presented by the Commission regarding a parallel procedure concerning the liquidation of businesses. Instead, the 1995 Convention ends up authorising the opening of secondary procedures, creating derogations from the general rule that the Commission would like to see accepted. Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam, the Commission would therefore have preferred the adoption of a new text which expressly supported the thesis of unity.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Central Asia and the Caspian Sea area threaten to become the Balkans of the 21st century. This is precisely why the stabilization of the large states of Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan is so important. I would therefore like to ask you about a matter within your competence, namely, the status of the negotiations for cooperation agreements with both countries, that is, political relations. This falls within your direct competence; my other question concerns Mr. Nielsen's area of expertise, specifically environmental cooperation, particularly with regard to water and the problem of cotton monocultures, which exacerbate drought. A couple of weeks ago, at the Istanbul summit, we were able to meet and hold talks with some of the Central Asian republics. It is my fervent hope that we will strengthen our relations with them. If you wish, I can send the Honorable Member a detailed analysis of exactly where we stand in the negotiation of the partnership and cooperation agreements with each of the Central Asian republics. Obviously, everyone will expect your prediction of what might happen in the future to be rather pessimistic. But I have no doubt that you are right to point out the strategic importance of Central Asia. I have also heard the Honorable Member speak about the Caucasus in the past. You are absolutely right to say that a Union that talks about conflict prevention would have to look at what it can do in these specific areas to ensure that in the future there is not the kind of conflict that has caused so much devastation in the Balkans and that has cost us far more than we would have been able to spend otherwise, had we taken more preventative measures if possible. Therefore, the Honorable Member's reflections on the strategic importance of these regions are extremely well realized. We are contributing to programs in the region that have some ecological impact. Our food programs are directly linked to structural reforms in the agricultural sector, as well as to the eradication of poverty. These programs themselves are intended to ensure that agriculture has a stronger position in these societies and does not simply consist of plundering the land. There is an ecological aspect that we must continue to prioritize. We also take note that the Member who asked the question applauded the Commissioner's response. This is not a common occurrence. Furthermore, the Commissioner did not cite any bibliography in this case. Thank you very much, Mr. Patten, for your interventions today. Question No. 35 by (H-0778/99): Subject: Greek Employment Action Plan. According to the results of the evaluation of the Employment Action Plan, Greece, along with Italy, is the main target of the Commission's observations regarding its inconsistency in terms of employment support measures and policies.

In one of the major accidents recently, it was not the cargo itself that was dangerous. The margarine and a few kilos of paint, which in principle posed no risk, caused a real disaster. We must therefore examine how requirements can be further optimized to ensure maximum safety. In conclusion, I would like to say that safety is a matter for all modes of transport. This week, we will be holding a debate on maritime safety following the Erika disaster, and we must also debate air safety objectives later this year. I want to stress that safety is a priority for the Commission. As I will say in the debate on the Erika, we are not waiting for a disaster to address the safety aspect; we are working on it in the margins of these events. However, these events demonstrate the urgency of an effective response to problems of this kind. I would like to thank all the speakers once again, and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Koch. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. Transport of dangerous goods by road The next item is the report (A5-0104/1999) by Mr Koch, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council (COM(1999) 158 - C5-0004/1999 - 1999/0083(COD) ) amending Directive 94/55/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States with regard to the transport of dangerous goods by road. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States with regard to the transport of dangerous goods by road, which entered into force on 1 January 1997, contains a number of transitional provisions whose validity is limited and linked to the completion of certain standardization work by CEN, the European Committee for Standardization. Delays in CEN's work are now causing problems in the application of this directive. In particular, annexes cannot be adapted in line with technical and industrial developments. I regret this, because we have to act because others have failed to do their work. In this respect, I accept the proposal under discussion today to amend Directive 94/55/EC. Failure by the European Union to act would oblige Member States to amend their national legislation for a short period, namely until the CEN's work is completed, which would cause unnecessary costs and uncertainty. The amendment to the directive on today's agenda therefore does not change the existing harmonization of the transport of dangerous goods within the Community. It merely extends transitional rules by postponing deadlines, deletes provisions that are no longer applicable, and regulates the procedures for a) ad hoc transport of dangerous goods and b) the adoption of less stringent national provisions, particularly for the transport of very small quantities of dangerous goods within strictly localized areas. Thus, the amendment to the directive is entirely in keeping with the principle of subsidiarity; it gives Member States more powers. The EU Commission decides whether Member States may adopt certain of their own regulations. It is assisted in this process by a committee of experts on the transport of dangerous goods, acting in accordance with the regulatory procedure. The modalities for the exercise of these implementing powers conferred on the Commission were revised by a Council Decision of June 1999.

I regret the delay with which LEADER, like the other three initiatives, was submitted to Parliament and the resulting delay in the entire procedure. Finally, I am concerned about the small amount allocated, especially considering that the programme is open to all the territories of the Union and will be applied for one year longer than the previous LEADER II. I would like to thank the Commission services for their willingness and cooperation, and I would like to thank my colleagues on the Committee on Agriculture for their contribution through their amendments. . (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my report on EQUAL is an opinion in the context of the consultation process on a new Community initiative aimed at transnational cooperation to promote new methods of combating all forms of discrimination and inequality in the context of the labour market. The report is quite long as it also includes the opinions of four other committees, namely those on industry, regional policy, women and home affairs. This Community initiative is the successor to two previous programmes, "ADAPT and EMPLOYMENT", and has a very low budget of approximately EUR 2.8 billion. It adopts a completely new approach, aiming to develop innovative employment models within the framework of transnational development partnerships at geographical or sectoral level. The clear intention is to have targeted projects developed at transnational level, projects that follow the four pillars on which the employment guidelines are based, namely employability, entrepreneurship, adaptability and strengthening equal opportunities. This objective is certainly to be welcomed and is also widely supported in the European Parliament. Furthermore, EQUAL should be integrated into the national action plans for employment, i.e. its implementation should also be verifiable through the aforementioned action plans. It is an important Community initiative financed together with the other three, URBAN, LEADER and INTERREG, under the Structural Funds. In my report, I proposed reducing excessive administrative burdens and making the approach to development partnerships a little more flexible and open. I believe that technical assistance is certainly necessary, but, due to the problems that have arisen with the previous Technical Assistance Offices (TAOs), we must avoid setting up new TAOs before Parliament's resolution has been adopted, thus preventing political responsibility from being transferred to technical assistance. However, there is still a need for technical assistance. Particular attention is also paid to disseminating results and mutual learning through the dissemination of best practices and mainstreaming. I have worked to ensure that the report receives the widest possible consensus, which has led to a reduction in the number of amendments - from 100 in committee to 22 in plenary - and has also allowed for numerous possibilities for compromise. A compromise has also been reached on the issue of asylum seekers. In this regard, Madam President, in order to allow us to further finalise the details, I would ask you to vote on the EQUAL report on Wednesday instead of tomorrow.

Mr President, I have a question about a specific, real case where the precautionary principle could be applied. It concerns brominated flame retardants. The problem is only now coming to the fore, with high concentrations both in the environment and in the human body. Many people say that these substances pose serious risks, while others tend to downplay them. Recently, in the Council, both Sweden and Denmark urged the Commission to take the initiative to ban brominated flame retardants. I therefore wonder whether such a ban is being prepared and whether such an initiative might not fit perfectly into your vision of the precautionary principle itself. Mr President, I thank Mr Sjöstedt for asking this question: the problem of brominated flame retardants is a serious problem. It was raised very recently in the Environment Council by a number of ministers who are asking the Commission to study the terms and indicate how to intervene. We are now looking at the issue to see what the current state of knowledge is and what can be done. I would like to point out, however, that the precautionary principle does not necessarily mean a ban or a total ban. A range of different measures can be envisaged: we cannot immediately speak of a ban. As regards brominated flame retardants now, it may be that, in time, we will come to a ban, but it is important to remember that the precautionary principle allows for the full range of possible policy interventions and measures. This is a very topical issue. The Commission will have to do its job by examining the issue thoroughly before it decides on what to do. You said that the precautionary principle should not become a disguised form of trade protectionism. Is there agreement on this point on both sides of the Atlantic? I think we will have problems, especially with hormone-treated meat and genetically modified crops. Are we sure that the Americans' interpretation of this principle coincides with ours? Mr. President, I am pleased to announce that in Montreal we signed a protocol on biological safety. There, we managed to reach an international consensus on the definition of the precautionary principle. I believe that having managed to sign that protocol represents a decisive step forward. I believe that it will set an example for future discussions on the precautionary principle and that it can serve as an example of the interpretation of that principle, which is recognized as an instrument that is both important and effective. Mr. President, I have two questions that I will try to explain as briefly as possible. My first question concerns the application of the precautionary principle. I understand that there are some uncertainties regarding its interpretation. Is it perhaps necessary to first conduct a risk assessment, including a cost-benefit analysis? If that is the case, I find it very disturbing, because the cost-benefit analysis should not have been used as a criterion for deciding whether or not to resort to the precautionary principle: it is the precautionary principle that takes precedence.

On the same basis, it is essential that Member States comply with their obligation to report to the Commission on aid granted to their steel undertakings, as required by Article 7 of the Code in question. The Commission suggests that Member States send these reports within two months of the end of each half-year and, in any case, on an annual basis, without being obliged to request them. Like the rapporteur, I welcomed the Commission's report even though it did not cover all aspects of aid. Although the Steel Aid Code is very clearly worded, the Commission has on several occasions authorised aid to steel undertakings which did not fall within the categories provided for in the Code. In the interests of greater fairness, the Aid Code should therefore be applied rigorously or it should be amended if the Commission wishes to authorise aid other than that which is currently legally permitted. Finally, there is the question of the consequences of the expiry of the ECSC Treaty. It will be necessary to ensure that the aid system continues beyond 2002. On this point, I believe that only a Council regulation can provide the necessary legal certainty and guarantee the formal prohibition of any aid not covered by the code. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of Mr Langen's report and I am now waiting for the Commission to respond to our questions and requests. (The sitting, suspended at 1.05 pm, resumes at 3.00 pm) Oil-polluted sea in France The next item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the oil-polluted sea in France. Commissioner Loyola de Palacio has the floor on behalf of the Commission and will open the debate with her speech. Mr President, I speak on behalf of the PPE/DE Group but also as a Breton elected representative, directly affected and shocked by these events. With Françoise Grossetête and the PPE/DE, we have tabled a motion for a resolution. Today, we are faced with a compromise proposal and I am delighted about that. The Erika sinking is actually a European issue because it mutilates and soils some of the most beautiful European beaches with very serious consequences for tourism, for those who carry out maritime activities, for environmental defenders and then because it involves regulation and control whose natural dimension is clearly European. Certainly a catastrophe of this magnitude would not have been possible off the American coast. Why? Because the Americans were able to learn from the Exxon Valdez catastrophe and in 1990 they drafted the Oil Pollution Act which confers greater responsibility since it can imply the liability of the charterer, is more binding and above all provides for better control through various regulations and in particular through the American Coast Guard. If we had had similar provisions, I repeat, the catastrophe would certainly not have occurred. For this reason we believe that it is necessary to review the applicable legislation and in particular the 1992 Protocol which exempted the charterers, in this case the oil company that chartered, from any liability.

There is talk of pre-accession aid, and this falls under heading 7. Last year, Parliament accepted, exceptionally, that the sums earmarked for this expenditure should be included in heading 4, and in this way the two candidate countries are not being treated on an equal footing with the candidate countries of Central and Eastern Europe, which they should be, in accordance with the declarations of the Helsinki European Council. Funds must therefore be set aside in heading 7, where a revision of the financial perspective is needed. This is the crucial point. The essential issue is that the money intended for pre-accession aid for Cyprus and Malta should be taken from heading 7, and that a revision of the financial perspective should be carried out, because if the Council does not support this measure, it is effectively acting contrary to its own decisions in Helsinki in December. As regards the amount mentioned in the Brok report, EUR 130 million, I would like to say, on behalf of the Liberal Group, that we must define an amount, we must negotiate until we have established the size of the amount. The most important thing is that a multiannual programme is guaranteed and that it is included in the correct heading, so that programming can be started for Cyprus and Malta. Mr President, the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance supports the decision taken by the Helsinki European Council that the resolution of the conflict cannot be a precondition for Cyprus's accession. Strong pressure must be maintained on the Government of Cyprus, but the will of the majority of the population cannot be the object of a blackmail, of blackmail, of a part of it, also because we express serious doubts about the representativeness of the government of that part of the island. It is clear that the window of opportunity - the "janela de oportunidades", mentioned by the Presidency - must be exploited to the full. But we are also convinced that, although Turkish-Greek relations have improved, this cannot be enough. The solution to the conflict in Cyprus depends above all on improving relations between the two communities, with a view to the establishment - hopefully not too far away - of a federation. In particular, we must work to resolve the issue of establishing effective freedom of movement, the problem of demilitarisation and the disarmament of the island. The European Union must more decisively assume, beyond financial support - which is certainly important - an active role as guarantor and promoter of contacts between the two communities, by establishing confidence-building forums and programmes. I would like to say that at this moment I greatly miss, within the European Parliament, Alex Langer, who was a builder of peace and an example for all of us of how to build coexistence between peoples. Mr President, the evocation of dialogue between the two Cypriot factions under the aegis of the UN reminds us that 26 years after the invasion of the island by the Turkish army, from the occupation of almost 40 percent of the territory with 35 000 soldiers and heavy military vehicles, the settlement of over 50 000 settlers continues in total violation of the relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions.

Now, for this to actually happen, it is essential that it remains a public service. Only in this way can we guarantee that the network, from collection to delivery, remains integral, that it cannot be fragmented or used only in part, according to agreements made with postal service operators. But, in the meantime, we know that the Commission, following the directive on common rules for Community postal services, commissioned studies, the results of which have not been forwarded to the European Parliament, according to which the impacts of implementing this directive are unknown, either in terms of the service offered to citizens or from the point of view of current European postal operators, both in terms of economic aspects and employment. Therefore, in our opinion, the entire process of implementing the directive, including its timetable, should be interrupted. And any change in the current situation must be preceded by a rigorous study of its various implications, always keeping in mind the objective of guaranteeing a high-quality public service, the maintenance of current public operators and existing jobs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to fundamentally support this proposal while starting by asking whether what the previous speaker said - namely, that we need, on the one hand, a competitive, innovative high-quality service and, on the other hand, that this service must be a public service - is not a contradiction in itself. I think we have a differentiated approach here. European policy has liberalized monopoly markets - energy, telecommunications and air navigation - and the consumer has always been the focus. The objective was precisely to offer a better service, and it is also the user who must be at the center of the liberalization of the postal service. I believe that the consumer can decide for himself and define what he needs. For this, it needs no government, no parliament, and it needs no Commission either! The postal market is following behind from afar, and unfortunately, we have wasted precious time. I think we should also give the postal service the chance to respond to new developments. I refer here to the very good intervention by my colleague Mr. Rübig, who also spoke here about e-commerce. This development will happen very quickly and will bring new demands for the various companies in our society, demands that must be met very quickly and very flexibly. I believe that a liberalized market accelerates this development more than a less liberalized market. Furthermore, there is also the opportunity to present European policy in a positive light. We must also seize this opportunity because citizens are always asking the question "why" Europe is there. These are the areas where citizens can clearly see the usefulness of Europe. But I am also pleased that the Competition Commissioner, Mr Monti, is here in person today, because he is pursuing an excellent policy. And I would like to touch on an area where, in my opinion, Parliament and the Commission must, and this is also evident from this debate, consider whether to draw a line on competition. We approve of competition as an element of the social market economy - we do so also because we want to make this economic system as good as possible.

I am referring in particular to the Structural Instrument for Pre-Accession (SSPA), the implementation of which I will be responsible for in the coming weeks. Ladies and gentlemen, as you can see, we have only just launched the new programming and we are already together reflecting on the impact of enlargement of the Union on our structural policy. The sixth periodic report, on which, Mr Berend, you have expressed a broadly positive opinion, provides a good basis for reflection for us and for me. I thank you sincerely for your contribution to the reflection on future orientations and also for the good application of the guidelines for the period 2000-2006. Approval of the minutes of the previous sitting The minutes of the previous sitting have been distributed. Are there any objections? Mr President, in response to the invitation addressed to me yesterday afternoon by the President of Parliament, I would like to speak on behalf of my group on point 11 of the minutes of yesterday's sitting concerning the establishment of the order of business. First of all, I believe that the issue raised yesterday by the Chairman of the Socialist Group regarding the reinsertion of the discussion with the President of the Commission on the strategic objectives for the next five years into the agenda was so important to the other Members who had asked to speak briefly that their request could have been granted. I would like to make this clear, even though, with all due respect, I disagreed with the motion of the Chairman of the Socialist Group and voted against it. My second point - which I would have liked to make yesterday before the vote - is that Parliament, as other Members pointed out yesterday, can only operate truly effectively if it works in close cooperation and synergy with the European Commission. We should also have the humility to admit that if we had wanted a strategic discussion accompanied not only by a presentation and a clarification by the President of the Commission, but also by a five-year programme, we should have organised ourselves in detail beforehand - and not waited until the week before the debate in the Chamber - so that we could debate and report our wishes to the Commission in good time.
