I would like us to draw a lesson from this experience: whenever in future discussions of great importance are put on the agenda between Parliament and the European Commission, all the details regarding our mutual expectations should be clarified at least a good month in advance, first between the political groups in this Parliament and then between Parliament and the Commission, so as not to find ourselves at the last moment in the unpleasant position of needlessly causing a rift in institutional relations. After having looked at the articles published in the press last Friday, I think I can say that the Commission, in the person of its President, has shown commendable moderation in commenting on the facts and I appreciate that immensely. I hope we will learn the lesson and avoid repeating a similar experience based, in my opinion, on a misinterpretation of expectations, rather than on bad faith on the part of one of the two institutions.

Unfortunately, as everyone recognized during the military actions in Kosovo, civilian sectors, particularly those related to infrastructure that directly affect the population, and even inhabited areas were hit during NATO air actions. This is a recognized fact; it happens in all wars, and the Kosovo war is not a clean war, it is not an exemplary war; it is the possible war. I know that it was a necessary war. It was the possible war, it was the necessary war to put an end to what was an absolutely unacceptable aggression and completely condemned by the entire international community. Mr. Deputy Speaker, regardless of the interpretation we may make after the fact - it is easy to make an after-the-fact interpretation if there had been no action - I think that, given what happened in Bosnia-Herzegovina, as well as the impunity for what happened there and the continuation of that impunity, we can make a less catastrophic interpretation of NATO's military action in Kosovo. Question No. 4 of (H-0028/00): Subject: Turkish blockade of Armenia Given that the European Union is actively promoting the development of social, economic and political relations with Armenia, within the framework of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed on 12 October 1999, what measures is the Council taking to persuade the Turkish Government to lift the economic blockade of Armenia? Has the time come for the Turkish Government to lift the economic blockade of Armenia? Mr President, I would like to thank the representative of the Council Presidency for his answer. I am, however, a little saddened that this is primarily seen on a bilateral level, whereas ultimately it is a triangular relationship. We provide partnership funds and have a cooperation agreement to help Armenia, and yet the aid is proving ineffective because Turkey maintains an economic blockade, so that many things cannot reach the Armenians. Negotiations are being held with Turkey with a view to its possible accession, and it is in all our interests that any state that wants to become a member of the EU also maintains friendly relations with its neighbors. Can you not exert greater influence over Turkey to facilitate peaceful developments, to give the Armenians access to the development necessary for continued cooperation? You are absolutely right, Madam, to say that we must take advantage of relations with Turkey precisely so that this country can play a constructive role in this situation and, in particular, so that it becomes part of the solution and ceases to be part of the problem. We believe that the fact that Turkey has entered a new phase of relations with the European Union and is faced with the need to respond to the European Union's positions on foreign policy and common security represents - it must be said - a test of this country's will with regard to the European Union's priorities in its relations with the outside world.

We have considered this problem, can you believe it? We have considered it and are examining it very carefully, particularly thanks to the concerns you have expressed. Frankly, I do not believe that these fears are ultimately justified. The Commission's proposal gives it a central role in determining the direction of competition policy. The reform does not imply any reduction in the Commission's work, but rather a refocusing of it on the most important issues. It will lead to a gradual development of the European competition culture - I would like to emphasize this because the expression used by President Randzio-Plath, which I fully share, struck me deeply. The reform will therefore lead to a transplantation, a rooting, in the field of the European competition culture, where today various small, but not uniform, plants of different national competition cultures thrive. The fifteen national laws will gradually be abandoned to give way to a broader use of Community law that can be applied by a greater number of actors. This, I would like to emphasize, is a communitarization and not a renationalization of competition law. Consistency in application. The risk of inconsistent application of competition rules must be borne in mind, but I believe it should not be exaggerated. Like many other provisions of the Treaty, Articles 81(1) and 82 have, after all, been applied for decades by national authorities and judges, and it does not seem to me that this has created any major problems. In a regime of legal exception, maintaining consistency will depend first and foremost on the clarity of the substantive rules. The Commission will strive to refine the legislative framework, both through acts of general scope and through its decision-making practice. Effective conflict prevention mechanisms will also need to be established, and the White Paper contains information and consultation mechanisms. On this subject, I would like to say a few words about the idea, which I think is excellent, of Mrs Riis-Jørgensen and Mr Huhne, namely the idea of monitoring enforcement. So that is the idea of monitoring enforcement. I think this idea is sound and we will probably adopt it. Although we deeply respect the work done by national competition authorities, among others, it is clear that we will scrutinize the way in which EC legislation is applied by national authorities and the courts. That is why the Commission wants to retain the right to remove a case from the hands of a national competition authority in the event that the application is not correct. This may alleviate your concerns somewhat, Mrs Peijs. (EN) To respond to Mr Evans' point about the impact on businesses, it is important to say that the cost-benefit analysis should be carried out seriously. The purpose of publishing the White Paper is, after all, to gather feedback from businesses and other sources. We have received a large number of excellent comments and contributions, which provide us with the necessary information to conduct a cost-benefit assessment for businesses. We will carefully consider all this material before preparing a legislative proposal for a new regulation.

You will certainly say yes, but I would like to know from you: Do you gentlemen also know what the consequences of this are? My next question, Ms. Wallström: When will you begin to apply this in legislation, for example in chemicals legislation, for example in legislation in other areas? My final question: Will we be able to see where this has been applied in the legislation? In other words, will there be a separate sheet in every proposal stating that the precautionary principle has been reviewed and that this is the conclusion reached? Thank you very much, Ms. Roth-Behrendt, for these questions. Of course, the entire Commission shares this view. This is a joint communication prepared by the three of us – David Byrne, Erkki Liikanen, and myself – but it was also adopted unanimously in the Commission today. It received strong support from the other Commissioners and is the result of consultations with the various services within the Commission. So we have worked through this document very carefully, and I am sure that everyone will be able to explain the guidelines and principles set out in this document. I would even say that we are already using this working method on various difficult issues, such as the question of a new strategy in the field of chemicals. And I am sure that we will also make it clear when we are working with this principle. Just recently, we applied the precautionary principle in a case involving the ban on phthalates in soft PVC toys, and of course, we use it in various environmental areas. It has been used primarily in the environmental field, but also in issues of human health. So we will try to make it very clear how and when it should be applied. Mr President, Commissioner, on the relationship between science and the use of the precautionary principle, the communication states that applying the precautionary principle requires a political decision precisely when science does not yet have any evidence. This, of course, transfers a great deal of power to science. We can ask ourselves which scientists will provide this documentation and what they will defend. Since the communication also states that a sufficiently recognized minority of scientists is sufficient to apply the precautionary principle, I ask: what is the definition of a recognized minority? How do you describe it? How do you arrive at a recognized minority? Regarding the political decision, my question is: who will make this political decision? The Commission? Or the Council? To what extent will the European Parliament be able to play a role? What role is intended for the scientific committees? What will the role of the food authorities you will establish be? Finally, will this decision-making be transparent and public? Those are my three questions. Yes, Mr. President, that's right. There were many difficult issues that weren't always very clear and explicit, but I want to try to answer some of the questions. Who will make the decision, who are the decision-makers? Well, that depends on who the legislators are. This is part of risk management.

I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether, after spending a few hours working with Members of the European Parliament in this Chamber, he has had the opportunity to assess what they are worth in terms of remuneration. Mr President, since the debate on the remuneration of Members of the European Parliament is not limited to your country but also to mine, I know exactly how much the remuneration of Members of the European Parliament is. I am therefore fully aware of the problem. Mr President, I would like to thank you for this answer and to table a supplementary question that is somewhat similar to the one asked by Mr Sjöstedt. We both come from Sweden. In our country, the bulk of taxes are paid in the form of local taxes, because public services are managed locally and because they are quite extensive. In Sweden, there is a problem of trust in politicians, not least in European politicians in this Parliament. In your opinion, what impact would it have on our credibility as politicians if we were granted the right to use services in our place of residence - school, health care, etc. - but without paying taxes, without contributing to them? In your opinion, how would this impact on our credibility as politicians? Mr President-in-Office of the Council, this is a question to which you are not obliged to answer because it is truly philosophical. But if you want to delve into the realm of philosophy, please! No, Mr President, philosophy does not tempt me. These are fundamental questions that have to do with the very matrix of the statute of a Member of Parliament and its role within the political system. I do not want to delve into this type of discussion, as it seems to me that it could go à prejuger, to use a French expression, of the interpretation that the Portuguese Presidency will give in the context of the negotiations on the Statute for Members, in which it is involved. I would ask you to excuse me from making any comments on this matter. Since Council Question Time is over, Questions No. 11 to No. 35 will receive a written reply. This concludes Question Time. (The sitting was suspended at 19.05 and resumed at 21.00) Address by the President of the Czech Republic, Václav Havel Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honour for me to extend, on behalf of the European Parliament, a warm welcome to the President of the Czech Republic, Václav Havel. I would also like to welcome Mrs Havel, who is in the gallery. (Applause) This is not the first time that we have welcomed you to Parliament, Mr President. You already had the opportunity to address a plenary session in Strasbourg almost six years ago, in March 1994, and many of us, who were already parliamentarians at that time, still have vivid memories of that. Indeed, immediately after the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty, you spoke out in favour of strengthening European values, of creating a European ethic, of opening the Union towards the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. This means that for many citizens, not only in your country, you embody that Europe of values to which we feel deeply attached.

The Commission reaffirmed and reaffirms today that it shares the concerns underlying the Portuguese Presidency's declaration of 31 January. These concerns are legitimate and well-founded. There is no need to recall here the political career of Jörg Haider and his numerous public statements, which are xenophobic and racist, and therefore anti-European. The fact that a clearly extremist, racist, and xenophobic party comes to power in a Member State of the European Union cannot fail to concern the other participating States in the European project, just as it does not leave the European Commission indifferent. Secondly, the Commission reiterated and reiterates its commitment to continue exercising its duty as guarantor of the Treaties, particularly with regard to Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty on European Union. One of the important innovations of the Treaty of Amsterdam was precisely the explicit clarification of the fundamental principles that are the common heritage of the Member States and the establishment of a mechanism to monitor their compliance and to react in the event of a violation of one of these principles. The Commission thus demonstrated, in practice, its commitment to one of the basic principles—that of the rule of law—which imposes on the Commission the obligation to act within the limits established by the Treaties, and within this framework lies the declaration of 1 February. The Commission is not a State; it cannot and should not act as if it were. But to respond specifically to the honourable Member's question, I must recall that the mechanism established by Article 7(1) of the Treaty on European Union requires, for its activation, verification—I quote—"of a serious and persistent violation of the principles enshrined in Article 6." A serious and persistent violation is—I repeat—the indispensable condition for the Commission to propose to the Council the adoption of measures against a Member State. It seems clear to me that the conditions for its application to the situation in Austria are not met. For the rest, we all hope—I don't think I'm mistaken in saying this—that these conditions of serious and persistent violation of human rights and democracy never arise, neither in relation to Austria nor in relation to any other State of the Union. But I want to assure you here today of my personal commitment and that of the Commission, as President Prodi reaffirmed this morning, to do everything necessary to ensure that the application of Article 7 is not necessary. But I also want to assure you that we will not hesitate to apply it, if necessary. Values are at stake that are too fundamental and essential to allow for contemplation or compromise. People and governments must be judged more by what they do than by what they say. And in the case of Austria, the statements are at the very least contradictory. On the one hand, any of us can compile a series of incendiary phrases from the leader of the Austrian Liberal Party. On the other, the program of the new Austrian government renews its commitment to the defense of democracy and human rights.

In March of last year, a member of Sam Rainsy's party was assassinated by a group of men in military uniform in Kandal province. In September, two party members were arrested on suspicion of involvement in a rocket attack on the prime minister. Note that this is the only Cambodian party without a military wing. In October, a parliamentarian from the same party was kidnapped by men in uniform and released only after a ransom was paid. The pattern of intimidation is clear. But other things are still happening in Cambodia: torture of prisoners, involvement of the army and police in the trafficking of women and children, excessive preventive arrests. All of this is on the agenda. Even more serious is the government's refusal to have the Khmer Rouge leaders tried by an international tribunal. It is true that the civil war in Cambodia is over and political tensions are lower. However, the way in which the political opposition is currently being treated is causing us deep concern, and if it continues this way, it must have consequences for the Union's relations with Cambodia. Mr. President, a new doctrine is emerging in international law, according to which no state may any longer treat its citizens and the people living on its territory haphazardly, and the sovereignty of a state can no longer prevent third parties from intervening in cases of serious human rights violations, even in cases where the leaders of a state were legally or even democratically elected. Vivid examples of this were the Pinochet-Ugarte case and Kosovo, or, less blatantly but within the Union itself, the debates over the formation of the new Austrian government. This development will now be jeopardized in Cambodia if the former leadership of the oppressive regime cannot be prosecuted. At the same time, the fight against impunity is being jeopardized. The situation should also remind us that ratification of the treaty establishing the International Criminal Court has been shamefully slow. Mr President, yesterday's debate on human rights was extremely useful. I am pleased that we once again had the opportunity to examine a number of regions of the world - Kosovo, Angola, Chechnya and Cambodia - where the protection of human rights is a particularly great challenge. First of all, with regard to Kosovo, the Committee fully shares the concerns expressed in these draft resolutions regarding the general policy towards Kosovo, the continuation of ethnic violence and the prisoners in Serbian jails. In Kosovo, as in the region, our efforts are aimed at short- and medium-term recovery and long-term stabilization. We particularly support the development of a free, democratic and multi-ethnic society. Our aid programs in the areas of democratization and human rights should continue to build trust in general and try to build trust between different communities in particular.

B5-0173/2000 by MEPs Papayannakis and Sjöstedt, on behalf of the GUE/NGL, B5-0179/2000 by MEPs Schroedter and others, on behalf of the Greens/EFA Group, on the environmental disaster in the waters of the Danube. Mr President, this week we debated the Water Framework Directive, and the disaster in Romania shows us once again how seriously we must take water protection. This disaster has raised a number of important issues that concern us as a European Union. We welcome the promise that the rivers will be cleaned up with EU help. Raising environmental awareness, both in Romania and, more generally, in Central and Eastern Europe, is at least as important. We welcome the speed of Commissioner Wallström's visit there, as it can contribute to this awareness. Ultimately, this is a candidate state, and this disaster adds to the already existing concern about whether all candidate states will comply with EU environmental rules on time. The polluter must pay. I wonder if the European Union can pass on these kinds of costs to the environmental cowboys operating in the so-called Wild East by exploiting the weakness of the environmental legislation there. I would be in favour of that. Mr President, Commissioner, ecological disasters follow one another and, unfortunately, are similar. There is reason to be dismayed, once again, by this serious pollution that is now polluting the fourth largest wetland in Europe. The Danube Delta is in danger. As in Spain in April 1998, as in Brittany and Vendée since last December, this time again, an exceptional natural site is seriously threatened. In its resolutions, the European Parliament has constantly drawn attention to the dangers of this type that threaten our environment, disrupt our ecosystem and, once again, weaken populations. This new disaster raises the problem of integrating the acquis communautaire in environmental matters for the candidate countries. The authorities of these states, which are still very fragile from an environmental point of view, must overcome numerous obstacles. First, they should be able to prevent this type of spillage more effectively by remediating the most critical industrial sites; second, they should have sufficient technical means to stop such pollution and reduce its scale; and finally, they should be able to implement restoration programmes for the most affected and most sensitive sites. Today, the banks and waters of more than four rivers running through four states are polluted. This is why the European Union must focus its efforts and pressure on the urgent need for all candidate countries to align themselves with Community environmental protection standards. But beyond this, it is the technologies and means implemented to prevent, and to deal quickly and effectively with, this type of disaster that are at stake.

Finally, in relation to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, European citizens must become aware of their citizenship. The euro and employment are not enough, nor even security. They need a "European soul", as a distinguished Spanish professor said. Mr President, unlike some speakers who have spoken previously, I want to return to the words spoken by the Portuguese ministers and Commissioner Vitorino. The words of this trio were music to our ears, as Mr Ceyhun said. As with any kind of music, the tune played must be in tune and properly orchestrated. Many of us in this House are very optimistic about the next six months. The tune that will be played will be the one that the people of Europe will listen to and will want to hear the right kind of tune. As has been said this afternoon, it will help to forget some of the unpleasant tunes that we have heard during the European elections and over the last few months. The Treaty of Amsterdam and the Tampere Council were based on this project of an area of freedom, security and justice in the European Union. There is, however, one area that is very important and Parliament must be involved in it, and that is the area of scrutiny. There are many laws - and I very much welcome the Portuguese programme that was presented to us last week - but we must be absolutely sure that there is scrutiny, that Members of this Parliament and Members of national parliaments and the citizens of Europe are aware of all that they entail. We must also make sure that the details are applicable, adequate and relevant for the various countries. I would like to draw attention to some aspects of the resolutions that we have been discussing this afternoon, one or two of which have already been mentioned. I welcome the trend towards recognition of judicial systems in the various countries and cooperation in the fight against crime. This is an area to which the citizens of Europe will respond with interest and with which they will be satisfied. The Commission and the Council must be aware, however, that many of us in this House have reservations about the EURODAC system, for example. We accept the Council's leading role in this area, but there are some reservations and I am sure that the Council will listen to what MEPs have to say when this issue is discussed. Mr Schulz said earlier that he was not sure what a 'scoreboard' is. Anyone who is English or British or follows cricket knows what it is. A scoreboard is used to indicate the score and it must be up to date, clear and visible. I am sure that Commissioner Vitorino will ensure that this is the case. At the end of six months, I hope that the music will still be playing and that Europeans will still be listening. Mr President, I would like to welcome the President-in-Office of the Council and his colleague from the Ministry of Justice, Mr Costa, and thank them for the welcome they gave to my committee in Lisbon last week and for the constructive meeting we had. Amsterdam and Tampere have given us a lot of work to do together, as demonstrated by the excellent motion for a resolution tabled today by Mrs Terrón i Cusí.

To do this, we need a European Commission that, beyond good intentions, clarifies its guidelines and makes every effort to monitor the commitment of these resources by the Member States. Italy, for example, has had problems in the use of the Structural Funds in recent years, mainly due to excessive bureaucracy, poor information and the limited involvement of economic and social operators at local level. There are therefore two points to which I would like to draw the Commission's attention: firstly, we need to make the best use of concertation as a method of coordination and participation in decisions by all local and regional operators, precisely to avoid imbalances and inequalities; secondly, we need a real effort to simplify and make administrative processes transparent, which are too often unnecessarily long and complex to the point of jeopardising access to the Funds, something that small and medium-sized European enterprises in particular complain about. I conclude, Mr President, by saying that it is rather serious that the Commission communication has paid so little attention to territorial pacts and, above all, to ways of combating unemployment among women and young people. Mr President, like Mr Evans, I am particularly pleased to be able to stand up to make my first speech in this Parliament during the debate on such an important issue, especially given that I represent the West Midlands, a region of the United Kingdom that has so far benefited from funding under Objective 2. However, the report before us tonight is a clear example of how, if we are not very careful, we can produce ideas that seem great but which in fact lack substance and therefore prove useless to those who should immediately benefit from them. The intention of the report is good but, as often happens when we deal with these issues, its objectives are not clearly defined and it lacks a solid basis that could make it of any use. That is why my group and I are proposing three substantial amendments and additions to the text, not so much to take away from the proposal, but to make it more relevant to those to whom it is intended to serve as a guide. Let me explain our reasoning. First, we want to ensure that the resources of the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund are used appropriately. Past experience has taught us that we, as elected representatives of European taxpayers, must demand probity and financial transparency in the disbursement and control of these funds. Our amendments and additions are therefore aimed at finding indicators of profitability in the process of granting and spending the funds. Second, too often large sums of money are spent on projects whose results at the start of programming are inevitably vague. But halfway through or at the end of that period there is no effective way to stop a project that has proven to be useless. Therefore, our additions call for the provision of practically implementable termination strategies, so that not only is there the necessary guarantee in relation to current expenditure, often passed on to the taxpayer, but that the well-known syndrome can also be avoided whereby money continues to be spent to carry forward a project that has already proven to be a failure.

These inspections can take place on the road, in ports or other parking areas, or, as regards public service vehicles, generally at the owners' premises. Indeed, several Member States already carry out checks of this kind, so-called "roadside checks," as provided for in the directive, that is, somewhat unexpectedly. This is perhaps truly the best way to achieve effective monitoring of the condition of vehicles using our road network. I would like to say that the Commission is aware of Parliament's concern that this proposal could lead to discrimination against private hauliers or against commercial vehicles from certain countries or even certain makes of vehicle, and that its rapporteur intends, with his main recommendation, that the penalties imposed by Member States on owners be harmonised as a prerequisite for the application of this directive. We share this concern but believe that Amendment 2 is too radical, and in this sense we would support Amendment 3, which captures the spirit of what we are all seeking while offering sufficient flexibility. We also accept Amendment 1, and I would like to respond to what Mr Bouwman said. We are very concerned about the fact that vehicles are circulating on the Union's roads whose drivers are citizens of third countries, particularly candidate countries, and who do not have employment contracts in accordance with Community rules or those of a Community State, but simply follow the standards of those third countries, in many cases candidate countries, or sometimes not even that, because there are no appropriate checks in those third countries. I have therefore written to all the Transport Ministers of the fifteen Member States of the Union to initiate a debate on this issue and also to request a report on their experiences with such cases in their countries and what positive proposals they can put forward to resolve this problem, which is of great concern to us and which could have negative repercussions for road safety, which must be our primary concern, and for fair competition, to which we in the Commission also attach importance. In this spirit, I hope that we can address these issues at the next Transport Council at the end of this month, as well as all the issues, as Mr. Watts said, relating to road safety in general, since the Portuguese Government has identified it as one of the key issues during its Presidency. Based on the significant progress achieved in recent years, I believe that much remains to be done, because 42,000 to 43,000 European citizens dying on the roads is too high a figure. Greater efforts must be made. But on the issue of drivers from third countries, I would like to say that we hope to have an answer by the end of the month, and in any case, we will address it in the Council. And in the context of a question or initiative, I will be able to provide an answer here in Parliament, either during the plenary session or in committee. Otherwise, I certainly hope that we will be able to put forward a concrete proposal in the foreseeable future that will enable us to effectively and genuinely combat such abuses.

This does not prevent these Member States from taking measures related to public policy within the framework of the prior declaration obligation. The Commission also finds the proposal that legal residence in a Member State remain valid for three months after the expiry of the card's validity period unacceptable. It is unacceptable for a third-country national to continue residing in the host country for a longer period after providing services. For this reason, the Commission supports Ms. Palacio's Amendment 22 on both counts. Regarding the second proposal, the Commission understands the desire to clarify what is meant by a self-employed person and wishes to provide a solution for this in the amended proposal. These are some preliminary observations on the most important amendments. I hope you will allow me again at the end of this debate, when all speakers have spoken, the opportunity to go into detail on the various amendments. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the vast majority of members of the PPE Group will vote tomorrow in favor of the amendments from the Committee on Legal Affairs and the amended version. I will limit myself to commenting on two points. First of all, we must ask ourselves what the proposed directive is intended to achieve—in the literal sense of the term. On the one hand, there are the interests of the economy and also of the individual. In my considerations, I assume that this is an honest individual who does a good job. On the other hand, there are the interests of the Member States, which, for those affected, should perhaps proceed from the idea that this is a worst-case scenario. If we lean toward one of the extremes, namely the interests of the Member States, there are undoubtedly sufficient reasons to make the service provision card subject to relatively strict conditions. From this perspective, it is legitimate to introduce the obligation for prior declaration, even if the card is implemented. If I opt for the other extreme, that is, for the fewest possible formalities, I run the risk of the procedure coming to nothing, since, in that case, this directive will certainly not have the approval of the Member States. In other words, it's one of two things. Either I have a directive on the service provision card that actually doesn't allow the card to be issued to anyone, since the demands placed on the economy are too rigid, or I find myself without a directive. Both outcomes are unsatisfactory. Perhaps this is why, as we are told, the negotiations within the Council are also at a standstill. We have struggled to find a point of intersection between one interest—public policy—and another. We have struggled to find the simplest solution. We want a solution that imposes demands on the economy, but which, once these demands are met, guarantees simple implementation.

May I suggest, Madam President, that Parliament wait and see whether Mr. Haider's party will influence that country's politics. Then, and only then, could you assess whether human rights are being compromised. This Parliament could consider appropriate measures to address this situation, and then, and only then, could it consider interfering in the constitutional affairs of a European Union country. Madam President, as a member of the Freedom Party, I respect the concerns of some colleagues about democratic developments in Austria. You may perhaps be surprised by my reaction when I note that the particular sensitivity towards Austria, in its questioning appreciation of human rights, its sense of responsibility towards its own past, and the stability of democracy, meets with my personal understanding. Austria itself is responsible for the often dubious image that prevails abroad, rightly or unjustly. The years-long refusal of our governments to acknowledge our complicity in the horrors of World War II, and their refusal to provide just reparations to the Jewish victims and forced laborers, have contributed significantly to this negative image. Now, the FPÖ has entered a governing coalition with the ÖVP, based on an electoral mandate from October 3, 1999, when the old government was voted out. This is the right of the citizens of a state, because it is the fundamental principle of a democracy. After the talks between the SPÖ and ÖVP failed, the Socialists attempted to form a minority government and asked the FPÖ for support. We were offered three ministerial posts—you only need to read the newspapers—by the very party that is denounced here as fascist! When we suddenly rejected this offer, a passionate campaign of agitation and propaganda began that we still don't understand. The FPÖ is a well-established party in the Austrian political landscape. It provides the governor in one of the nine federal states and participates in all other governments. Why, so many Austrians are asking today, is their democratic decision suddenly being interpreted as an expression of fascist sentiment, why did the hate campaign only begin when the Freedom Party refused to support a minority SPÖ government? This is a prejudgment that—without addressing our platform—reduces the most gruesome epoch in European history to a political spectacle. I am filled with disgust when some of our opponents exploit the deaths of millions in the gas chambers of concentration camps for cheap propaganda, such as the Italian MP Bertinotti, who yesterday accused Mr. Haider of Holocaust denial on Italian TV. Shame on you, Mr. Colleague! Even if you run out of political arguments, you have no right to use the murdered victims for your cheap propaganda. You don't become an anti-fascist by denouncing a democratically elected politician as a Nazi! On the contrary, they mock the true victims of National Socialism and trivialize fascist dictatorships. They act based on their own prejudices, forgo any political debate, and act in precisely the style they claim to oppose. The attack against Austria's new government, the attempt to exert political influence in a member state, is an insult to the Austrian people.

We cannot afford to delay. An ambitious timetable is essential. I do not consider it an overly bold approach, assuming that there will be no more discharges into waterways by 2020 and that we are aiming for zero pollution and emissions of toxic substances by that date. The aim is to do what is technically possible—nothing more, of course—but we must be sufficiently ambitious. I would like to address an issue that has already been raised. I believe the Committee on the Environment, Public Health, has defined the question of water redistribution too narrowly. This is not just a Spanish problem; it is also a problem in the Nordic countries. I sincerely hope that trust will be placed in national solutions, provided they are better from an environmental and economic point of view than those provided for in the directive. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate Mrs Lienemann on her excellent work. Water and air surround us everywhere. We share them with everyone on this earth. Water is a prerequisite for human life, which unites an increasing number of people. Mrs. Schleicher suggested this morning that clean water is an unrealistic demand. Nothing could be more wrong! It is unrealistic to gradually worsen water quality and thus the conditions for life. This is particularly unrealistic for agriculture, which of all depends most on clean nature and unpolluted natural resources. I would therefore like to appeal to the Members of this Parliament to recognize that a clean environment represents the greatest realistic long-term goal. Mr. President, we—and this applies to me personally too—support Mrs. Lienemann's report, the objectives it sets out, and the directive under discussion. Nevertheless, we should examine some aspects in more detail. For example, major problems in my country are the diversion of rivers and the damming of water by means of lakes – ostensibly development projects which in reality pose considerable risks to groundwater, the water table and surface water. Regardless of whether we ultimately reach agreement on who may decide on such diversions, I believe that the rules must apply equally to everyone and be extremely strict. However, the key point, Commissioner, is, in my view, planning for the restoration of the water table and the natural courses of rivers and the natural state of lakes, which can be achieved within the ten-year timeframe we have set. Such projects should certainly be eligible for subsidies so that they can receive financial support, because in the end, such restoration could prove to be an excellent development measure. Mr President, this is essentially a good measure. It sets realistic standards based on the principles of subsidiarity and river basin management. It pursues the right goal of ensuring good water quality for humans and animals, for the environment, and for economic purposes. Preventing water pollution and deterioration of water quality are desirable goals, as are the ability to manage water resources during periods of drought and flood.

It has been placed in the hands of a single Commissioner, Mr Antonio Vitorino, and we are also pleased about that. He has also been entrusted with the drafting of a scoreboard that will enable us to measure the progress actually made in this area at Community level, but also – and this seems important to me – at Member State level. We are pleased and congratulate the Council on these decisions, even though the Treaty of Amsterdam contained one disappointment for this Parliament: the five-year delay in the exercise of our role, our ability to participate actively, the democratic scrutiny of this area of justice, freedom and security, and the role that the Court of Justice must play within it. However, if, in examining the progress achieved in 1999, as is the mandate of the Treaty for this Parliament, we leave the field of grand declarations and look at the decisions actually taken and implemented, the panorama becomes rather bleak, Mr President. It is as if the Council had more than one face and two hands, and what one signs and declares, the other distorts. Despite all the commitments made at the highest level, the Council has failed to take the decisions it intended to take. The programs are proliferating and overlapping, and there is no way to verify their implementation and effectiveness, or at least, this Parliament cannot. We have put a number of questions to the Council, and I know that the Portuguese Presidency is willing to answer each one. We hope that this Presidency will initiate a change in the Council's attitude toward this Parliament. I said there is no correlation between the decisions taken by the Council and the policies actually implemented. There are doubts in my group and in this House, for example, on an issue that should be good news: the communitization of Schengen. Schengen has—as we said before—been incorporated into the acquis, but this has been done in a very opaque context. No information, no request reached the European Parliament during this process, neither about the United Kingdom's association nor about the inclusion of Greece, nor about the negotiations with Norway or Iceland. The same can be said about immigration policy. We have passed the time by drafting mountains of reports, but we don't know what has happened to these initiatives; they have disappeared. We hope that 2000 will be the year of implementation, just as 1999 was the year of expectations. And we hope that the Council will also be willing to submit itself to the scrutiny of this House. The Council has decided that justice and home affairs policy should be an integral part of the Union's internal affairs. The Council can act in accordance with its decisions or continue to shamefully thwart the involvement of the other institutions in this vital project. If it chooses the latter course, it must be aware that this entails risks and weakens the foundations on which the area of freedom, security, and justice is built.

One of the reasons we were very keen to present it was that, whether we like it or not, the European Union is notorious for fraud and mismanagement. This is sometimes exaggerated, but it is the case. We have to do something about it. Some of the measures we have taken in the past have not been implemented by some Member States... and we must not forget that Member States are responsible for implementing approximately 80% of the EU budget. Many of them have not signed, have not ratified, the Convention on the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests, so it was clear that something more radical had to be done. We must take this task seriously. It is necessary to be able to prosecute people who commit fraud against the European Union. The question is: who prosecutes? That's when we really run into difficulties. Whose responsibility is this when it comes to an organ that crosses so many borders? We must also be sensitive to the concerns of the Member States. The proposal to create a European Public Prosecutor's Office is very delicate. We all know that a completely federal approach and a situation in which a European judicial authority takes precedence over national judicial authorities is a step too far for some. But it is necessary to start the debate on this, which is why we will ask the IGC to initiate discussions on this. Of utmost importance to Parliament, as custodian of the European Union budget, is how to address the issue of individuals working in the European Union institutions. At a time when we are examining the entire reform process, it is crucial that we send the right signal. Citizens must understand that if they commit fraud, they will be prosecuted, and at the moment, that is not the case. Ms. Palacio has outlined the question of whether we have the legal authority to do so. I would like to say very clearly that my group will propose an amendment to delete the details of how the Commission should address this issue. We know this is a sensitive debate. We know that the Commission may need some leeway to negotiate a situation that would be acceptable to all parties. Let me say very clearly that this is not a commitment to a corpus juris, a commitment to a federal European public prosecutor's office. But it is a clear commitment to change the status quo, which is completely unacceptable. Mr. President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs. Theato on her report. I believe it is an excellent report, which will largely be supported by my parliamentary group. I only have the feeling that, deep down, she wanted to go a little further at this stage. Given the debates of the last five or six months, that could have been the case. We all know that in 1995 it was agreed that better criminal protection of the Union's financial interests had to be implemented.

I am referring to Cuba's expressed intention on February 2 to become a full member of the ACP group of countries. A Cuban delegation participated in the last meeting of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly in Nassau, and Vice-Minister Dalmau appeared before the plenary, with whom a lively debate took place, followed by numerous conversations with many of us. After Nassau, a delegation from our Parliament, led by Mr. Corrie himself and the Chairman of the Committee on Development and Cooperation, Joaquín Miranda, visited Havana, where a series of very enlightening exchanges of views took place. I have the impression that this mission from the European Parliament was the final push that convinced our Cuban friends of the opportune moment of taking a step forward in the mechanisms of cooperation with the European Union. We are facing a situation of considerable political importance, and I hope that, from the European Parliament, we will promote the appropriate favorable view and a generous attitude on the part of the Union, which will prompt a positive response to Cuba's aspirations as quickly as possible. This will be important for at least three reasons. First, it will be important for Cuba, for the development and prosperity of its people, and for definitively breaking the blockade imposed by the United States, which has been repeatedly condemned by the European Parliament and the United Nations. Second, we must bear in mind that Cuba's candidacy has been supported by all ACP countries. If the European Union responds positively to the recommendation of our partners, we will be demonstrating respect and consideration for those partners, which will have positive effects throughout the framework of our cooperation with them. Nor can we ignore the value of a decision like the one I propose, as proof of the coherence and autonomy of the European Union and its non-subordination to any pressure. By accepting Cuba into the ACP Community, we will demonstrate that we are not a Europe immersed in the undignified dynamic of paying but not playing, and that when we were outraged by absurdities like the Helms-Burton Act, we were not doing so hypocritically but rather willing to act to the ultimate consequences. In a few weeks, the ACP-EU Joint Assembly will meet again, and I am sure this issue will be discussed within it. It would be desirable for the European Parliament's representatives to lend their support to Cuba's intentions during this process, as will undoubtedly be the case with their parliamentary colleagues from the ACP countries. Cuba must, of course, comply with all the conditions laid down, just like any other partner. Cubans know this and will surely accept it. It must also be made clear that no more will be asked of Cuba than what has been asked of other interlocutors. Cuba's willingness to join is welcome, and Cuba is welcome to this circle of ours. I say this wholeheartedly, but also with the deep conviction that, just as the blockade has produced nothing but misery and, as a consequence, tension and hardening of the Cuban people, the integration we are supporting here and the prosperity that it brings will translate into the détente and openness that we all desire and from which we will all benefit, especially the Cuban people.

It took us fifteen years for the Economic and Monetary Union. We can take fifteen years for defense and security policy and foreign policy, but the process must be clear. I also think that we must not underestimate—this is a question I am asking you—the influence and strength of the foreign ministry lobbies. We know the strength they have acquired over these forty years of community building. Today, they would have everything to lose from a communitarization of foreign policy, and I think they are working towards this. Finally, on the question of Kosovo—Mr. Cohn-Bendit was right to insist on this point—I believe it is urgent that the European Union raise the question of the final status of this territory. Without this status, there will only be instability, murders, provocations from Belgrade, and the European Union must, as a matter of urgency, pronounce itself on this. Finally, I thank Mr. Poettering because I believe that Belgium's initiatives, as they say in somewhat clear language, are beginning to work. I think that many Member States, among the fourteen other Member States, would have many reasons not to collaborate in European Union meetings on matters of justice, for example. Four years after the arrest of Mr. Dutroux and his colleagues, we still have no trial, we still do not know what is happening. In terms of tourism too, many among these fourteen Member States might wonder about the advisability of discouraging holidays for parents with young children in Belgium, for example. So, it would be time, and I invite Mr. Solana and Mr. Patten, to inform our colleague, Mr. Michel, that perhaps he is overdoing it and that ultimately this risks, which I hope, backfiring on him. Mr President, I would first like to wish Mr Solana a very happy 1 March, the date on which a whole series of structures relating to the European Security and Defence Policy were put into operation. But I am actually wondering what he thinks about it. The documents mention good collaboration with the High Representative. You even said earlier that you discussed it at lunch; it would be the height of irony if you did not discuss it and if there were not good collaboration between the new structures and you! But do you not suffer from not chairing these structures yourself and not being at their centre? I would like – like many in Parliament, I believe – for you to be the driving force behind these structures and not to risk being sidelined in any way. In recent months, particularly in discussions with members of the NATO Assembly, High Representative Solana and Commissioner Patten have sought to delineate the lines between the defence policy of the European Union and that of NATO.

I must acknowledge the immense work you have done: the fast pace of meetings, the efforts made to establish a rapid response force, the concrete actions aimed at preventing, managing or resolving crises through civilian and, where necessary, military means. I would like to take advantage of your presence to ask you two questions that relate to the content of future actions. The first concerns the next European Councils in June and December and the extraordinary Council in Lisbon. What are the fundamental and priority developments that you would like to see achieved during the next Summits? And above all, what do you most need at these Summits? My second question is different, although it is somehow linked to the previous one. It concerns the next IGC. Do you not think that the agenda of the IGC should include the question of the European security and defence policy in order to complete the Treaties, should it emerge that the current wording of the texts does not allow for the implementation of a genuine defence policy? I believe that the Italian Prime Minister raised this point during your meeting on 24 February. Can you explain your position on this matter? Mr President, Bosnia and Kosovo have awakened Europe. The European Union is finally recognising that it cannot afford to leave the political and military initiative to the Americans all the time. The decision to create its own peacekeeping force is excellent. However, if Europe wants to be able to intervene militarily at a crucial moment, a flexibility clause must be included in the Treaty. Mr Solana can play an important role. He is not a madman, certainly not. He is a committed and competent man. However, we must ask ourselves whether this accumulation of functions is not excessive in relation to his competences. In addition to being Secretary-General of the Council, Mr Solana is Secretary-General of the WEU and High Representative for Foreign Policy. He is also responsible for the Policy Planning and Early Warning Unit. With all this work, will he find time to rest, Mr President? I believe that, from a democratic point of view, this accumulation of functions is fundamentally unacceptable, especially given that Mr Solana is not a democratically elected politician but a high-ranking civil servant who is not held accountable to any parliamentary assembly. His position threatens to overshadow that of Commissioner Patten, as has also been pointed out today. The impression is that, with the development of European security and defence policy, the Commission and Parliament are being excluded from this process. I believe that this exclusion is also unacceptable. Obviously, nothing should be left out that could make European policy more efficient, but this must not lead to an undesirable concentration of power. Mr Solana must awaken Europe without himself becoming tired. Mr President, the European Union was created first and foremost for peace. I am pleased that Commissioner Patten and Mr Solana have stressed this on several occasions.

Environmental bodies often lack the knowledge and procedures for integrating this dimension into their daily work. Naturally, I would like to know whether the Commissioner is prepared to integrate the gender dimension into environmental policy and environmental programmes. I think that is important. If the whole policy is to be permeated by it, I think it is essential that senior management should take on this basic notion. It is natural that, in my view of mainstreaming, it should permeate all our work. In the plan being developed by my Directorate-General, gender issues play a key role. I am prepared to take action myself, for example by moderating seminars on leadership or other topics, in order to encourage women to take on more and more tasks within the Commission. In order to motivate everyone, I think it is of the utmost importance that this message is conveyed throughout the hierarchy, both from the top down and from the bottom up. My understanding of environmental commitment in general is that it is often the prerogative of women. Since it needs to be spread, women also need to be given opportunities to take up senior or other positions in environmental work. I repeat that our action plan takes this into account, but there is certainly room for more. I have some experience of formulating and implementing plans in general. I hope that I can be of assistance. Question No 43 by the Honourable Member (h-0045/00): Subject: The Boyne Estuary and the Drogheda Harbour Company The Boyne Estuary region has already been designated a Special Protection Area (SPA) under the Birds Directive and, as an area of international importance, is currently being considered for designation as a Special Area of Conservation under the Habitats Directive. However, the Department of the Marine, Louth County Council and Drogheda Corporation have given permission for a new harbour to be built in the SPA, and even for the removal of a mud flat at Stegrennan which was recently incorporated into the SPA at the specific insistence of the Commission. In addition, a huge warehouse has been built - for which planning permission is proving difficult to obtain - and Drogheda Corporation is planning further infrastructure. How can the Commission ensure that this type of development, funded through the Structural Funds, does not conflict with the nature conservation needs of the region? Is the Commission prepared to suspend funding altogether, pending a review of the development plans for this area? The Commission is aware of the construction of the harbour, but has no information on either the warehouses or the other infrastructure mentioned by the Honourable Member. The development of the port is being financed by the Structural Funds and essentially involves the dredging of the Boyne Estuary and the temporary storage of the dredged spoil on the mudflat at Stegrennan. The Boyne Estuary region is classified as a Special Protection Area under the Birds Directive. This means that any exploitation activity in or near the Boyne Estuary which may affect the Special Protection Area must comply with the provisions for the protection of the area set out in the EU Habitats Directive.

You have the good, charming idea that the outcome and benchmark for your policies and your five-year program would be the election result or turnout in the next European elections. When I imagine presenting your work program to my voters, whom I see weekly and to whom I have to explain it weekly—not in the high echelons of important politics, but on the street—then I ask myself, what should I say then? Mr. Prodi, what should I say that's new about it? There's nothing new about your work program. You used 12 pages for five years, and 18 pages for a one-year work program. Does that give me hope for the year 2000? No, it doesn't! In your 2000 work program, you say something very clever. You say that environmental concerns must be integrated into all other policy areas. Have you done that, Mr. Prodi, and have you also read your work program for this year? Because you haven't! You have not integrated environmental policy into enlargement, even though it will be one of the core issues surrounding enlargement. Nor have you integrated it into economic policy, competition, or the internal market. You have not done that anywhere. You have pieced together individual pieces, but you have not created an overall structure. When you said earlier in your speech that a disaster like the one on the Danube must be the reason for a disaster program—no, Mr. Prodi, we must finally begin implementing legislation and also ensuring that legislation is monitored. In your five-year program, you write that the people of the European Union rightly expect better food standards and better food legislation. Mr. Prodi, you don't know what you're talking about! The European Union's food legislation is the most ambitious in the world! What's lacking and lacking is implementation in the member states and monitoring. Finally, take your task seriously as President of the Commission, to pull the member states by the ears and force them to fulfill their tasks and duties! They shouldn't just be pursuing hobbies, but doing their everyday, normal work. This is what we expect from you in the next five years! Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! As Chairman of this Parliament's Committee on Fisheries, you, Mr. Prodi, are not making things easy for me at all. I feel compelled here and now to publicly criticize the absence of fisheries in the program you have presented to us. The next five years of the Prodi Commission—you solemnly announce this in the first of your conclusions—will be marked by major changes. I hope that this change you announce, judging by your pitiful and absolute silence on this matter in your program, will not consist in an even greater marginalization of fisheries. Not a single line, not a single word on fisheries or the CFP. I am not asking you for details or precise indications, but a mention would, I believe, be necessary. How can you completely forget a common—I emphasize common—policy with such economic, social, and regional impact—and therefore with consequences for Europe's economic and social cohesion?

At this stage I will simply say that I hope that it will be integrated into the programming of rural areas under Objective 2, just as the EAGGF, Guidance Section, is integrated into the Objective 1 regions. In any case, I have noted how vigilant the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development is on these issues. Before concluding, I would like to say to Mr Savary that the specific debate on the consequences of the storms that have hit France, Austria and Germany in particular in recent weeks is scheduled for tomorrow, as is the debate with my colleague, Mrs de Palacio, on the lessons to be learned from the oil spill that hit the French coast. With your permission, Mr Savary, I reserve my position on this issue, which largely coincides with the recommendation you made on what can be done to combat the oil spill in the context of Objective 2. I would remind you that tomorrow the Commission will approve the map of the areas recognised as Objective 2 for France, Sweden, Austria and Luxembourg, which will provide us with a working tool, in particular for a large part of the departments affected by the storms. That is why the day after tomorrow I will be visiting the two French departments that were seriously damaged by the bad weather. In conclusion, I would like to thank the President for his understanding and the rapporteur for the quality of her work and that of her parliamentary committee, and I would also like to say that, regardless of some differences of opinion on the role of the guidelines - we have discussed this and I have tried to make my point clear - I am very pleased with the support expressed by this Parliament for the Commission to draw up the guidelines submitted to the Member States in order to prepare the national programmes. This can only support the concept based on good practices drawn from the experience of the programmes for the period 1994-1999. I believe it to be a good omen for effective cooperation between our two institutions, at the time of starting the programming for 2000-2006, a good practice of working together, consolidated, Mr Hatzidakis, by respect for the Code of Conduct which is imposed on our two institutions and which is particularly close to my heart. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, at 12.00. Situation, social and economic development of the regions of the Union The next item is the report (A5-0107/1999) by Mr Berend, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, on the sixth periodic report on the socio-economic situation and development of the regions of the European Union (SEC(99)0066 - C5-0120/99 - 1999/2123(COS)). Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the sixth periodic report on the situation and social and economic development of the regions of the European Union marks an important step forward in the analysis of regional data and highlights the progress made in this field since the publication of the fifth periodic report. However, I believe that talking about a real convergence of average regional development in Europe gives a somewhat incomplete picture of reality, and unfortunately that is precisely the message conveyed by the press and proclaimed in certain speeches.

We must provide a satisfactory response. Flora Brovina's case is never just one. We rightly mention it in the draft resolution, but there are hundreds, thousands of Flora Brovinas. I call on the Commission and the absent Council to finally do something for these political prisoners. The fact that they are imprisoned in Serbia contributes to the foundations of the disorder and violence in Kosovo. Mr President, in paragraph 10, the joint draft resolution before us rightly calls on the Council and the Member States of the European Union to redouble their efforts to provide the United Nations police force with the necessary personnel and resources. This request is in full agreement with the opinion of the United Nations High Representative in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner. To fulfill his mission of restoring and maintaining law and order in Kosovo, he estimates that he will need at least 6,000 foreign police officers. The United Nations promised to send a police force of 4,800 men. To date, Kouchner has only 2,000 police officers at his disposal. Furthermore, half of this group comes from the United States and Germany. It is understandable that the UN High Representative in Kosovo is largely unhappy with this situation, especially given the endemic ethnic violence in the region. Yet, Kouchner's sharp criticism of the French government in recent days is astounding. Paris is completely abandoning its compatriot in the region by providing it with a handful of police officers, no more than 37. According to Kouchner, the culprit for this dishonorable position on the part of France is none other than Interior Minister Jean-Pierre Chevènement. According to Kouchner, he is obstructing the dispatch of French police officers to Kosovo for ideological reasons. I ask the Council and the Commission to examine these serious accusations in depth and to inform the European Parliament about them. Freedom of the press in Angola Mr President, I will not repeat the premise from earlier: I could be accused of unfair publicity. On the "Angola" issue, I think that a first result is to finally have a resolution. This has not happened in our Parliament for a very long time. So, I welcome it as such. I believe that the European Union and the West, in general, have been targeting Mr. Savimbi in their crossfire for some time, without any discrimination, but that the corruption in Mr. Dos Santos' regime is now such that even his long-time friends are beginning to struggle to pretend they see nothing. So, I believe that it is urgent to be able to make a general political resolution, where we could get to the bottom of things, in particular also on some rather worrying things, which are being discussed, notably logistical support given, at the level of the intelligence services, by the United States and Great Britain, the widespread corruption of the regime linked to multinational oil companies, and many other things, certainly very "tasty", which will have to be explored in depth.

Mr. President, Commissioner, the measures provided for in this directive range from the development of water management plans, broad rights of information and consultation, and greater cooperation between Member States, to combating water pollution by specific harmful substances. Knowing how many years this House has been trying to achieve a framework directive of this nature, I am pleased that we have reached this point today and would like to congratulate Mrs. Lienemann, who has been fortunate enough to be able to present this report today. However, I also think it is extremely important to note an aspect that many consider self-evident. Nevertheless, I would like to emphasize it. The directive provides no legal basis, under any form, for diverting water from the territory of a Member State against its will. In order to confirm this point once again, I have tabled an amendment—with strong support from the EPP, for which I am grateful—and I would be very pleased if it were to receive the affirmative vote of the House tomorrow. Its purpose is to make it clear that water—as has been repeatedly emphasized today—is not an ordinary commodity, but a good that belongs to the population of the relevant Member State of the Union and that must receive protection and treatment that take this fact into account. I know, and the previous speaker emphasized, that some European Union states have water problems. I believe that all of us have the opportunity to better manage water in our countries and to promote less polluting use of water. No country can be exempt from this effort. Only when each country has made the maximum effort to conserve its water resources, when everything possible has truly been done in our own countries, only then can we, in my opinion, contemplate a shared use of water, if necessary. Mr. President, Commissioner, it should be a cause for joy that the second reading of this directive is now on the table. However, I must say that I am not overly pleased because I believe it is a directive of poor quality, that it will pose many problems in implementation, and that it has many shortcomings. First of all, I think it's an excessively harsh and simplistic, reductionist directive. Other existing directives regarding water have often not been complied with, and governments and the Commission have often failed to impose discipline as they should have, although I know it's not pleasant. It's not a question of having much tougher regulations because the problems in many cases are management-related, of assuming one's responsibilities and not transferring the major problems of the water system, whose complexity we all know to be, to the legislature. A reductionist directive has been drafted; countries with navigable rivers cannot be lumped together with others that lack water, whose land is open with large cracks due to the lack of it, and whose temperatures are 55 or 60 degrees Celsius in the sun.

But from the political side, control must be properly reestablished. The triangle of Commission, Council, and Parliament must also be reestablished in the field of foreign and security policy, where so far too much has been left to the Council, and here especially with regard to the crude crisis management measures, where the powers lie exclusively with the Commission. All of this has not been sufficiently incorporated into this overall concept. We must examine whether, in this regard, changes are not necessary within the framework of the Intergovernmental Conference. The Portuguese Presidency of the Council has said yes, that it will reconsider this matter with a view to eventually extending the mandate. I would like to draw attention to another important point. The discussions we are holding these days, for example, on the government of a country in Europe show, however, that we must reflect the moral orientation, the rule of law, and the common good of the European Union, and that, for this reason, we must introduce legally binding fundamental rights into the Treaty, as this will be a decisive stabilizing element. I ask those who still have deep reservations about this matter to reconsider whether now is not the time to view it in this context as well and perhaps to muster the courage to appropriately promote fundamental rights in this area. The European Union does not need, or hardly needs, new instruments or new powers. What it needs are the instruments to be able to exercise its powers. For this reason, we must adopt the necessary measures to ensure that these instruments enable us to fulfill, on behalf of the citizens, the tasks already formally assigned to us by the Treaty. I believe that the efforts of this Intergovernmental Conference should be particularly focused on this point. If we make progress in this area, then we will be able to face the historic task of enlargement of the European Union with greater confidence. This is the decisive point. Honorable Presidency of the Council, I am convinced that under your leadership, it will be successfully shaped. Mr. President of the Council, you have been able to understand, after listening to several speeches, that within the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and also among the leaders of the political groups in this Parliament, the prevailing view, not without differences, was to trust the Portuguese Presidency and not increase its difficulties by postponing the start of the Intergovernmental Conference. I can assure you that it was not easy to achieve this last week within the committee I chair; however, in the end, we decided to back the Portuguese Presidency, and we truly want to win the bet. You told us about the start of your tour of various capitals and the difficulties some states face in reaching a consensus in their countries and, therefore, in their parliaments. I would like to inform you that yesterday we had, I believe, a very interesting day of debate and dialogue with the representatives of the 15 national parliaments, who were represented by qualified and committed delegations.

We are ultimately concerned about the stability of the financial markets, not because it is the goodwill of the financial markets, but because it also affects our growth, our investments, and our jobs within the European Union. In this regard, we must ask ourselves what instruments we have at our disposal to effectively generate a certain order, which has been lacking until now. We have all contributed to the liberalization of financial transactions; to date, however, we do not have a functioning regulatory framework, and we have had bitter experience of this with the repercussions of the crises in Asia and Latin America. It is therefore high time that we consider, first, supervisory rules and, second, the transparency of the financial markets and the information relating to them. It is important that we know the players and their solvency. We must also ask ourselves whether there is not a requirement for fiscal justice. At a time when the tax burden on the labour factor is increasing both at European and international level, we must consider how to achieve effective taxation of capital income and, in this area, we must also consider the taxation of short-term financial transactions. I believe it is really important to have a thorough report and conclusions from the Commission so that we, as the European Parliament, can see whether the European Union should not, together with the USA and Japan, ensure that international solidarity is truly achieved in order to increase the stability and security of the economy and the financial markets. This is the intention behind this oral question, and we will need to achieve a balanced and truly forward-looking proposal in Parliament, through the regulatory procedures through committees and plenary meetings. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I must express, on behalf of the Group of the European Liberal, Democratic and Reform Party, my surprise at the current debate on international capital flows and their possible taxation. Although it is not mentioned in the text, it looks like an attempt to resurrect, as was done in the introduction, the issue of the tax proposed a few years ago by Mr Tobin, which our group opposed clearly and categorically during the previous legislature with a series of arguments set out clearly and coherently by our Chairman, Mr Cox. Arguments that, modestly, I will have to repeat during my speech, given that the issue is being raised again. We do not agree with this type of taxation because its application, provided it is possible, would not serve the objectives that Mr Tobin presented in his time and that the left in this House seems to want to resurrect. First of all, there is no evidence that taxing international capital flows could reduce the risks of volatility or instability in international markets. On the contrary, since it is certain that not all countries would accept it, we would open the door to speculation and fraud, which would cause volatility, instability, insecurity, opacity, and unfair competition in the financial services sector that operates internationally. Moreover, the idea of obtaining resources to use them for economically more needy countries is so complex, when we consider its practical application, that it is simply impossible.

The second problematic aspect concerns the data to be collected under the Regulation. Firstly, as regards economic data, Amendment 2 provides for two changes. The first is to ensure that the data collected is limited to the objective to be pursued. The second change consists in replacing the reference to sales products and other financial income, subsidies, interest received, etc., with a simple reference to the volume of sales. It is thought that without these changes Member States might have to bear too high a cost for data collection and there would also be a problem of confidentiality. In line with these changes, the reference to accounting entries has been deleted in Amendment 5. Secondly, as regards environmental data, the original proposal only refers to biological and economic information. However, the Commission has made it clear that it intends to engage in wider environmental studies and pilot projects and that it may wish to extend the range of data collected by Member States at a later stage. Amendment 3 brings the data needed to monitor changes in aquatic ecosystems into the Regulation. This will obviously facilitate the introduction of a new regulation on environmental data, and may even make it unnecessary. It should be stressed that the amendment does not in any way oblige the Commission to include the collection of such data either in the minimum or in the extended programme, but gives the Commission the possibility to do so. As has already been said, the proposal for a Council decision can be divided into two parts. The first concerns the financing of the Member States for the implementation of Community programmes. The second provides that the Commission itself may finance studies and pilot projects. There are some minor amendments, such as Amendment No 2, which aims to ensure that the financial contribution to the Member States can cover not only the costs of data collection, but also those of their management, compilation, aggregation, etc. Amendments Nos 3 and 6 aim to speed up the implementation of the Regulation and to allow Member States to know the content of the programmes as soon as possible. These amendments also aim to align these implementation times with the dates and with the Regulation. Amendments Nos 1 and 2 aim to ensure that the Commission itself can finance studies and pilot projects. Amendments 4 and 5 are designed to ensure that financial information is provided continuously to the budgetary authority.
