More specifically, through Amendment No 1, the Committee on Fisheries accepts the recommendation of the Committee on Budgets that the funding should be placed under Heading 1b rather than Heading 3 of the financial perspective. Although in the preliminary draft budget the Commission had placed the appropriations under Heading 3 "Internal policies", Parliament has created the new budget item B1-500 to finance the measures we are discussing, in order to ensure that the necessary resources continue to be available. Mr President, I think it appropriate to fully agree with Mrs Attwoll who, at the beginning of her excellent report, said that the two Commission proposals, aimed at gaining a better understanding of the scientific and socio-economic situation of the fisheries sector, come at a critical time.

Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, we can be satisfied with the global scope of the objectives announced, which are commensurate with the challenges that Europe will have to face. I see that you consider the fall of the Berlin Wall to be the essential element of this end of the century. It is an event that heralds enlargement. Rather than using the word "enlargement", I would almost like to speak of reunification, a term that seems to me to be charged with much greater political meaning. You return to the idea of concentrating your activities on the most important missions; this is an objective of your reform and, in essence, of applying the principle of subsidiarity. Clearly applying this principle will certainly benefit the actions carried out by giving citizens a clear image of each level of competence. Mr Prodi, there is a world of difference between saying and doing! You will have to fight against the tendency typical of the institutions to try to extend their powers. I will judge accordingly on the facts. And, in the meantime, I give my approval and encouragement to the will that clearly emerges from your communication. However, there are two essential points: simplification and application of Community law. In 1998, 123 appeals were lodged with the Court of Justice for failure to apply or transpose; 25 percent of the directives in the environmental sector are not applied or transposed. Recent events demonstrate the absolute need for this. Community law must not remain unapplied because it is too complex or hair-splitting. The Union must not give in to this bad habit and, on this point too, I regret that your communication does not go into sufficient detail. You are realistic about the impossibility of the welfare state providing adequate answers to today's problems, which include unemployment. Nevertheless, I regret that no clear alternative has been proposed. It would have been correct to underline the rejection of any welfare policy, accompanied, however, by the valorisation of the spirit of initiative and responsibility. You do not mention the ageing of our population, which will have substantial repercussions on the structure of our society, not only from an economic point of view, but also in terms of public health. In fact, it is a silent revolution and, from this point of view, I expected more from your communication. Finally, you insist on European research as a central element of our future, without however indicating the instruments you intend to implement. Ethical principles are also at the heart of this research, but your communication does not say so. Mr President, you intend to inform citizens better: start by strengthening ties with Parliament, because we are the citizens' representatives. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we can only agree with the general orientations of the five-year programme and the programme for the year 2000, illustrated with such passion by President Prodi this morning. In the two documents, strong emphasis was placed on the need to define new forms of European governance and to implement, for this purpose, a new agenda for the Commission, defining more stringent priorities in pursuing the objective of full employment, through more effective coordination of the economic and social policies of the States and - I would like to underline - first and foremost of the nations that have joined the Monetary Union and which must be put in a position to constitute the first example of enhanced cooperation.

By placing finance first, this movement has strengthened the need for profitability and tightened management conditions everywhere. This is the context for mergers, acquisitions, corporate restructuring, and the collection of enormous resources on the financial markets that continues to grow. Unemployment and the pressure on workers around the world tend to increase. Markets and real growth are hindered. The brutal inflow or withdrawal of speculative capital threatens the economies of many countries, to the point of sinking, as has happened in Asia, Russia or Brazil. Faced with this neoliberal globalization, under the domination of the financial markets, there is a growing need, as demonstrated by our request, for another idea of the world according to which the common law would be that dictated by the duty of solidarity in an increasingly interdependent world. No one can ignore the challenge to civilization represented by the lack of nearly a billion jobs. The need to allow unprecedented efforts in terms of development, access to knowledge. In this regard, all ideas deserve to be taken into consideration and we believe that the Tobin tax is an important proposal, as are other forms of transactions that could be envisaged. The tax in question can help curb speculation, without penalising the activities of the real economy, and would make new resources available for investment in human resources, and this at a time when the UNDP estimates that 40 billion dollars a year is the sum needed to eradicate poverty, provide access to drinking water for all, and meet health needs. At a time when the debate on the capacity or otherwise of politics to influence the economic sphere has been launched at a global level, the establishment of this tax could become one of the symbols of the political will to reconquer the democratic spaces confiscated by international financial operators. I would like to respond to the Commissioner who said that to achieve this result, a minimum number of industrial countries is needed. It seems to me that the European Union is made up of a fair number of industrial countries and I think, like Mr Désir and several other Members who have spoken, that the European Union that we have formed can take the initiative in this regard. In any case, I believe that the European Parliament would be honoured to echo the desire of the citizens to control the world in the sense of well-being for all. Madam President, I too am pleased that this long-awaited debate is taking place. We know very well that each generation, over time, has blindly relied on what could be called a dominant ideology, that is to say a series of prejudices accepted as such by general conformism and which, however, end up revealing to subsequent generations how full of drama they were. Free trade and the constant exaltation of globalization constitute, in our opinion, the dominant ideology of today, that is to say the grave error of this end of the century, as dangerous as was once the ideology of the dictatorship of the proletariat in the corridors of the Kremlin or, even before that, the certainty erected into a dogma according to which the earth was flat.

I am sure that, with the spirit you have shown here today, the first thing that will happen, in this new climate of understanding between us, is that you will take into consideration the motion for a resolution that we will submit to you. Question Time (Council) The next item is Question Time (B5-0003/2000). We will examine the questions addressed to the Council. Question No. 1 by (H-0780/99): Subject: Construction of a nuclear power plant in Turkey, vulnerable to earthquakes. The two recent earthquakes measuring over 7 on the Richter scale in Turkey raise serious doubts about that country's insistence on building extremely expensive nuclear reactors at Akköy, while the energy reserves of the Ataturk Dam are exported to third countries and the EU, by cutting its budget, pays for the damage caused by the earthquakes. Turkish nuclear projects, which ignore the risks they pose to the inhabitants and ecosystems of Turkey and the entire region, give rise to suspicions that they are hidden behind preconceived plans by the Turkish political-military hierarchy to acquire nuclear technology that would make it possible to build nuclear weapons, given the intention to acquire Canadian-made reactors similar to those possessed by India and Pakistan. What measures has the Council taken or intends to take to prevent nuclear accidents and the proliferation of nuclear weapons in a country that seeks to join the EU and spends enormous sums on nuclear programs while receiving European funds as economic aid? Mr. President, the Council wishes to clarify that Turkey is a signatory to the Convention on Nuclear Safety, whose objectives coincide with the concerns expressed by the Honourable Member. Indeed, that Convention, which entered into force on 24 October 1996, aims specifically to achieve and maintain a high level of nuclear safety worldwide through national measures and international cooperation, as well as to establish and maintain protection against potential radiological risks at nuclear facilities in order to protect individuals, society, and the environment from the harmful effects of ionizing radiation that such facilities can emit. As is known, the Convention also covers the prevention of accidents with radiological consequences and the mitigation of those consequences when such accidents occur. Furthermore, I would like to point out to the Honourable Member that Turkey, as a candidate country for accession to the European Union, must sooner or later, that is, as a precondition for accession—and I believe this point is important—accept, within the framework of its own pre-accession strategy, a set of policies in order to be able, in due time, to accept the Community acquis in its entirety, including, consequently, all the provisions in force regarding nuclear safety. Thank you for your reply. But I would like to add the following: With this unit, Turkey intends to increase its energy potential by only 2%. Yet, it reportedly wants to acquire Candu-type reactors, the same ones Pakistan and India acquired, with which they developed nuclear weapons.

(Applause from the right) It is through diplomacy, persuasion, culture, solidarity, and not through unconstitutional means, that the Institutions will be able to gain respect and ensure that principles are respected. Bilateral relations involve the States, so the fourteen Member States have nothing to do with them. This amounts to substituting for the European Institutions to defend political logic with an incompetence worthy of parties barely emerging from totalitarian systems and not representatives of democratic traditions. As we have already written on several occasions, many things, too many things, separate us from Haider, notably his claims to Alto Adige, which is very Italian. We knew that. Today, we see with anguish that other representatives of the Union seem to have renounced the democratic role of Europe. We are in favor of legality and democracy expressed by the people, of respect for national sovereignty as long as it does not violate the principles of the Treaty or human rights. We believe in Europe, while others seem to have begun the process of disintegrating the Union. These are the results of hasty enlargements and a lack of clarity regarding roles and responsibilities. We have created a Europe of the circus market, not one of principles, rights, and politics. These are the consequences! We can therefore only call on the Commission to continue on the path of moderation and to support those who are working to ensure that the autonomy and sovereignty of the Austrian people are respected, while ensuring that this people remains free and shows solidarity with others. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we have a date with hypocrisy. We have a Council that has managed to flout the Treaty and use a method completely outside Articles 6 and 7, which allowed, in the event of serious and persistent violations, the condemnation of a State. In this case, there are no serious and persistent violations in Austria. There are risks - we are all aware of them - but there is absolutely no serious or persistent violation as it stands. If we were to apply the criteria of Articles 6 and 7, if we were to apply the Copenhagen criteria to our institutions, to the European Union, this European Union would most certainly not be able to become a member, as is being asked of the countries of Eastern Europe. And if we are talking about serious and persistent violations, we can perhaps talk about certain Member States, we can talk about Italy and France, respectively the first and third countries condemned by the Council of Europe, by the Strasbourg Court. We can talk, dear Belgian colleagues, about Belgium, the Dutroux affair, the dozens and dozens of children abducted, tortured, raped, murdered by figures from that country and whose investigations are bogged down, still bogged down. We could, dear colleagues, a third of the Members of Parliament, force the Council and the Commission to question this. We could question the fact that the Austrians reject ten years, thirteen years of party rule that has corrupted and rotted a country – Austria – just as it is rotting and corrupting countries like Italy, Belgium and other Member States of the Union.

Therefore, we will try to be perfectly clear about how and when to apply it. Mr. President, Commissioner, the communication states, referring to the relationship between science on the one hand and recourse to the precautionary principle on the other, that invoking the precautionary principle always requires a political decision when scientific evidence is lacking. This puts considerable power in the hands of science. We can ask ourselves: what kind of scientists will provide us with this documentation and what do they defend? The communication also states that it is sufficient for there to be a sufficiently recognized minority of scientists to invoke the precautionary principle. I would like to ask you: what is the definition of a recognized minority? How do you define it? And how do you arrive at a recognized minority? If it is a political decision, I would like to ask you: who will make that political decision? The Commission? The Council? To what extent will the European Parliament play a role in this? What is the role of the scientific committees? What will be the role of the food authorities that you will establish? Finally, will all decision-making be done transparently and publicly? Those are my three questions. Yes, Mr. President, that is true. There are many aspects that are difficult and not always perfectly clear, but I will try to answer some questions. Who will make the decision, who are the decision-makers? Well, that depends on who the legislators are. It is part of risk management. We need to analyze, for example, the level of concern in society about a specific issue and judge based on what we know about the scientific evidence in some cases. But it is true that it is not necessary for a large majority of the scientific community to resort to the precautionary principle. The principle can be used based on the evidence of a minority or in cases where the science is incomplete. That is where we need to find the balance between this principle, as a political tool, and the science. It is not always easy to describe exactly how this process is carried out, but it is not a question of changing the scientific basis. We turn to experts to obtain all possible scientific information before taking action; and this will continue in the future. We must consider it a tool for managing risk factors. We must decide whether we want to endanger people, for example, or whether we want to protect the environment; and we must study the available scientific data. An assessment of all these factors and the scientific evidence is required. We then make the decision whether to take action or not. Therefore, there are no answers to all your questions, but that does not alter the system of turning to scientists as we currently do, nor the system of experts we currently use. Mr. President, I would like to ask a question about a specific, current case in which the precautionary principle could be applied.

There are two reasons for our refusal. First, this is a terribly complex and highly sensitive legal issue, and the proposal presents, in my view, certain risks to legal certainty that have not been acknowledged. This reason in itself is sufficient to explain our refusal to vote for the proposal, but there is a second reason: even though it is a convention, that is, a collaboration between states, the proposal reveals very clear tendencies, namely the creation, in the longer term, of a common European jurisdictional area, a common European penal code and a common European administration of justice. We are opposed to this development, we are against this mantra "an area of freedom, security and justice", which consists of barbarically creating community systems that cripple certain legal traditions linked to these sensitive and important issues, which are above all national prerogatives. Mr President, I too believe that the convention we are examining today is only a small step, still too small, in the construction of the common area of freedom, security and justice that – we hope – Europe will one day become. Europe is today an area of free movement of goods and people where crime knows no borders, while difficult obstacles still stand in the way of those who must combat it. A small step – I said – but a welcome one. The Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs has specifically sought to prescribe further limits and protections in the name of defending the fundamental rights of individuals, which are in force in the States and within the Union, even if they are not yet enshrined in a Charter of Rights of the European Union which, we hope, will soon see the light of day: fair limits and protections because the rights in force are, unfortunately, not always concretely respected by all public authorities in all States. In certain passages of the Commission's proposals, precautions have undoubtedly been exaggerated, such as when it was intended to leave the accused the choice of accepting or refusing his temporary transfer to another Member State of the Union for the purposes of the investigation. Personally, I cannot accept, for example, that Mr. Pinochet should be allowed to choose whether or not to be transferred to Spain for a confrontation. Or again, when it was intended that the witness or expert – and not only the person under investigation, the accused – should have the right to a lawyer for remote interrogations. These are minor flaws, unintended by the rapporteur, which will – I hope – be remedied by the vote of this House. The rapporteur has done a commendable job, which I acknowledge and for which I thank him. The overall result is appreciable and I hope that the Council will take it fully into account. As other Members have already pointed out, one point – the most delicate one – remains unresolved: Article 18 of the Convention concerning the interception of communications taking place in a Member State, carried out directly by another Member State without requesting mutual assistance from the State where the interception takes place, a procedure made possible these days thanks to modern technologies.

The Helsinki European Council approved enlargement to 13 Member States. There is therefore inconsistency between the opening of accession negotiations with these 13 countries and the desire to carry out only a de minimis reform. As far as we are concerned, in line with the logic of the Treaty, we want the agenda of the next intergovernmental conference to allow for a much more far-reaching reform of the Union. That said, Mr. President, Parliament is holding this debate today because it did not want to delay the start of the conference. Theoretically, we could have done so. We could have voted on the 17th of this month, so that the conference could not have started on the 14th. But we did not want to do so because we wanted to send a clear political message to the governments and candidate countries: we want to carry out this reform precisely to facilitate enlargement. Mr President, I am pleased to be able to say this to the Portuguese Presidency, because it has earned great esteem within this House. The Portuguese Presidency shares many of this Parliament's aspirations and has undertaken to do its utmost to ensure that the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference includes other subjects, which are absolutely necessary. I would like to say, Mr President, that this aspiration of the European Parliament is selfless. In any case, the European Parliament will emerge politically strengthened by the Treaty resulting from this Intergovernmental Conference, quite simply because, at this Intergovernmental Conference, in accordance with what was decided in Helsinki, we will examine which matters currently subject to unanimity will be moved to qualified majority voting. The number of matters decided by qualified majority voting will therefore increase. However, the acquis communautaire already provides that legislative matters decided by qualified majority voting will also be subject to codecision by Parliament. Consequently, if qualified majority voting is extended, Parliament's codecision will also be extended. But Parliament would not be fulfilling its task as a supranational European institution if it did not consider the Union's political project. We are working on this. We believe that other issues need to be addressed in the context of this Union's political project. Among other issues, those related to the integration of security and defense issues into the Treaty, subjects that have made considerable progress recently but which should be introduced into the Treaty. The same goes for the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, of course, which we began drafting yesterday, and I believe that this has begun in a very positive way. We will work seriously to ensure that Europeans see that being European represents a plus and that European citizens have fundamental rights that bind the Union's institutions. Consequently, Mr President, our proposals, which we will put into practice in a new report, will constitute, together with the proposals of the Commission, which has produced an excellent document - I am pleased to be able to say this here to Mr Barnier - documents of the Conference.

But even the decision of the Finnish Council Presidency in June was not the best that could have been achieved. It does have some weaknesses. The greatest weakness, in my view, is that the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises is not sufficiently taken into account, but the automotive industry is not only made up of large corporations. Small and medium-sized enterprises play a very important role, especially in the supplier sector, and we must also consider the interests of the employees in these small and medium-sized enterprises. Well over two million people work in this sector. Many of the amendments proposed by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, as well as our group's amendments to Article 5 regarding costs, also serve to address this situation of small and medium-sized enterprises. In terms of environmental policy, the common position is also not a shining example. There is a lack of perspective on the bigger picture, and when my colleague from the Green Party says that this is the first time that the European Parliament has watered down a common position, then that is unacceptable. After all, it makes no environmental sense for us to prevent modern, fuel-efficient cars like the 3-liter car, which uses a lot of plastic, through rigid, high recycling quotas! Therefore, we must support an amendment that at least allows for exceptions when we have particularly fuel-efficient cars. The industry's objections in this area are certainly not illogical. However, the arguments of the plastics and automotive industries would also increase if we were committed to reducing CO2 in Europe in more than just this context. Mr President, we are indeed in an unusual situation at the moment: those who want to stand up for environmental values are supporting the Council's common position. Unlike the previous speaker, I am truly proud that we achieved a common position during the Finnish Presidency that defends environmental values. If we overturn the Common Position and attempt to share the disposal costs, we will create loopholes: We will fail to achieve a sensible, clear system that regulates responsibilities. Therefore, in my opinion, the primary responsibility must lie with the manufacturer. Only in this way can we adequately solve the problem and also create incentives for manufacturers to produce vehicles that can be disposed of as cheaply as possible in the future. Mr. President, the Council's draft directive contains two fundamental problems. First, there is the unconditional obligation for manufacturers to take back end-of-life vehicles. This risks creating a monopoly in the dismantling industry, particularly in areas with great distances and numerous small businesses involved in dismantling. I believe that an EU directive, regardless of its content, must not disadvantage small and medium-sized enterprises within the Union. The unconditional responsibility of manufacturers also endangers the used goods market, as the manufacturer is obliged to sell new parts to a greater extent. However, this trade is particularly important for those who collect and recondition older vehicles. Even from a market economy perspective, this principle is rather dubious. Companies must be able to change, be sold, and be liquidated. They must establish themselves in new markets, but also be able to leave old ones. Binding manufacturers to a responsibility that can extend far into the past is ill-suited to a flexible and development-promoting market economy.

First of all, I would like to point out that the debate on social protection issues began within the European institutions several years ago and that, in 1995, the first communication entitled 'The future of social protection' arrived, followed by Parliament's contributions drawn up by Mrs Weiler and Mr Pronk. Today, in examining Mr Andersson's report, I believe I can say that we have made great strides, given that we are now talking about modernising social protection. Secondly, we must take into account the legal basis on which the Commission can operate. As you know, the Treaty does not provide a legal basis for policies at European level, but there is a certain consensus, also expressed in the last Council, to undertake coordination actions and exchange of experiences between Member States on the most successful programmes. Thirdly, in the four areas on which the communication under consideration focuses, namely paid work, the sustainability of pension systems, social inclusion and quality of health, there is a horizontal approach to the women's issue, given that in each of the four sections, as the honourable Members have pointed out, there are particular problems for women which, in many cases, should be addressed with different policies. My next point concerns the specific actions already undertaken. As we know, the Portuguese Presidency has already set up a high-level group, which will present its first report to the Summit next June. The Portuguese Presidency focuses on two issues: sustainable pension systems and social inclusion. I think that the proposal to set up a similar group at parliamentary level is very positive, because it could help to take a further step forward after the approval of its establishment. In response to many of your comments on the role of social protection systems and their cost, as well as the role that these systems play in the competitiveness of Member States, I would like to point out that policies seek to reconcile competitiveness with social cohesion in Europe. Competitiveness must certainly be taken into account, but we must also think about the planning of social protection, so as to transform it into a factor of economic growth and employment. I believe that this is clear in the communication. Ladies and gentlemen, in the coming years, once the unanimous approval of the Council has been obtained, the objective will be to reach a first level of coordination, exchange of views, identification of social problems and creation of a database for better coordination of policies. As many Members have pointed out, I believe that an important step has already been taken: at the IGC, social protection issues will be addressed in depth and we will enter a new phase, where social policy will become a truly European policy. Thank you, Mrs Diamantopoulou. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11.30. WIPO Treaties The next item is the recommendation (A5-0008/2000) by Mrs Cederschiöld, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, on the proposal for a Council decision concerning the approval, on behalf of the European Community, of the WIPO Copyright Treaty and the WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty [COM(1998) 249 - C5-0222/1999 - 1998/0141 (AVC)].

Thank you very much, Mrs Schreyer. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. VOTES (Parliament approves the Commission proposal) Heaton-Harris (PPE-DE). Mr President, this is a point of order. I would like to ask for clarification regarding the Rules of Procedure: namely, Rules 133(2) and 133(4), both of which relate to voting. As regards votes other than roll-call votes, these are initially taken by show of hands, and only when certain doubts arise is electronic voting used. Is that correct? Indeed, dear colleague, I proceeded with a vote by show of hands, since no group had requested a roll-call vote. You know that a roll-call vote or electronic verification is only held if colleagues request it. In this case, I assure you that there was an overwhelming majority in favour of the directive we have just voted on. Mr President, I was not referring to this vote in particular, but to votes in general. It is obvious that some chairmen do not deal with the hands, so to speak, and proceed directly to the electronic vote. I wondered if this was the correct procedure. I know it takes longer, but should we not always vote by show of hands first? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with regard to this second reading, the Commission can accept the only proposed amendment put forward by Parliament. The Commission takes up and accepts the proposed amendment. I have three points to make. The first is that a mature dialogue between the Council and the European Parliament is essential. It is only six months since Amsterdam required our two institutions to work together; we have studied each other, we have had some small squabbles, but we really need to work together. Let us stop not taking things seriously. Let us abandon the elaborate charades and respect the duties that the Treaties impose on us and the time allowed for a truly democratic discussion. Involve us in your discussions on policy and the evolution of the process. Let us not pretend that national parliaments can exercise real democratic control over government activities in this area. My second point is that we need a Commission with adequate resources. We have set up a new Directorate-General, yet it only has 70 people in total. There is an agreement to double that number, but as far as I know no new resources have arrived so far. We are giving the Commission a very heavy task, not least that of drawing up the scoreboard. The Council and Parliament must work together to provide the resources the Commission needs. Finally, on the content of the debate, I welcome the fact that the Presidency has put the area of freedom, security and justice at the top of its agenda. Three seems to be the number that marks the good, especially in the area of European politics. Two hundred years ago it was about freedom, equality and fraternity and everything was fine until left-wing governments put equality above everything else. Now it is about freedom, security and justice, and I hope that the current left-wing governments will take Commissioner Vitorino's words into account and resist the temptation to elevate security, important as it is, above the equally important demands of freedom and justice. Mr President, I would like to join my colleagues in welcoming the Council representatives and the Commissioner. I thank them for their statements to the House. Rather than returning to the issues that have already been discussed, I would like to focus on one specific issue: the question of drugs and how we deal with the spread of drug culture in our societies. I hope in particular that the Portuguese Presidency will build on some of the enormous work done by the Finnish Presidency and come forward with coordinated plans and actions among Member States. At international level, there are already programmes to combat drug trafficking, money laundering and so on, but also, on a more human level, programmes to provide assistance to those seeking to free themselves from drug addiction, with adequate checks and mechanisms for rehabilitation; secondly, to ensure coordination between police forces and judicial systems on common laws and penalties; thirdly, to undertake an information and awareness-raising campaign for young people; and to put an end once and for all to the very dangerous terms of 'normalisation' and 'harm reduction' and to demonstrate that any weakening of our determination to prevent drugs from being legalised must be for the good of all.

In reality, the charge is about four times higher. The more remote the community, the greater the difference. This gives us an idea of the problem. It is not against liberalization to call for these factors to be taken into account and for the continuation of a universal and affordable postal service. On behalf of all our remote and island communities, wherever they may be in the European Union, and not just on behalf of the people of Scotland, I urge you to preserve the vital service that the postal service represents. Mr. President, I consider it a privilege to be representing my colleague, Commissioner Bolkestein, in such a high-level debate on postal services. I will endeavor, based on the information provided to me by Commissioner Bolkestein, to respond to the questions raised in the discussion. I would like to reiterate that Commissioner Bolkestein will be available to the Parliament's Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism on Monday. Some Members, such as Mr. Stenmarck, complain that there have been delays with the new proposal. Others believe that it is not a bad thing to have a short pause after the first liberalization step. Mr. Berthu, for example, shares this opinion. The Commission's position is that the delays surrounding the new proposal are mainly due to internal Commission problems, which Parliament may not be entirely unaware of. However, we believe there is a legal obligation for a proposal to be submitted. Commissioner Bolkestein intends to submit such a proposal to the Commission for adoption in the first half of this year. The planned deadline of 1 January 2003 for the implementation of the next steps remains feasible. The proposal will take into account the studies conducted and will examine, in particular, issues such as universal service, which I will return to shortly. As regards the current directive and its implementation, most Member States have taken the necessary legislative measures to transpose it. A number of problems exist relating to the structure of the regulator and its independence. The implementation deadline for the Member States is January 2003. Further liberalization will follow thereafter. In some areas, such as parcel and express services, competition already exists. The quality of service has generally improved, particularly in cross-border transport. The quality of service, which is so important for consumers, was the main concern of all speakers, and some of them, like Mr. Rübig, were very clear on this issue. The experience of countries where liberalization is more advanced, such as Sweden, Finland, and the Netherlands, shows that, provided liberalization proceeds properly, the quality of service can actually improve as a result of the higher quality requirements imposed by national regulations and subsequent measures. There is therefore no sell-off of service and its quality. Liberalization often leads to guaranteed standards, and the ongoing standardization of service quality measurements also contributes to this, as these standards better reflect actual performance. This allows for meaningful benchmarking and, as a result of the combined pressure from regulators, competitors and customers, improved customer orientation by the responsible operator.

This system seems unsuitable for practical use. However, to compensate for this, all possible obstacles must be removed before the service provision card is issued, and stricter conditions for issuing the service provision card must be met than those in the Commission's proposal. The requirements of legal employment, residence, and insurance coverage must be met not only at the time the card is issued, but also throughout the card's entire validity period and for three months thereafter. This should provide the receiving state with a guarantee that the employee or self-employed person will return to the sending state after completing their assignment and will be covered by insurance in the event of illness or accident. The entry and residence status should also be clarified before the service provision card is issued, within the framework of an appeal procedure. We propose that the EU service provision card not only must be applied for for all member states, but that it can also be applied for for individual member states. I believe that this system also better meets practical needs. I hope for the same from the proposal to reduce the minimum length of previous employment to three months and to base the validity of the service card more flexibly on the length of previous employment. However, we maintain that the maximum validity of the service card should be 12 months. For the self-employed, in addition to the changes already outlined, we propose that the residence criterion be tightened and that we provide a way to counteract possible abuse through bogus self-employment. I would also like to briefly address the amendments tabled, which go beyond those proposed by the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market. I would also like to say, of course, that I continue to support all of the amendments tabled by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which were adopted unanimously. I have myself tabled four amendments on behalf of my group, which essentially relate to the correct citation of a Council decision. I must say that I have received extremely contradictory statements from Parliament's services regarding how this Council decision should be correctly cited: only by the number, only by the date, or by both, as the Council decision is quoted in detail. Two amendments were cancelled by the services because their content was supposedly already taken into account in the report. I withdraw the two remaining amendments – Amendments 18 in the report on the self-employed and 21 on the employed. I can only appeal to the Conference of Presidents to reach an agreement as quickly as possible on the correct approach to the issue of comitology and how to cite correctly. That would make the lives of the rapporteurs in this House considerably easier in the future. There is also an amendment to both of Mrs De Palacio's reports. I regret to say that I cannot support this amendment because it fundamentally alters the result we reached unanimously in the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, and I would like to stick with the result we reached jointly in the Legal Affairs Committee after lengthy discussions. Finally, I would like to thank all my colleagues in the Legal Affairs Committee who supported me in these not-so-easy reports.

But since 1997, no significant results have been achieved. So far, the Cologne Employment Pact has not been able to be filled with much substance. Furthermore, the European Parliament, as an equal partner, is missing from the macroeconomic dialogue. Indeed, the Luxembourg guidelines on employment policy have been implemented by the Member States only insufficiently in some areas, for example, in the area of lifelong learning, as the 1999 Joint Employment Report noted. Particularly in the area of information technology, some European countries lack a skilled workforce, as Mr. Souminen stated. Better than their "imports" from third countries are relevant investments in vocational training and further training, in human capital. This is the most effective way to combat unemployment. The most important objective of the Summit, namely, improving the competitiveness of the European economy, must be achieved as quickly as possible. The Ciampi Group also mentions the statute for the European public limited company in this context. It estimates that the absence of such a statute means an annual economic loss of 30 billion euros. We do not want the pure European public limited company. We need this European company, accompanied by minimum criteria for worker participation. Indeed, our political and social objective is not the pure market economy, but the social market economy as a European model. We should also measure the Lisbon Summit according to its contribution to achieving this objective. Mr. President of the Council, do you know how Archimedes expounded his theory of the lever? He said: "Give me a fulcrum and I will lift the world." It is obvious that, in Lisbon, you are trying to lift the world, or in any case a world that is ours: that of Europe. As for the lever, you described all its mechanisms through your proposal, which is fascinating and exciting in many respects. The fulcrum remains. The fulcrum is resources. Now, you are here before an Assembly in which several members are still living with the memory of what I would call the White Paper syndrome, that formidable initiative by Jacques Delors that crashed against the accountants of Ecofin. We would not want the same thing to happen to you today, because the project you are proposing to us is so stimulating that it can revitalize and give Europe the future our colleague Goebbels desires. But that requires resources, resources which, I fear, you still lack today. It is therefore up to you to create them. And, certainly, the straitjacket of Agenda 2000 will not provide you with the necessary means. Therefore, you will have to encourage your colleagues to secure funding for the proposals you are going to make to us. An example—and it is one of the important mechanisms you are proposing to us—is that of the information and knowledge society.

The agreement with Macedonia must be seen as an open door to the country's accession to the European Union, even if this is still a very long-term prospect. In the meantime, our policy must be to ensure that Macedonia's legislation begins to resemble that of the Member States, and our policy must reflect this fact even in the names of the aid programmes for Macedonia. I am thinking here of the PHARE programme. The name of the republic, Mr President, is still problematic because of Greek sensitivities. I assume that the Member States will feel increasingly free to use whatever name suits the republic in their own language. If some countries wish to keep the words former Yugoslavia, that is their business; others should not be obliged to do so. There is no question of constantly putting us under pressure. That is why I support Mr Swoboda's intelligent report; he has not accustomed us to anything else, and this also explains my laudatory words about the respectable Republic of Macedonia. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, allow me to say how much I personally appreciated the quality of the work of the rapporteur, Mr Swoboda. We are voting today in favour of opening negotiations on a Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Macedonia. We do so in the knowledge that this decision, the very first concerning the region, is part of a completely new phase in our relations with the Balkans. It is itself a factor in this new phase, or rather this new policy which, in the perspective of the European integration of the region, determines the only possibility of a peaceful settlement of the conflicts which are shaking the Balkans. Our agreement on the negotiating mandate stems, as the rapporteur explains in his explanatory memorandum, from the conviction that the Union's policy must be supplemented by either a regional dimension or a more specific valuation of the efforts and results of the individual countries on the path to integration of the acquis communautaire. It is this dual objective that, in my opinion, we must pursue: on the one hand, we must support programmes relating, for example, to infrastructure, prepare the stages for the introduction of free trade - even if this is premature - and encourage initiatives for economic and commercial cooperation between the countries of the region; on the other hand, we must now create with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia a model for a policy of closer integration. That said, we can only, for various reasons, express a favourable opinion. As our missions to Skopje, in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, have observed, significant economic progress has been made in terms of democratic advances and, more delicate and difficult in this region, in the coexistence of several ethnic groups. Moreover, the country has paid a high price for the war in neighboring Kosovo, both in terms of logistical support for NATO forces and the decline in exports to northern Europe.

In this context, it is necessary to state very clearly which criteria should be used to select these rights. In my opinion, the essential criterion is the rights of citizens vis-à-vis the European institutions. These are the rights of citizens that flow from the European project enshrined in the Union Treaties. I understand your concern about children's rights. I believe that part of our work, and in particular my work as Commissioner for Justice and Home Affairs, is to ensure children's rights. In doing so, we are operating in an area where the principle of subsidiarity fully applies. The primary responsibility for defining responsibilities towards children lies with the Member States. As regards the Union's responsibility as such, I believe that children's rights must be recognised in the Charter, taking into account the areas in which the Union can bring added value to improving the social, economic and, in the broadest sense, civic situation of children. I hope we will succeed in meeting the challenge that the Honourable Member has set before the Commission and the Convention as a whole. Mr President, I have had the honour of hearing the Commissioner speak on this subject several times today, and I can only agree with him. However, I would like to ask a slightly different question. We have just heard from Mr Barnier that he intends to improve communication with citizens and place the main issues that the Commission will be addressing this year at the heart of the Commission's information policy. Would the Commission support the allocation of part of the Commission's information budget to informing and consulting citizens on the subject of a Citizens' Charter? It is very important that citizens feel involved in this process. I know that the Convention itself will do a great deal in this area, but the resources available to the Commission are not the same. Could the Commission envisage using part of its information budget to involve citizens in this debate? The Commission pursues a policy of open and inclusive debate on the Charter of Fundamental Rights, not only with non-governmental organizations, but also, given the far-reaching nature of this Charter, with all citizens. I can assure you that the Commission will do everything in its power to stimulate the debate on a future Charter of Fundamental Rights. The best solution would be a clearly worded text that is easy for citizens to understand and, at the same time, usable as a legal instrument. One does not exclude the other. The challenge is simply to shape the final version of the Charter so that it meets both requirements. I am very pleased that I can count on your support in this regard. Question No. 40 by (H-0095/00): Subject: Articles 6(1), 7(1), and 7(2) of the Treaty on European Union. Article 6(1) of the Treaty states: "The Union is founded on the principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, and the rule of law." Jörg Haider and the FPÖ, as is clear from some of their statements in recent years, do not respect human rights and fundamental freedoms as far as third-country nationals and minorities living in Austria are concerned.

It is limited to examining only three issues concerning the structure and functioning of just two institutions of the European Union – and that is not even an exhaustive one. Since they are well known to everyone, I hardly need mention them again. This statement is justified, on the one hand, by the demands in this regard made repeatedly and sometimes quite forcefully by European citizens, and, on the other, by the enormous scale of this enormous undertaking which the European Union has now embarked on with enlargement. In this respect, it is unacceptable that issues whose solution would ensure the smooth functioning of all, and not just certain, institutions of the European Union should be excluded from the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference. Consideration must also be given to the issues which concern and confront the citizens of Europe on a daily basis. The European Parliament has clearly expressed its support for the convening of the Intergovernmental Conference in many debates and in the reports submitted so far. At the same time, however, I call for issues that will improve and perfect the reform—I repeat—of all the institutions, as well as areas of direct concern and interest to European citizens, to be discussed there. These include, for example, health, energy, culture, transport, and tourism. Whether or not an expansion of the agenda will ultimately be implemented has not yet been decided. Let me take this opportunity to truly commend the political conduct of the Portuguese Presidency, for it has repeatedly committed itself to the European Parliament to make the necessary efforts in this regard. On the other hand, the question of whether further points are included should in no way diminish the importance that each individual Member State must attach to the Intergovernmental Conference. The institutional framework for the future of Europe is, in fact, a fundamental principle of European integration and therefore a matter of the utmost national importance for every Member State of the Union. I therefore ask this House to approve the opinion presented to you by Mr Leinen and myself, so that the Intergovernmental Conference can open on 14 February and our two representatives at that Conference, Mr Brok and Mr Tsatsos, can, with the European Parliament's approval, begin the difficult task that awaits them there. The same applies to the European Commission, and I would like to thank Commissioner Barnier once again for his cooperation with the European Parliament and his extremely constructive proposals. Mr President, the Group of the European People's Party was not satisfied with the outcome of the Helsinki European Council. The agenda seemed too short to us because our group placed itself in the logic of the Treaty and, more specifically, in the Protocol on the Union's institutions. In Helsinki, governments confirmed that a mini-reform was sufficient as long as the European Union consisted of fewer than 21 Member States, whereas with more members, a more far-reaching reform was necessary. The same Helsinki European Council approved enlargement to include 13 new Member States. Thus, there is an inconsistency between the opening of accession negotiations with 13 states and the desire for a mini-reform. We, however, continue to follow the logic of the Treaty and want the agenda of the next Intergovernmental Conference to allow for a more profound reform of the Union.

Is it conceivable to apply a tax base based on the equivalent of alcohol? The question of excise duties, to which the Honourable Member refers, is a matter for the Member States concerned. The Commission has no means of imposing a reduction or increase in excise duties on alcoholic beverages or other products. The Commission will present a report on excise duty differentials between Member States towards the end of the year. There is no doubt that such a report will give rise to a discussion with both Parliament and the Council, given the substantial differences in the level of excise duty rates between Member States. For example, I believe the Honourable Member was referring to this point, in France there is no excise duty on wine, whereas in the United Kingdom there is, which distorts the single market because wine is smuggled from France to the United Kingdom. The question specifically concerned the relationship between excise duties and the alcohol content of goods subject to excise duty. The Commission has no means of intervening. In the case of Sweden, excise duties are indeed used to reduce alcohol consumption. Although this leads to a disparity in excise duties between Sweden and the other Member States of the Union - and this in turn increases cross-border smuggling of alcohol - it is a legitimate instrument to reduce alcohol consumption. Of course there is also the elasticity of demand, in our case the price elasticity of demand. I am not sure what the value is, but it is not equal to zero and therefore has an effect. My question would have been practically the same as that of Mr Purvis, but I will insist. Given that, as you say, excise duties are a prerogative of the Member States, using that prerogative in a way that unfairly discriminates against producers in one region of the Community compared with others could still conflict with the principle of the single market. Returning to the example of Mr Purvis, and I am thinking in particular of malt whiskey production in the Highlands - a very depressed, remote region of Europe, with a whole farming community dependent on it as well as the distillery sector - the widespread practice of imposing higher excise duties on the alcohol contained in Scotch whiskey, Dutch gin or Danish brandy than on the alcohol contained in beer or wine seems to me to be discrimination and a discriminatory use of a power which is clearly the prerogative of the Member States. I can confirm to Mr MacCormick and the other Members that the current situation, namely the existence of different excise duties between Member States, is indeed not conducive to the proper functioning of the single market. We must not limit ourselves to alcoholic beverages alone. In the case of petrol, for example, excise duties in Germany are different from those in the Netherlands and as a result Dutch motorists cross the border to fill up in Germany. This is clearly a distortion of the internal market.

Although the civil war in Cambodia is over and the political situation has eased, the way in which the political opposition is now being treated fills us with great concern. If this continues, there must be consequences for the Union's relations with Cambodia. Mr President, a new doctrine is currently gaining ground in international law, according to which no state may treat its citizens and those living within its territory as it pleases, and state sovereignty does not constitute an obstacle to external intervention in cases of gross human rights violations, even if the government itself was legally or even democratically elected. Evocative examples of this are the Pinochet-Ugarte case, the Kosovo conflict, and, to a lesser extent, the debate within the Union's own ranks about the formation of a government in Austria. The same danger now exists in Cambodia if the former leadership of the violent regime cannot be held legally accountable. At the same time, the fight against impunity, the impunity of those responsible, is being jeopardized. This situation should also remind us that the ratification of the treaty establishing an International Criminal Court is progressing extremely slowly. Mr President, we had a very useful debate on human rights yesterday. I am pleased that this has provided another opportunity to highlight a number of areas in the world—Kosovo, Angola, Chechnya, and Cambodia—where the protection of human rights poses a particularly great challenge. First, Kosovo. The Commission fully shares the concerns expressed in the draft resolutions regarding the general policy towards Kosovo, the ongoing ethnic violence, and the prisoners in Serbian penitentiaries. Our efforts in Kosovo and the wider region are directed toward short- and medium-term recovery and long-term stabilization. We support, in particular, the emergence of a free, democratic, and multi-ethnic society. Our assistance programs in the areas of democratization and human rights should be continued in order to build trust in general and, in particular, to build trust between the various communities. We have consistently condemned ethnic violence, regardless of the ethnic group at stake or victim. We consider it just as unacceptable against the Serb and Roma minorities as we considered it unacceptable against the Kosovo Albanians in the past. We support the efforts of UNMIK, KFOR, and the OSCE to establish a functioning civilian administration and to ensure law and order. In this context, we strongly support the High Representative's recent appeal to Member States to contribute more police officers to the UN civilian police mission in Kosovo. This point was raised by several speakers during the debate. I hope this makes it clear that, in developing a common foreign and security policy, we must address both the non-military and the military aspects of that policy. We must have clear objectives for our oversight and institution-building, but it is equally important that we have clear objectives for a military capacity. We remain deeply concerned that so many civilians are currently being held in Serbian prisons awaiting trial or following conviction.

My answer is perhaps unsatisfactory at this time, but I would like to assure you that the Commission will make that decision within a matter of weeks. I ask for your understanding for this slight delay in the Commission's decision. Commissioner, do you have any reason, for reasons of public health, to make a difference in the tax rates applied, for example, to Scotch whisky or French Bordeaux wine, or even to my colleague's Bavarian beer? Is it possible to provide for the application of an equivalent base for alcoholic beverages in the European tax system? The issue of excise duties, to which you refer, is a prerogative of the Member State concerned. The Commission does not have the instruments to apply an increase or reduction in excise duties on alcoholic products or any other product. Towards the end of this year, the Commission will present a report on the differences that exist between Member States regarding excise duties. The report will undoubtedly trigger a debate with Parliament and the Council on the current situation, which reflects the existence of significant differences between Member States regarding excise rates. For example, in France—and I believe this is what the honourable Member was referring to—wine is exempt from excise duty, while in the United Kingdom it is not. This creates a distortion of the internal market, leading to the smuggling of French wine into the United Kingdom. The issue relates specifically to the relationship between excise duty and the alcohol content of products subject to excise duty. The Commission has no means at its disposal to intervene in this area. In the case of Sweden, the instrument of excise duty is used to curb alcohol consumption. Although this practice results in inequalities in excise duty between Sweden and other EU Member States—which in itself increases cross-border smuggling of alcoholic products—it is a legitimate instrument for reducing alcohol consumption. There is, of course, elasticity of demand, in this case, a price elasticity of demand. I'm not quite sure what it is exactly, but it's not zero, so it must have repercussions. My question would have been almost identical to the one asked by Mr. Purvis, but I would like to press the issue a little further. Agreed, as you say, excise duties are part of the prerogatives of the Member States. However, using that prerogative in a way that unfairly discriminates against producers in one part of the Community compared to those in others could infringe the principle of the single market. For example, if we take the case that Mr. Purvis and I were thinking of, that of the Highlands where malt whisky is produced - a very peripheral area of Europe which is in a difficult situation, where an entire farming community as well as the distilling community depends on whisky - the general practice of taxing alcohol - Scotch whisky, Dutch gin or Danish aquavit - at a higher rate than the alcohol in beer or the alcohol in wine - seems to me to be discrimination and a discriminatory use of something which, I recognize, is part of the prerogatives of Member States.

Next week I'm going to the Bundestag in Berlin. I've already been to the French Senate. So, throughout this debate, whenever I can, I'll also go directly to see the national representatives. This dialogue with citizens is not about propaganda, publicity, or even communication. I would like it to be a real dialogue, and after the screening of a short film in which the imperatives of institutional reform are objectively explained, those present here in the galleries can intervene and respond with an open microphone. We are going to carry out—I repeat—this initiative for dialogue in sporadic or structured cooperation with the Member States, and I ardently hope that the governments of the Fifteen, with the support of the honourable Members, will participate, according to the modalities they consider most appropriate and suitable, in this initiative for dialogue. Mr. President, I would like to join Mr. Barnier's study group of 700 interns so that I have someone to debate with. It's not very fun having to discuss the Governmental Conference and transparency with oneself. Regarding the Governmental Conference, Mr. Barnier said during his presentation in Parliament that social policy was not subject to majority decisions. However, looking at page 63, I see that the fight against discrimination, the right of free movement and establishment—that is, the residence directives—all social security, the renewal of Regulation No. 1408, and measures in the area of social policy—with a few exceptions—will be subject to qualified majority voting. Does Mr. Barnier have no qualms about touching the backbone of the electoral processes in member countries with this? These are the issues that drive people to the polls and lead to a new majority in the Danish Parliament and other parliaments. Can they be regulated from Brussels? Is this part of the radical decentralization process that Mr. Prodi spoke about this morning? I was very pleased to learn last week that the Commission will be paying special attention for several years to the concept of subsidiarity, and its reference not only to relations between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Union, the Member States, the regions, and the cities. I hope that in his pursuit of dialogue for Europe's regions, Commissioner Barnier will delve deeper into this thinking and learn from what he hears. Commissioner, I refer to one of your answers to previous questions in which you mentioned what I call the possibilities of closing the Treaty in the face of risks of deviation and, in particular, the diversification of the sanctions that can be imposed on a Member State, pursuant to Article 7, for violations of fundamental freedoms. Do you believe that such proposals or proposals of that nature can be part of the mandate of the IGC, as formulated in Helsinki? For my part, I do not think so. Aren't you afraid that such sanctions will be misdirected and not serve to punish human rights violations, but rather simple disagreements, crimes of opinion, or divergences from mainstream European thinking?

Finally, they reiterated, in contemporary terms, the proposals in President Delors' White Paper for promoting a European project aimed at achieving a unified network of infrastructure and services. These suggestions, which largely coincide with the guidelines of the Portuguese Presidency's programmatic document, which will therefore be debated at the Lisbon Summit, have been rejected and distorted within this Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs by a majority that has been able to find its precarious unity only in its ideological aversion to a European Union based on the convergence of national policies and not solely on an assembly of markets. This Parliament, Mr. President, which has on numerous occasions demonstrated a strong pro-European vocation, must demonstrate in this circumstance that it can express a majority in favor of a political union of Europe, capable of confronting the weaknesses and failures of the markets. Mr. President, Mr. Katiforis's report is interesting. In its original version, it shows the path toward a renewed economic policy, which aims for more than just cuts and balance. The EU is in a position where we can achieve high growth and seriously combat unemployment, without jeopardizing objectives such as price stability and a balanced budget. It is therefore regrettable that the EPP-ED and ELDR voted in committee against the proposal that addressed the serious fight against unemployment. The debate and vote here in plenary should correct this. However, it is gratifying that unity has been achieved on some strategic proposals, namely that the Union's economic policy should prioritize investments, among other things, to integrate all citizens of the Union into the information society, something that can also have great economic significance. I also think that the trans-European network connections must be strengthened so that they reach the candidate countries, both with regard to physical transport and IT infrastructure. This is important for growth, but also for avoiding differences between people, both within the EU and vis-à-vis the candidate countries. The candidate countries must not be left behind; part of the project must be for the EU to become a global pioneer in the field of communications. This requires society to assume responsibility for the rapid and energetic construction of modern information technology infrastructures that reach small businesses, poor regions, and ordinary citizens. Now is our opportunity; let's seize it! Mr. President, the advantage of speaking at the end of a debate is that we can object to what has been said before. I would like to say that I completely disagree with Mrs. Villiers about this being such an interesting debate. I believe that the European Parliament is doing a great disservice by dwelling only on outdated concepts and expressing outdated political currents and ideas.

This is the only time I've spoken about it. But today I have to do so, and I do so from the heart. I was born in Germany, Madam President, I was educated in Sweden, and I married a Spaniard. I know what democracy is because I had the advantage of growing up in a country like Sweden, which had a long democratic tradition. I came to the Basque Country with all my goodwill for integration, and despite what has happened to me, I remain convinced that one day the Basque Country will have the desired peace, because to those who think there is conflict in the Basque Country, I say that the only conflict the Basque Country has is called ETA, and it must disappear. We'll talk about the rest. (Loud and prolonged applause) We democrats will resolve the rest by expressing all our ideas, because there is freedom of expression in the Basque Country, there is freedom to vote, there is freedom. The only thing that restricts this freedom is ETA. Let ETA disappear, and let the democrats speak. (Loud applause) I thank you, Mrs. Dührkop Dührkop, and express my sympathy and respect. Approval of the Minutes of the previous sitting. The minutes of the previous sitting have been distributed. Are there any comments? We are about to consider the matter of Committee reform, and as you will recall, Madam President, at the beginning of the last part-session, I raised the question of whether, in the interests of transparency, the register of Members' interests could be made more widely available to the public by publishing it on the Internet. You promised Parliament that you would raise this matter with the Quaestors that evening. I would like to know if you are now in a position to confirm to Parliament whether the Quaestors have agreed in principle that the register should be published on the Internet and, if so, whether you will personally set them a deadline—perhaps April 1—for doing so. Ladies and gentlemen, the Bureau has expressed its agreement in principle to include online registration of the register in which Members must declare their financial interests, but the Quaestors are still reflecting on the legal issues that this entails. We will have a decision very soon. (The Minutes were approved) Reform of the Commission. The next item is the Commission's communication on the reform of the European Commission. I now give the floor to Mr. Romano Prodi. (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last July, here before you, I solemnly undertook the commitment to reform the Commission. I would like to briefly recall what happened last July: after the crisis at the previous Commission, I had just been appointed, and you ratified that appointment for the first time. The culminating moment of that episode was my commitment to reform the Commission: a major reform that must bring about a true revolution in the way the Commission works.

In that sense, we believe we fully respect what we concluded. I simply ask the Commission, before implementing the second tranche, to report to the Committee on Budgets. I fully agree, and we will do so. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:00. ALTENER The next item is the report (A5-0011/2000) by Mr. Langen on the joint text, approved by the Conciliation Committee, of the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council (C5-0333/1999 - 1997/0370(COD)) adopting a multiannual programme for the promotion of renewable energy sources in the Community. Mr. President, I would like to thank Mr. Langen—although he is not present—for the work he has done to ensure that this programme is approved both in Parliament and in the Council. This project has been long and complicated. In the future, research aimed at determining the use of renewable energy sources must also continue to be significantly encouraged. While this new directive has many strengths, it also has many flaws. For example, the absence of bog peat in the directive. Peat should not be classified in the same group as fossil fuels. If peat cannot be directly included among renewable energies, among non-fossil energy sources, then it should be considered as a specific group, especially when it comes to applying an environmental tax. It is unfair for peat to be assessed using the same indicators as, for example, hard coal. The development of renewable energy sources is part of the range of solutions to end the Union's dependence on imported energy. Research also plays a key role in the framework of the next round of negotiations for EU enlargement. Dependence on imported energy most severely affects some Eastern European countries, whose economic infrastructure is still subject to the dependence on Russian energy that was created during the Soviet era. The EU adheres to the Kyoto Protocol on climate change. We are all concerned about the environment and the future of our children. We must increase the share of renewable energy sources in the bulk of energy production, but this must also be done in a rational manner. We must remember that it will take a long time before we are in a position to build our energy production base solely on renewable energy sources. And for this, we will need climate-neutral energy: nuclear energy. Mr. President, on behalf of the PSE Group, I am pleased that we have achieved a result in the conciliation procedure on the ALTENER II program. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Langen, for the excellent work he has done on this report. I would also like to thank the head of the delegation to the Conciliation Committee, Mr. Provan, because, as Mr. Langen has already pointed out, the fight in the Conciliation Committee has been tough. However, today we can see that the outcome of the conciliation clearly bears the stamp of the European Parliament.

Perhaps before we direct our criticisms at people outside Parliament, we should do some soul-searching to really understand what we are doing. Mr President, I will not use my speaking time to deal with the individual cases that we are dealing with today. I agree with Mrs Plooij-van Gorsel that we cannot discuss them in detail. Perhaps next time we should talk about CORUS, the merger between Nederlandse Hoogovens and British Steel. I would like to put the discussion in a slightly broader context, looking at the relationship between EU policy in the field of corporate mergers and policy in other areas. In this respect, I am pleased that Commissioner Liikanen is here and that we can have this debate, which concerns workers' interests, not only with Commissioner Diamantopoulou, but also with Commissioners responsible for other sectors. Unlike the previous speaker, who assumes that there should be no rules, I would like to call for greater coherence in the Commission's policy in this area, taking into account the different perspectives. We need to develop a view that takes into account the reality of business. We are currently witnessing the emergence of numerous large mergers between companies with an Anglo-Saxon tradition and companies with ties to the Rhine tradition. In this context, what remains of the concept of what a company should be is of enormous importance, i.e. whether it represents exclusively a property in the hands of shareholders or whether it constitutes a broader stakeholder society, aimed both at ensuring a certain continuity for workers, consumers, suppliers and the local population, and at fulfilling a social function. I therefore call on the Directorates-General of the Commission and the various Commissioners to develop a broader vision of corporate government. I think this would be highly appropriate in view of the programmes presented in recent days on good government in Europe, of which corporate policy is also a part. In Italy too, the government is meeting with a delegation of trade unions and Goodyear delegates to try to find a solution to the closure policy unilaterally decided by the North American multinational in an area of central Italy, Cisterna di Latina, already affected by other restructurings. The closure means the loss of more than a thousand jobs, both direct and indirect, hundreds of families left to insecurity and new poverty. Goodyear workers are leading an exemplary fight, with the awareness that they are not only defending their interests but also those of Goodyear workers in various European countries, and there are many of them: France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Poland, Luxembourg and Slovenia. Today, a small delegation of workers is here with us in the gallery, anxious to understand what their future will be and what solidarity the European Union will offer, what policy it will adopt to prevent multinationals from acting solely and exclusively in their market and profit interests. Goodyear, like other multinationals, has received more than 166 billion. The European Union, in all its instances, must exercise all its power to ensure that these and other disputes are resolved.

Question Time to the Commission is closed. (The sitting, suspended at 7:30 p.m., resumed at 9:00 p.m.) Community water policy (continued) The next item is the continuation of the debate on the recommendation for second reading on Community water policy. Mr President, the freshwater situation in Europe is not as serious as in other parts of the world, but, in general terms, it is a fact that demand for water has continued to grow and its quality has continued to decline. Added to this are the water pollution problems affecting the potential new Member States in the East. Has not a tank containing cyanide just burst in Romania, threatening the aquifers that supply the people of Yugoslavia? I understand that Mrs Wallström, whom I thank very much for being here this evening, will be visiting the region. I believe that no country, no government, and, of course, no Member of this Parliament can deny the need for this directive to put an end to the fragmentation currently characterizing water policy and facilitate the implementation of a program of measures specific to each river basin. The gestation has been difficult and complex; the interests at stake are multiple and opinions divided. I have no doubt that the rapporteur in this legislature, Mrs. Lienemann, has made a great effort and spent a lot of time reconciling and conciliating positions, and she has largely succeeded. However, knowing and correctly assessing all the situations and perspectives is an almost impossible task. I come from a country whose southern half looks out onto the Mediterranean, and where water availability has historically responded to the whims of a changing climate and a difficult terrain. The Mediterranean region has had to fight for its development, trying to overcome this adversity century after century, year after year, and day after day, right up to the present day. This is why the practical application of the directive to the obligation, contained in Article 164 of the Treaty, that Community legislation must take into account the diversity of its regions, seems essential to us.
