Precisely in application of this principle, the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will oppose Amendments 4 (recital 21), 13 and 49 (Article 11, letter d) because they imply a serious limitation in an area of exclusive management by the Member States, such as the regulation of their water resources. The Community would find it very difficult to determine the conditions for its regulation in the different regions, given the different internal balances that are always at stake and which in any case require a thorough knowledge of the different areas and interests concerned. Likewise, we reject the amendments that seek to include the total cost of water for 2010. We must unquestionably set water prices that encourage its efficient use but, at the same time, allow the competitiveness of production sectors in the most disadvantaged regions to be maintained and do not prevent their legitimate development.

Will you include it in the work of your audit committee? Finally, the Socialist Group agrees with activity-based and accountability-based budgeting, and, as Mr. Prodi says, you will be judged by your actions, not your words. This item is closed. I thank President Prodi and Commissioner Kinnock. Statement by the High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy. The next item is the statement by the High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy. I have the pleasure of extending a warm welcome to Mr. Javier Solana, to whom I immediately give the floor. Madam President, as you can imagine, it is a great pleasure for me to be with you again here in the European Parliament. Since the last time, ladies and gentlemen, that I appeared before you to address you on issues related to foreign and security policy on our continent, many things have happened. Sometimes we would think that too much has happened. This afternoon, I would like to share some thoughts with you, primarily on the Common Foreign and Security Policy. It is true, as I have said, that the world has moved a great deal in recent months and a number of events have taken place, but I will leave it until the question and answer period to address any of the questions you may have. Over the past few months, since I last appeared before you, important events have taken place here, including in the European Union. Allow me to remind you of two. One is very dear to all of you, Members of Parliament, and especially to the Presidency: the inauguration of the Intergovernmental Conference and the opening of negotiations with the future members of the European Union. Undoubtedly, the events in Kosovo and in the Balkans in general have stirred all our hearts and minds; important issues in the Middle East, where the President of Parliament played an important role on her recent trip; Some important events to unblock the summit between Europe and Africa, in which I had the pleasure of participating in cooperation with the Portuguese Presidency; the major meeting that took place in Portugal, in Vilamoura, with the eighteen Latin American countries to try to build a deeper relationship between the European Union and the countries of Latin America. Chechnya has undoubtedly also been close to our hearts, and I will have the opportunity to say a few words at the end of my speech, following an important conversation I had this morning with the representative of the Council of Europe, Mr. Álvaro Gil-Robles, about his recent visit to the region. But I understand that you have asked me to appear here to speak to you more directly about foreign policy and, above all, about security policy in Europe after Helsinki. I will refer to that briefly; if you would be kind enough to ask questions during the question period, I will be happy to answer them. Let me remind you that the summit under the Finnish Presidency in Helsinki took place not a century ago, but barely two months ago. Fundamental decisions for our continent's foreign and security policy were made in Helsinki.

While restructuring to improve competitiveness and gain market share is laudable from an economic point of view, such a measure can be reprehensible if it is carried out at the request of financiers, who are often shareholders, for the sole, unacknowledged purpose of increasing the value of these companies in order to generate greater profits. The various recent announcements mentioned by my colleagues, whether by Michelin or Goodyear, are symptomatic in this regard. In my view, rationalization of management and improved results must primarily serve the company and, therefore, its employees, although this may also have financial repercussions. Today, a process of mergers and acquisitions and of production relocations is underway, with their well-known effects on product quality, as well as their dramatic social repercussions on a human level, especially for the family as the core unit of society, notably unemployment, more difficult working conditions, and greater flexibility. There is therefore a grave danger of our planet becoming divided: on the one hand, the poor countries that supply labor, and on the other, the rich countries that provide capital. Shouldn't Europe offer protection to maintain a certain balance between greater profitability and social well-being? We should not forget that human capital is the foundation of a company's operation, ensuring its good results. Finally, I would like to point out that the third letter in the name of the group to which I belong means "difference." Europe has the task of raising its voice as an alternative to purely profit-driven, unregulated restructuring, pointing in a different direction in this single stream of restructuring. Mr President, in one of my neighboring regions, last month the Michelin Group announced large-scale layoffs at its Stoke-on-Trent plant due to the company's restructuring and increasing global competition in the world tire market. Like all the Members present, I am saddened by this loss of jobs. I am equally saddened by Goodyear's announcement, which prompted this resolution. However, I very much doubt whether a European Works Council would have been able to change that company's decision. This House is indeed very good at drafting resolutions and laws, and sometimes we in this institution forget that Europe cannot survive alone. We need multinational companies that have their business base on our continent. After the few months I have been here, I find it astonishing that while we all talk about the need to encourage business growth in the EU, almost every resolution we pass actually causes companies to leave. At our last plenary session in Brussels, we voted on the End-of-Life Vehicles Directive and passed a retroactive law that will impose huge additional costs on European motor vehicle manufacturers that they could not have foreseen. Two days later, Toyota, which employs several thousand people in my region, announced that this directive would not only increase the cost of cars but could also mean redundancies at its Derbyshire factory. In a world where less regulation is certainly crucial, we in this House seem to believe that we can impose more regulation and more costs on companies and that they will remain in the European Union without being tempted to move to other locations with less burden.

We cannot therefore say that we are completely dissatisfied with what has been achieved. Of course, it is always better to have more resources available - I will continue to insist on this point - and more quickly. However, I believe that this programme offers good prospects for many others. I would like to point out that culture is not financed exclusively from this fund. Culture is not only included in the chapter that bears this name, but falls within many other areas. Significant resources for culture are also available within the Structural Funds, an aspect that we must take into account and highlight. Fortunately for me, I am a member of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism and therefore I will work to ensure that this aspect receives the attention it deserves. I also believe that it has been decided to support the position according to which the planned budget is sufficient. In fact, if the proposed changes do not come to fruition, the citizens will pay the consequences. I have always supported the rapporteur from this point of view. However, I believe that it is necessary, as the rapporteur reiterates, to arrive at a change in the codecision procedure within the IGC. In this case, unanimity will no longer be necessary. We view the many improvements that have been made very positively. There is no longer any talk of mega-projects, space is being made for cultural networks, and attention is being shifted to promoting reading and translations, which are very important issues for the smaller language areas. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and Mrs Reding on this text on CULTURE 2000. Now I can only say: let us get to work. Madam President, the honourable Members who preceded me have already covered all my points and I believe that there is consensus among the parliamentary groups and among the members of the Committee on Culture. I must say that, reluctantly, I too will vote in favour of the draft joint decision of the Council and Parliament. I say reluctantly because of the unacceptable attitude of the Council and not because our delegation, the rapporteur and President Gargani have not done a very good job - quite the opposite - or because I have objections to the position taken by Commissioner Reding, who has adopted a very positive attitude given the margins at her disposal. Shame! An allocation of EUR 167 million for so many years is a disgrace for the European Union! We are literally forced to humiliate theatre groups, young musicians, pioneers of the arts and literature, giving a sop to one and failing thirty others, and we offer the image of a Europe that is alien, hostile, hostile and opposed to any attempt at cultural activity, when in fact the Union should not be absent. Such a conclusion is truly painful, given that our future is not only made up of euros, enlargements or geostrategic conveniences, but we must also ensure cultural growth for European unification. There will be no progress as long as we maintain the principle of unanimity, according to which yesterday the Netherlands imposed its ultimatum of 167 million euros and tomorrow the Haider government will tell us which cultural activities should be supported.

Parks have been set up all over the place, which are a key element of the LIFE programme. The fact remains that these parks, built with little financial resources and without signage, have no effect and serve no purpose. I therefore call on Parliament and the Commission to give this matter the attention it deserves. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the beginning of 1999, discussions have been taking place between the institutions on the proposed regulation concerning a third stage for the environmental instrument - LIFE. I would like once again to congratulate the Committee on the Environment and Mrs Lienemann on the excellent and constructive cooperation we have had on this matter. Thanks to this cooperation, I can confirm that the Commission can accept in full or in principle nine of the fourteen amendments adopted by the Committee on the Environment. The Commission approves, above all, Amendments 1, 2, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 13, relating to comitology procedures. Parliament has, in this case, fully taken into account the Commission's objections to the common position. The Commission can also approve Amendment 4 in principle, although it must be introduced in a different way into the text. Regarding Amendments 5 and 6, I would like to point out that the project for the sustainable use of groundwater and surface water, as well as the project to limit atmospheric pollutants that contribute to the greenhouse effect, are largely covered by LIFE. However, the Commission believes that mentioning this separately runs counter to the initial decision to focus the proposal on a few priority points. There is also a risk of overlap with other Community programmes such as the Fifth Framework Programme for research, technological development and demonstration activities. The key measures in this programme – water quality, the city of tomorrow and innovative products and processes – partly cover the same topics. As for the budget, I welcome the confidence shown by the Environment Committee. Amendment 12 proposes a larger budget than that set out in the common position. I am also convinced that LIFE has enormous potential. This instrument could finance good projects with appropriations greater than those mentioned in the budget proposal. The amount set out in Amendment 12, however, is not in line with the budget plan drawn up on the basis of Agenda 2000. Let me also add that if the budget is increased, it is clear that the Environment Directorate will also be required to handle an increasing number of projects. Other programmes must also be taken into account, for which decisions must be taken under the codecision procedure. The Commission is, at this stage, sticking to the amount set out in the common position. As regards Amendment 3, which we did not adopt at first reading, I would like to point out that each programme has its own objectives, eligible costs and requests.

This applies to the minimum rights laid down in the Treaty, to safeguarding the free movement of workers—while simultaneously preserving social rights—and it also applies to economic coordination and cooperation. We therefore need coordination and cooperation, but convergence should be sought in terms of objectives, not means. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Jan Andersson, for his very constructive efforts to reconcile differing opinions and for supporting his report. I personally support the report, but I am critical of certain points. For example, I do not support the demand that the Commission take action against so-called unfair competition between social and tax systems if such intervention is to be used to stifle innovative thinking, development, and more effective design of our social systems, or to prevent the reduction of excessive tax burdens in many EU countries. I reject detailed Commission regulations on the extent and quality of childcare or elderly care, and I am skeptical about setting a value for a common poverty line. The coordination of social policy and dialogue is good. However, we should not treat everyone according to the same pattern; there must be room for a variety of possible solutions. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to make some positive comments on the modernization of social protection outlined here, but I would also like to point out problem areas. I welcome the fact that this dossier is slowly but surely moving forward. I consider that to be correct and useful. I am also positive about the guidelines of the communication, the strategy. Hopefully, the four objectives identified therein can then be reasonably achieved. We would also like to underline the importance of the way in which we are tackling the problem: on the one hand, the Luxembourg-style process, guidelines. But we also need, for example, as Mrs van Lancker has already pointed out, guidelines for atypical work, for the self-employed without employees, etc. Nevertheless, two problems are likely to arise for which we must find solutions. Firstly, the level of social protection is being lowered where we hope for convergence at a level. Let me cite a few examples from a recent study conducted by Dutch trade unions on the impact of reforms in the European Union on social protection. According to this study, convergence is taking place everywhere. Many, indeed most, of the convergence is clearly downward, while the rest are improvements. Most adjustments relate to pensions: eleven reductions and two improvements. Regarding unemployment benefits, we observe six deteriorations and five improvements. The convergence is due, for example, to the promotion of employment and the reduction of social spending, but also to competition and the EMU criteria. This political competition is primarily found in the northern countries. The most secure social protection and even improvements are observed in the southern countries. All in all, the influence of the social partners in this entire process is likely to decline. That is not encouraging, and therefore the convergence strategy should be based on the best approaches. Cappuccino, to put it that way, does not always do us good. Mr President, Now, for my part, I would like to congratulate the Commission and the rapporteur. The Commission for taking another step toward social protection convergence, and the rapporteur for delivering an excellent report.

Social integration, which requires a firm commitment in economic, political, and social terms on the part of the responsible authorities, is the only way to prevent these events from recurring in places where there are already large communities of immigrant workers. We are all immigrants. For generations, human beings have not always remained within the borders of a nation state. There have been constant migratory flows. Geographical mobility is not a 20th-century invention, nor are their economic and labor reasons. We are all immigrants, whether personally or through a member of our family or one of our ancestors. However, instead of being the cause of events that we condemn here, these migratory flows must generate social, cultural, and economic enrichment. We believe that what happened in El Ejido, which unfortunately is not exclusive to this locality in the European Union, requires, first of all, the clear and unequivocal condemnation of the brutal racist and xenophobic outburst by some residents of El Ejido against immigrant workers in the area, blaming, criminalizing and attacking an entire community for an isolated incident that we all regret. Secondly, it requires immediate action from all administrations; coordination between them is essential in order to combat this type of xenophobic and racist acts. More specifically, local authorities, mayors, have a direct responsibility in preventing any racist or xenophobic manifestation, even more so when it involves violent events against people and their property. These authorities also have the obligation to promote difficult agreements between the parties involved and not to prevent them, as is the case with the mayor of El Ejido. Thirdly, this requires that political parties assume direct responsibility in the political exercise of their public functions and prevent any individual act or statement that is contrary to the principles and values of coexistence and tolerance expressed by the European Union. Finally, it requires the European Union to be responsible for monitoring the application of its principles, preserving its territory from any manifestations of a racist or xenophobic nature, and to support and collaborate with the rest of the national, regional and local administrations, as well as with associations and non-governmental organizations, in the application of these principles and in the context of ongoing action to combat racism and xenophobia and promote the integration of all immigrants residing in the territory of the European Union. Mr President, initially, our group did not see the need to present this proposal because it appeared to be a local phenomenon. However, the events in El Ejido are a symptom of a phenomenon that is sweeping across the whole of Europe and deserves the greatest attention. We thought we were rid of the horror of intolerance that racism had unleashed in Europe, but as the years go by, why not say it? The social degradation in our Europe is combined with the increase in migratory flows from the countries around us and a greater awareness of human rights, and this climate of racism and intolerance is increasing. That is why what seemed to be a local phenomenon - in El Ejido - is becoming a worrying symptom that coincides with the rise of parties like Haider's. That is why we are proposing, from the European Parliament, the adoption of urgent measures that address all the factors involved and that are immediately applicable: respect for human rights, tolerance and multiculturalism, the increase of budgets and lines of action in social and health matters.

The question, Your Honor, is one that we must all ask ourselves, and I recently did so diplomatically. It concerns the very consistency of Security Council resolution 12/99. I know it is an extraordinarily delicate issue, but we must all question the logic underlying that resolution and the possibility of its implementation. We are in favor of its full and complete implementation. However, we must examine that resolution—and this is probably something the United Nations Security Council will have to do, sooner or later—in the sense that, as has happened in the past in other global strategic frameworks and scenarios, we can examine whether or not certain types of procedures and certain types of logic and balances should be maintained in the future, which, moreover, were the logic and balances that led to the adoption of the resolution. What we must do, what we are doing on behalf of the European Union, is to guarantee Mr. Kouchner every means, and the Honorable Member is right: we have an obligation, before our citizens, to explain regularly and clearly to what extent these means are being used appropriately or not. For the Council, we intend to provide information on this during the Portuguese Presidency. Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, I fully agree with you. The problem is not Mr. Kouchner, but the legal basis on which he works, namely, Resolution 1244. That said, I believe that the Union's responsibility—yours, but also ours—is to begin working to overcome this provisional nature of Resolution 1244 and imagine a future scenario for the entire region. I believe that it is the lack of definition of this scenario that causes or encourages the excesses, the accidents, the murders that Mr. Alavanos has spoken of. Does the Council intend to raise the issue of Kosovo's final status? And if so, does it intend to do so through a general redefinition of the region, avoiding as far as possible the multiplication of micro-states, as some have a tendency to do, and reuniting the parts, in this case, Kosovo and Albania? Since its author is not present, question 7 falls. Question 8 by (H-0796/99): Subject: New INTERREG initiative. In point 1 of Annex 2 to its draft communication on INTERREG entitled "Promoting urban, rural and coastal development", the Commission authorizes the renewal and development of historic town centres through a joint cross-border strategy, from which, however, housing is expressly excluded. Given the high number of historic buildings in rural areas, including small cottages, and the need, for various reasons, to maintain the population of rural areas and attract new residents, does the Council not believe that these objectives could be achieved by funding housing projects in the areas covered by INTERREG? Mr. President, the Council—and we could even say the Portuguese Presidency in particular—is acutely aware of the importance of the problems addressed by the honourable Member in his question, and I would like to emphasize that we always devote our full attention to Community policies for the development of rural areas.

It has been demonstrated, as we have been denouncing since 1995, that this transfer is absurd. We think it is right that Portugal and France want to reach an agreement, but those anchovies must be fished in Portuguese waters and not in the Bay of Biscay. Today, scientific studies show that the anchovy population in the Bay of Biscay is in danger of extinction. And now here come the measures to restrict the quantity of anchovies that can be fished in the Bay of Biscay. I do not know whether you have realised the responsibility that, as a Council of Ministers, you have had in recent years, and that you will have in 2000, towards the thousands of families who live from anchovy fishing in the north of the Iberian Peninsula. I would like to point out, Honourable Member, that in its ruling of 5 October 1999 the Court of Justice of the European Communities decided that this transfer, which had been approved, was in accordance with the principles laid down in Council Regulation No 1073/2001. 3760/92, and in particular in paragraph 1 of Article 9, which provides that Member States may exchange all or part of the fishing availabilities allocated to them. The Court also held that the principle of relative stability had not been infringed, since the anchovy quota allocated to Spain in subdivision 8 was maintained at 90 per cent and that of France at 10 per cent. Furthermore, Honourable Member, the Court is of the opinion that the transfer between Portugal and France does not infringe the principle of rational and responsible exploitation of living marine and aquatic resources, since fishing pressure in subdivisions 8 and 9 does not increase or adversely affect the overall share of resources allocated to Spain. In view of all this, Honourable Member, the Council reiterates that without the transfer in question, an increase in the fishing possibilities for anchovy by France in the Bay of Biscay should be considered. Therefore, Mr President, the Council confirms that fishing pressure would be greater and more dangerous for the fish stocks than with the solution chosen. Specifically: 3 000 tonnes represent 57.5% of Portugal's fishing possibilities in 2000, compared with 5 008 tonnes, or 73.9%, in 1999. These figures represent, in our view and from the Council's perspective, a real improvement in terms of conservation, when compared with the 80% quota established by Council Regulation No 685/95. Question No 6, by the Honourable Member (H-0788/99): Subject: Measures to address the ongoing ethnic cleansing of Serbs and Roma in Kosovo NATO Defence Ministers have launched (2.12.1999) a strong appeal for an end to the ethnic cleansing of minorities in Kosovo. The European Parliament also condemns the continuing violence against the Serb population in a resolution on the terrible acts of violence against Serbs and Roma, and calls on the leaders of the Kosovo Albanians to fully respect UN Resolution 1244. The EP resolution also stresses that previous persecutions against Albanians "cannot be used as a pretext for murder, kidnapping, detention, intimidation, arson, looting, destruction of property, occupation of houses, etc."

Honourable Member, I take note of your statement and the existence of this joint resolution. If the Presidency services confirm that it has been tabled, it goes without saying that it will be taken into consideration. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday at 12 noon. (The sitting closed at 8.14 p.m.) Approval of the minutes of the previous sitting Mr President, I would just like to pass on some information. There was a terrorist attack in Madrid this morning. They put a bomb in a car. One person died. I would simply like, on behalf of my group, to condemn these terrorist acts once again. Thank you, Mrs Fraga. We have indeed heard of this deplorable event. Unfortunately, once again, murderous terrorism is affecting Spanish society and the Presidency of this sitting, being Spanish, welcomes your words, as you will understand, with particular intensity. (The Minutes were approved) Resumption of the session I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament, adjourned on Friday 21 January 2000. Madam President, allow me to point out that tomorrow marks the second anniversary of the Cermis massacre. Two years ago, in Cavalese, Italy, an American plane from the NATO base in Aviano, during a low-altitude exercise - beyond safety limits - cut the wires of a cableway, causing the death of more than 20 European citizens. Since then, the families of the victims, who have not had the comfort of justice since the pilot responsible for the act did not face criminal consequences, have been expecting at least prompt financial compensation from the United States. I therefore appeal to the President of this House and to the President of the Commission to act as guarantors to the US authorities for immediate compensation, and this in defence of the rights of the families of the victims. I thank you and take note of your speech. Madam President, I am speaking to support the decision of the Conference of Presidents and I take this opportunity to point out that, after having publicly criticised the Presidency last January, this time I consider the statements made by the Presidency on the subject in question to be appropriate - also on behalf of the Socialist Group -: we agree with them on the substance, the form and the timing. There could not be a more appropriate debate for applying Rule 50 of the Rules of Procedure. This is a topical, urgent and highly relevant debate. To make room for it, we therefore believe it necessary to change the agenda. (Applause) Is there a speech against the proposal? Madam President, I intend to speak against the proposal on a question of principle which I consider fundamental and which concerns respect for the Treaties, in particular Article 7 of the Treaty of Amsterdam. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, until now, on the basis of the provisions of the Treaties of Rome and Paris which established the Communities, which later became the European Union, we believed that the Union was an association of free, independent and sovereign States. Although many developments have raised many doubts, we had believed, despite everything, in their appropriateness and even recently we had alluded, albeit only in passing, it must be said, to the principle of subsidiarity.

You have started boldly, emphasizing, quite rightly, the need to focus on so-called "core tasks." As you yourself said today, this means you will also need to identify tasks, policies, and programs that are peripheral or irrelevant to the Commission's primary vocation. Perhaps many of the European Union's current policies and programs have simply passed their expiration date or have proven cumbersome, difficult to manage, or ineffective when implemented at the European level. The challenge now is to have the courage to devolve as many non-core tasks as possible to lower levels of national, regional, and local government. If we are to persuade a skeptical European society of the benefits of closer European integration, we must be able to demonstrate that we are as active in devolving unjustified EU powers as we are in developing new EU powers. We must not allow those who criticize European integration to claim, as they currently do and not without some justification, as we heard from Mr. Bonde, that the increase in Community powers is a one-way street. It must be shown that it is a two-way process, in which current Community policies and programs that are not clearly justified on grounds of subsidiarity and proportionality are returned and revoked. If you are able to support these aspirations with action in the coming years, you will make an unprecedented contribution to the future of the European Union as a whole and, as we have heard today, you can count on broad support from this European Parliament. Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, I fully subscribe to the logic of the proposals made by my colleague Heidi Hautala regarding the Commission's strategic objectives for the next five years. For my part, I will limit myself to a topic that you have not addressed and that was planned, which is the Commission's work programme for 2000. I am aware of the limitations of the exercise, since we are working within the framework of the current Treaty and are limited by its operating rules—I am thinking in particular of an important topic such as fiscal matters. But I would precisely like not to address these. I will begin by welcoming a series of proposals you are making for this 2000 programme. I am thinking of all these proposals on food safety, which are ambitious and important, and I am also thinking of maritime safety, following the two oil spills we have experienced along the Brittany coast and in Turkey. It is good that the Commission is reacting quickly on this issue. On the other hand, on other issues, I believe it could be more ambitious, moving more quickly. And I would like to make a series of positive proposals, thinking in particular of the social sphere, the environment, and the follow-up to Seattle. A preliminary observation: you've said that it's necessary to reconcile European citizens with the institutions, that's obvious, and therefore I think it's important to ask ourselves about citizens' priority concerns. I believe, for example, that in social matters, it's not enough to announce a communication on a program of social actions.

In his fourteen-page document there is not even once mention of national parliaments, which are elected by the people. However, it is true that they have no role to play in his strategy. He does not even have the courage to call things by their name and takes refuge behind a pseudo-fashionable semantics by calling "gouvernance" what is nothing other than a federal, autocratic and central government. After having tried for years to convince by talking about shared sovereignty, today you confess your ultimate goal: to sell off all European sovereignty, national or collective, to a world government in which you do not even hope to obtain a prominent position. Finally, you allow yourselves to condemn and sanction, or have condemned and sanctioned, the free democratic vote of millions of Austrians, for the sole reason that the result does not please you, while at the same time you support communist China and trade with countries that have been blatantly violating human rights for decades now. Today, MEPs are jointly attacking a telegram from President Prodi to Chancellor Schüssel, which is clearly not a show of sympathy, but a political maneuver. Your antics are fooling no one, because you know very well that, whether you like it or not, you will need Austria to reform the treaties and harmonize the tax treatment of savings. You will use Austria to strip the States a little more of their real powers in building the European Union, you will do it with cynicism, hypocrisy, but you will use Austria as a very convenient scarecrow. It is true that you Commissioners are not the only ones responsible: the governments that support you, out of cowardice or ideology, are equally responsible. Brussels is not all of us, as you try to make us believe, it is all of you. You don't even lie any more, you don't give a damn about the will of the European peoples, free to choose only between your best of all worlds and the pillory. More than ten years after the collapse of the Soviet Union, your plans stink of the gulag with the addition of a soothing moralism. We belong to the small group that denounced the communist dictatorship and we are and will remain among those who fight the pro-European dictatorship. We appeal to all the peoples of Europe to resist your monstrous plans. The salvation of European democracies lies in the nation state, in the nation state, that of Europe in the cooperation between its nations. (Applause from some benches) President Prodi, you have presented us today with a five-year program of the Commission with many shared objectives, a program made up of scenarios and themes and it is therefore right to remain, beyond the concrete moments, on the big themes. It seems to me that, from your words and from the document that you have sent us, a theme that is very dear to you, Mr President, as it is to me, has remained in the background: solidarity, not so much on the international level as on the internal level. The Archbishop of Milan, Monsignor Carlo Maria Martini, is calling on all politicians, and in particular those like you and me, Mr. President, who make the commitment of Catholics in politics the cultural and value-based origin of their presence, to reconsider a theme of development that, beyond economic profit, looks with great, very great attention to the least, the excluded.

In this context, we must monitor what happens with the port in Gaza, with the northern transit route between Gaza and the West Bank, with the continued release of security prisoners, and with the fulfillment of economic commitments. The second point concerns Syria. In this, the border issue is essential. We still know nothing about the outcome of the negotiations. However, the important thing is that they have begun. An important issue in this context is the distribution of water. Currently, the Golan Heights supplies between one-third and one-seventh of Israel's water. The third aspect is the peace talks in Syria, which are closely linked to Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon. According to UNIFIL data, there are concrete signs that Israel is preparing a withdrawal, which we welcome. Other contentious issues are also the water supply and the situation of Palestinian refugees in Lebanon. My last point is the future Palestinian state. It is possible that it will be established this year, with or without Israeli support. The Barak government has indicated that it is prepared to sign a peace agreement with a state. Although the peace negotiations will not be concluded by September of this year, there are no treaty impediments to the creation of a Palestinian state after that date. In this context, it is important for those of us who support this idea to achieve what Commissioner Patten indicated, namely, a transparent and democratic state. We all want to contribute to this. Mr. President, I would first like to refer to the joint resolution that will be drafted at the conclusion of this debate, to which my group has contributed and which we naturally support. But, more specifically, I would like to express here our satisfaction that Israel and Syria, after so long a period of disagreement, have resumed talks to resolve their differences of opinion. The recent negotiations already constitute an important step towards permanent peace in the Middle East. It is therefore regrettable that the peace talks have currently been suspended. Both sides must truly make a tremendous effort. Lasting peace in the region can only be achieved through an agreement that guarantees the security of Israel's borders and the integrity of Syria. This requires the establishment of stable diplomatic relations and ongoing dialogue. In addition to bilateral meetings with Syria, I hope that, within the foreseeable future, Israel will also begin negotiations with Lebanon and that, within the framework of economic and regional cooperation, a multilateral approach will be possible. However, it must continue to be regretted that the European Union, one of the most important financial donors, is not always able to play an influential political role in the peace process. This Middle East peace process is one of the priorities of the European Union's common foreign and security policy.

By not introducing this environmental dimension in data management, the Commission could unilaterally and at its discretion prohibit the use of this or that fishing gear. Amendment 4 specifies the obligation on scientific experts to process and transmit all data to the competent authorities, including national and regional authorities, so that they can contribute to the decision-making process. Amendment 5 allows the Commission's proposal to be softened. In fact, the information requested from the authorities must be reasonable, so as to allow operational knowledge of fishing activity to be achieved without infringing the fundamental right to confidentiality, for example in the tax field, where there is no Community competence. Amendment 6 aims to make the Commission's participation in the control procedure more binding. It is necessary for all data to be transmitted annually and for the Commission to regularly review the overall results. Lastly, Amendment 5 7 requires the Commission to draw up a report by the end of 2001. Since the reform of the common fisheries policy is scheduled for 2002, it is necessary for all political actors to be able to see the information on which the Commission's proposal will be based. Hudghton report (A5-0036/2000) - (FR) The amendment to the directive, as presented to us by the Commission, is important because it deals with a specific disease, infectious salmon anaemia, a contagious viral disease transmitted through water via organic substances such as blood, faeces, mucus, etc. There is no scientific evidence to confirm the possibility of vertical transmission of the disease through fish eggs or milk. However, we know that other species, such as trout, eel or herring, can be carriers of the virus without being affected by it. This disease was isolated in 1984 in Norway and in 1996 in Canada. However, since the virus does not survive above 26ºC, it does not pose any danger to humans. The disease, which mainly affects the Scottish salmon sector, was identified there in May 1998. Today, ISA affects 240 salmon farms and it is therefore important to contain the disease so as to prevent it from spreading to all aquaculture farms in the various Member States of the European Union. The Council's proposal aims to establish a system of progressive elimination of fish affected by the disease and a vaccination programme. As regards the progressive elimination system, we can only support the proposal. It is essential to help the affected farms to "clean up" the infection source, thus preventing the spread of the disease and facilitating the commercial movement of live fish. As regards vaccination, it should be remembered that the Directive initially prohibited the use of vaccines against ISA. With the new proposal, the Commission would be in favor of authorizing its use, but no such vaccines have yet been discovered. The utility of the proposal is therefore limited at best, at least in the short term. Canada has a vaccine that has proven effective in 76 percent of cases, but since the Canadian strain is different from the European one, the vaccine in question cannot be used as it is in Europe.

The forced convergence of different systems, in addition to clashing with the principle of subsidiarity, Mr President, I do not believe will lead to the desired result, because ultimately there will always be a way to circumvent the system, with disastrous results for the environment. Mr President, every day five million pieces of solid waste are thrown overboard from ships. This waste floats in the seas and ends up on beaches, causing serious damage to the environment and to marine flora and fauna. The consequence is that millions of birds and one hundred thousand marine mammals and sea turtles die every year. The MARPOL Convention aims to prevent pollution caused by ships but it is clear that legislation is also needed to ensure its application. Hence the importance of the directive in question and this is why I am pleased this evening with the progress made in the Council with a view to reaching a common position that obliges ships to deliver the waste they produce to waste collection facilities in ports. I too congratulate the rapporteur, whose commitment reflects the strength and passion with which our committee addresses this particular issue and the strong desire across the political spectrum of MEPs to put an end to these environmentally disastrous practices. I particularly welcome his strong support for the proposal that environmental requirements should apply to all ships regardless of their flag and that adequate waste reception facilities should be made available in all Community ports, all with a view to improving pollution prevention and avoiding distortions of competition. One area where British Labour MEPs disagree with the rapporteur is how to apply the polluter pays principle. We strongly support this principle, but believe that its application can be made more efficient if Member States retain the freedom to decide which charging system is best suited to their particular circumstances. For example, in the UK we have a system that works well, whereby the ship pays the waste collection operator every time it uses its reception facilities, without any involvement of the port. This system is based on a consensus reached by all the stakeholders, with the participation of the ports and environmental organisations such as the RSPB and the WWF. However, like the rapporteur, we absolutely do not want different charging systems to increase the risk of marine pollution. That is why we support the Council in its proposal to strengthen the review clause, to ensure regular monitoring of the impact of the directive. Mr President, those who have witnessed the disastrous environmental effects of the Erika disaster will certainly not be able to vote against a report on the disposal of ship fuel waste. This is an exceptionally important report. In this respect, it should be stressed that what is most lacking is not legislation. All EU countries have signed the so-called MARPOL Convention, while the Baltic countries have also signed the Helsinki Convention. Both respond to the purpose of avoiding discharges into the sea. However, it is necessary to improve access to reception facilities and create incentives to use them.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Nielson, the conclusion of the new EU-ACP Convention is an important step towards greater coherence. It is positive that this new agreement establishes criteria such as human rights, democracy, the rule of law, and good governance more than ever before. It is positive that past colonial relations no longer permeate most of our relations, but that these political criteria have gained greater weight here. This is the prerequisite for any development. If these criteria are not respected, development will have no chance. This, Mr. Modrow, also applies to Cuba. I welcome Cuba's involvement in this process, but some changes still need to take place in that country. We are all familiar with the Amnesty International reports. It may be that you, as one of the last holders of communist power, possibly view it differently than most of this House and that you see problems with good governance. However, this is an important criterion for the European Union. I would like to address a second issue. We are talking here about coherence. Many colleagues have given examples of the extent to which the various policies are inconsistent. But, from my point of view, development policy itself needs more consistency. It is inconsistent that coordination with the Member States continues to fail, that in developing countries, Member States of the European Union are partly implementing very opposing projects. Nor is it consistent with the European taxpayer that we pursue a development policy that is regulated in the Union budget, but that the EDF continues to be excluded. Mr. President of the Council, if you can ensure that these €13.5 billion are in the future subject to the control of Parliament, of the Committee on Budgetary Control, and are subject to mechanisms such as OLAF, then I believe that the level of acceptance will increase. I believe that this should also be a demand of the Intergovernmental Conference: the establishment of the EDF within the European Union budget. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, overall, we believe this text is indeed well-intentioned, and yet we did not vote on it in committee, nor will we vote on it in plenary, for two reasons which, moreover, gave rise, on our part, to amendments that I would like to briefly elaborate on here. First and foremost, the Committee on Development and Cooperation seeks the communitarization of the European Development Fund, and it is clearly mistaken in this regard. Cooperation is, and, in our view, must remain, an intergovernmental exercise. At a time when Europe is preparing for enlargement, communitarization of the European Development Fund would allow some to very easily disguise their lack of commitment behind the screen of the Community budget, without taking into account, moreover, that it would eliminate a fruitful and promising way of associating our partners in the South with our cooperation policy. Finally, as Mrs. Maes has just rightly pointed out, the Commission has recently demonstrated the difficulties it experiences in transparently managing the funds it allocates to its development and humanitarian aid programs.

Just as we thought the debate was over, dazzling amendments reached the House, which I request that you reject outright. They suggest, for example, that we should use the meager fishing budget to finance artistic treasures or promote maritime tourism. Other amendments, such as amendment number 4, which calls for the funding of biological recovery periods, demonstrate a profound ignorance of fisheries regulations by calling for measures that are already in force, even though everything could still be improved. I therefore ask that the four amendments tabled be rejected and that the chapter on fisheries and the environment be closed with the idea put forward in the committee debate, namely that both are closely linked and suffer the effects of the same attacks on the environment. As I have said so many times, fishing is more the victim than the cause of the destruction of the marine ecosystem, and tomorrow, in the debate on the Erika, we will have the opportunity to demonstrate this. Mr President, Mr. Katiforis's report had the merit of injecting vitality, polemics, and a combative spirit into a communication in which the Commission merely lists a series of good wishes while admitting its inability to put them into practice. What Mr. Katiforis certainly did not lack was the courage to set out the measures that, in his view, could contribute to the recovery and conservation of the sea's natural resources. I say this because I disagree with many of his proposals, as I am among those who believe that in fishing, it is not only the resources that are important—they are—but also the people who have practiced this activity for centuries. I agree with the rapporteur that greater coordination of European fisheries and environmental policy is needed. What we fundamentally lack, however, is the courage and political determination on the part of the Commission and the Member States to make decisions and apply the existing rules. Not only fisheries and the environment should be integrated, but also maritime transport, employment, and energy. With regard to the Structural Funds, I could cite a whole series of examples here, but I will save that for another occasion. The European Parliament is aware of the limited nature of resources and the need to conduct responsible fishing. It demands rigor from the Commission and the Member States regarding compliance with TACs and quotas established according to objective scientific criteria, and demands that everyone be judged by the same yardstick. Discards, as Mr Katiforis says, represent a waste of resources that we cannot accept. Twenty million tonnes of unusable catch are thrown back. The fleet must be equipped with fishing gear for increasingly selective fishing. This Parliament has already opposed driftnets, and yet we see certain Member States not only disregarding their obligation to eliminate them but increasing the number of vessels using this gear or simply failing to provide data, given the passivity of the national and Community authorities. We Socialists believe that defending the Common Fisheries Policy means advocating for regulated and controlled fishing activities. It is essential that the Commission launch an information campaign on the CFP with this message in mind.

The next point concerns the actions we have undertaken. As you know, the Portuguese Presidency has already established a high-level group, which will present its first report in June at the Summit. The Portuguese Presidency is focusing on two themes: sustainable pension systems and social inclusion. I believe the proposal for a corresponding group at Parliamentary level is very positive and could contribute to taking us a step further following the approval of this high-level group. Regarding certain comments on the role of social protection systems and their cost, and on the role these systems play in the competitiveness of Member States, I would like to point out that what policies in the European Union are trying to combine is competitiveness and social cohesion. Naturally, we must take into account the issue of competitiveness, and social protection planning must be done in such a way that social protection is a factor in economic growth and employment. And I believe this is evident in the text of the communication. Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, the objective is that next year, following the unanimous decision of the Council, we will move forward with the initial level of coordination, the exchange of opinions, the recording of social problems, and the creation of a database for better policy coordination. As many of you have expressed, I believe we have taken an important first step. Social policy issues are now being addressed more broadly at the Intergovernmental Conference, and I believe we are in a new phase, where social policy will largely constitute a European policy. Thank you very much, Ms. Diamantopoulou. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday at 11:30. WIPO Treaty The next item is recommendation (A5-0008/2000) by Mrs. Cederschiöld, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, on the proposal for a Council decision (COM(1998) 249 - C5-0222/1999 - 1998/0141 (AVC)) on the approval, on behalf of the European Community, of the WIPO Copyright Treaty and the WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty. (SV) Mr. President, we are about to take a decision on an important matter, an international agreement, a matter that could influence the development of well-being in many countries. In my country, Sweden, it concerns one of the largest export sectors. The branches affected are music and phonograms. It concerns the copyright of artists, for the protection of their artistic creations. These are the WCT (World Copyright Treaty) and the WPPT (World Performance and Phonograms Treaty). Without copyright protection, economic incentives and creativity are stifled. Counterfeiting is big business. It is estimated that €4.5 billion in revenue is lost in Europe alone due to pirated copies. The problem affects many jobs in the entertainment industry. This treaty is historic, as the EU is one of its signatories. This is true, even though the members of the organization are the member states of the Union, not the EU.

And here we come to the heart of the matter: This project on social harmonization not only touches on social policy; it is a follow-up to the Community EMU project, which has a very specific interest in the three countries that remain outside and can be saved from this Titanic, namely, Great Britain, Sweden, and Denmark. Hence, it is important for us to emphasize that we cannot support a proposal whose logical basis is to consolidate the EMU project. Mr. President, I voted in favor of the Commission's communication on the modernization of social protection because, in my opinion, it moves in the direction—although it does not entirely succeed—of finally providing European legislation in the social and pensions fields. I listened with regret to the previous explanation of vote, as I believe that the spirit of this report is oriented toward the possibility of protecting the elderly even more, if possible. And this, despite the fact that we know that the governments of the fifteen Member States would like to reduce the amount of pensions as much as possible. I hope that Parliament will have the power to legislate on pensions as soon as possible. Older people rely on the European Parliament to enable them to live well and with dignity, and better than they do now. Less developed nations must reach the same level as the states that, within the European Union, guarantee greater social protection. (DA) The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament today voted in favor of the report by our Swedish colleague, Social Democrat Jan Andersson, on the Commission Communication: A Concerted Strategy to Modernize Social Protection. The Commission Communication takes as its starting point the launch of EMU, which, with its ambition for stability and growth, creates the basis for Member States to strengthen their social security systems. The report makes it clear that modernization does not mean reducing the level of social protection, but rather making better use of existing resources. Furthermore, we have also noted that the explanatory memorandum establishes that modernization does not mean harmonization of social security systems and that harmonization would be detrimental, as it could require higher standards in weaker Member States and, at the same time, for reasons of competition, could pressure the more socially developed states to make cuts to the social security system. A situation from which no one would benefit. Both the Commission Communication and Mr. Andersson's report emphasize that it is the Member States who are responsible and thus who decide the content of social security systems. Collaboration on these issues under the auspices of the EU must provide added value, based on the exchange of experiences and the mutual evaluation of policy developments with a view to establishing best practice. (SV) We believe that the report contains many good practical proposals, which we support, but we are very critical of the convergence perspective that characterizes the report.

Even today there are no certain answers on the control of nuclear power plants in the Eastern Republics. We therefore need to have resources to spend before proceeding with an enlargement, to finally give life to a European control force, charged with verifying the quality and conditions of life, in order to create a new world in which certain tragedies no longer occur. I would also like to say a word about Africa, Madam President. The Third and Fourth Worlds are abandoned: one dollar, one euro and a half would be enough to save many children. Europe, so democratic, so progressive, is silent and does not take charge of these tragic problems, while half of Africa dies of AIDS and other diseases. One last consideration regarding the Internet and globalization. The globalization of the economy cannot become the standardization of products and qualities, just as the globalization of politics cannot become the flattening of values, hopes, and enthusiasms. The people who do not participate, and slowly move away, leave room for an oligarchy that takes power and leaves control to a few. As for the Internet: Europe must finally have the courage to say that rules are needed. At this time, allow me, in a personal capacity, to address my applause to those pirates who, by acting as they are acting, are forcing the world to reflect on the only system that today has no rules. We are the world of rules: let us also give rules to the Internet, thus giving rules and hope to the future of our fellow citizens. Madam President, as a taxpayer from the Po Valley, I have already experienced the grip of the tax collector Prodi, then Head of Government in Italy, to whom Padania is also fiscally subject. I listened to him now with concern, when he mentioned new resources, a concept that can easily be translated into the imposition of new taxes and new duties, in view, among other things, of enlargement, that is, the entry of new States into the Union. But why don't they pay their own entrance fee? My Padanian voters who, thanks to Prodi, have already paid what in Italy is known as the tax on Europe - only partly repaid - have absolutely no intention, again thanks to Prodi, of paying another one for someone else. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Commissioners, five months after taking office, the Commission has put in black and white the direction in which it intends to push the European Union. The result is an ambitious document, certainly, but also pompous. Isn't it pathetic to say that "the world is looking to Europe"? Furthermore, the European continent is not only made up of the fifteen Member States of the European Union. Claiming to want to guarantee peace, democracy and respect for human rights in, note well, the whole of Europe seems rather ambitious to me and I am especially fascinated to know how the Commission intends to achieve this objective. The model of European integration as a form of global government, I wonder whether this perhaps means exporting a model based on the concentration of power on a large scale. The Commission believes that foreign policy can only be successful if everyone knows exactly who is in charge! But who is in charge?

Mr President, Commissioner, the Middle East peace process is an extremely delicate issue. The exact borders of the State of Israel, the only democracy in this region, can only be recognized by all if these negotiations are successful. The implementation of the trade agreement between the European Union and Israel, which does not further define the territory of the State of Israel, must take place in this context. Add to this the existence of a close link between economic activities on the Israeli side and those on Palestinian territory. To this end, the Paris Protocol annexed to the Oslo Accords also provides for a customs "envelope" that encompasses the State of Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Furthermore, the Commission and the aforementioned parties have agreed to the establishment of a joint working group to address underlying issues, including the fact that the Palestinian economy would be affected by unilateral actions by the European Union. Potential investors in this region have already indicated that they will withdraw if joint ventures are no longer preferred. Mr President, this House broadly shares the concern raised in Mrs Morgantini's question. I believe that Commissioner Vitorino has made the Commission's position clear and, in my view, adequately addressed the concerns raised here, but it seems to me that we should not stop there. Therefore, it seems to me that we could, based on this statement, broaden the points of convergence, drawing on the valuable information that Mrs Morgantini and I were able to deduce during a visit to the region with the President of Parliament. I believe, firstly, that despite the existing difficulties that we were able to observe in situ, we must reiterate our support for direct dialogue between the Government of Israel and the Palestinian Authority, with a view to a just, stable and definitive peace agreement. Secondly, I believe that both parties have an interest in ensuring the economic development of the region and in firmly addressing the reduction of the significant imbalances of wealth observed in the region. Thirdly, finally, the Commission could perhaps consider the usefulness of deepening the task of a trilateral working group, obviously with the participation of the European Union, ensuring compliance with trade agreements and helping us to advance the cooperation offered by the European Union for the benefit of all parties concerned. I listened to Commissioner Vitorino's response and I must say that I am satisfied. I believe that his intervention addresses the concerns raised in the question. I also believe that we must stress the importance, for the European Union and therefore, from an executive point of view, for the Commission, of promoting tripartite activities, particularly with regard to the levels of economic, financial and scientific cooperation, so that our quantitative presence in financial terms can more often be transformed into a more significant presence in the Middle East. This, I believe, is the lesson to be learned from this already long-standing story. As for the specific subject, I heard that Mr. Galeote was referring to the visit of our President and Mr. Menéndez del Valle to that of President Prodi to Israel and other countries in the Middle East.

Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Guterres for his remarks this evening and for his initiative regarding the Lisbon Summit, which is very important for us. If we are honest, we must admit that it has been a long road from the Luxembourg Employment Summit to the Lisbon Summit, and that we now expect concrete results from this Lisbon Summit; something tangible must come out of it. There are many European citizens in the public gallery this evening, and I wonder what they think of our discussion today. I hope that these citizens will leave this evening's plenary session certain that the European Union institutions have now embarked on a process that will truly lead to the restoration of full employment in the European Union. Many challenges lie ahead on the road to full employment. Some of these challenges will be difficult to overcome, but what is important is that we put into practice what we have been talking about for many, many years: full employment, a society without social exclusion, a society of innovation and knowledge. This is the great challenge and the great importance of the Lisbon Summit. I would like to briefly highlight some key aspects that will enable us to put our words into action. First, we need to establish benchmarks and initiate a mutual evaluation process; we need to set objectives, real objectives that we can achieve; and we need to encourage governments to undertake the courageous process of saying, "Yes, we are not afraid of comparison with each other; we will measure ourselves against the rest of the world." This requires courage, because some Member States will find themselves at the bottom of the table, and that is not pleasant for anyone. It is nevertheless important that the Lisbon Summit leads to concrete results and not to a different direction—a direction Prime Minister Guterres certainly does not want to take because he is genuinely interested in achieving something at the Lisbon Summit. Other areas must not be neglected either. This includes the challenge of creating an "e-Europe" that includes all citizens and leaves no one behind. Another area is the creation of a genuine internal market, which we still do not have, and this includes skills development, which is central to creating an innovative knowledge-based society. This requires difficult choices, but I would like to address the citizens in the gallery following this debate and reassure them that we will achieve a society based on full employment, that the Lisbon Summit will mark the end of a long journey and will deliver concrete results. I welcome the new strategic objective of making Europe the most dynamic and competitive area. Who could question such an ambitious goal? I would point out, however, that dynamism and entrepreneurship, as well as social cohesion, are ambitious goals, not to mention the creative tension between these two.

I do not believe that there is a broad consensus in Europe in favour of introducing qualified majority voting on taxation, justice and internal and foreign affairs at Union level. According to Article 99 of the Treaty of Rome, tax decisions adopted at European level must be voted unanimously. I believe that this provision should remain in force, as a common tax code would reduce rather than increase the functioning of the European Union. I am in favour of enlargement of the European Union. I am in favour of institutional changes that will allow enlargement to be implemented in a structured and simplified way. However, we must not forget that the public opinion of 370 million citizens of the European Union is a fundamental factor to be taken into account if we want to change the Treaties. Changes must not be introduced too quickly and must not be too radical, otherwise public opinion will oppose the ratification of any future Union Treaty. Madam President, I will speak on behalf of the Italian Radical MEPs. Mr President of the Commission, you said earlier that no political structure produces five-year plans. That is true, if we think of Russia's plans in the 1930s, but you yourself announced a few months ago, at the beginning of your mandate, to the Conference of Presidents that you would instead present a legislative programme, that is, the broad lines of the European government over which you preside, and in whose exercise we are today engaged. So, if it must be a government programme or a programme of tendencies, the analysis of the document that you have distributed to us and of the speech that accompanied it reveals itself more as a catalogue of good intentions or, better said, of problems on the table, without however giving the impression that the Commission is taking a clear position on any of these points, that is, is carrying out the task that is proper to the European Commission. In the Chamber of this Parliament we have had, in the past, major debates on major strategic options that the Commission, by virtue of its power of initiative, launched, rather than as trial balloons, as proposals that then went more or less far, but which nevertheless contributed to the integration and development of the European Union. In this case, Mr President, we certainly have a decalogue: a whole series of problems have been listed but, if I may, with the impression that on none of these has the Commission in any way dared to say "this is what should be done". Only on one point do you seem to have insisted a lot - I think too much - and that is on the fact that the task that you are almost setting as a priority is that of dismantling "unnecessary" activities. But let us be careful, Mr President, because we have had a crisis of confidence in the Commission and we have placed our trust in this Commission - the majority, at least, of this Parliament has placed its trust in this Commission - precisely because, first and foremost, the reform of the Commission was linked to a strengthening, to a new identity, to a new awareness of being guided once again by a sure hand.

(SV) Mr. President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, "women hold up half the sky," a successful man once said. But when it comes to political decisions and priorities, women's voices are absent. Women, who make up more than half of the population, are insufficiently represented in the political, social, and economic spheres. This is unacceptable in a democracy! The greatest gap in equal opportunities, de jure and de facto, lies in the decision-making process. Achieving balance requires a concrete action plan with a fixed timetable. A benchmarking system would be an important part of this action plan to ensure full female participation in power and decision-making structures. I am therefore pleased that the Commissioner agrees to a system of this nature. I propose that the targets for women in the decision-making process be based on the average of the three most successful Member States in each sector, with each Member State required to report annually. These reports will then need to be evaluated. Women are the primary victims of human rights violations such as rape, sexual abuse, domestic violence, and human trafficking, yet they are underrepresented in the judicial and legislative bodies that prosecute these crimes. This means that these crimes are not given priority and that the perpetrators often go unpunished. Women are the primary victims of armed conflict, yet they are absent from peacekeeping, conflict resolution, and reconstruction efforts. Therefore, in the resolution, we urge Member States to increase the proportion of women in conflict resolution and peacekeeping activities. Equal female participation is not only a demand for social justice and democracy, but is also a duty to ensure that women's experiences and knowledge are fully taken into account. Failure to include women's capacity in the decision-making process is an unacceptable waste. Women must not only "bear half the sky" but must also have the right to assume responsibilities on Earth. Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the Presidency of the Council and the Commissioner for the excellent speeches they have made today. We have high expectations of their actions. We are beginning a millennium and a century that will be—we hope—decisive for women and for their ability to occupy decision-making positions. We want this opportunity to bring about important changes to our life in society, for democracy to also be synonymous with equality between men and women, and for women not to be excluded either economically or socially, as is still the case today. And thus, for values dear to women—such as peace, fraternity, equality, justice, security, and environmental protection—to predominantly guide life in the European Union and, if possible, in the world. To achieve this, it is necessary to give women the opportunity to counter the inertia of a society that has so far been essentially imbued with masculine values.

This is a problem of compatibility between our VFU directives and the old directives, including AUTO-OIL, which we voted on a few years ago. We can therefore be satisfied with the common sense shown by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, which reintroduced, to dispel any doubt, the exception relating to vintage cars which are part of our industrial and cultural heritage. In conclusion, I will say that this directive is not ambitious enough to solve the problems linked to the current car fleet but is rather hypocritical in terms of the fate it reserves for abandoned cars which still clutter up our forests, our lakes and our gardens. Once again, the "polluter pays" principle is not applied and it is always the taxpayer who pays. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, reading the leaflets distributed in recent weeks, one might think that we are discussing the maximum acceptable ecological risk or the death of the car industry in Europe. Neither hypothesis is correct. We must be objective: this directive is good; it represents ecological progress in Europe and we can be proud to translate this directive into law and pass it. However, there is one point on which we disagree. Perhaps, given the size of the directive, it is a small point, but that is where the controversy lies. It is the costs of recycling. In this respect, we are clearly distant from the debate in the Council last year, in which free last-holder tax and the problem of financing were mixed up in the same pot, and free last-holder tax was called into question. In February last year, Parliament decided - and we in the PSE Group are sticking to that decision - that free last-holder tax is out of the question! But who should pay for the vehicles to be disposed of? It is clear to us that for new vehicles these costs should be borne by the manufacturer, because then they too will be encouraged to design and build vehicles that are easily recyclable. But what about vehicles that are already on the road? For example, if it were to be responsible for all its end-of-life vehicles, the UK-based Rover would be responsible for 5.8 million vehicles in the European Union and would have to immediately set aside €250 million to cover the costs of recycling, while a Korean manufacturer building similar vehicles would only have to set aside "peanuts", as a representative of Deutsche Bank put it. These are distortions of competition that have nothing to do with environmental protection, but only affect the investment capacity and jobs of the European car industry. We therefore propose creating a fund for end-of-life vehicles from which the costs of recycling these vehicles would be paid, in order to respect the principle of free of charge. I understand colleagues from countries without an automotive industry who argue that the entire burden should fall on the manufacturers and that the problem of distortions of competition and the associated provisions does not concern them.

For two years, these fears have materialised. The banana dispute is the most striking proof of this. Developing countries are being asked to align themselves with the liberalisation of trade, despite the fragility of their economies. Although Mr Corrie's report denounces this situation well and reaffirms the Joint Assembly's fidelity to the Lomé model, it does not sufficiently highlight a second problem which, in all fairness, also stems from the free-trade error: the inconsistency of regional trade agreements concluded by the European Union. The cooperation agreement with South Africa is the best example of this. The Council approved this agreement, negotiated by the Commission, at the same time as the agricultural chapter, although essential, had not yet been finalised. As Mr Paul-Marie Coûteaux very correctly observed in his speech yesterday and in his proposed amendments, one wonders what political coherence such a blank cheque can have. All this is very worrying, especially as a similar agreement seems to be on the cards with Mexico. Likewise, we cannot support the rapporteur when he calls for the European Development Fund to be merged into the Community budget. We do indeed want to maintain the clear commitment and responsibility of each Member State that only the intergovernmental nature can guarantee. We have unfortunately seen too many examples of collective aid being diverted for which no one feels responsible, and we do not intend to extend this disastrous practice to the European Development Fund. Madam President, I welcome the Corrie report, which is a balanced assessment of the work done by this House over the past year. The report comes hot on the heels of the agreement to renew the current Lomé Convention, which expires at the end of the month. The new agreement provides for EUR 13.5 billion in development funding over the next seven years; it is essential that this money is used to benefit the poorest groups and individuals in the ACP countries. We must also work tirelessly to eradicate corruption and waste, and we must involve civil society in the planning and implementation of these projects. The decision to include a clause requiring ACP countries to take back people who have illegally emigrated to Europe is worrying; this clause must be applied with extreme caution. I hope that before this new Lomé Convention expires we can welcome Cuba as a full member. According to estimates by the Joint United Nations Programme on AIDS, at the end of 1998 there were a total of 33.4 million people in the world living with HIV. More than 95 percent of all infected people live in developing countries, with sub-Saharan Africa being the most affected region in the world. Only 10 percent of the world's population lives in sub-Saharan Africa, but it is home to 70 percent of all people diagnosed with AIDS in 1998. Eighty percent of the 13.9 million AIDS-related deaths worldwide occurred in this region. In Africa, AIDS is not just a public or private health problem; it is a development issue.

The under-representation of women in politics, for example, continues to be a reality. And yet, we all recognise the importance of women's ever greater involvement in politics.
