Only women are capable of inventing policies that can change structures designed by men for other men, because it is precisely structural discrimination that women have to contend with most, whether in politics or on the labour market. It is therefore up to European political parties to open up to women. Article 191 of the Treaty itself (ex 138 A) highlights their role as, and I quote, "an important factor for integration within the Union". And the article goes on to state that "they [political parties] contribute to forming a European awareness [as well as a European identity] and to expressing the political will of the citizens of the Union". Such a provision, although not having legal force, is nevertheless extremely symbolic, as it gives political parties an important role in building a democratic Europe which could be expressed, for example, in the implementation of positive actions and the promotion of equality within our political parties. During the 1999 European elections, some parties presented equal lists. Well, this is good practice which needs to be generalised. I do not know whether there is a causal link, but it is true that the proportion of women MEPs rose from 25.7% in 1994 to 29.9% in 1999, not to mention that, since the 1999 elections, the Parliament has been presided over by a woman. I will end by reiterating the conclusions drawn from the April 1999 Conference organised by the Commission, entitled "Women and men in power". Equality between men and women is not an issue which concerns women alone, it is a challenge which concerns our whole society! Progress has been made recently in increasing the participation of women in decision-making bodies in the Union. Today, 30 percent of elected representatives in our institution are women, including the President of the European Parliament, while Finland has just elected a female President. On average, a quarter of the governments of the Member States are women and more than a fifth of the national parliaments. This is far from satisfactory, given that the figures vary greatly from country to country and that the Nordic countries have significantly higher representation of women in key positions in terms of responsibility and decision-making power. This is above all a question of approach and respect for the quality and skills that women can bring to society, and not a system of fixed quotas. In general, my group is not in favour of quotas, as they could be counterproductive in the long run and even undermine the cause they are intended to promote. We nevertheless recognise that experience varies from country to country and that the use of such a system could be justified as a temporary measure to rebalance the presence of women where women are poorly represented. We decided to vote for the resolution on women in decision-making which was adopted in commemoration of International Women's Day on 8 March and which incorporated ten amendments tabled by the Liberal Group and toned down the references to quotas, in line with the approach described above.

The measures are not limited to legislation. To promote and support dialogue as a cornerstone of successful adaptation to change, the Commission is also currently addressing the recommendations of the Lillehammer Report by working on the establishment of a European Observatory on Industrial Change. We are also considering another proposal from this group of experts, the report on managing change. Finally, let me turn to some of the other issues raised in the draft resolution presented to this House. Regarding the link between competition and social policy, I would like to remind you that the Merger Regulation contains a provision giving workers' representatives the opportunity to be heard by the Commission in the context of the relevant procedure. We broadly recognize the need for due attention, in the various bodies, to all aspects of such measures, including their impact on employment. As an example, I would mention that the public authorities, namely the Commission, have already taken measures, through guidelines on national regional aid that entered into force on 1 January this year, to ensure that the provision of public funds remains linked to the recipients of regional aid and, consequently, to the jobs associated with the investment. To this end, any regional aid is made conditional on the continued existence of the investment in question for a minimum period of five years. The same provision has been incorporated into the Structural Funds Regulation, so that it applies to all investments co-financed by the Structural Funds. Social cohesion and the interaction of policies at EU level are the focus of the upcoming Lisbon Summit. I know we will return to these issues in the future to see how best to ensure that our policies are adapted and reformed to underpin economic and social progress in Europe. Thank you, Commissioner. Mr Gorostiaga Atxalandabaso, I see you have raised a point of order. If it is a personal statement, would you please wait until the end of this debate? I will then give you the floor. Mr President, this is a matter of public honour in this Parliament; it is not a personal statement. This morning, the President of Parliament, Mrs Nicole Fontaine, repeatedly refused to allow me to raise a point of order. Unfortunately, this is not the first time that the President has behaved in this unacceptable manner towards me. In doing so, the President infringed Rule 142, which gives priority to a point of order over all other points of order. She also infringed Rule 122, which gives all Members of this House the right to make personal remarks, remarks which, in this case, reject the comments of another Member, those of Mrs Vidal-Quadras. This partisan conduct by our President should be condemned in the strongest possible terms. I am ready to accept the President's apology at any time. Thank you for your explanation. We will, of course, ensure that the President is informed of your statement. I can assure you that, to my knowledge, the President is always reluctant to allow a debate on the matter in the middle of a vote.

(SV) Mr. President, I think it is very important to show the guidelines for the use of the precautionary principle in this communication, as a way of refuting claims that we always apply it for protectionist purposes. I am sure there will be more conflicts, for example, with the United States. We cannot be naive and believe otherwise. However, since we signed the Montreal Protocol, we have had international recognition and a common definition established in a protocol on the environment, health, and trade. That is why it sets a good example. Let us not think that there will be no conflicts in the future, but then we will be able to demonstrate that we do not arbitrarily apply the precautionary principle. There are now a series of guidelines for its application, and we have the strong support of our people for doing so, which is very clearly corroborated in this communication. Thank you very much, Commissioner. The attention paid to the principle of political precaution meant that we debated it for almost two hours, and this topic is now considered, so to speak, more of a matter of routine administration, although, as we have seen from the interventions, questions and answers, it is a topic to which great importance is attached. The debate is now closed. Intergovernmental Conference The next item is the report (A5-0018/2000) by Mr Dimitrakopoulos and Mr Leinen, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the convening of the Intergovernmental Conference (14094/1999 - C5-0341/1999 - 1999/0825(CNS)). (EL) Mr President, first of all, my thanks to the Portuguese Presidency and the Commission for the extremely useful contacts we have maintained throughout this period. Let me also thank once again my fellow speaker, Mr. Leinen, for our extraordinary collaboration. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the Intergovernmental Conference about to begin is important in general terms, and especially in the perspective of enlargement. Its work will shape the structure and mechanisms that will underpin the functioning of 21st-century Europe. And there is no doubt that a more effective, more democratic, and fully transparent functioning of the European Union of the future requires a broad and profound reform of both its institutions and its working methods. The main prerequisite and condition for the success of this reform is the agenda that will guide the work of the Intergovernmental Conference. It is clear from the decisions taken at the Helsinki European Council that the agenda agreed upon there is unsatisfactory and does not guarantee the substantial changes necessary for the creation of a more functional, more effective, more democratic, and more transparent Europe. This is because it is limited to examining only three issues that only fragmentarily concern the structure and functioning of only two institutional bodies of the European Union. I won't repeat this, as it is well known to all. This observation of mine is justified, on the one hand, by the constant, sometimes particularly intense, demands of European citizens; and, on the other, by the enormous challenges posed by the great undertaking undertaken by the European Union, the undertaking of enlargement.

I consider this a report in which the cooperation between the committees worked very well, and the result before us today is a sober, objective report on a particularly delicate area. Sobriety and objectiveness are therefore particularly necessary in the development of Article 280.4. If we had to award a prize to the article that is the most difficult to understand, the least clear, the most unclear – however you want to call it – then there would certainly be fierce competition, because the Treaty is a sample collection of complicated articles, but this is without doubt one of the most promising candidates for the prize. At the same time, it is a particularly delicate issue because it concerns the protection of the Community's financial interests, as Mrs Theato very rightly said. We are all aware of the need – and this Parliament has raised this concern and has been a great champion in this matter – to protect the Community's financial interests. But be careful, as the French say, "ne jettons pas le bébé avec l'eau du bain" (don't throw the baby out with the bathwater). In other words, when protecting the Community's financial interests, one must respect, on the one hand – and Mrs. Theato said it – the powers of the nation states, but also other matters that concern citizens, those that concern essential guarantees. The conclusions of the Theato report fully preserve these. Therefore, in my capacity as Chair of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, and of course also in my capacity as a Member of this House, I hope that this Parliament will support the report tomorrow with a broad majority and that it will be well implemented by the Commission. Mr. President, as Mrs. Theato pointed out, this report touches on a critical issue. This report was proposed by the Committee on Budgetary Control and prepared as an own-initiative report. One of the reasons we were so keen to take action is that, whether we like it or not, the European Union continues to be accused of fraud and mismanagement. Of course, exaggerations are sometimes made, but there is some truth to the accusations, and we must do something about them. Some of the measures we adopted in the past are being ignored by some Member States. We must not forget that Member States are responsible for around 80% of the implementation of the EU budget. Many of them have neither signed nor ratified the Convention on the Protection of Financial Interests, so it was clear that more radical action was needed. We must take this responsibility seriously. We must be able to take action against those who commit fraud against the European Union. The question arises as to who should do this. This is where it becomes truly difficult. Who is responsible in a body that encompasses numerous countries? We must also take the interests of the Member States into account. The proposal to establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office is extremely sensible. We are all aware that a clearly federalist approach and conditions under which a European judicial body takes precedence over the respective national judicial bodies would be a bit too far for some. But the discussion on this must begin, and we therefore call on the Intergovernmental Conference to initiate it.

On China, we should not be deterred from raising the issue simply because discussions on the matter may be blocked. In any case, it is imperative that the Union speaks and acts as one, and threats of trade sanctions should strengthen rather than weaken our resolve. However, if the decisions that may ultimately be taken in Geneva are to be fully reflected, the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights will need to be provided with the resources it needs. The United Nations' financial resources are under-distributed, and as a result many crucial programmes depend on voluntary contributions to remain operational. Resources are also needed to promote practical cooperation and human rights, strategic planning, priority setting and strengthening communications between the donor community and United Nations Member States. To this end, the High Commissioner recently launched an annual appeal for USD 53 million to enable her Office to carry out these tasks. The European Union and its Member States should take the lead in providing a significant share of these funds. In this way, we would not only embarrass the United States by forcing it to shoulder its responsibilities for funding the United Nations, but we would also demonstrate that our commitment to the protection of human rights goes beyond mere and sterile rhetoric. Mr President, this debate focuses on the preparation of the upcoming annual session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights and on the role of the Commission and the Council in that context. Let me begin by expressing my great satisfaction with the statements made so far by Commissioner Patten and the Minister. I am also pleased that today we are also discussing both China and Cuba. Cuba remains the last example of a dictatorship in Latin America, and that is something we must not forget, despite all the sympathy that that country enjoys here and there. Cuba is a dictatorship, it is therefore not a democracy. In the two minutes I have available to me, I would like to focus on two countries with which I have a special connection. The first is Indonesia. We are of course very pleased that Indonesia now has a new government and that the offices of President and Vice-President are held by Mr Wahid and Mrs Soekarnopoetri. We are also pleased that the situation in Timor is slowly developing in the right direction. However, I must tell you that in the Moluccas, which are just north of Timor, violence is still rife, after thousands of deaths in the last two years. Tens of thousands of people are now fleeing. The situation is out of control. Tomorrow or the day after tomorrow, Dutch television will broadcast a long programme in which observers have been asked to participate, purely and simply to observe what is happening in the Moluccas, so that everything that has really happened can be recorded, also for the benefit of posterity or human rights commissions. The urgent appeal that I now want to make concerns a point that has been included many times in our resolutions, namely the possibility of sending observers to the Moluccas.

In a sparsely populated country like mine, Finland, going to the post office is a social event. In a networked world, the post office is the most democratic network, as it creates and maintains human relationships. The common market in the postal sector will be carried out according to the conditions of market forces. For us in the north, this means that the EU is going to destroy the social infrastructure. Mr. Monti, the principle of competition does not fit into the area of human relationships, and therefore, postal services must be developed, not abolished. If we want everyone to have access to and use information technology, the only way to guarantee this aspiration in society is through a public postal service. The post office is a democracy and can perform these functions better than telecommunications companies. In the telecommunications sector, prices have risen due to the continuous buying and selling of companies, since more than 50% of these companies' turnover is spent on advertising. We must make democratic investments to preserve democratic postal services. It is particularly fitting that Mr. Monti is responding to this debate, since the great dilemma facing postal services is how to balance an open market and free and fair competition, on the one hand, with the provision of a service that is universally available, even in the most remote and uninhabited region of the European Union. In the hills and valleys of Scotland, in the rural border area with England and the Midlands, in the beautiful but fragile Hebrides, Orkney, and Shetland islands, there is real concern about the possible loss of this essential service. However, we all know that the quality of service can only improve if postal services, like all service activities, are given the financial and managerial freedom of the private sector and the incentive of open, even international, competition. I will suggest one possible solution, which is already widely used in the transport sector. Air, ferry, train, or bus routes operating within and to the most remote areas are put to tender. The bidder offering to provide the specific service at a set level of quality and with the lowest degree of subsidy wins the contract. Let's call it a "negative bidding franchise." This allows for desirable competition in the provision of these services under a publicly supported but fully transparent franchise system. Why couldn't postal collection and delivery in a particular region be subject to such negative bidding? The lowest subsidy would get the franchise for a set period. Why couldn't a sub-post office in a remote village also be subject to this kind of negative bidding? It would then be up to the democratically responsible local, regional, or national governing body—probably under overall EU supervision—to set the service criteria and the financial resources to serve this specific social objective. Otherwise, postal services could become subject to all the demands and requirements of the market. Mr. President, Commissioner, it is no coincidence that I am the fifth Scottish Member of this House to speak in this debate. This reflects the importance of our postal services to us.

So, when we come to the problems of the new knowledge-based economy, the new digital economy—which, as far as I know, has only created unemployment in Europe instead of employment—it is certainly legitimate to ask whether the inability to address the current problems of unemployment is now being replaced by a largely phrase-filled explanation of the employment problems of the future. No one understands better than all of us the crucial role played by the internet, the digital economy, and the knowledge-based economy, but these were not the original objectives of the Employment Summit. Mr. President-in-Office, you concluded on a slightly ideological note, and that was a good thing. If this is what Social Democratic policy for the economy of the future looks like, then I must remind you that one of the most serious problems with the internet-based economy and Europe's backwardness is the lack of entrepreneurial spirit, which can be seen in the education system, in the actions of governments, and in the work of institutions. And it is precisely this that must be addressed to guarantee the knowledge-based economy of the future. Mr. President-in-Office, First of all, I would like to welcome you to the European Parliament, especially because your visit symbolizes what the Chairman of the Group of the Party of European Socialists has already pointed out here: that it is politically symbolic that, during your tour of the capitals, you have also come to hear the European Parliament. This is not the first time during the Portuguese Presidency that there has been a different and politically invigorating relationship between the Council and Parliament. But as Comrade Barón Crespo has pointed out, this is indeed a significant gesture, and we are happy to acknowledge it as such. Our position is clear: we support the Portuguese government's initiative because it is serious and because we identify with its content, both strategic and other objectives. This is also clearly reflected in the way this Council is being prepared. Firstly, the seriousness and thoroughness of the document presented in January. Then there are the various preparatory conferences, the contribution that both business and trade unionists are making to this summit. And above all, the recent contribution in the field of research, made at the conference bringing together Nobel laureates and ministers of science and technology. This demonstrates seriousness, a clear interest in the content of the summit preparations. But we also support the initiative with regard to the main objective already mentioned, because it not only brings employment and social issues back to the center of the European debate for the first time, but also because it once again appears possible to "achieve the goal of full employment." For years, many have said that this would be impossible, that it would not be possible again in the new societies. I congratulate you, Mr. President, on putting this issue back on the agenda without denying social cohesion and values that are fundamental to us. These values are not only the foundation of the founding project of the European Union, but also the foundation of our culture and, above all, our conception of the extent of solidarity necessary among all Europeans.

The lesson of the experiment in Europe is that it is precisely where wages are lowest and wage relations are most flexible that unemployment is highest, while where wages are highest and social relations are best regulated the unemployment rate is lowest. Mr President, this policy should arouse deep disappointment, not hope, in the hearts of European workers. With its resolution, our committee shows that, in addition to the Commission, the ECOFIN Council and the ECB, Parliament is also in favour of an extremely neoliberal socio-economic policy, which has had many negative repercussions on the living and working conditions of employed people and other large sections of the population in the Member States. Our committee has firmly rejected any attempt by the rapporteur to give, in the explanatory statement, a different dimension to the discussion on the economic situation in the European Union and to send certain messages to the Commission and the Council, different from that of Parliament, a body elected by the citizens of the Union. Even the positive contribution of international economic institutes and high-level experts, who have contributed to the reflection, has received a poor reception. With this resolution, Parliament is taking on serious responsibilities towards the citizens who elected it, because it supports an extremely neoliberal socio-economic policy which promotes widespread privatisation, claims to be against everything that is public, undermines workers' rights in the fields of employment, wages, social security and pensions, imposes a rigid financial policy with strong anti-popular and anti-social connotations and, giving voice to the demands of employers, asks workers to become more flexible if they want to find a job. My group rejects this concept outright and will therefore not vote in favour of the resolution. Mr President, the report presented by the Commission on the economy of the Union in 1999 seems to us to be vague because it does not explain at all why our results remain desperately below the potential that Europe's immense human resources should enable us to achieve. It is certainly pleasing to note that the 3% growth forecast for 2000, which may have seemed risky when the Commission formulated it in November 1999, now has a serious chance of being realised, and this in the context of low inflation, given that the peak of 2% recorded in January for the euro area remains, however, lower than in the past. One has the impression, however, that this growth, fuelled first by the results of the United States, then by the increase in productivity of the new economy, as well as by the new information and communication technologies, is being driven by the general trend of the world, and this despite our handicaps. We know these handicaps well, which must be remedied with extreme urgency; I am referring to the structural rigidities and excessive compulsory levies that have always characterised us. Let us not forget, however, that, with the single currency, a new one has been added. Indeed, the unification of monetary policies and the progressive alignment of other policies impose additional constraints on the euro area countries, forcing them to behave in ways that are not necessarily suited to their structures and economic circumstances.

I will conclude. I will not go into further detail: we will have the opportunity to do so at other times. But, it goes without saying, as one of the speakers pointed out, and I thank you all for your very positive and pertinent contributions, that we cannot afford to say again, in one, two or three years, that we have not done what we should have done. For my part, I can assure you, after having discussed this within the College of Commissioners, that the Commission is prepared to present to Parliament and the Council the legislative measures, amendments and directives necessary to provide us with the highest levels of security. The political will of this Parliament is necessary, and I see that I can count on that will, as is that of the Council of Ministers. Thank you, Commissioner. We have taken due note of your availability. I have received eight motions for resolutions, tabled on the basis of Rule 37(2) of the Rules of Procedure, to conclude this statement from the Commission. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday at 12 noon. Storms in Europe The next item is the Commission statement on the storms in Europe. I call Mr Barnier, on behalf of the Commission. Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your comments, particularly for the very concrete proposals concerning the victims who are expecting enormous help from the European Union and the help we can provide. Personally, in the first days following this terrible storm, I sent you a letter asking you to request that the French authorities readjust the Objective 2 perimeters so that all areas affected by the storms, both in France and elsewhere, could benefit from Objective 2. I think this was done because you did not mention it. We all know that if you are not within an Objective 2 perimeter, you will have great difficulty obtaining aid. So, it's best to address this problem immediately. You also know that the problem isn't just a short-term issue, but also a medium- and long-term one. Let me explain. I was in Lorraine during that terrible storm that devastated about 20% of the deciduous forest. Indeed, for some so-called forest communities, 20% of which are affected, this represents an enormous loss. We know, for example, that it takes between 150 and 200 years for a tree to reach maturity. The loss that these communities will suffer will therefore not be spread over one year, two years, or five years, but over much longer. The communities concerned estimate that it will be spread over 40 years. I therefore think that it will be very difficult to compensate for the loss of financial income for these rural communities through subsidies. I believe that this is an aspect that must be etched in our minds so that we don't forget it in our various policies.

If I had my way, I would wave a magic wand and harmonise excise duties throughout Europe, so that smuggling would no longer exist, except in cases where certain products are intrinsically more expensive in a given Member State. But I do not have a magic wand and I cannot do it my way. In this area, we need unanimity, as Mr MacCormick knows, and if the Member States do not agree on harmonising excise duties, that will not be possible. I repeat that towards the end of the year, the Commission will present a report on the excise situation and I am of course always available to discuss that report with Parliament. Community water policy (continuation) The next item is the continuation of the debate on the recommendation for second reading on Community water policy. Mr President, the situation of fresh water in Europe is not as bad as in other parts of the world. However, the facts show that, while the demand for water has constantly increased, the quality of that resource has, on the contrary, decreased. To this should be added the problems of water pollution in the potential new Member States of Eastern Europe, as well as the recent rupture of a tailings pond containing cyanide in Romania, a disaster which could now affect the water pipes supplying the Yugoslav population. I understand that Commissioner Wallström, whom I thank for being here this evening, will be visiting the area. I believe that no country, no government and, of course, no Member of this House can refuse to recognise that this directive is essential to put an end to the current fragmentation of water policy and to facilitate the launch of a programme with specific measures for each river basin. It has been difficult and complex to draft, with many interests at stake and divergent opinions. There is no doubt that Mrs Lienemann, the rapporteur in this parliamentary term, has made great efforts and commitment to trying to reconcile and reconcile the positions, and has largely achieved her objective. However, it is almost impossible to know and assess all situations and expectations equally. I come from a country whose southern half faces the Mediterranean, a country where the availability of water has always been linked to the whims of a fickle climate and a complex conformation of the land. Century after century, year after year, day after day, up to the present day, the Mediterranean region has had to struggle against this adversity in order to develop. That is why we believe it is very important that this directive reaffirms the obligation laid down in Article 164 of the Treaty which requires Community legislation to take account of the diversity of its regions. In order to see this principle applied, the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will oppose Amendments Nos 4 - Recital 21 -, 13 and 49 - Article 11(d) -, which seriously limit the sphere of exclusive competence of the Member States, as in the case of the regulation of water resources. It would be very difficult for the Community to determine the conditions of such regulation in the various regions, given the different internal balances that are always present, balances that require, in any case, a deep knowledge of the different areas and interests at stake.

In this situation, the policies of the European Union bear a great responsibility. Naturally, we must adapt these systems. In France, in particular, we must stop relying solely on the labor market to finance health insurance and pensions. Furthermore, we must reform the archaic administrative system, which is a source of injustice, mismanagement, and waste. In particular, we must pursue a family policy geared toward demographic growth, an economic, monetary, and fiscal policy focused on growth and the reconquest of our internal market, which contributes to job creation. The Commission's proposals and the Andersson report have nothing to do with social policy; rather, they are an instrument for granting Brussels excessive decision-making powers regarding the financing—that is, the organization and benefits—of the social protection systems of European nations. For this reason, we voted against this text. Social protection must, above all, be an expression of national solidarity, and it is primarily and exclusively the responsibility of the nation states. Social protection must be based on the principle of national and Community preference. Otherwise, it will merely serve to financially regulate the intolerable social conditions that result from immigration, to the detriment and disadvantage of European citizens. We did not participate in the vote on Jan Andersson's report on a concerted strategy for the modernization of social protection. Our fundamental attitude towards the European Union is positive. As Swedish Liberals, we view European integration as a way to solve cross-border problems, such as environmental issues, trade, international mobility, human rights, and conflict resolution. Here, Europe's democracies can show the world that cooperation leads to peace and prosperity. However, we also believe in the principle of subsidiarity, which means that decision-making must take place as close to those affected as possible. For this reason, we are actively working for a Constitution for the European Union that clearly outlines the distribution of competences for everyone to see. It must be absolutely clear to all citizens of the Union that the EU is concerned exclusively with the issues it is best placed to solve—cross-border problems. All other matters should be dealt with at the local, regional, or national level. Social policy is an example of an area where the EU should have only limited competence, except in cases involving the free mobility of people within the Union. Each Member State should have full responsibility and the right of self-determination for its social protection systems. Healthcare, childcare, and elderly care are clear examples of areas that are not directly cross-border. The same applies to employment policy. We do not believe that a common European legal framework in these areas will solve the problems of social security systems. We believe it is important that the Union instead focuses on a few issues where real benefits can be achieved. However, this does not prevent Member States from cooperating and exchanging ideas in the social field. Social security and equality have traditionally been high on the Liberal agenda. That is why we can fully support many of the proposals put forward in the Andersson report at the national level.

Mr. Barnier, I beg your pardon, but you have not fully answered the last part of my question regarding major energy transmission networks. Could you please provide an answer in that regard? Is the honorable Member concerned about whether the installation of nuclear power plants will be financed from the Structural Funds somewhere? I am being blunt. We could say that there is no need to even think about it. I told you, Honorable Member, that, under the Structural Funds Regulation, project selection remains the responsibility of the Member States. Consequently, the Commission services are not systematically informed of all the selected projects. However, the honorable Member is right to ask me; it is your job, and mine is to answer you. As has happened in the past, Member States are obliged to respond to the extent that the Commission questions them or requests clarifications. So, I will go a little further than the trust usually shared between the Member States and the Commission and look at exactly what this is about, in the specific case mentioned by the honorable Member. The Member State or States concerned should then reply to me, and I will forward their reply to the Honourable Member when I receive it. I thought I had already replied on the issue of large networks. The energy situation varies greatly across regions of the European Union, and aid from the Funds could be justified in certain cases and regions, particularly where connection to the basic energy networks is still underdeveloped. This is the answer I can give on this link between large energy transmission networks and the Structural Funds. - Question No. 46 by (H-0052/00): Subject: Structural Funds and Additionality. In light of the Commission's recent, careful reply to my priority written question on the Structural Funds and Additionality, could the Commission indicate whether it intends to amend the rules on additionality in any way? Would you be in favor, in particular, of modifying the rules so that additionality would not only apply at the level of the Member States but also within them, with regard to budgetary arrangements between central governments and regions or countries with internal self-government status? I would like to reply to Mr. MacCormick that the Commission has no intention of modifying the regulations on additionality, which, for the period 2000-2006, were contained in Article 11 of the general regulation of the Funds. As in the past, the principle of additionality applies, as provided for in those regulations, to the relationship between the Structural Funds and all—and I should say all—of Member State development expenditure. In this regard, it should be emphasized that the expenditure financed by the Structural Funds is that which must be additional. It is not mandatory that the co-financing provided by the Member State be additional, that is, that it be added to its expenditure. As long as the Member State does not reduce its overall own expenditure, the Structural Funds can be considered, and we consider them, to be complementary to national expenditure, and therefore the principle of additionality is respected. As for the budgetary arrangements applicable in the Member States, between the central government and regions or countries enjoying internal autonomy, these are determined by exclusively national considerations and are therefore not affected by additionality, as formulated in the regulations.

So if she has any lessons to offer, they are in good hands in this House. She knows me well enough to know that, at all stages of our five years of working together in this House, there has not been a single occasion when I have not given full, official, and detailed information about everything I have done. Mr President, allow me first to pay tribute to the careful and, as I understand, dedicated work of Mr van Hulten in preparing this report. Although he has not been a long member of this House, he is in many ways an old hand, as a former civil servant certainly in his familiarity with the institutions, and I think that this excellence is demonstrated by his ability to tackle this difficult issue, which, as several Members have pointed out, is of vital importance to all our institutions. I thank him and wish him a long and successful parliamentary career. As you know, Mr Van Hulten's report on the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts had to be very long, and since I want to give a comprehensive response to it, particularly in relation to the issue of financial management and control, I should like to ask for your indulgence in this regard. Of course, I will not take up Members' time any longer than absolutely necessary. When the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts was discussed in this House last September, I gave an assurance on behalf of the new Commission that the report would serve as an essential basis for the proposals to reform the Commission. The House will see the efforts we are making to fully implement this assurance when it turns to the reform package adopted today by the Commission, which, incidentally, is well within the ambitious timetable we set ourselves four months ago. I am sure Mr Pomez Ruiz will find this encouraging. The vast majority of the proposals contained in the paper are very similar to those of Mr. van Hulten, and this paper contains—I say this to him and Mr. Staes—a very precise timetable for the actions to be taken in the course of the reform. For this reason, the report I had the honor of drafting contains no unresolved or ambiguous points. The opinion of this Parliament will be of great importance during the coming four- to five-week consultation period, for obvious reasons. I would like to reply to Mr. Elles that we are certainly in receiving mode. However, he will no doubt recognize, with his usual generosity, that in order to receive any response to our proposals, we must first transmit them. Hence the transmission. While time does not allow me to discuss all the elements of the motion for a resolution before the House, I am pleased to assure you that the details will be treated as important input for our reform proposals throughout the consultation period and, of course, for our work in other important areas. I now turn to the main themes of the motion for a resolution and would like to make the following observations.

In this way, we will create a cooperative climate that will have a positive impact on the quality of reform. Parliament's representatives at the Intergovernmental Conference must make it clear to the negotiating partners that, by making institutional changes to the Union, we also assume responsibility for its constitutional development. They should therefore be aware that such issues cannot be resolved solely through haggling. The issues addressed by this Intergovernmental Conference are extremely sensitive. It may be easy to formulate solutions, but the question is to what extent these solutions will stand the test of time. I would like to point out two potential points of conflict. First, we have the balance we have maintained so far between large and small states. Europe is not a classic federal state and cannot become one. The solutions we decide on must be subordinate to the fundamental concept of the European Union, which is a union of states and a union of peoples. The other area where tensions could arise is even more complicated. In view of the impending accession of new members, we demand more efficient institutions from the future European Union. This means they must function more simply and quickly. However, the European Union is and remains inherently a complex and complicated multi-state institution. There are certainly opportunities for streamlining and simplifying it, but even here there are limits. If we overshoot the mark in favor of one-sided efficiency, then the legitimacy of the European Union will be called into question. I am, however, confident. Mr President, the mandate of the Intergovernmental Conference must be broadened. The most important issue that needs to be addressed in this regard is the internal differentiation of the Union. Unfortunately, even here in the European Parliament, this has not been addressed at all so far, although it is necessary for the Union to be enlarged in the agreed manner. Former Commission President Jacques Delors once again publicly raised the idea of a European confederation, pointing out that the vanguard countries at the forefront of the union should move forward faster than others and, for the sake of clarity, establish their own institutions. The current Commission President, Prodi, and High Representative Solana, have expressed similar views. In the opinion adopted last November, the Liberal, Democrat and Reform Group took a position on internal differentiation, proposing a system of concentric circles for Europe, the "onion model." In the next resolution on the Intergovernmental Conference, Parliament should really examine the issue of differentiation and flexibility in depth. If we fail to create the system of concentric circles proposed by the Liberal Group, both enlargement and integration will be at stake. My colleagues, Mrs. Frassoni and Mr. Onesta, have already expressed some skepticism about some aspects of the issue we are currently debating. I would like to add a word of concern about the issue of subsidiarity, not only between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Member States and their own autonomous regions. This has not been given due consideration so far, even though there are many issues here that give cause for concern. I would like to focus in particular on one of the implications of enlargement for this Parliament. The upper limit was set at a maximum of 700 members so that this Parliament can continue to fulfil its role as a consultative assembly.

Thank you, Mr. Medina Ortega. I fully share the regrets you express. Would you be so kind as to write to me so that I can, with supporting evidence, contact the competent authorities of both Air France and the French government? I truly believe that this is no longer possible, and we absolutely must protest in the strongest possible terms. Madam President, I had the same experience as Mr. Medina Ortega yesterday. I believe that the French authorities—who have the honor of hosting the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg—must realize their responsibility to guarantee adequate connections with all the capitals of the Union. Absolutely, Mr. Napolitano, thank you. Madam President, this is not about flight delays: I would like to apologize for the absence yesterday of my colleague from the Green Group, Caroline Lucas, who is a British MP. She could not be present because she was arrested during an anti-nuclear demonstration in Glasgow yesterday morning. Her identity was taken down: it became very clear that she is an MEP, but she was nevertheless detained all day. I consider this to be absolutely unacceptable and I will ask you – I have also written to you with my colleague Mrs Hautala on this subject – to intervene with the British authorities to ensure that such incidents do not happen again and that an apology is offered to Mrs Lucas. Thank you, Mr Lannoye. I have received your letter and I have already intervened with the British representation. Madam President, with regard to today's vote, I would like to ask something that I already raised yesterday, during the oral debate on the EQUAL report. I am asking for a postponement of the vote on the EQUAL initiative, because we simply need a little more time to resolve an important point. I am optimistic and I truly look forward to the vote with serenity and confidence; We will find as broad an agreement as possible for this position on EQUAL. We only need a little more time to sort out the details on the asylum issue, and I therefore ask that we vote tomorrow rather than today. Madam President, following up on Mr Lannoye's point: Ms Lucas was arrested outside Glasgow for demonstrating against the Trident base at Faslane. I have a great deal of sympathy for that demonstration. However, I have no sympathy for Ms Lucas trying to hide behind her parliamentary immunity. I, for one, was also arrested for demonstrating at Faslane. I did not hide behind my immunity. I accepted the sanction that was imposed on me. Ms Lucas should do the same. Madam President, I would like to come back to Ms Stenzel's request to postpone the vote on the Community initiative EQUAL until tomorrow. Indeed, this initiative was the subject of a fairly lively discussion within the committee and, since it is an important proposal from the Commission that relates to the agreements reached last year, I believe it is acceptable. We agree with Mrs Stenzel that the request for referral is justified in order to find the greatest possible agreement between the groups, so that Parliament can express its position on this initiative by the largest possible majority.

Already last autumn, we heard Mr Bernard Kouchner call for police forces. I am pleased to hear that Mr Javier Solana will be holding a meeting of the Interior Ministers next weekend to discuss the issue of police action. I hope that this discussion will focus primarily on Kosovo, so that a solution to this desperate situation can be proposed. Still on the subject of the Balkans and Kosovo, I also hope that the Council will follow the wish expressed by Parliament - and if I am not mistaken, also by the Commission - to see a budget set aside over several years for action in Kosovo. Mr Solana, the events in Kosovo have taught us several lessons: we have learned, for example, the need, in order to deal with crises, to equip ourselves with a military capability that we have already put to practical use. But another equally important lesson must be learned: namely, that it is better to prevent crises rather than be obliged to intervene after the fact. The EU therefore also needs an independent and credible capacity for conflict prevention. As far as the Commission is concerned, Commissioner Patten has already taken several commendable initiatives in this regard. I am thinking of the proposal to set up a rapid reaction facility and a rapid reaction force for non-military actions, as well as to create headline goals for non-military actions and a Commission crisis centre. The last question I would like to address to Mr Javier Solana is: what concrete preparatory work has been carried out in this area of conflict prevention? How was it organized in Mr Solana's department, and how was it coordinated with the work of the Commission? Mr President, Mr Solana, you have the full support and confidence of the Liberal Group, but we would like to remind you of the enormous responsibility that now rests on your shoulders. I am thinking, among other things, of humanitarian, peacemaking, and peacekeeping operations. But I am also thinking of the responsibility,² which is now yours, to ensure that the new European defense cooperation does not create the slightest division between NATO and the EU, nor between the USA and Europe. Such a division would only delight despots and rogue states that threaten freedom and human rights. You have, I believe, heard the concerns expressed last week in our Parliament by some members of the American Congress. You must ward off these concerns, Mr. Solana, because, as you yourself said, if we are united on both sides of the Atlantic, we can do something. If we divide ourselves, we weaken ourselves and thus prolong the suffering of the oppressed. Therefore, Mr. Solana, maintain the closest contacts with our American allies, without forgetting Norway, Turkey, and Canada. It is also largely thanks to them that we will not become paper tigers. We have, as Mr. George Robertson has often said, two million soldiers, but we were not even able to field 40,000 in Kosovo. Perhaps it was our weakness and lack of credibility that led to the war.

But beware of the fact that this backfires on the workers and the unemployed, who are told that everything is getting better and better, when they find that their lives are not improving, but, on the contrary, are getting worse. This is the main ideological struggle for Europe that we face. I think this debate sums it up perfectly. The main political divide was evident tonight, and it is no surprise that this issue has polarized the debate in an Assembly known for its capacity for consensus and distinctive politics. I am pleased that this difference of opinion can be seen so clearly, because this is a radical report. This report is a wake-up call for Europe. This report recommends radical measures that will, essentially, make recruiting staff easier. It's that simple. The reason we have such exorbitant unemployment rates in Europe is because, in many cases, recruiting staff is too complicated due to red tape, regulations, and the inflexibility of labor markets. It is the only way we can move forward, because the true way to guarantee social justice in Europe—and that, after all, is what we are here for—is through the creation of prosperity, opportunities, and jobs. This report clearly points to the most effective way to do this, because Europe needs to wake up. You cannot create jobs solely through public spending. You cannot create jobs through legislation to reduce working hours, as if jobs were a cake to be sliced and divided among people. The real world simply does not work like that. And if Europe wants to be left behind, left behind in stagnation, unemployment, statism, and corporatism, then yes, vote against this report tomorrow. But if you want Europe to move forward and begin to respond to the people of Europe, then I would like to ask you all to support this report, because it will provide those jobs and those opportunities, and because it is the only way to achieve that. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Giorgos Katiforis's report, in its original version, had the great value of extracting from the specific observations in the Commission document on the economic situation in Europe, strong guidelines for a European Union strategy capable of providing continuity and stability to the prospects for sustainable development that are emerging in 2000 for all the countries of our continent. These guidelines referred to the need for effective coordination of the Union's economic policies, and to overcoming the separate management of economic and social policies that until now has represented a serious obstacle to defining a coherent strategy to combat unemployment, with a view to full employment. Dear Mr. von Wogau, it is this lack of governance in the European economy that is, at least in part, determining the weakening of the euro. The document also referred to the creation of a European research area and the promotion, in all EU states, of convergent measures in the areas of research, lifelong learning, and employment, overcoming all forms of unfair competition between states in tax matters.

Of course, the relationship with Armenia is an element of these external relations, as the agreement signed last year shows. We believe that if Turkey wants to come to share the fundamental values of the European Union and the general framework of its relations - regardless of the bilateral idiosyncrasies it may have towards another country -, in general terms it will have to behave according to the basic models adopted by the European Union in its external relations. We are also sure that this issue will be one of the priorities in the bilateral relations between the European Union and Turkey in the near future. Question No. 6 by the Honourable Member (H-0122/00): Subject: Ethnic cleansing of Serbs in Kosovo Since the end of the NATO and EU bombing of Yugoslavia to prevent the ethnic cleansing of Kosovar Albanians by Serbia and the arrival of KFOR on 12 June 1999, 200 000 Serbs living in Kosovo have been expelled and 768 have been murdered, with the result that there has been comparatively more ethnic cleansing of Serbs than by the Serbs themselves. In recent days we have witnessed the murder, as always, of Serbs by Kosovar Albanian mafias with impunity. What decision does the Council intend to take to put an end, once and for all, to this ethnic cleansing and to ensure respect for human rights for all the people of Kosovo, irrespective of race or creed? I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his answer, but I would also like to point out that, statistically, there is more violence in Kosovo now than there was before the NATO bombings. It is worrying that the bombings have aggravated the situation, and it should be acknowledged that NATO and the European Union made a mistake in taking that decision. The President-in-Office of the Council spoke rightly - there is no doubt - about Belgrade's faults, but it should also be remembered that the secret services of the USA, Germany, France, Italy and Great Britain continued to supply weapons and money to the KLA, a mafia in other words, to help create problems in the area. Therefore, we are all to blame. I would like to ask a supplementary question on the global context. Do you not think that it would be appropriate to lift the embargo on Serbia in order to restore greater economic normality to the area and allow Kosovo, as a province of Serbia, to benefit from it? Mr President, I am not a friend of Milosevic or his government. However, I have very serious doubts about the legitimacy of NATO's action against Yugoslavia over Kosovo, both because of the lack of authority of the UN Security Council and because it could have been avoided by not imposing unacceptable terms on Serbia's sovereignty at Rambouillet. The current situation in Kosovo, where the ethnic cleansing of Serbs and Roma is now complete, speaks for itself. Shouldn't NATO at least acknowledge the error of deliberately targeting the Belgrade TV tower and killing 20 civilian journalists, which remain a serious moral stain on the management of the war and now open up the embarrassing prospect of possible war crimes indictments against Western leaders?

This will lead us to make CULTURE 2000 the citizens' programme. This increased participation of our citizens, which I strongly hope for, must be as broad and fruitful as possible. For my part, I undertake to work so that, over the five years over which the programme will be structured, this participation becomes a tangible reality. I know that you parliamentarians, in your regions, in your countries, are working with the participants in the programme so that all these little flowers, as a colleague said, become a vast multicoloured carpet. I would like this programme to become a tangible reality and for culture to represent for us citizens not only a factor of enrichment, both on a personal and socio-economic level, but also a right that must be affirmed and the sign of a newfound understanding within the Union. This is the contribution of our European programme CULTURE 2000. It is not a competition with the cultural policies pursued in the various Member States, which are necessary and I would like to see them developed even further. It is simply a complementary addition, a bridge between the different cultures of our different countries. Broadening and enriching the participation of European citizens in culture therefore seems to me to be an essential task that justifies our efforts. We must measure the success of our action and that of our Union by the yardstick of culture. Many Members of Parliament have argued very appropriately that if a Union is made up solely of economic elements, it is stillborn, but if it is made up of culture, civilisation and participation, then it can live. This is the basis, ladies and gentlemen, that I intend to develop, taking into account in particular the following five lines: offering innovative opportunities to our creative people so that their talent finds in our programme the support it deserves; encouraging exchanges, mobility and training in the cultural sector; encouraging cooperation between cultural operators; broadening the audience by giving particular importance to young people; and finally, safeguarding and making better known the common heritage of European importance and the history of the European peoples. I am sure that the new programme, thanks to its structure and its organisation based on transparency, efficiency and balance, will be a competitive and irreplaceable instrument at the service of our action. Madam President, I thank Parliament for its support and for having once again demonstrated the importance it attaches to culture in the context of the Union. I am sure that it will not be disappointed by its support and I undertake to inform it personally of the various stages of implementation of our action, of the action of our citizens, which I hope will be significant for the future of the Union. Thank you, Commissioner. I think we can once again thank our rapporteur. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11.00. (The sitting closed at 9.55 p.m.) End-of-life vehicles The next item is the recommendation for second reading (A5-0006/2000), of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, on the common position of the Council for adopting a European Parliament and Council directive on end-of-life vehicles [8095/1/1999 - C5-0180/1999 - 1997/0194(COD)](Rapporteur: Mr Florenz).

During the budget procedure, we were told that the funds for Kosovo had to be approved quickly, and now, according to our information, no calls for tender have yet been published or carried out. This is serious, because it is delaying the entire process of reconstruction in Kosovo. Finally, and this is the logical conclusion of my remarks, we call on the Commission to inform the Committee on Budgets regularly, monthly, about the status of expenditure implementation. We have documents that speak of fixed commitments. We don't need fixed commitments; we simply need commitments, and we need to know what has actually been paid and, above all, what has not been paid. Kosovo has suffered enough from payment delays. Mr. President, when we talk about Kosovo today, as we have often done, we should also take stock of what has already been done in Kosovo, or whether anything has been done at all. I think some small steps have already been taken toward normality, and one should at least mention them once in the context of such a debate. Starting February 9, there will be a so-called interim council – it's called the Kosovo Transitional Council – in which both the political parties, the minorities, and civil society are represented, and which is intended to be a kind of interim parliament. This is good, we welcome it, but I think they also need to be given a tool and a strategy for what they are supposed to prepare, because elections are planned for the fall. No one really knows what these elections will lead to, or what kind of parliament they will become. No one knows what powers this parliament will then have vis-à-vis UNMIK. That means there are a whole host of imponderables that we aren't informed about, and that others probably can't properly assess either. The very Albanians who are now being integrated into this interim council should actually have a bit more of an idea of what awaits them. In addition to economic work and reconstruction, we must also consider establishing coexistence among Serbs, Albanians, and other minorities – including the Roma – in this country, so that, hopefully, reconciliation can take place through coexistence sometime in the near future. I want to enumerate once again the actual things we can be happy about. There are now 34 tax inspectors in the administrative sector. That's fantastic! People are now being encouraged to pay their taxes there too, because in the long run, it can't be sustainable for everyone to depend solely on the coffers of the EU and other donors; some of this must come from our own resources in this area as well. It must also be noted that four of the 19 departments already have administrative leadership, which is also an improvement over what we had there previously. We also have something very important for the constitutional state that we want to establish. We have 130 judges and prosecutors who have now been sworn in and who can begin their work to administer justice there, to enrich the culture of tolerance there and, of course, to at least get to the bottom of the crimes and then be able to hand down convictions.

I wonder, however, why we can't talk about public health. It's an important part of social protection that is immersed in a kind of crisis—which also costs a lot of money and is important to many people—and which the Council obviously isn't going to talk about yet. Then Mr. Barón worried me a little because he said that the program you're presenting, Mr. President, is fundamentally a social democratic program. I then reflected a little more on his speech, and indeed, I believe there is an issue in it that was clearly social democratic. It is the point about designing the macroeconomy in such a way as to create jobs. If you implement good macroeconomic policy, it obviously leads automatically to greater job growth. We've already seen that. But on the other hand, the sound rules of macroeconomics cannot be abused by overly specific. We would then end up in a situation that many economies governed by the social economy or social democracy have experienced or still experience, whose ultimate victim is employment, due to a misguided macroeconomic policy. This must not happen. Therefore, I hope that the Prime Minister will not propose to cancel the macroeconomic policy we have pursued in recent years, which has brought us much success, or to change it in such a way that it is no longer effective. As a final point, Mr. President, I have a problem with the Portuguese Presidency documents and, to some extent, also with those of the Commission, and that is their defensive nature. There are some countries in Europe, including Denmark, but also the Netherlands and Ireland, that have performed as well as the United States in the area of employment. In other words, it is possible for Europeans to match the United States. There are other countries that have proven no less capable. It is therefore much more prudent to investigate why some countries are doing so badly, why some regions are performing so badly, rather than saying that we are all doing much worse than the United States. It seems to me that this is not entirely true in general terms, even less so when we take into account that the internal market has only been operating since January 1, 1993. And that is a relatively short time. Mr. President, Prime Minister Guterres has been convincing. The presidency's proposals contrast with the usual EU jargon. European citizens do not want a theological debate; they expect concrete actions. According to Professor Fitousi, the greatest deficit currently threatening European society is the deficit of the future. Many of our fellow citizens fear a future that has been painted black for them for two decades. The slightest accident is presented as an irreversible ecological catastrophe. Science is often demonized. The result: young people are increasingly less oriented toward scientific studies. People are asked to be flexible, to participate in the frantic race for productivity.

Human rights should not be limited to a reading limited only to the moment of denunciation or punishment. As Parliament, we must approach the issue of human rights above all from the perspective of prevention. In this sense, we must be able to export a culture of legality, a culture of law, and the appropriateness of law. I believe that a long period of piling up treaties and treaty signatures has definitively come to an end. Today we have many, perhaps too many, treaties that refer to the issue of human rights: if these treaties are reduced to a mere enunciation, they are merely examples of useless thinking. Today we must move to a subsequent and necessary stage, that of the daily and mandatory application of what is written in our treaties, although we must not forget that some fundamental treaties still have to be incorporated. I am referring to the Rome Conference, since 14 of the 15 states of the Union have not yet ratified the Treaty on the International Criminal Court. I believe we must review and modify some of the political instruments through which we measure the quality of human rights on the planet. We have often used instruments that, from a formal point of view, may be convenient but, from the point of view of political results, are absolutely useless. I am referring to the use, and often abuse, of the embargo over the years and the overly cautious application of the suspension clause in agreements between the European Union and third countries in the event of human rights violations in those countries. I believe we must update the horizon of human rights protection. Globalization risks being interpreted in a particularly punitive way. Currently, in many countries, the principle of the universality of human rights is being called into question. Many human rights, including the right to life, denied by the death penalty, are considered dependent variables, while globalization, often understood in a punitive sense, risks becoming, in fact, the only network that holds together the rights, actions, and policies of all countries. Consequently, we must update our scope of action in this effort to protect human rights. I'm thinking of social rights, workers' rights, the quality of work, and the need to ensure respect for all the criteria that have been indicated, as they should be, by the International Labour Organization. I'm thinking of the right to tolerance, the right to respect, which is a right of all minorities, especially within the European Union. I'm also referring to the right to development, which is a right of peoples who are themselves a collective of individuals: every individual, within the people to which they belong, has the right to development, to a future that is above all a place of hope and growth. I believe that all of this is part of a reasoning, a debate, and a contribution that the European Union must make to the field of human rights.

The Commission cannot, however, accept amendments Nos 1, 4, 9, 11, 13, 15, 19, 23, 39, 40, 41, 49, 51, 59, 61, 64, 66, 70, 71, 72, 74, 77, 83, 87, 90, 91, 92, 95, 97, 98, 81(rev.), 100, 101, 103 and 107. Thank you for your attention. (Parliament declared the common position as amended approved) Report (A5-0033/2000) by Mr Andersson, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the communication from the Commission on a concerted strategy for modernising social protection (COM(1999) 347 - C5-0253/1999 - 1999/2182(COS)) (Parliament adopted the resolution)President. This concluded the voting. EXPLANATIONS OF VOTE - Lienemann report (A5-0014/2000) I welcome the quality and ambition of the report on LIFE. I would like to point out briefly that LIFE is a financial instrument at the service of environmental policies in the European Union and in third countries, be they neighbouring Mediterranean countries, countries bordering the Baltic Sea or candidate countries. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy has proposed several amendments, most of which have been taken into account in the common position adopted by the Council. For the third phase of LIFE (2000-2004), this instrument will be divided into three axes, LIFE-nature (47% of resources), LIFE-environment (47%) and LIFE-third countries (6%). In my opinion, the most important changes concern: LIFE's contribution to sustainable development in the Community and to the promotion of Community policy in the field of the environment, in particular with regard to the integration of the environmental dimension into other policies, and its contribution to the implementation and updating of environmental legislation; improving the effectiveness, transparency and methodology of LIFE's implementation procedures, the procedures for informing and disseminating information to the public and those for cooperation between beneficiaries; the objective of LIFE, which must consist primarily of sustainable urban development, in close association with the pilot projects carried out under the URBAN initiative, on which I have also had the opportunity to express my views; the contribution of projects aimed at promoting the sustainability of socio-economic activities and, consequently, the creation of jobs. What seems essential to me is that the LIFE instrument will remain open to the participation of the candidate countries of Central and Eastern Europe. The other candidate countries (for example, Cyprus, Turkey, Malta) will also be able to participate in LIFE when agreements to this effect are concluded with them. The main obstacle in the negotiations with the Council is the level of the financial envelope envisaged for the third phase of the LIFE programme (2000-2004). The Commission proposal approved by the Council is EUR 613 million, while the Committee on the Environment considers that the amount should be EUR 850 million. I support the rapporteur's firmness. Since the creation of the programme, in fact, the financial envelope has never been adjusted, not even on the occasion of the transition to fifteen Member States following the enlargement of the European Community. If the report is adopted in plenary, a conciliation procedure, as foreseen by the codecision procedure, will have to be initiated to resolve the issue of the amount of appropriations foreseen for the programme.

At the beginning of this decade, we must plan how our institutions will develop internationally until the end of this decade, and particularly what place we should occupy within international monetary bodies, what place we should occupy within United Nations bodies, and so on. We must open this debate. In conclusion, this morning, the day after Valentine's Day, the newspapers announce that your honeymoon is over. I don't know whether you are romantic or not, Mr. Prodi. Perhaps that is a very unromantic statement for such a day. However, we in the Liberal Group welcome it because we believe it means that we have now seriously set to work. That is in the order of things. Considering the many adjectival descriptions you used for Europe during your speech – an energetic Europe, an enterprising Europe, a Europe with a human face and that is inclusive – allow me to define, in a word dear to the hearts of my liberal colleagues, in two words, the Europe that we want to see outlined in your governance plan: a Europe of possibilities. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, I have great respect for your frankness in admitting that the European Union must change completely. You reflect on major issues of principle in your programme. I believe that citizens will begin to take a greater interest in politics if we are able to raise major issues as well as the small, everyday matters. At the same time, however, it must be noted that your programme unfortunately resembles a party programme in many respects. It does indeed contain many good intentions, but concrete proposals on how to achieve all this are largely lacking. Like any party program, it also contains several internal contradictions. With my intervention, I would like to help you identify these internal contradictions. First of all, the economy and social development. We must be able to think about how to reconcile the objective of competitiveness with the objective of full employment; this is therefore mentioned in your program. Finally, should there be a convergence criterion which—as you actually suggest in this program—would aim to ensure that unemployment in no Member State exceeds, say, the rate of the three countries that have been most successful in this area? Ecological tax reform is what my group wants to emphasize. We can indeed only create jobs and sustainable development by changing the structure of taxation, but unfortunately—as we all know—this is an area in which the European Union is completely incapable of acting. I urge you to raise this issue at the Intergovernmental Conference. The European Union can only achieve legitimacy by focusing on tasks that individual countries cannot handle alone. Parliament certainly agrees with you on the importance of supranational decision-making in this regard. An internal contradiction in your report is related to globalization. I think you have a lot of merit in raising the notion of "global control," as others here have noted.

I hope and trust that you, Commissioner Monti, will support these proposals, and I look forward to your comments and your position on them. Finally, I would like to welcome the report on competition from the Commission's DG XXVIII, to which a considerable amount of work has once again been devoted. However, as I have already mentioned, our ultimate goal must remain transparency and clarity. There is still a need to improve efficiency in the areas mentioned, and there is therefore sufficient reason to continue working with a view to resolving the problems related to the lack of transparency and clarity in the field of State aid. This is particularly necessary in relation to the upcoming enlargement, and I would like to express my gratitude to Mr. Jonckheer, who has very thoroughly addressed in his report all the problems related to enlargement and how to ensure that these countries meet our requirements and also that we compete on a level playing field. It is clear that as liberals and Greens we have different worldviews; however, we largely agree on our objectives and will try to find a reasonable solution to our problems. Mr. President, Commissioner, we simply have to answer two questions. Are state aid to companies legitimate, or are agreements between companies legitimate in a market economy, and who should oversee these exceptions to the absolute rules of the market economy? Regarding the first point, we openly affirm that, in order to take into account the needs of sustainable development to which the European Union subscribes, it is essential that in certain cases there be state aid to companies, whether in the form of tax relief, a differentiated tax regime, or simply direct aid. It is equally legitimate for agreements between companies to exist, self-limitation agreements, all those agreements that make it possible to mitigate the harmful effects of competition on social or ecological needs. We therefore answer quite clearly yes: it is legitimate for aid to exist, for agreements to exist, but we affirm that each of these agreements must be expressly subject to reasoning. The von Wogau report proposes returning the control of this legitimacy to the national level. We find this relatively dangerous, but we will nonetheless vote in favor, because we recognize that the Commission cannot do everything. We demand greater transparency and that the Commission be given greater powers of investigation to verify ex post the legitimacy of these exceptions. Mr. President, once again we are debating the European Union's competition policy. However, under what conditions is this debate actually taking place, and what conclusions should we reach? What characterizes the current reality is the materialization of gigantic takeovers, mergers, and acquisitions of enormous monopolistic companies and the formation of tremendously powerful global groups. Frankly, shouldn't our debate address this situation? What competition policy is willing and able to establish controls on the actions of these monopolistic companies?

We are changing the law so that it becomes enforceable again; I find this unacceptable. The Commission is giving up its monopoly on exemptions. Given this planned system of legal exceptions, restrictions on competition are automatically exempted, provided the requirements of Article 81(3) of the EC Treaty are met. The need for notifications in Brussels is eliminated, meaning that the Commission will be flying blind in this regard in the future. I find this unacceptable. The Commission's concept is supplemented by increased ex post control by national authorities and the courts of the Member States. However, if this continues as part of a renationalization, we will end up with a patchwork of competition policy in Europe. I believe this is unacceptable. A core element of European policy is being weakened here. The systemic change in European antitrust law envisaged by the European Commission is highly risky from a competition policy perspective. We have sufficient other options within the existing system to ensure open markets and free competition.
