Moreover, with its proposal, the Commission is returning to old proposals that were already put forward in the 1950s and 1960s. They failed to gain a majority back then. Because France placed such a strong emphasis on the legal exception at the time, it was compensated with concessions in agricultural policy. Forty years later, this proposal is now back on the table, and I am certain it will create scope for the formation of cartels to the detriment of European consumers. I do not consider this acceptable! Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, in this important debate on competition policy this morning, I would like to comment specifically on Mr. Langen's report on the Steel Aid Code. As the European Court of Justice recognized in 1996, the iron and steel industry is particularly vulnerable to disruptions in the competitive landscape. Incidentally, I reached this conclusion several years ago in a report on the strengths and weaknesses of the European iron and steel industry. It was therefore entirely legitimate to introduce an aid system for this sector to ensure the survival of efficient companies, even if this contradicts Article 4 of the ECSC Treaty. This is precisely the aim of the Sixth Steel Aid Code. At the same time, however, it is important to avoid any infringement of competition rules and any serious disturbances of the equilibrium of the markets, and this aid must therefore be regulated. State aid must therefore continue to be limited to research, development, environmental protection, and closure aid. In the same vein, it is paramount that Member States fulfill their obligation to account to the Commission for the aid they have granted to their steel companies. The Commission proposes shortening the deadlines, and I agree with this request. Like the rapporteur, while welcoming the Commission's report, I regret that not all aspects of steel aid are addressed. Although the Steel Aid Code is very clearly drafted, the Commission has approved aid to steel companies that do not fall within the categories listed in the Code. In the interests of equal treatment, the Code must either be applied or amended. Finally, Mr President, let me say that with the expiry of the ECSC Treaty, the rules must be revised, because I believe the aid system must continue beyond 2002. Therefore, I am in favor of a Council regulation that ensures certainty in this area.

(Applause) Madam President, we Belgian Christian Democrats are concerned, and fortunately many of our colleagues are as well. The coalition agreement being finalized in one of the Member States is certainly an Austrian issue, but there is no doubt that it also has a European dimension. Because what unites us in Europe are, first and foremost, the values and principles of freedom, democracy, and respect for human rights. The president of the Austrian Liberal Party, Haider, has repeatedly expressed his contempt for these values. He also disdains the most basic forms of diplomatic courtesy. He is a dangerous man. The Christian Democratic parties in my country made the choice long ago, and remain faithful to that belief, to heed the protests of far-right voters, but never to negotiate with far-right leaders. Values must come before power. We therefore regret what is happening in Austria. Indeed, we are completely shocked. We are deeply disappointed. We call on the ÖVP to ultimately seek other solutions. We continue to insist on Article 6 of the Treaty. We continue to fight against the trivialization of the far right. If a government is ultimately formed with this coalition, then we call on our ÖVP colleagues to ensure in their program, both in words and deeds, that the principles and values that are the foundations of European integration are respected. President, ladies and gentlemen, Austria has a great responsibility here. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that in this Parliament we largely agree on rejecting Haider and his policy, but it is also clear that we have differences on the question of how this policy can be most effectively combated. Have you ever wondered what the effects are in Austria of this debate here and of the Council Presidency's statement last weekend? Have you ever asked yourself whether we do not also bear responsibility for the subsequent development of the political situation in Austria when we set ourselves up as judges here? Have you ever wondered what would happen if a colleague's wish were granted and elections were held in Austria in the coming days? According to the consistent reports from all observers, Haider would emerge even stronger. Who could possibly want this? Don't we have a responsibility to consider how we can combat this policy? Europe is a community of law. Among the principles we must defend are those of democracy, respect for human rights, and the rule of law. The democratic mandate includes the fact that even if we don't like the decisions taken in the elections, we respect them, and therefore we must respect it if the Austrians, for reasons rooted in their politics, decide as they have. It is a matter of the rule of law that the Council Presidency does not express itself as it has, in a way that contradicts the Treaties.

We must prevent this, adopt preventive measures to avoid this type of disaster from happening again. This is the meaning of the oral question we have put forward on behalf of all the Members of the Fisheries Committee. We hope that the Commission will present concrete proposals: actions, not lamentations. Parliament will today approve a joint motion for a resolution from several parliamentary groups, which I consider, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to be very important and timely. Mr President, the sinking of the Erika on 12 December off the coast of Brittany caused an oil spill, the effects of which on the environment will be felt for many years. In addition to the destruction of natural resources, we must add the serious impact of this disaster on certain economic sectors, fundamentally those dependent on fishing. The situation could get even worse with the 20,000 tonnes of crude oil remaining in the compartments of the grounded vessel. For the aquaculture and oyster farming sectors, helpless in the face of the pollution that has irremediably reached the coasts, the results have been very serious from the very first days and also subsequently, due to the loss of market share in these sectors and the rejection by consumers of a guaranteed product but affected by this pollution. Ladies and gentlemen, these are peripheral regions whose economic balance is unstable and which have been deeply affected by this oil spill, which is unfortunately not an isolated incident. This region - like other neighboring regions - relies mainly on natural resources. A nature too often punished by human activities that could be avoided if the public authorities had greater control over them. "Prevention is better than cure," they say. The budget says so too. Ladies and gentlemen, preventive measures are much less expensive than repairing the damage caused by disasters of this magnitude. Mr Fischler says he is present whenever Parliament calls him. However, in the Erika affair, he gave the impression – perhaps not to us, but to the people of Brittany and Vendée – that, as Commissioner for Fisheries, he was not there or only partially there. As Parliament already pointed out in the first resolution of 20 January, the needs of the fishing, oyster farming and tourism industries must be taken into account as affected sectors. This is why we have asked the Commission to adopt urgent measures for the fishing sector, by mobilising specific funds. Galicia and Brittany, the two Finistère regions of Europe, have both been affected by these oil spills. We do not understand why disasters such as the Urquiola and the Amoco Cadiz have not served as a lesson to strengthen legislation in the maritime transport sector, both in terms of safety controls for the transport of dangerous goods and in terms of flags of convenience. We ask that this be the last time. We ask that lessons be learned and that we hurry to amend our legislation and close the loopholes that mean that we are always faced with the unbelievable, and that this unbelievable is nevertheless true. The "polluter pays" principle seems to us not only necessary, but also justified.

Established in March 1969, it is officially required to meet every two years, but in practice, it meets annually and makes its decisions based on scientific advice. The organization then issues recommendations for the conservation of stocks. The organization has four standing committees, composed of national experts, covering the areas of research and statistics, finance and administration, compliance, and conservation and management measures. There are also four working groups for tropical tunas, northern and southern temperate tunas, and other species. These working groups are empowered to initiate regulatory measures for species covered by the convention. Proposals from these working groups are submitted to the Commission, which then proposes recommendations to the contracting parties. These recommendations are binding, but contracting parties have a six-month period during which they may object. As a contracting party, the European Union is obliged to transpose such recommendations into Community law. During its session held in Santiago de Compostela in November 1998, ICCAT recommended certain amendments to the rules on minimum landing sizes for bluefin tuna. ICCAT also issued recommendations in 1974, 1994 and 1996. From now on, it is prohibited to land or sell bluefin tuna of age 0, weighing, of course, less than 1.8 kilos. During the November 1998 session, the ICCAT Standing Committee on Research and Statistics was asked to conduct a new assessment of the bluefin tuna populations in the western and eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The committee would thus provide the organization with the information necessary to review, develop and improve stock recovery plans. It was decided that the SCRS should present a study during the 1998 session, highlighting various possible scenarios for stock recovery, to levels that could produce maximum sustainable yield, taking into account the various variants of possible levels of recruitment and stock mixing. In addition, the SCRS study should indicate monthly closures for purse seine fishing, so that closures would be more effective for the conservation of bluefin tuna. As a result of this research, the session agreed that, instead of imposing a blanket ban on purse seine fishing for bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean during the period 1 to 31 August, a more selective approach should be implemented. It is important to protect tuna fisheries for future generations. Bluefin tuna is the most expensive fish in the world, fetching up to €90,000 per tonne daily at the Tokyo auction. The importance of Mediterranean tuna is evident in the fact that it accounts for 70% of all landings in the region, estimated at nearly 30,000 tonnes. Of this, 80% is caught using purse seines. The Mediterranean is an important spawning ground for bluefin tuna, so it is important to take the necessary measures to strengthen the protection of juveniles. We must respect the minimum size and implement technical measures if we are to eliminate catches of fish aged 0. The measures adopted in November 1998 came into force on 21 June, I repeat, 21 June 1999, almost nine months ago, several months before the communication was sent to the Committee on Fisheries. I believe, Commissioner, that this is not enough and that in the future we must learn the lessons from this.

However, the truth is that the Commission's guidelines do not fully comply with these objectives. On the other hand, it is important to have precise guidelines and sufficient funding in the areas of quality job creation with rights, as well as the effective promotion of equal rights and opportunities, in support for the social and solidarity economy, rural development, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, and improving the quality of life of urban populations in needy areas, particularly in the social housing sector, with a view to sustainable urban development. (IT) While the content of Article 158 of the Treaty is aimed at promoting harmonious development throughout the Community, we must say that achieving the elimination of disparities is still far off, or rather, in some cases, such as for the Italian regions that are part of Objective 1, paradoxically, disparities are increasing, especially due to the still limited capacity of the structural apparatus to adapt to Community procedures and the persistent cumbersome nature of the procedures. In fact, despite regulatory initiatives, the streamlining of Community structures has yet to be achieved. Without administrative simplification, it will be difficult to achieve the Community's objectives of reforms inspired by efficiency and concentration. In this regard, the Commission document lacks any recommendations to Member States aimed at simplifying national procedures and regulations regarding the submission and processing of projects by national authorities, as well as financing, action, and oversight. Small and medium-sized enterprises, microenterprises, and artisans, in particular, remain "weak subjects," given that the regulatory and administrative hurdles imposed by some Member States, including Italy, pose significant obstacles to their access to the Structural Funds. A considerable handicap is the inability and impossibility of the regions and other stakeholders to program in a timely manner. Therefore, the Commission, which, based on Decision 97/99 on the guidelines (Howitts report), should have consulted Parliament at the time, in fact found a kind of convenient excuse in establishing the reduced programming phase in the Member States and published the guidelines in July 1999, before the newly elected Parliament began its legislative activities, thus preventing Parliament from influencing the current structure of the guidelines. For this reason, the mid-term assessment of Article 42 of Regulation No 1260/99 will be very important. In general, the current guidelines lack clarity and transparency. Despite their importance, they only address the possibility of measuring progress against verifiable objectives fully aligned with Community policy strategies. They do not sufficiently address the implications of enlargement, as they contain no specific provisions or clarifications on this matter for either regional or national authorities or for the candidate countries. That said, the different approach to the guidelines, which, aside from geographical objectives, are based on sectoral policies, can be positively assessed.

The exhaustive collection of data that is proposed and its appropriate processing will be valid elements for addressing the revision of the common fisheries policy with greater rigour. All this, of course, if the data is obtained. Because, as the rapporteur rightly points out, the Commission proposal does not contain any element of obligation towards the Member States. The transmission of data by the latter is voluntary while failure to submit them will only result in the loss of a certain economic compensation which, moreover, is not even very high. With the experience gained on the submission of data in the fisheries sector and I am referring to the reports on the fulfilment of the MAGPs, I believe that instead of a detailed picture of the situation in the sector, we will find ourselves faced with a confused panorama in which some Member States will transmit, for example, scientific data, but not data on employment, while others will provide data on employment but not on the situation of resources, depending on whether they can, or want to, obtain and transmit them. Of course, I am very much afraid that some will prefer not to get funding if they can continue to hide their mismanagement, which has already been seen even in cases where data transmission was mandatory, as in the case of the POPs mentioned above. Given this shortcoming, which I consider the most serious, the report of the Committee on Fisheries improves the proposal in some interesting ways, especially with the rapporteur's suggestions on more reasonable deadlines for submission and with the request for a check by the Commission. My group has supported two requests that I consider reasonable. The first suggests that, in cases where the collection of a series of data proves interminable, data from studies and samples should be used. The second suggests that data strictly linked to the fiscal aspect of companies should be eliminated from the Commission's proposal, taking into account, among other things, that such data does not fall within the competence of the Community. In the light of all this, I believe that the report is appropriate and, on behalf of my group, I ask for its approval. I would first like to congratulate Mrs Attwooll on preparing and presenting the report. I support the establishment of a Community framework for the collection and management of fisheries data, which I believe is absolutely essential if we are to properly assess the level of stocks of the various fish species. It is important that this data is both economic and environmental and that the information provided by the Member States is standardised throughout the European Union and, as highlighted in the report, brought into line with international provisions. I support the allocation of funds for national programmes, also taking into account the provisions to be observed in relation to minimum programmes. I agree with the proposal that the Commission should also be provided with the information intended for international organisations. Otherwise, the purpose of data collection and aggregation would be lost and, in the absence of information, a cautious approach would continue to be applied. It is in the interest of the industry that the information is concrete and based solely on facts.

. Women suffer from growing inequalities because they are victims of sexist discrimination that can be exercised openly (violence, rape, sexual harassment, domestic violence, etc.) but also in a more insidious way. This oppression is based on a sexual and social division of labor that values the work of men over that of women. Wages are unequal, their work is still perceived as "side work" and more generally, female employees do not have access to the same positions of responsibility as men. In addition, family responsibilities fall mainly on them. Women must have the right to full-time employment, just like men. Coercive laws must be passed to promote professional equality. States must develop a public service for early childhood care. Finally, to allow everyone to engage in public life, there must be a massive reduction in working hours. There must be a real diversity in political, economic and social life. We oppose the idea that the biological difference between women and men gives rise to two different world views and two different value systems. Women have the right to be present in the decision-making process as "individuals" and not as representatives of the female sex. My colleagues in the British Conservative delegation and I are fully committed to addressing the need to increase the number of women playing an active and full role in public life. We share the regrets expressed about the persistence of inequality and discrimination on the basis of sex, and in particular about the under-representation of women in politics. However, we are not convinced that one discrimination should be countered by another, namely the introduction of quotas to guarantee seats for women. I feel this particularly keenly because on Thursday evening, my 27-year-old daughter, Caroline, was selected as the Conservative candidate for the constituency of Southampton Itchen in the United Kingdom. She arrived at this position entirely on her own merits and as a result of competition against all participants. We should not adopt a position that in any way diminishes the position of the growing number of women who are showing that they can assert themselves in public life without fear or favor. The members of my delegation and I therefore supported a large part of the resolution, but we oppose the call for positive discrimination in favor of women, which we believe would not be a good way forward, but would actually be degrading to women and distort the democratic process. Accordingly, we abstained in the final vote. Katiforis report (A5-0041/2000) Mr President, I voted in favor of the Katiforis report on the performance of the European Union's economy in 1999 as a matter of group discipline, because it exposes an extremely serious shortcoming that it will, I hope, help to eliminate in the coming years. This report does not clearly explain, or even explain at all, that the economy of the States of the Union also and above all depends on the way in which the funds allocated to pensions, taken from workers, are used.

If we allow Europe to be diluted by enlargement, we will drown in our own political quagmire. Mr. President, there are days when I truly cannot understand this Parliament, which takes a masochistic pleasure in self-mutilation. After having limited its participation in the IGC to two small posts of its own accord, Parliament today refuses to complete the agenda of the IGC. Indeed, whether out of weakness or foolishness—and neither option is truly glorious, as you will recognize—our Parliament, by rushing to give its assent, abandons the only means of action conferred upon it by the Treaty, namely, that of demanding, as a preliminary matter, a complete agenda for the IGC before making a decision. Why should we vote for this assent tomorrow, February 3, in a hurry, when we could wait, in a position of strength, for the opening of the Strasbourg session on February 14, and thus impose on the Council a finally complete and, therefore, coherent agenda? No small amount of hypocrisy was needed to mask our current weakness. Hypocrisy that we must bitterly regret in our resolution: that the agenda of the IGC falls short of the imperatives, when, by rushing forward, with culpable naivety, we deny ourselves the possibility of imposing this more ambitious program. If at the end of this IGC there are democratic gaps, I must say that the responsible parties will be the political groups that have encouraged this haste. Whether we like it or not, as our Parliament will itself extinguish the only spotlight that allowed it to shed some light on the debates, the locus of decision-making will now shift to the fifteen states of the Union. Therefore, I ask the Members of the vast majority of this Parliament who in November considered that the future of Europe deserved broader debates than the remains of Amsterdam to take up their pilgrim's staff and go and convince their government that this IGC should be expanded, since the Helsinki Council resolution allows for it. Because of the situation in Austria, this day is a dark one for Europe. We realize then that the victory of democracy is never definitive and that we must convince and convince once again. To affirm our fundamental values, it is urgent to put them in writing, and, apart from this IGC, I believe we owe Europe a constitution. Mr. President, the motion for a resolution we are discussing calls, as before, for the future Intergovernmental Conference to have a broad agenda, one that includes the profound reform of the institutions. The future enlargement of the Union is used as an argument for this. I am convinced that this conception is flawed. A federal EU, tending toward centralization and increasingly governing the member countries, will, in reality, be in a worse position for enlargement. A flexible EU, concentrating on fewer but more important issues and respecting differences and national democracies, will be better able to encompass many more countries.

Throughout this Conference, ladies and gentlemen, it is not only the status of the negotiators that is important, but also the quality of what they say. And I want to remind your Parliament once again, given my experience before Amsterdam, that whatever the ambiguity or weakness of the status that was granted to the two representatives of the European Parliament before Amsterdam, the quality of what Mrs Guigou and Mr Brok said counted for a great deal in these negotiations. I am sure that it will be the same, and as far as I am concerned, in my position, I will ensure that the ideas put forward by your two representatives are listened to and respected throughout these negotiations. I am sure that the European Parliament will not be a spectator of these negotiations, any more than the Commission will be a spectator. We now await, ladies and gentlemen, with great interest, your subsequent opinion in which you will specify Parliament's priorities and concrete proposals for these negotiations. It is of great importance that the two European institutions that will be present in these negotiations, the Commission on the one hand, the European Parliament on the other, alongside the members of the Council, clearly explain to the citizens of the Union, always and every day explain to the citizens of the Union, what the issues at stake in this Conference are and what responses we recommend, as European institutions responsible for ensuring the smooth functioning of this enlarged Union and the common interest. In the coming months, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission will therefore work in close consultation, in good understanding, with your two representatives, Professor Tsatsos and Elmar Brok, in order to bring our points of view closer together, if necessary. Our points of view and positions will probably not always be the same; there will undoubtedly be differences, as is normal. What is important is that there is consistency, and it is to work towards this consistency that I have committed myself since the beginning of my duties within the College. We therefore have the concern and the ambition, on a very large number of issues, to be on the same wavelength and to take these negotiations to the next level. This will not be by chance, since, I repeat, it seems to me that we have the same ambition for these negotiations and we feel together that it truly constitutes a moment of truth for the European Union. Finally, I would like to make three additional observations, quickly, Mr President. First, to congratulate and thank President Napolitano and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs for the extremely strong and original initiative that was taken yesterday in bringing together the qualified representatives of the national parliaments, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and the Commission for an initial joint debate. This dialogue between the national parliaments, the European Parliament and ourselves is extremely important. I also said that I would play my part by going myself before each of the national parliaments.

If amendments were adopted that weaken the directive, it would be extremely detrimental, not only for the environment but also for the European Parliament's credibility on environmental issues. It was pointed out in today's debate that we must not forget the millions of people who find work in the car industry, nor countries with a highly developed car industry, such as my own country, Sweden. I myself was a car worker before my election and am certainly one of the few people in this Parliament who has stood on an assembly line and assembled cars. I believe that the automotive industry must be subject to high standards, as this favors modern, environmentally conscious, and rapidly developing car manufacturers. And it is precisely this type of car industry that we must promote in the European Union. Mr President, I am very pleased that environmental protection is now a priority for Parliament, as well as for the citizens of Europe. Old vehicles pollute the environment and pose a serious threat to it, and our citizens expect us to represent their interests in this regard. Every year, eight to nine million cars are scrapped in the European Union. This alone generates a huge amount of waste. Vehicle and parts manufacturers, as well as material suppliers, must strive to limit the use of hazardous substances as far as possible. It is therefore important to ensure, right from the design phase, that recycled materials can be used in vehicle production. We know that the Netherlands has approved treatment facilities for the collection of end-of-life vehicles, and I believe we should introduce these throughout the European Union. As far as Ireland is concerned, I am aware that the Irish Department of the Environment has begun consultations with representatives of the automotive industry with the aim of establishing suitable end-of-life vehicle collection centers in Ireland in the near future. In my view, there is no reason why concession agreements should not be concluded across Europe for treatment facilities to dismantle the eight to nine million vehicles withdrawn from the European Union each year. Car manufacturers must provide information on the reuse, recycling, and recovery rates for used cars they intend to achieve in the coming years. Under the new provisions of the Treaty of Amsterdam, the 370 million consumers in the European Union have a right to consumer-specific information. I am convinced that EU consumers will support those car manufacturers that introduce the most environmentally friendly practices in the coming year. Finally, I would like to say that relevant regulations and laws should take into account the special position of the classic car sector within the European Community, which plays a particular role in social, economic, and environmental matters. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the End-of-Life Vehicles Directive undoubtedly marks a milestone in the improvement of the environment in our European Union. I also believe that enormous efforts have been made to ensure sound material recycling, reduce environmentally harmful waste, and promote technological innovation. From this point of view, we are certainly on the right track, but, as some colleagues have already pointed out, the real problem is that the manufacturers may be left to bear the responsibility alone.

Mr Rübig has the floor. Mr President, fourteen Member States have imposed bilateral sanctions against a Member State because a democratically elected government has been formed there. Both parties have already participated in the government. They have not committed any legal violations to date. Are preventive sanctions compatible with the Charter of Human Rights? Would a right of veto by the President of the Council over national government formations be compatible with the Charter of Fundamental Rights? Is calling for violent demonstrations compatible with the Charter of Fundamental Rights? Mr President, as President-in-Office of the Council, I have no answer to give you for the simple reason that the position taken by the Portuguese Prime Minister, on behalf of the fourteen Heads of State and Government of the Member States of the European Union, took place at a bilateral level and not at that of the Presidency of the European Union. I would like to say, however, that the set of preventive actions that have been adopted on a strictly bilateral level by the Member States of the European Union concerns a set of actions of a nature, I would say, of political prophylaxis on a diplomatic level, which seems to us perfectly justified and which seems to us to be in line with what is reasonable in the face of the behavior of a party and of personalities in this party who do not seem to give the guarantees of being able to fulfill the aims of the Union, in the government of which it would be a part. I would not like to dwell on this question on behalf of the Presidency of the Union because this is an intervention that my government made at the request of and in collaboration with fourteen Member States and not as the Presidency of the European Union. Mr President, I have the honor of being part of the Convention that drafts the Charter, so I will not ask the Presidency to speculate on its content or whether it thinks that the Convention should be declaratory or whether it should have legal force. I would like to know what will happen to the draft charter that the Convention is currently drafting. Will the Council treat it as a document that it must accept as is, or will the Council consider itself free to amend this document? Will the Council simply say yes or no to this draft, or will it be in a position to rework this draft charter once again? The answer is neither yes nor no. I don't know, Mr. Deputy; it will depend on the decision taken at Council level. Question No. 8 of (H-0042/00): Subject: Granting of export credit guarantees and consequences for the construction of the Ilisu dam in Turkey. The G8 meeting in Cologne invited the OECD to initiate a process of establishing common standards in the area of granting export credit guarantees. Indeed, these guarantees can be used to distort competition and finance dubious projects. Will the European Union take the lead in launching this process? The need was demonstrated recently when the British government announced that it was "willing to grant" an export credit license to a company involved in the construction of the Ilisu Dam in Turkey.

It must be clear that subsidiarity applies, that is, it must be made clear that we will not legislate in areas where it is not necessary. The second problem concerns budgets. Given a growth rate higher than the 2.5% in the financial perspective, we can consider slightly different measures with regard to budgets than we would otherwise have done. On behalf of my group, I would like to warn the Commission against shifting agricultural spending from Category 1 to Category 4 at this stage. In Great Britain in particular, agriculture is in desperate straits and is desperately hoping for some support for certain parts of the sector. Shifting the appropriations earmarked for agriculture from one budget category to another would send out the wrong signals at this stage. Finally, a word of caution on the issue of information. This problem has strained relations between our Parliament and the previous Commission because, under the Treaties, we have, in principle, access and the right to access all information. It looks as if there may be difficulties with our framework agreement. I therefore stress that we must resolve this issue as soon as possible and that there must be no restrictions on documents accessible to citizens if we want the Commission and Parliament to work together. As Mr Bonde quite rightly stated, the aim is to create a European Union in which there is a free flow of information between administrative structures and all our citizens. President of the Commission, when you took office, you said that the Commission should be characterized by transparency. This has been mentioned several times today. But what is the situation now? Why are Commission press conferences no longer broadcast live by satellite so that everyone across Europe can follow them? I hope Mr Prodi is listening. Mr President Prodi, regarding your letter to Mrs Fontaine on the question of the Ombudsman, do you understand that the Ombudsman is bound by a principle of loyal cooperation between the institutions? Where do you find a legal basis for this in this case, and do you believe such a principle could suppress the Ombudsman's right to express himself freely to the press? Furthermore, with reference to your letter to the editor in the Wall Street Journal, I would like to raise the following fact. There, you refer to a seminar on transparency held in April as evidence that the regulation was drafted under transparent conditions. This seminar was organized by the European Federation of Journalists, Members Lööw, Thors, and Hautala, among others, but the proposal discussed there has nothing to do with the current one. The latter was drafted in complete secrecy. Above all, however, Mr. President of the Commission, the question arises as to whether the principle of sincere cooperation should take precedence over the principle of freedom of expression. What is the basis for such a principle that you could use to suppress this right and confront the Ombudsman with such demands? Mr. President, I will simply address some aspects of your very ambitious and comprehensive report.

Why should I not say that we have observed, on the part of the Greek Government, in recent years, a certain deficiency in the application of the new regulation and the previous regulation for the association of representatives of civil society. I say this objectively and when a problem or a deficiency is observed, this problem or this deficiency must be eliminated. Therefore, I will ensure this in the context of the implementation of the new Community support framework. I call Question No 45 of (H-0041/00): Subject: Structural Fund financing of research in the field of civil nuclear energy. Can the Commission confirm that in the last programming period of the Structural Funds 1994-1999, no support was allocated to research in the field of nuclear fusion and fission? Can it also undertake to exclude any measure of financing of this type of research in the current negotiations with the Member States on the plans and programmes for the new period 2000-2006? What role, however, will the contribution of the Structural Funds play in promoting renewable energy? Can we expect Structural Fund financing in the area of energy policy to be focused on promoting regional and renewable energy resources? Will the Structural Funds also finance major energy transmission networks? I would like to respond to Mrs Isler Béguin on the first point and remind her that improving the scientific base and technical capabilities of the regions in order to increase their competitiveness was one of the Community priorities during the previous programming period. The support allocated by the Structural Funds for technological cohesion, that is to say, research and technological development within the context of the Community support frameworks during this period, is estimated at approximately EUR 7.5 billion. This, Madam Deputy, is approximately 6% of the total Community contribution. Specifically regarding your concern, I would like to tell you that, as in the previous period, the Commission does not intend to directly finance research and technological development in the field of nuclear fusion or fission through the Structural Funds. It remains the responsibility of the Member States' managing authorities to select the projects that are implemented within the framework of these CSFs. Therefore, Madam Deputy, even if this is not a Community priority, a Member State may decide to finance research and development projects in the field of civil nuclear energy, provided that these projects contribute to regional development and without systematically informing the Commission. As regards your second point, which, as you know, interests me and continues to interest me greatly, renewable energies, the Commission's approach is presented in the document on the Structural Funds and their coordination with the Cohesion Fund. These provide that investments in the renewable energy sector should be encouraged to the extent that they promote the development of local resources, contribute to reducing dependence on energy imports and also create local jobs. I was able to verify this, for example, during a visit I made to Portugal a few days ago to the Azores, a natural source of renewable energy. The contribution of the structural funds, in favor of greater penetration of the renewable energy market, was also highlighted in the campaign for the take-off of renewable energy sources, launched by the Directorate-General for Transport and Energy.

Three issues still need to be addressed. The first concerns the transfer of water between catchment areas. This affects my colleagues in Spain, Ireland, and the United Kingdom. Amendments 4, 49, and 87 would be unacceptable because they would limit a country's ability to redistribute water from areas where it is abundant to areas in need, such as low-rainfall areas or cities. Second, while we must set targets, they must be realistic. A look at Amendment 7, which calls for the total elimination of naturally occurring substances, shows that some of the targets set are unrealistic. Furthermore, some of the targets envisage values close to zero—a formulation that makes little sense in English. We need to look at this in more detail. The term "continuous reduction" used in Amendment 58, on the other hand, is much better. Third, I would like to address the issue of Scotch whisky. The production of Scottish whisky, and especially malt whisky, the finest whisky, requires the extraction of considerable quantities of water, which are then returned to the river. Some of the water, however, ends up in the bottle and is drunk. We must ensure that Amendments Nos 49 and 87 do not revoke the exemption, so that it is still possible to enjoy high-quality whisky. In this context, this means that good Scottish peat water must be used. My third request, therefore, is that we examine these measures thoroughly before adopting the measure as a whole. Mr President, first of all, let us denounce the utter hypocrisy of those who claim to be dedicated to the environment and water, yet at the same time, through criminal acts such as the attack on Yugoslavia, have not only caused thousands of deaths and injuries, but have also caused enormous ecological devastation, including to water resources, thus rendering them not only unusable but even extremely harmful to health. As for the report itself, we believe that the application of the cost-recovery principle for water services must under no circumstances lead to additional taxation of economically weaker sections of the population, or even to the extinction of small and medium-sized farmers, who may then no longer be able to afford to irrigate their crops. We also point out that in regions with acute water shortages, such as my country, and particularly on the islands, water-saving infrastructure projects must be financed. This saving cannot be achieved by increasing costs, but by increasing quantities, particularly by collecting rainwater, which currently remains unused, flows into the sea, and causes soil erosion with all the resulting problems. In this respect, we support Amendment 107 by Mr Marset Campos. It is also necessary to ensure that life in regions with chronic water shortages is safeguarded through the optimal use of river water. The Council's assertion, which the Commission also endorses, that there is no need for many specific references and explanations because these points are covered by the examples in the directive or are included elsewhere, can only be understood as nitpicking. This is intended to continue operating in a rather opaque area, as it makes it possible to codify critical decisions in favor of big business during the initial implementation phase of the directive.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I need not repeat what the rapporteur has said, nor what Mr Coelho has already said. All of that is true and correct. The euro can easily be counterfeited. We are in a dangerous transitional phase in which, in criminal law terms, a phenomenon is occurring that is – I believe, perhaps unique in the history of the monetary system: that money that does not yet exist, that is not yet in circulation but exists only as book money, can nevertheless already be counterfeited. However, because it is not yet in circulation as currency, the crime of counterfeiting cannot yet take effect at that point. A very complicated problem. This means that if we do not act quickly – and Mrs Cederschiöld is right about this – we could already make a few counterfeit euros and possibly not be held accountable for putting them into circulation. For some, I would like to say in passing, this may be an attractive prospect. What is the European Union doing about it? Mrs Cederschiöld has described many correct things, but in connection with what she has described, Parliament must comment less on the content of the framework decision, and less on the report Mrs Cederschiöld has written on it, but rather on the procedures that are being applied. The European Parliament has been consulted by the Council, by far the most undemocratic institution in Europe, in a manner that mocks the very concept of democracy. We have been sent a text for consultation that the Council itself has been tinkering with for a very long time, only partially successfully, incidentally – I will come to that in a moment. The European Parliament is now expected to comment on this complex, difficult, and at times contradictory Council document within three months. It is only thanks to the tremendous commitment of Mrs Cederschiöld, and to the European Parliament's refusal to exercise its democratic right to conduct its consultation procedures in sufficient time and with all texts available in all languages, that we can now reach an opinion and thus the decision due in March within the timeframe requested by the Council. On such an important issue as counterfeiting or protection against counterfeiting, and the harmonisation of criminal law that is necessary for this, we cannot really work at the breakneck pace that the Council is demanding. Therefore, on behalf of my group, I want to make it absolutely clear here: We have discussed at length with Mrs Cederschiöld whether it makes sense to work in this way. We have concluded that it does not, but in view of the importance of the subject matter, we have agreed to accept the procedure as it is. This framework decision is without doubt a step forward. However, the legal certainty actually desired by the Council - as Mrs Cederschiöld has already explained - will not be fully achieved in the end, because these deficiencies have not been remedied in the desired minimum standards, the minimum standard of criminal liability and, above all, the application of the same criminal law provisions in all Member States - even in those that have not yet adopted the euro, but in which counterfeiting could theoretically occur.

Evidently, we are paying the price of our own carelessness because our countries, with the blessing of the Community, have deemed it appropriate to no longer have their own merchant fleet and have allowed a profound expertise in shipbuilding to disappear, we no longer have clear traceability of ships and we see real garbage ships plying our seas under flags of convenience, at the mercy of the short-term interests of multinational companies. We absolutely must put an end to the avalanche of irresponsibility, irresponsible charterers, untraceable shipowners, complacent classification societies. Today, the greatest confusion reigns. These issues obviously need to be addressed at a global level, but the current international rules of the IMO are completely insufficient and too lax. Neither our countries nor the Commission have tried tenaciously to make them more rigorous despite previous catastrophes. Of course, there is the International Oil Pollution Compensation Fund, the FIPOL, but it dilutes responsibilities and provides for ceilings at an insufficient level that needs to be reviewed. The issue of flags of convenience must be reviewed at the IMO. To this end, it is up to the Member States and the Community to take the necessary initiatives. I recall that the Erika was flying the flag of convenience of a State that is a candidate for membership in the European Union. On the other hand, there are Community directives that are, however, little or not at all applied due to the insufficient number of national controllers. This deficiency must be remedied urgently. A directive on maritime safety has been in preparation for many years but is progressing at a very slow pace. From this point of view, there is unacceptable inertia and unacceptable cowardice on the part of the Commission. The date for the presentation of the Commission communication on this essential problem has been continually postponed and is now scheduled for July but it must absolutely be brought forward. The provisions on the matter that need to be provided for must be clear and severe. I will mention three that our group considers to be priorities. First, the liability of the owners of the oil cargo must be clearly determined and the victims of pollution must be able to appeal to it without any ambiguity. For the future, the best prevention will be the certainty for charterers of a heavy civil, criminal and pecuniary sentence, if they are not sufficiently vigilant about the safety of the ships they choose. Second, it is necessary to impose as quickly as possible, without putting it off until the Greek calends, the condition of double hull for oil tankers allowed to sail in Community waters. Third, it is urgent to set a strict age limit for ships allowed to sail in Community waters: it could be 15 years at the most. In the absence of a sufficiently clear, severe and rigorous Community regulatory framework, Member States that wish to draw one up should be authorised to do so in order to protect their populations and their territory, just as the United States learned a lesson from the Exxon Valdez disaster by requiring double hulls and banning from their waters all ships over twenty years old. For this reason the United States had refused the Erika access to their waters.

To achieve the above objectives, both the resources and the policies of the new program financed by the Social Fund for the period 2002-2006 must be used, with the support of the Commission. The Commission will closely monitor the extent to which the Greek government fulfills the commitments it has entered into. I thank the Commissioner for her reply. But, Commissioner, the situation is this: in terms of unemployment, we rank second in Europe at 11.3%—it wasn't that bad before—we have the highest increase in unemployment figures and the lowest expenditure on the unemployed, namely less than 1% of GDP, while other countries (e.g., France, Belgium, and Germany) spend 3-4%. Furthermore, it is not clear how the resources provided by the Social Fund, among other things, to combat unemployment have been used. You mentioned that the Commission has issued some recommendations. That's all well and good, but we really hope that these recommendations will be followed up on. However, I have long been preoccupied with the following question: What happened with previous policies? Did anyone find work? How many obtained positions? If you cannot provide us with figures for the current year, then for last year or the year before last. What about training and continuing education? Are the infamous training centers intended to provide jobs for those who train there, or for those who are trained there? Is there any concrete data on this? Do we therefore have any means of monitoring the outcome of the Greek government's policies? Mr. Papayannakis, in response to your question, I can only say that the Greek government must indeed intensify its efforts to electronically record statistical data relating to existing structures so that the implemented programs also produce the quantitative results you mentioned, and so that the situation can be monitored and used as a basis for developing appropriate policies. In Greece, there has been an increase in the employment rate and—as far as I can see—productivity growth. The Commission can intervene where specific guidelines are concerned. As is well known, each country is assessed against 22 guidelines. These relate to access to training opportunities, broken down as a percentage for men and women, and special measures for the long-term unemployed. The Commission will endeavour to quantify the data for all the specific objectives and to arrive at concrete figures on the basis of the implementation of the new framework of Community action for the period 2000-2006. Question No 36 by (H-0782/99): Subject: Danish early retirement scheme. Can the Commission say whether the Danish early retirement scheme has been approved as a whole, and whether there are any differences of opinion between Denmark and the Commission in other social policy areas? Under the Danish pension system, Efterløn, only people residing in Denmark who have completed the required number of years of service in that country are entitled to a pension. Some workers have complained to the European Commission that they are not entitled to a pension. However, the Danish authorities consider that Community law does not oblige them to pay this compensation to workers in early retirement if they do not fulfil the conditions laid down in Danish law.

The sticking point in the negotiations with the Council lies, of course, in the amount of the financial envelope provided for the third stage of the LIFE programme (2000-2004). The Commission's proposal, endorsed by the Council, is for 613 million euros, while the Environment Committee believes that the budget should be 850 million euros. I support the rapporteur's firm position. Indeed, the financial allocation has not been adjusted since the creation of this programme, nor even during the transition to fifteen Member States following the enlargement of the EC. If the report is adopted in plenary, conciliation will have to be opened, as provided for by the codecision procedure, to resolve the question of the amount of appropriations provided for the programme. This type of procedure is common practice since programmes or legislative measures are too often allocated budgets that are inadequate to match their ambitions! Böge Report (A5-0023/2000) As a Member of the European Parliament, and especially as a citizen-consumer, I welcome the European Commission's proposal, which represents a further step towards greater food safety within the European Union. This proposal is twofold: firstly, it amends the 1991 Council Directive on animal health conditions by deleting the provisions concerning scrapie in sheep, and secondly, it introduces a new regulation laying down rules for the prevention and control of certain transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) or BSE-type diseases affecting sheep and other animal species. The advantage of this new legislation lies in the fact that it creates a specific legal basis for combating scrapie in sheep. I am all the more pleased as this was one of our main requests in our follow-up report on the mad cow crisis. It also seems to me essential, for the sake of consistency, to merge the existing legislation on scrapie, limited to trade in sheep and goats, into a single, comprehensive set of new rules governing TSEs affecting all animals throughout the European Union, rules designed to prevent the consumption of food or feed. This regulation is particularly welcome given that doubts still exist about scrapie in sheep. Some scientific hypotheses suggest that scrapie in sheep may have evolved to become BSE in cattle and thus be the cause of the BSE epidemic. Although the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention and control of certain TSEs needs to be clarified and strengthened, particularly with regard to the detection and control of scrapie, it represents a significant improvement. It is a pledge to European citizens who have repeatedly expressed their concerns about European food policy. Their concerns, relayed by our European Parliament, have been heard. Debates on the precautionary principle, traceability, responsibility, and transparency have led the European Commission to present a White Paper on food safety. This White Paper launches several avenues for reflection and, in particular, proposes the creation of an independent European Food Authority. All of this is part of a European strategy to regain consumer trust.

Mr President, I would like to sincerely thank Commissioner Patten for showing such awareness of the difficulties of the peace process and the challenge facing the European Union to make this process a reality. In the Middle East, it is truly time for peace; it is time to complete the historical phase that began with the Balford Declaration in 1917 and the Arab-Israeli War of 1948; it is time for every country in the region to have secure borders, for political, social and economic rights to exist, for human rights to be recognized and practiced in Syria, Palestine and Israel, everywhere. For every people and every individual, it is also a question of sovereignty and democracy, but for this to happen, it is essential that each party in conflict has the courage to promote peace and respect for rights, that it recognizes the other as a partner and not as a subject to whom concessions must be made. I am referring primarily to the Palestine-Israel nexus, but this also applies to the Golan Heights, occupied since 1967, and South Lebanon since 1982. Israel must assume its responsibilities, withdraw from the occupied territories and share water resources, but at the same time, it must be certain of its own security and be able to live in peace by practicing economic and political exchanges with all the countries in the region. Security, however, is not only a matter for Israel. This applies to other countries, first and foremost to the Palestinians who still live under military occupation and who, even today, despite the agreements signed since Oslo, see their land confiscated in Areas B and C. After Oslo and up until October 17, 1999, 174,000 dunans of land were confiscated, 8,462 of which were confiscated under the new Barak government: trees were uprooted, houses demolished again, and, especially in East Jerusalem, water use was reduced or even banned, while settlements continue and are constantly increasing. However, there is no doubt that the elections for the new government have made progress possible; at least negotiations are resuming. Nevertheless, in the Middle East, there can be no stable and lasting peace unless the Palestinians have their own state and can move freely within their territory. The international community simply needs to implement Resolutions 332, 248, 245, and 194. We are concerned about the postponement of relations with Syria, as well as Prime Minister Barak's decision to postpone the Israeli military withdrawal and the Sharm el-Sheikh agreements. We believe it is vital that the European Union play a political role in the negotiations equivalent to its role in economic aid. We cannot simply remain in the wings; on the contrary, we must be leading actors, without risking a collision with the United States, as Minister Gama said.

In fact, one gets the impression that they both believe that the Petersberg tasks will eventually be taken over by the Union's defense policy. The Treaties also point in this direction, but they leave even greater room for a more general defense policy that is closer to the old discourse on the integration of our policy into a European bloc. We would therefore express ourselves via this European bloc within NATO. To tell the truth, I hear less and less about this. I have the impression that the European Union has reduced its ambitions to the Petersberg tasks and that Mr. Patten is in charge of civil affairs, including the rapidly mobilizable police and civil service corps, which he rightly spoke about with enthusiasm, while Mr. Solana is in charge of military means and military engagement, all in a perfect spirit of cooperation. This seems self-evident to me. But is there really nothing else? In terms of defense policy, isn't the emphasis being placed on NATO's role in collective defense? The European bloc, which no longer functions as such, is limited to the Petersberg missions. Is that really what we want? There is also talk of the integration of the Western European Union into the European Union, but there is no longer any mention of Article V, which we are, of course, following very closely since it deals not only with Petersberg, but also with broader defense missions. Is that article being removed? There is also talk, generally speaking, of increasing defense budgets. I think that's a good thing, but no clear distinction is being made in this plea between the Petersberg missions and the broader collective defense missions. I wonder how the situation is developing. I would actually like to ask Mr. Patten and Mr. Solana how they ultimately see things. Is it necessary to pay greater attention to this at the IGC, or can this flow naturally from the Treaties? I am pleased that an opening has been created in terms of defense policy. But I wonder: what will happen if Turkey proposes a brigade? Will we have to allow this country to take part in decisions concerning this policy? Structurally, there are Haiders within the Turkish government. This seems strange to me. The Baltic states are also presenting themselves. Will they also participate in our defense policy? This is, to say the least, a very interesting situation. Mr. High Representative, you effectively recalled the progress made in this area between Amsterdam and Helsinki, as well as some of the decisions taken after Helsinki, such as the establishment of the three committees and the decision to create the contingent of 50,000 to 60,000 troops, decisions also taken recently, at the informal meeting in Sintra. This acceleration, however, makes the gap between these decisions and the current Intergovernmental Conference even more evident.

Of course, we must not lose sight of competitiveness, but social protection must be designed in such a way that it contributes to economic growth and employment. I believe this is also made clear in the report. Following the unanimous decision of the Council, our aim is to begin next year with coordination, exchanging views, recording social problems and setting up a database to improve policy coordination. I agree with many Members that a first important step has been taken. A broader approach to social policy issues will already be evident at the Intergovernmental Conference. We should now have entered a new phase in which social policy is to a large extent a European policy. Thank you, Mrs Diamantopoulou. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. WIPO Treaty The next item is the debate on recommendation (A5-0008/2000) by Mrs Cederschiöld, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, on the proposal for a Council decision on the approval, on behalf of the European Community, of the WIPO Copyright Treaty and the WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty (COM(1998) 249 - C5-0222/1999 - 1998/0141(AVC)). Mr President, we are taking a position here on an important issue: an international treaty in an area which can influence the development of prosperity in many Member States. In my home country, Sweden, for example, one of the largest export sectors is affected. This concerns music and sound recordings, and the right of artists to copyright protection for their artistic products. The subjects under discussion are the WCT (World Copyright Treaty) and the WPPT (World Performance and Phonograms Treaty). Without intellectual property protection, financial incentives and creativity are stifled. Counterfeiting has now become big business. In Europe alone, revenue losses of €4.5 billion are estimated due to piracy, a problem that also affects many jobs in the entertainment industry. This is a historic treaty because the European Union is one of the contracting parties, even though only the member states, not the EU as such, belong to the organization. There is a special clause requiring Parliament's consent in two cases. As far as this treaty is concerned, both conditions are met: a new institution, an "Assembly," is created, which will continue to deal with the treaty and its effects in the future. Furthermore, the treaty concerns issues that must be dealt with under the codecision procedure. Thus, Parliament must give its consent, as its competence is involved. Time will tell whether it is right to limit the Commission's competence in these matters through this new parliamentary assembly. In any case, Parliament cannot take any action in this regard at this time. The treaty complements the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary Works. It establishes international legal protection for distribution, sale, rental, communication to the public, and making available to the public, as well as protection for computer programs and databases. However, problems arise with the term "author," as this term, for example, is not defined. Another issue that could lead to complications is caching. The treaty contains a general clause for this, but it does not contain a definition.

When the United States and NATO, and ultimately also the EU, reacted, it was already late, very late. Much suffering could have been avoided, particularly if the EU had acted earlier and more clearly. The EU therefore has a special responsibility to assume when it comes to helping and assisting the Balkans in their reconstruction. Our priority objective must be to create the necessary conditions for all the countries of south-eastern Europe to be integrated, along with the others, into the EU – economically, commercially and politically. The best way to create the breeding ground for democracy in this war-ravaged part of Europe is through trade and economic integration. The members of the Liberal Group are prepared to act quickly and thoroughly, as Mr Paolo Costa said. That is why we welcome with the greatest satisfaction the proposal for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Macedonia that has been presented to us, and we thank Mr Swoboda for the high quality of his report. Macedonia deserves our support, especially considering the sacrifices and selfless work made by its people and leaders during the Kosovo war. As Macedonia struggles to extricate itself from the destructive trappings of communism and nationalism, it is incumbent upon us to act unequivocally and offer our support. And we must do the same for the other Balkan countries. This is an imperative duty for the EU. Mr President, allow me here to remind the members of this House – linking this to a topic we discussed earlier this evening – that the man who bears the primary responsibility for this war, for the violations of human dignity, for the murders and for the expulsion of innocent people from their homes, continues to rule what remains of Yugoslavia, namely Serbia. This man, who is accused of genocide and who is due to appear before the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague, is still at large. I am talking about Mr. Milosevic. As long as he remains in power and Serbia has not embarked on the path to democracy, this country will represent a threat to peace in the Balkans—including Macedonia. Mr. President, the proposed agreement will constitute the first application of the Stability Agreement in Southeastern Europe. It is obvious that the terms of this agreement, which the Swoboda report adopts, do not have peace as their objective but rather greater political and economic control of the country, the exploitation of its natural resources, the hyperexploitation of its labor potential, and the use, to a greater extent, of the country as a bridgehead against other countries and peoples in the region who resist the new order. And all this in exchange for the promise of future membership in the European Union. The report accepts these guidelines, as well as the European Union's broader policy towards Southeastern Europe. It is typical that the report congratulates FYROM for its constructive attitude during the NATO attack, praises its peacemaking role, and accepts the stationing of NATO forces on its territory. Naturally, the popular exasperation, manifested in mass movements during the NATO bombing, is ignored.

A lot. Mr President of the Commission, when reading your White Paper on the reform of the Commission, one cannot help but notice that the guiding principle, the idea underlying this reform, is something very trite, something we in this Parliament cannot accept. This guiding principle essentially consists in protecting the Community's financial interests. This is, of course, a concern for all of us, but it is only the starting point. The Commission must begin its work on this basis and fulfill its obligations under the Treaty. Let me give you an example, because I don't have much opportunity to explain this idea in the time allotted to me. Take the reform you mentioned in relation to infringement procedures. What is envisaged? Simply that it is a matter of managing the resources available at each level, rather than responding to this Parliament's demands for the creation of a genuine administrative procedural law for reasons of legal certainty, which is necessary from the point of view of the European citizen, that is, from the point of view of those who can initiate these infringement procedures. It is simply stated that this administrative procedural law is not created, but that the actions are selected. How? The way these things are selected is purely arbitrary. From the perspective of this Parliament, such conclusions cannot be accepted. We understand that the Commission must be reformed, we share the objectives of this reform, but of course not in such a way that, for the sake of an important interest that is in the interest of all of us—namely, the protection of the Community's financial interests—the great impetus for European construction is thrown overboard, an impetus that it is primarily the Commission's responsibility to provide, due to the obligations imposed on it by the Treaty. Thank you, Mr. Prodi, for your presentation and your documentation. Congratulations on making the internet available to the general public—a very good idea. I want to start with trade. We agree with you that we need a trading system subject to certain rules. That is what really matters. Seattle failed because the US, in particular, seemed unable to understand that measures such as environmental protection, the preservation of rural communities through the Common Agricultural Policy, animal welfare, health protection, and social rights represent legitimate concerns. They demonstrated an astonishing degree of lack of instinct with regard to the legitimate concerns of developing countries, and frankly, there is little for developing countries to be grateful to the WTO so far. We expect the European Union to continue the negotiations, maintaining our unwavering position on all these issues. At the same time, our contacts with developing countries must ensure that the next round is a fair one. Could we please have detailed proposals on how this can be achieved within the next three months? Innovation and knowledge—a theme appropriate to the new century. How much innovation has taken place in the Commission and, if I may say so, in Parliament? A few years ago, we had a White Paper on innovation—what has happened since then? One thing I would like to stress here is that we are concerned with follow-up action, not just with an excellent communication, which we welcome, but with follow-up action, follow-up action and more follow-up action!!!

I believe it is very serious, at the institutional level, to move toward replacing the collegial decisions required by the Treaty in the European Union with bilateral decisions between governments. I am not discussing the substance of the Austrian issue; I am discussing the serious precedent that could be set if the collegiality imposed by the Treaties is replaced by bilateral decisions: today against one country, tomorrow against another or other countries. That is the first issue. The second issue addresses the problem of the Employment Summit. I was convinced—not least because I attended the debates that led to the inclusion of employment issues on the agendas of the Council and the European Union—that the original intention of the Employment Summit was to combat the problems not of the new knowledge economy, but of the old European economy, the problems of unemployment that exist in factories, shipyards, metallurgy, and steel industries, and that these were the employment issues that were originally presented as the agenda of the Employment Summit. And so, it makes perfect sense to ask the question of whether, when we talk about the problems of the new knowledge economy, the new digital economy—which, as far as I know, has not yet created jobs in Europe—we are not replacing an inability to act on the problems of current unemployment with what is largely, and to this day, rhetoric about the employment problems of the future. No one understands more than all of us the decisive role that the internet, the digital economy, and the knowledge economy play, but those were not the original intentions of the Jobs Summit. The President of the Council concluded on a vaguely ideological note, and thank goodness so. If that is the Social Democratic policy for the economy of the future, I must remind him that one of the most serious problems relating to the internet economy and Europe's backwardness is the lack of entrepreneurial spirit embedded in the education system, in the actions of governments, in the functioning of institutions. And that is what we must fight against to guarantee the knowledge economy of the future. Mr. President of the Council, I would first like to welcome you to the European Parliament, particularly because your appearance symbolizes what the President of the Group of European Socialists has already said here, which is the political symbolism of having also come, in the midst of a tour of the capitals, to hear the European Parliament. This is not the first time, during the Portuguese Presidency, that there has been a different and politically stimulating relationship between the Council and Parliament, but it is, in fact, a significant gesture, as my colleague Barón Crespo has observed, and we are pleased to note it. Our position is clear: we support the Portuguese Government's initiative, because it is a serious initiative and because of its content, both in terms of its strategic objectives and other goals with which we identify.

They must also be pursued in the context of the bilateral and multilateral agreements being negotiated by the Community. While the communication reveals the Commission's valuable intentions in this sector, it also highlights the absence of certain activities and where improvements in control and management could be made. The communication can be quoted verbatim. Overexploitation is so intense in Community fisheries that scientific authorities have recommended a rapid reduction in exploitation levels by up to 40%. This appeared in the communication of last July. Since then, the Fisheries Council meeting on December 16 decided on drastic reductions in the total allowable catches of certain species such as cod and anchovy, which in the region amounted to 25% for cod and 43% for anchovy in 2000. Furthermore, the Commission adopted an emergency regulation for the recovery of Irish Sea cod, effectively establishing a halt to cod fishing in the Irish Sea between February 14 and April 13 due to the crisis affecting this species. These are examples of the serious problems facing the fishing sector caused by overexploitation. What can be done to alleviate the damage caused to fishing communities? The first consideration must be the recognition that Community legislation must be strengthened and control procedures improved. Secondly, the principles of Community legislation must be extended to international agreements to which the Community is a party. Thirdly, the European Union must act to improve the monitoring and prevention of existing pollution in Community waters that is harmful to marine life, including fishery resources. More controls must be introduced to prevent oil spills, as in the case of the Erika in the Bay of Biscay, and the intentional dumping of residual fuels. The pressure on the marine system due to the urbanization of coastal areas must also be recognized. This pressure is enormous in the case of Europe. In this context, we can also mention the problem of discarded unwanted catches, fishing gear that destroys the seabed, and the destruction of natural habitats due to over-intensive aquaculture. A quota management system like the one in place in New Zealand since 1986 is a possible alternative. Under this system, and given the total allowable catch, a market is created for individual fishing rights within a given area, which the holders of those rights can trade among themselves, use for fishing, or temporarily lease to other fishers. The property right created in such a system is the right to fish—not the fish itself. Such a market organization can yield better long-term prospects for the fishing industry. Dear colleagues, we currently cannot be fully informed about the vast ecosystem that is the sea, nor about the many factors that affect resource reserves in this marine system. However, we must not abandon scientific research, we must never stop gathering information, we must never stop exploring improvements to existing systems, and if necessary, we should at least consider changing policies.

As far as social protection is concerned, I can confirm that we have made proposals on qualified majority voting and unanimity voting without any ideological ulterior motive. In your country, Mr Bonde, as everywhere else, importance is attached to the smooth functioning of the internal market, to the fairest possible conditions for competition and the free movement of goods and persons. And this is what we are guided by. We are indeed proposing that certain policies or measures in the field of taxation, social protection, or social security be decided by qualified majority voting if they are directly related to the smooth functioning of the internal market. Our proposal is not general or universal in nature. I am well aware of the sensitivity of these issues of taxation and social protection. In my opinion, there is no need to standardise all national social security systems – that has never been the question – but simply to ensure the best possible conditions for the functioning of the internal market in a Europe of 30 or 27 countries, without any one state being able to block the other 26 or 27. Mr MacCormick, yes, I confirm to you that this dialogue will go well beyond the national capitals; it must reach people where they live, where their roots are. And if I were to say otherwise, I would be contradicting myself as the Commissioner responsible for regional policy, that is, one of the most concrete and visible policies, which serves to support employment and the quality of life of people in their region. I often say that this policy is not only pursued with the primary objective of cohesion and solidarity between regions, but also, as a complement, to ensure that people can preserve their roots, their soul and their identity where they live. We will therefore conduct this dialogue in the cities and regions. Mr Berthu, the Helsinki mandate is clear, and we are operating within that framework.
