It stipulates that we should first and foremost address the three fundamental issues that remained unresolved in Amsterdam. To these must be added the related institutional questions, and finally, the questions that the Portuguese and French Presidencies consider still necessary in the course of the negotiations. The Commission will act in accordance with its mandate if it considers it necessary to supplement its position on a wide range of institutional issues on one point or another. I am not yet sure whether this will be the case with Article 7, but if we do so, it will not only be in response to a specific situation, one so serious, however, that the fourteen governments of the Union jointly resolved to react, but we will also consider the future in general. Everything that can be done to definitively safeguard the community of values that we have formed together since the founding fathers established the Union in 1957, and even earlier since the end of the Second World War, is useful. I am sure, Mr Berthu, that we – you and I – can reach agreement at least on this basis.

The answer we received was always the same: "We cannot free him; he is a war criminal." Amidst the emotion, the pain, the passion, and the commitments, it was impossible to break the infernal cycle of bloodshed and revenge. If we want to help Cambodians in the task of reconciliation they have begun, it is necessary to try and condemn those responsible at the highest level and exonerate the simple perpetrators and all those who, whether forced or not, were dragged along by them. I hope for the creation of a tribunal, whose impartiality will be guaranteed by the United Nations, the trial and conviction of Ta Mok and his top officials. This will be the only way for Cambodians to forgive those who were mere followers and, thus, achieve lasting peace. Mr. President, this week it has been announced that two prominent Cambodian opposition newspapers have been threatened with closure for having insulted the King and the Prime Minister. These are two newspapers that actively support opposition politician Sam Rengie. Proceedings have been initiated against Sam Rengie to lift his parliamentary immunity so that he can be prosecuted for treason. The reason for this is that in his speech marking the new millennium, he dared to raise the issue of King Sihanouk's succession, demanding clarification of the procedure to be followed in the event of his death. Last March, a group of men in military uniform murdered one of Sam Rengie's party members in Kandal province. In September, two members of his party were arrested, alleging involvement in a missile attack against the Prime Minister. It should be noted that this is the only party in Cambodia without a military wing. In October, one of the parliamentarians from this same party was kidnapped by men in uniform and released for ransom. The pattern of intimidation is evident. There is more happening in Cambodia. Prisoners are tortured, the army and police are involved in the trafficking of women and children, and pretrial detention is abused. All of this is commonplace. However, the most serious aspect is that the government is resisting prosecution of the Khmer Rouge before an international tribunal. It is true that the civil war in Cambodia is over and political tensions have eased. Nevertheless, we are seriously concerned about the treatment of the political opposition. If this situation persists, it will inevitably have consequences for relations between the Union and Cambodia. Mr. President, within the framework of international law, a new doctrine is being shaped, according to which no State may treat its citizens or residents in any manner whatsoever, nor is the principle of national sovereignty a pretext to prevent other countries from intervening in cases of serious human rights violations, even when the State's leadership is legitimate or even democratically elected.

As for internal reform, you are aware of the commitment my Commission has made to this issue since day one. I am well aware that we will not be able to achieve any political objective unless this deep and comprehensive internal reform is carried out, unless the Commission becomes more effective in all sectors, starting with the one where we are most behind: external aid. Providing rapid aid where it is needed saves lives; providing late aid can sometimes be worse than not providing it at all. When I speak of external aid, I am thinking first of the Balkans, where we are seeing some encouraging signs thanks to the commitment of our officials on the ground, an extraordinary commitment given the organizational problems encountered. I am also thinking of the efforts made by Mr Kouchner, the Stability Pact, which we support energetically and with absolute dedication, but also of new developments, for example in Croatia, where the situation changed in a matter of weeks. The European institutions immediately opened the door to dialogue with this country; they welcomed these changes, knowing full well that the problems of Bosnia, and especially of Serbia, can only be resolved if democracy is established in Serbia. This is the new element that we must help spread throughout the Balkans. We must be more effective in this region; we must restore traffic on the Danube. It is pointless providing aid to Romania and Bulgaria and preventing these two countries from using their main resource. We must decontaminate the river. To this end, the Commissioner for the Environment will present specific plans in the coming days to control this serious problem. We have done a lot in the Balkans: our new European Reconstruction Agency for Kosovo, the Balkans Task Force, a new regulation to speed up procedures. However, we absolutely must do more. We must liberalize trade in the region, as well as trade between this region and the European Union. We must contribute to the establishment of infrastructural links that break centuries-old isolation. We must intensify efforts to build a democratic and pluralistic society in these countries, equipped with institutions, public structures, police forces, and the organization of civil society. But above all, we must encourage these countries to collaborate in a unified regional perspective, both politically and economically. If we do not do this, we will be failing in our duty. Remember the Marshall Plan; its effectiveness was not the result of its sheer resources alone; it was even more effective because it forced us, Europeans, to collaborate on a new perspective, to give a new horizon to our politics and our economy. This is what we must do for the Balkans. Europe must prove—from the Balkans to the rest of the world—its capacity to expand the area of security, peace, and freedom, its capacity to act on the international stage.

And I would point out, before I move on to my question, that what happens within the framework of the Staff Regulations within the Commission plays a fundamental role in terms of our responsibilities also as employers, because, of course, the staff of the European Parliament work under the same conditions. This will be part of the work that we will have to do, and I am convinced that you will all want to engage in this process today. Well, I would like to follow up on two points with Mr. Kinnock, if you will allow me. The first concerns the timing of these important reforms. Mr. Prodi said in his very important opening speech that he had identified serious problems within the Commission relating to low morale and low motivation, which is clearly a major concern. There are high expectations of these reforms, both within the Commission and outside. And if we want to move forward, I would say that personnel reforms, which are early evidence of a change in culture, that empowerment and motivation of staff must be carried out as soon as possible. And according to the original proposals - and I have the impression that the new ones will not differ in this respect - the general reform of the civil service regulations would not have been completed until 2002. Moreover, some of the fundamental elements would not have been introduced until 2001. I think that is too long a timeframe, and we really need to move much faster than that. The second point I want to raise concerns information technology. Have you really taken into consideration the changes that new information technology will bring to the staff structure, because they will be fundamental to the new direction of these reforms? As for the second part of Mr Harbour's question, he will find that, in the course of this year, we will demonstrate with greater precision how the wider application of information technology will facilitate change, not only in terms of staff working practices and conditions but also in the functioning of the Commission, as the President briefly outlined in his statement. Let me thank Mr Harbour for his energetic commitment to the subject for which he is rapporteur and respond by saying that we firmly believe that the morale, motivation and professional commitment of Commission officials, which are already very high, will be improved by the introduction of comprehensive training, by the allocation of responsibilities, by improved management and by a number of other changes that will be introduced. Cultures are the products of structures and systems, and structures and systems have become old. By renovating them, sometimes in a very radical way, we will help those in the Commission who are resolutely pursuing the European ideal and whose abilities are very high, to express their talents and to make them manifest as they have never done before. I would like to make one final remark in response to Mr Harbour.

Finally, I would like to add that I had my doubts during last week's debate on the formation of a government in Austria. However, I have no reservations about discussing and criticizing Austria's asylum policy. I hope this plenary will be just as committed to this. Mr President, during the last financial perspective for the period 1994-1999, with its total of 13 different initiatives, the cross-border INTERREG II initiative was given great importance. The fact that the INTERREG initiative is included in the next round of Structural Funds for the period 2000-2006 is, in my view, clear evidence of the importance attached to it by the EU Member States. The INTERREG I programme from 1989-1993 and the INTERREG II programme from 1994-1999 have proven to be outstanding successes in terms of convergence in social and economic development between neighboring Member States. In my home region, the border counties in northwest Ireland, I have been able to observe the important role played by INTERREG I and II over the past few years, and I therefore look forward to INTERREG III with great joy. The Commission has allocated 67 million pounds for the INTERREG III programme to continue developing economic projects for communities on both sides of the border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The European Union has played a key role in the development of these border regions over the years. With its 80 million pound contribution to the International Fund for Ireland, the EU is the largest single funder, and it also provides 75% of the funding for the Peace and Reconciliation Support Programme. All in all, INTERREG, the International Fund for Ireland, and the Peace and Reconciliation Programme have each made a decisive contribution to advancing the peace process. Mr President, I will limit my remarks on INTERREG to a few critical aspects, also in order to keep within the time available to me. We supported the relaunch of this program and the expansion of the areas of intervention, not only in the area of cross-border cooperation, but also in the context of transnational and interregional cooperation. Nevertheless, we are aware that the largest share of resources—between 50 and 80%—will be reserved for cross-border cooperation, that is, for Strand A of the INTERREG III program. Therefore, we continue to believe that the decision to consolidate the current cooperation areas in this Strand is wrong and inconsistent with regard to the selection of eligible regions. We hope and wish that the Commission will address this, that it will accept Parliament's position in substance and not merely give it formal recognition. Cross-border cooperation continues to relate almost exclusively to continental borders, and in cases where exceptions have been made with regard to maritime borders, the relevant decisions are not transparent and often involve balancing other areas of Community policy. The island regions, which live in a regional situation inevitably linked to purely maritime borders, are particularly disadvantaged. This constitutes a continuing discrimination that ignores the content of Article 158 of the Treaty, which mentions islands in the context of policies to strengthen economic and social cohesion.

We understand that collaboration and joint work by the two institutions—Parliament and the Commission—are important, and that the collaboration that exists with the Committee on Regional Policy, and specifically with the Transport Group, is magnificent. The common position includes practically all the amendments accepted by the Commission, harmonizes the minimum requirements for the examinations of security advisers, and, at second reading, we can accept the amendment on the proposed date, which is much more realistic than the one initially proposed by the Commission, given that we have been debating this issue for several years. Very briefly, I would also like to thank the various Members for their interventions and tell the Honourable Members that security is a priority for the Commission in the field of transport. And as Mr. Simpson rightly said, the process can never be taken for granted, assumed, or completed. The process of increasing margins and security guarantees in transport is a process that must be improved day by day. In this regard, I would also like to briefly address the problems of tunnels, mentioned by Mr. Rack and Mr. Swoboda. This is undoubtedly a very sensitive issue in Austria, so efforts must be made to see how to increase safety. In one of the major accidents that occurred recently, the cargo transported was not in itself dangerous. The margarine and a few kilos of paint, which, in principle, posed no risk, caused a real catastrophe. Therefore, we must see how to further refine the requirements to ensure maximum safety. Finally, I would like to say that safety must be considered in all modes of transport. This week we will hold a debate here to discuss the safety of maritime transport, due to the Erika disaster, and we will have to discuss, throughout this year, the safety objectives for air transport. But I would like to say, ladies and gentlemen, that safety is a priority objective of the Commission. As I will say in the debate on the Erika, we do not wait for a catastrophe to focus on the safety aspect; rather, we work on it regardless of those circumstances, which only serve to highlight the urgency of an effective response to these types of problems. I would like to reiterate my thanks to all those who have spoken, and especially to the rapporteur, Mr. Koch. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12:00. Transport of dangerous goods by road The next item is the report (A5-0104/1999) by Mr Koch, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, on a proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council (COM(1999) 158 - C5-0004/1999 - 1999/0083(COD)) amending Directive 94/55/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States with regard to the transport of dangerous goods by road.

I would like to thank Commissioner Patten who, despite the short notice, was willing to participate in today's debate and answer our questions on the extremely critical situation in Mozambique. As other speakers have said, the television images from the Limpopo Valley have left us absolutely breathless: we have seen children who have lost their parents and helpless and hopeless families who have lost everything. As has already been said, this was predictable and had been foreseen, and the fact that the response to the disaster is slow and inadequate - shamefully slow and inadequate - should make us realise that a major investment is needed in preparing a response to such disasters. As the Commissioner has said, we need to put in place a mechanism and a rapid response force that, in situations like this, will enable us to deal with crises that have arisen only because we did not apply the right strategies or did not make the necessary logistical preparations. This morning there were seven helicopters in the air, all concentrated in the Gaza region alone. The Save River is also at high risk of flooding, but no one has been there yet. 85 percent of the relief operations are taking place within an hour's drive from Maputu, so they are not in a position to assess the scale of the problem. I would like to point out to the Commissioner that European citizens want to know exactly what ECHO is doing. Most of us would not want to stop at €3 million; it will take much more, and I hope the Commissioner can come back with a promise of more money and an initiative that can coordinate our efforts. Clearly, a large airlift will have to be set up. As has been said, there is a need for a large amount of food, water purification equipment, tents and blankets. I wonder whether we are ready to take on the next phase of relief and reconstruction that has been talked about, as this phase will also require a lot of resources. Are we ready to provide the necessary financial coverage? Mozambique is one of the poorest countries in the world, but it is also one of the most successful in Africa. The country has worked hard to promote economic growth, poverty reduction and democracy, despite the enormous pressure of public debt. Mozambique is a model country, but it will most likely face a period of great difficulty because of what it has suffered. We should now try to understand how much the catastrophe will cost Mozambique, and that will depend entirely on the quantity and quality of international aid that is provided. Thank you very much, Mrs Kinnock. Mr Nogueira, we note your interest and concern in this matter, but your group is not registered to speak in the debate and I will abide by the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. Economy of the Union (1999) The next item is the debate on the report (A5-0041/2000) by Mr Katiforis, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Commission document entitled 'The 1999 Economy Review of the European Union' (C5-0081/2000 - 2000/2046(COS)). The Commission's report presents an assessment of the current European economic situation which it finds promising, particularly in relation to the recent recovery in economic growth which should lead to a reduction in unemployment to 8% by 2001.

It's worrying that the bombing has worsened the situation, and it should be acknowledged that NATO and the European Union were wrong to take this measure. The Minister has rightly spoken—I agree—about Belgrade's guilt, but we must also remember that the secret services of the United States, Germany, France, Italy, and Great Britain have been supplying arms and money to the KLA, to a mafia, to contribute to the problems in that area. Therefore, we are all to blame. I wanted to ask you a complementary question, given the global context. Don't you think it would be beneficial to lift the blockade on Serbia to achieve greater economic normality in the area and also benefit Kosovo as a province of Serbia? Mr. President, I am no friend of Milosevic or his government, but I have very deep doubts about the legitimacy of NATO's action against Yugoslavia over Kosovo, both because of the lack of authority of the United Nations Security Council and because I believe that what happened could have been avoided if unacceptable terms for Serbian sovereignty had not been imposed at Rambouillet. The current situation in Kosovo, which has now been ethnically cleansed of Serbs and Roma, corroborates what I have said. I believe that the least NATO should do is acknowledge its guilt for the deliberate attack on the Belgrade television tower, in which more than 20 civilian journalists were killed. This constitutes a grave moral blemish on the conduct of the war and now opens the embarrassing possibility that our Western leaders will be accused of war crimes. Your Honor, we do not, at the level of the positions adopted by the European Union, have a selective interpretation and analysis of military objectives, particularly of the initiatives taken against certain types of infrastructure that supported Mr. Milosevic's political and propaganda system. Therefore, I cannot tell you whether or not we agreed with a specific action carried out by NATO. It is part of a global plan on which we agree. Some of these actions could be debatable, and some were considered regrettable even by NATO itself. Others will be justifiable for tactical reasons, in the sense of preventing Mr. Milosevic from continuing his internal propaganda campaign. In any case, I, on behalf of the Council, do not wish to make any value judgments regarding any specific action carried out by NATO in the military sphere. Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, given that I am familiar with the history of the Balkans, I would like to remind you that for many decades the peoples of Yugoslavia lived peacefully. The destabilization began, approximately a decade ago, with the dissolution of Yugoslavia, a process in which the European Union played a decisive role. Yugoslavia's crime was that it was the only Balkan country that had not applied to join either NATO or the European Union. And so, what remained standing after the air raids is now being destroyed by the supposedly disarmed KFOR, right under the noses of KFOR, whose role as an occupying force is becoming increasingly evident.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether this principle is actually applicable and whether we will receive any compensation from the individuals mentioned. The second question relates to the Commission's announced White Paper on environmental liability, which is intended to ensure that the polluter pays principle applies in the future and that we have a better opportunity to implement European environmental legislation accordingly. The White Paper acknowledges that the polluter can only be held liable once they have been identified, if the damage is quantifiable, and if a causal link has been proven beyond doubt. The Erika wreck is a prime example; it is precisely what the White Paper is about that happened here. It can therefore become a benchmark for how to deal with problems of this nature in the future. The proposed directive provides for strict liability for damage resulting from dangerous activities regulated by the EU. My concern, and perhaps the Commissioner can comment on this, is whether the White Paper on environmental liability is actually the appropriate means to deal with problems of the magnitude of the Erika wreck. Will it truly meet the requirements, or will the perpetrator of shipping accidents on the high seas continue to escape without having to pay for the damage? Mr President, we would like to express our sympathy and solidarity with the people and regions affected by the disaster. Good intentions alone are not enough; compensation must be provided for the damage and the losses must be made good, both in terms of environmental restoration and in terms of shellfish farms and fishing equipment. We welcome the Commissioner's statement that it is necessary to act and compensate swiftly and retroactively. We also criticize the lax inspection of ships and support the creation of a European coastguard and, in particular, the call for stricter legal requirements and for ships with double hulls. We continue to denounce the practice of flags of convenience for both merchant ships and fishing vessels. We are also shocked that the cargo was highly carcinogenic due to the polyaromatic hydrocarbon content of over 1000 ppm. This means that among the 15,000 tons of oil that entered the sea, 15 tons were highly toxic products. This is unacceptable. Moreover, we learned of this too late, so medical check-ups are now necessary, particularly for the volunteers who worked so hard to restore the environment. We believe that special attention must be paid to the prevention of such risks and to scientific research to prevent and repair damage. Numerous proposals have been made that should be examined. Solutions to disasters are not found at the last minute; action must primarily be taken in advance. Mr. President, more than two months after the Erika wreck, the coastal areas that had already been cleaned up are still being polluted. I would like to once again express my solidarity with the victims and pay tribute to the great dedication of the volunteers and professionals who are still working to clean the polluted beaches. As a result of the local mobilisation, which our House championed by holding a debate and adopting a resolution on 20 February, an initial package of measures has been announced.

In 80 percent of the market subject to free competition, prices have fallen. This shows that competition really works. My conclusion is: ensure competition in the other 20 percent! In light of these facts, more and more are demanding... (The speaker is interrupted by Markov) I thought I was the one who had the floor. Perhaps we can discuss this a little later. However, I note that it is precisely as I stated, namely, that prices have fallen in sectors where there is competition and have risen where there is a monopoly. This is how it almost always works. I therefore recommend the formation of a committee to take the necessary initiatives and ensure competition in the postal sector. Mr. Markov, you will have a few minutes in five or six minutes. I would appreciate it if you did not interrupt your colleagues. Mr. President, there is a mystery here. What happened to the Postal Services Directive that was adopted on 15 December 1997? The Commission has maintained a deafening silence during the intervening period. I am sorry that it is Commissioner Monti who is here today. I hold him in high esteem. He is one of the most diligent and hardworking Commissioners. I regret that I cannot say the same about some of his colleagues. During this time, there has been no real progress on the Postal Services Directive. Commissioner Monti stated that this is partly due to the organization and redistribution of functions. This was not done until recently. For more than a year, the former Commission could have worked on the issue. The truth is, we have not made much progress. However, since Commissioner Monti is here, I would like him to convey a message to Commissioner Bolkestein telling him what the Postal Services Directive was about. It was about gradual liberalization; it was about a guaranteed universal service at an affordable price; it was about direct mail and cross-border mail remaining in the reserved sector. These issues were fundamental in that report and should remain so in any future directive. The postal service is not just for Christmas. It is for life. In the part of Scotland where I come from, it is much more than just a postal service. It is a means of keeping communities together. The postal service is also the bus service. The postal service is also the social service. The postal service is also the medical service. If we allow postal services to drift towards complete privatization, then we will lose all of that, and many of our local communities—we voted on tourism earlier—will lose their tourism activity. We will isolate them. Postal services are important. This message must go out from here today. And the Commission must listen to it. Mr. President, we support the liberalization of postal services in the Union. This means, above all, that customers will have a better service. This is what is intended, and this must be the ultimate goal.

The Financial Regulation is the legal framework for implementing the priorities set out in accession cooperation with Malta and Cyprus. I cannot begin until we have it, as I lack the legal basis. If the alleged lack of coherence has anything to do with this point, I must say that this regulation is merely a legal framework and nothing more. Compliance with this legal framework can be found in the accession cooperation priorities agreed upon last year by the Commission and the Council, which are now being implemented in the corresponding programming and project management. I would say that there are many areas in European policy where one can complain of a lack of coherence, but in this case, I commend the Commission and the Council for developing a very clear and coherent policy. (DE) Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, after the Commissioner has explained to us in an extraordinarily coherent manner that the lack of consistency was due to the responsibilities of the former President of the Council and his Minister for Europe, could you perhaps help us and the Commissioner so that this resolution can be adopted? A very helpful solution would be if you could respond positively to my questions on the financial projections up to 2004 and on Category 7, or at least if you could say that the Portuguese Presidency of the Council intends to compensate for the lack of consistency at that time by making an effort such as the one described, just as the Commissioner will also try to achieve in the Commission. Mr. President, I believe that the question raised by the honourable Member and my friend Elmar Brok will be examined by the Council. I believe that the criticism made of the previous Presidency is irrelevant. I consider that what the previous Presidency did in formulating the financial perspectives was excellent work, regardless of who was involved in it. In any case, the issue you raise is important, and we, at the Council level, will not fail to support the Commission's proposals in this regard. Mr. President of the Council, I understand; Mr. Brok was referring to an even longer Presidency. Mr. President, I asked Commissioner Verheugen a specific question about the Meda financing instrument, to which he has not responded. I ask you to do so, as your response also determines the voting behavior on various amendments submitted to us. Dear Mr. Poos, I beg your pardon. Precisely where you posed the question, there was an unclear aspect. In the case of Meda, the situation is such that Malta and Cyprus can participate in the supraregional programs, but not in the country-specific programs because the revenues are too high. Thank you very much, Commissioner Verheugen. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday.

It should also be noted that, once again, the Commission is effectively avoiding the issue of concrete action in the area of equal opportunities. In conclusion, we are faced with a document that is not particularly satisfactory and, in some respects, disappointing. Berend report (A5-0107/1999) We agree, in essence, with the rapporteur's assessment and considerations regarding the sixth periodic report on the social and economic situation and development of the regions of the European Union. We will therefore confine ourselves to highlighting certain aspects only. Firstly, as the Commission itself says, the fact that the GDP per capita of some of the poorest regions increased significantly between 1991 and 1996 is due to a large extent to the inclusion of the new German Länder in the calculations of the Community average, starting precisely from the first year. This fact is obviously the cause of a significant reduction in the level of GDP per capita in the Union. Secondly, it is particularly important for us to note that the recovery of some regions - where it has taken place - has been accompanied by a minimal increase in employment, which therefore requires new development strategies, with major concern for this area. This situation contradicts the slow adoption of employment promotion measures reserved exclusively for the internal policy of the Member States, as the report does. Last but not least, we would mention the rapporteur's proposal to include in future in this type of report, among other aspects, an analysis of the interregional evolution of cohesion in each State. The multiplicity of situations and the differentiated evolution from one region to another, within the same State, in fact require a thorough evaluation of this issue in order to allow and guarantee the correction of regional (and other) policies in order to ensure cohesion also at the internal level of each Member State. Given the employment situation in the Community and the European Union's stated ambition to tackle unemployment resolutely, the Commission's analysis of mergers should take into account factors other than competition. I take as an example the restructuring of the ABB-Alsthom Power company, for which a large delegation of employees from across Europe is present in Strasbourg today. The management of ABB-Alsthom Power, which resulted from a merger carried out in June 1999, announced a restructuring with the prospect of job cuts already in a number of countries. This situation, which is detrimental to employment, raises many questions, particularly regarding the information given to the European Works Council, which has existed since 1996. This implies updating and strengthening the Community directive on European Works Councils. It also implies merger control that takes employment, the environment, and consumers into consideration. Since the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is insufficient from this point of view, I abstained. By claiming to apply the principle of subsidiarity at the level of European competition policy, the Commission is decentralising responsibility for decisions and abuses of dominant positions in relation to company agreements that create distortions in the market to national authorities and courts, although issues of concentration of companies and state aid remain within the notification regime.

The European Union and its Member States must set an example and contribute a significant portion of these funds. By doing so, we would not only embarrass the United States in terms of fulfilling its financial responsibilities regarding the financing of the United Nations, but we would also demonstrate that our commitment to defending human rights is more than just rhetoric. Mr. President, this debate aims to prepare for the next annual session of the United Nations on human rights and the actions of the Commission and the Council therein. First of all, let me say that I am very pleased with what Mr. Patten and the Minister have said so far, and I think it is right that both China and Cuba are being discussed. Cuba remains the last dictatorship in South America, and we cannot forget that, despite all the sympathy Cuba arouses in some circles. It is a dictatorship and, therefore, not a democracy. I would like to draw attention during my two minutes to two countries with which I have a special bond. First, Indonesia. Of course, we are very pleased that Indonesia has a new government and that Mr. Wahid and Mrs. Sukarnoputri are serving as president and vice-president, respectively. We are also pleased that the situation in Timor is gradually moving in the right direction. However, I inform you that the violence is not yet under control in the Moluccas, a territory located north of Timor. Thousands have died in the last two years. Tens of thousands of people have fled. The situation is not well controlled. I know that tomorrow or the day after tomorrow there will be an important program on Dutch television urging the dispatch of observers, simply to examine precisely what is happening there, so that, in any case, what is happening is recorded, also with a view to the human rights commissions later on. My urgent request is, and this is something we have included in resolutions on various occasions, that we negotiate the dispatch of observers to the Moluccas. The thousands of dead, thousands of wounded, tens of thousands of refugees are enough. My second country—and I want to be very brief, since Mr. Patten knows it very well—is Burma. It is unacceptable that we do not speak out about this country. I have the impression that Burma has been gradually forgotten. The elected president has been under house arrest for ten years now. Parliament has not functioned for ten years now. Countless parliamentarians have been killed or fled, and only a handful still live in Burma. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have left Burma for Thailand or India, yet it seems that no attention is being paid to that country anymore. I think this country should be put back on the agenda, especially given the change that has taken place in Indonesia.

It is a fact that a new agreement has been concluded with the ACP countries. In itself, this is a positive development, particularly considering the pressures aimed at terminating it and the fact that several Member States were even opposed to continuing it. In due course, we will have the opportunity to analyze more deeply the exact terms under which this agreement was established. However, there is no doubt that the European negotiators were more timid and fell short of the proposals we made at the time, even though the new agreement contains new and innovative elements. And some politically important features of the new association agreement will have contributed to this. This was undoubtedly the result of a complex negotiation in which both parties made substantial concessions, as is true in the case of the European Union, particularly in the areas of good administration and trade. But it was above all the result of a strengthening of the ACP group, which clearly found a new spirit in the wake of what happened in Seattle. I would like to emphasize in particular that a new way of looking at these issues seems to be emerging, particularly in the area of trade, so a new approach in this regard is very necessary. Finally, it is necessary to go further in policies to support the development of developing countries. At the financial and budgetary levels, in the level of debt, in support for sensitive areas such as food and humanitarian security, education and health, and also in the environmental, investment, or access to information and new technologies, as well as in the area of trade, while ensuring full coherence of development policies with other Community policies and also between them and the corresponding policies implemented by the Member States. We cannot be content with essentially continuing something that has proved insufficient and flawed in the past. Mr. President, after listening to the Commission and the Council today, I simply had to take a look at my agenda. Yes, it does indeed appear there: "Coherence of the various Union policies with development policy." However, we have not heard a single word about it, and I find it extremely shameful. We have been waiting for a report on coherence for years. It should have been presented in writing here today, and having heard Mr. Nielson's speech, I can easily imagine that he has encountered very powerful opposing forces within the Commission. I know that the Commissioner himself holds views that are both solid and extremely sensible regarding coherence, and I would have liked to hear them here today. Since the joint motion for a resolution sets out some effective mechanisms for ensuring coherence, I would like to limit myself, in the very short time I have, to mentioning another: the obligation for the Commission to also carry out an assessment of relevant new legislation in this regard. And, incidentally, I would also like to focus on the catastrophic effect that the EU's common agricultural policy has had on developing countries. Dumping beef into the sea in the Sahel and South Africa, tomato paste in West Africa, powdered milk in Jamaica—hopefully, all these examples are well known.

How do we implement what is laid down in relatively great detail in the treaties regarding development aid programs? Several Members, Mr. Ferber and Mr. Cushnahan, spoke about the gap between Sunday speeches and reality. Mr. Cashman pointed out that words cannot replace actions, which is quite true in a way. Of course, words can achieve something, as Mrs. Malmström said. She explained that she had received a letter from the Chinese ambassador, an extremely amiable and highly intelligent representative and servant of his country, in which he told her that she was mistaken and that the European Parliament was wrong in its stance on the issue of human rights in China. I expect that Mrs. Malmström will receive a flood of letters from the Chinese authorities after her speech today. She will then be able to fill an entire filing cabinet with letters about the supposedly real situation in China. She has expressed the viewpoint of many non-governmental organizations, as well as many people who admire Chinese civilization but are concerned about current events in China. It is entirely right to consider what we can do. In his first speech, Mr Salafranca mentioned two areas in which action is being taken, apart from the Geneva meeting. One of these measures has been made possible by the generosity of the European Parliament, on behalf of European taxpayers: the budget available to us for strengthening human rights, which includes some EUR 100 million for the programs for which I am responsible. Most of this money will be allocated to non-governmental organizations, where it will be used to promote human rights and the democratization process. We will discuss with Parliament how best to design and direct these expenditure-intensive programs to promote human rights in the coming years. There is also the issue raised by Mr Salafranca, who, unfortunately, cannot be here at the end of this short but useful debate. It also concerns our human rights policy in general and the relationship between human rights and foreign policy. I would like to remind Parliament that by the middle of the year the Commission will have presented a comprehensive and theoretically sound explanation of why human rights should be placed at the heart of development policy and the Common Foreign and Security Policy. This is of the utmost importance, and if I had not already been convinced of it, I would certainly have come to this conclusion after today's remarkable speech by Mr Havel. This debate has been very useful. I hope there will be more debates like this one. I would welcome, in particular, a discussion about how we can put these good intentions into practice where it matters, where people are still being tortured and raped, and where people are still being denied their civil rights, which this House, like me, takes for granted. I have received seven motions for resolutions, pursuant to Rule 37(2), to conclude this statement. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday. Cyprus and Malta. The next item is the joint debate on:

The issue is very important and I would like to know, given that we could talk about a "baby scam", whether the Commissioner will ensure that those funds are not taken away from the Andalusians, so that the funding that the European Union allocates to Andalusia, based on the census criterion, takes into account those 400,000 children that Aznar does not take into account when it comes to providing them with schools and services. Honourable Member, I ask everyone, do not take this as a call to order, to deal with purely community issues. I realise that for Spain these are very important issues on which opinions differ... I would like to point out to the Commissioner that Aznar is the Prime Minister of the Spanish Government. Please, can you answer the question. Honourable Member, given that I have heard that you have a voice, I hope that your voice is strong enough to be heard in Madrid. In any case, I understand that your comments were not addressed to me directly. I have answered you. I am concerned that the Structural Funds, particularly those under Objective 1, are allocated where they are needed. We have criteria to apply and we know approximately how much each region of Europe should or could receive. This does not mean that I do not hide behind it, but I am always required to refer to the general regulation, that I must discuss with the national authorities of each country and with the government of each country. It is up to them to proceed with the most objective and fair distribution possible. I still need to know, which is why I told you that I am not in a position to answer today. Since I do not have the answer, I wrote to the Ministry of Economy and Finance on 14 December. I am now impatient for the answer and when I do, I will send it to you. I regret that the Commissioner has once again been involved in an imaginative, and in this case impassioned, intervention. I want to remind everyone that in Spain we are not in an election period, we are only 25 days away from the elections. It is a consolation for the Commissioner that the call to the polls will be held in 25 days, because after that he will probably no longer have to hear this type of question. I think it is important to state that Andalusia, within the Community, will receive 50% more and that Spain has a record in the implementation of the Structural Funds, which means that the distribution is strictly based on the implementing regulations and is decentralised through the regional development plans and the various Community support frameworks. Finally, I would like to ask you a specific question, Commissioner: do you think it is necessary to amend the implementing regulations for the Structural Funds or do you consider the current distribution criteria acceptable? I find this debate fascinating. I realise that it has a dimension that is not exclusively Community-wide. Having said that, we must accept the idea that elections are continually being held in all the countries of the Union. I am pleased that the Structural Funds in Greece and Spain are finally being discussed. Just a moment ago, in this Chamber, we were talking about civic debates, about public debates.

We find ourselves in a historic situation in which negotiations are being conducted or are about to begin with 12 states, and now we are together in a situation in which the unification of Europe can become a reality within a foreseeable period of time. But how is the Union to be enlarged if we do not get down to business now – that is, before enlargement actually takes place? That is why we as a group are in favour of the Intergovernmental Conference. We consider it indispensable and urgent and hope that it will indeed produce the results that will make an early enlargement of the European Union possible. My group, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, has noted with satisfaction that the Council Presidency is not satisfied with the current situation. You can therefore be assured that the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left will also work to ensure that the Union finally does its homework. It is about nothing more and nothing less than the future of Europe, and above all, it is about a Europe that citizens truly see as their own, because they can help shape it and because the worries and needs, the problems and questions that concern them every day, are taken seriously by politicians. Closed-door policies, secretive discussions – all of this must be a thing of the past once and for all. That is why transparency is necessary. I believe that you, as the Council Presidency, should ensure that the train does not continue to roll along as before and that people are not left on the platforms like treaty illiterates. We consider it essential not only that everything is done to comprehensively inform citizens about the course and results of the Intergovernmental Conference, but that they must also be directly involved in the entire reform process. We also believe that political decision-makers must finally overcome their fears and, after the conclusion of the Intergovernmental Conference, ask citizens in referendums whether they agree with how their Europe will develop in the future. In this way, we would truly have a Europe of citizens, and we would truly have a completely new quality of democratic legitimacy for the Union. I want to clearly address another central democratic issue. As a member of the Convention, which has now begun its work on the Charter of Fundamental Rights, I want to make it clear: For me and my group, a solemn proclamation of the Charter is not enough. What will citizens say if their rights are solemnly proclaimed to them, but they cannot enforce them individually? No, I think that would only further deepen the Union's credibility crisis. The low turnout in the European elections should really be alarm signal enough for everyone. What we need are rights visible to everyone; the Charter of Fundamental Rights must become legally binding for all people living in the Union, for all its citizens. We should work together toward this goal in the interest of the citizens, and I expect the Intergovernmental Conference to revise the Cologne decision on this matter at the end of the year. Of course, it is also about the efficiency of decisions and functioning institutions in a Union of 27 or more Member States.

How do you now intend to operate also according to psychological criteria in this crisis region, ensuring the best possible support? Honourable Member, as I have already said, I understand your concerns. I think that at the moment and, in particular, in recent months, there have been some positive developments regarding the means that Mr Kouchner will be able to use for effective action. I remember that I heard Mr Kouchner on this matter during the ministerial meeting of the Council of Europe and I believe that many of the concerns he expressed then, about the lack of means to be able to overcome certain problems, have now been resolved, or that such means have been provided to him. In particular, two are essential: firstly, a strengthening of the police - an important element for the protection of civilian populations, especially for the protection of certain civilian populations - and, secondly, an increase in appropriations that specifically allows the maintenance of certain officials with important tasks in the administrative process, if we want to call it that, and functional within Kosovo. The question we all need to ask ourselves, honourable Member - and this is what we did a short while ago in a diplomatic way - concerns the very coherence of Security Council Resolution 1244/99. I know that this is an extremely sensitive issue, but we all need to question the logic behind this resolution and whether it can be implemented. We support the need for its full and total implementation: however, we need to examine this resolution - and this is probably something that the United Nations Security Council will have to do sooner or later - in the sense of verifying, as has happened in the past in other areas and in other strategic scenarios at global level, whether certain types of procedures, logic and balances - the same ones, among other things, that led to the resolution being approved - should or should not be maintained in the future. What we need to do and what we, as the European Union, are doing, is to guarantee Mr Kouchner all the necessary means. You are right, Mr President, we have a duty to our citizens to report regularly and openly on whether these means are being used well or not. As a Council, we intend to provide information on this during the Portuguese Presidency. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I completely agree with you. The problem is not Kouchner, but the legal basis on which he works, namely Resolution 1244. Having said that, I think that the Union's responsibility, that is to say yours, but also ours, is to begin to make an effort to overcome this provisional nature of the resolution and to imagine a future scenario for the whole region. I think that it is the lack of definition of this scenario that causes or encourages the excesses, the incidents, the murders that Mr Alavanos spoke about. Does the Council intend to raise the question of the definitive status of Kosovo? If so, do you intend to do so within the framework of a general redefinition of the region, avoiding as much as possible the multiplication of micro-states, as some tend to do, and reunifying the parts, in this case Kosovo and Albania?

To give one example, in Ireland we have seen the success of the LEADER I and LEADER II programmes in the sense of jobs being created through the administration of these programmes in rural areas of Ireland and Europe. LEADER III is due to be implemented towards the end of this year. The LEADER programme essentially offers the public sector, the private sector and voluntary groups the opportunity to pool their collective talents to create sustainable, long-term jobs in small and medium-sized enterprises in rural areas. This is a classic illustration of how the concept of partnership works and how these programmes should be applied with the broadest possible mandate. The European Peace and Reconciliation Fund has also been successful in creating jobs in the Irish Border Counties. Once again it is the active participation of public and private actors and the voluntary sector that demonstrates how these funds can best be used to support the different local job creation projects in the region. During the next round of the Structural Funds for 2000-2006, other Community initiatives such as EQUAL and URBAN will operate. These initiatives must also involve local authorities and communities in the effort to identify the optimal use of the European Structural Funds. The rapporteur mentions the need to follow an integrated approach for the new Structural Fund plans and programmes which must promote a decentralised, efficient and composite partnership, based on the skills and commitment of all sectors in regional and local authorities. This is a very delicate issue because the main economic and social difficulties in our country cannot be overcome without a crucial integration between national, local and European funds. This report brings us back to the question of why we have a regional policy. To bridge regional gaps, of course. But, above all, because although the European market guarantees us a priori a better functioning of the economy, it can also be a source of inequalities. Jacques Delors used to say that since the market is short-sighted, there is a political need to reduce disparities. This is the phenomenon of solidarity that is at the origin of the European social model that we all defend, from which economic and social cohesion is born. A true political objective, just like the economy and the monetary system, it is implemented in collaboration with the Member States, the regions and local authorities. The Commission, for its part, is responsible for indicating to the Member States, through guidelines, the direction to follow to achieve the desired objectives in the context of programming. For this reason, I will support this report, while regretting, for reasons of time, that the European Parliament was consulted only late on guidelines which should have helped the Member States, regions and local authorities in the programming of Objectives 1, 2 and 3. On the other hand, I hope that our Assembly will also take into account the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, which contributes a series of reflections on essential issues such as the fight against social exclusion, support for the social economy and the implementation of an employment strategy.

The European Union has a specific role to play in this area of responsibility, but we cannot claim to be able to quickly restore structures which, as the Honourable Member rightly pointed out, were not the best even before the military action in Kosovo. Furthermore, it does not seem to me, Honourable Member, that the military actions in Kosovo contributed to such massive destruction of the health care structures that they had a direct impact on the current situation. What we are currently experiencing is essentially due to the dramatic situation of the displaced populations, to a number of economic factors, and to the level at which basic health care needs are met as a result of the general deregulation of the administrative structure in Kosovo. This central question lies at the heart of the entire current situation. If we do not resolve the political problem, which must be done within the framework of the relevant United Nations resolution, then there will be no solution to the problem of children's health, nor to other areas of development in this region. I would, however, like to broaden the debate to include the situation in Mitrovica. The international community, with European assistance, has rebuilt the hospital there. However, it is located in the northern part of the city, making access extremely difficult for Kosovo Albanians. This means that Kosovo Albanians are excluded from any medical care. Since this is also the case in other parts of the country, tensions arise between Kosovo Albanians and Serbs; no one trusts anyone anymore, and Albanians don't want to be cared for by Serbs, and vice versa. I understand your point—and rightly so—that the European Union must work within a larger international organization. But where will you place your emphasis? What will you do to ensure that Kosovo Albanians can also be treated in a hospital, including the one in Mitrovica? Mr. Member of Parliament, the Mitrovica problem is well known. It is a very specific situation with high levels of interethnic tension, which fortunately does not reach the same level of danger in other parts of Kosovo. I fully understand the Member of Parliament's concern. I would like to say to him, however, that in his approach to this matter, Bernard Kouchner has followed a line of preserving what underlies the United Nations resolution in question, namely, trying to create the conditions for multi-ethnic structures that can serve the individual communities, including the various administrative levels. I believe that we should not make hasty judgments about responsibilities on this issue, because several key players are involved. The situation in Mitrovica is deplorable; it is characterized by specific tensions, and I believe that positive security measures have been taken in the area in recent hours. I would like to say, however, that, regrettably, we do not have the police capacity—this is due to the contributions of the Member States—to guarantee what we set out to do in the follow-up to the military action, namely, to set up sufficiently secure inter-ethnic cooperation mechanisms, particularly regarding access to hospital facilities.

However, one gets the impression that this growth, which is due first and foremost to the efficiency of the United States, then to the productivity gains of the new economy and the new information and communication technologies, is being driven by the general trend of the world, even despite our handicaps. We are well aware of these handicaps, which urgently need to be remedied: structural rigidity as well as excessive taxation. But let us not forget that the single currency has brought with it a new handicap. The single monetary policy and the gradual adjustment of other policy areas are creating additional rigidity for the eurozone countries by imposing on them behaviors that are not necessarily consistent with their respective structures and economic conditions. This unification is viewed as positive in the Commission's report. In reality, however, it cannot be ruled out that it is leading to a global situation that is far from optimal. If we also take into account the strangeness of a single currency that is not based on a state, which in turn is based on a people, it is easy to explain what remains a great mystery in Brussels: the markets' distrust of the euro. Certainly, the weakness of the single currency at the beginning of 1999 had its advantages, as it promoted growth in unexpected ways, but in the long run it cannot be concealed that it is in fact the symptom of bad policies and poor operating conditions. Mr President, this draft resolution is controversial. This is hardly surprising given its subject. Economists do not always agree, especially when it comes to the future. The rapporteur's carefree plea for higher economic growth seems like an attractive method of combating high unemployment. In reality, however, this is a short-term policy. Even if the rapporteur advocates sustainable growth, this has nothing to do with sustainability. In light of ecological and demographic developments, we should encourage member states to pursue selective economic growth. Increased investment, production, and consumption only bring short-term prosperity. The consumption of scarce raw materials and energy must be significantly reduced. Other priorities include the repayment of high government debt and the restructuring of pension systems. If member states do not take action in this regard, even fewer resources will be available for healthcare, education, and other important public institutions. A plea for more active government policy makes a rather strange impression. This ignores the recent Eurostat reports on rising inflation, which is now at 2%, the maximum permissible level. Those who nevertheless want higher government spending, should it be implemented, need not wait long for the next interest rate hike by the European Central Bank. Any job creation the government might then achieve will be wiped out by the unfavorable developments, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. The high unemployment rate in the European Union is a concern for all of us, especially since the downward trend does not appear to be continuing. However, promoting employment requires a long-term perspective, a structural policy. It is primarily the responsibility of the Member States to pursue sound policies. To do so, however, they must be given sufficient leeway. Rigidity through the imposition of social convergence criteria and other Community directives certainly does not contribute to the desired employment growth.

And, since today is Valentine's Day, as a former mayor of a regional town, I propose that we declare our love for the European regions that need it. Mr President, Commissioner Fischler, rural development must and can take into account three issues: maintaining employment, protecting the countryside, and above all, local culture, because it is important. The quality of life in rural areas can only be preserved in the long term if the rural population remains there. One only has to look at what is happening in certain Alpine regions to realize how catastrophic the consequences of rural exodus are. I would, however, warn you against the risk of transferring urban culture to rural areas through these programs. We should also avoid creating subsidized structures that are eternally dependent on these subsidies. To ensure this sustainability - a term that, incidentally, has become rather hollow, but we all understand what it implies - it is particularly important to establish links in the countryside between, for example, tourism and agriculture. Investments must now have a visionary orientation. It is therefore imperative to involve the young and creative minds of our countryside, because if they desert the countryside, nothing much will happen. We are not all very keen on sprinkling things in, nor are we all keen on pilot projects that are supposed to have a snowball effect, so to speak, and generate other similar projects. I am rather in favour of closed circuits. And even though Leader I and Leader II may have had certain shortcomings here and there, these two initiatives have certainly proven to be positive overall. I call on my colleagues to reflect and ask them to be careful not to make an exception just for the Nordic countries, but also to include the mountainous regions, namely the Alps, the Pyrenees, the Sierra Nevada, where I come from, especially with regard to population size and density. Mr President, I would like to talk about the EQUAL report, and in particular refugee policy. Last week we had a very lively discussion about the formation of the Austrian government. Today we are already discussing the refugee policy that the Austrian government coalition intends to pursue, since Mrs Stenzel, who drafted the EQUAL report, represents the conservative party in power in Austria and its policy. The most striking point in her first report was the desire to limit aid to refugees to the small group of people covered by the Geneva Convention, in other words, those known as quota refugees, or UN refugees. In fact, it is the other refugees, those excluded from the UN quota and support, who need help the most. The Committee on Employment and Social Affairs rejected this discriminatory proposal and decided that the EQUAL programme should apply to all refugees, on equal terms. However, part of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs defended Mrs Stenzel's proposal and formulations. This means, in my view, that Haider's policy is already casting its shadow over this Parliament.

This item has been postponed to the next March part-session. It is still listed on today's agenda by mistake. Mr. Swoboda, I confirm what you have just said. It is indeed a misprint. The agenda that was distributed is not authoritative because the decision was taken to postpone the discussion on this item. Mr. President, I would like to point out that this morning, on my way to the plenary, I noticed two people smoking outside the Chamber. The smell is truly disgusting! Please do something about it! I don't think I can do it, but I agree with you that a way must be found as soon as possible to educate even those who do not comply with the bans we ourselves have imposed. As for the flight delays and the resulting problems, those who have had difficulty getting to this part-session in Strasbourg could join forces—honestly, I don't know how many there are—to make a stand. then we could examine which problems have actually arisen and to what extent. Coherence of the various Union policies with development policy The next item on the agenda are the statements by the Council and the Commission on the coherence of the various Union policies with development policy. Mr President, it is a great pleasure for me to address this Parliament for the first time on behalf of the Presidency of the Council, in recognition of the extremely important role that the European Parliament will undoubtedly have to play in the coming period in further shaping development policy at European Union level, for I have the honour of presenting to you today a statement on the coherence of European Union development policy. I should, of course, like to leave it to the Commission to add some of the comments that I shall have the opportunity to make. First of all, I would like to stress that, at the level of the European Union, we all feel it necessary to reconcile the extraordinary development and progress that have taken place in many aspects of life, particularly through technological advances that have accelerated in recent decades and have contributed to the well-being and improvement of the living conditions of broad sections of the world's population, with the fact that, at the same time, the disproportions between certain regions and geopolitical areas of the globe have become even more pronounced. This calls into question the stability of the international system and threatens peace, giving rise to a moral obligation for all of us to tailor our policies, as best as possible, to ensure greater stability and balance in the various areas that make up our planet. This calls for a reassessment of development policy as a response to the globalization of economic and financial markets. As has been seen, the conditions under which these markets operate are severely distorted, which naturally requires significant adjustments, which in turn—also inevitably—imply new options for development policy. Consequently, we are on the threshold of a new paradigm for development policy, and to achieve this, I would like to stress, it is necessary that our action focuses on four essential aspects:

But who defines this mission? Who draws the line beyond which this public service mission is committed? Our answer is clear: it is not the Commission, it is not even the Council or the European Parliament, it is the people of each Member State, through a democratic debate. To wish to proceed differently would distort the spirit of our institutions. Mr. President, we are in the first phase of adapting Directive 97/67/EC on postal services, and I fear that a new stage of liberalization will result in a significant reduction in public service provision. During Mr. Bolkestein's hearing, my colleague Véronique Mathieu had stated that "any new proposal, once known, should be subject to impact studies, so that the consequences of the programming of this liberalization are known before the provisions are adopted." Where are we today? Do we have the outcome of this impact study? As you know, we, members of the EDD Group, along with other members, defend rural life, the preservation of employment, and social cohesion in rural areas, a cohesion that must be strengthened by a quality universal public service. I would like to be able to say, of course, that the examples I have witnessed daily in my country, in my deeply rural region, allow us to embark without fear on a new phase of liberalization. Unfortunately, that is not the case. And currently, by combining the beginning of the entry into force of the European directive with the 35-hour law, which is very French, but also by modifying the working time criteria—for example, 1,700 objects/hour that must be managed per workstation, compared to the previous 1,400—we can see in our rural areas either a reduction in opening hours or the possible closure of some post offices. This is an intolerable setback for public service. I have here the municipal newspaper of my town, where I can read: "The Postmaster informs the population that, as of January 3, 2000—which is very recent—the last collection will be made at 3:45 p.m. instead of the usual 4:30 p.m. until then." You can understand, then, why I fear a broader phase of liberalization and its package of measures, which will bring about a new wave of desertification. As you know, in our country, every town has its own post office, or at least its mailbox, where the mail is collected daily. The postman is not simply a distributor of mail; he is also the only social link with the inhabitants. He also delivers money and sometimes even medicines, thus making it possible for elderly and geographically isolated people to continue living in their town. With a poorly controlled liberalization of postal services, more post offices will be closed, invoking that all-too-famous profitability that is often the cause of rural decline.

I can say that the Commission's report on this matter of State aid to the steel industry, as you know, does not cover individual decisions taken under the exceptional procedure provided for in Article 95 of the ECSC Treaty, as these decisions fall outside the scope of the Steel Aid Code. With regard to the future provisions on aid to the steel industry, which will come into force in July 2002, we will take measures to ensure that rigorous regulations continue to be applied, the need for which is shared by the industrial sectors themselves. Once we have finalized our proposal for the new rules and chosen the most appropriate legal form, I will be happy to present our views to you. Mr. President, what I take away from this debate, for which I am extremely grateful to Parliament, is the European Parliament's intellectual and political support—I believe without distinction—for competition policy, substantial recognition of the work the Commission is doing, and confidence that it can continue to do so in the future, things for which I am especially grateful. We will continue, especially with the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, but more generally with Parliament, this interinstitutional dialogue that has been established. In this regard, Mrs. Palacio, I appreciated your words: we must all row, and if possible, in the same direction. Competition is not an objective, as Mr. Rapkay rightly observed, but an extraordinarily important instrument in our European construction. As Mr. von Wogau said at the beginning of the debate, competition, ultimately, is not something abstract: it is in the interest of citizens; it is the basis of the social market economy. And I would like to add that competition has had and will continue to have a civic, and not just economic, value in European construction. Thank you very much, Commissioner Monti. The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday at 12:00. Criminal protection of the Union's financial interests The next item is the report (A5-0002/2000) by Mrs. Theato, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, which contains Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of criminal protection of the Union's financial interests. Mr. President, year after year we hear, particularly through the Court of Auditors' audit reports, of the loss of funds from the European Union budget due to waste, mismanagement, irregularities, and even outright alleged fraud. These anomalies led Parliament some time ago to consider proposing, on its own initiative, measures aimed at protecting European taxpayers' money, which ultimately funds the Union's budget. In this context, the fight against fraud, its investigation, punishment, and deterrence deserve special attention. The establishment of UCLAF from the Task Force and the subsequent creation of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) were important steps, as was the Regulation governing the protection of the Community's financial interests and on-the-spot checks.

The Chinese leaders have no doubts about our position on all these issues and on the evolution of the situation in Tibet. We have made our views very clear. While we all know that for many people in China there has been a real long-term improvement in financial prospects and social and economic freedoms, there is also a dark side to this picture. Those who criticise the proposal to table a resolution argue that at least now there is a dialogue with China on human rights. This is true and potentially useful, although I have to say - and I have told Chinese officials as has the Presidency - that the content of our dialogue has not come close to what we would have liked. As is well known, the dialogue has enabled us to identify and implement EU cooperation programmes in the legal field and in the sphere of human rights. We are very pleased with this outcome and I believe that our village governance programme should also help to promote democracy at the grassroots level. It is clear that any complex dialogue like the one on human rights will be a long-term process, but I would like to be able to aim for more concrete results. The next dialogue in Lisbon, on 25 February, will be an important test. It will show whether the dialogue produces results or not. Finally, what are the first steps we would like to implement? For example, we would like to see China move from signing the UN Covenants on Civil and Political Rights and on Social and Cultural Rights to actually ratifying them. I would like us to be closer to that step. In the light of all this, what should our attitude be this year? I repeat that the Member States will have to take a decision. I hope, first of all, that Europe will adopt a common position and stick to it, without suppressing anything from it, that this position will not be based on illusions or pretensions and that it will be a common and reasonable position. I know that some people say that we should find a more effective way of lobbying for human rights than by tabling resolutions. If that is true, then we must at least make an effort of imagination and be more honest with ourselves in seeking that way of moving forward. If we want to base our position on human rights dialogue, then we need to be able to convince you, the NGO community and the general public that we are actually making progress. That, in my view, is the challenge for the coming weeks. I am grateful to the House for the concerns it has expressed about human rights in the world and in China in particular. Thank you very much, Commissioner Patten. I adjourn the debate on the joint statement on the next UN Human Rights session for the vote. Welcome I warmly welcome to the Chamber the delegation from the Hong Kong Legislative Council. (Loud applause) VOTES Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, following this vote I would like to ask the responsible Commissioner Byrne whether he is now prepared, having seen the high degree of consensus in Parliament, to accept the amendments.

It would be a great victory if we could export this model with the Macedonians to the rest of the Western Balkans. This exemplary model also applies to regional cooperation. I fully agree with the rapporteur that a balance must be struck, that we must encourage regional cooperation on the one hand and openness towards Bulgaria and Greece on the other, and not isolate the latter. Mr President, Commissioner, if we complete this first step successfully, we will have already come a long way. If we rush it, we will have lost even more. Mr President, let me first of all make it clear that I have no problem supporting this very well-founded report in principle. I simply want to highlight an issue that I believe is missing from the report and which presents a major problem for the Macedonians and for the effectiveness of EU aid, financial or otherwise. I want to talk about the sanctions against Yugoslavia. Just so that there is no misunderstanding, I also believe it is imperative that we effectively oppose the Milosevic regime. However, first of all, these sanctions also affect many neighboring states, including Macedonia, in a comprehensive and negative way, even though they are already in a very difficult economic situation. Secondly, this politically counterproductive strategy, which contravenes essential humanitarian principles, has the effect of making the Yugoslav population dependent on Milosevic and his entourage. I therefore believe that the issue being debated today should lead us to demand a rapid end to the sanctions policy, as provided for in Amendment 10. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we did not have to wait for the end of the Kosovo conflict to arrive at the conclusion that, after several wars in the territory of the former Yugoslavia, with their attendant harmful effects on the stability of the Balkan region, it is necessary to implement a comprehensive and lasting strategy guaranteeing peace and stability in South-Eastern Europe.
