This strategy, which took the form of the Stability Pact adopted on 10 June 1999, considers the South-Eastern European region as an entity, but at the same time recognises the diversity and unevenness of the development of the different countries that make it up. The European Union's contribution within the framework of the Stability Pact, translated into the so-called "Stabilization and Association Process", relates to the development of the regional concept that the EC drew up in 1996 for the five countries of the region, namely Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Albania, the most significant aspect of which is the establishment of political and economic measures to support the Dayton Peace Agreements, which should thus contribute to the stability of the region. Therefore, the establishment of completely new bases for relations between the European Union and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and the opening of this country to the prospect of full integration into the structures of the European Union through a mechanism provided for in the Stabilization and Association Process, constitute an important contribution to the stability of the Balkan region.

We must do everything in our power to support East Timor in achieving this goal. Human rights are such a high priority within the ACP-EU Joint Assembly that Joint Vice-Presidents have been appointed specifically to closely monitor human rights issues and report to the Assembly. A number of cases have been raised, including the use of child soldiers in Sudan, where many children have been trafficked from neighboring countries. I was elected European Co-President at the beginning of the fifth parliamentary term, and Mr. Clair from Mauritius is the new ACP Co-President. I advocate for a number of changes in our Assembly, which will be particularly necessary after the signing of the new agreement in May. We need a greater degree of equality between our ACP partners and our European members, and the "us versus them" syndrome must be overcome. First, I advocate for a Joint Assembly with elected members from the ACP countries as delegates, rather than ambassadors or ministers from their respective governments. This is part of the new agreement. Second, the new agreement allows for regional assemblies in the six regions, which will enable us to work much more effectively in the future. These assemblies are subordinate to the Joint Assembly. A highly productive regional debate has already taken place in Nassau in the Caribbean. Another regional debate is planned for Abuja in West Africa. I want to transform the Joint Assembly so that it is no longer just a club for discussions, but a workshop for working on improving the living conditions of all people in developing countries. I want to give civil society a louder voice. To achieve this, we must overcome corruption and address this goal head-on. We must reward states that strive for good governance. But we should also take tough action against states where corruption is prevalent or where the pluralistic governments we demand are constitutionally prevented. I am pleased with the developments in Zimbabwe. European taxpayers will no longer allow their money to be misappropriated. A wind of change must sweep across Africa; new standards must be set and maintained. The Joint Assembly, together with the Commission, should take a leading role in monitoring the legal enshrinement of good governance, human rights, and democracy. I am confident that the elected delegates of the EU and the ACP states are equal to this task. I ask you to support this report. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Corrie on his excellent and comprehensive report. The foundation of all development policy considerations must be respect for human rights and the fight against poverty. If poverty must be combated, then the reduction in funding for development aid in many Member States and in the EU is in stark contradiction to this. Looking ahead, when it comes to financing, the Joint Assembly must be provided with additional resources, which will enable it to deploy election observers at the request of the ACP states, for example. In the future, the EU must, on the one hand, adopt a more diverse approach to coordinating development projects and, on the other, coordinate better with individual states in order to work more efficiently and use resources more effectively.

In a debate in the Socialist Party about the Irish process, someone said the following: "In the end, the solution in Ireland was for all parties involved to make the following consideration: Is it so important to be Irish or English? Let each person be what they want to be, because if Ireland and England are in the European Union, it is not worth killing because you are English or Irish. What difference does it make if from now on national schemes will no longer work!@ In this case we could ask the same question: is it so important to be Basque or Spanish or European? We discuss a lot about what it means to be Basque, but today Basques dress like Danes and read the same things as English people. If life is destined to develop in a much larger space - which is already happening - and if our children will certainly live in this Europe, what sense is there in killing each other for these reasons? He used to say B and probably in Ireland this reflection has been assimilated by everyone -: "But if we are killing for nothing B and there they were really killing because there were paramilitary gangs from all sides involved -, in the Basque Country we should also ask ourselves this question out loud: what does it matter if it is all the same? Be what you want to be. If in the near future we are going to function in a European context in the economic, political and vital decision-making fields for each country, it is not worth killing for this. Neither killing nor dying for this@. May he rest in peace. (Loud applause) B (ES) Madam President, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party and European Democrats, I would like to convey to the families of Fernando Buesa, representative of the Basque people, and Jorge Díez, member of the Basque police, the expressions of our deepest solidarity, which we naturally extend to the family of the Socialist Party of the Basque Country. Madam President, sadly, in recent times in this Chamber we have had to talk about European extremism. Whatever their meaning, in the end, they are all different expressions of the same thing. Faced with all this, we democrats cannot resign ourselves to the peace of the dead; on the contrary, we must be strengthened by knowing that, in the Basque Country, the only social fracture that exists is the abyss that separates those who kill and those who support and understand them from the vast majority of the Basque people, who simply aspire to live in peace and freedom. (Loud applause) B (ES) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Liberal Group, I express the most categorical and firm condemnation of the terrorist attack of 22 February in Vitoria, which cost the lives of the Socialist deputy and spokesman for the Basque Parliament, Fernando Buesa, and his bodyguard, Jorge Díez. We reiterate that, in a State governed by the rule of law, a member of the European Union, it is possible to defend any idea and any option, provided that these are expressed in a democratic manner and are part of the defence of respect for the rights of the individual and the principles and values of justice, freedom and economic and social progress on which the Union is based, which moreover does not, evidently, allow the transgression of these principles, as clearly established in the Treaties.

Berend Report (A5-0107/1999) We essentially share the rapporteur's assessment and considerations regarding the sixth periodic report on the social and economic situation and development of the regions of the European Union. We will therefore limit ourselves to highlighting a few aspects. First, as the Commission points out, the fact that the sharp increase in GDP per capita in some poorer regions between 1991 and 1996 was largely determined by the inclusion of the new German Länder in the calculations of the Community average, starting precisely from the first of those years, which evidently led to a significant reduction in the level of GDP per capita in the Union. Furthermore, we consider particularly important the observation that the recovery in some regions—where it did occur—was accompanied by minimal growth in employment, which consequently requires new development strategies, with a considerably greater level of concern in this regard. This situation contradicts the relegation of the adoption of employment promotion measures to the exclusive internal domain of the Member States, as the report does. Finally—and this is not unimportant—a reference to the rapporteur's proposal that in the future this type of report should also include, among other aspects, an analysis of the interregional development of cohesion in each of the States. The multiplicity of situations and the differentiated developments that occur from region to region, within the same State, indeed require a more in-depth evaluation of this issue in order to allow for and guarantee corrections in regional (and other) policies with a view to ensuring cohesion within each of the Member States. (FR) The Berend report offers an interesting analysis of the situation and economic development of the regions of the European Union. However, the French delegation of the Union for a Europe of the Nations Group cannot but disagree with some of the statements it contains. Thus, paragraph 26 "emphasizes the need to consolidate the budget as a precondition for the success of Economic and Monetary Union and the enlargement of the Union." At a time when Member States are forced to follow a budgetary slimming diet to meet the convergence criteria—a diet they have, moreover, imposed on themselves—the federalists are displaying a most surprising display of financial greed. As a sign of recognition of the failure of cohesion policy and EMU, the inadequacy of the results achieved is entered into the overdraft account, and everyone vie with each other in eloquence to demand more appropriations, without anyone questioning the effectiveness of the funds used. What can be said about budget management that consists of setting a spending target rather than a spending ceiling, of searching at all costs for projects to spend approved appropriations at all costs, rather than allocating appropriations for existing projects?

We must affirm gender equality, the famous gender mainstreaming, which is one of the least developed topics in the Prodi Commission's agenda. And this means prioritizing gender equality, adapting the social model, and, above all, a clear fight against populism in a situation where our economic and social cohesion is threatened, and this is also something that must appear as a top priority in the Commission's work. And this must be complemented by a clear fight against racism and intolerance to be able to affirm in practice the evolution of a Union that has become a magnet for the rest of the world and a zone of immigration, given its prosperity and its autumnal demographics. And this, I believe, must be the first objective we must pursue. In this regard, I would also add another element, which is economic governance, with a single currency—I believe it is essential—and also an issue on which the Commission must make progress. I would like—my group would certainly like—with regard to the ambitious objectives and, above all, with something important that the Commission has done, which is to adopt this enlargement in the negotiation and integration process, for there to be more clarity regarding the revision of Agenda 2000. Does the Commission think there will be no revision until the end? And the issue of imposition also seems absolutely key to us. Regarding governance in general, I think a theoretical reflection could be very interesting. I would draw attention to one thing: it is dangerous to rethink the entire governance of the European Union from here. I would clearly be in favor of subsidiarity. If we are able to define our area of governance, I think it would be very positive. Otherwise, I believe that subsidiarity also applies to reflection. It should not only be the Commission, but also our States, our Parliaments, and our civil society who reflect on it. Finally, Madam President, I would like to make a brief reference to the last objective, which we consider absolutely fundamental: the stabilization of the continent and the strengthening of Europe's role in the world. There, I would say that there is agreement and support regarding the priority of southeastern Europe, with enlargement and—as I have already mentioned—with the integration process and the strengthening of the Euro-Mediterranean program and our capacity for conflict prevention, and with an issue that is rarely discussed, namely the North-South challenge. We must not forget Africa, which is the continent absolutely abandoned not only by God but also by Europe, nor our significant contribution to development cooperation. And finally, an issue in which we are increasingly responsible, as the world's leading economic and trading power, which is the voice of the European Union in the world. This requires not only an active stance in relation to the Millennium Round. It requires the reform of the United Nations and the international financial institutions, in which Europe has an enormous responsibility.

In my view, the Commission's proposal must include elements that allow for greater transparency in the workings of several institutions, but there is certainly always room for improvement. We are prepared to examine the proposals put forward in this regard. The question raised by Jonas Sjöstedt and other Members is a very important one. In Sweden, there is the principle of openness, which strengthens democracy and promotes positive dialogue between citizens, decision-makers, and authorities. We are keen for the EU to follow this path, which is indeed supported by the Treaty of Amsterdam. A few years ago, Parliament adopted a Lööw report, which is very important in this context. It warned that future developments would lead to a restriction of the principle of openness in the Member States. We can now see that Parliament's warning may have had some justification. I would like to ask the Council, in light of the Commission's working documents, whether it can understand this warning. I listened carefully to the President-in-Office of the Council's comments on transparency and the Intergovernmental Conference. My question now is whether I can conclude from Mr. Seixas da Costa's truly interesting remarks on the issues mentioned that the Portuguese Presidency is committed to examining and supporting the expansion of the IGC's agenda. The issue of transparency in the functioning of the institutions must not, in any way, be examined in secret, or in conjunction with other issues or within certain corridors—although I too know how important corridors are. This requires a specific item on the IGC's agenda, which must therefore be expanded. Mr. President, the issue of transparency is an issue that is naturally linked to the institutions. This IGC is, at least initially, based on the focus on the more optimal functioning of the institutions, taking into account, in particular, the desire we all have for the institutions to be more democratic, transparent, and efficient. All of this, however, within a general framework of global acceptance of all the solutions we can find to achieve these three objectives. Clearly, this issue of transparency will remain on the European agenda in the long term, and it will evidently be on the agenda of this Intergovernmental Conference. I can assure you that the Portuguese Presidency will continue to raise this issue with the Member States and the representatives in the Conference's preparatory group. In this area, it must be able to count on the support of the Members of the European Parliament, who are certainly motivated to support this proposal. After that, we will examine at ministerial level how to proceed with this process. However, we must acknowledge that we have the Treaty of Amsterdam, adopted in May of last year, that there are a number of measures introducing transparency that are still being implemented, and the question is whether it would be premature to initiate a new procedure in the area of transparency. I believe, however, that it is an issue that must always be on the agenda because there is clearly a certain awareness of the problem on the part of public opinion and because it is linked to the truly necessary responsibility of the European institutions and bodies towards the citizens.

Postal services are not just a mail service, but also a social service. For some, the postman is the only person they meet during the day. We can pay homage to the postmen who, in any weather conditions, walk many kilometres on foot to ensure their service to everyone. Dismantling the postal service, the service of proximity communication, would be a serious mistake; furthermore, the equality of all citizens would not be protected. Pursuing profit at all costs means hindering fraternity and social cohesion. Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution and I would like to explain why. Several speakers have pointed out that, especially in mountain municipalities, the only person with whom the elderly have any contact is the postman. I agree with this observation. However, I believe that the pensions of many elderly people are being reduced in line with the state budget. In Italy, my country of origin, there are around 200,000 postal workers and they cost the State around 50 million lire per capita per year, or 25,000 euros. The total cost is therefore around 5 million euros. By liberalising this service, the State budget would be freed up, that is, it would have a surplus of around 10 million lire per year for each pensioner, to be allocated to a million pensioners, who would see their pensions double. This would more than compensate for the sacrifice of not having contact with the postman. Mr President, I voted for the resolution on European postal services with all the greater satisfaction because it once again reiterates the position I have always defended, namely the need for a high-quality universal service, particularly in the less densely populated regions, the rural areas, and there is one in my small country, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. In these regions, but also in some districts of large cities, as my colleague Posselt explained, post offices and postmen play a role that I would almost call socio-cultural, which goes beyond the simple delivery of mail. I know that this service is deficient. It would perhaps be less expensive to provide homes or isolated villages with a fax or e-mail service. In principle, I am in favour of abolishing monopolies in the public sector, whether it concerns water, gas, electricity, telephone, antennas, cable networks and so on. However, liberalisation, which has brought considerable advantages to users in terms of prices and quality of services, especially in the telephone sector, must stop where the supply of the service becomes insufficient or disappears, where the companies that benefit from liberalisation are not profitable. If they cannot be forced to provide a service that the state monopoly has guaranteed, in particular through the obligation of a universal service, it is necessary to maintain the public service. I think we can afford to maintain a postal service, even if our P & Ts currently function like businesses. It is clear that they must make an effort to no longer be called "snail mail", even if they cannot reach the speed of e-mail.

We bear a special responsibility with regard to promoting economic development in this region. The start of talks with Syria has paved the way for the convening of the Multilateral Coordination Group in Moscow at the end of this month. I will attend this meeting and hope that we can finally move the negotiations forward again. The European Union has an important role to play in the peace process, as has been underlined by all sides: Palestinians, Israelis, their Arab neighbors, and the United States. Our role is not limited to that of a financier. We must be prepared to act swiftly to consolidate peace in this region. But we should not deceive ourselves: a comprehensive peace solution in the Middle East comes at a price. The Commission is already examining how the recent encouraging developments will affect the European Union. We will discuss this issue in detail with Parliament and the Council soon. However, I would like to remind Members of the House that the European Union is already providing significant financial support to the peace process. We are the largest donor to the Palestinians. We have also provided substantial financial assistance to Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, and Egypt. With Israel, we have further intensified cooperation in several areas of particular interest to the country. The Community's contribution of more than EUR 600 million in grants and loans between 1994 and 1998 provided effective support to the Palestinian Authority and significantly assisted the reconstruction of the dilapidated infrastructure in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Member States of the European Union jointly provided a further EUR 860 million during this crucial phase. In this context, I welcome the important steps recently taken by the Palestinian Authority to improve budgetary transparency. President Arafat will meet with the Council of Ministers next week. This meeting will provide a good opportunity to discuss the need for equally bold measures to improve Palestinian administration and strengthen the rule of law. The Commission is actively involved in these efforts. The Commission has also increased its planned support for regional Israeli-Arab cooperation projects. Last year, we allocated more than EUR 20 million to these projects. This package included additional funding for citizens' initiatives and cross-border Israeli-Arab cooperation at non-governmental and expert levels. Members will be aware that the European Union is the largest donor to efforts towards reconciliation between the peoples of the Middle East. Other potential areas for Community support will emerge in the next phase of the peace process. This includes support for an agreement for the Golan Heights, under which we can support security arrangements as well as mine clearance and the reconstruction of communities in the Golan Heights. Economic development in Syria needs support to ensure the successful transition from a war economy to a peace economy. Reconstruction and rehabilitation measures in southern Lebanon, the only region in the Middle East where military conflict remains, will also require considerable efforts.

Anyone who threatens, in principle, the production of this factory by demanding repayment of the aid granted at the time is threatening not only this steelworks but also an employer in this region on which small and medium-sized enterprises naturally depend. It goes without saying that this cannot be the European Union's competition policy. If we want competition, we must achieve this combination of the needs of the national economy and the demands of businesses. This is also the only chance of developing economic circuits in underdeveloped regions that lead to the social protection of citizens and the strengthening of purchasing power. Furthermore, we must without hesitation consider an economic policy geared more towards demand rather than solely towards supply. Mr President, since my election to the European Parliament in 1994, I have never read a report imbued with as much anti-Irish sentiment and overtones as the Jonckheer report we are debating today. I would like to quote the report verbatim: "State aid per capita is highest in Italy, Germany and Ireland, with the latter country clearly leading the way when national aid and aid from the regional and social Community are added together." I believe the rapporteur is simply playing with figures. I find it difficult to understand how he can introduce social and regional funds into this mathematical equation. I would like to remind him that the European Union approved the new guidelines for regional aid for the period after 2000, which was simply an extension of the policy objectives designed to complete the internal market within Europe. Regional disparities must be overcome if we want the internal market to be successful and prosperous. I welcome the fact that 40% aid and an additional 15% aid for SMEs for fixed-income investments will be authorized for companies setting up in Objective I regions in Europe after the year 2000. I remind Mr. Jonckheer that Irish companies or foreign companies established in Ireland still have to cross two seas to reach the European market on the continent. No other Member State is disadvantaged to this extent. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, the prohibition of cartels is the very heart of a functioning legal order in Europe. The Commission has found the practical implementation of the monitoring of this prohibition to be unsatisfactory: let us say straight away that we approve. But opinions differ on the solution. Formally, the Commission's proposal does not depart from the prohibition of cartels, but ultimately, this proposal is a transition from prohibition subject to authorization to authorization subject to prohibition. We are moving from the principle of prohibition to the principle of abuse. Along with other colleagues, I resolutely reject a systemic change of this magnitude. I do not accept that a transposition problem can motivate a practical change in the legal system. We are amending the law to make it enforceable again: I find this unacceptable.

I shall give the floor for all procedural points at the end of voting time. Report (A5-0029/2000) by Mr Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the proposal for a Council regulation on the implementation of measures in the framework of the pre-accession strategy for Cyprus and Malta (COM(1999) 535 - C5-0308/1999 - 1999/0/0199(CNS)) Amendments 22 and 24 Madam President, I should like to criticise the absence of the current Presidency of the Council. I believe that, when it comes to these third pillar issues and these agreements which are so important for the creation of the area of freedom, security and justice, it is unacceptable that the current Presidency is not here today. I would also like to speak about the problem of translations. I'll just give one example, because we don't have time, but this is a case where translations are very important because of the very precise legal terms involved. Amendment 83 states in Italian, the original language, that 'the minor must assist a person in his fiducia or in an external legal position.' This 'external legal position' becomes 'neutered lawyer' in the French version, and I don't know what a neuter lawyer is. I think that's a contradiction in terms. But in the Spanish version, the word 'lawyer' disappears entirely; there is no lawyer at all. Madam President—you've said it several times—this is a very serious problem. In this matter, I believe the legal-linguistic experts will have to do meticulous work to arrive at a sensible version. Absolutely, Mrs Palacio Vallelersundi, this is not the first time, and it is indeed very worrying. We will look into this problem and check all the translations. Madam President, before the vote, I just wanted to echo Mrs Palacio Vallelersundi's sentiments and say that I very much regret the Council's absence from this debate on such important votes on third-pillar matters. I would like you, Madam President, to convey to the Council our wish that it be present at such votes in the future. Absolutely; I am well aware that the absence of Council representatives is not normal, and I will be happy to convey that. Amendment 31 Madam President, I would like to add that in the phrase - I will read it out in French, as that is the version I have to hand - the words 'par le droit de l'Etat membre requis ou requérant que la personne donne son consentiment' should be added. (Parliament adopted the draft legislative resolution.) Madam President, I would just like to point out that, in the heat of the moment, I forgot to tell you that in the Spanish version of my report on the deficit, there is an error in the last paragraph: instead of saying 'la propuesta nos parece correcta', an 's' has been omitted, and it says 'la propuesta no parece correcta', which means exactly the opposite. It is just a matter of correcting that. Motion for a resolution (B5-0132/2000) tabled by Mr Bonino and others, on behalf of the TDI Group, on the Commission communication on the strategic objectives for the next five years

(The sitting adjourned at 11:50 p.m.) Resumption of sitting The Minutes of yesterday's sitting have been distributed. Are there any objections? (Parliament approved the Minutes.) Mr President, I should like to comment on a meeting of various Members of this Parliament from all political groups, which took place yesterday evening in the presence of several Vice-Presidents and Quaestors, as well as the architects who built this Chamber, to discuss ways of further improving our work. At that meeting, we noticed that behind the pretty white curtain behind your platform, Mr President, there is in fact a large window. When you raise the curtain, it seems to reveal a magnificent view across the river, but, we were told, this curtain remains closed so that you are not sitting against the light and so that we have better light during the debate. What prevents us, however, from opening the curtain before debates begin or during adjournments, so that we can enjoy a little – free of charge – of that supposedly magnificent view behind you? I'm perfectly happy for our plenary chamber to be illuminated by the brilliance of our debates, but I think it would be even better if real sunlight could illuminate our "dome of democracy" from time to time. It would seem appropriate if you, with the ushers, could explore the possibility of opening the curtain from time to time. Thank you very much, Mr. Colleague. I am grateful for any suggestion that could make our meeting room more humane. I would like to suggest the following: We will continue with the meeting as it is in the room. In the meantime, I will check whether this is technically feasible. If so, let's conduct a half-hour trial to see what it looks like with the President sitting backlit. UCITS Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, I hope that Parliament is ready today to take decisions on expanding and strengthening the financial market in Europe. For me, as a new Member of the European Parliament, it has been very interesting and instructive to be entrusted with responsibility for this important matter. I would particularly like to thank my colleagues in the committee for their willingness to compromise, for the openness of the President and the Bureau in the face of the complexity of the issue, for the good contacts with the Commission, especially with the Commissioner, and with the Council, and also for the selfless work of the Committee Secretariat. There was broad agreement in the committee, except for one point on which we hope to reach a solution. The issue of certain undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS) may seem complicated and technically and politically risky. I believe some people don't even know what UCITS means. However, let me state very clearly that this is an issue that truly affects the citizens of Europe. It concerns how their savings are managed, what choices are available, how competition works between countries regarding different forms of savings, what security requirements savers have, and what options European citizens have for wise retirement provision.

That being said, to govern is to foresee, it is also to be responsible, and in this new, imposed context, competition law naturally has an essential role to play. In this area, the Commission has prioritized several lines of action: by acting on the structure of the markets by actively pursuing anti-competitive practices, by refocusing the control activity of its services on only those cases presenting a clear Community interest and by signaling its desire to modernize competition law. As regards State aid, we must ensure that the system is not made more cumbersome and the introduction of a public register, in which all aid would be recorded, does not seem desirable to us, because this onerous obligation would naturally run counter to attempts to alleviate bureaucratic constraints. Finally, with regard to the modernization of the application of Articles 85 and 86 of the Treaty, we do not believe that a decentralized application is necessarily a step in the right direction. Indeed, the Commission not only retains the power to remove a case from the jurisdiction of national authorities, but national courts are also clearly obliged to avoid any conflict with the Commission's decisions. National states would thus become the Commission's secular arm for ensuring compliance with the application of rules over which they have no control. In conclusion, I would say that while certain measures are going in the right direction, we will naturally remain vigilant in order to avoid a federalist spiral that would be detrimental to Europe and the sovereignty of states. Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, we express a generally positive opinion of the Commission's White Paper on Competition, particularly with regard to the abolition of the notification and authorization system, but we still have some doubts. Above all, there is the risk that the decentralization of powers to individual states, which is necessary in many respects, could lead to an abnormal expansion of competition initiatives and encourage someone to use antitrust not as an ultimate guarantee of the efficient and predictable functioning of markets, but as an instrument of economic and industrial policy, of planning and interference with the spontaneous dynamics of the markets themselves, or even as an instrument serving protectionist visions. In this regard, I believe we should draw inspiration from the writings of von Eieck and certainly from those of the great Italian liberal Bruno Leoni, who denounced the risks of an abnormal expansion of anti-competitive policies. The most serious damage to the market, to competition and to the free choice of European consumers is still today attributable to state interference in the economy. We know about state aid to businesses—we've talked about it—we still feel a strong state presence in the economy—just think that the Italian Treasury controls 15% of the stock market capitalization—and there are the obstacles that governments and central banks are putting in the way of mergers and acquisitions. We've often talked in recent weeks about the Vodafone-Mannesmann affair and the rescue of Holzmann.

Cross-border workers, posted workers and migrants, as well as jobseekers, trainees and students, are hindered in the exercise of their right to free movement by the lack of coordination and convergence in the area of social protection. The same phenomenon is also evident in the area of taxation. In order to combat distortions of competition and prevent social dumping, the Commission has developed an approach that seems to me to be balanced because it follows a middle path between harmonisation and non-intervention. On the one hand, it uses mandatory and binding rules on equal pay or supplementary pension schemes, and on the other, it uses incentive programmes to combat discrimination and social exclusion. Building on a long series of recommendations, reports and communications, the Commission has taken a further step towards convergence by setting clear objectives and also by setting up a working group of high-level officials. Both proposals have already been adopted by the Council. It is therefore now a question of supporting this approach in order to arrive, within a reasonable timeframe, at being able to judge with full knowledge of the facts whether, to what extent and in what way the European Union should proceed with a reorganisation of social protection, which has been made inevitable by enlargement, globalisation, the ageing of the population, the individualisation of society and the transformation of family structures. Denying these transformations means, in fact, condemning social protection to death. To Eurosceptics and nationalists, I reiterate that a social protection system that remains limited to the borders of a Member State does not deserve the name of social and does not offer effective protection. The dismantling of social protection systems dictated by competitive motives also undermines the role of this system as a productive factor: lower levels of social protection lead to a reduction in purchasing power, a smaller number of workers in good health and less satisfied workers. I would remind Eurofanatics that a European social protection system is neither feasible nor desirable. Both in terms of services and entitlements, and in terms of income and benefits, the differences between the Member States are too great to allow for standardisation. The path taken by the Commission is therefore fully understandable and has the advantage of clarity: data is collected and experiences are exchanged in order to agree on common objectives, to develop sound comparative indicators and to issue recommendations. I fully agree with this approach. I support the Commission's proposal and I hope that a further step forward can be taken in Lisbon. Mr President, Mr Andersson's report contains many interesting elements. Unfortunately, the most interesting aspect is that the report, which should focus on the overall strategy for the modernisation of social policy, instead proposes an expansion of traditional social policy, with a greater supranational component in this area. Social policy must be renewed, so that unemployment in the Member States can fall. Even if the socialists, because there are now so many governments with a social democratic majority, talk much less about unemployment than in the past, unemployment is still high. This despite a favorable international situation.

The second aspect to be taken into consideration with regard to policy coherence is that of development policy in the context of the Union's foreign policy. We know that the Union is experiencing a new dimension in its foreign policy, we know that with the creation of the High Representative, the Rapid Intervention Force, the Military Crisis Management Centre, there is a whole dynamic of affirmation of the European Union that we cannot disdain when we consider the role of development policies and also that there are aspects linked to political dialogue, the adoption of common positions or actions, the preparation of common strategies, preventive diplomacy, the development of regional capacities for crisis prevention and management. Undoubtedly, all these aspects will not fail to make important contributions to strengthening the role of development policies in the context of the European Union's foreign policy, as regards its implementation and development. Let us say that at this level too, at the level of the European Union, the framing of development policy in the context of foreign policy will certainly have to follow the same path as that taken by the development policies of many Member States, in the context of their respective foreign policies. Its affirmation necessarily presupposes a strengthening of the decision-making mechanisms and institutional structures of CFSP means, which allow for better articulation between the instruments of development policy and the instruments of foreign policy. In this context, our conviction is that we must move from a post-colonial paradigm to a truly European paradigm of development policy, knowing, as we know, that development policy has been strongly conditioned in the European context by the policies of certain Member States, according to the post-colonial references of the policies of these States. The third aspect that must be considered is that of the policy of the European Union and the policy of the Member States. Policy coherence at the level of the European Union certainly presupposes better coordination of the policies of the Member States with the policy of the European Union in the field of development. If it proves impossible to establish better mechanisms for coherence between national policies, it will certainly be difficult to think of a more coherent framework for the European Union's development policy. The fourth and final aspect I would like to put to you, still concerning development policies, concerns the role of the Development Council. There has been discussion, particularly in recent months, about the role that the Development Council can play in the context of Union policies. We know that the difference in status between development policies and other policies at Union level is flagrant - one only has to see the difficult conditions in which the communitarisation or non-communitarisation of the EDF was settled - and it is difficult to admit that we can develop more coherence in the policies of the European Union without a more active and more interventionist role of the "Development" Council in the taking of political decisions which eminently concern the competence of development and which take place within other councils, other decision-making centres, which range from the "Agriculture and Fisheries" Council to the Environment Council, but in relation to which the "Development" Council has had no opportunity to be heard or to intervene until now.

The United Nations has a peace plan. We should seize this opportunity to end the latest colonialist episode in Africa. I would also like to discuss the issue of migration. I am concerned about the new provisions in the partnership agreement we have concluded with the ACP countries, which aim to make it easier to turn back immigrants, asylum seekers, and refugees for less clearly established reasons. I would also really like to see the EU act as a pioneer on the issue of patents on living organisms. We now know that every four seconds, a human being dies of hunger. Three-quarters of these famine victims are children under the age of five. This is not due to a lack of food, but to what we have talked about so much today: increasing poverty. Food security and the protection of biological diversity must take precedence over commercial interests. I believe that the sole purpose of granting patents on living organisms would be to control the world's food supply, especially for commercial purposes, and for no other purpose. I would also like to see in this report, which I hope the Commission will submit to us, some information on the role of women. In all contexts, and particularly in development policy, women seem to be completely absent - but in fact, this is not the case. Mr President, our debate today highlights the need to discuss development policy in terms that go much further than simply increasing the flow of aid. The level of such aid is, of course, important, and it should be increased for all rich countries. This is particularly necessary to combat poverty and to build capacity in the regions concerned. The level of aid, however, is only one of many instruments that have a significant influence on the development of poor countries. A number of my colleagues today mentioned areas that are important beyond aid, and where the contrasts and oppositions between different policy sectors have very serious consequences. These included trade policy, and agricultural and fisheries policy. Other equally important elements could, of course, be mentioned: the flow of private investment, cooperation in the fields of research and technology, and the way in which the international community addresses various global problems that concern us all, and the financing of corresponding measures. These problems include climate issues, biodiversity, public health issues, and so on. This observation is further accentuated by globalization, this new form of economy that we are seeing spreading. The links between the different policy areas are further strengthened. What we are discussing today in this Chamber, in my view, is partly the EU's contribution to the debate on globalisation, on the opportunities it offers and the risks it entails, and on the rules of the game that must be established to ensure that poor countries have real opportunities for development. It is, of course, absolutely essential to study, or summarise, as Mrs Maij-Weggen has requested, the overlaps between the various policy areas and the resulting contradictions. I can only wonder why the Commission has not done more in this regard.

Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to congratulate you on having reconciled Europe with the idea that the modernisation of the economy and social cohesion are compatible concepts. The preparation for the Lisbon Summit has shown that we are not working enough in Europe, and that if we want to be the most dynamic region in the world, we must not only work more, but work with more information and the ability to use it. To increase the employment rate and finance social protection systems, we are forced to work longer and, above all, we must be able to count on a greater number of women in the world of work, and with better knowledge. We hope that this Lisbon Summit will help to change the current model of female employment. I would like to ask you, Mr President, whether you expect this Summit to produce conclusions that will enable us to take concrete measures within a set timeframe so that there are more women in the world of work, and above all in the new knowledge economy. Ladies and gentlemen, I am grateful to you and would like to thank you for the important and excellent contributions you have made to this debate on the preparation of the extraordinary Lisbon Summit. I believe that this debate and the participation of Parliament were necessary because I think that Europe still lacks a strategic direction; and to make this strategic direction possible, an institutional alliance is needed that goes beyond natural political divergences. Such an alliance is, among other things, already fully achieved thanks to the excellent cooperation of the Commission, led by Romano Prodi, and its document for the preparation of the Lisbon Summit. However, Parliament must also play an essential role. I would like it to be possible at the Lisbon Summit not only to agree on a strategy, but also to define a set of concrete measures and an open method of coordination. In this regard, I will give you two examples that are connected, among other things, with everything that has been said here about the concrete measures that I would like to see approved. The first example is that by 2002 all schools and training institutes in Europe should be connected to the Internet and, at the same time, should have the staff required to provide the training needed to ensure that young people leaving compulsory school and all those in vocational training, whether unemployed or not, can acquire a kind of "license" for the information society that allows them to use computers and surf the Internet. If this were to happen, we would then have created the conditions for information technology not to be a factor in social disruption, in increasing the gap between those who are successful and those who are not, but instead to become an important vector for integration, an important means of combating exclusion. The second example is that we have spoken about women in the labour market and equal opportunities for men and women in society in general. The concrete measures connected to what I have just defined as a common objective for support services for families and, in particular, for children, constitute a decisive factor for the creation of jobs and, at the same time, make equal opportunities concrete by increasing the participation of women in the labour market.

Europe's environmental problems can never be solved by one person alone. Finally, for those who still harbor doubts for economic reasons: just consider how high the cost of cleaning up our seas would otherwise be! The time will come when we are faced with such demands. Then we will be grateful that we have done everything in our power to prevent oil discharges. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to say very briefly that no one doubts the need for a directive on this issue. This is a serious problem not only for Europe, but for all the world's oceans, and therefore effective and urgent measures are required. I would like to make it clear that there are a number of universal principles with which we therefore fully agree. First, all ports must have the necessary waste treatment facilities. Second, the polluter pays principle applies, of course. I acknowledge that there may be differences of opinion regarding the exceptions regarding ship types and sizes. However, we cannot start a battle that distorts competition between the various ports, leaving us with a situation where a series of theoretically environmental measures designed to protect the coast or the sea ultimately distorts competition between the various ports. Effective measures must therefore be taken on this point, because if we do not find an appropriate solution, this directive will ultimately be a complete failure. It will only benefit some ports to the detriment of others, all because of fine words about the environment that conceal a competitive struggle between ports. A logical approach, for example, would be to establish the principle of a single tariff for all European ports, an absolutely identical tariff that would not cause any distortion of competition or have any similar consequences. Any decision that, for example, allows Member States to subsidize various ports would distort competition and ultimately be ineffective. Mr President, I share with you all a love of the sea, diving, and sailing, and I am convinced that everyone here is concerned about how we will be able to guarantee clean seas for present and future generations. I believe the work being discussed here today is a major step forward. In this spirit, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Bouwman, and the entire Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism on the meticulous work they have done throughout the debate and throughout the preparation of this initiative. As you know, marine pollution is a matter of great concern to the Commission. At the earliest opportunity, I hope to be able to send you an initial package of measures for better monitoring of safety on oil tankers—measures that I hope we can all advance together, especially in light of the dramatic shipwreck of the Erika. This dramatic circumstance may perhaps enable us this time to go beyond certain very specific interests, which will undoubtedly be affected by the measures I shall propose in the near future. However, even if accidents are the cause of major problems and major disasters, it is a fact that most discharges do not result from accidents, but simply from the habitual, completely reckless cleaning of bilges by some ships.

We should give more responsibility to local resources by ensuring that they are adequately funded. This would create development that would benefit from local activity and continue even after the funding phase has ended. We should ensure that all projects are implemented through the commitment of local actors. Mr President, thanks to this regulation, the European Union has an instrument and a legal but also political responsibility to integrate the environmental dimension into development policy, and this obviously presupposes an adequate financial allocation. For this reason, like one of my predecessors, I support the rapporteur's Amendment No 11. Since environmental integration is a long-term commitment, I would in principle be against setting a deadline for the validity of the regulation. However, the arguments that lengthy negotiations with the Council would damage existing projects and those in the process of being implemented have convinced me otherwise. I also believe that Amendment No 11 is a good idea. 9, which aims to promote the participation of civil society in the exchange of information and the implementation of the regulation, is very important, because in my opinion the debate on civil society and good governance cannot be limited to fine words, but must be translated into concrete political actions. I also support the rapporteur's proposal for a bipartite comitology procedure: the guidelines would be adopted using a management procedure, while the measures concerning implementation would be adopted using the consultative procedure. We hope that we are close to the conclusion of the process that began a year ago during the previous legislature. In addition to the importance of the issue itself, this regulation and the accompanying regulation on tropical forests are the first regulations on development cooperation to be subject to the codecision procedure. For many of us, this is an interesting learning experience. The previous regulation expired at the end of 1999 and since the beginning of this year the Commission has not been able to make new financial commitments on these budget lines, which puts the Commission and the European Union in an increasingly difficult situation. Hence our eagerness to conclude the adoption process in the near future. In this context, we supported the informal negotiations between the Council Presidency and the Parliament's rapporteur in order to arrive at a proposal acceptable to both sides. The main points of disagreement concerned the financial reference amounts, the comitology and the duration of the regulation. I would like to make a brief comment on each of these points. A few words on the financial reference amount. We accept the compromise proposals presented in Amendment No 1. 11. As regards comitology, our position has always been to defend the advisory procedure rather than the management procedure for the Regulation, pursuant to Council Decision 1999/468/EC of 28 June 1999 which states "The management procedure should be followed as regards management measures such as those relating to the application of the common agricultural policy and the common fisheries policy or the implementation of programmes which have significant budgetary implications."

But if we only diagnose the inconsistencies of our policies, we will be utterly frustrated, and what's more, the diagnosis will be negative. As with the systems of forces in classical physics, it makes no sense to set in motion policies that inhibit one another. The result of this absurd game is not zero, but would be a negative value made up of material, financial, and human resources wasted in a useless effort. A negative value that, in politics, is multiplied by the number of results that are always not achieved when one measure cancels out the effects sought by another. In today's globalized world, this truth is even more evident. There are no limits to Community policies either. I am therefore pleased that the Commission and the Council have rediscovered their interest in the coherence of Community policies and that they intend to shape the European Union's development cooperation policy, along with complementarity between national and Community policies and coordination between the Commission's departments. Both the Commission and the Portuguese Presidency include in their respective work plans the desire to integrate coherence into policies that have a very significant impact on developing countries, but without listing concrete measures in which this coherence will be reflected. Both institutions identify the main areas in which this concept should be applied. The Commission, for example, states in its long-term guidelines that the objective of sustainable development must be expressed in strong solidarity, supported by a trade policy that takes common interests into account. The Commission refers to a very important area: trade policy. To this, however, we in Parliament want to add the policies on development aid, agriculture, fisheries, migration, the position in international financial institutions, foreign policy and common security, and structural adjustment aid. The Council, as Mr. Luis Amado said this morning, has spoken on several occasions about the need for coherence—most recently in November 1999, but also on other occasions, such as the Development Councils of May 1999 and June 1997—but without any concrete results. We agree with what the Development Council has outlined—which is very important—and can say little, as someone else has already pointed out in their speech. As Parliament, however, we would like to propose—as has also been said and is called for in the resolution—the creation of an inter-directorate working group, including those responsible for all the policies mentioned, and the creation of an observatory on the coherence of the various Community policies, capable of anticipating the impact of each policy on developing countries and on each other. But the fact is that we want to be realistic, and it is not lost on us that pursuing these objectives of coordination, complementarity, and the most complex of which we are discussing, coherence, requires a more sophisticated policy than we currently have in the European Union. Let us hope—and we do—that the winds of change brought about by the Intergovernmental Conference, the reform of the Commission—which will also affect development services—this new parliamentary term, and the prospects of enlargement will guide us to further perfect a more coherent political union.

I was delighted to learn last week that, for several years, the Commission has been paying close attention to the concept of subsidiarity and referring to it in relations not only between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Union, the Member States, the regions and cities. I hope that Commissioner Barnier, by continuing the dialogue in the regions of Europe, will develop this idea and learn from what he hears. Commissioner, I refer to one of your answers to the previous questions in which you mentioned what I call the possibilities of locking the Treaty in the face of risks of deviance, and in particular the diversification of sanctions that can be imposed on a Member State, pursuant to Article 7, for violation of fundamental freedoms. Do you believe that these proposals, or proposals of this nature, can be part of the mandate of the IGC as it was defined in Helsinki? For my part, I do not have that impression. Aren't you afraid that such sanctions could get out of hand and serve to punish, not human rights violations, but simple differences of opinion, or divergences from the dominant European thinking? Yes, Mr. Bonde, we are going to begin this debate with 700 young people in Brussels. It so happens that they will be working in the institutions and with the Commission, and I think this is a good start for this dialogue with motivated young people. Regarding social protection, I confirm that we have made proposals on the basis of qualified majority or unanimity, without ideology. In your country, Mr. Bonde, as everywhere, I believe we are committed to the proper functioning of the internal market, to the fairest conditions of competition and movement for goods and people. And so that is our rule. We are proposing that certain policies or measures in the areas of taxation, social protection and social security be decided by qualified majority when there is a direct link with the proper functioning of the internal market. Our proposal is not general, nor is it systematic. I am well aware of the sensitivity of these issues of taxation and social protection. I do not think that all national social protection systems should be put in the same mold; that was never the question, but simply to ensure, in a Europe of thirty or twenty-seven countries, the best conditions for the functioning of the internal market without one State being able to block the other 26 or 27. Mr MacCormick, yes, I confirm that this dialogue must go beyond national capitals, that it must go as close as possible to the people, where they live, where they have roots, and if I told you anything else, I would not be agreeing with myself, as Commissioner responsible for regional policy, that is to say one of the most concrete, most visible policies, which is designed to help employment and the quality of life of people in their region, and you will often hear me say that this policy is not only designed for the priority objective of cohesion and solidarity between regions, it is also designed as a complement so that people, wherever they live, can maintain their roots, their traditions, their soul, their identity.

The two presidents rightly did not include this issue in their dossier. Everything must remain in its place and have its own priorities. In my opinion, the two highest representatives of Parliament and the Commission were right to address the most delicate points of the peace process, which, as we know, is still encountering quite a few difficulties. We must absolutely support this peace process, and the attention we are paying to the phenomena denounced in Mrs. Morgantini's question does not contain any prejudice against either party. It reflects our friendly severity, our severity towards the friendly government of Israel, so that these illegalities and irregularities do not recur because they harm everyone. From this point of view too, this initiative must be seen as a positive development, as an initiative that seeks to encourage the peace process in the Middle East. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current trade agreement between Israel and the European Community is indeed quite confusing. Furthermore, it is extremely difficult to determine the origin of the products in question. I therefore also believe that it is desirable to clarify this issue quickly. However, we must take into account a whole series of other essential factors. We all agree that the recent resumption of peace negotiations must be encouraged and not hindered. At the moment, the Israelis and the Palestinians are intensively negotiating their future borders. Any attempt by anyone, any third party, to define, or even impose, the territorial scope is therefore premature. In my opinion, it is preferable to await the outcome of the trilateral working group on rules of origin to be set up at the initiative of Israel, the European Commission and the Palestinians. I am pleased that the Commissioner shares this view. Let us hope that this working group will find a temporary solution to the problem within the existing legal framework, without jeopardizing the peace process, because this process must be considered an absolute priority, especially by the European Community, and Europe cannot put obstacles in its way. There seems to be a remarkable consensus today in the House, but I would like to make a few comments. Here in Parliament, trade in the Middle East has always been an extremely sensitive political issue. We are major donors, but we have unfortunately been sidelined in terms of policy and political influence for too long in the Middle East, and we can contribute positively, as many speakers have pointed out today, just as we did in the case of Northern Ireland. We are major consumers of the products of Israel and the occupied territories, with trade probably being our main political strength in the region, and our encouragement of the promotion of the rule of law is our main asset in our effort to contribute to the peace agreement. Borders are being closed, sometimes arbitrarily, sometimes following a terrorist attack.

Under the system proposed in these directives, third-country nationals wishing to travel to the United Kingdom under the procedures described will be able to do so with a services provision card issued by another Member State, thereby circumventing border controls in the United Kingdom. If any changes are to be made to the current UK border provisions, they should be made by the UK Government and the UK Parliament and not en passant through the European legislative process. For this reason, we will vote against both proposals. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to express my gratitude to the rapporteur and Mr. Wieland, who have taken the time to summarize with striking consistency the various amendments and concerns relating to this report. Both proposals play a fundamental role in transposing the four key principles that lay the foundation for the internal market for the freedom to provide services. The new regulations within the framework of the free provision of cross-border services will certainly benefit the functioning of the internal market and the competitiveness and capacity of businesses. The development of the EU Service Provider Card—and I agree with Mr. Wieland on this point—must necessarily be governed by strict general conditions, since it helps us prevent potential abuses such as illegal immigration and fraudulent contracts. Why do I consider the directive absolutely essential? I see three reasons: the economic weight of third-country national workers in the EU, the competitiveness of businesses, and the proper functioning of the internal market. That is why, on the one hand, I welcome the rigid regulatory framework and, on the other, I call for the control measures adopted by the Member States to be as effective and as simple as possible. Finally, I would like to ask the Commission a question, since it is asked of me time and again. Will the directive jeopardize the accession negotiations? How do you interpret and explain Article 1, given that it plays an important role for our country, which borders numerous new countries, and the accession negotiations? Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, businesspeople have until now been faced with the reality that two of the most important freedoms, especially the free movement of persons and services, could not yet be applied to them. Indeed, they had to submit to endless bureaucratic procedures in the Member States where they wanted to provide a service. There are approximately 13 million third-country nationals residing in European territory. I assume that the number of businesspeople, although exact figures are unknown, is probably not small. Therefore, until now, their access to the entire territory of the Union was not regulated by Community law. The two proposals for directives presented here aim to promote the free movement of services within the internal market by introducing an EU service provider card.

This is an issue that affects the daily lives of citizens and is key from the perspective of the EU's credibility. It must be acknowledged that the EU has already supported, I would even say extraordinarily, the development of the poorest countries. I am reminded of the state of Portugal and Greece when I drove through these countries for the first time, twenty-five years ago. In this regard, French speakers will surely say to the EU "cou de chapeau"—that is, I take off my hat. It is true that the EU deserves to be crowned, but, within countries, the gaps between rich and poor regions remain too great. What are the consequences of this? People react by voting with their feet, that is, by going elsewhere in search of bread. Thus, we are forced to repeatedly build schools and hospitals, the entire infrastructure for the same people and in the same country. This is very expensive and also causes very serious social problems. However, the majority of the population would like to live in their home region, provided they are given the opportunities to do so, that is, if there is work. We must provide that opportunity. This is a moral obligation of the EU and of all of us. I believe the solution is to clearly stimulate the entrepreneurial spirit. And by entrepreneurial spirit, I don't mean exclusively the fact of owning a business; rather, I understand the expression as a state of will. I mean the attitude, the desire of a person to prosper in life, whether they are an employee, a business owner, or a civil servant. What is a fair society? It is a society in which anyone from humble origins can prosper in life, so that their children can enjoy a more comfortable situation. Consequently, optimal regional development is also possible, since citizens do engage in entrepreneurship and work, if they are given the opportunities to do so. In conclusion, I would say that, in this regard, we should take our cue from the United States, where hard work has come back into fashion and success is a manifestation of personal worth, and not an object of envy, as is often the case here in Europe. (FR) Mr. President, as all the speakers have done, I, in turn, would like to thank Mr. Berend and congratulate him on the quality of this work. As with the previous report, this extremely competent and precise analysis, the recommendations it makes, and the observations of Members will be very useful to the Commission in general and, in particular, to the Commissioner responsible for regional policy, as we embark on the programming of the 2000-2006 appropriations. For my part, I would like to make a few observations; first, on the rapporteur's assessment of this sixth periodic report. The honourable Member has emphasized its quality and, if I am not mistaken, has even written that, compared to previous reports, it constitutes a real improvement. On behalf of all the Commission officials and my predecessor, Mrs. Wulf-Mathies, I must tell you that we have been very sensitive to this assessment by the House and by the Honourable Member personally.

That's not so clear in the German text. I would like to ask that it be reviewed again. Otherwise, I would like to thank our rapporteur very much. This is a difficult subject, and I hope that we have presented it in such a way that we can now deal with it better. Mr President, I congratulate the rapporteur on her report. I would like to add that Mrs. Frassoni's conciliatory attitude is a welcome change, as is her willingness to compromise with the other institutions. As far as the IGC is concerned, Mrs. Frassoni represents what the French call "les pures et dures": no compromises, no negotiations with the other institutions; we would rather block the entire conference than deviate from our positions. Nevertheless, Mrs. Frassoni is prepared to accept the progress achieved, which in no way corresponds to Parliament's original position on the issue of comitology. I would like to remind everyone what is at stake here. Parliament essentially criticized four aspects of the committee system as it existed before the new Council decision and the addition of this interinstitutional agreement. First, the entire system is opaque. It is not transparent; hundreds of committee meetings take place, agendas are not known, and no one knows who sits on the committees. This is where the agreed new system will bring about a real improvement. We will find out who is on each committee. We will be informed when the meetings are taking place. We will receive the agendas. We will receive the documents distributed to the committee members. The entire system, despite its continued complex nature, will become more open and transparent. So this is at least progress. Our second criticism is that the system has severely constrained the Commission. We adopt the legal acts of the European Union, the Commission is tasked with implementing them, and then there's a system that hinders the Commission and makes implementation more difficult. Of particular note here is the so-called "contre-filet" procedure, under which the Council could block the Commission by a simple majority even if it could not present an alternative to the implementing measure in question. Here, too, progress has finally been made. The Council can no longer indefinitely block implementing measures after the three-month deadline has expired if there is no qualified majority for them—in other words, if a large portion of the Member States represented in the Council do not reject the measure. This is a more sensible system. This, too, should be considered progress. However, we are less satisfied with our other two points of criticism. First, we criticize the system whereby the Commission is monitored, reviewed, or, if you will, controlled only by a committee appointed by the Member States or the Council, and there is no control by Parliament. The legislative branch, the Council and Parliament, should have equal rights. We confer implementing powers on the Commission, and then only a body appointed by the Council or the Member States acts as an arbitrator and can stop the Commission and halt an implementing measure. Parliament does not have powers of equivalent rank. In the new system, such powers are now to be conferred on us.

Mr. President, the debate we are addressing today is extraordinarily important because the principle of competition has probably been the cornerstone of the internal market. In applying the principle of competition, the legal system has developed Articles 85 to 94, competition policy itself, the review of all state aid, and tax provisions that could alter competition. First, indirect tax provisions; recently, thanks to Commissioner Monti, direct provisions, and most notably the Code of Good Conduct. This has worked fairly well, but, as in the famous film Casablanca, time passes, and it is necessary to adapt the legal system we have applied until now to new circumstances. In this regard, I observed a significant consensus in all the interventions. First, it is necessary that the design of the legal system include clear and comprehensive rules. In this area of the legal system, the existence of confusing rules, regulatory gaps, or rules that merely enshrine vague legal concepts is probably more repugnant than in others. Much more so—as is the case in the second part of this reform—when the application of the legal system is entrusted to national authorities. Third, I believe the role the Commission must play, against the temptation to create independent agencies that would distort the very essence of the Commission, to ensure uniform application by international bodies is important. Fourth and finally—and this has already been mentioned—the international legal order has changed. We saw this at the aborted Seattle Conference and we are seeing it in bilateral conferences with different regions or countries around the world. The principle of jurisdiction must now be universally applied. And we must ensure compliance with environmental and labor standards, to avoid dumping in this area, to ensure that property rights are scrupulously respected, to review state aid, which—as has been said here—in many sectors distorts competition and destroys jobs within our own country, and, ultimately, to ensure that similar conditions are applied to prevent aid and internal distortions from other countries from being transferred to the international arena through, ultimately, cheating. Mr. President, dear Commissioner, Mr. Monti, there is much to be said for Mr. Jonckheer's report on state aid to the steel industry and other sectors. First of all, the report reflects Parliament's determination to systematically reduce state aid to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market. However, many of the report's conclusions are a source of serious concern, at least within our group. For example, the fact that the level and amount of State aid per capita vary considerably across Member States demonstrates the need for such comprehensive studies. Aid stemming from selfish national interests grants unfair advantages to businesses, distorting competition and leading, from a Europe-wide perspective, to an inefficient and unprofitable distribution of scarce financial resources. Nor does the type of aid allocated make any difference.

Water as a human right that should be available free of charge – that sounds very good, but water isn't free, just like housing or food. Only with effective taxation instruments can we achieve better water management and greater conservation. I would also like to add that I support a tighter timetable, clarification of targets and exemption criteria for groundwater and water heavily altered by human activities, as well as the explicit mention of radioactive substances. During the debate, several speakers emphasized the importance of public information and consultation with citizens. I can only emphasize this once again. Public involvement through good information and a consultation process is crucial to our success, as is also reflected in Recital 14. I would like to say to Mr. Bowe that both he and my Scottish colleague can continue to indulge in a glass of Scotch whisky from time to time in good conscience! The Commission has concluded that the extremely small amount of water abstracted for whisky production does not require regulation. Allow me now to comment on a few areas in more detail. Limiting the discharge of pollutants into our waters must be one of the most important objectives, and I am pleased that Parliament's amendments have focused on this. The Commission supports the request to incorporate the OSPAR provisions into the text. However, we must adhere to their precise content and scope. As I have already said, the OSPAR objective and timetable are primarily political commitments. A legally binding timetable would be inconsistent with this. Nevertheless, it is necessary to ensure that Member States and the Community are compelled to take measures that will achieve the objectives set and meet the timetables. For these reasons, I welcome Amendments 6, 10, 14, 24, 58, 60, and 88. In contrast, the Commission cannot accept Amendment 19, whose definition of dangerous substances differs from that in OSPAR. The Commission's proposal contains a clear procedure for selecting these substances, making an additional definition unnecessary. While I agree with the content of Amendments 79 and 106, they go beyond the OSPAR provisions and therefore cannot be adopted. The Commission can, in principle, also accept Amendment 60, which calls for a timetable for the Commission's proposal regarding the emission of substances on the priority list. Amendment 59 calls for the priority list to be kept under continuous review. However, this would lead to legal uncertainty regarding the status of this list and is therefore unacceptable. The request expressed in Amendments 60 and 93 for an indicative list and a list of substances for which insufficient data are available cannot be met. Such lists would have an unclear legal status and would be incompatible with the procedure for adopting the priority list.
