We defend the constitutional rights and prerogatives of the Austrian people, but here in the European Parliament, we have a duty to remember our fundamental values, as stipulated in Article 6 of the Treaty—the values of freedom, democracy, and respect for human rights. All conscientious members of this Assembly believe that these values are universal and indivisible, regardless of race, class, or creed. We must promote and defend these rights, while telling the people of Austria: our fight is not against you. With regard to the Portuguese Presidency's initiative, I would like to say that we support the spirit and political intention behind it. It may not be an ideal initiative in terms of its structure, but we recognize, Mr. President-in-Office, that it is anchored in idealism, and for that reason we are inclined to support it. I share with President Prodi the preference for the Community method, and we must analyze Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty. Article 7 provides for the possibility of suspension in the event of serious and persistent breaches of our fundamental values. We must find, as institutions, a way to measure and give meaning to this, so that it has reality and substance. Then, we can work together to apply the Community method to eradicate this cancer from our environment. I would like to address a few words to Mr. Schüssel, Madam President. Mr. Schüssel is a man with an honorable record in European politics. Now he intends to ride into government on the back of a political tiger. Mr. Schüssel, you are about to assume a very serious responsibility—personal, national, and European. That responsibility, which you now assume, Mr. Schüssel, is to respect the letter and spirit of the European Treaties. Finally, Madam President, this debate touches the heart of our democratic values and institutions and reminds us that the price of freedom is eternal vigilance. On this continent, especially, with the experience of the odious racism we have suffered in the past, which has exacted such a heavy toll, we must insist that today's debate is not about interference with the sovereign rights of a State. It is about the stubborn insistence on the part of the democratically elected institution of this Union that as Europeans, we will not tolerate a return to the past. (Loud applause)

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I apologize for my lateness, but unfortunately, this other political issue is still on the agenda today. The Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy recommends that you release the EUR 35 million, and this recommendation is made because this money can truly benefit the people affected. Our criticism is not so serious that we do not want to help the people there. But this does not mean that we forget to criticize. We would, of course, be much further along in our procedure if the Council administration had not forgotten to inform the European Parliament early on and to officially submit documents. Only in this way could we have conducted truly sensible, in-depth discussions on the matter. I ask the administration to ensure that this cannot happen again in the future. It is only for the sake of the people affected that we are prepared to refrain from drawing any conclusions. However, we must ensure that we introduce certain conditions here. One condition is that the money be given where it can be used sensibly, and not to those who could potentially use it for other purposes. That is, this money should truly be under Mr. Kouchner's purview and not diverted to other areas. Secondly, even if the Commission and the Council take a different position here because they see realistic problems, we believe that the other donors must also fulfill the commitments they have entered into. This is a mission under the jurisdiction of the United Nations, and it cannot be the case that the European Union alone fulfills its obligations! The other donor countries must also fulfill their obligations during this period in the interests of the people affected. This leads me to believe that we must generally address this issue much more intensively in the future, not just with this specific project, but with the entire development in Southeast Europe and the aid being provided there. This is another example of the European Union being willing to help, to provide the money, but of the lack of consistency in its political leadership. We have so many coordinators responsible to so many employers that we'll soon have to appoint a coordinator for the coordinators. Perhaps it would be better, however, if the responsible bodies of the European Union and the other institutions – from the OSCE to the United Nations – would come together to establish a uniform, coordinated procedure and examine how the people there can be truly helped. I know that the Commission is thinking hard about how to achieve this, but if the European Union is doing most of the work, then it should also be in charge there and then implement it in a uniform manner so that the people can truly be helped. It makes no sense for us to have competition between the various international institutions and associations here rather than actual effort being put into helping the people on the ground! When I see that the donor conference for the Stability Pact is being postponed again and again, now until the end of March, that no one knows what the real projects are, that there is no overview of how they can actually be implemented, and that there are only new press conferences being held, then this does not seem to be the way in which we can achieve peace and reconciliation among the people in this part of Europe!

A Common Fisheries Policy must optimally reconcile the needs of species conservation and resource management with those of the economy and the market. This will require more comprehensive, comparable, and uniform data, which, if properly collected and evaluated, will provide us with more general information about the Union's fisheries sector. However, we also hope that the specific characteristics, differences, and diverse fishing conditions and traditions will be better recognized and highlighted, rather than being ignored, restricted, or even eliminated—as has often happened—as a result of a misunderstood approach to harmonizing fisheries policy. Let me cite the Mediterranean, and fisheries in Italy in particular, as an example. After years of the CFP for the Mediterranean being limited to regulations on marketing and operating aid, Regulation 1626 and the measures it contains for the conservation and protection of fish stocks finally establish a responsible fisheries policy to ensure sustainable exploitation of fisheries. This is a worthwhile objective, but its implementation has sometimes failed to take into account the biological characteristics of Mediterranean fish species. A subsequent regulation, Regulation No. 1448 – adopted in 1999, not by chance – allowed for certain exceptions specifically for so-called "certain Mediterranean fisheries." However, this derogation is only valid until 31 May of this year, and the Commission must submit a proposal by then. We hope that this will take into account this fishing system, which is vital to the economy of extensive coastal areas in Italy and, according to the scientific data collected so far, has a certain sustainability from a biological perspective. Thank you, Commissioner Fischler. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:00 a.m. Control of certain fish diseases The next item is the report (A5-0036/2000) by Mr Hudghton, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 93/53/EEC laying down minimum Community measures for the control of certain fish diseases. Infectious salmon anaemia (ISA) is a contagious viral disease first recorded in Norway in 1984, later in Canada (1986), and finally in Scotland in May 1998, thus being the first time it has been detected in the European Union. Although the virus has been found in other species, the disease itself has so far been limited to salmon. The virus cannot survive above 25ºC, and scientists therefore agree that it poses no threat to human health. It simply cannot survive in warm-blooded creatures. The Scottish salmon farming industry is the largest of its kind in the EU, and its farms are located in outermost regions. It provides employment for approximately 6,500 people and generates approximately €800 million annually. It is therefore clear that this problem is of particular importance for Scotland, but it is of utmost importance for all parts of Europe that this disease be contained and, if possible, eradicated. Current directives prohibit vaccination; instead, all fish from an infected farm must be culled, regardless of whether they are infected or not.

By ratifying the Treaty of Amsterdam, all Member States declared that they wish to give the fight against fraud against the European Union's financial interests the same priority as they do against fraud against their own interests. However, the reality is that only the first four Member States have yet to ratify the agreement, adopted in 1995. The Commission fully agrees with the rapporteur that this situation is unacceptable. A legal act, a directive, that provides a uniform definition of fraudulent activities, such as money laundering or corruption, and establishes a binding obligation to prosecute them, can take an important step forward in this regard, and I will therefore propose that the Commission consider this step very promptly. The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is one of the most important instruments with which the Commission fulfills its obligation to combat fraud. The Commission has therefore not accepted that the two European banks, the ECB and the EIB, have denied OLAF's right to conduct investigations within these two institutions, citing their independent status. The Commission therefore decided at its last meeting to bring legal proceedings against these two banks, and I hope that Parliament will approve this step. The second recommendation of this report concerns the review of OLAF's investigative measures in the various European institutions for their legality. The OLAF Supervisory Committee, which was set up at the same time as OLAF was founded, is tasked with ensuring OLAF's independence, but cannot perform the task mentioned in the report of monitoring OLAF's internal investigative activities. In this, I fully agree with the Supervisory Committee and the rapporteur. This means that there is a gap here that needs to be filled, and I will examine the approach proposed in the report with a view to further developing it. However, I would like to make one request: I believe that we must prevent the debate on expanding OLAF's legal basis from leading to the misunderstanding that OLAF does not currently have sufficient authority. No, it must not lead to an undermining of OLAF's authority, and I also think that this is not what the rapporteur has in mind. I therefore ask you to fully support OLAF's work in its current form. Thank you very much, Commissioner Schreyer. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. Votes (Parliament adopts the Commission's proposal.) Heaton-Harris (PPE-DE). Mr President, a point of order. I ask for an explanation of Rules 133(2) and 138(4). Both rules concern voting. Is it not the case that, with the exception of roll-call votes, votes should first be taken by a show of hands, with use of the electronic voting system only being made in cases of doubt? Yes, Mr President, I called for a show of hands, as no political group had requested a roll-call vote. As you know, a roll-call vote or electronic verification is only provided for if Members request it. In this case, I can assure you that an overwhelming majority voted in favor of the directive we have just voted on. Mr President, I was not referring to this specific vote, but to votes in general.

Joint resolution on Austria Madam President, the Europe of Nations Group has not signed the joint PPE/DE-PSE resolution on the political situation in Austria following the formation of a coalition government in that country between the conservatives and the national liberals of Jörg Haider. In fact, this PPE/DE-PSE resolution welcomes the initiative promoted by fourteen Member States to exert pressure on Austria by organising a sort of diplomatic boycott. What strikes us most is that this joint intervention boasts the principles of the Treaty as if it were written somewhere that, from now on, the free and democratic expression of a people can be annulled by the will of the Heads of Government of neighbouring countries who, in this case, have been careful not to consult their respective peoples. Regardless of the verbal excesses of Jörg Haider - which we in fact condemn - the Austrians have made a democratic choice and we must respect it. It seems clear to us that the left wing of the European Parliament, in contact with the Austrian left wing, which was also defeated in the elections, has engineered an exquisitely political maneuver by recalling the memory of a sinister era, fortunately over. Although the comparison of Haider to Hitler lacks credibility, it has partially achieved its goal by making some PPE-DE deputies waver. Beyond this political maneuver, what the majority of the European Parliament fears more than anything is that the questioning in Austria of a right-left cohabitation, which has corrupted its political life, will soon extend to the European system of co-management, which has caused equally disastrous consequences. To avoid this questioning, this majority is prepared to do anything, even to annul the results of free elections, to establish a thought police, to establish a new form of totalitarianism. Madam President, on behalf of the members of the National Front, the Vlaams Blok and the Italian Social Movement, I ask this question: who is pulling the strings of the unprecedented interference in Austrian affairs in which the European Union has taken part, in violation of international law, the Treaties and morality? Is the hysteria spontaneous? Is it the fruit of pure stupidity or, more likely, of a precise strategy, the same everywhere in the world? Who is imposing their will on the European nations, claiming to prevent them from deciding their own destiny? Some hidden alliance? The government in Washington? The Israeli government? Or their socialist spokesmen who, in this Chamber, have the nerve to impose their values on us? What are the values of these socialists, who built their electoral fortune in the last century by deluding the underprivileged with the idea of greater social justice, and who today are nothing but the party of protected civil servants, trade unionists and state capitalism? What are the values of the Belgian Socialist Party that is struggling between scandals of pedophilia and corruption, passing through those of Vandam, like the Agusta scandal? What are the values of the French Socialist Party that has blackmailed all the municipalities where it held the majority in the Urba, Sages, Graco affairs?

I have also submitted, on behalf of the EDD Group, a draft resolution on this matter. Mr. President, in recent years, oil tankers have caused repeated disasters around the world without any appreciable or effective measures having been taken to prevent them. This time, the situation is particularly serious, not least because it affects a large European state, a fact that could happen again at any time. We urgently need a directive to limit these risks. The 15 rules we have are apparently not enough. They offer at least—without claiming to be exhaustive—three guarantees: no oil tanker or cargo ship fit for scrapping may now call at any European Union port; all parties involved, including the consignee of the transport, must be liable for the damage caused and must take out adequate insurance policies. Only in this way will it be possible to ensure that those affected can assert their right to compensation for the damage suffered. However, we must be clear that the long-term objective must be much broader. In other words, we must assess the true costs of our entire energy supply system. Mr. President, let me begin by thanking Commissioner De Palacio for her clear, appropriate, and also very firm response. Thank you very much. This also means that I have great respect, in any case, for the communication from the meeting she sent on January 10, but also for the measures she announced today. The Erika disaster shows that when proper traffic and transport regulations are lacking at European and international level, nature and the environment suffer. The damage inflicted, including in environmental matters, cannot be quantified in monetary terms. That is why we are now holding this joint debate with my colleagues from transport and environmental protection. During the Christmas holidays, when the Dutch media were paying attention to the Erika disaster, I looked online to find out what action was available, especially after Prime Minister Jospin had said that Europe should do more. What I deduced from all this is that there is actually enough regulation, but the problem lies in the lack of control. Let me mention a few issues here, which have also been highlighted by the Commissioner. First, "port-state control," the 25% of ships that must be controlled. I not only believe that this 25% should be maintained, but we must also ensure that it is controlled more, that is, that this 25% should be increased. Furthermore, when a ship is no longer permitted to sail, not only must the facts be controlled, but there must also be a legal system that establishes: it is advisable that it no longer sail, or it is no longer permitted to sail. But this does not exist. Mr. President, with regard to this issue, I would like to see action taken. Finally, regarding the technical requirements for ships, my colleagues have also just pointed out that, since 1999, oil tankers in the United States must have double hulls.

Is this the message we wish to convey? Furthermore, one point in particular is close to my heart: Member States must be able, when they wish, to decide to set up transnational water transfers. This type of project reflects the principle of regional cohesion and solidarity that we have always defended. In this spirit, it should benefit, largely, from the support of the European Union, within the framework of the promotion of trans-European networks and regional policy (through the Structural Funds). I would like to point out that our Assembly adopted, two years ago, an own-initiative report on the technical feasibility of trans-European hydraulic networks and I would appreciate it if the European Commission could soon inform the European Parliament of the follow-up it has given to this report. (ES) We have witnessed the transformation of a report that was primarily concerned with the quality of water in Europe into an instrument of trade war. We all agree that water quality is a goal of prime importance, especially given the adverse consequences that the development of the accelerated industrial growth model has on nature. It is clear that the logic of private benefit inherent in this model has been harmful, which is why the polluter pays principle is adequate to address these consequences. But beyond these principles, we must consider water as a common good that cannot be subject to market rules. Surprisingly, I imagine that with the best intentions, this ecological objective has been transformed into an instrument of commercial warfare by making consumers, especially in the agricultural sector, bear the cost of installations and procedures to ensure good water quality. In fact, water becomes yet another commodity subject to market laws. Thus, the neoliberal model is being applied to water. When we do not differentiate between countries and regions where water is abundant and poses no problems, and regions where drought and low rainfall make it a scarce commodity, limiting their possibilities for minimal economic and social development, we are already distorting the ecological principle into a devastating weapon. In the same vein, it is somewhat ironic to complicate the possibility of sharing this commodity, which in some areas is scarce, while those who live in regions where water is abundant advise those living in regions affected by drought to restrict water. It is this lack of sensitivity and solidarity that motivated my vote, as an MEP from one of the dry Mediterranean agricultural regions but with prospects like the Murcia region. On behalf of the Labour Party in the European Parliament, I would like to point out that, although we supported most of the Lienemann report, we have certain reservations. The date set in the report – 2020 – is unrealistic and impossible to meet, but the date set by the Council – 2034 – is too far away. We therefore believe that conciliation will set a more realistic date.

Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal for a directive on end-of-life vehicles that we are dealing with today aims, on the one hand, to ensure a high level of environmental protection within the Union, but also to maintain the proper functioning of the internal market in this sector. A few words to say that, of course, historic and vintage vehicles must be excluded from the scope of this directive. Cars too, and I think we will all agree on this, are part of our cultural heritage. Having said that, one of the stumbling blocks concerns Article 12, that is, the date of application of the directive. The solution proposed by Parliament, namely 18 months from the entry into force of the directive itself, for vehicles placed on the market for the first time, is not very realistic. The European car fleet includes several tens of millions of cars that will have to be withdrawn even though they were not at all designed to be recycled. The common position was more practicable because it provided for the 2006 date for vehicles already in circulation. This would also give companies time to build up funds to cover additional expenditure. Like my group, I will support the common position in this respect, which I believe represents a balanced compromise between the constraints on companies and the necessary progress in environmental protection. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament must make an important decision today, namely whether it will commit itself to environmental and consumer protection that opens up a new way forward, or whether it will be prepared to lackey the German car industry, as the amendments tabled by Mr Florenz, Mr Lange and others suggest. The credibility of Parliament as a pioneer in environmental protection is at stake. It would be extremely disheartening if Parliament were to take more than one step back from the positions of the governments of the 14 Member States and the Commission on producer responsibility and environmental protection. The aim pursued by Mr Florenz and Mr Lange is clear: to destroy the directive! By proposing to share responsibility, they are aiming to deprive the polluter pays principle of all substance and to nip product innovation in the bud. By placing a whole series of obstacles, they are aiming solely to prevent a material flow policy and, by imposing approvals for different models, they want to postpone the implementation of the directives by at least 12 years, which is completely unacceptable. I therefore appeal, especially to the German Members of Parliament: do not allow such serious political damage to be done today! The Green-Red government leading the Federal Republic has certainly not done itself credit in the debate on the End-of-Life Vehicles Directive. Let us not continue this trend! The complaints about competitive disadvantages are ridiculous if it is really only a question of harming the German car industry! Behave as representatives of the people and do not allow yourselves to be degraded to representatives of Volkswagen! Vote for environmental and consumer protection as well as for innovation in the car industry and recycling! Mr President, this directive has been under discussion since 1997 and it is time to reach an agreement. Since I broadly agree with the positions of my colleague Mr Sjöstedt and the Green representative, Mr De Roo, I will not use the two minutes at my disposal, but will focus on just two issues.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not need to repeat what the rapporteur and my colleague, Mr Coelho, have said before me. All of this is indeed correct and relevant. The euro can easily be counterfeited. We are currently in a dangerous transition phase in which an unprecedented phenomenon is emerging from a criminal law perspective: a currency that has not yet been used, not yet put into circulation, but is only used as banknote money, can nevertheless already be counterfeited, even though the offence of counterfeiting is not punishable in this specific case because the currency is not yet in circulation. This is therefore a very complex problem. Clearly, if we do not act quickly – I agree with my colleague, Mr Cederschiöld – counterfeit euros can already be produced, and their putting into circulation cannot be subject to any criminal sanction. I would like to point out in passing that this might be an attractive prospect for some. What is the European Union doing to address this possibility? A series of relevant points, which our colleague, Mrs Cederschiöld, has detailed for us. In relation to what has been described, Parliament should focus less on the content of the framework decision and the report drawn up by Mrs Cederschiöld than on the procedures currently applied. Indeed, the way in which the European Parliament was consulted by the Council, which is by far the least democratic institution in Europe, insults the concept of democracy. We have received for consultation a text that the Council itself has been tinkering with for a very long time, a text which, moreover, is only a partial success – but I will come to that immediately. The European Parliament must now take a position, within three months, on this complex, difficult and, in some places, contradictory text proposed by the Council. It is only thanks to the considerable investment made by our colleague, Mr Cederschiöld, and to the fact that Parliament has resigned itself to not making use of its democratic right, which allows it to apply its consultation procedures with sufficient time and all the texts translated into each language, that we can now give our opinion within the short timescale requested by the Council and thus reach the decision that must be made in March. For a subject as important as protection against counterfeiting and the criminal law harmonisation that it requires, we really cannot work at the infernal pace imposed on us by the Council. That is why I wish to state very clearly on behalf of my group that we had long discussions with our colleague, Mr Cederschiöld, to determine whether it was reasonable to work under these conditions. We came to the conclusion that it was not, but that given the importance of the subject, we agreed to accept such a procedure. The proposed framework decision constitutes undeniable progress. Only the legal certainty desired by the Council - Mrs Cederschiöld has already alluded to this - will ultimately not be fully achieved because, as regards the minimum standards required, the minimum criminal standard and, above all, the application of the same criminal standards in each Member State - even those in which the euro has not yet been introduced, but in which it could theoretically be falsified - these gaps have not been filled.

I can only say that these are the truly tough nuts that need to be cracked once and for all! Mr. President, first of all, I would like to sincerely congratulate my colleague, Mr. Van Hulten. It is nice to be able to say that he belongs to our delegation, and I think I can be a little proud of him. In any case, congratulations on your report. Mr. President, the resignation of the Commission has caused a feeling of fear among many officials in the hierarchical and bureaucratic ranks. I believe the whole argument about making a change towards a culture of responsibility is essential. In the Committee on Development, I have seen firsthand how thousands of projects have come to a standstill; how, sometimes, up to 80 percent of the money has not been invested, sometimes creating a huge money pit. And this, not because it is not absolutely necessary, not because there are no good proposals, but because the entire system clogs itself up. Lack of accountability, too much ex ante, too little ex post, and from this emerges a culture based on very few truly effective investments. Spending money efficiently and organizing all the work around this—it would be fantastic if we could signal in that direction with this report. I eagerly hope that the contribution we will make here, if the Commission's first draft report becomes an official report on 1 March, will allow us to see real changes. Without a doubt, this will be a service, Mr. President, rendered to the European public, and thanks to the results we show, we will regain and recover some of what we have obviously lost in recent years. This is the best support we can give to European democracy. If we thereby emerge from the culture of the 1950s and move into the next century, we will have a pleasant experience here. Mr. President, first of all, my congratulations to Michiel Van Hulten for his first report. It was a difficult trial, but in the Netherlands, we have a nice saying: You learn to swim faster if you jump in early. Your Honor, I believe that after this test, you can qualify for the Olympics. There are two points that, in my opinion, deserve special attention from the ELDR. First, the individual responsibility of Commissioners. This must be regulated during the IGC. We prefer, however, that this important issue not be left entirely in the hands of the Council, and we have therefore tabled an amendment calling for an interinstitutional agreement between the Commission and Parliament, in order to ensure a kind of fallback position and not leave our fate entirely in the hands of the Council. The second point, and my colleague, Mr. Mulder, has already said this, is that the ELDR believes that the European Parliament should be vetted by independent experts. This will go a long way to restoring, in particular, the confidence of European citizens in this institution. We cannot credibly oppose this reformed Commission until we examine our consciences and the European Parliament also puts its affairs in order.

You will find the content of this framework in the Accession Partnership Priorities, which the Commission and the Council defined last year and which are now being implemented in the corresponding planning and management of projects. Contrary to this criticism, I would say that one can deplore a lack of coherence in certain areas of European policy, but that in this case I would like to claim that the Commission and the Council have developed a very clear, transparent and coherent policy. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, after the Commissioner has shown us in an extremely coherent manner that the then President of the Council and his Federal Minister for European Affairs were responsible for the lack of coherence, perhaps you could help the Commissioner and us to make this decision. It would be very helpful if you could respond positively to my questions on the financial perspective up to 2004 and on heading 7, or if you could at least state – as the Commissioner will try to get the Commission to do – that the Portuguese Presidency intends to compensate for the lack of coherence at the time with such a commitment. Mr President, I believe that the question raised by my friend Elmar Brok will be examined by the Council. I believe that the criticism levelled at the previous Presidency is irrelevant. I believe that what was done by the previous Presidency in defining the financial perspective was excellent work, regardless of who was involved in that work. In any case, the question he is asking is important, and we in the Council will continue to support the proposals that the Commission will present in this regard. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I understood that our colleague Mr Brok was referring to an even earlier Presidency. Mr President, Commissioner Verheugen has not answered my very specific question on the MEDA financial instrument. I would ask him to answer it, as his answer will determine our voting behaviour on various amendments. Commission. (DE) Dear Mr Poos, I apologize. There was some confusion at the precise moment you asked your question. So, as far as MEDA is concerned, Malta and Cyprus can participate in the supraregional programmes, but not the national ones, because their income is too high. Thank you very much, Commissioner Verheugen! The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday. Question Time (Council) Question No. 1 of (H-0022/00): Subject: Control of access to Community waters by oil tankers Following the sinking of the oil tanker Erika off the French coast, which caused an oil spill, what measures does the Council propose to adopt to control access to Community waters by oil tankers flying flags of convenience and not complying with Community safety standards? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 24 January, the Council considered the consequences of the sinking of the oil tanker Erika in December.

The European Commission's Sixth Report offers some very valuable conclusions. I would like to briefly summarize two of them; the rapporteur has already mentioned them: one positive and one negative. The first concerns the fact that significant progress has been made in territorial and social cohesion throughout the Union, and that Community funds represent an important, if not decisive, factor in reducing regional disparities. The negative aspect is that these major efforts have had a greater impact on converging the GDP and productivity of European regions than on converging their employment levels. Therefore, it is necessary to link structural funding more closely to job creation. This, Commissioner, is the first priority for the coming period. Therefore, Mr President, I ask my distinguished colleagues to support this report, and, like other colleagues before me, I call on the Commission to carefully consider the conclusions of its Sixth Periodic Report when planning for the period 2000-2006. Mr President! Commissioner! Dear colleagues, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the factual consideration given to the proposed amendments received during the committee's discussion. The sixth periodic report provides a good basis for assessing the implementation of regional policy objectives in the Union and shows that, despite all efforts, growth is uneven. The regions of Central Europe continue to experience particularly rapid growth, with growth in the strong economic centers occurring at a pace that is above the European average, while many southern and northern European regions are progressing considerably more slowly. What is now needed is an in-depth analysis of why regional policy is not achieving the desired success in all areas. Is this due to bureaucracy, or have the differences between the regions, the great distances, very cold or hot climates, sparse populations, and harsh conditions not been sufficiently taken into account? How is the Union managing to meet the challenges of global development in such a way that even the less developed regions can keep pace? It is also important to examine the impact of enlargement on the Structural Funds and the development of the outermost regions. Member States must not shirk their responsibilities here either. Some countries have violated the principle of co-financing and reduced national funding for the regions while increasing the Union's regional aid. This has been to the detriment of regional policy. In the future, we must also consider establishing indicators that will enable measures to be targeted at the right time and in the right place. Uncontrolled migration, for example, has not been sufficiently taken into account. In this context, too, the crucial importance of small and medium-sized enterprises as a driver of employment and regional development must be emphasized. The introduction of the latest technology and know-how by companies in lagging regions is very important. Our group supports the adoption of this report. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, to date, the European Community's regional policy has failed to significantly reflect the existing disparities in per capita performance.

That is why we expressed our great satisfaction with the decisions taken on this matter at the Helsinki Summit in December. An overly ambitious programme would currently risk delaying the enlargement process. This is not what we want and that is why we voted against the report. However, we fully agree with our colleagues that the Intergovernmental Conference must be transparent so that citizens can see how our work is progressing. (SV) We are pleased that a limited agenda was set for the Intergovernmental Conference at the Helsinki Summit. Potential future Member States must also participate in the formation of the future EU and have an influence on it. The 1999 European Parliament elections made it abundantly clear that citizens do not support the arguments for an ever more federalist EU in the spirit of Brussels. With the opening of the next IGC, the European Union process is once again topical. Once again, the debate will be monopolized by heads of state and government. That is to say, fifteen people will discuss and decide behind closed doors the fate of more than 350 million individuals. We can therefore understand the disinterest of the people in the face of European construction being carried out behind their backs and far from their concerns. Indeed, one only has to look at the agenda of the IGC: the institutions, enlargement, and autonomous defense. In reality, it is about strengthening the executive power, developing annexations to the liberalism of Eastern countries, and relaunching the militarization of Europe, notably by increasing military budgets. Social Europe, used as a foil by the EU, has completely disappeared from the agenda. All this only legitimizes the development, on a European scale, of resistance movements anxious to impose a social charter that would harmonize the main demands of workers from above. This is why I am voting against the report. I voted for the resolution that gives a favorable opinion on the convening of the IGC because it enshrines the philosophy of the Portuguese Presidency, which enjoys the support of a large majority of Parliament, of opening up the IGC agenda, beyond the points strictly related to the rebalancing of power between Member States, large and small, as originally described in the convening of the Helsinki Council. Unfortunately, in the topics addressed in the resolutions relating to the matters of the Treaty on European Union that will be subject to revision, nothing indicates, to date, the need to revise its Article 7, which deals with the suspension of a State in the event of a serious and persistent violation of the "founding" principles of the Union, set out in Article 6. As we see with the current crisis with Austria, the Union has the right to defend itself. The legal mechanisms provided for by the Treaties are nevertheless weak, difficult to apply politically and legally, they do not organize the powers of the institutions and they do not guarantee judicial treatment for a process of the highest importance, namely, the condemnation of a Member State to suspension.

Your Honor, with regard to the Presidency's ability to support the actions of non-governmental organizations, particularly in the specific case of the fight against homelessness, I would like to tell you that these kinds of initiatives are worthy of our approval, and we are fully prepared to consider supporting them. We have collaborated with Portuguese non-governmental organizations and with some initiatives that these same non-governmental organizations presented within the Portuguese Presidency's framework for action, which we link to the set of concerns underlying our own program. We do not have any specific initiatives in this regard, but we do not rule out the possibility that an initiative from non-governmental organizations proposed to us in this regard could be examined during our Presidency: this, it should be said, falls within the scope of the Council's powers. But we must understand that anything that might affect the Commission's right of initiative must, of course, be done through the Commission itself. Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, you've told us a lot about the future: what the Commission is going to do, what the Presidency is going to do in Lisbon, etc. And you've told us something that frightened me, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council. You said that in Lisbon you're going to discuss a more dynamic and competitive development. I've begun to get scared, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, because that's where social exclusion comes from, at least in part. I don't see how you're going to be able to answer, if you have opinions like that. What I've asked, and I'm asking again, is the following: What are the views of the Portuguese Presidency on issues such as those, for example, presented by the networks for combating poverty and exclusion, on the division of labor and social security, on the implementation of fiscal policy, especially of speculative capital, on the policy of income redistribution? I would like an answer on this, whether the Portuguese Presidency has this in mind and intends to do something. The Honorable Member must understand that the effective capacity of a Presidency to reverse general social or economic trends in its six months of office is indeed limited. I believe it is perfectly clear that our capacity is also closely linked to the Commission's own right of initiative. I have spoken of the extraordinary European Council and the initiative Portugal took to hold it, and I have referred to the future because there are two complementary ways of viewing this issue of social exclusion: one is the set of immediate measures that must be adopted to address its specific effects; the second is the creation of conditions of international competitiveness that allow us to improve the economic fabric within the European Union, with positive side effects on the problems of social exclusion. Therefore, the Portuguese Presidency does not have any miracle keys to respond in six months to issues that have been going on forever. It is available to act on Commission proposals in these areas, in all areas that fall within the Community's competence. It naturally has the potential and the benefit of encouraging the full range of measures that may be presented, particularly by non-governmental organizations, but also within traditional intergovernmental coordination in these areas.

This is the programme for the next five years in the area of internal security, freedom, citizens' rights and judicial cooperation. This document, in its brevity, is nothing but a farce! A farce precisely because we know and appreciate the work of Commissioner Vitorino and what is presented on paper is in clear contrast with reality. A document of this kind is not at all the basis for a scoreboard. It has been welcomed and praised as a great achievement, but personally I remain convinced of the need for a scoreboard. Parliament wants to seriously examine the basis for a programme in which future developments in this policy area will be included. We are calling for minimum standards for asylum procedures, in order to be able to provide timely assistance to refugees but also to provide clarity for those who are not. We want tools that will allow us to prevent abuse. We want a Community immigration policy to be launched that obviously also takes into account the integration capacity of the Member States; we also need to strengthen the operational functions of EUROPOL, for example, by adopting very concrete measures in this area to combat organised crime. We are taking these tasks seriously and enthusiastically and we ask the Commission to do the same even when it is simply a matter of submitting a document! Madam President, I too applaud the Commission's initiative to present us with a document on its strategic objectives for the next five years, with the hope, however, that it intends to correct, in subsequent documents, the excessive generalities and the vagueness of the text submitted to us today. Having said that, Madam President, here I am again crying in the wilderness about the absence of a fisheries policy. It is truly astonishing that in the strategic objectives for the next few years, the Commission does not include the process of reviewing one of its common policies in view of the reform that is to be finalised in 2002. This review process is undoubtedly the most important event that will affect the fisheries sector for many years to come. It seems, however, that this is not the opinion of the Commission, which has nevertheless been given the task of presenting to the Council and Parliament, by 2001, a report on the functioning of the common fisheries policy over the last decade, which will serve as a basis for the Council to take the appropriate decisions to amend it. In reality, the revision process has already begun for many institutions, such as for example the European Parliament, which already in 1998 drew up and approved a report highlighting all the problems and shortcomings that the common fisheries policy still suffers from. We have asked for a minimum timetable for the revision several times without receiving a response. A period of less than two years is not a long time, given that, we must not forget, the fisheries policy is experiencing an anomalous situation as regards the rules of the internal market and that these anomalies should be resolved within the reform process.

Madam President, distinguished Members, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to thank Mr. Procacci for the report he has prepared. But I would also like to thank the committees that collaborated and Parliament for the broad support they have given to the LEADER+ initiative. This initiative aims to give rural areas new impetus to develop and test new and original approaches, approaches that should later be included as models in the general programmes. I am also pleased that Parliament essentially supports the Commission's concept that the LEADER+ programme should be implemented in all rural regions, that higher priorities should be introduced, and that, above all, active cooperation and interconnection of rural areas must be encouraged. In this regard, I note that Parliament shares the Commission's view that priority should be given to implementing LEADER+ in the form of global grants. To answer some specific questions that have been raised here, I must also confirm that we wish to have the broadest possible participation and partnership in LEADER+. Various groups, whether environmental organizations or employment-focused groups, have the opportunity to collaborate in the drafting of Commission directives. The resources made available during this period are not fewer, but rather more. I would also like to point out that setting up an observatory is nothing new. There has also been an observatory for LEADER I and LEADER II. This office's sole objective is to maintain the interconnection of specific LEADER groups. Funding for this observatory should not exceed 2% of LEADER resources. Regarding the possibility of projects focused on training and development, I must say that this is precisely a point we have now integrated into the new rural development policy, so that, from our point of view, it is no longer necessary to do so within the framework of LEADER. I now turn to the content of the report. In point 14, Parliament urges the Commission to submit a report on the evaluation of LEADER II without delay. I would simply like to point out that at the moment this does not make much sense, since, as in the past—specifically, until the end of 2002—funds can be withdrawn under LEADER II. For this reason, we believe it makes more sense to conduct this evaluation once the program concludes. We will, of course, do so and will send you a report on it. In Item 18, Parliament proposes the production of a compendium of examples of successful initiatives. In this regard, I cannot but say that one already exists. It has already been prepared by the Commission, and I can make it available to any Member of this House who is interested. In Item 21, Parliament insists that the guidelines for LEADER+ must be adopted quickly so that the programs can begin.

We find you, as always, faithful to the fundamental values, to those principles that have always guided your action. You also reminded us of your 1994 speech, which you yourself described as provocative; in this regard, it must be said that utopias can sometimes be productive and we were able to evaluate together the path taken. You also appropriately highlighted the fundamental role of civil society, not only in relation to the candidate countries but also within each country of the European Union, to restore citizens' confidence and credibility to social solidarity, which we need so much. Finally, summarizing the concept that struck me most in your speech, you wanted to explain to us that, beyond the economic aspects, the construction of Europe must first and foremost be a work of the spirit. We sincerely hope to continue this work with you. Thank you, Mr President. (The formal sitting ended at 12.40 p.m.) ACP-EU Joint Assembly The next item on the agenda is the debate on the annual report A5-0032/2000 by Mr Corrie on behalf of the Committee on Development and Cooperation on the results of the work of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly in 1999. Mr President, I had hoped to be speaking at 9 a.m. rather than 9 p.m. to present the report. I hope that the number of Members present in the Chamber does not indicate a lack of interest in development work in overseas countries. However, it is standard practice for the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly to be presented to Members of the European Parliament and I have the pleasant task of doing so this evening. Once again I can report on two very important sessions, one in Strasbourg and the other in Nassau. In many ways it was the end of an old era and the beginning of a new one. The ACP-EU Joint Assembly is a unique organisation on the world political scene. Where else do 86 nations come together to discuss issues of common interest? The Strasbourg session was the last one chaired by Lord Plumb. In recognition of his outstanding work in difficult times, the Bureau of the Joint Assembly in Nassau elected him Honorary President, and now that he has come to the end of his career we wish him all the best for the years to come. The two sessions were dominated by negotiations on the renewal of the Lomé Convention: I look forward to the new Convention being signed and to all the countries concerned ratifying it as soon as possible. I remember that at the last mid-term review, when I was rapporteur, the then Commissioner Marín said that there would not be another. Well, he was wrong and I would like to pay tribute to Philip Lowe and his team who worked so successfully behind the scenes to conclude a new Convention in very difficult circumstances. I was also very pleased to hear the statement this morning from Commissioner Nielson, who has worked tirelessly to ensure the success of the negotiations. I pay tribute to him in particular for the success achieved, but also to Mrs Kinnock and her working group for their commitment to the future of Lomé.

Now that you, Mr Prodi, and your predecessors have deprived citizens of their right to self-determination, the quality of the work carried out in Brussels must improve significantly and must be carried out in full transparency so that citizens at least have the impression that they are being heard. I would just like to make a comment about what Mr Dell'Alba said about the dream of the founding fathers: Just read the memoirs of Jean Monnet. His dream was to create what he called a small, practical secretariat. It is certainly not this small secretariat that Mr Prodi is now president of. Madam President, this morning, Commission President Prodi outlined the European Union's ambitious objectives for the next five years, laudable objectives indeed, to ensure a strong and effective European presence in the world: ensuring the success of enlargement, meeting the challenge of selling electronic Europe, and introducing better principles of governance. We understand that Europeans, especially the younger generation, need to be given a broad view of where Europe will be in the years ahead. But how can we succeed when available resources are limited and the credibility of our institutions is undermined? We must make this project correspond to reality. Here, there are three elements I would like to outline. First, we need a thriving European economy. We must ensure that unemployment rates continue to fall throughout Europe, consolidate the trend toward privatization and deregulation, encourage the introduction of information technology and Internet literacy, and show that e-Europe is a positive initiative. However, we must avoid falling back into the pitfalls of old-fashioned regulation, which stifles individual initiative and entrepreneurship. We must not fear globalization, but we must ensure that we understand its political impact within the network society. Without a thriving European economy, we will not be able to meet the challenges ahead, and especially the challenge of enlargement. Secondly, we must ensure that we only legislate when necessary – in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. Doing less, but better – a central point of the last Commission – must also become the objective of this Commission. We will examine this point in detail when we move on to the annual programmes of legislative proposals. Mr Bonde rightly said that there is this image of doing less but better, and then, suddenly, we see that the annual programme for the year 2000 has 500 proposals and recommendations, which seems to indicate a completely different direction. We must establish priorities and ensure that the money is used wisely in each of these programmes. Finally, we must ensure that the European Commission is reformed properly, genuinely. Yes, the Commission – guardian of the Treaties – is supposed to be an independent body, but it must also be accountable to the citizens of Europe through our Parliament. The problem of information, to which Mr Bonde has just referred, is being treated as if it were a mere possibility, with the Commission appearing to restrict the information to which, as citizens and as parliamentarians, we are entitled under the Treaties.

The advent of the euro at the beginning of last year has unleashed enormous competitive tensions among European companies which are being met by a wave of mergers of unprecedented proportions. For example, last year's figures put the total value of mergers in Europe at €1.4 trillion, or seven times the level of the peak in the previous European merger boom, 1990. This poses enormous challenges to competition policy, which I hope can be met, as it is certain that many of these mergers will be aimed at protecting companies' profit margins from competition rather than simply boosting productivity and enabling companies to operate on a larger scale. Commissioner Monti and his colleagues face a challenge of gigantic proportions and the Liberal Democrat and Reform Group is concerned about a possible dilution of competition policy, both in terms of scrutiny of mergers and in terms of policing restrictive practices. The delegation of powers to national authorities is a good thing, but we would like to underline an assumption made by Mr von Wogau in his report regarding the need for constant monitoring of national authorities to prevent any deviations in the European component and we would like, in particular, for the Commissioner to reassure us that there will be random checks in this area. Mr President, in the limited time available to me, I would like to support the work done by all the rapporteurs and to agree with many of the statements heard in this debate, and in particular with Mr Jonckheer in criticising the excessive aggregation of data and in underlining the need for transparency and a socio-economic assessment of aid. I also agree with the criticism regarding the insufficient attention given to the development of Article 82, especially when we are witnessing abuses of a dominant position in a context of market concentrations. As a Member of the Basque Country, I would like to express my full support for the measures to implement the necessary market competition. If I say this, it is to dispel any doubts that may have arisen from the criticisms we have levelled at the Commission in general, and at Commissioner Monti in particular, for having opened proceedings against the incentives paid to Basque companies, considering them to be State subsidies. Our disagreement is due to the fact that the Commission still shows that it does not understand the nature of the general system and of co-responsibility of our legal system, by virtue of which the Basque tax provisions have the same nature, the same foundation and the same purposes as the provisions of the Member States of the European Union and are applied generally to all taxpayers who, on the basis of the rules governing the relationship between the State and the Regions in fiscal matters, must comply with them. Mr President, Commissioner, it is true, we need competition! We need it to reduce unemployment to a minimum, to have high-level health care, for social justice, to have high social standards; then of course - and these are criteria of competition from a national economy - we also need competition between companies: maximum quality of products, same conditions of access to the market for all companies, eco-friendly products.

The Union cannot be enlarged to 28 without addressing the question of whether Europe has some principles, some common values, whether it is limited to an economic free trade area or whether, instead, it has a greater aspiration: to want to be a supranational union, in ways to be defined, which also wants to trace a new path of civilization and democracy in the world. This is what was wanted and is meant when a European Constitution is called for. The modification of the Treaties has instead been limited to a revision of some internal rules, a necessary and important revision but which does not answer the fundamental question that precedes it: what is Europe, what are its common principles and, therefore, its objectives and its limits? But politics takes revenge and, chased out the window by a debate on a limited agenda, comes back, in reality, through the door, and through the main door with the Austrian case, since in Austria a party that seems to refer to intolerance, xenophobia, and forms of racism is in government. And it is not a problem of ties with the past; It is a question of prospects for the future, and there is nothing more wrong than to be divided, on this, between right and left. I belong to a world, that of liberal Catholics, which is not left-wing but which is as attached to the values of tolerance, to common European values as anyone else and which has nothing to do with lines that deny these values. The Council did well to raise this issue before Europe and the world, and if these values are not recalled in a fundamental Charter of Rights, in a European Constitution, we will build a Europe that will not have solid and lasting foundations. I know, Commissioner Barnier - at least I think I know - that you and the representatives of the Portuguese Presidency share these values: take advantage of the openings left to you by the December Conference to include these issues and these principles, because only in this way will we build a lasting Europe. Mr President, I find myself in the pleasant situation in which I can refer to some interesting interventions by a small group of Nordic sceptics who oppose the violent and widespread process of integration that profoundly threatens the whole of democratic Europe. I am thinking of the speeches by Mr Bonde and Mr Sjöstedt, who point out that this proposal contains a series of relatively unconscious, but undoubtedly rational and power-driven initiatives towards a centralist and federalist European Union. They rightly mentioned the problem of monetary union and central management, and set out some alternative democratic principles. I may add that all the rational political agitation in my country, Denmark, is dictated by the fact that we are enormously increasing the number of countries belonging to the European Union and thus expanding in breadth, so that it is impossible, at the same time, to achieve deeper integration while pursuing more intensive qualitative integration towards the United States of Europe, which is what has happened so far.

I did this not only because I was born in a seaside city, Genoa, but above all because the borders of the regions bordered by the sea are also borders. These borders open the door to African states and the Middle East: we must give greater consideration to the importance of developing coastal regions throughout Europe. As a Member of the European Parliament from a border region, this third INTERREG initiative is of particular interest to me. It is impossible to overemphasize the difficulties that have arisen in the past in economically, socially, and culturally separated border regions on the coast and inland. The existence of the border has turned them into peripheral zones of their respective states, which has often led public authorities to neglect these regions in national policies. This is why the Interreg Community Initiative was launched back in 1990. Its objective is to promote cross-border, transnational, and interregional cooperation and the balanced development of the Community area with the aim of strengthening the Union's economic and social cohesion. INTERREG essentially finances joint projects in the areas of SME support, vocational training and education, cultural exchange, healthcare, environmental protection and improvement, and energy, transport, and telecommunications networks. I would particularly like to emphasize that interregional cooperation contributes to the involvement of local and regional authorities in the European integration process. It is indeed important to encourage more active participation by local and regional authorities in Community initiatives, since, due to differences in the legal framework and level of development on either side of the border, local and regional authorities often have very limited opportunities for cooperation. Within the framework of cooperation in cross-border areas, particular attention must be paid to improving the framework conditions for job-creating small and medium-sized enterprises. Equally, given that 50% of unemployment is structural, the financial resources provided under INTERREG must be substantial enough to meaningfully complement national employment promotion measures. In concrete terms, cross-border mobility is still all too often prevented, hampered, or made particularly problematic by obstacles related to tax policy (double taxation) and social security. My hope is that the projects under the individual programmes will help find solutions to these problems and give concrete substance to the principle of free movement of workers, which is not particularly well-developed in my region. Furthermore, INTERREG funds must also contribute to the creation of a European research area. Last but not least, there are high expectations of this initiative in the regions, as the areas not eligible for Objective 2 hope to receive compensation from INTERREG! So, a great deal is at stake, because the integration of border regions represents an important element in the development of a future European spatial planning policy! It is to be hoped that everyone is as aware of this as F. Decourrière, whom I congratulate. The INTERREG Community Initiative is part of a harmful European regional policy. This policy, which appears generous because it is officially intended to support regions in difficulty, represents a bad deal for French taxpayers. While France contributes 17% to the European budget, it receives only 8% of the regional structural funds.

(The sitting adjourned at 00:05) Sinking of the Erika The next item is the oral question (B5-0011/2000) by Mr Varela Suanzes-Carpegna, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, to the Commission on the sinking of the Erika. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to commend Mr Fischler for his consideration in being with us today. Yesterday, our President informed us that he would be absent due to his schedule. But I believe that he reflected and did what he usually does: show consideration and respect for this Parliament, as he has always shown, and I thank him for that. I rise today in this Chamber on behalf of the European Parliament's Committee on Fisheries to focus our concerns once again on the sinking of the oil tanker Erika. A dual political consideration has led our committee – and myself, as Chairman of this committee – to raise our voices in this matter. Firstly, to demonstrate to the Commission, the Council and the Member States that this Parliament cannot and will not forget this serious accident. And secondly, to focus today on a concrete aspect of the serious environmental disaster caused by this accident, namely its impact on the fisheries and aquaculture sectors in the affected regions. The epilogue to this accident must undoubtedly be the urgent adoption of measures to repair the damage and prevent such a disaster from recurring in the future. Enough of the lamentations and the reflections. We must all, Mr President, get straight to the point and adopt measures. Firstly, safety in maritime transport - especially when it comes to the transport of hydrocarbons and dangerous goods - requires effective controls in Community waters and in its ports. Issues such as ship construction, double hulls, their age, control by classification societies, insurance, the creation of databases containing all the necessary information, Community cooperation and coordination, increased control by inspectors, and the liability of carriers and cargo owners will all have to be addressed, and in this respect, the Commission is best placed to launch serious proposals for European harmonization in these matters. Transport carried out under flags of convenience - which also cause such damage to fishing that we have called for "responsible fishing" - must also be subject to special monitoring and regulation. The entry into Community waters of vessels flying flags of convenience that do not comply with Community safety standards must be controlled. We expect the Commission to take concrete measures. With regard to the fishing and aquaculture sectors - which are particularly important, developed and prestigious in the affected areas of Brittany and Vendée - the European Commission must make known the damage caused, its assessment and the specific measures of any kind it intends to adopt - political, economic, social, financial, etc., to repair the damage caused to fishermen and industries that have been seriously affected overnight. How are we going to regain consumer confidence in products from this region? What compensation will the victims receive? We are facing a very serious problem that the European Union - an economic, commercial, industrial and fishing power - cannot afford to leave unsolved. Commissioner, we must get to work. We must be pioneers and avant-garde in matters of environmental, industrial and professional destruction.

I am against Amendments 7 to 13, which were also decisively rejected by the Committee on Fisheries. Their content is largely unnecessary or is already included in my proposal. In particular, I have focused on the need to study the extent of the disease and the interaction between farmed and wild salmon, to discover the origin of the disease and to extend research on the virus to wild species. These amendments, tabled by the Green MEPs of the Verts/ALE Group, serve to justify Amendment 13. This amendment is completely unacceptable, as it not only seeks to retain the provision requiring the immediate compulsory slaughter of all salmon, but also to prohibit farms affected by the virus from selling any fish, whether infected or not. I must stress that the current directive prohibits the sale of infected fish and that there is certainly no proposal to change this rule and allow their sale. Amendments 7 to 13 13 simply do not take into account the reality of the conflicting data from Scotland and Norway. In Scotland, a draconian measure was applied which did not achieve its objectives. In Norway, with greater experience, the mandatory 100 percent eradication of fish was abandoned a few years ago and a series of measures were adopted which have significantly improved the situation. It is in our interests to contain the disease in Scotland and prevent its spread. Last week in Scotland, a report on contagious salmon anaemia was published by a joint government and industry working group. This comprehensive study takes into account a wide range of possible risks and suggests how to combat the disease in areas such as transmission from one site to another, safety measures to reduce escape of salmon, treatment of waste and effluent, methods of detection and diagnosis, breeding and rotation, disinfection of equipment, etc. Some of these measures will be implemented immediately by local authorities using the tools at their disposal, while others will be reflected in codes of practice. All of these measures will serve not only to combat infectious salmon anaemia, but also to achieve higher standards of quality in aquaculture in general, where necessary. Ladies and gentlemen, by voting in favour of my proposal as approved by the Fisheries Committee, you will enable the introduction of a broader package of disease control legislation in Scotland based on the reality of the situation in Scotland and the positive experiences of other countries. I congratulate Mr Hudghton, fully support his report and ask Members of this Parliament to do the same. As the rapporteur has said, fish farming is an important source of employment in some remote parts of rural Scotland. At a time when these areas are experiencing the worst recession in a hundred years, the aquaculture industry provides a vital boost to the rural economy on which many thousands of jobs depend directly and indirectly. Currently, as the rapporteur said, more than 85,000 tonnes of salmon are produced on Scottish farms: it is an industry that brings in more than €800 million each year.

Amendment 16 endangers investor protection, because the prohibition on the provision of collateral with the depositary is a contradiction in terminis. Securities lending transactions carried out through clearing houses or stock exchanges - as opposed to the purchase and sale of securities - are also not automatically covered by these institutions. For this reason, we cannot accept the proposed amendment. Amendment 42 concerns a provision that has not been changed by the proposal and has not caused any problems since the implementation of the Directive. I therefore see no reason to delete Article 22(3) and therefore reject the amendment. Amendment 44 cannot be accepted, because if it is stipulated that non-harmonised funds must apply the "Directive" rules on borrowing and lending, purchases made in an unhedged position and the depositary, only very few funds, such as Swiss funds, could be considered for investment purposes. This is in conflict with the Commission's objective of broadening the range of investments and the wording of the amendment could violate the General Agreement on Trade in Services. Amendment 47 is unacceptable as regards the proposed changes to paragraph 1 of Article 22a, because it is in total conflict with the distribution rules of Article 22, especially where UCITS are obliged to indicate a reference point in their prospectuses, as decided by the Council. The main problem with the first proposal, however, is the amendment tabled by the Parliament allowing over-the-counter instruments to be used for generic investment purposes. The Commission draws attention to the fact that, under the legislation in force in some Member States, the use of OTC derivatives for generic investment purposes is already permitted. The Commission also expresses reservations in view of the higher intrinsic risks associated with these investments compared to more traditional financial instruments. I think that OTC instruments could cause problems, as they are illiquid, difficult to price and involve uncovered risks for the counterparty. It does not seem appropriate to take an overly cautious approach to investments such as non-harmonised funds or deposits, and at the same time allow much riskier investments in OTC instruments. By rejecting the rapporteur's Amendment No 39, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has taken the same line as the Council. The adoption of this amendment tabled by Parliament would have the effect of theoretically allowing funds to invest in OTC instruments and to trade participation rights in their funds throughout the internal market. In practice, access to other Community markets for these theoretically harmonised funds investing in OTC instruments could be blocked due to the application of different national regulations and protective measures against OTC investments. This would be in conflict with the fact that Community legislation covers all funds investing in OTC instruments. In view of this possible negative consequence for the internal market and the inherent risks of OTC instruments, the Commission cannot accept amendments Nos 12, 15, 37, 38, 39, 43, 46 and 48 and parts of amendments Nos.

You answered it the way I knew you would. I would like to link it to something Mr. Goodwill asked, namely our relationship between the precautionary principle and the world outside the European Union. I'm not asking that without reason. You rightly said that the precautionary principle is necessary precisely when science has yet to provide any evidence. How do we ensure that we don't make ourselves vulnerable at any time, for example, to our partners in the USA – and the Biosafety Protocol isn't enough in that case? How do we ensure that our colleagues in industrial policy and foreign trade policy don't keep kicking your heels in, like they did with your predecessors the last few times? That's precisely what it's about; otherwise, there's no need to talk about the precautionary principle here, Commissioner! Mr. President! I consider it very important to refer to the guidelines contained in this communication that apply to the application of the precautionary principle, in order to counter claims that we always apply it for protectionist reasons. I am convinced that we will have to deal with even more conflicts in the future, for example with the USA. It would be naive to believe otherwise. However, since the signing of the Montreal Protocol, we have had international confirmation and a common definition enshrined in a protocol on the environment, health, and trade. This can therefore be seen as a good example. We must be prepared for conflicts to arise in the future, but now we can demonstrate that we are not applying the precautionary principle arbitrarily. We now have a set of guidelines for this, clearly laid down in the communication, as well as strong popular support. Thank you, Commissioner. Due to the attention paid to the principle of political precaution, we have discussed it for almost two hours, and now this issue is considered more of a matter of day-to-day administration, although, as we have seen from the contributions and the questions and answers, it is a matter of great importance. The debate is closed. Intergovernmental Conference The next item is the report (A5-0018/2000) by Giorgos Dimitrakopoulos and Jo Leinen, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the convening of the Intergovernmental Conference (14094/1999 - C5-0341/1999 - 1999/0825(CNS)). Mr President, I would first like to thank the Portuguese Presidency and the Commission for the many extremely useful contacts I have had recently. I would also like to thank my co-rapporteur, Mr Leinen, for his excellent cooperation. The forthcoming Intergovernmental Conference is important both in general and specifically with regard to the coming enlargement. The way Europe will be structured and function in the 21st century will depend on the discussions it holds. In order to make the processes in the future European Union more efficient, more democratic and transparent in every respect, a comprehensive and far-reaching reform of its institutions and the way they work is understandably necessary. The first and most important prerequisite for the success of this reform is the agenda on which the Intergovernmental Conference will begin its work. The agenda agreed at the Helsinki Summit is insufficient and offers no guarantee that the necessary and fundamental changes will be implemented to create a more functional, efficient, democratic, and transparent Europe.

The Commission, ladies and gentlemen, will, for its part, take initiatives to initiate and enrich this public debate. Cross-border services Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I must first apologize that my voice has already sounded a little harsh today, but as Austrian Members of Parliament, we have had a lot to explain and talk about today. I would first like to thank the Commission most sincerely for the initiative it has taken and for these two draft directives that we are debating here today. In doing so, it closes two serious gaps in the internal market that are of great importance to the European economy and to the 5 million third-country nationals in the European Union who are employed or self-employed here. The current situation, and this should be borne in mind again, is such that there are judgments from the European Court of Justice in the area of employees, in particular the judgment in the Rush Portuguesa and van der Elst case. They have clarified that the freedom to provide services must allow third-country nationals to be employed as workers for cross-border services, even without obtaining work permits. However, the European Court of Justice did not explicitly address the issue of visa and residence requirements, and the Member States were subsequently unable to clarify this issue.
