Even with regard to the abolition of work permits, not all Member States have adhered to the Court's rulings and still maintain a multitude of inadmissible barriers to cross-border services – barriers that are often impossible to overcome, especially for smaller companies. For the self-employed, the current Community acquis does not provide for a right for third-country nationals to provide cross-border services. In any case, a legislative act is required here. Both draft directives aim to facilitate the freedom to provide services for EU companies. They are not about original rights for third-country nationals modeled on freedom of movement. All regulations, including entry and residence issues, are to be viewed as accessory to this freedom to provide services. I, along with the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market of the European Parliament, therefore believe that the legal bases chosen by the Commission are correct and that the opposing opinion expressed in the opinion of the Council's Legal Service is incorrect. I therefore see no real legal obstacle to the expeditious further consideration of both draft directives in the Council. I also believe that the amendments proposed by Parliament should facilitate the adoption of the directives in the Council compared to the Commission's proposal. Many of our amendments stem from concerns that were also expressed in the Council, and we are trying to reconcile these concerns with the mandate given to us by applicable law and economic common sense. Especially with regard to acceptance in the Council, I can only appeal to the Commission to adopt the amendments adopted by Parliament as completely as possible, even if they deviate significantly from the Commission's original proposals. I am firmly convinced that we can more easily reach agreement in the Council on this basis. Now for the most important changes we propose. A key difference is that instead of a "services pass plus notification of each individual contract" system, we no longer provide for the possibility of requiring prior notification to the receiving state for each individual contract.

This morning there were seven helicopters, and naturally, those helicopters only operate in the Gaza region. The Saave River also has enormous flooding problems, but so far no one has gone there. Eighty-five percent of the work is located within an hour of Maputo, so we have no idea of the scale of the problem. I would also like to say, Commissioner, that European citizens want to know exactly what ECHO is doing. Most of us here would not like to boast about €3 million. We must do much more, and I hope the Commissioner will return with those promises and also with an initiative to coordinate the efforts being made in the area. It is clear that high-capacity air transport is also needed, in addition to, as you say, tons of food, water purification equipment, tents, and blankets. Are we really prepared for the next phase of relief and rehabilitation you referred to? Because this, too, will require enormous resources. Are we prepared to provide those resources? Mozambique is one of the poorest countries in the world, yet it is also one of the best examples of overcoming obstacles found in Africa. Its achievements include economic growth, poverty reduction, and democracy, despite the enormous pressures of debt. Mozambique is a wonderful example, but it may now suffer enormous hardship as a result of what it has had to endure. What we should now analyze is how far the catastrophe will set Mozambique back, and that depends entirely on the quality and quantity of international aid that this stricken country receives. Thank you very much, Mrs. Kinnock. Mr. Nogueira, I must tell you that we have noted your interest and concern about this issue, but your group is not registered to speak, and I will abide by the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. Economy of the Union (1999) The next item is the report (A5-0041/2000) by Mr Katiforis, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the European Commission document: "Situation of the economy of the European Union in 1999" (C5-0081/2000 - 2000/2046(COS)). The Commission's report presents a encouraging assessment of the current situation of the European economy, particularly in terms of the recent recovery in economic growth, which is expected to lead to a reduction in unemployment to 8% by 2001. In the view of your rapporteur, this picture contrasts with the background of sluggishness and an annual growth rate of barely 1.9% during the 1990s, with the exception of isolated instances of higher growth rates during that decade, which, however, could not be consolidated. It could be inferred that if we do not want to repeat the same failures of the past, we must seize this opportunity offered by increased economic performance to launch a new policy of transition toward higher levels of sustainable growth for our economy. That is the challenge. Faced with this challenge, the Commission essentially recommended that our economic policy should simply extend our past position, which was limited to correcting the monetary and fiscal foundations of the economy, while for everything else we relied on the markets to perform the miracle without any further intervention by socially conscious agents.

Is there any colleague who wishes to speak on behalf of the PSE Group to present the request? Madam President, I do indeed owe Mr. Wurtz an explanation, and I will give it to the entire Parliament. We had reached this agreement in principle at the Conference of Presidents. At that time, I was unaware that Commissioner Mr. Bolkestein would appear next week to speak on this issue before the Committee on Transport, Regional Policy and Tourism. The issue has been discussed in my group and we believe that, given the current situation in the entire process of market integration and deregulation on such a sensitive issue, it is appropriate for Parliament, regardless of what it does in the future, to have an initial statement so that Commissioner Mr. Bolkestein can take note and guide the debate next week. Madam President, I would like, without further ado, to ask our colleague Mr. Wurtz to reread what this is about. This is not a substantive disagreement, but simply the following question: When will the Commission finally be in a position to present the directive after having already had three and a half years to do so? What we want with the resolution is simply for the promised deadlines to finally be met, and in this regard, it is important that we act as quickly as possible. For this reason, I would like to support the Social Democrats' request for the vote to take place on Friday. (Parliament agrees) Madam President, the Cederschiöld report has certainly been withdrawn from Thursday's agenda. For this reason, we should have a little more time on Thursday. Since we are very short on time on urgent matters due to the large number of items we have to deal with in an hour and a half, I would simply like to ask whether the sitting service could check whether we could have an extra half hour for urgent matters, so that there would be sufficient speaking time. In my opinion, the running of the sessions in recent weeks has seemed a bit chaotic. We were very short on speaking time, and suddenly, last Thursday, we had a time slot of between an hour and an hour and a half, during which no matter was on the agenda, and we had to wait for the vote. On Friday of this week, we have only one item. This is, admittedly, absurd. I would really like to ask for a review of the management of the part-session. This is quite possible: let's see if we can extend the emergency sitting for another half hour, taking into account the withdrawal of Mrs. Cederschiöld's report. This is the sole and exclusive purpose of this. Madam President, I wanted to speak in relation to an item on Wednesday's agenda, which the Honorable Member has not announced.

Let me give you an example. The European Union rightly granted aid to the Grönitz steelworks in Brandenburg, even though its 5,000 jobs have now been reduced to just 700. But these jobs are competitive, as the steelworks is currently the second-largest producer of tool steel in the Federal Republic of Germany. Those who are now jeopardizing the production of this steelworks by demanding the repayment of this aid are threatening not only the steelworks but also an employer in that region, on whom, of course, several small and medium-sized enterprises also depend. This, of course, cannot be the European Union's competition policy. If we want competition, we must succeed in combining political and economic requirements with the requirements of business economics. This is, moreover, the only way to establish regional economic networks in underdeveloped regions, which make it possible to provide social security for people and improve their purchasing power. As part of this approach, we must also take more decisively into consideration demand-side economic policy rather than focusing exclusively on supply-side economic policy. Mr. President, since I was elected to this Parliament in 1994, I have never seen a report with such anti-Irish statements and overtones as the Jonckheer report we are debating today. I would like to quote the following from the report: The highest levels of state aid per capita are allocated to Italy, Germany, and Ireland. If we group together national and Community regional and social funds, Ireland clearly occupies the top spot. I believe the rapporteur is simply playing with figures. I find it difficult to understand how he can include regional and social funds in that mathematical equation. I would like to remind the honourable Member that the European Union has approved the new guidelines on regional aid for the period beginning in 2000. This was a simple extension of the policy objectives aimed at completing the internal market in Europe. For the internal market to succeed and prosper, regional disparities must be reduced. I welcome the fact that, starting in 2000, a 40% grant and a 15% supplement for fixed investment by SMEs will be allowed for companies setting up in Objective 1 regions in Europe. I must remind Mr. Jonckheer that Irish or foreign companies based in Ireland still have to cross two seas to reach the continental European market. No other Member State is at such a disadvantage. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the cartel ban is at the heart of a functioning competition system in Europe. The Commission finds the way in which the monitoring of this ban has been carried out in practice unsatisfactory, with which we can also initially agree. However, opinions are beginning to diverge regarding the solution. The Commission's proposal does not formally deviate from the cartel prohibition, but the result is a shift from prohibition with a reservation of authorization to authorization with a reservation of prohibition. This amounts to shifting from the principle of prohibition to the principle of abuse.

The report itself contains good intentions, but, as is often the case when we deal with these issues, it lacks clarity of purpose and a solid basis for its operation. This is why my group and I are proposing three key amendments and additional proposals to the text, not with the intention of removing everything from the proposal, but rather to make it more relevant to those who must implement it. I would like to explain our thoughts here. First, we are concerned about the proper use of the Structural Funds and Cohesion Funds. Past experience dictates that, as elected representatives of European taxpayers, we must and should demand financial integrity and transparency in the disbursement and auditing of this money. Our amendments and additional proposals therefore relate to achieving what we refer to as "value for money" indicators in the grant-making process. Second, we have seen too often huge amounts of money spent on projects whose results are necessarily vague at the initial stage of the program period. But all too often, at the midpoint or end of that period, there is no real way to terminate the project if its effectiveness has not been demonstrated. Therefore, our additional proposals advocate for the provision of practical and enforceable exit strategies so that we can not only have the required insurance against incurred costs that are typically charged to the taxpayer, but also avoid the well-known syndrome of losing more money trying to recover what has already been lost. Finally, we advocate for a change in the balance and method of disbursement of funds. There must be greater engagement from the private sector, which must present financial reality as an element of the funding equation. Also, the type of projects funded requires a move away from small-scale, revenue-based projects, which are difficult to monitor, toward capital plans where, in most cases, we can all clearly see the benefits. In this way, the much-vaunted need for transparency in the use of these funds and the temptation to unnecessarily resort to the local tax base as late as possible in the areas where these projects are being developed will diminish, and the European Parliament will show that it takes the need for this reform seriously. If the House supports the introduction of these changes to the report today, I believe that they will move us to a further stage, in which the historic objectives that the funds are meant to fulfill will be achieved: that is, to provide financially sustainable assistance to the most needy areas of the European Union whose standard of living requires an increase, not by giving them a handout, but by giving them a boost. I ask the House to support these changes. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her report; it is a difficult and conscientious piece of work. There is no doubt that the European Union's structural policies and cohesion policy are the primary tools for creating the conditions that make development possible and for the progressive elimination of economic and social inequalities between regions. Inequalities that, despite the progress made, remain at very high levels—intolerably high, specifically with regard to unemployment.

This makes me anxious, because that is where social exclusion stems, at least in part, from. I don't see how you intend to suggest possible solutions with such considerations. My question, which I repeat here, is: what is the Portuguese Presidency's position on the demands made, for example, by the networks to combat poverty and social exclusion, such as the separation of work and social security, the application of tax policy, particularly to speculative financial capital, and a policy of income redistribution? I would therefore ask you to tell me what the Portuguese Presidency's position is on this and whether it intends to take any action in this direction. Mr. President, you must understand that the real possibilities for a Presidency to reverse global social or economic trends in the six months of its term of office are effectively limited. It is certainly clear that in this regard we are also very closely bound by the logic underlying the Commission's own intervention through its right of initiative. I spoke about the special European Council summit and the initiative that Portugal had to implement, and I also spoke about the future, because there are two complementary approaches to this problem of social exclusion: one is the comprehensive set of direct measures that must be taken to counteract its concrete consequences; the other is the creation of conditions for international competitiveness that will allow us to improve the economic structure within the European Union itself, with a positive impact on the problems of social exclusion. And that is why the Portuguese Presidency has no magic formulas for answering, in six months, questions that have always existed. It is ready to act on all matters that fall within the Community's competence, starting from proposals from the Commission in these areas. It is, of course, able and interested in promoting all the measures proposed, particularly by non-governmental organizations, but also within the framework of conventional intergovernmental cooperation in these fields. However, Mr President, it must be borne in mind that, in an area with such serious financial implications, it is not possible to work exclusively with measures that a Presidency can propose in a six-month period. Therefore, we consider all the measures we have referred to in relation to longer-term strategies - although we are also aware that some homeless people may have died after a long period, that is true - to be measures that can ensure sustainable policies within the European Union. And we will try to contribute to these strategies as best we can during our term of office. Question No 12 by (H-0801/99): Subject: Portuguese Presidency and development policy. Can the President-in-Office of the Council outline the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency with regard to development policy, the Lomé Convention and the response to famine? I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his detailed answer to my question and also express my gratitude to the Minister who explained his position to the Committee on Development and Cooperation last week in Brussels. However, not all issues have been resolved. The current program does not appear to give the fight against AIDS a special priority.

We cannot but hope that the extraordinary conference will truly meet the high expectations it has raised. Indeed, as you have already emphasized, we do not need one procedure after another, one formality after another, but rather we need facts by which the population of the European Union can measure the usefulness and added value of the European Union's actions. For this reason, you have also rightly grouped together employment, economic reform, growth, and social cohesion and made them the main issue. It is important that all actors in the governments and the Commission pull together in the direction of full employment. Then it will be possible to convince all actors in economic policy of the need to maintain a consistent approach, something that still does not exist. Europe should not lament the success of the American economy or the strength of the dollar without drawing a lesson for itself. Reforms of financial services, services capital, and labor markets are certainly useful and necessary. However, these reforms will not give growth the driving force necessary to organize a high-level, sustainable growth that will have an impact on employment. We experienced this many times in the 1990s. Under conditions of an average productivity increase of 2%, a growth rate of 3.5% is necessary to achieve full employment within ten years. This is very close. For this reason, full employment must indeed be at the top of the agenda. We must set a growth target of at least 3%. The goal of full employment cannot be achieved through economic policy alone. The Europe of innovation and the information society must contribute to this goal. However, for now, we are very far from this. We must also consider that we need a different form of economic policy and economic practice. It cannot simply be that shareholders or the boards of directors of public limited companies decide alone about jobs and the economy, about the development of stock prices. When 13-year-olds play computer games after school, trying to change their parents' stock positions, it may have more to do with a casino than with responsibility. I believe that the extraordinary Lisbon summit will set a signal for responsible economic practice in the European Union. Mr. President, Mr. Prime Minister, Mr. President of the Commission, the Portuguese Presidency has presented an ambitious project for the extraordinary summit. Congratulations. I also welcome the support that Portugal is receiving from the Commission, not least through the communication that it wants to make the Community an information society for all. What Christian Democrat Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker said about the Luxembourg employment summit in 1997 also applies to the Lisbon Summit: it must not be a summit of literature, and by this he was referring to the numerous non-binding declarations at many summit meetings. Through the Luxembourg procedure, the Heads of Government achieved concrete successes.

I thank the rapporteur, Mr Karl von Wogau, for his commitment and welcome the reflections he has put forward. I would also like to express my appreciation for the views and observations sent to me by Professor Tesauro, President of the Italian Competition Authority, which Professor Monti will certainly take due account of in a very cooperative spirit. The real problem undoubtedly lies in greater liberalization of the market and, above all, in the unification of the various national markets, which currently display considerable differences that are clearly evident when comparing the English, Italian, and French markets. The French market, for example, is characterized by strong elements of state protectionism, which do not exist in the English market and are extremely limited in Italy. Another problem is posed by the economies of the candidate countries, which, without gradual adjustment, risk being permanently dependent on support. I also believe that a threshold should be set below which two important elements, characteristic of our economic fabric, must be integrated: SMEs, which are the pillar of the European economy, and the social protection that Europe has always provided to the economically weaker sections of the population. Respect for the social function of the market is the distinguishing mark between a free economy tout court and a system designed to improve people's quality of life. One aspect that the new legislation must take into account is the economy of the outermost regions and island territories, which must be preserved. I therefore believe that thought should also be given to the creation of two external markets and, to this end, fruitful relations should be established with Russia and the Mediterranean countries so that their economies are less peripheral. I hope—and I thank Professor Monti for this—that the new legislation will be given as much economic character as possible while safeguarding its social function. Mr President, competition is the core and strength of Europe's internal market policy. A free, open market can only exist thanks to competition that is constrained by clear, uniform rules. Mr. Karl von Wogau sums this up in his report. But Europe is changing. Economies are growing, and soon we will have 25 to 30 Member States. The European Commission will be overwhelmed with work if it continues to pursue its current policy. Therefore, competition policy must be modernized. There is no doubt about that. Nevertheless, the proposed decentralization worries me. How will the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, ensure that competition matters are decided uniformly in London, Palermo, Helsinki, and soon also in Budapest and Ankara? Legal inequality must be avoided, and the court that hands down the most lenient sentences must not be inundated with competition policy matters. Simply pointing out that the Member States can look back on 40 years of experience is not enough. In the Netherlands, the competition authority is still in its infancy. The country has a very small market, which, unfortunately, is often defined as the relevant market. Germany, with its extremely experienced antitrust authority, is facing this challenge and commands a gigantic market. We Catholics call the European Commission's confidence that legislation will, almost naturally, be interpreted in the same way in all directions "bold confidence," and that is forbidden.

This symbolizes the need for solidarity with the countries of the South, particularly those of Africa, the Caribbean, and the Pacific, which also appealed to us in Seattle on this issue. To fully achieve its objective, the redistribution of the money supply freed up by such a tax must necessarily go to the poorest countries. In this way, we give meaning to the moralization of trade rules and to solidarity with the peoples of the South. Madam President, not only must we continually repeat the figure that many previous speakers have already mentioned, but it must also be mentioned, Commissioner, that 80% of these gigantic daily foreign exchange transactions have a deposit period of no more than eight days. Investment and job creation cannot be less lucrative than short-term currency and stock transactions. We cannot allow the possibilities for political shaping to be taken away from us, nor can we allow income from non-economic activity to grow ever more rapidly. Since Tobin developed his idea, in Germany, the proportion of cash wealth has almost doubled from 7.6% of total income. It cannot be accepted that the poorest countries on Earth are those most intensely subject to the speculative struggles of short-term currency fluctuations. Nor do I believe it is impractical. Why shouldn't it be possible to reach an agreement among the G7 states, the other EU states, China, Singapore, and Switzerland on the introduction of the Tobin tax? There must be a general economic interest. Why can't it be feasible—since it is identifiable—for transactions for the immediate exchange of foreign currencies, all so-called cash transactions, foreign exchange transactions, and forward option transactions to be subject to this tax? Why can't it be feasible to determine the amount of this tax in such a way that it does not jeopardize necessary long-term economic investments but ultimately makes short-term and speculative investments unattractive? Undoubtedly, many difficult issues will arise, but the only major problem I see so far is political will and this attitude of shifting responsibility from one place to another. Mr. President, we are not asking for more bureaucracy, as Mr. Karas pointed out a few minutes earlier. We are looking for solutions. Of course, capital markets need transparency—that is the idea. The Tobin tax will bring some clarity to a very obscure issue. "The more progress is made towards trade liberalization, the more rules are needed," as Commissioner Lamy said during the Millennium Round in Seattle. He acknowledged that the combined effort of the Single Market and the Single Currency that characterize the process of building the European Union is intimately linked to an enormous number of new rules. Now that financing can be quickly sought across national borders without any difficulty, it will be strictly necessary to employ the same approach, all the more so considering that an enormous amount of financial resources is spent on speculative transactions every day.

Secondly, there is a lady who is thirteen weeks away from retirement and is impatient to hear the judgment that will seriously affect her financial situation in her old age. These are just two examples of real-life problems lurking behind delays in the Community justice system. Delays in justice can lead to personal hardship and even tragedy. This is not to say that all our national justice systems are perfect, but all too often they are forced to await a preliminary judgment from the European Court of Justice. Statistics point to a worrying upward trend in the time taken for preliminary references. This should not be taken as a criticism of the Court of Justice or its staff, but rather of its structure and lack of resources in an ever-enlarging European Union. The proposals contained in this report are welcome as an interim palliative, but Europe is a legal construct, and its courts are fundamental to its proper functioning. With a view to the forthcoming enlargement, the Intergovernmental Conference must address a fundamental reform and restructuring of the judicial system. Otherwise, all of us, in our capacity as elected representatives, will increasingly face the clamor of our citizens who lack access to swift and effective justice. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues, I too would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report. Furthermore, I fully agree with the conclusions he has outlined. Specifically, he proposes increasing the number of lawyers per judge at the Court of First Instance and providing that Court with its own translation service. I consider this truly essential, given that during the Committee on Legal Affairs' visit to the courts in Luxembourg, we were told that, logically and naturally, the Court of Justice takes precedence over the Court of First Instance when it comes to using the common translation service. The result is that on numerous occasions, cases handled by the Court of First Instance cannot be properly processed. But on the other hand, I believe that the reforms must go beyond what we are going to agree to here. Thus, for example, I believe we should consider the possibility of making the Court of First Instance the court of last resort, granting it the final say in those areas where adjudicatory bodies, which are similar to courts, make a preliminary decision. It's enough to mention the word Alicante or to recall that this procedure is planned to be applied in the area of European civil service law. And it seems to me that we will probably also have to take measures in response to the European Commission's tendency to renationalize competition decisions, referring them to the national level. This matter is worthy of reflection since, in this way, such cases will no longer end up before the Court of First Instance, but will be dealt with by the Court of Justice as referral orders. We must find a way out of this situation. If necessary, we could also consider submitting referral orders in competition matters to the specialized chamber of the Court of First Instance.

I particularly expect the Portuguese Presidency to take advantage of the enormous work of the Finnish Presidency to present proposals and coordinated action plans among the Member States. At the international level, action plans are already in place to combat scourges such as drug trafficking and money laundering. On a more human scale, however, much remains to be done: first, to help those trying to get out of drugs and provide them with the appropriate controls and mechanisms for their reintegration; second, to ensure coordination between police forces and judicial systems regarding common sentences and legal provisions; third, to conduct an information and awareness-raising campaign aimed at young people; and fourth, to eliminate once and for all these very dangerous notions of "normalization" and "harm reduction" and to show that any weakening of our resolve to fight drug legalization must be in the interest of all. Mr President, I would like to use the few seconds of speaking time I have to point out or remind the Commission representative that the Belgian Government is currently pursuing a policy that will enable thousands, even tens of thousands, of illegal aliens to be regularised and granted permanent residence, family reunification, and so on. This measure by the Belgian Government constitutes a flagrant breach of the Schengen Convention. On 23 December, I submitted a written complaint on this matter to Commissioner Vitorino. I would like to ask him to examine this complaint and to inform me as soon as possible of the measures that the Commission will adopt to sanction the Belgian State's violation of the Schengen Convention, pursuant to Article 226 of the Treaty. Mr President, dear Portuguese friends and, in particular, dear representatives of the Council, you are faced with great expectations from us. I would like to show you, by way of an example, how you can respond relatively quickly to these expectations, at least partially. This is Eurodac. You will recall that in December, this European Parliament decided, full of hope, that Eurodac should become a reality as a regulation and a system, also as a Community instrument that we urgently needed to no longer allow multiple asylum applications, to have an instrument against illegality and, above all, to establish beyond doubt which Member State was responsible for a specific asylum procedure. We clearly declared ourselves in favour of this instrument, accompanied by an implementation committee and a suitable database established within the Commission. We believed that Eurodac should become a reality. In Tampere, too, they believed that Eurodac should become a reality. But since the follow-up Summit held in December, the Council has embarked on a different path and taken a further step backwards by deciding - which we resolutely rejected - to maintain the executive powers within the Council, to attach the Implementation Committee to the Council and perhaps to use Gibraltar as a means of pressure.

From this perspective, the issue must be investigated, because the instability of the Caucasus can lead many to think inappropriately. Second, regarding the safety of the facilities. In regions of high seismic risk, it is not enough to have earthquake-resistant buildings, because in exceptional cases—and I am speaking to you as an engineer—we use models to investigate the consequences of certain hazards. However, we cannot create models with operating nuclear facilities. It is impossible. In this sense, in high-risk regions, a priori, nuclear power plants are not built. Given this, as Turkey is on the doorstep of the European Union, we must help it become a country of security, peace, and cooperation in the region. This is our role, and this is the objective of my question. Mr. President, I recognize the relevance of the arguments put forward by the Honorable Member. In reality, this is a very delicate issue. Furthermore, as you will understand, this is an issue that concerns not only Turkey in terms of its proximity to the current territory of the European Union, but also other states with which we have a relationship within the framework of our own closeness. We understand the Honourable Member's concern and will not fail to take it into account, particularly in the context of the future contacts we will hold with Turkey when formulating the agenda for the accession strategy planned for that country. This issue will also be at the heart of our concerns, and the European Commission will not fail to take it into account. Thank you, Mr. President, and thank you, President-in-Office of the Council. I am convinced that the President-in-Office of the Council is a very pleasant person and is very affable with his wife, his children, and his dog. However, allow me to be somewhat suspicious of the answer you have just given us. I do not believe that the statements made within the Council and the votes will be made available to the public immediately. Therefore, will you undertake, before the next plenary session in February, to tell me in writing where I can find this information on behalf of the public, immediately after the Council has adopted a legislative act, rather than waiting for it to be published weeks later in a press release? Will you send me this information in writing before the next plenary session? Your Honor, first of all, I would like to say that I excuse the personal comments with which you began your second question, and if you could refrain from making them in the future, I would appreciate it. Regarding what the Honorable Member has said, it gives us an idea that the criticism of the Council, in addition to being formulated very specifically and of which we also take note, does not refer to the opacity—let's say so—of the legislative process, but almost to an excess of transparency. But I would like to tell you, Your Honor, that the results of this type of transparency process are, for us, clear and we consider them beyond doubt.

Since 1998, the Commission has received complaints alleging that the port facilities will damage the Stegrennan Coastal Strip, which is currently part of the Special Area of Conservation, and that protection standards have not been met. After analyzing these complaints throughout 1998 and early last year (the project did not receive Structural Fund funding during this period), the Commission was satisfied in the summer of 1999 that the port works had met protection standards. A thorough study of the environmental consequences was conducted. The most negative effect of the project, the loss of the Stegrennan Coastal Strip, will be temporary, and the developers are responsible for restoring it. At the Commission's request, the Stegrennan Coastal Strip was formally added to the Boyne Estuary Special Protection Area, from which it had previously been excluded. To offset the negative effects of the temporary disappearance of the coastal strip on the life of wild birds, it was considered to improve other suitable habitats for these birds in the estuary area. However, since the summer of last year, this measure has been called into question. First, the Irish authorities withdrew their commitment to make improvements. Later, they renewed their commitment after protests were lodged by an environmental non-governmental organization in the Irish courts. The new commitment, however, contained minor changes that, in turn, gave rise to further protests. Considering that Ireland has committed to adopting compensatory measures and that other issues have already been resolved, the Commission, for the time being, does not wish to propose freezing the Structural Funds. However, the Commission wishes to examine the compensatory measures of the Irish authorities, especially those relating to habitat improvement, in light of the still unfinished proceedings before the Irish courts. I did not fully understand what the Commissioner said. The Stregrennan Mudflat, which was declared a special protection area at the request of the Commission, has already been completely destroyed. It is clear that the activities carried out there clearly violate EU directives. You state that no further funding will be granted. I would like to know whether it is proposed to suspend funding completely at this stage, pending a proper investigation. If not, why not? If it is proposed to suspend funding, when exactly will it do so? Is it right and proper that the corporation that owns the company is also responsible for granting the license, as well as essentially receiving the EU funds and handing them over to a company that it 100% owns? Is that right and appropriate? What is your view on this? All funding for the project must be stopped because it clearly violates EU directives. Even the area designated by the Commissioners as a special protection area has been destroyed. Further compensation will not repair the damage caused.

Unfortunately, nothing is changing now and nothing will change in the future. You want to drive out the devil with Beelzebub and apply the same disastrous methods and the same economic principles to areas that have previously been beyond your jurisdiction: education, wage policy, direct taxation, labor law, social protection, and social assistance. The most extraordinary thing about all this is the fact that this policy of social cuts is largely being pursued by left-wing governments of various stripes—pink, red, green—who preach social justice during election campaigns but pursue general social cuts once they are in power. At this point, I would like to reiterate our conviction that without national and European priority, and without protecting our markets from unbridled global competition, no social policy and no policy of full employment are possible. When it comes to jobs, social protection, family, or pension policy, we must think of the Europeans first. The economic globalization you are promoting is neither necessary nor inevitable. This globalization is being imposed by force by the only superpower to survive the Cold War and by multinational corporations, which are becoming independent economic powers that are subjugating states, nations, and peoples unable to defend themselves to their economic will. You are thus complicit in this development. You are promoting this process, you are collaborating with it, and, despite your announcements, you are in fact promoting the disintegration of our social protection systems. You are creating insecurity and organizing social cuts. This economic globalization, especially in the form in which it is taking place today—that is, without taking into account the social and national characteristics of each state—could be disastrous for the European social model. Your rush toward extreme liberalism will certainly not solve the social problems, the problems of insecurity, and the employment problems of millions upon millions of Europeans. Mr. President, we will once again hear many fine words at the Lisbon Summit. We'll gladly listen to these words, but they won't change the fundamental problem: that we have an Economic and Monetary Union that prioritizes combating inflation over employment. The Central Bank has announced that the rate of price increases must never exceed 2%. The Stability Pact states that the budget deficit may not exceed 1% in normal years. However, there is no requirement that unemployment be lower than 5%, or—even better—lower than 2% or 1%. What's more important is that the price of money and public spending must not rise. It's conceivable that a country might want to combat unemployment with public investment, but that's forbidden. Monetary policy should remain a sacred cow; it's more important than providing jobs for the unemployed. For me, on the other hand, it's more important that the family budget is in order, that Dad gets paid, not be laid off. That was the attitude of the Danish government formed in 1993. In 1992, unemployment stood at 9.2% in Euroland, i.e., in the 11 countries, and also in Denmark. Between 1992 and 1998, the unemployment rate in Denmark fell to 5.1%. In Euroland, it rose to 10.9%.

Let me give you an example. In the 1998 Court of Auditors' report, a miscalculation in exchange rates for Italian wine cost European taxpayers £8 million to £10 million. This is clearly unacceptable. What about the person responsible for the miscalculation? We need a system of bonuses and promotions, and these promotions must be based on merit. We recognize that most Commission officials are hard workers. But we also note that some practices are outdated. We eagerly await the Commission's full proposal on reform and hope that we can work out the details together, since, contrary to what Mr Elles has just said, the Commissioner has undertaken to discuss this with Parliament by 1 March. We must also recognize that those who live in glass houses should not throw stones. The European Parliament has not always been very clear in its approach throughout its history. We also have a long way to go before we reach perfection. Our personnel policy itself is outdated. Some of our working practices need to be radically changed. I hope that Parliament will remain in the Commission's wake throughout this reform process. We share the proposals for activity-based budgeting. We recognize that this requires discipline on the part of Commission officials, and we also recognize that, in Parliament, we are responsible for discipline when we talk about negative priorities. Finally, I would add that the Commission needs to review its relationship with citizens. European taxpayers need to be reassured. The fate of the Commission and the European Union as a whole rests on the delivery of this reform. That is the key issue: the delivery of these proposals. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Van Hulten, on his first report. I have particular admiration for his courage, which he continued to display when he was buried under amendments. I believe that the report by the Wise Men was useful, particularly for Parliament - as Mrs Morgan said - and that we were right to seek the advice of independent experts on how to run our administration. We have tabled an amendment on this subject. I would like to emphasise a few of the many points in Mr Van Hulten's report, not on the basis of their importance but on the basis of an arbitrary selection. I believe, first of all, that the Commission should pay much more attention to the proper preservation of documents. The Commission's archives leave a lot to be desired. We saw this when we had to investigate the Fléchard affair, which has still not been clarified. Strangely, very important documents had disappeared from the offices, even from that of the President and from various Directorates-General, and this is something that, obviously, cannot happen.

Finally, I support the European Commission's desire to formulate an ambitious objective in the fight against poverty to drastically reduce this scourge within a decade. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I believe it is essential to set an objective that challenges all Member States to fight against the social exclusion of all citizens from our society, not only children but also their parents and the elderly. I wish the Council Presidency good luck in realising its ambitions. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President, the extraordinary European Council in Lisbon on employment, economic reform and social cohesion will, as we have seen, pursue an ambitious objective, a very ambitious one, at the risk of disappointing our fellow citizens, who are aware that it is not enough to decree full employment and the eradication of poverty in Europe to make it a reality. However, this summit has a significant merit: that of defining, after Cardiff and Luxembourg, the political will to ensure clearer social cohesion, especially with regard to the 57 million people who live in poverty in our country: among them, single mothers, large families and children, to whom will be added tomorrow still others excluded, that is, those who will not have access to new areas of knowledge, and this will translate into new social imbalances. It is therefore necessary to develop an economic and social policy clearly oriented towards the future, so as to avoid the creation of a gap, in terms of numbers, between the "info-rich" and the "info-poor", or a digital divide, as one of my colleagues has just called it. It is for this reason that, if on the one hand I think that new technologies represent a formidable vector of integration for our growth, on the other they can only be so if taught from childhood, since, by 2010, one job out of two will be provided by sectors directly linked to information technologies. In this regard, I call for three decisions to be taken at the Lisbon Summit: first, a lifelong learning strategy, with the launching of an agenda for the eradication of child poverty, both economic and intellectual poverty; second, the establishment of the European society, for the benefit of the European research area; third, the establishment of an open method of working and coordination, based on our social and economic policies, with a concerted assessment of our national plans. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an idea in the Portuguese Presidency's declaration that I like very much, and that is that the strength of our European economy is based on the skills, imagination and creativity - in short, on the knowledge of the people who participate in the economic process in Europe. If we take this idea seriously and really want to elevate it to a political programme, then the policy of social inclusion would no longer need any further justification, because social participation would in itself be the most powerful productive force in our common economy. If that is the case, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, we urgently need common objectives, solid and measurable objectives - in a qualitative and quantitative sense - in terms of increasing employment rates, as has also been proposed in the meantime, for example, by the Commission.

I do not believe there is any difference between us and the Ombudsman. There is the question of the legislative basis, on which we have been well advised, and I believe we are on solid ground in that regard. I would like to reiterate that Members who, like the Member who asked the question, have a particular interest in this issue will wish to engage in dialogue on it. It is extremely important, and I understand the Honourable Member's concern. I would like to thank the Commission for what I consider a very positive response. To be sure, I would like confirmation that there is indeed nothing in Jacob Söderman's proposal, regarding the Commission and good administration, that the Commission finds unacceptable. Is it correct that the content of the proposal will be approved in its entirety? Let me read what it says in my notes—and since it is in my notes, it must be true! "I would like to emphasize again that the Commission has accepted all of the Ombudsman's recommendations contained in his draft recommendations of July 1999." Both documents, that is, the Commission's document and the Ombudsman's draft, largely cover the same points. The only important issue that has arisen concerns the legislative basis. I can go into detail if the Honorable Member wishes, but there is no doubt that we are in complete agreement with the Ombudsman on this important issue. We are happy to add Mr. Patten's notes to the bibliography, as another reference book that we Members will take into account. Since its author is not present, Question 32 falls. I apologize to Mr. Vitorino for this parliamentary discourtesy, which I regret. He is exonerated, according to the Rules of Procedure, from answering. I wish him a very good afternoon. Part Two Questions addressed to Mr. Nielson, replaced by Mr. Patten. Questions 33 and 34 in Part Two of Question Time to the Commission were addressed to Mr. Nielson. Mr. Nielson cannot be present today because he is in South Africa. I must tell you that the Vice-President of the Commission, Mrs. Loyola de Palacio, has sent me a very kind letter providing all sorts of explanations and informing me that Mr. Patten will be the one to answer these questions. Question No. 33 by (H-0829/99): Subject: Mainstreaming the gender dimension in EU development aid policy. In 1995, the Council of Ministers drew up guidelines for mainstreaming the gender dimension throughout EU development aid policy. These guidelines require all staff working on development issues to receive ongoing training in equality. However, so far only about 50 people have received such training, and it is still not mandatory within the Directorate-General responsible for this aid. Mainstreaming the equality dimension implies taking equality between women and men into consideration as an integral part of any policy, strategy, or initiative in the field of development. To achieve this objective, the Council's guidelines must be fully implemented.

This is the key to ensuring efficiency and security. We will create a management and control system in each Directorate-General. Currently, the control system is centralized throughout; with the reform, we will move to a control system that combines the decentralization of administrative controls with an efficient central audit system. We will therefore have a central financial service that will establish the rules for financial management and provide advice. There will be a decentralization of the entire chain—namely, programs, commitments, contracts, expenditure, and the corresponding ex ante control systems—to the level of each Directorate-General, and there will be an external audit service that will monitor all these operations. This will mean a total overhaul of the Commission's working practices, a completely new organization that also requires a completely new culture. We are fully aware of the problems associated with this transitional period, and it is this transitional period that most worries our staff. We will therefore take the necessary security and protection measures. With this reform, the Commission aims to become an administration that serves as a model for Europe and the world as a whole. We also want to be a model for the advanced use of information technology. We want to set an example of a fully computerized administration. The Commission has been accused of being buried under mountains of paper; we will therefore be a paperless Commission, so that we become more efficient internally and contribute externally to the increased use of new technologies. This will involve not just a technical overhaul, but a complete organizational overhaul. I will now leave it to Neil Kinnock to explain this reform in detail, but not before thanking him for the wisdom, enthusiasm, and energy he has put into this work. I would also like to thank everyone who contributed to this project, as well as all the Commission staff who participated in this most comprehensive discussion process ever undertaken in the Commission. I would like to emphasize that this is an extraordinarily new method of discussion, which, in my opinion, has also forced us to undergo a radical change in our way of thinking. The White Paper before us is also the result of their contribution: they understood that only a profoundly reformed Commission can once again become the institution that was so highly esteemed around the world and which formed the starting point for Europe's history. With the adoption of the White Paper, a chapter of the past will – I hope and wish – be definitively closed. Now we look to the future, to the challenges facing the Union and to all the objectives of the 2000-2005 programme, which we have already explained to you here in recent weeks. These objectives of the five-year programme contain the deeper political reasons for the reform. We – the entire Union – need a strong Commission, a Commission that regains its capacity to act as a political actor, recognizable as such by its actions. That is why we are now redefining all the priorities on which we must focus our work. Therefore - and this is another important chapter - we are getting rid of those activities which, in accordance with the principles of decentralisation and subsidiarity, are no longer appropriate for us to carry out.

At the 55th session of the Commission on Human Rights last year, the United States, at an already advanced stage, decided to introduce a draft resolution on China. This draft resolution was defeated by a Chinese non-intervention motion. The European Union voted against this motion. The European Union's position on the stance the Commission on Human Rights should take toward China was reaffirmed by the General Affairs Council on March 21, 1999: no European Union initiative regarding China and no support for a Chinese resolution. The European Union rejected the non-intervention motion in the vote. It is uncertain whether the cohesion of the European Union could have been maintained had the resolution been put to a vote. The United States will introduce a draft resolution on China at the 56th session of the Commission on Human Rights, and is currently pressuring the European Union to approve the draft. This situation provoked strong reactions from China: The Chinese authorities are currently taking steps in the countries and institutions of the European Union to persuade them to withdraw their support for the US initiative. This initiative is being discussed within the Union, but a decision is not expected soon. It is in the interest of the European Union to keep all options open within the framework of the dialogue between the European Union and China on human rights for as long as possible, and in any case until after the meeting on February 25, 2000. In view of the changes that have taken place in the composition of the Human Rights Commission, it is to be expected that the vote on the non-intervention motion will be suspended. It is therefore important that the countries of the European Union agree again this year on the position they will take in a possible vote on the resolution. In this context, it should be noted that the European Union regularly opposes China's requests that the submission of a resolution to the Geneva Human Rights Commission automatically exclude it from the dialogue on human rights. The European Union firmly believes that dialogue, while a very valuable tool for exchanging views and understanding the reasons behind each other's positions, must also produce concrete results on the ground. Failure to do so may require a resolution from the Commission on Human Rights, perhaps later in the dialogue. Furthermore, the European Union has consistently emphasized to China that the Commission on Human Rights is the appropriate forum for raising human rights issues and that, from this perspective, the initiative—whether the European Union chooses to support it or not—is fully justified. The next dialogue on human rights will take place in Lisbon on 25 February and will include seminars on legal issues and women's rights, which are also expected to include representatives from academia and civil society. The next seminar on human rights will be organized by the Portuguese Presidency in May 2000. At the last round of dialogue in October 1999, the Chinese side accepted the technical assistance offered by the European Union to support the ratification process of the United Nations International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which the Chinese Government is a signatory.

There is nothing natural about these recurring disasters, nor is there any predestined fate. They are the result of human inconsistency. This is an ecological catastrophe. Only those far removed from the harsh realities on the ground can doubt this. It is also an economic catastrophe for all those who live from the sea and tourism, such as fishermen, oyster farmers, mussel farmers, saltworkers, traders, etc. The Erika disaster must be the last in a series. First, the circumstances of this disaster must be fully clarified. Why not set up a parliamentary committee of inquiry or involve Members of Parliament in the mission just announced by the Commission? Then, we must urgently adopt legislation to ensure, above all, the precise characteristics of the goods being transported are recorded. According to experts, the oil on the Erika should have sunk to the bottom and never reached the coast. The consequences are well known. Furthermore, reliable roadworthiness testing must be introduced, similar to the roadworthiness testing required in France for motor vehicles older than five years. Regulations for the use of flags of convenience, the requirement for double hulls on ships carrying polluting and dangerous goods, and technological innovations for the treatment and recovery of mineral oils at sea are also required. In my opinion, this would be a minimum at the beginning of the third millennium. Ships that do not meet compliance requirements must be prohibited from sailing in European waters. At the same time, the liability of those responsible for damage, shipowners, and charterers must be established according to the polluter pays principle. Maritime surveillance must be strengthened to prevent any degassing. Serious and reliable inspection of tankers must be implemented. A well-funded "natural disasters" budget line must be established for member states. Special Community aid must be introduced. Affected departments must be designated as eligible for Structural Funds. I have submitted a draft resolution on this subject on behalf of the EDD group. Mr. President, in recent years, there have been repeated serious tanker disasters around the world without any significant or effective countermeasures being taken. This time it is particularly bad, not least because it struck a major European country, an incident that could happen again at any time. We urgently need a directive to limit these risks. The 15 directives are clearly not enough. They guarantee – without claiming to be exhaustive – at least three points: No tanker or freighter that is ready for scrap may ever again call at a port in the European Union. All parties involved, including the client of the transport, are liable for consequential damages, and they must take out adequate insurance. Only in this way can the injured parties have a chance of claiming compensation. However, we must be clear that the long-term goal must be even more ambitious. This means we need true cost transparency for our entire energy supply system. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Palacio for her objective, appropriate, and binding response. Thank you very much for that. At the same time, her communication of January 10, as well as the action plan she announced today, commands enormous respect. The Erika disaster proves that when coherent traffic and transport regulations are lacking at the international and European levels, nature and the environment suffer.

These are areas that are mutually dependent on each other. Economic stability is a factor of growth and can lead to high employment. This also ensures the possibility of increasing prosperity. But the opposite is also true: a comprehensive social protection policy can contribute to high employment and an increase in the growth rate. In other words, social protection is a productive factor. There are differences in social protection systems within the Union. Many of these differences have historical explanations. But we now have a number of common challenges ahead of us. I am thinking, for example, of a demographic trend in which not only the number of older people is increasing, but also the number of births is falling. The labour market is also changing: women are increasingly venturing into the labour market. Technological developments are another challenge. These are all challenges that we must address together. The Commission communication calls for a more intensive exchange of experience, the creation of a high-level group and benchmarking. Furthermore, the report on social protection in Europe will be published annually and will be examined together with the employment report. This is good, but it is not enough. We propose a procedure similar to the Luxembourg process. Clear guidelines and indicators are needed, and Member States will have to define methodologies in national action plans. A common model is created, but subsidiarity is maintained. This form of social convergence is a process that will continue for a long time. That is why Parliament must be involved in the work, and not by being included in the high-level group, but by allowing representatives of Parliament to follow the work of this group and to make proposals on how to conduct this process. Like cooperation on employment, the Commission's proposal is based on four pillars: making social protection systems more employment-oriented, making pension systems sustainable in the long term, promoting social inclusion, ensuring high-quality healthcare. All this is important. In our report, we have particularly highlighted the importance of combating poverty within the Union and of identifying indicators as soon as possible that will allow progress in this area. There is no specific pillar for gender equality: this is where mainstreaming comes in. Equality aspects must therefore be present in each of the four pillars. This is a fixed point for us. We are presenting a whole series of proposals, for example the transition to personalised social security systems, recognition of the validity of parental leave for the purposes of social benefits, better conditions for reconciling family and professional life, minimum old-age pensions that still allow a decent standard of living. These are proposals that primarily benefit women. In parallel with this European strategy for social convergence, we need a concrete plan for legislative work in the social field and proposals for framework agreements in the context of social dialogue, with a clear timetable.

The air, rail, ferry and bus routes that provide external and internal connections in remote areas are put out to tender. The contract is awarded to those who undertake to provide a specific service at a specific quality level with the lowest subsidy. We can call this a negative tender offer. This ensures a competitive offer of service provision, based on a publicly supported but transparent award system. Why couldn't the mail collection and delivery service in a certain region be put out to tender according to these criteria? The tender with the lowest subsidy would be awarded the concession for a certain period of time. Why couldn't the small local office in a remote village be put out to tender according to these criteria? It would then be up to the democratically accountable local, regional or national administrative body - perhaps under the control of the European Union - to set the criteria and the financial resources to be allocated to this particular social purpose. Otherwise, postal services could be left to the mercy of all the demands and constraints of the market. Mr President, Commissioner, it is no coincidence that I am the fifth Scottish Member to speak in this debate. It shows how important the issue of postal services is to us. Scotland is larger than some Member States and has many communities living in remote areas, accessible only by road, sometimes poorly served by public transport and sometimes not served at all. These communities rely on local services such as the school, the post office and the one shop for their survival. Older people in particular rely solely on the last two. Often the post office and the shop are the same, and the provision of these two services depends on the existence of both. Scotland also has many island communities: some can be reached by plane, but most are dependent on the ferry connection. It is important to note that the current cost of delivering a letter from Edinburgh to the Central Highlands is about ten times higher than that of delivering the same letter from one end of London to the other, and four times higher than the postal charges currently charged. This difference increases with the distance of the remote area. That is the problem. To ask for liberalisation to take account of these factors, allowing for the maintenance of a universal and affordable postal service is not to oppose it. It is for our remote and island communities that we ask you to maintain the lifeline of postal services. Mr President, it is a privilege for me to deputise for Commissioner Bolkestein in this in-depth debate on postal services, and I will try to respond on the basis of the information he has given me. I would remind you that the Commissioner will be present at the meeting of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism on Monday. Some Members, such as Mr Stenmarck, are complaining about the delays in tabling the new proposal.

The time for resolutions is over. What is needed now is action. Regrettably, the Council will once again—I fear—fail to act, and in the future we will once again be debating another maritime and ecological disaster. Mr. President, whenever there is a disaster of this kind, it is said that it must not happen again. In reality, we can never put an end to accidents at sea, but it is incumbent upon us to learn the lessons that emerge whenever an accident of this kind occurs and apply them to reduce risks in the future. The Erika accident was serious, particularly for the people of Brittany most directly affected, but it was devastating for the fauna and flora of much of Europe. Some say it is the worst accident ever to befall birdlife in this part of Europe. The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds believes that as many as 400,000 birds, perhaps mainly guillemots, may have died. The photographs many of us have seen of oiled birds being euthanized by official veterinarians were both distressing and tragic. We all want the highest standards for ships, regardless of the flag they fly. We must enforce regulations and ensure that the "polluter pays" principle is applied so that penalties and also financial incentives are used to put pressure on shipowners and oil companies and ensure the best procedures are introduced. I agree with everything the Commissioner has said in her remarks, but the question is: how long will it take to get the measures to address this problem as she proposes put forward? As a politician, she must remind her officials how difficult it would be if she were to return to this Parliament a year from now, if a similar, equally devastating accident occurred, if some of the measures she has proposed today were still simply fine words and she had not had the opportunity to implement them. The idea that an accident of this kind could happen in the near future must make your mind and those of your officials concentrate intensely. Mr. President, Commissioner, I have brought you a small gift: a cake of heavy oil sent to me by a resident of the island of Noirmoutier, who writes the following: "With each tide, the beach is covered with heavy oil escaping from the Erika. With each tide, volunteers, soldiers, and firefighters remove immense cakes of this thick, viscous, black tar. When will it be clean again, and when will this devastating accident end?" Yes, this Erika accident, like that of the Russian ship in Turkey, is unacceptable and intolerable precisely when high technology is at its peak. It is all the more unacceptable that it is occurring twenty years after the Amoco Cadiz disaster, despite the fact that it had already been said and repeated on several occasions, "Never again something like this!"

We need firm, jointly agreed targets for reducing the unemployment rate to 4% in 2010, as the Commission has now proposed, for example. We need to put an end to the logic of ECOFIN ministers who at home reap the praise for their successes in consolidation, while the responsibility for the high unemployment in Europe remains shrouded in fog. I wish you a lot of energy, the support of Parliament and I hope that there will be a commitment to ensure that this Parliament, in future, will have a greater say in matters of economic policy and employment, as the citizens of Europe would like. You would then have found an additional ally for your policy. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, it is gratifying and promising to hear in this Chamber, as we have done today, this new strategic objective for the next decade, which consists in transforming the European Union into the most dynamic and competitive economic and social area in the world, based on new technologies, innovation and knowledge, in order to be able to increase levels of economic growth, achieving more and better jobs and greater social cohesion. It is clear that we must redefine Europe's role in the world economy, creating a competitive Europe, paving the way for the creation of more and better jobs, and organising this evolution with a clear strategy of social cohesion. The central role of employment and social policy, at the dawn of this new society, is based on two factors. On the one hand, economic efficiency, since in this new technological context the quality of human resources is crucial. On the other hand, social equality, because, despite the economic recovery we are experiencing, enormous social inequalities persist. Unemployment, social exclusion and the risks of a future imbalance in social security systems are problems that are becoming more acute due to the inevitable challenges arising from globalisation, the ageing of the population, technological progress, demographic decline and the increasing inclusion of women in the world of work. Europe needs to achieve full employment. Full employment suited to the emerging society, with greater opportunities for women and men. European citizens must be able to believe in this project and in this reality; they must not perceive it as something abstract, discussed in Brussels and Strasbourg. We are therefore calling at this time for the transition to a new society, to an economy based on innovation, on the information society and on knowledge. We must learn quickly, create new practices that are more suited to this new society, invest in technological changes but without ever forgetting people and institutions. The Lisbon Summit will be a step forward and we must succeed in renewing the European social model, because only in this way will we achieve increased employment and at the same time greater social cohesion. To this end, we must focus on a series of priority issues: we must improve the effectiveness of active employment policies, strengthen synergies between adaptability, education and lifelong learning, multiply employment in the service sector by facilitating entrepreneurial initiative and lightening the administrative burden on small and medium-sized enterprises by reducing non-wage costs - and finally we must develop the integration of equal opportunities into general policies, with particular attention to aspects that help to reconcile professional and family life.

In the last speech of Mr Solana to this House, I strongly criticised the fact that he barely mentioned the concept of conflict prevention; he spoke at length today on this subject, but did not put forward any proposals for seriously addressing it. The ability to prepare 60,000 men in 60 days for a year's deployment has been proudly trumpeted, but there are crises raging on our continent, on its borders and elsewhere, in which the Union has given a very poor account of itself. We actually need a civilian police force of 60,000 men and women to deal with these situations. Mr Solana has not yet told us what pressure will be used in relation to Russia and Chechnya. He has not even informed us what kind of diplomatic intervention he or the European Union is seriously going to try to stop the massacre in Chechnya. It is not even clear what our human rights objectives in principle are. We have somehow gathered the strength to intervene in Kosovo, but now we are ruining everything because we are not able to muster the necessary resources and personnel there, and we are demonstrating our inability to carry out adequate conflict prevention. I therefore ask Mr Solana to clarify to this Parliament the position of the European Union towards Chechnya. What are we going to do to put an end to this tragedy? We have tools that would be effective with Russia, if we chose to use them; but for now we have chosen not to use them. Mr President, Mr Solana, Commissioner, I have two questions for you, Mr Solana: how do you think we can further and credibly deepen military and defence cooperation if the Member States are not prepared to respect the common commitments? Conferences are welcome, but what counts are the results. I also wonder what you have in mind to convince the Member States to make this force of sixty thousand men a reality, and not just a figure on paper. If we look around, the reality we see is that of a CFSP that risks remaining just talk. Consider, for example, the defense cuts made in Germany, which are of concern not only to Defense Minister Scharping, but to the whole of Europe. In my country, Sweden, the objective to be achieved in compliance with solidarity commitments is 2,500 men to be allocated to Union interventions. But our defense is currently only able to make 1,500 men available, precisely because of budget cuts. Making a calculation for the entire Union, a true calculation if there are no changes, in 2003 we will not have 60,000 men, but 35-40,000 in the best of cases. My second question concerns the following. A few weeks ago, you were quoted in a clearly distorted way by a German-language media outlet. I would like to know the background to this, and in particular whether you, as High Representative, have really considered the possibility of treating Austria differently from other countries in your office; if so, I would also like to know who would have given you this mandate and what room for manoeuvre you would have.

As you know, these goals aim to halve poverty by 2015, either by raising the age of compulsory schooling, by significantly reducing infant mortality, or by a range of welfare interventions that effectively achieve this goal. This would mean reducing the extreme poverty in which a third of the world's population lives, reducing the extreme poverty in the living conditions of about a billion people, which is extraordinary but certainly requires strong participation and strong action from the entire international community. This is the fourth aspect of the new development paradigm that I would like to emphasize: development policies are seen today, particularly in recent years, as an increasingly global issue that suffers from a lack of strong international leadership. The concerted actions of the institutions of the United Nations system have contributed significantly to this, as has the Bretton Woods system. It is particularly worth noting the strong impetus given to this debate by the World Bank, notably through its Comprehensive Framework document, and by the International Monetary Fund. For the first time, an institution of this nature is placing the problem of poverty reduction at the heart of its policies and establishing a connection, hitherto unimaginable for such an institution, between debt relief and poverty. It is also in the light of this new role that international organizations are playing in relation to development problems that we must reflect on the role of the European Union in this context. The Portuguese Presidency insists on the need for the European Union to make its important role at the international level, as the main donor, more compatible with a leading and more active role in this movement to renew development policies, at the international level, by increasing its capacity for articulation and coordination, particularly with the United Nations system and the Bretton Woods system. In order to strengthen the role of the European Union in the context of international development policies, we believe that three fundamental types of action must be developed. First, to improve the effectiveness of development policy. As everyone knows, a comprehensive evaluation of development policies took place in 1995. It was possible to present the conclusions under the German Presidency. The main conclusions emphasize the need for a more coherent European Union policy and a general strategic vision of the European Union with regard to development problems. They emphasize the aspects relating to the need for greater coordination and complementarity between organizational harmonization and simplification policies, the framework within which the Union's cooperation policy is implemented, and the need to make aid management more effective, in particular by reviewing its intervention mechanisms, as well as the need to strengthen the evaluation system and ensure greater transparency in the way this aid is applied. The second aspect that needs to be highlighted concerns the need for greater complementarity between the Union and the policies of the Member States.
