The reason she cannot do so, as some Members have pointed out, is that she has been to Hungary and Romania to see for herself the scale of the disaster and to determine how best to help the Hungarian and Romanian authorities deal with this crisis. We are prepared to do so. Earlier this month, we contacted the Romanian Government and the International Commission for the Protection of the Danube River to urgently obtain more information about the accident. The Romanians have contacted the UNEF and OCHA in Geneva, requesting that an international team of independent experts assess the damage in the Danube basin. We are prepared to cooperate in this assessment if Hungary and Romania request it and if access to the sites for the nationals of both countries is guaranteed, which is obviously crucial. It is clearly essential to establish an accurate picture of the scale of the damage as quickly as possible so that we can decide exactly how best to respond. Our efforts today pursue this objective. It is also necessary to shed light on the legal responsibilities of the mining company and the Romanian authorities. This point is important, as some speakers have pointed out. The polluter pays principle is a cornerstone of the European Union's environmental policy. The International Convention for the Protection and Sustainable Use of the Danube River reflects this, and it should be applied in this specific case. The European Union should not bear the cost of compensation owed in place of the mining company. The Union has mobilized some €20 million over the past seven years to support the protection of the Danube basin. As part of pre-accession assistance for the region, it might be possible to redirect some of the aid we provide through ISPA and the PHARE programme to address the most harmful consequences of this accident, as long as the polluter pays principle is fully respected. In the longer term, we will have to see what lessons can be learned from this disaster and how to prevent such catastrophes in the first place. This incident strengthens the case for strengthening European civil protection, as President Prodi said recently in a speech and as one or two Members have made clear today. But for the time being, the priority is to tackle the crisis. As I said, my colleague, Mrs Wallström, is here today. She will have to keep Parliament fully informed of the actions she will propose following this visit. This is a real catastrophe for Europe, and Europe must respond to it and do everything in its power to prevent such appalling accidents as this one from continuing to blight its future. The debate is closed. We now move on to the vote. VOTES. The only reason we voted for the PSE-Greens/EFA-UEG/NGL compromise resolution is that only this resolution allowed us to "condemn the decision of the Goodyear-Dunlop management to close its Italian factory."

Over the past few years, the Community has spent around €200 million on mine clearance, victim assistance and related activities. Member States have spent similar amounts. However, there is still enormous inefficiency and a lack of will to implement a strategy agreed with other members of the international community to resolve the landmine problem within a limited timeframe. Commissioner Nielson has highlighted the problems of lack of concerted action and the need for better complementarity with Member States. These are problems that have been discussed for years. The Commission needs to change its internal organisation, strengthen the coherence and effectiveness of its interventions, if possible by establishing a central mine action policy cell with adequate resources. It would also need faster contracting and implementation procedures, a strengthened multiannual budget line and a marked improvement in programme management. There is a need for a thorough evaluation of the effectiveness of demining programmes in each of the countries seriously affected by the landmine problem. In my view, the issue of anti-personnel mines presents many of the same organisational, procedural, operational and financial management difficulties that have long plagued the Commission and the Union as a whole. Are these evils of the past or will we find that in this relatively compact and limited area the European Union is still incapable of realising its aspirations? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Nielson, the conclusion of the new agreement between the ACP countries and the European Union represents an important step towards greater coherence. And it is good that criteria such as human rights, democracy, the rule of law and good governance are reaffirmed in this agreement more forcefully than has been the case up to now and that most of our relations are no longer based on the old colonial model, but that these political criteria have taken on greater weight. This is in fact the condition for any development. Without compliance with these criteria, development has no chance of success. This, Mr Modrow, also applies to Cuba. I am pleased that Cuba is moving closer to this process. However, some changes are still needed in that country. We are all familiar with the Amnesty International reports. You may have a different opinion to that of the majority in Parliament on one of the last bastions of communism and may not agree with the principle of good governance, but it is an important criterion for the European Union. I would like to address a second issue. We are discussing coherence here. Many colleagues have given examples that show the lack of coherence in different policies. However, in my view, development policy as such also needs more coherence. It is not a sign of coherence that coordination between Member States continues to fail, that sometimes contradictory projects are implemented in developing countries by the European Union and the Member States. It is also not consistent with taxpayers to have a development policy included in the Union budget, while the European Development Fund remains outside it.

I will conclude, Mr President, by stating that progress is undoubtedly difficult, fragile, uncertain and requires us to closely monitor the various stages, punctuated by rigorous and meticulous monitoring operations. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I rise to express the enthusiasm and hope with which the Group of the European Liberal, Democrat and Reform Party welcomes the opening of negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I sincerely hope that this agreement, as the rapporteur, Mr Swoboda, envisages, will serve as an example to be extended as quickly as possible to other countries in the region, especially Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Montenegro, Kosovo and, perhaps one day, Serbia. We are convinced that the rapid opening of these negotiations and their speedy conclusion offer the only possibility of restoring peace to the region, a peace that did not automatically follow the end of the war in Kosovo. We will thus avoid the recurrence of conditions conducive to further disintegration and a return to chaos and violence, with all the risks that this entails for the stability of the continent, and indeed of the planet. While it is true that the current courageous process of enlargement of the Union to include the countries of Eastern Europe is fundamentally motivated by the maintenance of peace and security, such a motivation must be even more present in our relations with Albania and the countries of the former Yugoslav republic and, logically, it requires us to commit ourselves resolutely to the path of this parallel enlargement to the countries of South-Eastern Europe, represented by the agreements under consideration. It is in this spirit, bordering on provocation, that we have tabled an amendment aimed at transferring competences concerning South-Eastern Europe from Foreign Affairs to Enlargement. The idea of a more rapid and direct participation of South-Eastern Europe in the life of the European institutions has also led us to propose welcoming to the European Parliament a limited number of observers sent by the national parliaments, who would also second members of their staff to work for the Court of Justice and the Commission. In any case, we are convinced that, in order to promote the evolution of the region towards a more democratic society, essentially based on the market economy, we must immediately take concrete initiatives to intensify the fight against corruption and improve the effectiveness of international aid for reconstruction and development. It is with this aim in mind that we have tabled several amendments in the hope that Parliament will accept them. The aim is, first, to eliminate customs duties on exports from the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to the European Union and to compensate for the gradual reduction of customs duties levied by Macedonia on European products, provided that the principle of common customs control at Macedonia's borders is accepted. Second, to induce the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, through adequate financial support, to gradually peg its currency to the euro, as a first step towards the Europeanization of the Macedonian economy as a whole and with the subsequent objective of eliminating any perversion of the banking system. Third, to give global aid and assistance to the region a certain multilateral character, without imposing on the recipient country direct obligations towards the donor country.

The aforementioned positions reinforce the question I address to Mr. Solana. Poland only needs five words to be fulfilled: nothing without us, above us! What do the current EU Member States do in response to this reasonable request from a state aspiring to membership? Mr. President, I would also like to welcome the presence of the High Representative and his willingness to answer the Members' questions at this second appearance. This was not possible during his appearance in November—certainly not through any fault of Mr. Solana's—although it is only fair to acknowledge that he took note and undertook to respond to the questions posed by Members as soon as possible. I believe it is also fair to recognize the efforts Mr. Solana is making to achieve a more effective, more visible, and more coherent common foreign and security policy for the European Union. And in this regard, I agree with the interventions made by some colleagues who spoke before me on the need to have a comprehensive policy that combines not only military elements, but also civilian, diplomatic, humanitarian, and police elements, to which Mr. Solana referred. The Portuguese Presidency has indeed made great progress, establishing a series of provisional or interim bodies. In record time, it organized this informal Council of Defense Ministers and outlined a series of milestones in the long march toward this common foreign and security policy. One of them was this Sintra Council, about which I would like to ask Mr. Solana a few questions. This Council was based on two documents: a British document on the headline goals, on priority objectives, and another document on the permanent military bodies of the European Union. Mr. Solana, I would like to ask you if, at your next appearance before the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defense Policy, you would be willing to explain at length to the members of this committee—together with Mr. Patten, to whom I am putting the same question, and with the President-in-Office of the Council, to whom I would also ask, Mr. Solana, to forward this request—the content of these documents discussed at the summit. A second question, Mr. High Representative, would be to know to what extent you support the observations and statements made by the French Minister of Defense, to the effect that Member States should allocate 0.7% of gross domestic product to defense spending. I would like to know your opinion, whether you share that point of view, whether you truly consider a more decisive contribution from Member States in this area necessary. Thirdly, what is your assessment of the recently concluded "Crisex 2000" exercises, in which the European Union, for the first time, shared a series of initiatives with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization? And fourthly, Mr. Solana, I would like to know whether, should the Member States request it, you would be willing to chair the Political and Defense Committee, and thus add to the entire experience you currently have as Secretary-General of the Council of Ministers, as High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy, as Secretary-General of the Western European Union, and as former Secretary-General of NATO. Mr. High Representative, as rapporteur for the Committee on Foreign Affairs on security and defense issues, I will limit my remarks to these matters.

This means that the proposal before us is not primarily concerned with solving the problem of the movement of these workers, but is only aimed at creating better conditions for service providers. Furthermore, in the name of simplifying procedures, the Berger report introduces highly questionable changes, such as the establishment of a common information system allowing access to documents issued by the authorities of any Member State. Berger reports (A5-0007/2000) and Berger (A5-0012/2000) It is with great satisfaction that I welcome the two proposals for directives which aim to facilitate the free movement of workers who are nationals of third countries and, at the same time, the free movement of services. Essentially, these proposals introduce the EC service provision card which, in future, will enable approximately five million nationals of third countries, legally resident in a Member State of the European Union, to provide services in other Member States. This possibility is currently hampered by problems such as obtaining visas and work permits. The first proposal for a directive authorises companies established in a Member State which employ third-country nationals to temporarily post them to another Member State to provide services. Under the terms of the provisions envisaged, the employer would only be required to apply for a service provision card for each worker concerned. Of course, in order to obtain such a card, the worker would have to reside legally in a Member State and be insured by a social security system. The second proposal grants the same rights to self-employed third-country nationals. While I agree in essence with the European Commission's proposals, it is also true that some of the provisions could appear ambiguous. This is why I am voting in favour of the amendments tabled by the rapporteur. This will make the provisions clearer and prevent any possible abuse. Other amendments aim to simplify administrative procedures, for example by authorising Member States to designate a single authority responsible for issuing the cards. Such an amendment seemed to me to be essential in order to avoid the administrative delays which all too often hinder the correct application of the new provisions. I can only welcome the adoption of these directives in their amended version. In fact, it would no longer be possible to tolerate people legally resident in the European Union encountering so many difficulties. This conflicts with the fundamental principle of non-discrimination enshrined in the Treaties establishing our Union. Marinho report (A5-0003/2000). We have serious reservations about the Council's proposed amendments. How can we explain that, just when it is asking for an increase in the number of judges of the Court of First Instance (which, as we know, is overworked), it is at the same time proposing to extend its powers? The effects of the first measure would, in fact, be cancelled out by the second. Some argue that perfection is not of this world, but a brief historical excursus should enable them to better understand our reservations.

Social security and social protection represent one of the greatest achievements of workers in Europe, achieved through years of struggle against the aspirations of big business and thanks to the constant solidarity that is characteristic of workers. In today's Europe of unemployment and underemployment, there is an urgent need to ensure more extensive social protection and the expansion of workers' rights. This, however, requires a different system of economic and social development than the one the EU, by its very nature and essence, is capable of producing. In summary, we strongly oppose the "modernization" of the social protection system sought by the Commission in its communication and point out that we will not support the report under discussion by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. This concludes the explanations of vote. (The sitting adjourned at 1:55 p.m. and resumed at 3:00 p.m.) Next meeting of the UN Commission on Human Rights (continuation) The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council statement on the Union's priorities for the next meeting of the UN Commission on Human Rights (20 March 2000), including the situation in China. Mr President, I regret the absence of the President-in-Office of the Council; this is a statement by the Council, and I think that his participation in the continuation of the debate might have been useful. It does not seem superfluous to me to recall that the inclusion of this item on the agenda is clearly due to the need, expressed by all the political groups, for Parliament to hold a debate before the next meeting of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva, in order to make its voice heard on an issue so sensitive and popular with this Parliament. I believe that, following the statement by the Presidency-in-Office of the Council and the Commission, we can all agree that the current situation in the field of human rights is far from what would be desirable. At Union level, we cannot fail to note that the situation is not entirely satisfactory. For example, although the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms is an element common to all Member States, not all its subsequent protocols have been ratified or signed by all States. A clear disadvantage in this area is also the fact that the European Union as such is not a signatory to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, with all the additional difficulties that this situation entails. I hope that all these problems can be raised and dealt with in the context of the current debate on the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. In terms of foreign policy, I believe that most of the points included in our resolution present a fairly realistic view and do not exactly give cause for optimism, since issues such as the abolition of the death penalty, the torture still practiced in many supposedly democratic countries, and the situation of minorities in many parts of the world require a clear, visible, and effective response from the European Union. I believe the resolution contains a number of essential points, but I would like to focus on one in particular: the need for greater coordination between the European Union and the United Nations.

When we hold intergovernmental conferences and reconsider amending the Treaty, we must bear in mind that the EU is expanding every day, even contrary to the Treaty, as we have just seen. I welcome Commissioner Barnier and the Portuguese Presidency here this afternoon. The Intergovernmental Conference will open on 14 February, and it must be completed before the end of 2000. It is a huge undertaking, but it can be done. I believe there is general agreement here this afternoon among all groups that the Helsinki agenda will not be sufficient to undertake the necessary reform to prepare Europe for enlargement. In other words, we must go beyond what have been called the important "Amsterdam loose ends." These loose ends include the extension of qualified majority voting—in my country we approved of it, but not in the area of taxation—a new weighting of votes in the Council to favor the largest states, and the number of Commissioners in an enlarged Europe. Regarding the last point, Ireland wants to retain its right to appoint a full and equal member of the Commission regardless of the number of Member States that join. We are willing to consider the new weighting of votes in the Council of Ministers, provided that the larger Member States agree to each Member State having a full and equal member of the Commission. I think I speak for many smaller countries in making this particular point. The IGC should also discuss the possible division of the Treaties in two—into a political area and an area relating to the Constitution. We would accept the division of the Treaties provided that it does not limit the control that smaller Member States have in the rededication of the entire political area of the Treaty. In other words, if we are not fully represented in the Commission, we will have no influence on the political debates. We are therefore closely monitoring the development of this whole point. We look forward to the presentation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and to learning about its content. The Treaty of Amsterdam, Mr. President, set the number of Members of the European Parliament at 700, and it will be necessary to debate in this Parliament how that number will be distributed throughout an enlarged Europe. Mr. President, the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference must be expanded. The most important issue that must be included on the agenda is the internal differentiation of the Union. It is regrettable that here in Parliament, almost no attention has yet been paid to the internal disintegration of the Union, which, however, is essential for the enlargement of the Union to be carried out as agreed. The former President of the Commission, Mr. Jacques Delors, has once again raised the idea of a European Confederation in the media. He also said that the countries at the forefront of integration, the avant-garde countries, should be able to advance at a faster pace than the others and, for the sake of clarity, should have their own institutions. The current President of the Commission, Mr. Prodi, and the High Representative, Mr. Solana, have put forward ideas that point in the same direction.

The Commission, for its part, is prepared to avoid any unjustified bureaucratic overload, but we cannot renounce - indeed, you would perhaps be among the first to criticize us for doing so - checking the relevance and quality of the programs proposed to us. Second observation, the deadlines for submitting programs and the possibility of presenting a programming supplement together with the programs. I have no objections to this idea of submitting a programming supplement together with the main program. However, this cannot mean an extension of the main deadline. I would point out that it is six months for this program. This deadline, which is also identical to the one we granted for Interreg and for the Objective 2 SPDs, should generally be sufficient, it seems to me, to establish a program, which does not prevent the projects from being defined later. Regarding URBAN, I would like to conclude with a final thought. One of you expressed the hope that this urban dimension would not be limited to URBAN. I fully agree. I myself said at the meeting of the Ministers for Planning, Territorial Development and Urban Affairs that I was concerned - and I am working on this - that in the SPDs, in the CCAs, in the programmes for which we are beginning negotiations, that the urban dimension is found outside of URBAN, in all the Objective 1 and Objective 2 programmes, and I believe I can say both our vigilance but also the translation of this urban dimension outside of URBAN into all the Structural Fund programmes. But for the future, since we must look ahead, I am extremely concerned to see how URBAN will be implemented in practice, and also to see the experiences or lessons that we can learn, because clearly this urban dimension will be at the heart of what could be, for the next financial perspectives, a new European territorial planning policy. I have not forgotten, we cannot forget, that 80% of European citizens now live in cities and that is why this URBAN instrument is extremely important. I say it again and again, we will be attentive to the presence of the urban dimension in all structural fund programming. I would now like, Mr President, to mention Interreg and thank, as I did for Mrs Arlene McCarthy, your rapporteur, Mr Francis Decourrière, for the quality and relevance of his work. He insisted on several points, on which we agree and many of you do too: the importance of this trans-European cooperation, with its three strands: cross-border, transnational, interregional; the Community added value of Interreg, its readability in relation to the general framework of the structural funds, and the truly cross-border, transnational strengthening of eligible programmes and operations; the importance of common structures - what I called, in connection with another debate that begins today, the Intergovernmental Conference, the common spirit of Europeans that we must strengthen, this is, with Interreg and thanks to Interreg, how to strengthen the common spirit through common structures for the implementation of programs with real financial solidarity; the importance of partnership to guarantee the active participation of all the local and regional authorities concerned as well as private sector associations and socio-economic partners.

Finally, with regard to major energy networks, the guidelines also provide for financial participation from the Funds in the development of energy transmission networks when this helps to reduce dependence on an external supplier or combat the effects of isolation. This applies, in particular, to the region I mentioned in the Azores, but also to all the outermost regions and, I would add, to certain regions handicapped by isolation due to mountainous conditions, for example. Commissioner, I understand your answer, but on the other hand, the reason I asked this question is precisely because we are concerned, given that the report on the third framework programme for research includes a project called the "International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor". It is worth several billion ECU, obviously, and areas eligible for structural funds, such as those classified under Objective 1, would be suitable for this type of installation. What we would like to know is whether, in fact, within the framework of the installation of this research site, and not perhaps directly within the specific framework of "nuclear research," the Commission would be able to finance this type of project. Mr. Barnier, excuse me, but you haven't quite answered the last part of my question about major energy transmission networks. Could you provide an answer on this subject? Are you worried about whether, with the structural funds, we will finance the installation of nuclear power plants somewhere? I am simplifying. We could say that this is not the case. I told you, Madam Deputy, that the selection of projects remains the responsibility of the Member States, in accordance with the Structural Funds regulations. Consequently, the Commission services are not systematically informed of all the projects selected. However, you are right to ask me; it is your job, and mine to answer you. As has already happened in the past, Member States are required to respond, to the extent that the Commission questions them or requests clarification. So, I will go a little further than the trust usually shared between Member States and the Commission, and on the specific point you raise, I will see exactly what it is. The Member State, or Member States concerned, will then be required to respond to me, and I will forward this response to you immediately. I thought I had responded to the issue of large networks. The energy situation varies enormously across the regions of the European Union, and assistance from the Funds, in certain cases and for certain regions, could be justified, particularly in cases where the connection to basic energy networks is still underdeveloped. That is the response I can give on this link between large energy transmission networks and the structural funds. I call Question No 46 of (H-0052/00): Subject: Structural Funds and additionality In the light of the Commission's recent helpful reply to my priority written question on the Structural Funds and additionality, I would like to know whether the Commission is considering amending the rules on additionality. In particular, would the Commission be in favour of amending those rules to apply additionality not only at Member State level but also within Member States, in relation to budgetary provisions applicable between national authorities and regions or countries with internal autonomy?

The identification of genetically modified additives plays a particularly important role here. On the one hand, it allows farmers to make a conscious decision about whether or not they want to use such animal feed, and on the other, it allows consumers to refuse feed that has been produced from GMOs. Finally, our group would like to extend its sincere thanks to the rapporteur, who has gone to great lengths. I think we can look forward to Mr Byrne's response. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is more concerned with formal issues, namely how additives should be approved, and to a lesser extent, which additives they are and how they work. I must take this opportunity to stress how important it is that all directives of this kind are dealt with in future using the Article 152 procedure, since both food safety and environmental issues require a coherent policy and a comprehensive perspective. We cannot continue, as we have done so far, to deal with every detail piecemeal, often when harmful consequences have already occurred. The rapporteur has focused on the testing and labelling that must be carried out on GMOs contained in additives used in animal feed. I would like to raise the issue of antibiotics once again. Although five of the nine types of antibiotics that were originally permitted for addition to animal feed are now banned, it is extremely important that the remaining four types be banned. Not only for the sake of public health, but also for the sake of the animals concerned. We are now at the stage where we know the formidable threat that antibiotic resistance poses to human health, particularly for young children. Many Member States are already able to demonstrate the extent to which the excessive use of antibiotics in animal farming is unnecessary. Several countries have long since abolished this practice, and a number of other countries are in the process of doing so, with positive results. When it comes to antibiotics, the famous precautionary principle was long ago ignored. However, when it comes to the environment, there is another important principle, namely the principle of exchange. I would like to briefly mention the issue of coccidiostats. This is a technical antibiotic, which is not absolutely necessary. There are alternative methods. It is possible to vaccinate chickens. This is admittedly a little more expensive, but has no environmental consequences. Today, slurry containing coccidiostats is spread on fields, which then passes into the water, i.e., into the most important component of our food. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the report on additives in animal feed addresses a technical and economic problem of restoring the competitive balance between different additives in animal feed and between the producers of these additives. But today, after the serious dioxin crisis that hit Belgium and other European countries last summer, we cannot simply reflect on a simple question of competition. Indeed, at the time, even if it went less well known to the general public, the Commission's scientific experts discovered industrial lime residues laden with dioxin in citrus pulp imported from Brazil.

Inaugurating an unfinished building in the middle of an election campaign, which could not be occupied eight months after its inauguration, has made the Spanish government look very ridiculous. The fact that the Spanish government has made a fool of itself does not worry me because, ultimately, it is responsible for it, but the fact that the Commission has made a fool of itself by endorsing, through its presence, this inappropriate conduct does worry me. That is why I ask you, Commissioner: does it seem normal to you that an unfinished building should have been inaugurated in the middle of an election campaign? Does it seem normal to you that the Commission should have endorsed, through its presence, this inappropriate conduct by the Spanish government? It is not for me to comment on the internal political situation of any Member State. I would therefore like to refrain from any comment on the situation just mentioned by Mr Berenguer. I must admit that the reason why an inauguration ceremony is being organized in Spain escapes me. I can tell you that I hope that this building will now be operational as quickly as possible. Let me add that I myself hope to be in Alicante at the end of May to speak at a conference. I hope that this building will have been operational by then. I would like to say to the Commissioner that this is not an electoral issue. As members of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, we have been following the creation of this institution and, of course, it is clear that this building was inaugurated for electoral reasons. Today – a year later – it is still unoccupied, which means that the Commission is spending money on a fake inauguration. One should ask to what extent this expenditure of funds on a fake inauguration was justified. Once again, the Commission does not deal with the considerations underlying the actions of the Member States. The Commission deals with what is officially declared and what is done. We do not intend to engage in what is called a trial by intention. We are therefore concerned with public and official acts and affairs and not with any underlying motives. That is why it seems difficult to satisfy Mr. Medina on this point and to answer his question. Once again, the Commission does not ask itself why something takes place more or less late, apart from the fact that the Commission attaches importance to the fact that a building such as the one planned for this Office is inaugurated and used as quickly as possible. Furthermore, the Commission is also not concerned with whether specific expenditures are real or virtual. As far as they are concerned, all expenditures are real. As for the rest, the future will tell. Question No 54 of (H-0117/00): Subject: Alcohol monopoly and the internal market What measures does the Commission intend to take to prevent Sweden from maintaining, as it clearly intends to do, its state monopoly on alcohol and therefore the corresponding import restrictions, thereby giving precedence to the rules of the internal market?

Europe's fishing sectors are facing serious problems, and I have a genuine concern for the industry's well-being. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to gather the necessary information and muster the political will to pursue truly long-term solutions for communities dependent on fishing, rather than myopically pursuing short-term fixes. I commend the report to the House. The Committee on the Environment is generally satisfied with the Commission's communication, and we are pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has adopted our amendments. It is now widely recognized that fishing has an impact on the marine environment that goes far beyond simply catching the target species plus a small amount of bycatch and is felt everywhere. We welcome the Commission's intention to integrate environmental protection into other EU policies—including the Common Fisheries Policy. After all, the Treaties have stated since 1992 that the precautionary principle and environmental protection should be integrated into Community policies. However, as has already been stated, the adoption of a strict definition of the precautionary principle is crucial, because it is all too easy to pay mere lip service and then continue with "business as usual." A good example in this context would be the 1995 UN Fish Stocks Agreement. However, one aspect is missing from the communication: monitoring and control. All sensible measures and regulations will not lead to stock conservation without an effective system to ensure compliance with the rules. Control is the responsibility of the Member States. The Council recently adopted a list of serious infringements, which attempts to coordinate, to a certain extent, the punishment of similar offenses in different countries. This is an important step forward, but the Commission and the Committee on Fisheries continually point out that much still needs to be improved in the control programs of all Member States. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent report. Mr. President, Fishing is a major economic activity, behind which very large investments are made and which provides basic employment for entire regions of the Community under truly harsh conditions. However, the idea that some people have of fishing is usually extremely simplistic and can range from pure folklore to the insult of viewing fishermen as callous pirates and plunderers. I regret to say that, because of its connection with the environment, this report seems to have provided an opportunity for people with such ideas to spout their own particular nonsense. If Mr. Katiforis's report had been adopted in its original form, no member of the Committee on Fisheries would ever again have been able to set foot in a fishing region without exposing themselves to some risk of being lynched. The relationship between fishing and marine ecosystems is obvious. But this relationship is much broader and involves many factors, such as pollution and maritime traffic. To blame fishermen alone for environmental destruction is as unfair as it is wrong. Our committee avoided its own humiliation by a series of amendments, 14 of which I myself tabled, most of which were accepted by the rapporteur, for which I sincerely thank him.

However, if some of the amendments were to be approved, particularly those tabled by the PPE Group, we believe that the report would be distorted and transformed into a contradictory document lacking in rigour; in that case, therefore, we will have to reconsider our support. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, among the various issues on the agenda of this joint debate, I would like to include a reflection on the issue raised by our colleague Berenguer, namely the modernisation of competition policy to which the Commission's White Paper refers. I frankly believe that this modernisation process has been satisfactory. Commissioner Monti is achieving good results in his policy, like his predecessor, with the clear merit of having been able to guarantee, in parallel with the creation and development of the European internal market, the necessary corrections for the regular functioning of the market economy in the Union without those side effects which, as we economists know well, risk being produced when a market expands, as has happened in the European Union since 1993. But if everything works, if we are satisfied, if the Commission's line has been substantially correct, then why a change? Various reasons have been put forward in support of this. Mr Berenguer has drawn up a very careful analysis, justifying the need for the change and the related reforms with the need to improve the functioning of competition; however, what is closest to my heart is ensuring that the standards and criteria applicable by the various competent authorities in the Member States are effectively identical everywhere. Otherwise, we would find ourselves in a paradoxical situation: it would in fact be the Commission that introduces elements of unfair competition into the functioning of the European internal market. In that case, instead of progress, we would have seen a regression in the application of competition policy within the Union. Mr President, I would first like to express my gratitude to the Commission for the improvement that the 28th Commission report on competition policy in the Union has made compared with previous editions. I would also like to highlight the work done by the rapporteur, Mr Rapkay, who has been able to analyse in concise terms a text as vast and dense as this one. And I fully support him when he says that regions - such as the Basque Country, which I represent here - need to be given room for action by virtue of the principle of subsidiarity. However, I cannot forget the criticisms formulated on several occasions by both Member States and market operators who, faced with the broad margin of manoeuvre and discretion recognised to the Commission in relation to the assessment of each individual case, complain about the existence of legal uncertainty, in the absence of clear rules of the game that allow interested parties to foresee the position of the authorities and, therefore, to act accordingly when submitting their respective applications for obtaining subsidies to support economic activities and employment, in mergers between companies, etc. The only guarantee has so far been represented by the attempt to seek a position favourable to authorisation already in advance, by submitting individual applications which in any case are not processed in less than six to eight months, an excessively long period which is added to the obstacles that already weigh on activities generating wealth and employment.

We tend to believe that this economic growth in the Union has a solid foundation, now and for the coming years, and that we must not lose sight of the fact that we are in an open, global and highly competitive economy. If we want to match the leadership of the United States, or even take over, we must avoid the interventionism initially proposed by Mr. Katiforis, and avoid any excessive intervention by public authorities in the construction of certain infrastructures. Furthermore, the Member States refused to allocate more resources during the discussions on Agenda 2000, so that at the level of the European Union, we will have few means at our disposal in the coming years. On the other hand, we insist on the need to continue to deepen the construction of the European internal market, which still has serious shortcomings. In certain sectors, such as air transport, energy or telecommunications, the costs borne by our companies are still very high if we compare unit costs with those of the United States or other countries that are equally competitive at international level. The report contains information stating that the bureaucratic cost of setting up a new business is 500 euros in the United States, while it is on average 1,600 euros in the European Union. There is therefore still excessive bureaucracy and disproportionate intervention. We believe that it is by respecting the austerity agreements established with the programs that follow the Stability Pact and by deepening the creation of a market with fewer obstacles at all levels that we will achieve the levels of competitiveness necessary for the European Union. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the passion that my predecessors recognized in Mr Katiforis had, to my ears, had no other objective than to call on the European Parliament to respond to the hope of tens of millions of unemployed, excluded and precarious people in our European Union. This is the objective to which he called on the European Parliament: to give hope to the people of Europe. There is economic recovery, certainly, but it is only marginally reducing unemployment in Europe. The votes of the EPP-ED and the Liberals have very significantly diminished, even reversed, the meaning of its message. This is why we did not vote for the report as amended by them, despite our efforts, and we will not vote for it in its current form. What are the minimum conditions under which we would vote for this report? Firstly, the affirmation that there is room for a Europe of growth, but a Europe of sustainable growth, respectful in particular of the European Union's commitments at the Kyoto and Buenos Aires conferences. There are enormous tasks to be accomplished to meet our commitments by the fateful year of 2008 when we will have to return to greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels. Enormous work needs to be done in the areas of transport, energy saving, and even replacing travel with Internet communications.
